column2: A diamond thief made a successful haul in Brooklyn Wednesday evening. The police of that city are doing all in their power to locate the gems, and the owner has offered a reward for their return, and no questions asked.

$10,000 REWARD FOR RETURN OF PROPERty taken from 5 East 26th St., New-York, Dec. 27; communications strictly confidential. Address HOWARD H. FALLOWS, care Carter Fallows, attorneys, 18 Wall St., New-York.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Mr. Carlisle, in the House, to-day. Introduced a bill requiring that in cities of the first and second classes each opening to an airshaft or hoistway in apartment houses, flats, hotels, office buildings, stores, and warehouses shall be protected by a guard rail four feet high. These guard rails shall be erected before July 1 next, under penalty of $50 fine.

James S. Clarkson, the Republican National Committeeman from Iowa, declared last night at the Fifth Avenue Hotel that Senator Carter would not be ousted from the Chairmanship of the Republican National Committee until a new committee is elected in St. Louis.

There is a very interesting and important contest going on in the Democratic Party in the State of Alabama over the control of the State Convention, which is to nominate a Governor. The candidates for the Gubernatorial nomination are Capt. JOHNSTON and RICHARD H. CLARKE. JOHNSTON has for several years been a very energetic and earnest advocate of extreme free-silver views.
Lord Dunraven's name was removed from the list of honorary members of the New-York Yacht Club last night by a vote of 39 to 1.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The Raines Excise bill has been traveling a rocky road to-day. Its friends and enemies have been doing hard fighting, and the "kick" was so vigorous against it that after four hours of caucusing to-night the Republican Senators were still at it, unable to agree.

Jared Flags, Jr., the real estate agent, who was indicted for renting flats, in West Eighteenth Street for immoral purposes, was found guilty by a jury yesterday in Part III. of the General Sessions Court on the second count, which charged him with "maintaining a public nuisance."

If Mr. Emil Paur, formerly of Leipslc and now of Boston, will continue to give NewYork audiences such programmes as that of the Boston Symphony Orchestra's fourth concert at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, he will not again be accused of being an antidote for insomnia. On the contrary, he will keep his public wide awake and sitting up to wonder what is going to happen next.

The most important measures affecting the interests of this city now before the Legislature, or likely to be before it at this session, are the bills introduced on Wednesday authorizing an issue of bonds to the extent of $6,000,000 in the course of three years, in addition to the regular issue of $3,000,000 annually for the Dock Department, to provide for carrying out the plan of improvement already approved by the Sinking Fund Commission.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The case of Dr. Montague R. Leverson of Port Richmond, S. I., who was arrested in the Albany Union Railway Station a week ago last night for a breach of the peace after an angry dispute with Anthony Comstock, came up in the police court to-day. Dr. Leverson ad Mr. Comstock were in court at the appointed hour, and neither showed a disposition to let the affair drop.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The Standard will tomorrow say: "It cannot be said that Lord Dunraven's letters mark a satisfactory termination of a painful misunderstanding. His position is morally and logically strong, nor could he be blamed if he positively refused to adopt the report of the committee. Unfortunately, he has expressed himself in a manner that leaves his attitude open to misconstruction.

-- The Queen of the Muna Islands, in the South Pacific, is dead. The Courts of Europe will not go into mourning for her, but the event has an interest of its own. Queen Margaret was the granddaughter of Francis Young, an English sailor who landed at the Island of Tau half a century ago and married the native Queen.
Geib-Windolph. Miss Louise Julia Windolph, daughter of John P. Windolph, Vice President of the Board of Aldermen, was married to Louis Geib in the Marble Collegiate Church last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Minister Andrade of Venezuela has received a cable dispatch from his Government announcing that the original documents, maps, and records collected by the historical commission appointed by President Crespo will be sent forward at once for delivery to the High Boundary Commission.

Lord Dunraven, on Feb. 19, sent his resignation to Secretary Oddie. This letter is on the White Star Line steamer Britannic, which will probably reach here to-day. The contents of this letter were cabled over by The United Press yesterday, and were as follows:

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I, Feb. 27 -- An end to the police court proceedings in the Lalor murder case was reached to-day, when Justice Ingram held Mrs. Minnie Lalor and John Fleischauer to await the action of the Queens County Grand Jury, the former as principal and the latter as accessory in the murder of William E. Lalor on Jan. 2.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 27 -- Two persons were murdered at 110 Phillips Street to-night, and another is dying. The murderer, John Mackin, is locked up in the Communipaw Avenue Police Station. Lizzie Mackin, twenty-two years old, and Bridget Connors, her mother, fifty-four years old, were killed outright.

Jesse M. Gregory's trial for the murder of his wife, Clara, on April 6, 1895, was concluded yesterday in Part IV. of the General Sessions Court, and the jury found him guilty of manslaughter in the first degree. The Jury recommended him to the mercy of the Court.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- The earnings of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad continue, to increase at a highly satisfactory rate, the last statement issued today being as follows: Gross earnings for January, $2,320,622; increase over 1895, $435,244; net earnings for January, $787,713; increase over January, 1895, $148,258; gross earnings for seven months ending Jan. 81, $20,397,344; increase over same period of preceding year, $3,707,876; net earnings, $8,690,308; increase, $2,716,786.

The Rev. Patrick Hennessy, rector of St. Patrick's Catholic Church, Jersey City, died yesterday at the rectory on Bramhall Avenue, after a long illness. He was prostrated by paralysis in November, 1894. He recovered sufficiently to resume his duties, but in August, 1895, he was again prostrated.

Rumors concerning the condition and prospects of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad were numerous and exciting yesterday. The Imaginative mind of the Wall Street operator was led to believe that disclosures of the most deplorable character regarding the company's finances were impending, and the scope of the rumors embraced almost every evil thing, from the alleged failure of the plans of the New-York syndicate to the prospect of a receivership.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- There is a proposition in the Senate to substitute for the several Cuban resolutions now before that body the series bearing on Cuba's wrongs reported to-day to the House. It is the opinion of many Senators that the House resolutions are much preferable to those which have formed the basis of so many speeches in the Senate in the last week.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Spanish Minister makes public the following dispatches which he received to-day from headquarters at Havana:
ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- More delay for the Greater New-York bill was arranged in the Senate this morning. The measure was the subject of a short debate, and was then recommitted.

The topic " Correspondents," was " \Vhat is a reason able and fair 'rate of compensation to pay correspondents who send telegraphic news? Should they be paid by the item, or by the column, or on a basis covering both?" \Vhen coffee and cigars had been served, President IinapP introduced the speakers. \\' C. Co vert spoke on " The Relation of the Press to the Public Service," Phil T. Dodge on " The Iv; of the Future," Stephen O'~Ieara of The Boston Journal on " The Patriotism of the American Press," and D. Peirce on " The National Advertiser." John E Barren, in speaking to "The Editorial End," said: "Some one has ad vanced the thought that the ideal news paper will be run without an editor. \\'hett that times comes we may expect to see the ideal engine run without an engineer, the ideal ship without a Captain, the ideal without a Colon;:l, the ideal State without a Governor, the ideal man without brains, and tae ideal local room without a reporter."

Booth is said, on good authority, to lie wholly it the fact that he has succeeded in almost completely Americanizing the Sal vation Army in this country. His methods aroused the antagonism of a little English coterie. headed b3' t:ol. Eadie, the Chief Secretar ', who came over from England one year ago. The General did not fancy the idea of the army in America breaking away from the English precedents, and was final ly prevailed upon to order the withdrawal of Baliington Booth. It is no secret that Hefbert Booth )tax tot' a long time coveted the position held by his younger brother, anti it is not a. surprise to Salvationists to Icno ' that he has practically succeeded his brother. He Zt as In command at headquarters 3'ester- day. The Salvation Army In America has grown to such proportions, and there is such a 'widespread love and devotion for Ballfng ton Booth and i\lrs. Booth, who have prac tically built up the whole organization, that !t is believed this action of Gen. Booth will cause a complete rupture be tween the English and American sections of the army. When the consideration of the Indian Appropriation bill was resumed, Mr. Grow (Rep., Penn.,) moved to malte the salaries $'1"OLIO, and against that proposition Mr. Crisp (Dem., Ga.,) raised a point of order that it changed existing law. A debate ex tending over two hours followed upon this, Chairman Payne (Rep., N. Y.,) at the close, overruling the point. In the course of the discussion much acidity of expression was shown. Mr. Hopkins (Rep., 111.,) spoke of Mr. Grows motion as the result of inspira tlon he would not name, but a tion of " factional oPPositIon to the Indian Committee."

The instrument of blackmail is alleged to be the Department of Justice. The Minister in charge of that department found, it appears, that one of his , who had been appointed " juge d instruction," or, as we should say, prosecuting officer, in connection with the affairs of the Southern railways, was pushing his to a point that might disturb a large number of the members of the Chamber of Deputies, upon whose Parliamentary support the Ministry relied. Now, however conven ient it might be to know all the facts in these legislators, and to hold the facts suspended over the legislators as a guarantee of their political support, it is plain that as soon as the facts were published 'by authority or made the ba sis of criminal procedures, the Ministry would lose its hold upon these legislators. Accordingly, the magistrate who was proceeding to unearth rascality without fear or favor found himself so obstructed and hampered by his chief, the Min ister of Justice, that he was forced to offer his resignation, and gave the reasons for it in a letter which has not yet been published. He was immediately succeeded, in defiance, it is said, of cus tom, if not of law, by an examiner who was supposed to be more amenable to litical considerations.

The belief that a revival of classic drama by Mme. [BERNHARDT] and her company would be gratifying to the admirers of the great French actress, found ample justification yesterday when Racine's "[PHEDRE]" was acted for the first time here in many years at Abbey's Theatre. There was a surprisingly large audience... In Rachel's time an actress who lightly put "Phedre" forward as a mere incident in a week of nine or ten performances of drama would have been regarded with amazement. After going through the flue acts of Racine, Mme. Bernhardt appeared again in the arduous r8le of Gismonda at. 8 o clock.

1'Ve see no very serious objection to the commission as proposed in the amended bill. But ft is said that PLar r and his men in the Legislature propose to follow this measure with others establishing State Police and Health Commissions in the metropolitan area, in advance of the actual consolidation, and in preparation for it. Any such project as that should be fought vigorously as soon as it is pre sented. It was a proposal of the present commission a year ago that consolidation be declared in name and boundary at once, and that " the framework of unifi cation " be vivified " by the immediate setting in motion of the executive De partments of Police and Health," but it did not propose State Commissions. It declared itself unreservedly for local self government on a " solid and permanent basis," and if consolidation is to be de ferred till Jan. 1, , all preparation of administrative machinery should be left for the commission to work out. " The fact of it is," was the an9wer diver, in a quiet, indifferent manner " that, so long a,s there is one man in the world to thinly well of me, I do not look beyond him to the balance of the human race, be cause I would not exchange the gold opin ion of that one man for the opinion of the whole human race." " You would take the opinion of that one man'"' Senator observed. " Then you must be a happy man," Sen ator remarked, sarcastically, " con sidering how much C. P. Huntington thinks of you.'

As the daily of prisoners in 189o ivas 97 greater than 1596, it is clear that very rigid economy was practiced in the latter year. he net. industry earnings in 189v exceeded those in 1594. In 1591 the total sum credited to earnings was $t)9,197; in 1595 the sum of $135,ISI was so credited. It is b3?this increase of net earnings that the of 1S93 is reduced. Tables are presented showing that. the earnings of the convicts in the three prisons for the six years-1SS9 to 1S95-amounted to $1,302,420. The prisons returned to the State Trea.s ury or expended by direction of the Legis lature all the money that it originally re ceived from the State. far industrial pur poses, and $94,635 in addition; that the prisons paid to convicts $52,775; that the prisons on Sept. 31, 15:75, had cash in banks amounting to $314,441, and had industrial assets on hand valued at $SIO,616. In .the course of his report, the Superintendent aa3?s: The-h ealth of the convicts fn the last )'ear was eery?good. The death rate of 1895 was the low est that it has be,n fur several years. In pre serving the health op the prisoners at Sing Slng and Auburn Prisons some clear disadvantages have: to be overcome, ?hich can be removed only by ne?v construction in order to obtain cell ac op the proper kind and to afford better ventilation and sanitation. The Practical importance and (al value of this change have been recognized for many years. The need op such change .has been enforced in the last three by the evidence Purnishetl in flue re ports--oP the physicians of the prevalence op disorders and op the great mortality W arises in the prisons from that cause. prisoners who have fitness for some one of them fof ? such . that is not permitted, the demand is still imperative that prisoners shall be kept at wont. The de mand arises from their condition, and must con tinue. In the prison system which is--now in operation, the convicts participate in the earnings of the prisons as compensation for theft labor. Their share !s not to exceed 10 per cent. op the of the prison fn ?.hich th=y are 3ned. The effect of this, provision has been that the 'ardens of the three State prisons have paid to convicts in cash, since 1889, the sum op $82,775.17. 'this money has been op very positive benefit to the men who have completed their Terms op imprisonment. It tides them over the immediate period following their release, until they can make some readjustment of their re lations to the world, and find occupation by which to live ?.

A rumor was heard some days ago that the sub-committee, of which i\Ir. [Lexow] is Chairman, would secure an extension oP its powers a.nd existence, so that it might employ the Summer months, after adjourn ment; in the preparation of the greater city charter. This rumor was then published in TxE NEw-YORK Tla>IES. Confirmation oP it has been had to-day?. It is said that llr. Platt proposes to continue the sub-com? mittee for the entire year, and to give into its charge the various bills Svhich will carry out the union of the various municipalities. This committee will represent Mr. Plate and the question arises whether it or the commission of fifteen which the bill calls for will be the paramount body. As the Platt legislators regard it, the subcom mittee wlll be the real actual construction agent. The nine Commissioners to be ap? pointed by the Governor ara expected to be eminently respectable, dignified, and intelli gent men. Gov. Morton will be expected tc designate such, and thereby he will himself of any charge of putting this im? portant work into the hands of politicians.

for a long time Prom the temper and style of the writers who assumed the task of perpetuating it. SS'hen he need ed money for supplies at Cambridge he wrote to a friend in the Continental Con gress that the amount sent him " would not be a flea bite." And one of his biog reports him as writing that the amount was " totally inadequate." This is the key to the false perspective of his biographies. His own stS le, in formal documents, was stiff with the conven tions of the Queen, Anne literature with which reading men of his day were most familiar. He had little gift of expres sion. The luminous simplicity of Hwnt ILTON, the intellectual audacity of JEF , the witty wisdom of FnwNxr.rN, the polished and biting c5 of Gou ~'I;R1L 'UR were aS to him as his own soundness of judgment and essential .openness of mind would have been to most of them. But if his way of speaking and writing and his de would now appear as priggish as would his well-combed wig and his unwrinkled silk stockings, what he said or rote or did is easily and is of the sort that wins the deep trust of men in all ages. And his actual expres sions, as we now have them in his corre , were far more direct, home ly, and full of force than the remarkable Sparksese in which, for the most part, they were known until . Fot3n's edi tion of his Letters appeared.

-A Formal transfer of the franchises and prop erty of the Eimira, Cortland and Northern Rail road Company to the Lehlgh Valley Railroad Company occurred in Phfladelphla yesterday, and the Lehlgh Valley assumed the management of the road. Previous to the Formal transfer Presi dent George S. Edgell and Vice President Henry V. Maxwell of the Elmira, Cortland and North ern resigned, and President E. Y. R'ilbur and Vice President Charles Hartshorn of the Lehigh Valley were elected In their places. -At Washington, Ind, last Thursday, the PW mets' Loan and Trust Company op New-York flied suit against the Evansville and Richmond Ralltvay Company to foreclose a ,age held by bondholders amounting to over $1,OLIO,21U0. -Articles op incorporation op tie Kingston and Lake .Katrlne Railroad Company were Albany 3'esterday. This company has $100, ODD capital, and proposes to build a .road 'Prom Kingston to Lalce Katrine.

Tallmadg'e, w111 preside, and grace will be said by tho Rev. Brockholst Vlorgan, Chaplain of the society. Before the speaking the Revolutionary hat will be presented to the President by Will iam G. Hamilton. Among the foreigners there are two land scapes by 1';. Boudin, " Troitvllle " and " In the Harbor of Bordeaux." Both are interesting. P. 11. Beyle has a large can vas called " A Pastime of tire Harem," showing an reclining on the divan, teasing with her Pan of Feathers a scarlet macaw, who swings upside down from his Perch. A view " On the Setne;" by Lepine, shows a drawbridge with streets along the bank and coal barges being discharged. Two landscapes by Damoye are well painted, and give pleas ant views op trench scenery.

To the left h0.ngs a sunset by l7, large both in size and conception, strong in painting, intense in its sentiment of the hour, a thorough harmony of the time and place. It represents a marshy stretch, with a bit of water in the foreground, and here and there along the horizon is a glint of red, as the sun out through the in clouds. It is quiet, , and thoroughly the work of a close student of nature. Nven more sympathetic than this is, perhaps, one of the best Rousseaus ever seen in this country. It is willed "Edge of the Woods." The theme is a simple one; there are trees, that al.. ways appeal very strongly to this painter; an Autumn sky , with cloud effect, cool, tender, and . The difficult problem of blue, always a stumbling to the painter, Rousseau has overcome, a? was his wont, with and apparently, no effort. The rich tones of reddish greens, of tender yellows, of distant haze-all these he has caught with the feeling of a poet, con amore. There are four more by Rousseau, ono of which, " Land scape," (No. 8,) is also a worthy example, though somewhat less important. Here is a hillside, near hfs favorite Font0.tne bleau, covered with shrubbery, with rocks in the foreground. It is very simple, but the artist has invested the scene with his personal touch, which, a magician s wand, seems to transform ything it comes near. The clever Eugene Fromentin is repre sented by two of his Oriental op Arabs on horses, one called " The Fal coner," and the other " A Fantasia," dexter. ous, dainty in technique, monstrously habits in handling, gray in color, full of action, vim, and snap, and-not too Profound. He seems to get all the qualities for which he is Famous in his moderate-sized panels, and when !t comes to the larger canvases, it is only after all an of his smaller work. Thus in his " Falconer " thero is the facility of brush work on gar ment, f0.ce, sky, anti foreground, while in his larger " Fantasia " the same peated by the addition of several more fig. uses.

Miss Linbeclc testified in her own behalf. She told of meeting blr. Gerry in London in 1593, through an advertisement she had published, . Gerry, she said, made in of Lady Jane Douglass, her former employer, and then employed her. She said she did not hear of the robbery at Newport until four days after it occurred. She said she had hidden the jewels in the sleeves of bliss Gerry's dresses. Some of the boxes she satw in hiss Gerry's sleeves after the robbery. Miss Linbecl; said she was absent from the Gerry from 3 to 4 o clock on the day of the robbery. She denied em that she had taken any of the jewels or had any as to who stole them.

The few Senators who some concern last night over \i r. \Iorgan's war cloud appeared to-day to have recovered their confidence. Several Senators said to a correspondent of Txe Nrn - TITfES that they couid see no basis for the state ments made by the Alabama Senator. They are inclined to think that a temporary at tack of jingoism was resPOnsible for them. The idea of Spain going to war with this country over Cuba, or any other ques tion, for that matter, is not entertained by officers of the army and the navy. About all the troops Spain can muster convenient ly are employed now in Cuba.

Among the changes proposed, of which just complaint is made, are those which are intended to discourage and hinder third panty and independent nomina tions. Under the law as it stands any party can nominate by convention and have a place on the ballot which cast 10,000 votes in the State at the last elec tion, or 1 per cent. of the vote in any civil division for which nominations are made. Under a proposed amendment it must have cast 20,000 in the State, and no provision is made for local nominations at all.

Dr. [Storrs]'s reference to Theodore Roose velt, a graduate of Harvard, was war mly applauded. " I am glad to hear you cheer him," he said. " I don't altogether ap prove of him. He had disturbed the moral equilibrium of this part of the universe. We always knew that New-Yorlc was greater than Brooklyn, but i'e used to think that Brooklyn was than New York. Now. when a New-Yorlc man wants to get drunk on Sunday, he has to cross to Brooklyn. But I rejoice in the man and his work. He stands as a of courageous manhood the highest ideal of education in Harvard.' Every one rose ani! sang "' Harvard" when President [Ellot] of the was introduced as " a son upon wham she has leaned for support.for twenty-five years." President Eliot's talk was largely devoted to a discussion of the spirit of liberty which he said was at the foundation of Harvard's system of education-liberty both for teach er and scholar. He cited as an.example of the growth of his chargo the Pact that in thirty years Harvard had increased fourfold in two years doubled, arid in the past year increased 10 per cent. 11 of ifs method of growth was the iri the number of students who were graduates of other colleges-03 in 1800 and 52o in the present year.

TVhen the prisoners were brought into the room [William F. Brockway] was in the lead, walking with head erect and firm tread, Mrs. Smith was bowed and weeping. ZVagner had his arm around her waist to support her, and, as she sank into her chair, he spoke words of comfort to her. After the foreman of the jury spoke, she down completely and VTagner threw his arms around her neck and held her head down upon his shoulder. . The scene became still more effecting when Mrs. Vooten, Brockway's devoted granddaughter, walked across the room to him and sat in his lap, while he her hair and bade her up.

Treasury gold reserve had once more crossed the hundred-million line. The Cree gold was placed at $lUa,UJ",SI3, an increase of very nearly :11,(OU,nOt1 since yesterday. 'fhe bank statement was to-day, but although it contained important changes in its items, it afforded little information as to the actual conditions of the banks. Au increase uC more than ,(S,,UOU in loans would, under ordinary circumstances, be regarded as evidence of growing activity in busi ness. At this time, however, it may pos sibly reflect drafts upon credit by those who had to make payments for Government bends. This explanation, however, is hard ly satisfactory, as the payments for the bonds were required last Saturday, and should not, therefore, play any part in this week s statement. Actual money holdings decreased $:7,000,000, and deposits decreased ;3,333,000. It is understood that some of the depository banks have included in their deposits the money held for the Govern ment on the bond transaction, whip others have not clone so.

Mr. Mantle called upon Senator [Carter]. this afternoon to read to him a letter which Mr. Mantle had written to Justice Bateman, woolen manufacturers, of Phil adelphia. This firm argued that the Mon tana Senators had been remiss in their duties in neglecting tog accept a measure of protection to wool that would advance the prices of that 3?and assure them oP a better' market. They assumed that Montana would benefit exceedingly by the increase of the duty to nearly 6 cents a pound. In this letter the silver question was not discussed, but the resisting Senators will add to their demand for higher wool duties another.that silver be Protected as well' as wool. The Philadelphia circular suggests . the importance of passing the Tariff bill of the House, alleging that it is a measure to .. the President would give his approval . . . The Montana:.Senators-. do not?bite at that bait. They do not believe, any more than Mr. Reed or Dir. [Dingley] believe it, that the President would sign the Dingley blll IC it should be passed.

This law was enacted at the instance of the three largest life insurance compa nies in the world, which have their prln offices in New-York City. Some time ago the Government oY Prussia adopt ed such stringent regulations against the New-Fork State insurance companies that tho Equitable Life Assurance Society withdrew from doing business in that coun try, as it would not Comply with the new regulations, which it was claimed were unreasonable and unjust. The New-Yorlc Life and the Mutual Llfe Insurance Com panics both complied with the regulations, but were afterward excluded from doing business in Prussia.

Chandler] also thought that the de termination of the administration, as here expressed, to prohibit the State from erecting any' buildings on R'ard's, Randall's, and Hart's Islands for the care of the in sane, was unwise, and he pointed out that there are now on 4~'ard s Island 3,-100 in sane, whereas the buildings there cannot comfortably accommodate l, i00 patients. Don't serve your notice within this year." llt,yor [Strong], replying, paid that he did not give his unqualified indorsement to the i\Ianhattan Hospital bill. " I approved it," he said, " simply from an economic stand point. Lnder the existing law wo had to keep all our own insane and pay 43 per cent. of the vost of the whole of the State's in sane. 'that law was unjust and we could g et no relief, so I thought it better that the State should tape care of the whole matter.

There are two of securing eco nomic statistics. First, the census method, by which aggregates are secured. The United States census takes up this 'branch of economic statistics, although it is not common in other nations. Notwithstanding the effort and money expended by the Fed eral Government to secure the facts rela tive to industrial progress them has re sulted much confusion, and this confusion grows out of inherent difficulties. There is great hesitancy on the part of manufact urers in giving certain facts called Por. This hesitancy and a faulty on the Part of the census have resulted in fal conclusions relative to the capital invested and the relation of capital to product. Tha manufacturer has always beet expected To state simply the capital actually paid fu and used in plant, of--what ever nature, as. working capital. ' That he has given nothing more Ihas not been his fault, for he has not been asked for more.

The two men n ere ready for the contest at 3:13 o clock, but a wrangle delayed thing s for some minutes, aitd for a time it looked as though there would be no con test. Referee Siler had the stals;e money in checks, and Julian, on behalf of [Robert Fitz] simmons, refused to go on with the con test. After considerable wrangling Fitz simmons gave in. Maker had in his corner " Jim " Hall and " Buclt " Connolly, while [FITZSIMMONS] was cared for by Martin Ju lian and "Jack" Everhart. Fltzsimmons appeared to be In fine condition the result of his six months' continued . 1\Iaher appeared nervous and was not in anything like the condition of his opponent, F'itzsimmons led with his left; Maker backed ' toward his corner. Fltzsimmons landed with his right, and a clinch followed. 1\Taher struck Fitzeimmons with his rlg ht hard while they were clinched, and Ref eree Siler warned him that IE he did so again he would give the fight to Fitzsim mons. After a breakaway [Peter Maher] landed his left on Fitzsimmons's neck. Close in fighting followed, and succeeded in landing his left on Fitz's upper lip, draw ing blood. The fatal tenth second was counted, Maker was declared out, and Fitzsimmons announced the victor after 1 minute and 35 seconds' rather lively fighting. Fitzsimmons s admirers cheered him to the echo, and i\Taper's seconds carried the defeated Irish man to hls corner. It was several min utes before he realized what had happened to him, and Fitzsimmons walked over to his corner and shook him by the hand. Fitzsimmons also hands with GZuinn_ and the seconds of Peter's corner.

The police station lodging houses will be permanently closed after March 1. Worthy lodgers who may apply for accommodation will be supplied with tickets which will admit them to the Wayfarers' Lodge and woodyard of the Charity Orgnnizauon So ciety, at 51G West Twenty-eighth Street, where they will be provided with supper, lodging, , and a bath, and have their clothing disinfected. In return they will be required to do a certain amount of labor in the woodyard. Other lodgers will ho referred to the city lodging house, foot of East Twenty-sixth Street. The Charities Department will supply the police with tickets for distribution.

IIe announced yesterday morning that he would glue it to Detective \ op the Central Ofilce instructions t0 take it to the institution and to arrest whomever it might fit. 'the cup would fit perhaps -thirds of tire little fellows in the school. llr. The story was to the effect that a check Por >Jglau's salary for the month of De cember last had not been received by him, that it had fallen into the hands of some person not entitled to it, who had forged ZJglau's indorsement, drawn the money, and, to prevent discovery, had murdered the professor. This theory dissolved into thin air when it was learned that no had been made out for >;glau s December salary, because, owing to illness, he had not rendered any service to the school dur ing that month. He is reported to have said that he believed his refusal to lend some money to Principal Greene last Octo ber was the reason that his salary wad withheld.

The Senate went into general orders, with Mr. Lexow in the chair. Mr. Hlggins moved the bill, to which Senator [Cantor] objected. He held that it was fin impor tant measure, was opposed by Boards of Excise, and ought not to be railroaded through the Senate while so many were absent. Senator Higgins pressed his mo tion. " This move of the minority; ' he said " is for the purpose of delay sand to defeat the object of the bill."

Ivlr. [Chanter]'s first expedition was in the shallow waters of Lake Jipe, on a raft made of palm stems. His object was to get a shot at the hippos. As he left his African followers on the shore, they showed their appreciation by shouting these cheering words: " Loolt out Eor crocodiles! If mas ter dies, who ll pay us? " There were many hippos-" the surface oP the lake dotted here and there by spots, which soon re solved themselves into the black, boxlike heads of my game." The huge beasts seemed quite indifferent at the approach of the strange craft. A group of five hippos n^as approached to 1'a0 yards; then, with a snort, they faced the raft. The rafts men seemed to have lost 3Ir. Chanter to stake a retreat, but he urged the crew until within 100 yards, when lie fired at the nearest animal; he missed, and then all oP the hippos disappeared. 1~'hen the sun rose, he counted fifty hippos, and talc(ng a good sight at ti. nearest one, he fired, and knew the bullet had reached its mark. He fancied that he would bag that hippo. but it sank out oP sight. Tr Cltan ler writes: "I had not 3 et learned that the brain of these animals is very small, and that the only fatal shot is under the ear." Then the hippos seemed to have crowded him, for they were decidedly too near for comfort. Next, " slowly but steadily.," 1\ir. Chanter felt that the frail raft was being lifted up. The boatmen yelled with terror. Evidently the hippo found he had made a mistake, and he left the bottom oP the raft. Ilr. Chanter had shot at three hippos and no dead animal was visible. Anything more disagreeable and danger ous than a hunt for buffalo in its own cov ert can hardly be imagined. The brush is not more than ten feet high, and through this the animals have made runways in numerable-but the branches meet at a man s shoulders. These paths cross and Cem oss in a labyrinthian way. Get caught In one o: these paths of a charging buf falo, and there can be no escape. Into just such an ugly brush as this llr. Chanter en tered, and there was a charge of buffaloes, but they passed on, separating just at the place where stood . Chanter. Then the follower said: " Ham del Allah "=' Praise be to God"-and our sportsman says lie " began to underst;tnd m hy buffalo shooting in the brush has been always considered unsafe." Mr. [Theodore Roosevelt]'s latest hunting experiences, in 1S93 and 189f, are neatly told. Antelope, where they once abounded, not far from his ranch, are by no means as abm:dant as they were. The only increase in the region of the Little \Iissourt has been in the wolves. Blaclctail at e not, how ever, diminishing. TVhere twenty were killed a dozen years ago for every one whitetail, now their numbers are about the same. The prong horn is getting scarcer, and so is the buffalo.elk. As to his battery, Mr.=Roosevelt has always been singular in his adhesion to the `Virichester, and he uses a .45-90. As to penetration, perhaps more stress is laid on that than it actually de serves. " Shock is useless if it is gained at too ,great expense of penetration or ac curacy." You may get flatness of tory, but IP you are not accurate there is little use in it. ~'e are rather conservative, and having been brought up in the school of the ancient small bore, with a long and solid bullet, and a fair charge of powder, :ye rather hang to that than to big bores, extra heavy powder, and hollow bullets. The l7 believes more in a double-barreled rifle. T'e put our faith in a repeating arm. " Each type has some good qualities' that the other lacks, and each has some defects." Then 1\Ir. Theo dore Roosevelt takes pleasure in noting what is Ilr. Selous's favorite arm. It is a rifle close to the type of that used by, us twenty-five years ago, of .45-calibre, with is grains of powder and a .bullet of 3u0 grains. blr, Roosevelt believes that we will even adopt a smaller calibre-one of .25G to .310-with 40 grains of powder, and a 200-grain bullet, But then the powder used to-day is a stronger substance than it was in former days. After all, there always is the personal equation which does the work, and so " the man behind the gun counts most."

The Standard will say it is understood that Sir Richard Webster, the Attorney General, 'has been revising the British case prepared by Sir Frederick Pollock, Corpus Professor of Jurisprudence at Oxford Uni versity. The case, as so prepared and re vised, will be issued early next week. The paper adds that it believes that the Gov ernment regards the case as historically un assailable, although in its diplomatic aspect it is not free from confusion.

The Soledad sugar plantation, near the City oP , is owned by I: I'. Atlans of Boston, Vlass. In the latter Part of June last the Lnsurgent , being active in the , l4 Cam pos directed Gen. to send a squad of soldiers to the Plantation and to throw up defensive in the of tha sugar house. Rut the of the plantation, appar ently fearful that this Course, if permitted by him, would bring down upon him repris als on the pari of the insurgents, refused either to receive the soldiers or to assist in the preparation of the defensive works, inform(ng the Spanish General that, as the plantation was the property of an American citizen, lte proposed to observe a strict neu tr , between the Spanish Government and the insurgents.

" Yes, my mother-in-law does own a house there," said Air. Spurgeon, very earnestly. " I am glad that this matter has come up. The old lady is very old-" " Now, gentlemen, don't laugh, I beg you," pleaded . [George Spurgeon], " It is true I married her daughter. She is the youngest of four children. The old lady made a will=' " But, Sir, there has Been an aspersion cast upon me." said 1\Ir. Spurgeon. " I want to set myself right. I would not live there. 1Iy wife got her interest out of her property, and we moved away, and only last night she aaid to me, ' George,' says she-"

In her opinion, the type of the American family is very likely the one that will at last prevail. For the same number Edward Atlclnson ha s writ ten a paper on " The Cost of an Anglo American `Yar."

" I feel highly elated to find myself free 0.fter eleven months' under con to solitary confinement for twen ty years, which was to eternity. Among those who will go to Baltimore are William Berrl, ex-Park Commissioner Frank Squler, Charles A. Zloore, Park Commissioner Tim othy L. ex- David A. Boody, Col. . Price, Gen. Stewart L. HER POINT OF VIEW. The Venezuelan matter being under discussion in a company of women the other day, one present who has resided in London for a number of years spoke again of the crass ignorance of American affairs, and notably of American sentiment on the part of the rank and file of the British public.

The recent elaborate dinner tendered to the artillery officers of the New-York National Guard by Brig. Gen. Howard Carroll, has, it is said, caused ill feeling among several officers present. The unpleasantness is reported to have been caused by a speech made by Capt. David Wilson of the Second Battery, which some officers took seriously, while others regarded it in the light of a joke, and did not believe that Capt. Wilson intended any offense.

LOWELL, Mass., Feb. 29. -- Gov. Greenhalge was taken worse this afternoon with nervousness, and to-night is very low. Dr. Nickerson, who is in attendance, is non-committal in regard to his ultimate recovery, though his condition is very critical. At 10 o'clock it was reported that the Governor was beyond recovery, but this his relatives would neither affirm nor deny.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 29. -- The annual report of the Minister of Marine and Fisheries has been laid before Parliament. It says that the total expenditure for the fishery service during the year was $420,000. Referring to the necessity for uniform regulations in the fisheries of the great lakes, the Minister says:

SUMMIT, N.J., Feb. 29. -- The Rev. S. Edward Young of Newark, President of the Christian Citizenship Union, addressed a meeting in Bonnel Hall, Millburn, last night under the auspices of the Civic League.

SOUTH MANCHESTER, Conn., Feb. 29. -- Louise Trebe, thirty-five years old, a single woman, daughter of the late Hermann Trebbe, was murdered at her home in South Manchester this morning by Caspar Hartlein, a farm hand, employed to do chores about the place.

As was told in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of last Sunday, Loie Fuller, who is dancing and whirling diaphanous raiment among beautiful light effects at Koster Bial's, has a very poor opinion of other women who imitate her work.

Late one afternoon in the Summer of 1894, at a fashionable watering-place in the South of France, two French gentlemen were sitting at a table in the garden of a hotel. A group of the usual "overdressed Americans" had just left another near them; one of the Frenchmen observed to the other: "The Americans are the most aristocratic people in the world."

The Mayoralty of New-York City has ever been an office of dignity and importance. Indeed, exacting as are now its duties, in olden-times they were far more comprehensive and vital. The Chief Magistrate was a High Mightiness, before whom every cap must be doffed; for he bore the keys of the city and held aloft not only the scales of justice but also of trade.

From The London Graphic. The graves of the first three Presidents of the Royal Academy are in a line in the centre of the south aisle of the crypt, beneath the choir of St. Paul's Cathedral. The most eastern is that of Sir Joshua Reynolds. About two feet to the west of this is the grave of the second President, Benjamin West.
Lent is the season when the Christian world gives itself up with more or less fervor to its spiritual devotions, and asks itself, "What is my duty toward my neighbor?"

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 29. -- While the last week has been far from a dull one it must necessarily seem quiet as compared with the gayety that celebrated Washington's Birthday. In the three balls of last Saturday night, Lakewood is acknowledged to have been at its very best in providing amusement for hosts of merry-makers and pretty girls.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The dinner giving and going fraternity have had no occasion to feel the loss of their usual enjoyments. The first week of Lent has been busy with them, and some of the most prominent hosts and hostesses have seen their names repeated in the public prints either at their own boards or at those of their friends nearly every day.

MADRID, Feb. 29. -- The Imparcial regards the international situation, in view of the action of the Senate of the "United States in regard to Cuba, as very grave, and expresses the opinion that the recognition of the belligerent rights of Cuba would involve great danger.

Grace Episcopal Parish will, March 7, celebrate one of the golden jubilees in its famous history, the fiftieth anniversary of the consecration of its beautiful edifice, on Broadway, near Tenth Street, known from one end of the land to the other as one of the most notable models of church architecture in this city.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29. -- There was very little feature to the local market to-day, and the changes were unimportant. The tractions were all steady and closed unchanged, except for Union and Baltimore. The former closed 1/8 higher, with the bonds 3/8 lower, ex interest. Baltimore declined 1/4, to 17 1/8.

The changes of the seasons and the recurrence of seedtime and of harvest must, from the earliest times, have been associated with certain changes in the position of the sun. In the Summer at midday the sun rises high in the heavens; in the Winter the sun is always low. The sun, therefore, had an annual movement up and down in the heavens, combined with the diurnal movement of rising and setting.

Mr. Daly will produce at his theatre Tuesday night Shakespeare's "Romeo and Juliet," for which he has been preparing for a long time. Mrs. James Brown Potter will be the Juliet, and Kyrle Bellew the Romeo. The company supporting these stars has been completely reorganized during the past few weeks, in view of this production, and is said to be strong and capable of interpreting Shakespeare.

NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 29. -- Already there are preparations about the cottages for the coming season, for in some instances the work of renovation was ordered by Summer residents to be begun this week. Cottage owners appear to be desirous of getting their places ready that they may take a run over to Europe before the opening of the Newport season, when they prefer to find their cottages prepared for use.

From Macmillan's Magazine. To the student of political institutions perhaps the most characteristic thing about the history of the German Empire is the example that it gives us of the revival or reaffirmation, so to speak, of the principle of monarchy. That principle has received some rude shocks in recent years.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 29. -- The Canadian Jockey Club bill has been passed by the Private Bills Committee of the Dominion House of Commons. The club is an organization which is proposed to be made up of various incorporated racing clubs and companies throughout the Dominion, having for its object the controlling of meets, promoting and holding of horse exhibitions, encouragement of thoroughbred breeding, and similar objects.

In choosing his cabinet for the ensuingyear. President Elliott has recognized all sections of the country and at the same time selected gentlemen of ripe experience in league affairs. Generally speaking, his appointments are regarded satisfactorily, only one "kick" having thus far been publicly recorded.

BOSTON, Feb. 29. -- Hardly had the outrage to the Boston schooner Navarino, which was held up and searched by a Spanish man-of-war, been confirmed by the officers of the schooner upon her arrival here Friday, when the startling intelligence was received here of another outrage to a Boston vessel in comparison to which the Navarino episode sinks into insignificance.

The poet prefaces her volume with a sonnet to Oliver Wendell Holmes, which is followed by a letter from that amiable autocrat commending "The Captain's Story" in words of high praise. With such a lion in the path he must be a bold critic who dares to enter this temple of verse except in reverent posture and with his hat off.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 29. -- The impression prevails in the minds of some persons that gold in paying quantities has been discovered on the Aspiawall estate, in the town of Red Hook.

From The London Times. The first public sale in London of frozen salmon from Vancouver -- the quantity disposed of representing 140 tons -- marks the formal beginning, on a commercial footing, of a new import trade.

At the instance of brokers who have been disappointed in the new Mining Exchange, a general conference of members was held yesterday, at which grievances were aired and notice served in effect that if the Exchange is to continue, it must be operated on an improved basis. The Directors were present in order that complaints might be clearly understood by those against whom they were made.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The Gridiron Club to-night, taking advantage of the fact that its chartered dinner day fell upon the 29th of February, broke into the symmetry of its record by giving a dinner at which the board was graced by the presence of many of the most prominent ladies in the social circles of the capital.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 29. -- At noon to-day nearly 300 prominent Democrats, representing the sound-money faction of the party throughout Missouri, met in the parlors of the Planters' Hotel, for a conference on the course to be pursued in the coming campaign. Ex-Attorney General Daniel H. McIntyre of Caliph was elected Chairman, and Dr. Jewett of Shelby was appointed Secretary.

"Can the defendant in a case of criminal libel give truth in evidence?" and "Are the jury therein to judge on both, the law and the facts?" were questions which the common law answered in the negative. It was the voice of Andrew Hamilton, while defending John P. Zenger, in 1735, which first protested against such restrictions on the liberties of the subject and of the press.

ALBANY, Feb. 29. -- The State Prisons Commission, though less than a year old, is striking out boldly to usurp the powers given by the State Superintendent of Prisons under the Constitution. Ex-Senator Lispenard Stewart, its President, notified the Finance Committee of the Senate that the commission could not carry on its work with less than $16,000 or $17,000 a year.

In a time of small poets, Austin-laureates, and similar curiosities, a volume of verse by William Watson must command more serious consideration than it would have got at the beginning of the present century, when lovers of verse could choose between the rhythmic sunbursts of Byron and the clear moonlight of Wordsworth.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29. -- Marcus Pollasky, the railroad promoter of this city, is negotiating for a connection, by rail between Colubus, Ohio, and Bay City, Mich. The project is really a revival of one undertaken several years ago, when the Columbus, Lima and Milwaukee Railroad Company was incorporated, the line to extend from Columbus to Saugatuck, on Lake Michigan, and there to connect by steamers with Milwaukee.

President John K. Cowen and First Vice President Oscar G. Murray were appointed receivers of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad in Baltimore early last evening. The appointments were made toy United States Judges Goff and Morris upon the application of representatives of the company. The Directors were in session for the greater part of the day.

In the beginning of the thirteenth century the annual revenue of the Byzantine Empire amounted to u130,000,000. Yet at that time not only was the Eastern Empire greatly impoverished by the ravages of the Crusades, but the chief part of Asia Minor, with its flourishing cities, had been wrested from her by the arms of Islam.

SATURDAY -- P.M. London took the Cuban resolutions with equanimity, prices from that centre at the opening of our market being only small fractions below parity. This condition was reflected in the early trading toy considerable general strength. The large short interest for the Washington account created yesterday also helped maintain prices.

The projectors of the present exhibition of the Architectural League have shown a very just sense of the nature and value of the exhibition by treating it as a museum and admitting the public to it free for four of the secular days out of six. If it were open to the public also on the seventh, the immense public benefit which such an exhibition is calculated to bestow would be very greatly enhanced.

PETERSBURG, Va., Feb. 29. -- A syndicate of Northern members of the Grand Army of the Republic is now negotiating for the celebrated "Crater" farm, which is situated a 'short distance from this city in the County of Prince George, and which is about half a mile southeast from the old Blandford Church burying ground.

From Good Words. The chief treasures in the Bronte Society's museum are among the manuscripts, which are both numerous and intrinsically interesting. Round one of them -- the plain, calfbound volume which contains the original manuscript of the first volume of "Jane Eyre" -- the whole exhibition may be considered to centre.

The anti-Platt Republican leaders of the Twenty-fifth Assembly District are making systematic efforts to form an organization which may send contesting delegates to the State Convention. Circulars are sent out to voters of the district, accompanied by postal cards on which the recipients are asked to enroll their names and then return them to James B. Townsend, at 29 East Twenty-sceond Street, the State clubhouse.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 29. -- Mr. Cowen, at 11 o'clock to-night, gave to the press the following official statement, which had been in the course of preparation for some hours:
GLEN COVE, L.I., Feb. 29. -- Five persons had a narrow escape from drowning in the waters of the upper lake, near this village, yesterday afternoon.

Steamers and sailing vessels are running ashore in this neighborhood with a frequency that is almost ludicrous. A lot of Captains seem to have tired of the all-water routes. At any rate, they are making big dents in our coast line, as if they thought coast lines didn't cost anything. It's about time these attempts to rival the overland transportation companies came to an end.

In the annual report of the State Board of Health, which was laid before the Legislature a few days ago, there may be found a statement of the results of a careful inquiry concerning a group of cases of typhoid fever said to have been due to infection derived from oysters which had been freshened in water polluted by sewage at Port Richmond.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 29. -- The wedding of Miss Emily Banta, soprano in Crescent Avenue Church here, to George Brooks of New-York took place Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Satisfaction in Washington over the passage by the Senate of the Cuban resolution has been manifested generally to-day, except in those quarters where the responsibility for further action is greater than it appears to be in the Senate or the House. Members of the Senate speak of the action of their body as promising an end, with gain to Cuba, of the Spanish war in Cuba.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 29. -- In the Circuit Court this morning Judges Field and Teney decided that Mayor Todd (Republican) cannot remove Democratic members of the Boards of Public Safety and Public Works without cause, declaring Section 32 of the City Charter unconstitutional. This means that 1,600 Democrats will be retained in office until the Mayor can find causes for their removals.
ALBANY, Feb. 29. -- Gov. Morton to-day signed Chapter 40 (Assemblyman Audett's) providing for interpreters for the County and Surrogate's Courts in Kings County, at a salary of $1,200 each.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 29. -- Among other things, the end of the century will record several false Christs. They are branded by the world as frauds and impostors. At the same time hundreds of intellectual, apparently level-headed people vouch for the genuineness of their claims, as in the case of Schlatter of Denver.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 29. -- The dreaded March lion is not yet in evidence here by the sea, but the proverbial lamb is reigning and Atlantic City rejoices at its prospects for the most prosperous Lenten season on record. Every day adds hosts of visitors to the contingent already quartered here, while, on the other hand, the departures are unusually few.

LONDON, Feb. 29. -- The statement made in the House of Commons last night by George N. Curzon, Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, regarding the attitude of the Government on the bimetallis question was open to misinterpretation. Mr. Curzon stated that the Government had been approached with a view to the convening of another international bimetallic conference.

FRIDAY, MARCH 6. -- By the Sheriff, execution sale, the right, title, and interest of Florestine Stanfield to 48 West Twentieth Street, south side, 167,4 feet east of Sixth Avenue, 25 by 92 by 92.0 1/8 four-story brownstone dwelling.

The approval of the Secretary of War having been obtained to the construction of the new East River Bridge, the commission will soon be able to set the work agoing. The Chief Engineer expects to be ready to begin upon the foundations of the piers within three or four months, and, as the funds will come from the two cities of New-York and Brooklyn, there is no reason to apprehend delays.

LONDON, Feb. 29. -- Certain favored Conservative journalists have obtained from the Foreign Office a story of what they call the Delagoa Bay plot, which throws the clearest sidelight upon the Boer and German intrigue to secure a foothold at Delagoa Bay, the capital of the Portuguese possessions in East Africa, which would afford the best inlet and outlet to the trade of the Transvaal.

ALBANY, Feb. 29. -- Capital City society has been very devout the first week in Lent. Its only dissipations have consisted of a few small dinners and receptions. On Wednesday evening a home dinner was given at the Executive Mansion, the only guests being Gov. Morton's two cousins, Mrs. Landon and Mrs. Stewart: Mrs. Erastur Corning, and Col. Selden E. Marvin.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 29. -- This city has now practically a new police headquarters, for the remodeling and renovation of the old building in Centre Street, which is just about completed, has transformed its appearance, both inside and out, to such an extent that it is scarcely recognizable. The building has been considerably increased in size and attractiveness, and in equipment and facilities for the Retention and care of prisoners.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29. -- New-York Biscuit continues active and strong in the face of a weak and dull market; the stock advanced to 77 5/8, the highest point it has reached in the history of the company. The balance of the market showed a decidedly heavy tendency with little demand for stock at any price.
Commissioner Willis of the Department of City Works, Brooklyn, dismissed eighty-five employes in that department, and reappointed a number of Republicans and two Democrats yesterday.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 29. -- Notwithstanding that rain fell heavily all night and all through the day, rendering the links extremely soft and muddy, eight members of the Golf Club tried for the silver loving cup, the gift of James Converse. Among the players was W.F. Wheelock, the old gentleman who captured the trophy last week, and who was not to be deterred by the rain.

Startling, almost incomprehensible, to those who have not studied what are superstitions and their origin, is an article to be found in the last issue of The American Anthropologist, by George R. Stetson, entitled 'Animistic Vampires in New-England." In this paper there is presented the horrid fact, that in New-England, there still exists belief in vampires.

When Mr. Thompson published his first volume of poems, it was received by the "chorus of indolent reviewers" with warm and genial praise. The present book sustains the reputation earned by the former one. It is undeniable that at times Mr. Thompson's verse is somewhat involved and his meaning obscure, but the elevation of his style is almost always such that it puts the reader's mind in a glow.

Here is a brave book. A little knot of slaves of the pen -- journalists, if you will have fine words on the tip of your tongue -- meet upon certain saints' days in the heart of London and discourse right cleverly about themselves, their surroundings, the surroundings they would like to have, and the strong heart of the world.

The necessity for all classes co-operating in the efforts to secure the deepening of Newtown Creek is becoming more and more evident as the period approaches for a hearing before the River and Harbor Committee of the National House of Representatives in regard to an appropriation by Congress of $300,000 for that purpose.

"Peg-leg" Anderson, the grizzled little old fisherman of Pier 2 East River, sat on the stringpiece at the head of the pier yesterday, oblivious of the depredations that the eels and porgies were committing upon his bait in the water below.
WEDNESDAY, March 4. -- By William Kennelly, auction sale, 19 Barrow Street, south side, between West Fourth and Bleecker Streets, 25 by 81.1, four-story and basement brick dwelling.
ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 29. -- Miss Taylor of Highland Avenue gave a very pleasant whist party at her home, to-night.

Speculation was very slow all day in every branch and the tendency was to weakness, with grain about 1/8c lower, and trading confined to local scalpers. Provisions reacted a trifle, and had a better demand. Cotton was dull and hardly changed. Coffee advanced a trifle, with Europe, and was quiet.
Stevenson Constable, Superintendent of Buildings, yesterday had his entire staff clothed in suits which gave a military air to the department quarters, at Fourth Avenue and Eighteenth Street.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 29. -- The members of the Bloomfield High School Alumni Association held a very pleasant mid-Winter sociable and reunion at the home of Miss Emilie Stout, 362 Franklin Street, last night. An entertaining programme was provided and dancing fallowed.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- Henry Fouquier, the influential dramatic critic of Le Figaro, signs, in association with Georges Bertal, the new play of the Odeon Theatre, "Le Modele." I presume that the capital idea, the starting point, the problem attracting to study, demonstration, and solution, was the worth, the effect, in artistic life, of love -- free or consecrated by proper social laws, the speech of the civil officer, or the blessing of the minister.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The phraseology of the Cuban resolutions adopted by the Senate yesterday: "Resolved, by the Senate, (the House of Representatives concurring,)" revives the question which was discussed in the House of Representatives when the Armenian "concurrent" resolution was adopted, as to whether the President is not obliged, under the Federal Constitution, to either approve or disapprove all such "concurent" resolutions, in the manner followed in the case of "joint" resolutions.

From The British Medical Journal. At the second January meeting in Manchester it was noted with interest by racing men that the horses which came in first, second, and fourth had undergone the operation of tracheotomy, and carried silver tubes in their windpipes. Among the principal drawbacks to the breeding and owning of horses of all classes is the affection known as "roaring."

Mme. Adelphine Kallwitz gave a musical last evening at the apartment of Mrs. John C. Meyer, in the Bolkenbayn, 763 Fifth Avenue, which was attended by a large number of people of social prominence. Mme. Kallwitz is a diplomee of the Vienna Conservatory. Her father was an officer in the Austrian army, and was attached to the Austrian Imperial household.

War Paint, the weekly publication of the Syracuse Cycle Company, is being widely circulated hereabouts by Charles J. Stebbins, the metropolitan agent for the "Crimson Rims." Several requests have been received by Mr. Stebbins, asking that the paper be mailed regularly to the applicants, and offering to subscribe.

Here is a volume of lyric verse, generally smooth and always readable, which never at any point exalts the emotions of the reader. Dr. Gunsaulus writes good, marketable poetry, and he is certainly, as his work shows, a man of cultivated taste, of wide reading, of sensibility, and of earnestness.
MOUNTAIN PARK HOTEL, HOT SPRINGS, N. C., Feb. 29. -- J.A.G. Allen and B.G. Smith, capitalists, of Baltimore, in company with J.J. Newman, civil engineer of Salisbury, arrived here Sunday evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The Naval Reserve probably will fare better by this Congress than ever. There has been for the past few years an allotment of $25,000 for the Naval Reserve. This sum has gone for the purchase of material, a small portion being expended for publications. The annual amount is distributed between the States supporting a reserve, according to the strength of the force.
From the mist-shrouded bay and Narrows there came yesterday the crashings of collisions and the reverberant notes of whistles from vessels that had gone aground.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The Brazilian Minister and Mrs. De Mendonca entertained to-night at dinner Miss Fuller, Miss Nott, Miss Bryan, Miss Philip, Miss Wilcox, Mrs. Mario De Mendonca, and the Misses De Mendonca, Mr. Trubert, Count Vinci, Lieut. Von Stumm, Count Buisseret, Mr. Pastor, Count Galarza, Mr. Alfredo Gana, and Mr. Mario De Mendonca.

Probably very few persons in New-York know that in the name of Rivington Street is perpetuated the memory of the man who in his day published the most rabid Tory newspaper that was ever printer in the Colonies. This was James Rivington, who, during and for many years previous to the Revolutionary war, was one of the most prominent individuals in this city.

At the invitation of President Roosevelt of the Police Board, Carl Schurz, President of the Civil Service Reform Association; Secretary McAneny and Alfred Mason Bishop, and Col. Silas N. Burt of the State Civil Service Board met at Police Headquarters yesterday for the purpose of investigating the workings of the department so far as promotions, dismissals, and reductions in rank are concerned.

The collision, which resulted in the sinking of the Ailsa aptly illustrates the suddenness with which disasters happen on the water as well as on the rail. The vessel was riding peacefully at anchor at 2:13 o'clock in the afternoon. Seven minutes later, by her officers' calculations, she was beached near the Long Island shore of the Narrows, with forward decks and bridge submerged and passengers avid crew clinging to the rigging.
The annual meeting of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America was held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon.

"The New Phonography," an article by Frederick J. Harrison in Anthony's Photographic Bulletin for March, advance sheets of which were sent to THE NEW-YORK TIMES, sustains the interest in Prof. Rontgen's discovery that certain substances, formerly considered opaque, are transparent to certain rays.

A new country club will be opened on the banks of the Hudson River early in the Spring, which, in point of elegance and magnificence, will undoubtedly exceed anything of its kind within the immediate vicinity of New-York. This will be the Ardsley Casino, situated midway between Dobbs Ferry and Irvington, where has been secured a plot of nearly 500 acres overlooking the Hudson River.

-- The Directors of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company have elected Horace C. Du Val Vice President, this office not having been filled at the regular election. The following Directors have resigned: Eugene L. Button, William F. Creed, Frederick S. Flower, Otto Zanker, Jr., Thomas C. Renwick, Floyd Vail, and J.N. Wallace. Their successors are John G. Jenkins, Theodore F. Jackson, Anthony N. Brady, Henry Seibert, Seth L. Keeney, David H, Valentine, and John Englis.

Streams of people carrying pots and pans, kettles and cans, jugs and pails wound down East Houston Street all day yesterday to a spot opposite No. 324, where a six-inch hose was discharging hot water into the gutter at the rate of 175 gallons a minute.

From The Fortnightly Review. As fish, have grown more knowing, man has grown more cunning, and has devised new schemes to outwit his prey. Now, instead of fishing downstream, he fishes upstream, that he may be below and behind the fish, and, therefore, less in sight: for fish, it must be borne in mind, always lie with their heads upstream.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 29. -- The ladies of the Highland Park Baptist Sunday school are much pleased at the success of their fair, which netted $100. It will be added to the building fund.

LENOX, Mass., Feb. 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. Anson Phelps Stokes have been spending a few days at Shadow Brook this week. They had with them a jolly house party, including Anson Phelps Stokes, Jr., and a few of his college friends, and the Misses Stokes and some of their girl friends from New-York. They had a very jolly time of it sleighing, coasting, and tobogganing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- There is to be another departmental proposition in behalf of the naval personnel. This advice will probably be confined, as usual, to the line. Secretary Herbert has at least offered the staff people no encouragement.

BOSTON, Feb. 29. -- Writing from Hamilton, Bermuda, Capt. Edward Sherlock of R.S. Palmer's schooner yacht Yampa tells the story of her voyage from this port. The Yampa left Boston Tuesday, Feb. 11, and was towed down the harbor almost to the tower light, from which point she proceeded under sail. The day was fair, but cold, and more than half a gale was blowing from the northwest.

These hours fluctuated as the influence of the Norman French waxed or waned.

This is an interesting and welcome little volume. The Bishop of Peoria has certainly shown no striking gift of verse in his translations, but he has done his work conscientiously and with some self-sacrifice. One need not read between the lines to discover places where the translator might have made his own stanza smoother at the expense of fidelity to the original.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The Washington Spring is close at hand. A week of fairly temperate weather would start the sap flowing in the trees. Already some of the early flowering shrubs in the Government reservations have begun to expand. The beautiful yellow forsythia will be the first to bloom, but the crocus will run it a hard race.

TUESDAY, March 3. -- By Adrian H. Muller Son, auction sale, 831 and 833 Third Avenue, east side, 30.2 feet south of Fifty-first Street, two four-story brick buildings, with extensions, respectively 14.6 and 15.0 1/2 by 66.6.

There has been considerable activity in art circles during the past, week, what with the sales of the Schaus and Reichard collections at Chickering Hall, the shows at two clubs -- the Lotos and Salmagundi, the Architectural League -- and the works of Henry Hosier at the Avery galleries.

The seventieth anniversary of the birth of Oswald Ottendorfer yesterday brought forth innumerable congratulatory messages from this city and country, and from Europe. All day long The Staats-Zeitung received felicitations from the large army of friends of the "Dean of German-American journalism."

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Feb. 29. -- The Wheelmen bowled two of the greatest games of the year last night on the alleys of the Bloomfield Cycling Athletic Association. The home team won both games from their opponents, the Tourist Cycle Club bowlers of Paterson. They had to roll big scores to do it, and the wildest excitement prevailed.
To the Editor of The New-York Times: The following was published in yesterday's (Sunday) Boston Globe:

The regular season of Augustin Daly's company, with Miss Ada Rehan, closed last night, after a duration of just fourteen weeks. It was the shortest season ever played by the Daly company in the home theatre, and Mr. Daly, in conversation with a reporter of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, gave this explanation of its brevity:

While the rainstorm was at its height, at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, four alarms were rung in quick succession for a fierce fire in the six-story mercantile house 29 and 31 Thomas Street. Amory, Brown Co. occupied the main floor and two of the upper floors, the latter of which they used for the storage of goods.

Thomas Cochrane, Lord Dundonald, is a most appropriate subject for another book in the series termed English Men of Action. It would be difficult to imagine a more active life than his, or one more replete with brilliant achievements -- achievements that were usually attained in the face of great odds through skill as a tactician and superb genius for plot and subterfuge.
