Edward Davicco, an Italian chemist, who had invented and patented a fuel-saving compound, which he dispensed from an office on the third floor of 1,180 Broadway under the name of the Eureka Fuel Economizer Company, was found dead in his office yesterday morning by the janitor of the building.

Every pew in Grace Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, was filled at yesterday morning's services. Many persons occupied chairs in the aisles, and no standing room was left when the organ voluntary began.

HOBOKEN, N.J., March 8. -- At the last meeting of the Chess Club it was decided to expend $5 on the prize for the winner of the interclass tournament which is now in progress. It was also decided that all matches in the interclass tournament must be played off before March 18. Profs. Wood, Webb, and Lawtor were made honorary members.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Extra pressure is to be brought to bear on all the Republican Assemblymen this week to drive the Raines excise bill through. Assemblymen and Senators returning from New-York City say that directions have been issued which will probably bring machine Republicans from nearly every county in the State to this city this week in the interest of the bill.

Some of the feather-headed politicians of the Republican Party are talking of what they call "energetic action" on the Cuban question. They are not satisfied with the resolutions that have been passed. They think them not strong enough. They object particularly to them that they do not impose directly and unavoidably any policy upon the President.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 8. -- At the annual Winter meeting of the Board of Trustees there were present Congressman John De Witt Warner and ex-Gov. Alonzo B. Cornell of New-York, Charles S. Francis of Troy, F.S. Wasnburn of Chicago, Miss M.C. Thomas of Bryn Mawr, W. B. Hoyt ot Buffalo, W.O. Kerr of New-York, and many of the younger Trustees.

The money market was quiet and easier. Call loans were made at 2 1/2@4 per cent., the average for the week being about 3 1/2 percent. Time money was also easier. Quotations were 3 per cent, for 30 to 60 days, 3 1/2 per cent. for 90 days. 4@4 1/2 per cent, for four to five months, and 6 per cent. for six to seven months.

The third competition of the season in the Covell Trophy Match, shot Saturday evening at the Seventh Regiment Armory range, resulted in another victory for Company B, whose grand total is now 809 points. The fourth and last competition will take place on the 28th inst.This match is open to teams of six from each company in the Seventh Regiment, three members of whom shall not be armory sharpshooters.

The provisions of the Dingley-McKinley Tariff bill have been curiously misrepresented by certain Republican journals in the West, and notably by The Chicago Inter Ocean, the foremost Western supporter of both McKINLEY and McKinleyism. In the course of some remarks about the attitude of Mr. CARTER and his Republican associates toward this measure, The Inter Ocean says:

"In face of the results that maritime capture has often produced, it is idle to pretend that privateering is not among the most formidable of belligerent weapons; and in the face of obvious facts it is equally idle to deny that there is no weapon the use of which causes so little individual misery."

The second of the chamber music entertainments of Miss Antoinette Szumowska and the Messrs. T. and J. Adamowski was given yesterday afternoon in the hall of the Mendelssohn Glee Club. The audience was of moderate size, but its approval of the performance was loudly expressed. It is a matter of mere courtesy to record this fact, for no musical performance has yet been discovered which cannot obtain a large amount of applause.

J.H. Dalton, who has been successful in Chicago as the proprietor of music halls, opened the old Koster & Bial's, in Twentythird Street, last night. The famous old house, wherein the fame and much of the money of the music hall pioneers was made is now called the Trocadero. In only a few other respects has it become different from the place that was abandoned by its original tenants two years ago last August.

Diligent effort is still being made by the anti-Platt Republicans in the Fifteenth Congressional District to elect anti-Plate delegates to the Republican National Convention at St. Louis, despite the fact that President Joseph Murray of the Excise Department has, for the time being at least, joined hands with the Platt forces.

Commissioner Willis of the Department of City Works. Brooklyn, recently dismissed eighty-five employes in the City Works Department and created eleven new offices, to which he appointed faithful Willis Republicans. The Civil Service Commission and the Civil Service Reform Association objected to these appointments, as they claimed it was against the spirit of the civil service law, and Corporation Counsel Burr was called upon for an opinion.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- There are several bills before the Committee on Irrigation and Arid Lands in the House, each intended to correct the faults in the Carey act, under which the General Government gives to the so-called arid land States 1,000,000 acres each, with the condition that the States reclaim and settle such lands.

Charities Commissioner Faure has almost completed the furnishing of a large barge at the foot of East Twenty-sixth Street for the accommodation of homeless men at night. The barge will be ready for use next week.

Napoleon Bonaparte was the subject of John L. Stoddard's third lecture in his Lenten course at Daly's Theatre yesterday morning, and he delivered a discourse which was followed with great interest by an audience which filled the house. Unlike most of his lectures, that on Napoleon is a review, rather than a story of the man's history.

The first of a series of union Evangelistic meetings, which, it is expected, will be kept up until Easter, was held last night at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue and Fifty-third Street. In these services the following ten churches have joined: Madison Avenue Reformed Church, Baptist Church of the Epiphany, First Reformed Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church.

MONDAY -- P.M. London came higher this morning, but it was some time before his market showed any signs of responding to the improvement abroad. In the afternoon, however, when it become known that the disposition in Washington seemed to be to take moderately rational action on the Cuban belligerency resolutions, prices rallied quite sharply, and, as a rule, closed at the highest of the day.

J. Pierpont Morgan with a small party of friends started for Florida over the Pennsylvania Railroad last night. The two private cars Grassmere and Mariquita were attached to the 9:15 P. M. train out of Jersey City, and Mr. Morgan's party will enjoy their exclusive use throughout the trip.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 9. -- The Albion Paper Company of Holyoke is unable to meet obligations, and a meeting of creditors is called for Saturday afternoon. The failure was unexpected. All notes at the bank have been met up to to-day. No attachments are recorded, but the officers say that there is no prospect of relief. The debts are said to amount to over $500,000, some placing them at $700,000.

Dr. Herman M. Biggs, pathologist and director of the bacteriological laboratories of the Health Department, in speaking yesterday of the new preparation of antitoxic serum for immunity from or the treatment of diphtheria, said he had become wary of talking on the subject, as he had been made to appear as having signed statements on the subject.

The contention on the part of a number of importers of precious stones that, by virtue of Paragraph 467 of the act of Aug. 28, 1894, diamonds are on the free list, has been definitely disposed of in the negative by a decision rendered in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in this district yesterday.

We remarked the other day upon the singularity of the introduction into Congress of a measure affecting copyright by a member who represents Pike County, Missouri, though he happens to live in the adjoining county of Audrain. It was indeed difficult to perceive how the Pike County heart can be fired on any question of international or of domestic copyright, of literature or of art.

BOSTON, March 9. -- The Exchange closed at 1 o'clock on account of the funeral of Gov. Greenhalge. The features were Pioneer Mining and New-Haven and Hartford. Investment stocks as a rule were neglected. Pioneer rose 7/8, to 9 7/8, closing at 9 5/8. Montana declined 3/4, to 76 1/8, closing at 76 3/8. Butte lost 3/8, to 1 1/2, but advanced later, closing at 2.
The New-York Society of Keramic Arts opened its Easter exhibition and sale yesterday evening at the clubhouse, 22 East Sixteenth Street.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 9. -- President Freedman says the New-York baseball players seem to be in better shape now, after two days' practice, than they were last year two weeks after their arrival. He is well pleased with the material on hand, and believes that out of thirtythree men signed he can produce a pennant-winning team.

An interesting course of study was begun for the first time this year by a class of young women at Barnard College yesterday. It was the graduate course in sociology, under Franklin H. Giddings, Professor of Sociology at Columbia.

CHICAGO, March 9. -- There seems to be no reaction in sight on "the Moore stocks," New-York Biscuit and Diamond Match. The former closed at the highest point of the day, and Match scored a 3-point advance. Outside of these stocks the trading was light. Bank clearings were $14,409,757. New-York exchange was quoted at 10c discount.

TRENTON, N. J., March 9. -- The committee of lawyers to which, was assigned the task of recommending to the Legislature an amendment to the Constitution relative to the judiciary of the State made its report to-night. It embraces the following recommendations:

The Board of Managers of the Manhattan State Hospital met yesterday at the office of George E. Dodge, the Secretary, 156 Fifth Avenue. There were present exJudge Henry E. Howland, President; Mrs. Eleanor Kinnicutt, Isaac N. Seligman, John McAnerney, and Mr. Dodge.
MADRID, March 9. -- Quiet prevailed in the City of Valencia to-day. More arrests were made of persons who took part in yesterday's riotous demonstration.

There may be seen at the Fifth Avenue Auction Rooms, 238 Fifth Avenue, near Twenty-seventh Street, a collection of oil paintings belonging to the estate of the late Hon. Henry C. Murphy, with additions from private collectors and others. All will be sold by auction on Thursday and Friday evening's, March 12 and 13, at 8 o'clock.

ALBANY, March 9. -- Republican Leader Ellsworth to-night made a grab for the control of the Niagara Reservation. He presented a bill designed, to transfer the control of that State property to the Fisheries, Game, and Forestry Commission. It is now under the control of the Niagara Reservation Commission, of which Andrew H. Green of New-York City for some years has been the President.

Some misapprehension exists as to the purpose of Chief Conlin in recommending the abolition of the Broadway and steamboat squads and transferring the work to the precincts bordering on Broadway and along the water front.

ROME, March 9. -- The official reports of the battle fought at Adowa March 1, between the Italians and Abyssinians, confirm the previous reports of heavy losses on both sides, those of the Abyssinians having been enormous. Gen. Arimondi was wounded and is a prisoner in the hands of the Abyssinians.

Mr. DEPEW "touches nothing that he does not adorn." The art of adornment is in politics difficult but useful, since subject matter is often presented which in itself is a little bare, not to say barren. An instance in point is Mr. DEPEW'S formal presentation of the candidacy of his lifelong friend, Gov. MORTON, for the Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Four copies of the Venezuelan Blue Book reached Washington yesterday, having been sent in advance of their publication in England. One came to Sir Julian Pauncefote, exclusively for his information, and not, as was expected, to be presented by him to the Venezuelan Commission as the British case.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., March 9. -- Charles Noyes and Miss Nellie Barnes, who, it is said, will some day receive an inheritance of $50,000, eloped and were quietly married a few days ago, much to the discomfiture of the bride's mother, Mrs. Mollie Barnes, and her uncle, George Martine.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 9. -- Senator Roswell Weissinger of Louisville, who had been the leader of the sound-money Democrats in opposition to the re-election of Senator Blackburn, died this morning. On account of his death there was no attempt to-day to proceed with the balloting for United States Senator.
Ballington Booth appeared at his new headquarters in the Bible House yesterday and began the work of organization.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Chairman Hull of the House Committee on Military Affairs may be in possession of the information from Leavenworth, Kansas, contained. in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of this morning, concerning the preference shown in the Soldiers' Home at that place for inmates who take the Keeley cure, but other members of the committee are not aware of it. Mr. Hull left the city Saturday night, to be absent ten days.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., March 9. -- The steam yacht Eleanor of the New-York Yacht Club, Scott, master, William A. Slater, owner, arrived in this harbor at 5 o'clock this afternoon, from a trip around the world, having been absent since Oct. 27, 1894, in which time she traversed 42,406 nautical miles, and did it almost without mishap, only trifling delays having been experienced during the entire voyage.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The President has granted pardons in the cases of Nathan Blum of Oregon, who pleaded guilty of smuggling; Charlie C. Rose of West Virginia, sentenced to five years in West Virginia Reform School for passing counterfeit money, and F.M. Salisbury of Oregon, sentenced in January, 1896, to $300 fine for using a penalty envelope to avoid paying postage.

A number of the members of the Society of Colonial Wars and the Sons of the American Revolution met last night at the Hotel Endicott, Eighty-first Street and Columbus Avenue, and formed an organization to be known as the Order of Colonial Founders and Revolutionary Patriots. John Quincy Adams presided.
The library of J.J. Peoli of New-York, comprising works in various modern languages, chiefly on art, was sold at auction yesterday by Bangs Co. Some of the works and prices were:

Gen. Wesley Merritt, commander of the United States Army in the Department of the Northwest, is at the Waldorf. He denied yesterday that he had been called to Washington by the President to recive instructions to visit Cuba and investigate and report upon the progress of the rebellion. In regard to the situation there he said:

Controller Fitch wrote to President Silas C. Croft of the Charities Department on March 5, calling his attention to a statement by the New-York Civil Service Board concerning certain appointments and increases of salary appearing upon the department's pay rolls for February.

Copyright, 1896, by Eacheller, Johnson Bacheller] PART I. Capt. Poison sat in his comfortable parlor Smiling benignly upon his daughter and sister His ship, after an absence of eighteen months, was onre more berthed in the small harbor of Sunset Bay, and the Captain was sitting in that state of goodnatured affability which invariably characterized his first appearance after a long absence.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I. March 9. -- There were startling developments this afternoon In the search for the murderers of Stephen Powell, who was found dying in the street a few feet from his own home late Saturday night.

Hockey as it is played in Canada will be exemplified at the Ice Palace, One Hundred and Seventh Street and Lexington Avenue, this evening, when the Montreal and Shamrock Clubs will play a match in that very vigorous fashion for which they are famous.

A goodly number of the members of the New-York Association for the Protection of Game sat down to a dinner in the Gerlach last night, and, prior to the routine of a regular monthly meeting, discussed fish, birds, and other things that all good sportsmen like to hunt and eat in their proper season.

On the unfounded assumption that the people of this State do not understand his liquor-tax bill, Senator RAINES has taken occasion to put forth an explanation of the measure, which is evidently intended as a defense. His statement consists chiefly of a summary of the provisions of the bill, which is meant to put them in a favorable light, but it does not succeed.

ALBANY, March 9. -- Bills which, if passed, would authorize the New-York City Board of Estimate and Apportionment to issue bonds to the amount of almost $20,000,000, are now pending in the Legislature. Some of them will not come out of the committee room; others will be reported with greatly reduced figures.

Ex-Senator MANDERSON of Nebraska is industriously cultivating an impression that he is a candidate of some promise for the nomination at St. Louis. He informs the public that neither McKINLEY nor REED can obtain a majority of the delegates' votes, and that the convention must take a Western man.

The ebullitions of popular sentiment that have occurred within the last week in Italy and in Spain seem to indicate that the "Latin races" are by no means so capable of self-government as the Teutonic, and that the political institutions which will fit one will not fit the other.

It was reported four or five weeks ago by The Philadelphia Press, a newspaper which holds that the present tariff duty of $7.84 per ton on steel rails is too low, that American manufacturers of steel rails had, within a few clays, been successful in overcoming the competition of English and German bidders with respect to an order for 12,000 tons of rails to be used in Chile.

ALBANY, March 9. -- The leaders came to a pretty definite agreement to-night on a programme which they think will send the Raines bill through both Houses flying. The Greater New-York bill is to go on the same swift wings.

Opposition to the bills introduced in the Assembly by Mr. Austin and in the Senate by Mr. Pavey limiting the height of buildings in City of New-York took tangible shape yesterday when two meetings were held of representatives of the interests immediately affected. The meetings were informal.

LONDON, March 9. -- The House resumed the discussion of the naval estimates on the vote for more men. John Dillon, the leader of the anti-Parnellites, and William Redmond, both contended that the naval proposals were intended as a menace to the United States, and for that reason every Irishman would oppose, them.

Mayor Strong has organized the heads of the city departments into a Cabinet, which will meet every Monday afternoon in the Mayor's office, at least until the Legislature shall have completed its business and adjourned for the year.

The City Club held a public meeting at its clubhouse in Fifth Avenue last night, and discussed the consolidation schemes now pending before the Legislature. In the absence of the President and Vice President, Joseph Larocque presided.
Sir Donald A. and Lady Smith of Montreal are at the Windsor Hotel, where they will remain for a few days. Sir Donald has received many honors from the Crown and from Canada, his adopted country.

The upper galleries of the American Art Association, on Twenty-third Street, (Madison Square South,) are quite filled with a collection of rare lacquers, kakemonas, prints, porcelains, bronzes, embroideries, ivory carvings, sword hilts, and other Oriental stuff of an artistic nature, rare of its kind, not too often finding its way into the auction rooms of this city.

Primrose and West's Minstrels celebrated their twenty-fifth anniversary at Madison Square Garden last night. A number of prominent theatrical managers and stage celebrities were in the boxes. The pit and the three large balconies were comfortably filled. The stage was in the north end of the arena.

HAVANA, March 9. -- Merchants, political leaders, and citizens generally have signed remonstrances against the action of the American Congrress in the matter of acknowledging the rebels as belligerents, and also against the speeches delivered in the Senate regarding Capt. Gen. Weyler.

Pedro Jose Rajas of Caracas, Inspector of Customs of Venezuela and nephew of the Minister of Foreign Affairs, is at the Waldorf, in this city. He is attending to Governmental business and will be here for several days. He spoke about the Venezuelan difficulty last evening to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES.
BROCKVILLE, Ontario, March 9. -- Ten persons were shot, one being instantly killed, at noon to-day on one of the principal streets of the town. The shooter evidently was a maniac. His victims were:

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., March 9. -- Robert Lantier, keeper of a restaurant on Borden Avenue, this city, believes that the murderers of Mr. Powell were in his restaurant early on Sunday morning. Lantier's place is about a block and a half from the Long Island Railroad Station. He says that two men, one colored and the other white, entered his place between 7:30 and 8 o'clock and ordered breakfast.

The second week of Mr. Waller Damrosch's season of grand opera in German began last night at the Academy of Music. The opera presented for the public delectation was Wagner's popular work "Tannhauser," which even Frenchmen liked when they first heard it, though the gentlemen of The Jockey Club tried to make it appear that they did not.

Thirty or so portraits by Charles Frederick Naegele are shown at the gallery of the Salmagundi Club, where they will remain on view until the 21st of the month. The collection is one reflecting credit on the painter, and the show will doubtless be much enjoyed by those who are fortunate enough to possess the "open sesame" to the doors of this organization.

Dissensions which have spoiled all plans for business at the new Mining Exchange, 35 Broadway, took a sharp turn yesterday, when George V. Sims, one of the promoters of the Exchange, was repudiated by his fellow-Directors. The brokers, to whom the action of the Directors was reported, passed a resolution depriving Mr. Sims of the office of Director, and intimating that action more severe might follow.

BOSTON, March 9. -- The British iron ship Bangalore of London, which arrived to-day from Java with a cargo of sugar in baskets, consigned to the American Sugar Refining Company, completed a most eventful passage.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

PERRY, Oklahoma, March 9. -- A month ago two outlaws, "Gen." Miller and James Harbolt, went to the house of Sheriff W. W. Glover of Day County, Oklahoma, and ordered meals. They were heavily armed, and Mrs. Glover, through fear, prepared a meal. Before it was finished, Sheriff Glover came in and recognized the men as persons for whom he had warrants, and for whose capture a large reward was offered.

Brooklyn clubmen are to a man opposed to the Raines bill, and last week there was a meeting of the Presidents of the various organizations in the Germania Club, when the bill was thoroughly discussed.

Frederick W. Dunton, the promoter, formerly President of the Bank of Jamaica, L. I., had a hearing yesterday before Police Magistrate Leroy B. Crane on the charge of stealing $10,000 from the NewYork and Brooklyn Suburban Investment Company of New-York during the time he was President of that corporation.

A special meeting of the Yacht Racing Union of Long Island Sound was held last night at the Firth Avenue Hotel. The meeting was called to receive reports from the council to adopt racing rules and arrange a schedule for yacht races on the Sound this Summer.

Darius Lyon. ex-Sheriff of Westchester County, died yesterday at the home of his son, Addison J. Lyon, in Mount Vernon, N. Y. His death was unexpected, though he had been failing rapidly for several days. Mr. Lyon was seventyfour years old.

If a large number of good. sturdy candidates and a faithful Captain are any criterion for the success of an athletic team, it is altogether probable that University will be well represented upon the track this Spring. For almost a month now sixty-seven athletes have been undergoing a course of moderate training, under the direction of Capt. William Fearing, in the gymnasium of the New Manhattan Athletic Club.

CHICAGO, March 9. -- Gen. J.S. Clarkson of Iowa is in the city on his way to Des Moines to attend the Iowa Republican State Convention Wednesday. He professes to be confident that Allison's chance of securing the Presidential nomination increases every day.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- Southwestern roads which have been making exceptionally low rates on grain from Missouri River points to the Gulf ports, thereby diverting the traffic from the regular channel, via Chicago, to New-York, have struck a snag that may compel them to either advance the rates to Gulf ports or reduce all rates from interior points in Kansas.

The first series of games in the bowling tournament of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs since the shifting of the teams in the merit column by the Executive Committee was rolled last evening at Reid's alleys, in Church Street. There was a noticeable lack of eminent "rooters" in the gallery seats, yet the games were well played and interesting.

STAPLETON, S.J., March 10 -- Miss Mamie Hagaman and Frederick H. Trapp, who came here about a year ago, were to have been married yesterday, but the marriage did not occur. Miss Hagaman is a daughter of August Hagaman, engineer at the Dejonge paper factory. She is about eighteen years old, and has been an active member of the Kingsley Methodist Episopal Church, and of the Epworth League connected with the church, for years.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 14 -- The reported successes of Kaffir corn in Kansas during the past two unusually dry seasons, when in at least one-third of the State little or no Indian corn reached any degree of maturity, have caused a flood of inquiry, not alone from adjacent States, but as far east as New-York, and even from distant countries and isles.

From The New-Orleans Times-Democrat. The present strained relations between the United States and Spain in regard to the Cuban matters and the recent attack on the United States representative in Barcelona by an infuriated mob recall another instance of like character in which the conditions were reversed and the Spanish Consul was attacked.

ALBANY, March 10 -- The Republican Assemblymen met in caucus to-night and finding they had votes enough to pass the Raines Liquor bill, clamped on the muzzle and decided to drive the measure through their branch of the Legislature. Seventy-five of the 103 members of the majority attended the caucus.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 10 -- The funeral of Stephen Powell, who was murdered near his home, in this village, Saturday night, was held at 3 o'clock this afternoon at the house of the deceased. Representative citizens of the place and many persons drawn thither by curiosity were present at the funeral services.

Yale is a university in the full sense of that term, with about 2,500 students ranging in age from seventeen to twenty-three years, with half a dozen Faculties, including medicine, law, theology, the applied sciences, fine arts, and music. She draws her matriculants from every State in the Union, and is in every other respect representative of our country.

The death of James H. McVicker, the veteran Chicago manager, may have some important effects on the theatrical business of this city. Horace McVicker, his only son, now in Chicago attending the funeral, is the manager of Abbey's Theatre here. For a long time Horace McVicker and his father were not on the best of terms, and that was the reason why the son left Chicago and came to New-York to make his home.

Thug rule was introduced last night by Sheriff Buttling of Kings County in the deliberations of the Republican County Committee, which were held in the Johnston Building, at Flatbush Avenue and Nevins Street, and in the character of leading man in the comedy of Republican politics, he outdid " I McGarry," and created the greatest row that has been known in Republican circles in many years.

ALBANY, March 10 -- State Superintendent of Insurance James F. Pierce will to-morrow transmit to the Legislature his report on the condition of the fire and marine insurance companies transacting business in this State for the year ending Dec. 31 last. The aggregate assets on that day were $183,875,200, classified as follows: New-York joint stock companies, $65,736,617; joint stock companies of other States, $115,475,458; New-York mutuals, $2,019,604; mutuals of other States, $643,519.

A meeting of the Salvation Army was held last night at the headquarters in West Fourteenth Street, at which Commissioner Eva Booth presided. The meeting was private, in so far as none but soldiers of the Salvation Army were permitted to be present.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

The present age certainly inclines to echo the well-known stanza: "A little learning is a dangerous thing; Drink deep, or taste not the Pierian spring. There shallow draughts intoxicate the brain, And drinking largely sobers us again." The series to which the present book belongs only exemplifies the spirit of the time, the love of accurate information drawn from authoritative sources.

The vicinity elections on Tuesday show Democratic gains. This is not extraordinary, but it is significant. The only Republican victory of note was at Niagara Falls. The result was the outcome of Democratic dissensions. It was not essentially a Republican victory at all. In Hornellsville a Democratic Mayor succeeds a Republican Mayor.

The project of erecting a monument to HEINE came yesterday to what appears to be the end of it, but in a manner that cannot be completely satisfactory to anybody concerned or interested. It expired, so to speak, in the arms of victory. The Aldermen accepted it on behalf of the city by a vote of nearly five to one.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 10 -- The old propeller John L. Hasbrouck, which has laid on Lime Dock Reef at New-Hamburg, up the Hudson, Since last Thursday morning, with two or three big holes in her bottom, has been in the freight and passenger service on the Hudson River since 1864.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 10.-- Charles A. Dana spoke at the rooms of the New-Haven Colony Historical Society to-night. His subject was " Lincoln and His Cabinet." Mr. Dana narrated many hitherto unpublished incidents of the history of the Lincoln Administration, relating them as seen by him when Assistant Secretary of War.

PATERSON, N.J., March 10 -- The police are to-night working on a new theory as to the murder of Mary E. Sullivan, and they say it is a very promising one. They believe that the murder was carefully planned, and was the result of deliberation, but the purpose of the murderer miscarried because he mistook Miss Sullivan for another woman.

ROME, March 10 -- The Prime Minister, Marquis di Rudini, has telegraphed to Gen. Baldissera, commander of the Italian Army in Abyssinia, giving him assurance that he will be furnished with all the troops that may be necessary to prosecute the campaign in Africa to a successful issue.

There was an exhibition of subserviency to a party boss in the Senate at Albany yesterday which is without a parallel in the history of legislation in this State, and it is generally expected that it will be repeated in the Assembly before the week ends. Then we shall soon see whether Gov. MORTON is prepared in his single person to make a similar exhibition.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- New-York Biscuit and Diamond Match stocks continue to lead in activity. The general market remains dull. Ally I was strong on the supposition that the stockholders will be allowed to come in under the reorganization by payment of an assessment. The brewery situation remains unchanged.

There was nothing of importance on the social calendar yesterday, and there will not be much of special interest to-day. The Knickerboker Bowling Club will meet this afternoon, and there will be several small musical teas. At the Hotel Brunswick tonight there will be a subscription dance arranged by several people of prominence in what is known as the literary set.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Shelby M. Cullom, United States Senator from Illinois, is having trouble in keeping his Presidential boom on the track. Several times since it was started the rails have spread through the machinations of his political foes, and he has been obliged to rescue the boom from the ditch.

ORANGE, N.J., March 10 -- The Essex County Park Commission is still quietly at work acquiring land and laying its plans for the establishment of the proposed system of parks and boulevards, although it is conducting almost all its transactions through its authorized agents, whose identity is carefully obscured in order to prevent land sharks and speculators from getting possession of the land desired.

OSHKOSH, Wis., March 10 -- Ex-Senator Philetus Sawyer has arrived from Washington to attend to some lawsuits which are to be tried at the present term of court. It is said that a friend met ex-Gov. W.D. Hoard, who has been supposed to be a candidate for United States Senator to succeed W.F. Vilas, and in Sawyer's behalf questioned him directly as to his intentions.

Those whom a pleasantly formal invitation, printed in script of civility, admitted to the Madison Square ballroom last night saw the twentieth annual festival of the Mardi-Gras Association, brighter than its nineteen preceding festivals, scintillate in a pell-mell of silks, satins, colors, metals, tinsel, powdered wigs, and flying scarfs.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 10 -- The Canadian Republican Committee has issued a manifesto addressed to the Canadian people and declaring that the time has come to change from a degrading colonial dependency to a free, prosperous, and independent Canadian republic. Thousands of copies, printed in French and English, have been distributed from this city.

TRENTON, N.J., March 10 -- Senator Lewis Emery, of Pennsylvania, with several representatives of the United States Pipe Line Company, appeared before the Senate Committee on Railroads and Canals this afternoon, to urge the passage of Senate Bill 138, which, it was held, would break the Standard Oil monopoly by giving the United States Company the right to compete with the Standard.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 10.-- The Republican State Convention to nominate a State ticket was held here to-day. Ex-Adjt. Gen. Elisha Dyer was Chairman of the convention.

Frederick W. Dunton, the promoter and formerly President of the Bank of Jamaica. L.I., was yesterday held by Police Magistrate Crane in $2,500 bonds on each of the two charges of grand larceny preferred against him by George E. Hagerman, President of the New-York and Brooklyn Suburban Investment Company of New-York.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 10 -- The Wisconsin Authors' Convention opened this morning at 10 o'clock in the Ethical Building. The hall was prettily decorated with palms, and the stage, with its background of palms, was occupied by members of the Executive, Reception, and Entertainment Committees.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Everybody was ready for the battle over the Raines bill when the Senate met at 10 o'clock. Hostilities were not long delayed. Even the customary prayer was omitted, and as soon as Lieut. Gov. Saxton had called the body to order, Mr. Ellsworth offered a cloture rule to apply during the consideration of the bill.

A letter inviting Frederick MacMonnies, the sculptor, to exccute a bronze or marble statue or bust of the late Gen. John B. Woodward will be sent to Paris to-day by George M. Olcott, Elijah R. Kennedy, ana Prof. Franklin W. Hooper, who were delegated to do so Monday night by a number of Gen. Woodward's Brooklyn friends.

Cuban affairs cut a wide swath yesterday. While Senators at Washington were talking on the conduct of Dupuy de Lome Cubans in this city were paying their addresses to Senator Hale for his speech of the preceding day. There was great elation at the Cuban Junta late in the afternoon over a report, subsequently learned to be unfounded, that the Senate had requested that the Spanish Minister be presented with his passport.

A wealthy broker of West Philadelphia had a rather singular experience the other day. He and his family have had in their possession for a number of years some very handsome opals, but the superstition which was formerly entertained concerning the stone's being unlucky prevented him from making use of the gems.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 10 -- George R. Perry of North Sixth and Lincoln Avenues, who was thrown from his carriage by a collision with a Union Railroad trolley car at William's Bridge Monday afternoon, died at his home the following night from his injuries.

Justice MacLean in Part I of the Supreme Court yesterday heard the arguments in the mandamus suit brought by the Commissioners of Charities to compel the Board of Managers of the Manhattan State Hospital to accept insane patients from Bellevue Hospital who had been refused admittance because they were not supplied with new clothing.

Fourteen pictures, views of the Cathedral at Rouen, France, under different aspects of light, are shown at the American Art Galleries. They are by Claude Monet, the present head of the Impressionistic movement in Paris, and they have received great attention from the critics in that city, eliciting from the man's admirers much praise and from others a due measure of respect.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 10 -- There is a rumor here that Major McKinley has promised that he will give the post of Secretary of War to Gov. W.H. Upham of this State in case he shall be elected President.
To the Editor of The New-York Times: The events of the past half-year have forced on the attention of our people the imperative need for a system of defense against possible foreign foes.
In submitting his annual report of the operation of the Missouri Pacific Railway system for the year ended Dec. 31, 1895, President Gould says:

The Montreal and Shamrock hockey teams came here last evening to play an exhibition game for a trophy offered by the managers of the Ice Palace, on Lexington Avenue. After two very sharply played halves of twenty minutes, the game was drawn, each team having scored a single goal. After a consultation with Manager Falk, the teams agreed to stay over a day longer, and to play off the tie to-night at 8 o'clock.

There was what was called a joint debate by Republicans of the Sixteenth Election District of the Twenty-first Assembly District last night, at 141 West Ninety-ninth Street. The subject was "All That is Good and Bad in the Politics of the Day."

ALBANY, March 10 -- The Rev. Dr. Richard S. Storrs of Brooklyn has written a lengthy letter to Lieut. Gov. Saxton, in which he takes a decided stand against the consolidation of Brooklyn with New-York City. Dr. Storrs writes:
ALBANY, March 10 -- A big delegation of Buffalonians, numbering 119, marshaled by City Treasurer Philip Gerst and Emory P. Close, met Gov. Morton by appointment in the Executive Chamber to-day.

Capt. M.V. Bates, whose remarkable height at one time attracted the attention of the world, has recently retired from his conspicuous position and lives in comparative obscurity on his farm in Guilford, Medina County, Ohio, half a mile east of Seville.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The bill incorporating the National University of the United States was to-day favorably reported to the Senate. It grants a charter to the university, provides for its government, grants it the ground in the City of Washington designated by President Washington as a site for a National University, and appropriates $15,000 for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1897, and $25,000 for the year following.

MADRID, March 10 -- A dispatch to The Imparcial from Havana says that the rebels under Gomez and Maceo are advancing toward Havana. From the position of the Spanish troops a serious conflict is expected.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The reiteration in London journals that negotiations are in progress between the British Ambassador and the Venezuelan Minister at Washington to dispose of the Uruan incident has again received an unqualified denial from both diplomats concerned.
MADRID, March 10.-- The Government is making preparations to enlist volunteers for home defense.

Dinshar Pestonjee Ghadially, known in India as the " Parsee Edison," late electrician to his Highness Maharaj Rana Sahib of Dholpur, Central India, and also late Telephone Superintendent of Dholpur State, is in this city on a tour of the world.

TUESDAY -- P.M. Speculation to-day was narrow and almost entirely professional. The heavy trading in Tobacco rather overshadowed the rest of the market. There was apparently no reason for the marked strength developed in the stock in the afternoon, as on the conditions on which it has been sold down from 82 still exist, many of them in an aggravates form.
" Did you know that a surprisingly large percentage of persons all over the world are walking on American feet? There were five at least sent from this city yesterday."
ALBANY, March 10 -- Speaker Fish was one of the spectators of the closing incidents in to-day's fight in the Senate on the Raines bill. He had had trouble of his own all the long day.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 10 -- The significance of the address which was presented to Gen. Weyler by the citizens of Havana, protesting against the action of Congress, and which has just been received here, appears to be greater than has been appreciated, as the signatures give it every appearance of representing citizens of high standing in Cuba.

The opinion which Corporation Counsel Burr of Brooklyn gave Monday, covering the application of the civil service laws in the Department of City Works was not altogether satisfactory to persons interested in the civil service in that city.

WASHINGTON, March. 10 -- The House Committee on Naval Affairs still has under consideration the Naval Appropriation bill. While the measure has not been completed, enough of its provisions are known to give an abstract of it approximating the shape in which. It will be presented to the House.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 10 -- The most notable feature of the short session of the Republican State Convention to-day was the speech of Senator-elect Foraker, in which he declared his allegiance to McKinley with characteristic vigor.

SYNOPSIS. Capt. Poison, returning from a cruise of eighteen months, finds that his daughter Chrissie during his absence, has become engaged to "Jack" Metcalfe, a smart young lawyer, who had once worsted him in a lawsuit. The bans are about to be called for the third time. The Captain stops the bans, and decides to take Chrissie away for a year's cruise.

ALBANY, March 10 -- The Senate has passed the Raines liquor bill. Unshorn of the iniquities with which it has been crowded, assailed on all sides, both within and without the party, abhorred by many who voted for it, because they dared not disobey the party boss, the measure was carried through this afternoon by a vote of 31 to 18.

The Dime Savings Bank in Willimantic, Conn., is in the hands of Receivers. The bank was closed on April 22, 1895, and in the following July the Treasurer, JOHN L. WALDEN, ran away. A report published in The Hartford Courant on Monday last shows a remarkable condition of affairs.

Yesterday was a big day for the auction rooms where real estate is sold. Not in several years were as many different pieces of property offered. Forty-nine parcels in all were scheduled for sale. The interest taken in the sales was also something out of the common. The room at 111 Broadway was so thronged at noon that it was well-nigh impossible for a person to move in it.

Charles Stern, calling himself a banker and broker, has been missing from his office, at 66 Canal Street, since last Thursday. The banking firm of Knauth, Nachod Kuhne attached his account yesterday in the State Bank, in Canal Street. He had left $17 there, which is $1,000 less than Stern owed that firm, for Austrian florins bought a week ago.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Returns from the township, county, and State correspondents of the Agricultural Department indicate as the amount of corn yet held by farmers 49.8 per cent, on the total crop, or 1,072,000,000 bushels. The proportion and total farm reserves are both unprecedented.

The following arrangement has been agreed upon between the representatives of Rutgers College and the New-York University, concerning the games between the Athletic Associations of both, colleges. The games this year will be held in New-York University grounds on Friday, May 22. It is proposed not to have medals as prizes, but to substitute ribbons and a banner.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10 -- Apathy prevailed to-day and fluctuations were narrow. Pennsylvania Heat issues lost fractions. Schuylkill River East Side 5s sold at 90 1/2, against 110 before the Baltimore and Ohio receivership. Money continues still. New-York exchange is heavy.
The Board of Aldermen decided yesterday, by a vote of twenty-three to five, that they would empower Commissioner Haffen of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards to accept the Heine Fountain.

LONDON, March 10 -- Dr. Jameson and the officers who accompanied him in the Transvaal raid were again arraigned in the Bow Street Police Court this morning, and the charges against them were renewed. Major Coventry and Capt. Gosling wore added to the list of accused. The courtroom was crowded with members of the aristocracy, among whom were the Duke of Abercorn, the Earl and Countess of Coventry, and Lady Annaly.

ALBANY, March 10 -- The Greater New-York bill was the special order in the House to-day. After the title of the bill had been read, Chairman Austin of the Cities Committee offered amendments making the bill conform with the Senate bill by requiring the appointment as Commissioners of people who are residents of the territory affected; requiring reports by the commission in February, 1897, and that the commission go out of existence in March, 1897.

Some of the mystery surrounding the proceedings before the Grand Jury a week ago, when it was reported that many indictments had been found in connection with alleged fraudulent charters of Lloyds fire insurance companies, came to an end yesterday afternoon, when detectives arrested Graham McAdam, a lawyer, of 140 Nassau Street, in the neighborhood of Washington Market.

TARRYTOWN, March 10 -- William S. Daniell, eighten years old, of this place, and Miss Elizabeth Rock, sixteen years old, of New York, were married this afternoon at the Daniell home here by the Rev. J. Feldon Spencer, of Christ Episcopal Church.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 10 -- The Court of Appeals to-day, in the case of ex-Police Captain Michael Doherty of New-York City, and his wardmen, Bernard Meehan and John Hock, affirmed, with costs, the orders of the General Term of the Supreme Court.

Henry HOWE. Henry Howe, who was found dead in bed in Cincinnati Monday, had the distinction of being known to London playgoers as "the father of the English stage." He was in his eighty-fourth year, and had been on the stage for over sixty years. Forty years of his stage life were passed in one theatre.

LONDON, March 10 -- A representative of The United Press obtained an interview this morning with Gen. Booth, commander of the Salvation Army, who has just arrived in London from India. Gen. Booth said he was busily considering the policy of the army in America, but had not as yet been able to formulate a statement on the subject.

Perhaps the most distinguished party of tourists the Brown Palace Hotel ever gave shelter to registered there yesterday afternoon. All of its members did not register, for one -- and he the most distinguished of them all, in his way -- cannot form a letter of the alphabet, let alone write his name. The illiterate traveler is a fox terrier, far advanced in years, and suffering from phthisis in its last stages.

The rioting in the Island of St. Kitt's is no more than might have been expected from the economic condition of the island, a condition which it shares with all the West Indies of which sugar is the staple product. It is not to be disputed that the raising of cane sugar is no longer profitable.

There was a crowded attendance at the morning call at the new Mining Exchange yesterday. The storm Monday seemed to have cleared the air. Brokers were in high spirits, and trading began in livelier fashion than at any time since Sims, Beers Co.'s Manhattan stock tumbled from 30 to 1. Mr. Sims did not visit the floor.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 10 -- An overcast sky and a keen air greeted the members of the Ocean County Hunt and Country Club when they gathered this afternoon at the Laurel-in-the-Pines for the first of the three runs planned for this week. The grounds of the hotel were thickly dotted with spectators, while a large number of carriages were in readiness to follow the chase.
CHICAGO, March 10 -- The earnings of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad for the first week of March were $590,565; for the same period last year, $203,283; increase $87,282.
"An actor's lot is a hard one, and ingratitude is his portion," said a well-known member of "the profession" in Manager Walter Sanford's office in the Star Theatre.

In the annual report of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, for 1895, just issued Dr. W.H. Tolman, the general agent, regards the general outlook as encouraging. The income of the association, including a balance of $6,806,34, was $101,458.55. The expenses amounted to $95,333.61, leaving a balance on hand Oct. 1, 1895, of $6,124.94.

"During the present Lenten season we have had more than forty species of fish on the market," Eugene G. Blackford of Fulton Market said yesterday to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES. "The salmon come all the way from Puget Sound, in boxes holding 200 pounds each. They are shipped in ice in refrigerator cars.

It is impossible for foreign observers to draw any trustworthy conclusions from the composition of the new Ministry which the Marquis DI RUDINI has had so much trouble in forming. They arc new men to the world, outside of Italy at least. Not one of RUDINI'S present colleagues served with him in his last Ministry.

BALTIMORE, March 10 -- A most remarkable condition of affairs -- unique, if not unprecedented in the municipal history of this country -- is presented in Baltimore's City Hall. The revolutionary action of the City Council last night, in taking from the Mayor practically all his power and overturning the machinery of the City Government, has caused chaos and confusion and excited citizens as no other movement has done for many years.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., March 10 -- Lawrence McEntee, thirty-eight years old, of 77 Grand Avenue, Astoria, is held in default of $2,000 bonds on a charge of having assaulted with his fists two young women on the street in Astoria last evening. He was arrested last night and was arraigned this morning. The trial was postponed until Thursday.

Teheran Dispatch in London News. At a time when the treatment of Christians in Turkey forms a subject of European concern, it will perhaps be of some interest to inquire into the condition of Christians in a neighboring country.
ALBANY, March 11 -- The Raines Excise bill was handed down to the Assembly today from the Senate. It was referred to the Excise Committee.

The "Hotel White" opened its doors to the public last night, and by 9 o'clock a man was asleep in every one of its 100 beds. It would be more correct to say that the hotel opened its portholes, for the "Hotel White" is the old excursion steamer which Commissioner of Charities John P. Faure has transformed into a clean, cozy, and comfortable lodging house for homeless men.

T is a fact not generally known, outside strictly scientific circles at least, that there exists an element (technically called hydropyrogen, symbol Hp,) possessing qualities of such a nature that its more abundant production, or any recklessness in use, might imperil the human race.

Island is a State in which the Republican delegates to St. Louis are bound to support the nomination of Mr. T.B. REED as long as there is any-chance of his success, and if that prove impossible, the votes of these delegates will be disposed of "where they will do the most good" in furthering any minor ambition that the Speaker may be compelled to fall back upon.

Lieut. William Babcock, executive officer of the United States steamship Michigan, died at the University Club, Twenty-sixth Street and Madison Avenue, last evening, after an illness of ten days. He contracted pneumonia while doing compass duty at Washington. After arriving at the University Club he gradually grew worse.

It is the purpose of those who control the Republican machine, under the orders of Boss PLATT, to jam the Raines bill through the Assembly to-day, and take another step in the perpetration of the outrage of which the first step was taken in the Senate on Tuesday. Such is the caucus decree.

The storm yesterday was not a blizzard, though it came at a time that recalled the terrible blizzard of 1888. Officials of the Weather Bureau termed it a cyclonic storm, and a very big one. Blizzards cover only a narrow strip of territory. The storm yesterday covered an area of 2,400 miles diameter.

There was a meeting of the Executive Council of the American Bankers' Association at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday to arrange for the annual convention of the association and to attend to other executive business. St. Louis, Duluth, San Antonio, Texas, and Springfield, Ill., were considered for convention purposes.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Judge J.I. Hall, Assistant Attorney General for the Department of the Interior, has resigned. Judge Hall is a Georgian, and will return to that State to take the post of General Attorney for the Georgia Southern and Florida Railroad.

WEDNESDAY -- P.M. All interest centred in American Tobacco to-day. Fifty thousand shares were done in the first twenty minutes, and the stock continued active all day with the exception of brief intervals. The best price was made shortly after noon, and although the stock reacted sharply in the afternoon it closed with a net gain of 3 7/ points, the final price being 78 3/8.

BOSTON, March 11 -- President Choate of the Old Colony, who is also a Director of the New-Haven Railroad Company, says: "The report that the Old Colony and the New-Haven Roads contemplate an expenditure of $15,000,000 in improvements during the coming two or three years is ridiculously absurd, and I authorize a denial of the report.

NEWARK, N.J., March 11 -- Major J.W. Wham, an old soldier in Gen. (then Col.) Grant's first regiment, delivered an interesting lecture in the First Reformed Church of Newark to-night, in which he told some new stories and incidents about the great General. The lecturer spoke under the auspices of Marcus T. Ward Post, No. 88, Department of New-Jersey, G.A.R.

RIVERHEAD, N.Y., March 11 -- Louis A. Chandler, a New-York lawyer, visited Riverhead to-day to see a prisoner in the county jail who had personated him, and caused a warrant to be issued for the lawyer's arrest. Chandler identified the fellow as C. Carroll Upham, a former resident of Woodstock, Conn., and a graduate of the Polytechnic Institute.

LONG ISLAND CITY, March 11.-- Detective James Sarvis of the Long Island Railroad arrested James Conlon of Deer Park to-day on a charge of attempting to wreck a train near that village last Friday evening. Conlon was formerly a section boss in the employ of the railroad, but was discharged some time ago because he was thought to be irresponsible.

Controller Fitch is withholding from payment pending an investigaton several bills for furniture, carpets, and oilcloths submitted by Frank D. Croft, who is in business at One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street near Madison Avenue. Mr. Croft is a brother of Silas C. Croft, who is President of the Department of Charities.

The spluttering effort of Senator LEXOW to call Lieut. Gov. SAXTON to account for expressing his opinion upon the Greater New-York question, in reply to a letter from, the Rev. Dr. STORRS, was a rather unseemly performance. This expression of opinion cannot be regarded as an attempt to influence legislation in any improper sense of the term.
PROVIDENCE, March 11 -- The Democratic State Convention was held to-day. Richard P. Comstock was elected Chairman of the convention, and, in accepting the place, spoke as follows:

TRENTON, N.J., March 11 -- The Republicans captured every office in Princeton yesterday. In Red Bank the Democrats and Republicans divided the four places. In Long Branch the Democrats took all but one of the offices.

ALBANY March 11 -- Senator parsons of Rochester to-day introduced a bill to regulate the use of bicycles, tricycles, and similar vehicles, and to require uniformity of ordinances affecting the same. It is almost identically the same law that has been passed in New-Jersey. The bill was referred to the Committeeo on Roads and Bridges.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 11 -- The Republican State Convention, to-day was a rather dreary affair. The main object for which it had met -- that of advancing the Presidential interests of Major McKinley -- had been accomplished yesterday when Senator-elect Foraker, on being elected Chairman, had made a speech cordially indorsing the candidacy of the protection apostle.
Two reckless drivers were arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday as prisoners of a bicycle policeman, and were fined $3 each by Magistrate Flammer.

The most notable of yesterday's sales at auction was that of the Osborne apartment house, at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street. This property was offered by Mr. Richard V. Harnett at the Exchange Salesroom in liberty Street by order of the heirs of John Taylor.

-- The engagement is announced of Miss Josephine Frame Mott, the eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Pentland Mott, to William Holden Muir, the only son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton T. Muir of Boston. The announcement comes by letter from Paris, where the Motts have been spending several months.

Cubans and Cuban sympathizers were surprised yesterday when they learned that the Federal Grand Jury had indicted Gen. Calixto Garcia, Benjamin, G. Guerra, Bernardo J. Bueno, Capt. Samuel Hughes, Capt. John Brabazon, and John D. Hart for violation of the neutrality laws.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 -- L.W. Adams of San Jose, who for a year past has been General Manager of the New-York and British Guiana Gold Mining Company, in Guiana, is in the city. He has just returned from that wild country bordering on Venezuela, and he tells a story full of interest.

A proposition to unite commercial bodies in an appeal to Congress to adjourn and let business have a chance was submitted at the monthly meeting of the Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday, and found instant favor. It came from Edward D. Depew of Wright, Depew Co., wholesale grocers at 103 Murray Street, in a letter to Darwin R. James.

More of Daniel Levy's love letters to Mrs. Harriet Lehman were read yesterday when the trial to detetmine Levy's mental condition was resumed before Justice Bischoff and a jury in Part IX, of the Supreme Court. A letter written by Levy to Philip Lehman was read in which he wrote: "If it is your father's wish that two loving hearts should be united, send me the means to marry Harriet."

BOSTON, March 11 -- Local stocks were quiet. Bay State Gas advanced 1/2, to 10 7/8, and the 1st 5s were steady at 79 1/2. Boston and Maine lost 1/2, to 169, and recovered to 169 1/8. Mexican Central 4s were unchanged at 70, the 1st incomes were up 1/2, to 22, but the stock was down 1/4, to 11 1/2. New-Haven and Hartford was up 1/4, to 178.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 11 -- A heavy rain early in the morning made the grounds too wet to be played upon, so the men or the New-York baseball team put in their time to-day in the gymnasium and on the road. One party took a three-mile spin into the country and came back against a thirty-mile-an-hour wind. A wiser party ran into town.

DBS MOINES, Iowa, March 11 -- The Republican State Convention met in this city to-day to select delegates to the National Convention at St. Louis, and to formally inaugurate the candidacy of Senator William B. Allison of Iowa for President. The convention was one of the largest ever held in the State.

CHICAGO, March 11.-- New-York Biscuit and Diamond Match were somewhat heavy to-day, but the remainder of the market showed a better tone. Brewery shares were in demand. Bank clearings were $14,897,738. Money loaned at 6@7 per cent. on time, and 6 per cent. on call.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The House Committee on Ways and Means to-day ordered Mr. Payne of New-York to report favorably to the House a bill prepared by the committee amending the administrative features of the present tariff law.
The will of George Bliss was filed in the Surrogate's office yesterday for probate. The value of the estate is placed at several millions of dollars, although no specific sum is named.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 11 -- The unseating of Kaufman, Democrat, in the House, promptly followed by the unseating of Walton and James, Republicans, in the Senate, to-day, created the most intense excitement of the present turbulent session of the Legislature.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 11 -- The assignment of Rothschild. Baum Stern, one of the largest wholesale clothing firms in this city, was filed in the County Clerk's office this morning. Julius M. Wile is named as assignee. The liabilities are between $300,000 and $400,000. There are no preferred creditors.

ALBANY, March 11 -- When the H.T. Andrews bill for an additional Police Justice in New-York City came up on second reading in the House to-day, Mr. Butts moved to strike out the enacting clause. Both Mr. Andrews and Mr. Austin spoke in favor of the bill. It was necessary, they said, where the heavy criminal business in police courts made it almost compulsory upon the Legislature to increase the number of Justices.

We do not know that any one familiar with the political career of Mr. McKiNLET and the history of local campaigns in which he was interested as a candidate should be surprised by the published assertion that his agents have recently been using large sums of money in the canvass for convention delegates and have appealed to the protected manufacturers in Pennsylvania and other States for more money to be used in the same way.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service Is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

LONDON, March 11 -- The Daily Chronicle to-morrow will publish another of its series of articles attacking the Venezuelan Blue Book recently issued by the British Government, in which it will contend that the statements that the claim to territory in the interior is based upon the facts of possession and occupation by the Dutch in the eighteenth century are disproved by the very references to the documents cited.

The publication in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday of the results of the experiments of Nikola Tesla in radiography has excited a great deal of interest in the medical profession. His conclusions were to the effect that the X rays were of the nature of a stream of material particles which strike the sensitive plate with great velocities.

Graham McAdam, the lawyer who was arrested on two indictments charging grand larceny in the second degree, which were found on testimony relating to his dealings with Lloyd's fire insurance companies, was arraigned before Judge Newburger, in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions, yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS. N.Y., March 11 -- The committee of the Board of Supervisors of Westchester County engaged in investigating the accounts of ex-Superintendent of the Poor Miles Adams held another session to-day. The committee is composed of Supervisors Lane, Haviland, and Davenport, who were present.

Over a score of enthusiastic members of the military Order of Foreign Wars of the United States braved the wintry blasts, the snow, and sleet yesterday to assemble in the Governor's Room in the City Hall, and organize a National commandery of the order.

The steps taken by Secretary HERBERT to increase the coaling facilities of Key West by the appointment of a board to look after the subject are in accordance with the provisions made by Congress last year, when that body granted appropriations both for additional coal sheds and for a coaling pier.

The arraignment of Dr. JAMESON and his officers in a police court has evidently impressed the filibusters with the notion that they have been committing a grave offense. To bring this conviction home to them was in itself a matter of considerable difficulty and importance.
PEKIN, March 12. -- A contract has been signed with an Anglo-German syndicate for a new Chinese loan of u16,000.000 at 5 per cent. The lean is to be issued at 94.

SYNOPSIS. Prof. McKazy, a distinguished scientist, has discovered a new chemical agent, hydropyrogen, which has extraordinary and terrible, efficacy in decomposing and inflaming water. Its action is like that of a destructive ferment, and the fire is unquenchable until the last drop of liquid is consumed.

By deciding to take no action in regard to the expulsion of Lord DUNRAVEN from the New-York Yacht Club the English Racing Association preserves a sort of dignity, no doubt, but the pretended indifference to anything that may be done by American yachting men will deceive no one and will be extremely hard to preserve.

There was a melancholy exhibition of partisan tyranny and cowardice in the Assembly at Albany yesterday when the Raines bill was "jammed through" that body. Republican members from the cities which are to be victimized were virtually put under duress and forced to act against their conviction of duty.
Four public lectures of more than ordinary interest were delivered at Columbia University yesterday afternoon and evening.

The Rev. James A. Weston, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, at Hickory, N.C., who lately wrote a carefully prepared work on "Historic Doubts as to the Execution of Marshal Ney," has informed his publisher. Thomas Whittaker of this city, that the theory that Ney was not killed on the day he is supposed to have been shot in France, on Dec. 7, 1815, has been still further confirmed by recent researches.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The conspiracy of the silver Senators in the Senate at Washington to provoke a war with Great Britain, Spain, or some other power, in order to put this country's finances on a silver basis, which your paper this morning exposes, is information that should be scattered to every part of our land.

George Hartman is locked up at Police Headquarters. The police say he carried on swindling operations in various cities, and that there are eighty complaints against him. He appeared in Essex Market Police Court yesterday and was remanded. His victims are poor persons who hold life insurance policies.

"The effect of the death of James H. McVicker on the American Theatrical Syndicate," said Joseph Brooks yesterday, "will be nothing whatever, Mr. McVicker was not a member of the syndicate personally, but only as President of the McVicker Theatre Company, which, as a corporation, became interested in the scheme.

The troubles in Cuba have had no material, effect as yet on the tobacco market, though the prospect of a limited future supply and a scarcity in certain grades has had the effect of making the market firm. Indeed, the scarceness of factory Vegas has already led to the closing of several factories in Havana, while the difficulty of obtaining labor would seem to render uncertain the outcome as to the Vuelta and Partidos crops.

The corridor on the eleventh floor of the Manhattan Life Building was filled with a surging crowd of professional and amateur stamp collectors yesterday afternoon. They were in search of the Cuban headquarters, and in their mad rush to get an advantage they jostled everybody within reach.

The ranks of the Salvation Army were depleted yesterday by the resignations of two officers. The first resignation to reach headquarters was that of Staff Captain Pattie Watkins, who reorganized the Bowery corps and is known as the "Swedish Nightingale." The second was that of Adjt. Hartwright, who for nine years had been cashier at headquarters.
The snowstorm of Wednesday -- six and three-tenths inches fell on the level -- incommoded the traveling public and business men little yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., March 12. -- The House gave almost the entire time of its morning session to-day to a discussion of Mr. Walling's bill to reduce the salaries of all persons employed in the State who receive more than $3,000 per year. The proposed cut is to the extent of 25 per cent. on the amount of salary in excess of $3,000.

MADISON, Conn., March 12. -- An old-fashioned heresy trial over violations of the orthodox creed in the Congregational Church will take place here, beginning March 24, and probably lasting several days. The pastor of the Congregational Church, the Rev. William T. Brown, has been accused of heretical teaching by conservative members of the congregation, and a council of about a dozen neighboring churches has been summoned to deal with the matter.

At the meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday an application was received from the Rapid Transit Commissioners for $19,814.85 for running expenses. In connection with this matter Controller Fitch made the statement that if the underground rapid transit plan goes through, this city will lose its largest source of revenue from city railroads.
ROME, March 12. -- According to The Agenzla D'Italia 30,000 dervishes are investing Kassala, the town which was captured from them some time ago by the Italians.

-- Frank Hegger of 152 Broadway is publishing a series of large photographs of the principal architectural monuments of Europe, which have received praise from such critics as Russell Sturgis, President of the New-York Architectural league, and Prof. Charles H. Moore of Harvard University.

BOSTON, March 12 -- The Railroad Commissioners to-day authorized the Old Colony Railroad to Issue $900,000 fifty-year 5 per pent, gold bonds to fund the floating indebtedness incurred by railway improvement and construction.

It must be very discouraging to Mr. HARRISON to have those who claim to be his particular admirers, and some even who have posed as his intimate friends, declare that he is really not "out" and that, in the language of politics, he is, on the contrary, very much "in it."

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 12. -- Bishop W.X. Ninde and Presiding Elders Germond, Schriver, and Mickle of the Methodist Episcopal Church, have concluded a conference in this city, at which, it is stated, it was agreed to change the pastoral assignments of a number of well-known clergymen to restore the equilibrium of the conference, which was destroyed by Bishop Newman's distribution last year.

LONDON, March 12 -- In reply to a question, George N. Curzon, Parliamentary Secretary of the Foreign Office, said the Government had no information that a settlement of the Venezuelan difficulty had been effected.
A San Francisco newspaper, under date of March 6, contained a story that James Ben Ali Haggin was dangerously ill in this city with appendicitis, and that his life was practically despaired of.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Mr. Sherman has given notice in the Senate of his intention to press the conference report on the Cuban resolutions, but there are several speeches in pickle, and he is unable to say when the Senate will agree to a vote on the proposition whether the report favoring the House substitute shall be adopted.
Many rare and valuable books were sold at auction yesterday by Bangs Co. Among them were the following by Savonarola:

President Brock of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs announced yesterday the standing committees for the ensuing year. The make-up of each pleased the wheelmen who saw the list. The Chairmen are men of much popularity and ability in cycling matters, a fact which augurs well for the success of the association this year.

The Washington dispatches in yesterday's TIMES contained the report of a remark made by one Senator to another in regard to which the most severe thing that can or need be said is that it did not excite in the minds of intelligent readers incredulity or even much surprise. The reported remark was that "we wanted a war with Spain.
ALBANY, March 12. -- The Raines bill, as passed by the Assembly, according to its first section, is to be known as "The Liquor Tax Law." Its provisions are:

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Hansbrough (Rep., N.D.,) introduced a bill to grant a Federal charter to a company, to be Known as the Maritime Canal Company of North America. The company asks for no bonus, but seeks authority to construct a canal connecting the great lakes with the Atlantic Ocean with a channel 26 feet deep and 300 feet wide.

John P. Faure, the Commissioner of Charities, who is chiefly responsible for the barge system of giving homeless persons a night's lodging, was greatly pleased yesterday at the success of Wednesday night's venture, when 100 homeless men were lodged on the barge for the first time.

ALBANY, March 12. -- The minority members of the Legislature claim that the Raines Liquor Tax bill was passed in the Assembly to-day in violation of the State Constitution. They to-night issued the following protest:

A movement to promote the efficiency or the medical library in the New-York Academy of Medicine has been started by prominent members of the Chamber of Commerce. They have set out to raise a fund that will fully equip the library with all the late publications and periodicals.

BOSTON, March 12 -- The handsome building 219, 221, and 223 Columbus Avenue, occupied by the Pope Manufacturing Company, bicycle manufacturers, was damaged by fire this afternoon. The building was six stories high, of white brick, with terra-cotta trimmings.

ORANGE, N.J., March 12. -- A new organization, the Elmwood Athletic Club, has just been organized in East Orange, and it promises to take a prominent place among the many clubs of this vicinity. Already plans have been drawn by Louis P. Scherrer for an attractive little clubhouse, with bowling alleys, reading, reception, and game rooms, all of which will be attractively furnished.

At a meeting in the rooms of the Patriotic Republican Club, 248 East Seventy-eighth Street, last night, resolutions were passed making McKinley the second choice of the Republicans of the club, in the event of Gov. Morton's failure to get the nomination. The crowd that filled the parlors of the clubhouse showed in every way, however, that it was for McKinley first and last.

The junior Republican organ in this city published three or four days ago the first of the series of "roorbachs" which will embellish its columns from time to time, we suppose, until election day in November. In the statement to which we refer, The Press asked everybody to believe that the woolen industry was in a condition of collapse which would soon be followed by complete ruin and extinction.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 12.-- Gov. Bradley and Mayor Julian had a conference this morning about preserving the peace in case of trouble in the Legislature to-day, and at 10 o'clock six big policemen were stationed in the lobby, between the House and Senate Chamber. The Mayor also had conferences with the presiding officers of the Senate and House.

-- Prof. Ramsay, the well-known chemist, who, with Lord Rayleigh, discovered argon, has written a letter to Nature which raises an interesting question of etiquette for men of science. He points out that when a discovery in science is published, other investigators make a "rush" to the subject, and thus in manner forestall further discoveries by the original investigator.

ALBANY, March 12 -- A substitute New-York School bill was introduced this morning in the Senate by the Senate Committee on Cities in the place of the Page and Pavey bills, and now goes to general orders. The substitute bill is built upon the Page bill, prepared by Commissioner Strauss, but accepts the provisions of the Pavey bill abolishing the office of Ward Trustees, whose terms of office are to expire on June 30, 1896.
It is a cozy little room. The walls are tinted a delicate shade of violet, and on one side of the mantelpiece is a long panel of violets, which seem to blend with the wall itself.

From a Staff Correspondent of The United Press. HAVANA, March 12. -- Several encounters between Government troops and detached bands belonging to the forces of Gomez and Maceo have been reported around Los Palos, in the Province of Matanzas, near the line of the Province of Havana, and also near Bagaes, in the latter Province.
Assistant District Attorney O'Hare and Capt. O'Brien, Chief of the Detective Bureau, created some excitement for a short time yesterday in Part I. of the General Sessions Court.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- Applications for places on the National Circuit should be sent in at once to the Chairman, in order to be considered. The lists will be held open until April 1, after which time no place can be assigned.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The Assembly passed the Raines Liquor Tax bill to-day, with 84 votes in favor of and 59 against it. Seventeen Republicans defied the party "wlippers-in" and voted against the measure. There were seven absentees all told, of whom five were Democrats. All the Democrats present voted against the measure.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 12. -- The Norwegian steamship Gurley arrived from Port Antonio to-day with a case of malignant smallpox aboard. The vessel reached her dock, but was ordered back to Quarantine with all on board. Four passengers, two of whom live in Washington, D.C., landed before the smallpox case was discovered, and are being searched for with the view of taking them back to the Quarantine station.

The adjourned hearing on the French bill, which provides that no fountain, monument, or memorial shall be accepted by the city without the consent of the Mayor. President of the Board of Aldermen, president of the Park Department, President of the Sculpture Society, and President of the Municipal Art Society, was held before Mayor Strong yesterday afternoon.
