FRANKFORT, Ky., March 15. -- Gov. Bradley, fearing that there may be trouble at the State Capitol to-morrow, growing out of the Senatorial contest, has ordered troops here from Lexington.

Perry Belmont yesterday expressed his opinion of the Allison and McKinley money platforms, and also asked some pertinent questions that would-be candidates for the Presidency may find it difficult to answer, in the light of their past declarations and the general demand for "sound money" and a confidence-inspiring financial policy.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 15. -- Arrangements are now nearly completed for the building of another Yale society chapter house and dormitory -- that of Theta Xi, a Sheffield Scientific School society, which now has quarters at 43 College Street. At the recent session of the Connecticut General Assembly the society was incorporated under the name of the Fox Association, for the purpose of doing the business necessary to the erection of this new building.

After a checkered existence of eighteen months, the semi-monastic order in the Protestant Episcopal Church, known as the Brothers of the Church, according to reports received in this city has collapsed. The news reached the General Theological Seminary, in Chelsea Square, yesterday. It created a mild sensation among the students and professors, who have watched the movement with interest.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

ALBANY, March 15. -- Greater New-York will be the next important subject to be finally considered by the Legislature. The Lexow Consolidation bill has passed the Senate, and will be handed down by the Speaker Monday night. It will take the regular course and be substituted for Assemblyman Austin's similar bill, which is on the order of third reading.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Republican canvassers of the elections of delegates to the Republican National Convention varied a good deal at the end of the week. One leading Republican newspaper of the McKinley stripe puts the number of delegates chosen at 206, of whom it finds 106 for McKinley.

From The Atlanta (Ga.) Constitution. The letter of Judge Crisp to the State Executive Committee is one of importance to the Democrats of Georgia. It was referred by the State Committee to the several county committees. The letter follows:

Just what sort of racing the patrons of the National Circuit meets will see this year under the changed conditions incidental to the absence of Class B remains an unanswered question with many students of the sport. It seems evident at this period that there will be fewer meets and not so many teams as formerly.

If the English Government shall determine upon a serious forward movement in what was a dozen years ago the Egyptian Soudan, it will be difficult to explain its motives satisfactorily to the average Englishman, unless the Government is in possession of facts quite unknown to the press.

PROVIDENCE, March 14. -- The local stock market continues quiet and firm. Prices generally show but little change. The bank stocks are in demand, with the usual light offerings which have prevailed for some time. American Screw stock is quiet. A small lot has sold at 202 1/2. Gorham Manufacturing preferred shows little or no change in price.

CONSTANTINOPLE, March 15. -- Information from various points in the Provinces of Sivas, Harpoot, Diarbekr, Bitlis, and Van shows that the process of forcing Christians to become Moslems is still in active progress. While Christian worship is allowed to be held in most of the cities and large towns, in the villages throughout the six provinces of the reform scheme it is in practice prohibited.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The woman suffragists of New-York State are claiming that suffrage should be forced upon unwilling women, because it is the voice of the people, and, consequently, the voice of God. They claim to have signed to the voluminous papers that are annually presented to the Legislature 300,000 signatures.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

Morris Rosengardt of Rosengardt Co., clothiers, who occupy the sixth floor of the seven-story warehouse, 163 Greene Street, was seriously burned in a fire in the building, just before 6 o'clock last evening.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst is about to lead another crusade, and this time he is going into State matters. He will not yet make public the lines on which he will conduct the attack. He simply allows it to be known that he will make his assault on the present legislative methods and ideas and the "boss" system.

The statement which BOSS PLATT has issued in defense of the Raines bill serves the purpose of dispelling all doubt of his intention of making it a law whether the people of the plundered cities like it or not. The issuing of such a defense involves the cool assumption of PLATT'S responsibility for the bill.
Thomas A. Edison has discovered a practical method of making Rontgen impressions through opaque substances visible to the naked eye.

Two or three days after the Ohio Convention had adopted that ambiguous and evasive currency platform, written by himself, which so many Republican newspapers are now denouncing, Mr. McKINLEY gave to the public a brief statement in which he urged that his attitude toward the silver question should be ascertained by examination of his record in Congress.

-- Assemblyman Austin has introduced a bill establishing Riverside Park extension to be bounded by One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street, the Central-Hudson Road, One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street, and Boulevard Lafayette.

CHICAGO, March 16. -- The market opened weak and sold off steadily. The decline ranged from 3 3/4 per cent. in West Chicago, to a point on New-York Biscuit. There seemed to be no buying orders in the market. New-York Biscuit sold under 90, and closed at 89 5/8. West Chicago, which opened at 105, sold off to 101 3/8 for the account.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Boisterous claims for McKinley may turn out, by early June to be not more effective in developing delegates into voters for the object of the boom than were the claims of the noisy Blaine boomers of the years past. But the McKinley boomers are at work, and they are so confident that they make the friends of "favorite sons" uncomfortable.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., March 16. -- Gov. Morton's action upon the Raines bill is awaited here and at Rockaway Beach with considerable anxiety. This place and Rockaway Beach depend largely upon visitors and boarders during the Summer, and should the Raines bill become a law it would have a serious effect upon business along this section of the Atlantic coast.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The docking of the battleship Indiana has taken on a more serious aspect than is indicated by the statement emanating from the Navy Department to-day: "There will be a delay in the docking until the wind changes."

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The President to-day put an end to a long drawn out contest, and at the same time caused much surprise in Government circles, by appointing John J. Brice of California to be Commissioner of Fish and Fisheries. Since the death, several months ago, of Fish Commissioner McDonald, there has been a spirited race for this desirable office by several men who were more or less highly recommended.

The storm had its effect, of course, on the attendance at the theatres last, night, yet the audiences were reasonably large in all the houses which put forward new bills. At the Garden Theatre, Minnie Maddern Fiske began a fortnight's engagement, presenting a three-act play called "Marie Deloche," adapted from the French of Alphonse Daudet and Leon Hennique by Harrison Grey Fiske.

It is reported that Austria is willing to accept the invitation of any power that wishes to call a new conference on international bimetallism. So is the Government of the United States. It is, of course, well understood that our Government is formally committed to the support of any practicable scheme for international bimetallism.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 16. -- Four hundred soldiers are encamped in the State House Square. Armed men are guarding every entrance to the Capitol and every entrance to the Capitol grounds. The Governor's order to the guards is to exclude from the square all but State officials, members of the Legislature, newspaper men, and telegraph operators.

Primaries for the election, of one set of delegates to the Congressional District Convention to choose delegates to the Republican National Convention, to be held in St. Louis in June, and for the election of another set of delegates to the Assembly District Convention, to select delegates to the Republican State Convention, to be held in this city next week, were held in all the local election districts last night.

The southwest wing of St. Luke's Hospital, at One Hundred and Thirteenth Street and Tenth Avenue, which is called the Norrie Pavilion in honor of Gordon Norrie, Treasurer of the hospital, was opened for patients yesterday.

ALBANY, March 16. -- Some of those Republicans who have to-day commented on the selection of two McKinley delegates to the St. Louis Convention in Erie County have recalled the position taken by Gov. Morton prior to his formal entry into the lists as a Presidential candidate.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The bill to amend the existing law so as to place further restrictions upon immigration to the United States was taken up in the Senate to-day, and Mr. Ledge (Rep., Mass.,) made a short address in advocacy of the bill. In the course of his speech he said:
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 16. -- A heavy thunderstorm passed over here this evening. The lightning was vivid and for a time almost continuous.

Weather forecasts with your mail is a scheme that may be put into practical operation through Postmaster Willett of Washington and Willis L. Moore, Chief of the Weather Bureau, which is in the Agricultural Department.

MONDAY -- P.M. Outside of a few specialties to-day's market was dull and featureless. The active stocks were Tobacco, Sugar, Ganau Electric, and Leather preferred. Tobacco sold up to 84, but closed at 83, a net gain of as. The principal buying orders were in the hands of brokers who usually act for insiders.

The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott has been preaching a series of sermons in Plymouth Church Sunday evenings on "The Theology of an Evolutionist." The first sermon was delivered Sunday evening, March 8, and in it Dr. Abbott discussed creation and evolution. In the course of the sermon Dr. Abbott made several statements with which some Brooklyn clergymen do not agree.

Notwithstanding the great storm which raged in this city yesterday morning the auditorium of Daly's Theatre was comfortably filled when John L. Stoddard stepped on the stage to deliver the fourth of his illustrated matinee lectures. His subject was "The Glories of India," and the lecture was one of the most interesting that he has yet given.

The Catholic Club tendered, last night, a reception to Col. George Bliss and Frederic R. Coudert in recognition of services rendered by them as counsel on behalf of the Catholic charities of the State, before the Constitutional Convention.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The Supreme Court to-day, in an opinion read by Mr. Chief Justice Fuller, affirmed the decision of the Supreme Court of the State of callfornia to the effect that franchises, capital stock, , of the Central Pacific and Southern Pacific Railroad Companies were taxable under the laws of that State.
BOSTON, March 16. -- At a special meeting to-day of the Massachusetts Board of Trade the following declaration was adopted:

BOSTON, March 16. -- Local stocks were somewhat more active, and the tone of the market was strong. The specialties were Pioneer, Dominion Coal, and Bay State Gas securities. The latter are being advanced on rumors of Mr. Whitney's great gas consolidation scheme. The stock advanced 1 1/4, to 11 7/8: the firsts to 78 3/4, and the seconds to 55. Dominion Coal advanced to 15 5/8, closing at 15.

A thief secured several hundred dollars' worth of silverware in the residence of M. Wincburgh, 25 West Seventy-sixth Street, yesterday. He was disturbed while leisurely testing the family plate with acids. Although chased through Central Park by a policeman, the robber escaped.
PARIS, March 16. -- The Chamber of Deputies has approved the Government's scheme for an International exhibition in 1900.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 16. -- At a meeting of the State Board of Regents, to be held on Wednesday, action will be taken on the new charter for the New-York College of Dentistry. Under its old charter part of its Faculty composed the Board of Directors. This is forbidden by the revised legislation.

The attention of William H. Maxwell, Superintendent of the Brooklyn public schools, was called yesterday to the remarks concerning him made by John Jasper, Superintendent of the New-York public schools. Mr. Jasper was quoted in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of Sunday as saying, among other things, in reference to Mr. Maxwell:
Mr. W.J. Merritt has sold, at about $30,000, the five-story American basement dwelling 213 West Seventieth Street, 17 by 60 by100.5.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The President to-day notified the Congress that he had permitted the joint resolution introduced in the Senate by Mr. Hansbrough, compelling the Secretary of Agriculture to purchase and distribute seeds in accordance with existing law, to become a law without his signature.

At the weekly meeting of the Methodist ministers, held yesterday morning in the Assembly Hall of the Bible House on Fifth Avenue, the Rev. Dr. F. Mason North, Secretary of the New-York City Church Extension Society, spoke on "A Greater New-York and a Greater Methodism." He made a comparative statement of the growth of Methodism in the city and in the metropolitan circle, with a thirty-mile radius from Forty-second Street, known as the Greater New-York.

"In the annals of the Brooklyn Bridge history," said one of the officials after the adjourned meeting of Trustees yesterday, "there has never been a snow which lay more solidly or interfered more with traffic than this one."
BERLIN, March 16. -- The united committees formed for the protection of the Northern Pacific Railroad bondholders have approved the New-York plan for the reorganization of that company.

A collection of nearly 200 pictures by modern French, Spanish, and Italian painters are now on exhibition at the Schenck Art Gallery, 85 Liberty Street, where they, will be sold by auction on the afternoons of Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday, March 18, 19, and 20, beginning each day, at 3:15 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The Cuban resolutions still hang fire in the Senate, and there is a growing belief that they will come to grief. Several Senators said this afternoon to a correspondent of THE NEW-YORK TIMES that the number of opponents of the resolutions was growing constantly, and that if a vote could be prevented this week there was a strong likelihood that the conference report would be rejected.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Representative Patterson of Tennessee made public to-day the following letter, which he received this morning from Secretary Carlisle:
"It is almost impossible to find persons in the ordinary walks of life who are not suffering, more or less, from want of vital force."

A band of ambitious men and women have come together and organized themseves into a society called the Liberal Art League, the principal object being the effort to place before the public pictures in a manner free from the personal prejudices of a jury, and to offer an opportunity for sales at a modest commission.

ALBANY, March 16. -- A concurrent resolution for the final adjournment of the Legislature was introduced in the House to-night by Majority Leader O'Grady. It provides that the Legislature shall adjourn sine die April 23 at 2 P.M.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The statements furnished the Department of Agriculture by all railways and transportation companies show that from Sept. 1, 1895, to Feb. 1, 1896, the total actual movement of cotton from the States of production to ports, Northern and "Western mills, Canada, Mexico, and all other destinations, amounted to 5,236,722 commercial bales. Reports from the officials of the mills show actual purchases during the same period amounting to 609,766 bales.

ALBANY, March 10. -- Mr. Platts declaration that the Raines liquor tax law is a wise, beneficent measure is regarded by some here as a stuffed club directed at Gov. Morton's head. If the Governor does not sign the bill, he will be in open revolt against the wishes of the "Boss" as publicly expressed. If he does sign it, Mr. Platt may have the credit of having helped the work along.

"I think you are a worse dictator than 'Boss' McLaughlin has ever been in his palmiest days," said City Clerk Joseph Benjamin to Mayor Wurster of Brooklyn in the latter's office yesterday, when the City Clerk headed a delegation representing the Fidelity Club of the Twenty-first Ward, that visited the Mayor in quest of patronage.

CANNES, March 16. --The yacht races for the cups given by Ogden Goelet and James Gordon Bennett were sailed off this place to-day. One of these cups, valued at $1,600, was offered for yachts above twenty-rating, and the second, valued at $800, was for yachts under that rating. The course was the great triangular one, each leg to be sailed over three times -- a total distance of thirty miles.

(Copyright, 1896, by Bacheller, Johnson, and Bacheller.) SYNOPSIS. Mr. Willard Davis is the head of the Union surface lines of NEW-York, and his office is in the rear of the company's rooms on the third floor of the Ann Street Bank Building. Associated with him in various schemes for the absorption of small street car lines is George Stalbridge.

Fourteen inches of snow on the level was the result of the storm which began at 10 A.M. Sunday and turned to rain yesterday afternoon. The storm was the fifth of the kind of this Winter, and the most severe.

The Young Women's Christian Association of New-York celebrated its twentyfifth anniversary by a mass meeting last night in Carnegie Hall. In the boxes were many women in elaborate toilets. The friends of the association were out in full force.

It is a healthy sign that any portion of the Spanish press should be discussing the possibility of home rule for Cuba and also of rational liberty for the commerce of the island. It is not surprising that the discussion should start with the Cuban representatives in Madrid, for they are the forlorn hope of any decent treatment for their countrymen short of independence achieved by the cruel and costly process of revolution.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16. -- Business to-day was nominal. Storage Battery stocks declined 1 per cent. for the common and 1 1/2 per cent. for the preferred. Pennsylvania Heat issues were firm. There was no feature in the tractions The close was dull and irregular.

LONDON, March 16. -- In the House of Commons to-day Sir Albert Kaye Rollit, Independent Conservative, member for the South Division of Islington, asked what truth there was in the reports that the United States Government had expressed willingness that the Venezuelan dispute be referred to a joint commission for consideration and settlement.

ALBANY, March 17. -- Two elements have entered into the operations of the railroads of New-York City which are devoted exclusively to the carrying of passengers which, despite the fact that they may still be said to be in their infancy, have made themselves manifest. They are the operation by cable and the transfer ticket system.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 17. -- Several big failures were announced here to-day. Oliver N. Long and William H. Long, trading as James Long, Brother Co., manufacturers of dress goods, made a general assignment to-day for the benefit of their creditors to David Nimlet, who also is a manufacturer.

The exclusion of a juror in the Devery case upon the ground of insufficient intelligence seems rather hard measure, considering what the test was. The question asked the talesman might very easily have puzzled, and would most certainly have pained, a competent professor of the English language.

MOUNT VERNON, March 17. -- The Huguenot Wheelmen's Bowling Club of New-Rochelle defeated the Mount Vernon Cycle Club team two games last night at Schpiher's alleys. The Street and Franklin Avenue, in the Weschester Cycle League tournament. The score:

The process in the libel brought by the United States Government to condemn the cartridges, dynamite, and other explosives seized upon the barge J.S.T. Stranahan at the time of the seizure of the steamer Bermuda, alleged to have been engaged in a filibustering expedition to Cuba, was called in the United States District Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The House Committee on Immigration and Naturalization to-day ordered favorably reported two important immigration bills. The first provides an educational test for immigrants by adding to the classes of aliens excluded from the United States "all male persons between sixteen and sixty years of age who cannot both read and write the English language or some other language."

Mr. Theodore Thomas, who five years ago shock the unappreciative dust of New-York from his shoes and fled to the open arms of Chicago, returned to the scene of his early labors last night to show us that he was still a power in music. Perhaps to-day we shall feel that he has renewed his youth, and shall sing:

ALBANY, March 17. -- Col. William Cary Sanger, who represents one of the Oneida County districts in the Assembly, holds that the word "confidential," as applied to the special agents provided for by the Raines bill, does not necessarily exempt them from the operation of the civil service laws.

Since 1888 people have been prone to call every flurry of snow that occurs after the 1st of March the beginning of "another blizzard." The snowfall which is now dissipating was very far from being a blizzard, but it has nevertheless made a "record" of its own. It is, we believe, unprecedented that a St. Patrick's Day procession should be obstructed by snow or slush.

JAMESTOWN, March 17. -- The action of the Chautauqua County Republicans in instructing their delegates to the State and Congressional Conventions to support for delegates to St. Louis men who would favor the nomination of McKinley for President was not the result of a spontaneous impulse, or a popular uprising in behalf of the Ohio candidate.

"School Life as a Preventive of Future Pauperism "was the subject yesterday of the fourth monthly conference, for the consideration of methods by which religious and charitable organizations can test exert their power to overcome pauperism.

Several experts on brain and nervous diseases testified yesterday when the trial to determine the mental condition of Daniel Levy was resumed before Justice Bischoff and a jury in Part IX., Trial Term, of the Supreme Court.

Prof. W.S. Franklin of Ames. Iowa, in a recent communication in Science, shows that many of the assertions that Rontgen photographs have been obtained with the electric are lamp are at least premature, as the following experiments by him prove:

In the month of May, 1894, work was commenced in pegging reefs and farm areas, and it was speedily discovered that very large isolated districts of auriferous country existed all over the land, in all of which a vast amount of work had been done by the ancients. These old workings, though in some ways advantageous, were not without their disadvantages.

LONDON, March 17. -- The examination of Dr. Jameson and his fellow-officers in the Transvaal raid was resumed in the Bow Street Police Court this morning. As at the previous hearings, the courtroom was filled with members of the aristocracy, friends and admirers of the defendants.

William Nelson Cromwell, the American counsel of the New Panama Canal Company of Paris, referring to recent statements to the effect that a consolidation of the Panama and Nicaragua Companies had been agreed upon or was under negotiation, made the following statement:

Counsel for the new East River Bridge Commissioners did not appear to be much disturbed' yesterday over the decision of Justice Gaynor restraining the Commissioners from paying $200,000 for the Uhlmann-Lauterbach charter.

Another arrest was made yesterday in connection with the Lloyds fire insurance cases. Frederick Vail, a promoter, of Flushing, L.I., who was indicted on Monday, was arrested at his office, 140 Nassau Street, yesterday. He was indicted on Monday for grand larceny in the first degree for selling fraudulent charters for Lloyds fire insurance companies.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- There has been a long-standing controversy between certain army engineers and the Treasury Department accounting officers, and an appeal has now been made to Congress for relief. The officers concerned are Col. W.P. Craighill, Chief of Engineers; Col. G.H. Mendell, retired, and the estate of Major J.C. Post.

Mrs. William Gossip, whose maiden name was Anna Catharine Coade, and who was among the first batch of prisoners taken by the Americans in the war of 1812-14, is living in this city. Mrs. Gossip was born in Halifax in 1809. Her father, Capt. Coade, was a native of Ireland, and for many years commanded the Admiral Nelson, an ocean-going ship.
The case of Mitchell vs. the Montreal Street Railway was continued and concluded yesterday, the jury awarding the Hon. Peter Mitchell $1,000 damages.

Northern men who visit the State of Florda hear many strange tales of schemes, but they are not to be compared to the stories of the rivalry that exists between the millionaires, Henry M. Flagler and Henry B. Plant. Not in the entire country can two millionaires be found who have so many peculiar ideas in common.

Rapid Transit Commissioner Alexander E. Orr, President William Steinway, John H. Inman, and Seth Low were in secret session two hours yesterday afternoon. There were present at the meeting Secretary Delafield, Edward M. Shepard, and A.B. Boardman, counsel to the commission.
HAVANA, March 17. -- It is reported that Antonio Maceo, the second in command of the rebel forces, is near Candelaria.

One Hundred and Second Street, north side, 75 feet west of First Avenue, and One Hundred and Third Street, north side, 60 feet west of First Avenue, two one-story stone stables, by Otto Volkening of 232 East Forty-fourth Street, owner; cost, $16,000.

VICTORIA, B.C., March 17. -- Because of representations alleged to have been made to the Dominion Government ay Collector Milne steps are to be taken shortly, it is said, for the better protection of Canadian interests at Herschell Island, where, according to latest reports, they are being infringed upon.

When Evangelist Aitken of the Church of England arrived in old Trinity Church, in Lower Broadway, yesterday noon, he found a large congregation awaiting him. The seats were filled, and at least 300 persons were standing. The topic for the sermon was "A Victim of Mammon." The evangelist said:

In his speech, last night at the dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, Mayor Strong took occasion, to speak against the Raines bill. The bill, he said, was good for the Irishmen, because it threw the liquor business into their hands, "but," he continued. "I do not believe in any legislation that takes away from the City of New York a single dollar that belongs to it."

American shares were fractionally higher in the London market. The principal changes were: Advanced -- Illinois Central 1/2, to 98 1/2; St. Paul 8/3, to 79 3/8; Louisville Nashville 3/8, to 53 7/8; Atchison 3/8, to 16 3/8; Union Pacific 1/4, to 7 1/2; Erie 1/4, to 16; do second consols 1/4 to 73; Northern Pacific preferred 1/8, to 12 7/8, and Canadian Pacific 1/8, to 57 1/4.
The concluding sale of the Charles W. Lawrence library was held yesterday by Bangrs Co. Among the books sold were the following:

The trial of George Ballard's suit against the Manhattan Railway Company for $5,000 damages for alleged false imprisonment was begun yesterday morning before Justice Giegerich and a jury in Trial Term, Part VIII., of the Supreme Court.

BOSTON, March 17. -- Bay State Gas and Dominion Coal have been features to-day. Both lost a part of the gain made in the last few days. The Whitneys are said to have pooled their interests, but beyond this there was no gossip. Dominion Coal lost 1, to 14. Bell Telephone was steady at 203 and Erie Telephone at 60. Boston and Maine was unchanged at 210 and Fitchburg preferred at 95.

There are to be six cows on the vacant lot farms of the Society for Improving the Condition of the Poor this year. This is to teach the embryo farmers to milk, an accomplishment very necessary to enable them to obtain positions in the country, the main object of the work.

The elements broke faith with the Weather Bureau yesterday. Instead of the predicted cloudy weather, with rain or snow, the sun came out bright, and with his effulgent presence honored the day of Erin.

The sale of boxes and orchestra stalls at the Metropolitan Opera House for the amateur performance of "Patience" to be given there to-morrow night in aid of the athletic interests of the University of the City of New-York, is going forward so rapidly that those who desire to secure either boxes or seats should do so immediately.

LONDON, March 17. -- In response to the proposal made to him by the Armenian Relief Committee, that a national fund, under the auspices of the Government, be started for the assistance of the suffering Armenians, Lord Salisbury says that the relief of distress in foreign countries has invariably emanated from private liberality or local authority.
The National Society of New-England Women held a meeting yesterday at the Windsor Hotel. The meeting was unusually well attended.

The students of the civil government branch in Columbia College assembled in Room 34, Hamilton Hall, yesterday, and listened to a lecture on "The Government of Cities of the Third Class," by Frederick William Holls, a graduate of the college.
The trial of ex-Police Captain William S. Dovery, accused of bribery and extortion, was begun yesterday morning in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court before Justice Smyth.

It was generally conceded yesterday by politicians in this city that the first clash or arms between the Platt-Morton and the McKinley forces resulted in a sweeping and decisive victory for the former.

At Redditch, the centre of the wholesale fishing-tackle trade, literally tons of rods are turned out every year; but many of these are for export. I have, moreover, been unable to learn the proportion of fly-rods to trolling and other rods, and the ratio of increase in output during the late years.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17. -- Judge Butler, in the United States Circuit Court, this morning overruled the motion for a new trial in the case of the officers of the steamer Horsa, who were convicted of beginning a military expedition for the carrying of men and arms to Cuba to assist in the war against Spain, and passed sentence upon the prisoners.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 17. -- At 12:05 o'clock this morning the public officials who were elected at the Spring election last Tuesday were sworn in, and took possession of their offices. The officers installed were: Mayor -- Franklin P. Story; Recorder -- R.H. Ingersoll; Alderman -- J.B. Southwick; Treasurer -- J.A. Jeffries; Councilmen -- S.B. Rose, William Irelarid, E.A. Parker, and E.F. Hahn.

NORWICH, Conn., March 17. -- William A. Slater's steam yacht Eleanor, New-York Yacht Club, started from this city shortly after 10 o'clock this morning for Bath, Me. She had just swung from her pier when she grounded, and it was nearly half an hour before she was floated and proceeded down the river to New-London. After a short stop there she will leave for Bath, where she will undergo a general overhauling.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.
PHILADELPHIA, March 17. -- The general market suffered slight recessions to-day. The tractions were steady, but the specialties wore heavy. The close was dull and steady.

The dead-lock in the Board of Police over the proposed promotion of Capts. Brooks and McCullagh continues, and unless Chief Conlin, who holds the key to the situation, abandons the position which he has assumed, the promotions will be delayed indefinitely.
A lecture was given at the Academy of Natural Sciences Wednesday afternoon by Mr. Witmer Stone, Conservator of the ornithological section, on "The Protection and Preservation of Our Native Birds."

It would be unwise in a civilian to express any opinion of his own on the very important problem of the degree in which modern appliances of war have deprived Constantinople of her peculiar powers of defense. We are told that, so far as the closing of the Bosphorus and the Hellespont extend, the resources of the artillerist and the submarine engineer have greatly increased their defensive capacity.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 17. -- The Republican State Central Committee will meet here Wednesday night, March 25. School Fund Commissioner Herbert E. Benton has held the Chairmanship of the committee for the past six years. It is understood he will retire this Spring from the Chairmanship of the State Committee.

Messrs. L.J. Phillips Co. have sold, for the Potter estate, to ex-Mayor Nolan of Albany, the plot of 114 lots, extending from both sides of the Fort Washington Ridge Road, 275 feet northward from One Hundred and Eighty-ninth Street, and westwardly to the Hudson River, with the water front.

First and foremost the composer must provide himself with a good libretto. On this we should say roundly the whole fortune of the piece depends. A good libretto will make amends for bad music, but good music will never make amends for a bad libretto. If the libretto is light, the music need not necessarily be flimsy.

The bowling quintet of the Colonial Club of this city visited the alleys of the Brooklyn Union League Club last night to complete a series of match games. The Union League Club bowlers again outplayed the Colonials, making it four straight and a total of 459 pins in favor of the Union League Club. The scores:

ALBANY, March 17. -- An attempt was made in the Senate Finance Committee to- day to have the Grady Canal Grain Elevator bill reported favorably, but the attempt failed. The three Democratic members of the committee -- Senators Cantor, Guy, and Koehler -- and Senators Harrison and Higbie, (Reps.,) voted for the bill, and the other Republican Senator against it.

The Republicans of Ohio in their recent convention demanded that the Nation should "return to the policy of protection," and we shall hear a great deal in the next few months about the desirability of this "return" to a protective policy which, it is assumed by Republican politicians, has been abandoned.

The shot tower is the cause of it all. "I don't know, but it will pervert the community," said a Brooklyn clergyman yesterday, as, coming over the bridge, he gazed across at the tall yellow structure climbing high up in the air, and apparently within handshaking distance. "I have heard more men make bets upon the location of that tower than I would like to count."

Commissioner John H. Burtis of the Department of Charities, Brooklyn, was at Albany last Friday, and on his way to Brooklyn stopped over at the Sing Sing Prison and had a long interview with John Y. McKane, who is serving a six years' sentence.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 17. -- The fast line express train, east-bound, on the Pennsylvania Railroad, which left this city at 3:45 o'clock this morning, ran into a live stock train near Steelton, a few miles east of here, and caused a serious wreck. Two men were killed and a dozen were injured. The dead are:

The anomalies, absurdities, and mysteries of medical professional etiquette with regard to advertising are strikingly and amusingly illustrated by an action which was tried at Manchester Assizes on Friday.

STAPLETON, S.I., March 17. -- The Republicans of Richmond County held their convention to elect delegates to the State and Congressional District Conventions here this afternoon at the German Clubroom. The convention was controlled by the followers of Mr. Platt in the county, and the business was transacted practically without oppo- sition.

FORT SMITH, Ark., March 17. -- At 2:15 P.M. to-day Crawford Goldsby, alias Cherokee Bill, was hanged. He was declared dead in ten minutes. The desperado showed no fear, and went to the trap the coolest man in the party. The execution was set for noon, but was postponed to allow the doomed man's sister to arrive here from Tallequah.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The latest information from Washington conveys no hope of any but an adverse report from the House Committee on Military Affairs on the bill presented by the Commissioners of New-York and New-Jersey for the fortification of the Palisades.

TACOMA, Washington, March 17. -- My Saito, the Japanese Consul here, has received dispatches confirming the report that Japan proposes to start two new steamship lines -- one to London and the other to the United States.

Mr. Gladstone's name had come up, as in those days it could not fail to do; and Father Healy was expressing admiration for his wonderful accomplishments. "He asked me to breakfast in his own house one day," he said, "and there were a lot of big men there; ministers and men of science, and writers and what not; but he seemed the master of every one of them on his own subject.

Mr. Augustus Birrell is one of the most untidy men in the House of Commons. He has a thorough contempt for purple and fine linen, and even for the black frock coat and immaculate trousers of the ordinary member of Parliament. He prefers a well-worn and ill-brushed tail coat, a wrinkled waistcoat, and a wandering necktie.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 17. -- The big battleship Massachusetts started from Cramps' shipyard at 11:50 o'clock this morning on an unofficial, or builder's, trial trip. The trip is principally for the purpose of "shaking down" her engines, for the adjustment of her machinery when in motion, and to give the builders an idea of her capabilities.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 17. -- The Kentucky Legislature has adjourned without electing a successor to United States Senator Blackburn. The last ballot was taken at noon to-day, and, like the fifty ballots that had preceded it, it was fruitless.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 17. -- Lawrence Wilson was brought here to-day and lodged in the county jail. He is charged with taking possession of the Central Railroad Station at Lorraine, and refusing to allow any one else to enter. He is said to have entered the station on Sunday. He was discovered on Monday morning.
WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Statement of the condition of the United States Treasury and the receipts and expenditures of the Government on the 17th day of March, 1896:

The history of a group of cases of typhoid fever in Buffalo is instructive. These cases attracted the attention of the city's Health Department a few days ago. Six families are infected, and to all of them milk has been supplied by a dealer named STAUB. The fever is of a severe type, and two patients in these families have died of it.

TUESDAY -- P.M. The market was at no time active to-day, but it was generally strong. Railway issues continued dull. Northern Pacific preferred advanced fractionally on covering of shorts, based on a growing belief that under the plan of reorganization the stock will be worth more than had been supposed.

Byzantium, to use that which has been the ordinary name with all Greek writers from Herodotus down to Paspates in our own day, is one of the oldest cities of Europe -- historically speaking, if we neglect mere prehistoric legend, little younger than Athens or Rome. Like them, Byzantium appears to have been founded on a prehistoric fort.
A man and a woman, were found dead in a room in the Menlo Hotel, at 101 West Twenty-eighth Street, at 8:30 o'clock last night. Near them was a revolver.
BRIDGETON, N.J., March 17. -- The following appointments were announced at the New-Jersey Methodist Episcopal Conference:
LITTLE NECK, L.I., March 17. -- St. Patrick's Day was observed here by Bloodgood H. Cutter, Long Island's farmer poet. He turned out four stanzas on Ireland's patron saint, as follows:

ALBANY, March 17. -- A dinner at the Hotel Kenmore was held to-night by members of the Legislative to commemorate St. Patrick's Day. Those present included members of the Legislature State officers, and many prominent citizens of Albany. The members of the Committee of Arrangements were Senators McCarren, McNulty, and Grady, and Assemblymen Murphy, Corrigan, Norton, Cullen, and Trainor.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 17. -- Prof. William M. Sloane, representative of America in the Olympian games, announced to-day that the following men had accepted his invitation to act as members of the American Honorary Committee: President Grover Cleveland, Presidents Dwight of Yale, Patton of Princeton, and Eliot of Harvard; Provost Harrison, J.W. Alexander, William S. Wilson, Joseph H. Choate, and President Gilman of Johns Hopkins.

TRENTON, March 17 -- In the Senate to-day the Voorhees act abolishing lay Judges was placed on its final passage. Mr. Voorhees stated that the bill was in the interest of economy, as it would, save the State $40,000 annually.

-- Constant W. Wadsworth of Peekskill, N.Y., died suddenly Monday night from a stroke of apoplexy. He had been at his store all day, and did not complain of feelling ill. He was a member of the Board of Trade and a prominent business man. He was also a Freemason and high in the order. He was born in New-Lebynon, N.Y., sixty-two years ago, and had lived in Peekskill about thirty years.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 17. -- The official closing quotations for mining stocks to-day were as follows:
The members of the St. Patrick Society of Brooklyn celebrated the day with a banquet, in the assembly rooms of the Academy of Music, last evening. Dr. John A. Kene presided.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am glad to see your editorial on "Lodging Homeless Men" in this morning's paper, for your warning is timely and is needed by many of the public, if not by the Commissioners of public charities.

Natoye, the papoose of the Indian camp at Madison Square Garden, who is called "Nit" for short by those who are on terms of intimacy with her, was the cause of a bad half hour for the managers of the Sportsmen's Exposition yesterday afternoon.

The mass meeting of wheelmen held last evening in Fifth Avenue Hall, in West Forty-second Street, was a very enthusiastic gathering. It was the first mass meeting of bicyclists ever held in this city, and it gave the Armstrong baggage bill, a legislative measure providing for the free transportation of bicycles on the railroads, when accompanied by the riders, a big boost in the public eye.

Whenever one reads in the foreign dispatches an opinion of Sir CHARLES DILKE one finds his name followed by the phrase, "the acknowledged authority on foreign aftairs," or its equivalent. Sir CHARLES DILKE'S information is not exclusive; he is not in the confidence of Cabinets; there is no reason why his information should be more impressive than that of any other well-informed reader of news of any country.

David Armstrong, thirty-five years old, and George L. Senior, the same age, both of whom lived at 744 Ninth Avenue, fell down an airshaft yesterday afternoon. Armstrong was killed instantly, and Senior received injuries which will probably cause his death. They fell locked in each other's arms, but whether they had been quarreling the police have not learned.

GREYTOWN, Nicaragua, March 4. -- The telegraph lines are cut and communication with the interior is only maintained with difficulty. Since the revolution broke out in Leon Feb. 24, when Francisco Baca "pronounced" against Zelaya and proclaimed himself Provisional President, with Gen. Ortega as Commander in Chief of the revolutionary forces, reported to be 3,000 strong, we have heard of three engagements, in which Zelaya claims to have been victorious, but which were clearly indecisive.

Considering the character of the Raines bill, the manner in which it was passed, and the state of public sentiment with reference to it, we have little doubt that Gov. MORTON would withhold his approval if he should act according to his judgment and his conscience, with regard solely to the rights and interests of the people of the State.

The plan just put forth for the independent reorganization of the Northern Pacific system appears to be an assured success at the outset. It has the unqualified approval of a large majority of all of the vested interests affected, and it has the cash backing of an underwriting syndicate with $45,000,000, formed by J. P. MORGAN Co. and the Deutsche Bank.

Commissioner Parker gave out for publication yesterday a long report made to Chief Conlin by Capt. Stephen O'Brien about his differences with Assistant District Attorney O'Hare, which culminated recently in O'Hare ordering Capt. O'Brien out of the inclosure reserved for the counsel for the people during the trial in the Court of General Sessions of Thomas Reilly, alias Thomas Murphy, charged with picking pockets.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Business men in New-York who have had occasion from time to time to complain of coastwise pilotage fees as an irritating and unnecessary burden will receive cheerfully the news that the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries has reported a measure for their relief.

Green flags were liberally displayed all over the city yesterday in honor of Ireland's patron Saint. Notwithstanding the sunshine, it was not a promising St. Patrick's Day, as the snow and slush in the streets were a serious drawback to the parade, which is the recognized feature of St. Patrick's Day.
Henry Hentz, the Chairman of the Special Committee on Sound Financial Legislation of the Chamber of Commerce, said yesterday:

SARATOGA, March 17. -- The Republicans of Saratoga County have begun a factional fight, and it is likely to increase in intensity. There is a growing distaste for the methods of the "machine" leaders, who were nearly beaten in the County Convention at Ballston Spa this afternoon.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 3 1/2@4 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 4 per cent.

OMAHA, Neb., March 17. -- Senator Thurston has sent from Washington his ultimatum to the Manderson men, who bitterly resent it, and the fight will go on. The Senator proposes that he be sent to the St. Louis Convention as a district delegate; that John L. Webster and Peter Jansen be two of the delegates at large, and that resolutions substantially as follows be adopted in the State Convention, and in all district conventions:

RED BANK, N.J., March 17. -- "Aunt Judy" Cummings, the oldest person in New-Jersey, died at her home here yesterday. The woman claimed that she was born at Griggstown, N.J., on Oct. 12, 1776, and she lived in this State all her life. She retained her health to a remarkable degree, and until within a short time of her death smoked a pipe and moved about freely without the aid of a cane.

The Senate will in the course of the next few days have an opportunity to regain somewhat of its departed reputation for common sense and dignity. It is a rare chance to secure what is sorely needed. We wish we were at all sure that it would be seized, but the odds are against it.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Gen. Hubbard, representing the holdings of the Searles estate in the Central Pacific Railroad, presented to the House Pacific Railroads Committee this morning his plans for the settlement of the debt of the Central Railroad to the Government. He explained his plan at length, and compared it with that proposed by the Smith bill, pointing out the defects in the latter, which were remedied by his plan.

There seemed to be a lack of frankness in the disclosures made in the House of Commons when the first notice was given of the proposed Egyptian expedition to Dongola. It seems to be necessary for a Government, before undertaking so important a movement, to set forth in detail both what the evidence is on which it proposes to act and what specifically it proposes to do.

Sheridan Knowles has not often been made so interesting, in these later years, as the charmingly simple and sincere acting of Julia Marlowe made him at Palmer's Theatre last night. The mind of any confirmed playgoer of mature years is well stocked with memories of "The Hunchback." It used to be always with us; and for the veteran it is not likely that the old play will ever seem a living thing again.

Albert Chevalier, the singer of the joys and sorrows, the loves and hates of the costermonger and the costermonger's "gal," arrived in this port yesterday on the Teutonic. He will begin an engagement of four weeks at Koster Bial's music hall next Monday night.

In the Republican Convention in the Eighth Congressional District, which was held in Webster Hall, in East Eleventh Street, last night, Lucas R. Van Alien and Lispenard Stewart were elected as delegates, and Simon Gavin and John Moran as alternates. Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy was elected as a candidate for Elector.

George J. Gould, President of the Texas and Pacific Railroad, in his annual report, just issued, shows that the company's business for the year ended Dec. 31, 1895, suffered in consequence of the poor cotton crop. The gross earnings were $7,015,309, a decrease of $337,705; operating expenses of $5,188,437, a decrease of $101,937, and net earnings of $1,826,871, a decrease of $235,768.
LONDON, March 18. -- To-morrow The Times will publish a Singapore dispatch saying the Japanese naval programme includes the buildings of seven warships.

There was somewhat of a sensation yesterday among those who had read with pleasure Mayor Strong's vigorous words against the Raines bill at the dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, when they heard him say yesterday:

WEST POINT, March 18. -- There is a dent on St. Anthony's Nose. Had it been there in Washington Irving's time there is no telling how he would have accounted for it. Everybody who has read "Knickerbocker's History of New-York" should know that St. Anthony's Nose is one of the principal hills of the Highland range.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

A tale of four "gold bricks" which was told in the Detective Bureau at Police Headquarters last night demonstrates both that the boldest and most venerable of cheats may be vastly beguiling in new disguise, and that the malefactor recognizes that this wise age requires abundant ingenuity of criminals who aspire to success.

Harmony of the Kilkenny eat order marked the proceedings of the Republican Convention in the Fifteenth Congressional District last evening. The Platt forces and anti-Platt forces engaged in a riotous time, and ended by electing a double set of delegates to the St. Louis Convention.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 18. -- The Ecclesiastical Court of Inquiry that investigated the charges against the Rev. D.O.C. Brown, pastor of the First Congregational Church, has declared that the minister was not guilty of improper conduct with Miss Martha Overman or Mrs. M.A. Stockton. Dr. Brown is censured for language used to a woman of his congregation.

LONG ISLAND CITY, March 18. -- Arthur Mayhew and John Wayne, the two negroes who have been locked up here on a charge of murdering Stephen Powell in Hempstead on March 7, were indicted by the Queens County Grand Jury to-day for murder in the first degree. More than a dozen witnesses were subpoenaed in Hempstead yesterday and their testimony to-day resulted in the indictment.
SOMERS POINT, N.J., March 18. -- After three failures, Gen. Calixto Garcia is at last upon his way to Cuba to fight against the Spaniards.

Messrs. W.W. and T.M. Hall have sold to A.M. Palmer the four and one-half story and basement limestone front dwelling 9 East Seventy-sixth Street, 20 by 62 by 102.2. Messrs. Hall J. How Co. have sold for the Marsh estate the two lots at the southeast corner of Lenox Avenue and OneHundred and Eighteenth Street.

William Willard Howard, who made an effort to enter Armenia to superintend the distribution of a relief fund raised through the instrumentality of The Christian Herald, arrived in New-York yesterday on the steamship Teutonic.

More than ordinary interest was exhibited at the Sportsmen's Show last evening over the miniature powder mill plant of the Laflin Rand Powder Company, because of the receipt of the news of the explosion of a couple of mills of the company's at Rifton near Kingston, in this State.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18. -- The freight and passenger steamship Atlanta, building for the Southern Railway Company for use between Baltimore and Norfolk, was successfully launched at 4 o'clock this afternoon from Cramps shipyard, in the presence of a number of distinguished visitors from Atlanta and Baltimore, and a large crowd of spectators who had collected to witness the event. The honor of christening the vessel was assigned to Miss Ida Glenn.

ALBANY, March 18. -- Mr. Austin this morning introduced in the Assembly a bill designed to increase the police force of NewYork City by 800 members. The bill comes from the New-York Police Commissioners, and, lest he might be held committed to the bill, Mr. Austin labeled it "by request."

LONDON, March 18. -- A dispatch to The Globe from Cairo says that Mr. Curzon's statement in the British House of Commons Monday in regard to the Soudan expedition has created a great sensation there, the gravity of the situation being fully realized. The consensus of opinion in Cairo is that more troops are urgently required.

Delegates from the Congressional districts of this city to the Republican National Convention were elected last night at District Conventions Ex-Senator Platt's men won in most of the districts, and where they were in doubt about winning they put up contests in the hope that the National Committee's body on contested seats will recognize the Platt men at St. Louis.

OSMAN DIGNA was celebrated, away back in 1884, as the man who had been killed by the English seventeen or eighteen times, and who still continued daily to "advance on Suakim" with unabated energy and loud cries. There were no clipping agencies in those remote days, else he could have made the finest collection of obituaries of himself that anybody ever possessed.

ALBANY, March 18. -- A.B. Boardman of New-York City came to this city to-day with a memorial from the Rapid Transit Commissioners to the Legislature, and a bill proposing some amendments to the law under which the commission is working. The bill was placed in charge of Senator Stranahan and Assemblyman Austin, the Chairmen, respectively, of the Cities' Committees of the Senate and Assembly.

ALBANY, March 18. -- The Mayors of many cities of this State appeared in the Executive Chamber this morning and besought Gov. Morton not to help along the proposed robbery of their municipalities by signing the Raines Liquor Tax bill.

ALBANY, March 18. -- Mrs. Edward Lauterbach and Miss Woodbridge of New-York City appeared before the Senate Judiciary Committee this afternoon for the Andrews bill, putting mercantile establishments in cities under the supervision of the Board of Health.The committee will meet to-morrow morning to decide on its action.

The Republicans of the Twelfth Congressional District, who met last night in the Murray Hill Lyceum. Thirty-fourth Street, near Third Avenue, to elect delegates to the St. Louis Convention, had no sooner been called to order than they split into two irreconcilable factions and, organizing separately, elected two delegations.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- The sub-committee of the House Commerce Committee, which has been engaged for several weeks in the preparation of a Nicaragua Canal bill, finished its labors to-day, and will report to the full committee next Friday. The bill agreed upon is substantially the Mahon bill, with certain amendments.
Fire burned out the premises of the Lucas-Brown Company, engravers and manufacturers of stationery, 68 Beekman Street, early last evening.

-- Mrs. Edward M. Knox has arranged a testimonial concert for Miss M. Louise Segur for to-morrow afternoon at 3 o'clock, at 854 Fifth Avenue, the home of Mrs. Wallace C. Andrews. The artists are Miss Marguerite Hall, Miss Lucille Saunders, Victor Herbert, Francis Fischer Powers, Albert McGickin, and Victor Harris.

President Roosevelt of the Board of Police gave out for publication yesterday a statement in relation to the numerous reports of alleged crimes which have from time to time, since the accession of the present Police Commissioners, appeared in the columns of The World.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 18. -- The steamer Three Friends of Jacksonville, in command of Capt. Napoleon B. Broward, arrived here at noon to-day, having succeeded in landing in Cuba Gen. Enrique Collazo, Major Charles Hernandez, and Duke Estrada, besides fifty-four men taken off the chooner Ardell, from Tampa, and the entire cargo of arms and ammunition of the schooner Mallory, from Cedar Key.

HAVANA, March I8. -- News has been received her of an important battle, which was fought on Monday in the vicinity of Candelaria, in the Province of Pinar del Rio. The Government troops were unable to drive the insurgents back, and retired from their position with considerable loss.
The effort to secure a jury to try Police Captain William S. Devery under the indictment for bribery and extortion was resumed yesterday in the Supreme Court before Justice Smyth.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 18. -- The investigation of the charges that have been preferred against the management of the Westchester Temporary Home for Destitute Children, in this town, and against Superintendent James W. Pierce in particular, for cruel and inhuman treatment of the children under his charge, was conlinucil to-day by Referee Daniel W. Guernsey in the Auditorium.

The Republican Convention of the Ninth Congressional District met in Walhalla Hall, 48 Orchard Street, last night, and elected ex-Police Commissioner Charles H. Murray and John J. Collins as delegates to the National Convention, and Christian Goetz and Abraham A. Joseph as alternates.

Regarded as a project of law, the bill introduced into the Assembly yesterday by Mr. KEMPNER is, of course, entitled to no consideration. If there were enough members in the Assembly of the same mind with Mr. KEMPNER to give his bill the slightest chance of success, the Raines bill, at which it is aimed, would not have been passed.

While it is true that the candidacy of McKINLEY has been promoted by intrigue and by the use in the South and elsewhere of money obtained from the protected manufacturers, it is also true that the movement in favor of the nomination of this man has been very perceptibly stimulated by the notorious conspiracy of the Republican bosses in the East.

The Commissioners of the new East River bridge were indignant yesterday at the attack made upon them by Justice Gaynor of the Supreme Court at the dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick of the Eastern District of Brooklyn Tuesday. He responded to the toast "Our Country," and interpolated into his speech a reference to the commission in charge of the construction of the new bridge. He is reported to have said:
MILWAUKEE, March 18. -- The Republicans of Wisconsin to-day went on record as favoring the nomination of McKinley for President.
KINGSTON, N.Y., March 18. -- The Laflin Rand Powder Mill at Rifton blew up soon after 11 A.M. to-day, killing five men and injuring several others.

CHICAGO, March 18. -- Little interest was shown in to-day's market either by room traders or the public. The Moore stocks continue to sell off, despite the reports from the companies of large earnings and bright prospects. The banks are loaning little money to any one outside of customers, which accounts for the dullness of the market.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18. -- The local market to-day, in general, was dull and strong. The tractions were without feature or material change. In the specialties there was a good demand for Storage Battery stocks, both the preferred and common closing at an advance of 1 1/2, each. Welsbach advanced 1/2, to 59 1/2, and United Gas Improvement reacted 1/2, to 68 1/2.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- The feature of to-day's proceeding's in the Senate was a short debate upon a joint resolution directing the Secretary of the Interior to carry out the act for opening to settlement some 2,000,000 acres of land in the eastern part of Utah, which have been part of the Uncompahgre Indian Reservation.

The members of the Knickerbocker Bowling Club met yesterday afternoon at the Tennis and Bowling Building, on West Forty-first Street. The attendance was quite large, and some good scores were made by the bowlers. Three members made records high enough to entitle them to compete for the Knickerbocker Challenge Cup. Theodore P. Cooper's score was 216, Dr. Potter's 202, and N.G. Johnson's 207.

Those who are working in earnest for the reform of municipal government are agreed upon the necessity of divorcing that government so far as practicable from partisan politics. They succeeded in inducing the convention which revised the State Constitution to prepare the way for that result by separating municipal from general elections and classifying the cities so that they might be dealt with by general legislation.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Having aroused the country to a full sense of its lack of knowledge as to what is the duty of the House in diplomatic affairs, it does not seem to be a profitable or impressive thing for the same House to divert itself by undertaking to lecture a diplomatic representative upon his duties abroad.

PARIS, March 18. -- It is semi-officially declared that the utterances of M. Berthelot, Minister of Foreign Affairs, regarding the gravity of the consequences of the British expedition to Dongola do not possess the meaning attached to them. They merely referred to the question of using the reserve Egyptian fund for the expedition.
ALBANY, March 18. -- The hearing on the compromise New-York City School bill was held before the Senate Cities Committee this afternoon. Many New-Yorkers were heard.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Having aroused the country to a full sense of its lack of knowledge as to what is the duty of the House in diplomatic affairs, it does not seem to be a profitable or impressive thing for the same House to divert itself by undertaking to lecture a diplomatic representative upon his duties abroad.

PARIS, March 18. -- It is semi-officially declared that the utterances of M. Berthelot, Minister of Foreign Affairs, regarding the gravity of the consequences of the British expedition to Dongola do not possess the meaning attached to them. They merely referred to the question of using the reserve Egyptian fund for the expedition.

WEDNESDAY -- P.M. London came lower this morning, and its weakness was reflected in the local market throughout the day. The foreign political situation in connection with the British expedition to Dongola explained London's attitude on the market.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., March 18. -- Four miles of the cycle path across Long Island from Patchogue to Port Jefferson have been completed. The Patchogue, Port Jefferson, and Selden committees who have had charge of the construction of the path met recently to see how things were progressing. More than $500 has been raised toward building the path, and nearly all this sum has been spent.

The work of clearing away the snow that fell Sunday and Monday will probably be finished to-night. It is expected that to-day's work will complete the cleaning of the principal streets, and the work on the side streets will be left for the sun, or a providential rain. Even with the smaller area that will be covered by the cleaning, the last snowstorm will prove the most expensive New-York has had in many years.

A very bitter feeling exists between the Wurster-Willis and the Worth-Buttling factions of the Republican Party in Brooklyn, and from present indications the breach will be widened to-night, when the delegates to the National Republican Convention will be selected. So bitter is the feeling that both sides last night hinted that the price for delegates was going up, and one prominent officeholder remarked to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES:

The examination of Frederick W. Dunton, ex-President of the Bank of Jamaica, L.I., on the charge of misappropriating $10,000 of the funds of the New-York and Brooklyn Suburban Company of New-York while President of that corporation, was continued yesterday before City Magistrate Crane, in the new Criminal Court Building.

Again the British Government has been asked what it will do in conjunction with other Governments to try to restore stability to the ratio in value of gold and silver. Again the answer has been that it will do everything and anything in its power that does not involve the abandonment of the gold standard.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Consul General Crittenden reports from Mexico City to the State Department that American capitalists have purchased the entire street railway systems of the City of Mexico. The purchase price is stated to be $7,750,000, but the entire transaction, including the contemplated re-equipment of the lines, will involve about $20,000,000.

ALBANY, March 19. -- For the first time this session the Republican majority in the Senate to-day refused to stand by Leader Ellsworth, but flatly turned him down. The exhibition of revolt came when Mr. Ellsworth introduced a resolution directing the Assembly to return Senator Cantor's Acetyline Gas bill.

We find in The American Wool and Cotton Reporter of yesterday, the 19th inst., the following paragraph, which appears to have been written by the chief proprietor and editor of that journal, Mr. FRANK P. BENNETT, who was a member of LAWRENCE'S committee of the Wool Growers' Association, which recently prepared for insertion in the next McKinley tariff a schedule of wool duties even higher than those imposed by the act of 1890:

ALBANY, March 19. -- The Greater New-York bill is not to be passed by the Assembly until after the State Convention has been held and delegates have been elected to the National Republican Convention. It was the original intention to have passed it to-day, and it might have been carried out if the bosses had not listened to the threats of Brooklyn politicians.

Gov. Morton was indorsed for President last night by the Republican County Committee, after three of the members had voted against him, and one had declared that Major William McKinley would be the next President of the United States. The meeting was held at the headquarters, in West Thirty-eighth Street.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 19. -- "The McKinley wave," of which supporters of the Ohio candidate for President speak in such glowing terms, has no terrors for the Harrison Republicans of Indiana. They are not worrying, apparently, over the selection of delegates to St. Louis, and so far as surface indications go, are making no effort to stem the Buckeye tide.
PHILADELPHIA, March 19. -- This week's bulletin of the Racing Board contains the following:

A modest collection of seventy-two pictures, the property of Godfrey Mannheimer, are on exhibition at the Fifth Avenue Art Galleries (Ortgies Co.), 366 Fifth Avenue. On Friday evening of next week, March 27, they will be sold by auction at Chickering Hall, at which sale, it is announced, S.P. Avery, Jr., will assist.

ALBANY, March 19. -- Police Commisssioners Roosevelt and Andrews were here today in the interests of legislation affecting the New-York Police Department. They reached the Capitol while both Houses were in session. The privileges of the floor were extended to them.
ALBANY, March 19. -- Assemblyman Kempner to-day sent an open letter to Mayor Strong of New-York City in reply to his published interview favoring the Raines Liquor Tax bill. The letter is as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- There was a picturesque gathering in the President's office in the White House this morning, when a delegation of Kickapoo Indians from Oklahoma Territory had an interview with Mr. Cleveland about the severally law. They were attired in full Kickapoo regalia, and their faces were daubed with paint.

Justice MacLean, in the Supreme Court, yesterday granted a writ of mandamus to the Commissioners of Charities, compelling the Board of Managers of the Manhattan State Hospital on Ward's Island to accept P.J. O'Donohue, an insane patient, from the pavilion at Bellevue Hospital, regardless of whether he is provided with new clothing or not.

Mayor Strong was the guest of honor last night at a dinner given by James Macnaughton, President of the Tradesmen's National Bank, at the Wool Club, in the Wool Exchange Building, West Broadway and Beach Street. The club's comfortable and dainty banqueting room was decorated with palms and American Beauty roses, and covers were laid for threescore guests at a horseshoe table.

WHITE PLAINS, March 19. -- Referee Guernsey, in the Auditorium, to-day continued the investigation of the management of the Westchester Temporary Home for Destitute Children and of the charge of cruelty against Superintendent Pierce.

Besides her portrayal at the Garden Theatre last night of Nora Helmer, in "A Doll's House," Which was already known here, Minnie Maddern Fiske presented another study of character, quite as realistic, and, proportionately, quite as finely elaborated. The little play that followed Ibsen's was "A Light from St. Agnes," and Mrs. Fiske is its author.

Dr. R.K. Duncan, the distinguished electrician, has made a careful examination of the so-called pictures made by Rontgen rays without the presence of Crookes tubes. His conclusions, as stated in the current issue of The Electrical Engineer, are that all these so-called Rontgen pictures are produced either by heat rays or by the leakage of light rays through the porous cover of the plate holder.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- At the Hotel Page an important conference was held tonight between the silver Republican Senators who voted against the consideration of the Tariff bill in the Senate and a large number of representative manufacturers of Philadelphia, who favor the linking together of protection and bimetallism.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The sub-committee of the House Judiciary Committee, which has been engaged in the preparation of a bankruptcy bill, finished its labors at a late hour this afternoon. Its bill will be laid before the full committee to-morrow. The original Torrey bill, as amended in the Fifty-second and Fifty-third Congresses, serves as the basis of the new measure, which provides for voluntary and involuntary bankruptcy.
Sorosis held its chief festival of the year yesterday, the birthday of the society, as its members called it.

The steamer South Cambria of the New-York and Puerto Rico Steamship Company, which arrived yesterday morning from San Juan, Puerto Rico, brought news that an attempt was made on the life of United States Consul J.D. Hall by a Spanish soldier on March 4. Felix Taussig, one of the South Cambria's passengers, said:

The office of The United Press Local News whose service is taken, by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The Spanish Minister and brother officials have endeavored to brand the Cuban army as incendiaries for burning the canefields, stating that if the sugar crop was entirely lost, the loss to the Spanish Treasury on the possible crop of 600,000 tons would be only $450,000, or less than 1 per cent, of the war expenses.

The New-York Board of Fire Underwriters has in its possession a report on the dangers of acetylene gas, prepared by Prof. Henry Morton of the Stevens Institute, Hoboken. As a result of this report, the board resolved not to insure any building in which acetylene gas is regularly used.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- An effort will be made to-morrow by Mr. Sherman, Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations, to secure the assent of the Senate to a proposition to vote Monday on the conference report which favors the House substitute Cuban resolutions. While Mr. Sherman is hopeful of success, there are several Senators who are preparing to speak, and it is by no means certain that the plan will be adopted.

The amateur performance of "Patience" last night at the Metropolitan Opera House by the Metropolitan Musical Society, under the auspices of the Alumni Association of the University of the City of New-York, for the benefit of the university's athletic interests, brought out a large number of people prominent in society.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The communication by "New-Yorker" published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES this morning concerning the Palisades bill prompts me to send you. though unofficially, a word of explanation and encouragement for him and any of our friends who, like him, may be discouraged.

CHICAGO, March 19. -- The market showed a broader tone than for some time. A feature was the activity of Canal and Dock stock. West Chicago was again active, the buying coming nearly all from one source. Diamond Match sagged off to 145. New-York Biscuit was steady at 88@ 88 1/4. Bank clearings were $13,914,841. Money was firm at 6@7 per cent. on time and per cent. on call.

The lifelong practice of Republican thinking seems to have a curious effect on minds that in other matters are clear and sensible. The Evening Post publishes an interview with Mr. STUYVESANT FISH, President of the Illinois Central Railroad, in which that able and experienced man of affairs discusses the chief candidates for the Presidential nomination of the Republican Party, of which by conviction and heredity he is an attached adherent.

-- With the exception of the amateur performance of "Patience" at the, Metropolitan Opera House in the evening, in aid of the athletic interests of the University of the City of New-York, and the benefit performance in aid of the New-York Kindergarten Association at the Fifth Avenue Theatre in the afternoon, there was little of importance going on yesterday to interest society.

LONDON, March, 19. -- The Daily News will to-morrow say that the letter of Justice Brewer of the American Venezuelan Commisssion to the Arbitration Society is peculiarly welcome as evidence of the spirit in which the commission will conduct its labors. It ought to be suitably recognized.

SALT LAKE, Utah, March 19. -- The visit of Gen. J.S. Clarkson of Iowa, who is on the coast in the Presidential interests of Senator Allison, will have a marked effect in the National Convention. Some powerful interests are at work in California, Nevada, and other Western States in favor of the Iowa candidate.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I noticed in your issue of Saturday last the publication of an interview with Mr. John C. Sheehan on the Raines bill, wherein Mr. Sheehan expressed his opinion as to the constitutionality of that measure. Mr. Sheehan's remarks may serve as a text for the expression of a few thoughts.
The local Weather Bureau received the following instructions yesterday afternoon from the central office in Washington:

The Rev. W. Hay Aitken, the English evangelist who hopes his crowded midday services in old Trinity Church for the last few days have done much toward the conversion of Wall Street, was in this country over a dozen years ago and conducted a similar series of services in the same church.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- There has been confusion in regard to the identity of Sir Henry Stafford Northcote, now in Washington, on what is well understood in official circles to be an important diplomatic mission, some persons with better memories of names than of facts mistaking him for Sir Stafford Henry Northcote, his father, who was a famous diplomat, and who died in 1887.

The work which Mr. Frank Damrosch is doing through the agency, of his Musical Art Society is most wholesome. It is a happy thing that Mr. Damrosch, when he set about organizing this society, secured the pecuniary support of a considerable number of persons notable in the social circles of the city.
TRENTON, N.J., March 19. -- The House to-day passed the Track Elevation bill by a vote of 56 to 0, and the bill was sent to the Governor, it having previously passed the Senate.
ALBANY, March 19. -- The Senate Cities Committee has agreed to report favorably the substitute for the Page and the Pavey New-York City School bill.

From The New-Orleans Picayune. The alarm and anxiety that have been felt in this community for several days past over the threatened spread of small-pox are shown by the official report of the Board of Health to be less seriously founded than was supposed.
WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The following letter, dated March 12, in relation to the Arbitration Conference, has been mailed to over 1,000 representative men throughout the United States:

The trial of Chu Fong, proprietor and manager of the Chinese theatre in Doyers Street, was continued yesterday before Judge Fitzgerald, in Part IV., General Sessions. Chu Fong is charged with Sabbathbreaking and conducting a performance on Sunday.

The first part of "King Henry IV," was presented at Palmer's Theatre last evening by Mr. and Mrs. Taber, for the first time in many years. Indeed, the younger generation of playgoers knows not this play at all, from stage performances. In NewYork, since Hackett's time, there have been two actors of the greater Falstaff, Ben de Bar and John Jack, and the portrayal of neither ever received much attention, or is well-remembered now.

HOBOKEN, N.J., March 19., Detective Fenton to-day arrested a well-dressed woman in Washington Street. She was intoxiated. At Police Headquarters the woman gave her name as Miss Willy E. Martin of Chicago. III. She Said she arrived from Chicago Saturday. When she recovered from her condition later in the evening she said she thought she had been drugged. Daughters found in her possession hare the title; "The King's Daughters Central Legion.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 19. -- A local paper printed to-day the following:
