WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The trial of Benjamin H. Milliken, formerly clerk to Senator Harris of Tennessee, who is accused of having broken into the house of Judge Phillips the night of July 4, 1895, was resumed in the Criminal Court this morning.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 19. -- After two adjournments, the inquest which was held at the Town Hall to determine by whom Stephen Powell was murdered on the night of March 7, brought in a verdict to-night. The jury finds the two negroes, Wayne and Mayhew, who were yesterday indicted by the Queen's County Grand Jury, guilty.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The Navy Department gossips are discussing the next Intelligence Officer. A detail must be made shortly, for the present head of the Intelligence Office, Lieut. Singer, will join the Terror as its Executive Officer on April 15.

ALBANY, March 19. -- The Albany Institute, whose history dates back into the last century, becomes the owner of valuable property, bequeathed by the late John Tayler Cooper, Gen. Cooper's widow died last week, and though this means the articles go to the institute. Hers is an abstract of a codicil go the will:

BOSTON, March 19. -- Some of the local specialties were quite active, the gold minings and Boston and Montana being the leaders. Montana gained 1/2, to 79, and closed at 78 3/4. Pioneer Gold fell 3/4, to 8 3/4, recovering to 9 1/8. Santa Ysabel dropped 1 1/4, to 12 1/2, but advanced later to 14. Gold Coin lost 5, to 75c. Quiney was up 2, to 30.
A meeting of New-York Baptists was held last night in the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, at Thirty-first Street, in the interest of the New-York City Mission work.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met yesterday and divided the theatrical and concert license fund. Representatives of various charitable institutions were present. The number of institutions which were beneficiaries of the fund last year was 73, and this year to institutions were added to the list.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Secretary Morton's invitation to seedsmen for proposals to supply the seeds called for by the recent action of Congress has a humorous sound. He calls for packed seeds, the packages to be marked "Governmental and Congressional Seed Distribution."

No doubt there is some very sincere opposition to the bill abolishing the School Trustees of this city among people who have the interests of popular education at heart. There is always a certain proportion of good people who are attached to what they are used to and opposed to innovation, however strong the reason may be for making a change.

There is an elderly woman living an Brooklyn who is known as the Swami Abahayananda of the order of Sanyasin monks of India. Swami means monk, Abahaya means fearless, and nanda means bliss. The literal interpretation of her name is, therefore, the "Monk of Fearless Bliss."

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., March 19. -- The Seventh Congressional District Republican Convention was held in the Hotel Castleton to-night. It opened with a row. The fight was brief but lively, and ended in the withdrawal of the anti-Platt contingent, which was led by Martin Henley of the First Assembly District New-York.

A dramatic and musical entertainment of extraordinary merit was given at the Fifth Avenue Theatre yesterday afternoon under the auspices of a committee of ladies, for the benefit of the New-York Kindergarten Association. The single dramatic item on the programme was the comedy by Carlo Goldoni, called "Pamela Nubile," which was founded on Samuel Richardson's epistolary "Pamela,'' and was nearly contemporaneous with the book.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- John C. Coombs of Boston, representing the Credits Commutation Company, whose interests are situated in Sioux City, to-day appeared before the House Committee on Pacific Railroads for the purpose of seeing where he could attach the interests he represented to the plans suggested by other parties.

Four more jurors were secured in the Supreme Court yesterday before Justice Smyth in the case of Police Captain William S. Devery, who is accused of bribery and extortion. There were ten men in the jury box when the court adjourned, and it is expected that the list will be completed to-day.

The efficient and beneficial work done by the new Joint Traffic Association was the subject at review and congratulatory remarks at a meeting yesterday of the Presidents who compose the Board of Control.

ALBANY, March 19. -- The Senate to-day passed the Albany Police bill over the veto of Mayor Thacher. It has been a foregone conclusion that this action would be taken, because the Albany Police bill is a machine measure, and the machine is in absolute control. It will now attempt to drive Gov. Morton to signing it.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The proposition to establish a new stone dry dock at Charlestown, Mass., was argued at considerable length to-day before the House Naval Committee. Representatives Draper, McCall, Simpkins, Moody, Barrett, Knox, and Walker, and Senator Lodge were in attendance.
BERLIN, March 19. -- The Government's naval estimates were passed by the Reichstag to-day.

The Republicans of this city will air many of their grievances before the National Convention at St. Louis. The National party will be asked to look into Mr. Plait's methods in New-York. There will be plenty of contests to further weight the Morton boom.

The State Controller appealed yesterday in Surrogate Fitzgerald's court against the report of David McClure, as appraiser, in placing the taxable estate of the late Jay Gould under the Transfer act of 1892, a $80,000,000. In a later report Mr. McClure reduced the amount to $73,615,473.

BOSTON, March 20. -- The regular monthly dinner of the Massachusetts Reform Club was held this evening in Young's Hotel, about 125 members and guests being present. The President, George S. Hale, presided. The special guests were National Civil Service Commissioners John G. Proctor, John B. Harlow, and William G. Rice.

[Copyright, 1896, by Bacheller, Johnson Bacheller.] SYNOPSIS. "Our learned fellow-townsman" is the title given to Percy Marfleet by the local newspaper of the little English town in which he lives. He has been educated at Cambridge, comes back from the university, and settles down in the place of his birth to continue certain historical studies which give him a leading position in the minds of his fellow-townsmen.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down an opinion affirming the decision of the Board of Police Commisioners in dismissing Capt. William Strauss from the police force on Nov. 22, 1895.

The dissensions among the members of the Police Board because of the inability of Commissioners Roosevelt, Andrews, and Grant to promote Acting Inspectors Brooks and McCullagh to Inspectorships in consequence of the opposition of Commissioner Parker and Chief Conlin have reached a straining point, and yesterday the three Commissioners drafted amendments to the laws regulating the department, which, if passed, will give to them power to make the promotions.

TRENTON, N.J., March 20. -- The Senate Chambers were crowded with, women today, the occasion being the celebration of literary Day by the New-Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs. Every club in the State was represented. There were many expressions of regret heard among the fashionably dressed delegates when it was announced that Gov. Griggs would be unable to deliver the address of welcome.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The Republicans of the House have carried out their intention to censure Ambassador Bayard for his utterances at Boston, England, and Edinburgh, and the "incident" now may be considered closed. The resolution, which has been the subject of much uninteresting oratory in the last few days, was divided at the request of Mr. Willis of Delaware, so that two votes had to be taken to dispose of the matter.

The Commissioners of the State Reservation at Niagara, in a communication to the Legislature, have something to say of what has been done and may be sanctioned in future as affecting the property. The communication, which is signed by Andrew H. Green, President of the commission, says, among other things:

It is very questionable whether the American Minister to the Court of St. James will be disturbed in his mind to the extent of losing an hour's sleep or a meal upon learning that he has been censured in the present House of Representatives "by a strict party vote." The vote was not quite strictly partisan, for it appears that three Republicans voted against it and five Democrats for it.

ROME, March 20. -- A dispatch to La Tribuna from Massowah says that Gen. Baldissera, the Italian commander in Africa, has sent two battalions of infantry and a battery of artillery to Keren, to operate against the Mahdists.
CONSTANTINOPLE. March 20 -- An irade has been issued dasbanding the reserves, who, owing to the recent troubles, were summoned to serve with the colors.

But one day more remains in which people may see the admirable show that has been gotten together for sportsmen at Madison Square Garden. The attendance yesterday was far in excess of that on any one day since the institution of the exposition a year ago, and the longer the Garden remains open the more interested people seem to become in the matter.

Weber's opera, "Der Freischutz," was performed at the Academy of Music last light for the first time in nearly twelve years. It was last given in the first season of German opera, that of 1884-5, at the Metropolitan Opera House, under the direction of Dr. Leopold Damrosch. It was an appropriate thing that the work should come forward again under the management of the son of that earnest musician.

Opposition to the management of the Mining Exchange culminated yesterday at a meeting of members, continuing until dark, at which nominations were made for a new Board of Directors. There are nine places in the board. Ten names were proposed for them, as follows: R.A. Ammon, William Brandreth, C. Vey Holman, H.B. Day, W. L. Boyd, H.W. Stocker, E.M. Pine, W.L. Scrymser, J.M. Downing, and H.A. Mott. The election will be held to-day.

A few members of the Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, dissatisfied with the management of the affairs of that body, seceded fifty years ago and formed the Congregation Shaaray Tefila, (Gates of Prayer.) and last evening this congregation, grown to be one of the most influential religious bodies among the Jews of New-York, began the celebration of its fiftieth anniversary in its beautiful place of worship, the West End Synagogue, in West Eighty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The Sub-Committee on Reciprocity of the Ways and Means Committee has begun to receive replies from manufacturers, merchants, and commercial bodies throughout the country upon the questions in its circular of March 4.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The topic which has subordinated all others to-day in Washington has been the meeting last night between representatives of the "tariff barons" of Pennsylvania and the silver Senators, who have prevented the passage of the Tariff bill, and the bargain proposed, at that meeting for joining the issues of protection and free coinage.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Senior Andrade, the Venezuelan Minister, continues to be uninformed as to the progress of negotiations so vital to his own country in the boundary dispute, but since President Cleveland's message to Congress, resulting in the high commission, Venezuela is no longer inquisitive as to the means pursued by the United States to settle the matter, relying with confidence upon the good intentions of the United States.

LONDON, March 20. -- In the House of Commons to-day G.N. Curzon. Under Foreign Secretary, said that the Italian Government had communicated to the British Government the information that there was a prospect that the dervishes would make an attack upon Kassala, and pointed out the effect that such an attack would have upon Egypt.

A request was received from the Park Board at the meeting of the Aldermen yesterday asking permission to let contracts for repairs to the Speedway, without public advertisement, to the amount of $150,000. This was laid over for a week.

The New-York State Central Committee for Scientific Temperance Instruction in Public Schools, of which the Rev. John Hall is Chairman and Albert F. Newton is Secretary and Treasurer, is considerably concerned over the possible handling of the Ainsworth law at Albany.

1846. "It is the most dreadful spot on the American continent!" said a distinguished Frenchman who once visited the notorious New-York slum known as the "Five Points." The same opinion was expressed by Charles Dickens after going through this dangerous quarter with an armed police escort. The five points, in those days, was famous as the abode of thieves, thugs, and murderers.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20. -- Some of the Philadelphia manufacturers who were present at the conference last night, in Washington, with the silver Republican Senators, have worried over the import of the meeting in to-day's papers.

NYACK-ON-HUDSON, March 20. -- Charles L. Seabury Co.'s works is one of the buslest spots in this vicinity, many steam yachts, marine engines, and boilers being constructed. Charles Fleischmann'a 135-foot steam yacht Hiawatha is very nearly completed, and there is every reason to believe that she will go into commission early in May.

It is not at all surprising that the Ministerial politicians at Ottawa should find that in attempting to please everybody about the school question in Manitoba they have succeeded in pleasing nobody. Especially, it appears, they have displeased the Catholics of Lower Canada, who declare that they have not only been defeated, but tricked, because the Government feared the Protestant vote more than it feared the Catholic vote.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 20. -- The vote on the second reading of the Manitoba School Remedial bill was taken in the House of Commons at 6 o'clock this morning, the second reading being: carried by a vote of 112 to 94. The House then adjourned, after thirty-eight hours' continuous sitting -- one of the longest sessions on record.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 20. -- Mrs. Morris Triger, a German woman of Rochester, traveling with two children, aged two and three years, respectively, gave birth to a child to-night on the Hudson River Railroad train from New-York to Buffalo leaving the Grand Central Station at 7:30 o'clock. Conductor Hopper telegraphed from Peekskill for an ambulance to meet the train, but before its arrival the child was born.

The Trustees of Cornell University have decided to establish a College of Architecture. A successful four years' course will entitle students to a degree hitherto un-conferred in America, Bachelor of Architecture.

The Mayor of Albany is a Democrat, and the Republican Legislature has not only passed a bill taking from him the power to appoint Police Commissioners, but it has not paid the least heed to his disapproval of the bill, expressed in accordance with the requirements of the State Constitution.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 20. -- There will be a memorable celebration, interesting alike to Yale alumni and undergraduates, in this city Monday night next, when the sixtieth anniversary of the establishment of The Tale Literary Magazine will be observed, by a banquet and literary exercises.

Little girls, as well as cats, come back sometimes. Three little girls in plaid -- two with blue eyes and one with brown -- furnished a verification of the feline adage yesterday. The girls were Agnes Maher. fifteen years old, of 640 West One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street; Eileen Wilson, fourteen, of 475 West One Hundred and Forty-fifth Street, and Rosabelle Birckhead, fifteen, of 550 Mott Avenue.
Argument was heard yesterday in the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Justice Van Brunt presiding, on two cases brought to test the constitutionality of the Gray-Percy racing law.

HALIFAX, N.S., March 20. -- A dispatch from Puerto Rico states that the Norwegian steamer Johan Sverdrup, Capt. Monsen, from this port for Puerto Rico, is ashore on that island, and will prove a total loss. The Sverdrup is of 500 tons gross, was built in 1880, at West Hartlepool, and was owned by P.G. Halvorsen.
The Republican Assembly District Conventions for the election of delegates to the State Convention in this city next Tuesday, were held last night in all the Assembly districts of the city.

ALBANY, March 20. -- Assemblyman Bondy of Onondaga County to-day introduced a bill which proposes to fix the price of licenses for the sale of beer and ale at one-half the rates prescribed in the Raines bill.

BOSTON, March 20. -- The market for local stocks was generally quiet, the only activity being in the mining shares. Tamarack was the principal feature; it sold oft 10, to 100, and closed at 101. It was reported that dividends paid in the past year had not been fully earned. Montana rose 1/1, and closed at 78 3/8. Butte declined 1/8, to 1 3/8. Kearsarge was steady at 11 3/4.

Six Republican Senators of the United States on Thursday night met some thirty Republican manufacturers from Pennsylvania at a conference in Washington. These Senators are all agreed that there can be no tariff legislation at this session or during the next Congress unless free coinage of silver go with it.
The Commissioners of the Fire Department yesterday discussed freely Mayor Strong's action in the matter of pensions for firemen.

CHICAGO, March 20. -- Private Alien of Company A, Fifteenth Infantry, shot and fatally wounded Private Call of the same company in the post quarters at Fort Sheridan this morning. While being disarmed, Alien, was accidentally shot with his own revolver, and he also will probably die.

A vigorous campaign has been started in this city against "fake" auctions by the Association for the Suppression of Fraudulent Auctions. L. Andrews is Secretary of the association, and among its members are the firms of W. J. Sloane, Arnold, Constable Co., A.A. Vantine Co., Lord Taylor, Joseph Wild Co., and Van Gaasbeck Arkell.

BUFFALO, March 20. -- A conference was held here to-day between John E. Milholland of New-York and Mark A. Hanna of Cleveland concerning the McKinley movement in New-York State. The meeting was appointed by telegraph. Mr. Hanna arrived in the night and took a room without registering. No one was admitted to see him until Mr. Milholland's arrival, just before noon to-day.

The bill for the admission of New-Mexico to the Union has been reported favorably in the Senate, and the Committee on Territories has decided to make a similar report with respect to Arizona. In due time the Oklahoma bill, we presume, will be approved in the same way.
ALBANY, March 20. -- Assemblyman William Cary Sanger's "corrupt practices" bill was reported favorably by the Assembly Committee on Judiciary to-day. It provides:

FRIDAY -- P.M. The stock market to-day was extremely dull and prices were irregular. The talked-of coalition between the free-silver advocates and protectionists had little influence principally because it was recognized that such a combination would mean the disruption and defeat of the Republican Party. There was an entire absence of influential news.

CAPE MAY, N.J., March 20. -- The plan to unite with the Pennsylvania Railroad Company all the various lines in South and West Jersey operated and leased by this corporation is being favorably received by the stockholders of the smaller roads. About two-thirds of the stock-holders have consented to the merger and sent in proxies to the committee to consummate the scheme.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The contested election case of Alexis Benoit versus Charles J. Boatner, from the Fifth Louisiana District, was called up by Mr. Johnson, (Rep., Ind.,) Chairman of the Committee on Elections No. 2, who moved the adoption of the resolution reported by the committee declaring the seat vacant and that no valid election was held.

One of the largest congregations ever seen in old Trinity Church was the one that greeted Mr. Aitken, the evangelist, at the noontide services for business men yesterday. The spacious edifice was packed with people, and policemen stood at the doors to prevent overcrowding.

The Governor has been rather a stickler for refraining from any exercise of his influence upon the Legislature for or against pending measures, or even expressing his opinion about them, in advance of legislative action. And yet he took the very unusual course yesterday of sending in a special message urging the prompt passage of the bill for reforming the school system of this city.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections this morning made a favorable report on the amendment to the Constitution providing for the election of United States Senators by a direct vote of the people. The report is very voluminous. Among other things it says:

ALBANY, March 20. -- Gov. Morton has taken a hand la the solution of the question of school management in New-York City. He believes the Trustee system, as it now exists, ought to go, and he said so frankly, in a message to the Legislature this morning. It was read in the Senate, and was ordered printed.

The eleventh and twelfth jurors were secured yesterday in the Supreme Court, before Justice Smyth, for the trial of Police Captain William S. Devery, on the charge of extortion. The completed jury is as follows:

John Most, the arch-Anarchist and wouldbe slayer of Kings, has resolved to renounce the work of spreading the doctrines of the followers of the red flag in his usual style, and to devote his energies as peacefully as possible to the drama.

The fashionable folks of New-York left their Lenten Browning readings, their history and parliamentary classes, their sewing for the poor, receptions and teas, and devoted themselves to dolls yesterday. It was the first day of the model doll show at Sherry's, and the elegrantly dressed Madames and chic little Mademoiselles of the doll world received their visitors, many of them with literally outstretched arms.

Messrs. Adrian H. Muller Son have sold for Henry O. Havemeyer the three four story brick buildings 43 to 47 Broad Street, 63.4 by 128.5 by irregular. The plot contains 8,500 square feet. Mr. Havemeyer bought the property of Charles E. Runk and D.B. Freedman on Oct. 26, 1894, Mr. Runk taking a lease of it until May, 1900, at $15,000 per year net.

As a result of recent meetings in this city, representatives of the transcontinental railroad lines have practically determined to revise the old Pacific Mail Steamship agreement. The details of the arrangement have not yet been settled, but sufficient progress has been made in the negotiations to warrant the belief that the relations which existed prior to the dissolution of the old Transcontinental Association will soon be resumed.

The controversy between the Charity Commissioners of this city and the Superintendent of the Manhattan Hospital over the requirement that insane persons transferred from Bellevue Hospital to the State institution shall be provided with new clothing has not been conducted in a very seemly manner.

XVIII. The Case of Thomas W. Dorr. The little State of "Rhode Island and Providence Plantations," the smallest in the Union, one of the original thirteen, and the last of these to ratify the Federal Constitution, presents in its history a curious view of the growth and change of political institutions.

WEDNESDAY, March 25 -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, Phil M. Leakin, referee, leasehold of triangular plot at northeast corner of New Chamoers and Chestnut Streets, 34.4 by 44.11 by 31, four-story brick tenement, with store. Due on judgment, $3,465.

We spoke a week or two ago of the disgraceful and dangerous condition of the water supplies of two capitals -- Washington and Albany -- and remarked that the influence of legislators in each of these cities should be exerted to procure the substitution of good water for the contaminated fluid that gives both capitals shameful prominence as centres of typhoid infection.
The committee that has had charge of the U.S. Grant statue that is to be erected in front of the Union League Club, Brooklyn, met in the clubhouse last night and finished its work.

PARIS, March 7. -- Theatre de la Renaissance. "La Figurante," a comedy in three, acts by Francois de Curel. The author means to command whatever degree of fame he covets by legitimate means, and by these only. To my knowledge, his plays number only five, including the " Figurante." The "Envers d'Une Sainte," the "Fossiles," the "Invitee," and the "Amour Brode" have had the highest recognition in these columns.

A hearty and generous response has come from the women of the United States to the appeal of the Armenian Relief Association, which seeks to aid the 300,000 starving people of Armenia, mostly women and children.

SUMMIT, N.J., March 21 -- An enjoyable entertainment of Scotch songs and readings was held at the Madison Webb Memorial Chapel Thursday evening for the benefit of the Young Men's Christian Association Library Fund. Selections from "Beside the Bonnie Briar Bush," by Ian Maclaren, were given by James McArthur, editor of The Bookman.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- The son of a farmer is to marry next month the daughter of a cabinetmaker; and in the name of all that is sensible, why not? Nevertheless, there is likely to be considerable fuss made about the match, for the cabinetmaker is immensely rich and the farmer no more so than farmers way out in Iowa are wont to be.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 21 -- A concert was given in the Church of the Sacred Heart, Bloomfield, Thursday evening, by the choir of the church, under the direction of M.J. Toohey, the organist. The special artists were J. Ignatius Kavanaugh, organist, and T.W. McDermott, violinist, both of Philadelphia; Miss M.T. Toohey of Newark, soprano, and John J. Brady, baritone.

ORANGE, N.J., March 21 -- Plunket Greene gave one of his enjoyable song recitals before a large audience in Music Hall to-night, under the auspices of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Young Men's Christian Association.

The Wellesley College Gymnasium presented a rather unusual appearance on Saturday evening, Feb. 15, when the class in Constitutional History, under the direction of Prof. Kendall, gave a representation of the English House of Commons. In the centre of the hall were seated, to right and left respectively, the members of the class who represented the Conservative and Liberal Parties.

Some one blundered, and a collision, involving horrible possibilities, occurred yesterday afternoon on the high curve of the elevated road at One Hundred and Tenth Street and Columbus Avenue. The structure at this point is nearly 100 feet high.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 21 -- On Wednesday evening the Missionary Bund of the First Reformed Church gave a literary entertainment, which was of a pleasing character.

No system more simple -- or more difficult of execution -- could be devised than that which the Baptist ministers are advised by one of their number to follow in the treatment of matters political. They must not, he says, advise the members of their congregations how to vote, but simply tell them the truth about the issues involved in any particular election, and leave the rest to individual judgment.

The Malby bill amending the Ainsworth act of last year, which makes the study of the effects of "alcoholic drinks and other narcotics" a requirement in the public schools, has been recommitted in the Senate for a public hearing. The Malby bill is a mitigation of the Ainsworth act, but it would not remove the objections to such mistaken legislation.

The present condition of Republican politics in this State is calculated to induce reflection on the part of Gov. MORTON. There is a convention next Tuesday at which he will appear as the favorite son of New-York. New-York has been a long time finding out where her affections centred, but never mind.

The information given below as to the Raines bill and Gov. Morton's attitude toward it was brought to this city from Albany yesterday. It was given to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES as coming from absolutely reliable and semiofficial sources:

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., March 21 -- A new argument against the Raines bill has been raised by the Rev. R.G. Quenell, rector of Christ's Episcopal Church of this city. Mr. Quenell said to-day that, so far as he had been able to learn, the author of the bill failed to make any provision whereby fermented wines can be used in the administration of Holy Communion.

FLUSHING, L. I., March 21 -- Henry A. Bogert, a wealthy resident of this place, and formerly counsel to the New-York Life Insurance Company, presented to the Seventeenth Separate Company of the National Guard of New-York a diamond medal ten years ago, to be awarded to the best-drilled man, if won three consecutive times.

LYNBROOK, L.I., March. 21 -- The members of the Long Beach Life Saving Station are suffering with what has been pronounced by many of the old seamen to be ship's fever, said to have been contracted from the crew of the schooner Mary E. Walker, which went ashore on Long Beach about ten days ago.

The Society of American Artists will make an innovation in the matter of receptions this year, in place of the ordinary opening a public varnishing day will be held on the model of that of the Paris Salon, invitations to which will be strictly limited, and to which the public will be admitted on payment of one dollar.

An executors' sale of the medical library, surgical instruments, electrical appliances, skeletons, sporting goods, , of the late Dr. S. Fleet Speir of Brooklyn, took place at Silo's auction rooms, on Liberty Street, yesterday. The sale brought together a remarkable admixture of medical men, speculators, and sportsmen.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 21 -- Owing to the heavy rains of Tuesday and Thursday, the members of the Ocean County Hunt and Country Club had to be content with one run only this week. It took place this afternoon, under a Summer sky and under most favorable weather conditions. The country selected for the run to-day was especially attractive to cross-country riders.

The railroad list remains practically unchanged; the industrials have fluctuated. In them the trading has been active, but the railroads have shown nothing beyond a little professional work of no special significance, beyond indicating that long stock is not easy to dislodge despite a certain gloomy feeling about the commercial situation.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 21 -- A labor riot which resulted fatally to one man and the injury of several others took place here this evening on West Washington Street, the rioters keeping up a running fight for more than a square and creating intense excitement on the crowded thoroughfare.

From The London Times. The latest issue of The Kew Bulletin contains two interesting reports on the cultivation and preparation of the so-called pickled or leppett tea of Burmah one from the Northern Khan States, the other from the tipper Chindwin.

Our London correspondent gives in his cable letter a very interesting and plausible view of the political events of a very eventful week. What is especially striking is his account of the manner in which Mr. CHAMBERLAIN, becoming weary of the absurd pretense that it was necessary to send a new expedition to the Soudan to defend the settlements from the dervishes, let the "imperial" cat out of the diplomatic bag.

As a result of a discovery made by Inspector Meaney, a Government official, on duty at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, charged with the investigation of all contract work, the Delaware Construction Company of Wilmington, Del., has been notified to suspend work on a causeway in the navy yard which it has the contract to build at a cost of $75,168.

FLUSHING, L.I., March 21 -- A religious reception took place at St. Joseph's Convent yesterday afternoon, when the following took the white veil and were admitted as novices into the community: The Misses Alexia C. Gleason, Mary E. Ryan, Ellen L. McNamara, Catharine M. Conlin, and Louisa G. Weir of Brooklyn; Elizabeth C. McCann, Margaret E. Smith, and Anna Maria Dowd of New-York, and Elizabeth M. Reilly of Binghamton, N.Y.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 21 -- Two games were played by the New-Yorks to-day. Manager Irwin said to-day that if such weather lasted every man in the team would be ready next week to play professional ball. All the pitchers let themselves out to-day, and will from now on. Seymour's speed proved wonderful, and surprised even Manager Irwin.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., March 21 -- The members of the Union County Country Club varied the monotony of Lent by giving a stag dinner on Tuesday evening in the Casino of the clubhouse. The toastmaster was S. St. John McCutchen, and the speakers were Mayor Gilbert, ex-Mayor W.L. Saunders, E.C. Perkins, and C.C. Burnett.

Vienna Dispatch in The London Times. In connection with the approaching millennium exhibition. Prof. Vambery of the Buda-Pesth University delivered a lecture here on the origin and development of the Magyar race, to which he has for many years devoted special study.

Three big yachts are being built at Morris Heights by the Gas Engine and Power Company that will attract considerable attention this Summer. Two are cabin naphtha yachts, and the third is a steamer. The two naphtha yachts are being built from the same plans, and only differ a little in the interior fitting's.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 21 -- Newport's season is to open fully two weeks earlier than usual, and everybody has therefore begun to have his Summer residence got ready for occupancy. In fact, it is doubtful if ever before as early in the year as this was there so much activity in and about the cottages.

The Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railway Company, one of the thirty-two railroad companies defendant in the suit of the United States against the Joint Traffic Association, has filed its answer with the Clerk of the United States Circuit Court.

SATURDAY, P.M. Notwithstanding lower prices from London, the market showed considerable strength to-day. The improvement was due to the covering of short contracts by traders who were indisposed to carry open obligations over the weekly recess.

LENOX, Mass., March 21 -- Baron Thielmann, the German Minister, was in Lenox this week. He leased the Oliver cottage for next season. It is located opposite Trinity Episcopal Church. Baron Thielmann came to Lenox last season for the first time, and he and the Baroness were pleased with the place so much that they decided to spend next season here.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 21 -- The work of painting the outside of the yacht Defender, which lies in Neptune Bay, has been completed. Next week painters will begin on the interior work. C. Oliver Iselin gave orders before he sailed for Europe, as THE NEW-YORK TIMES exclusively stated, that the Defender should be overhauled and in readiness for sailing by April 1.

The issue of postage stamps of the Republic of Cuba by authority of the Provisional Government has aroused the ire of the philatelists and the dealers in stamps in this country, who assert that the stamps have been issued for purely speculative purposes.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Rear Admiral John H. Russell, retired, is anxious to be paid hereafter the highest salary of his grade, on account of his past services, and he is making an effort before Congress to attain this object. At present, in common with other retired Admirals, he receives $4,500 per year.

ALBANY, March 21 -- Some time ago the statement was made in these columns that the prospect of completing the Capitol by contract was far from bright. Since that time nothing has transpired to change the situation. To complete the Capitol without the tower, as agreed upon by the Capitol Commission, two and a half million dollars is necessary.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Returns from all the refining works show that the total production of desilverized lead was 201,992 tons in 1895, as compared with 181,404 net tons in I894. The desilverized lead included 6,244 tons of hard lead. Desilverizers reported that 51.613 tons of their product were obtained by refining foreign base bullion in bond.

Charges of bad faith are made by representatives of the New-York State Central Committee for Scientific Temperance Instruction in Public Schools against the State Department of Public Instruction and certain leaders of education in the State who appear to have withdrawn their promised support from the compromise Ainsworth School Physiology bill and indorsed instead the Malby bill, to which the Central Committee is opposed.

The fashionable folks found pastime last week in sleighing and indoor skating. Beyond these two sports there was little else to entertain them. There will be little gayety this week, but after Easter Sunday the social calendar will prove far more interesting than it has for many weeks past, for there will be a large number of weddings, dinners, and luncheons and several dances.
A lecture on "A Visit to a Dead City in the Baltic" was delivered by Dr. Hasket Derby recently before the Catholic Union, in Boston.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- The market opened dull and lower, with the exception of West Chicago, ivhich seems pegged at 103. Diamond Match showed decided weakness at the opening, the first sale being at 144. The decline was steady until it touched 142 7/8, when it rallied and closed strong at 147. New-York Biscuit declined to 87, rallied again to 88 1/2, and closed strong.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 21 -- Some fresh proof that interest in matters scientific is confined to no one section of the country is found in the results of the Menage scientific expedition to the Philippine Islands, an expedition which has been fruitful for science. The expedition was fitted out by Mr. Louis P. Menage, a resident at the time of the City of Minneapolis, now a fugitive from justice in South America.
LEWISTON, Me., March 21 -- Chief Engineer W.A. Allen of the Maine Central Railroad, met an awful death here to-day.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Capt. Shoemaker, the head of the Revenue Marine Service, has induced the Secretary of the Treasury to extend the age limit of candidates for cadetships in that service. Hitherto young men over twenty-three years of age were not eligible for these positions.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., March 21 -- Charles H. Soltan, an employe of the United States Public Stores, at Washington and Laight Streets, New-York City, was arrested in this city this afternoon by Secret Service detectives. Soltan resides at 164 Twelfth Street, this city. He was arraigned before Police Justice Duffy, in the Second Precinct Police Station.

June 1, 1812, President James Madison sent a message to Congress which, after detailing at length the grievances that the United States had endured for years from Great Britain, he concluded as follows:

MALDEN, Mass., March 21 -- A special ecclesiastical court of the Episcopal Church will begin its sitting Thursday, behind closed doors, for the trial of S.R. Fuller, rector of St. Paul's Church, Malden, for alleged breach of canonical law, in his marriage last Summer to Miss Derby, a member of Trinity Church, Boston.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21 -- The feature to-day was the strength of Storage Battery stocks. The common advanced to 28 and the preferred to 30 on the favorable reports concerning the company's earnings. There was a better market for Choctaw, which advanced to 6 2/4. A better feeling exists since the announcement of the proposed financial rehabilitation scheme.

TUESDAY, MARCH 24 -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., executor's sale, Moses Taylor estate, as follows: 118 and 122 Fifth Avenue, the first being the northwest corner of Seventeenth Street, and 5 and 7 West Fifteenth Street adjoining, the parcels connecting in the rear and forming a '---'.

Lent is, rather paradoxically, one of the liveliest periods of the year in the club world of New-York, and has proved no exception to the general rule this year. The slackening of gayety which occurs with the opening of the penitential period releases numbers of men from social obligations and enables them to give more time to their clubs.

W.G. Grace, the champion cricketer, tells a story in which he was almost the willing victim of a bet he made with John Lillywhite. It was a benefit match, and, as the crowds always flocked to see "W.G." make runs, Lillywhite was anxious that the champion should get set. His consternation was great when he was bowled on the third ball of the match by J.C. Shaw.

The Republican State Convention for the election of delegates to the Republican National Convention, to be held at St. Louis, will be called to order in the Grand Central Palace, at Lexington Avenue and Forty-third Street, at noon on Tuesday by Charles W. Hackett, Chairman of the Republican State Committee.

Attorney General M.T. Moloney of Illinois began yesterday his inquiry in this city into the affairs of the Chicago Gas Company. He has a suit in Chicago against the Fidelity Trust and Safe Deposit Company of Philadelphia, the Central Trust Company, and the Chicago Gas Reorganization Committee, charging violation of the Illinois statute which prohibits the consolidation of stock companies.

From The Westminster Gazette. The result of a most interesting experiment in the direction of the municipalization of the liquor traffic has just been ascertained after a trial of many months. The experiment has been made by Mr. Lees, Secretary to the Water Department of the Birmingham Corporation.

ELLICOTT CITY, Md., March 21 -- An explosion of dynamite here to-day resulted in the death of two men. Persons fifty yards away were thrown to the ground, so great was the concussion, while windows were broken, and goods in a number of stores in the town were thrown from the shelves.

ORANGE, N.J., March 21 -- The Domestic Training School, the institution of which many of the fashionable housewives of the Oranges have been dreaming for the past year or more, was at last formally opened this week, and is now in full operation at the building, 432 South Main Street, formerly occupied by the Shepard School of Music, and which is admirably arranged for the purpose.

The Cunarder Campania, which, with fair weather conditions, arrives on Friday nights, frequently in time to land her passengers, did not reach port until yesterday morning. Speeding in her wake was the American Line steamship New-York, which had been overtaken by the Cunarder at 3:15 A.M., when 150 miles east of Sandy Hook.

Every boy in the country, doubtless, remembers the exploit of a young athlete who won fame a few years ago by wheeling around the world on a bicycle. Now the same journey is to be made with, a rig still more remarkable. A couple of enterprising lads in North Dakota actually propose to trot around the earth with a team of dogs.

A commercial traveler of France who saw Menelek in Abyssinia last month was at dinner with a friend in West One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street Sunday, and it surprised him that there were forty callers, at least, in the evening to hear him say how Menelek looked and Menelek talked.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 21 -- At the big annual basket ball between the sophomores and the freshmen of Smith College to-day for the first time in the history of the college the freshmen were victorious. The game was called at 4 o'clock. The innings lasted fifteen minutes each. At the end of the first half the score stood 11 and 4 in favor of the sophomores.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 21 -- The golfers were favored to-day with ideal weather for their customary contest for the silver loving cup presented by James Converse. As the competition closes April 4, and Jasper Lynch and James W. Morey are tied for first place with three victories each much interest was shown to-day in their playing.

From The Saturday Review. The inevitable has happened to the Salvation Army experiment in America. It is possible for this curious organization to maintain much of its original character and repeat most of its native successes without much variation in British colonies, like those of Australasia and Canada, where the population and customs are almost wholly British, but in the United States only one of two conditions was possible for it.

Much interest is being shown by the members of the Protestant Episcopal Church in this city, and particularly by the parishioners of Calvary Parish, in the consecration of the Rev. Dr. Henry Yates Satterlee as the first Bishop of the newly created diocese of Washington, D.C., which will take place next Wednesday in Calvary Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., March 21. -- For the last two days there has been held an "Agricultural School and Institute for the Promotion of the Agricultural. Horticultural, Dairy, and Other Interests of Westchester County," in Sunset Hall.

George Hecht, a small, nervous, round-Shouldered man, with sharp brown eyes, who has kept a drug store at 165 Rivington Street thirty years, engaged a new office boy and drug clerk Feb. 9. The little man had had trouble with his clerks before and he was specially careful to make proper inquiries about this one.

BRISTOL, R.I., March 21 -- The Herreshoffs have received two additional orders this week from New-Yorkers for thirty-footers in the Larchmont restricted class. There are at present four of the thirty-footers completed at the Walker's Cove Marine Railway, while in the north shop there is another completed, so that it may be taken from the shop to the cove any day now.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Henry Yates Satterlee, the new Bishop of Washington, comes to a diocese embracing thirty-eight parishes, and a population exceeding 314,000. It was erected within the bounds of the old diocese of Maryland by dividing the latter and forming a diocesan jurisdiction from the District of Columbia with the four Maryland counties of Charles, Prince George's, Montgomery, and St. Mary's.

BELLPORT, L.I., March 21 -- Threescore years and ten is an age that is usually reached and often surpassed in this village. Ten per cent. of the present inhabitants of the village are over seventy years old, and many are over eighty. Many others, who are between sixty and seventy years old, are classed as young, and their appearance indicates that they will reach the age limit ascribed to man.

From The London Times. The work on Herr Andree's balloon is proceeding rapidly at Gothenburg. The upper half is already sewed together, and the parts of the lower half are out out. Upward of 100 trials of the stability of the texture and of the seams have been made, with the result that the cloth is found to be much stronger than contracted for, and that the seams are still stronger than the cloth.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I am but one of many who must feel grateful to you for printing in your issue for to-day, and to "H.R." for writing the arraignment of The Evening Post's critic for his spiteful attacks on Mr. Damrosch.

WEST POINT, March 21 -- Over a dozen army officers gathered in Room No. 210, New Academy, this afternoon, to witness the photographing by the Rontgen process of James Gruber's wounded arm. Gruber received his injuries on Washington's Birthday, while firing a salute. His wrist bones were fractured, and the metacarpal bones crushed.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Lord Salisbury has cabled the British Embassy here that a memorandum embodying the correction of minor clerical errors in the argument of the Blue Book on Venezuela will be forwarded for delivery to the United States Government, adding that, while the modifications are of no great importance, they materially add strength to the British statement.

BERLIN, March 21. -- The strong difference of opinion between Dr. Miquel, Prussian Minister of Finance, and Count Posadowsky-Wehner, Imperial Minister of the Treasury, over the question of the disposal of the year's surplus of the imperial revenue has come very near producing a Cabinet crisis.

Mr. H. Galitzka has sold for C. Hagedorne at $15,500, the four-story brick double flat 333 Third Street; for Mary A. Robintun, at $10,000, the similar building 43 Cheever Place; for H. V. Aiken, at $13,500 the similar building 429 Seventh Avenue, and for Mary A. Robinson, at $4,000, the three-story frame flat 56 Cole Street.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The largest entertainment of the week was the dinner and reception in honor of the Secretary of State and Mrs. Olney given Tuesday night at the British Embassy, where hospitalities have been few and far between the past year. Her Majesty's embassy is an imposing place, and a company gathered in its drawing rooms and ballrooms takes on a brilliant look.

From The Quarterly Review. But some clever guesser boldly said that the "Jerusalem" was a corruption of the Italian girasole. It is not known who first started this derivation, but we have found it nowhere earlier than in a forgotten yet delightful gardening book, "The Manses Garden," written by Nat. Paterson of Galashiels, in 1827, a book full of humor and excellent gardening instruction.

It was during the reign of the last of the Georges that Mrs. Frances Trollope paid us a visit in 1830. Our ruler was Jackson, and she wrote a book about us, and just now this lady's life and literary work have been written up. Mrs. Trollope came to the United States in order to make her living, as she had an undoubted right to do.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 21 -- This old and historic village, twenty-two miles from the great metropolis, in Westchester County, is a rapidly growing place, as is attested by the number of new houses continually in course of erection, its beauties of scenery and general desirability as a residential place having attracted a large number of the wealthy business men to its hills and vales.

BOSTON, March 21 -- John G. Proctor, President of the United States Civil Service Commission, delivered an interesting address on the general subject of the civil service before the Colonial Club in Cambridge this evening. President Eliot of Harvard University presided, and among the audience were many of the Faculty or the university.
HACKENSACK, N.J., March 21 -- Albert J. Voorhis of Berry Street celebrated his ninety-third birthday on Thursday.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 21 -- It became known yesterday that Judge Woodward would shortly pronounce sentence of death on the colored man, Nelson Miller, who was some time ago convicted of being implicated in the Mountain Cut-Off murder, Oct. 9, 1894, near this city. Four persons were at the time killed and six injured by the use of dynamite.

The orthopaedic and children's ward of the Post Graduate Hospital, at Second Avenue and Twentieth Street, was crowded with visitors yesterday. All the friends of the little people were out in full force to see how the little sufferers are being treated.

An enormous crowd was at the Garden last evening to bid good-bye to the Sportsmen's Exposition. On Monday the last traces of the show that has furnished so much in the way of enjoyment to so very many thousands of ladies and gentlemen will be moved out of the Garden, and the stuffed beasts of this week will give way to the live beasts of Barnum's show, which will be in the Garden next week.

There were two men well disposed toward George Popham. One blended a certain respect with his liking, the other's was a shade contemptuous. Popham had a slowgoing, plodding steadiness, which, directed to business affairs, became almost 2 genius for routine. In the privacy of his meditations, Edward Morley admitted that a quarter of the fellow's Industry would have quadrupled his own success.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- All the old and worn subsidiary silver coin of the United States will soon, be replaced by the new design adopted in 1892. The progress being made in that direction by the United States mints is most encouraging to Treasury officials.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- The jury in the casa or W.J. Webber and his brother, J.G. Webber, charged with conspiracy to kill E.V, Hamlin, Secretary of the Kilmer Bale Tie Company, returned a verdict of guilty against both men this afternoon. After the Court had given both prisoners undeterminate sentences, W.J. Webber was stricken with paralysis, and fell to the floor unconscious.

In the Capitol Gallery at Washington are a score or more of statues of American statesmen, sages, and heroes, about which cluster most inspiring and instructive historical memories. Congress provided for these statues some years ago, permitting each State to contribute two of her most famous men in either marble or bronze, at the National Government's expense.

A truce was patched up yesterday between the New-York State Commission in Lunacy and the Commissioners of Charities of this city in their fight over the question of new suits of clothes for persons committed to the Manhattan State Hospital for the Insane on Ward's Island.

Albert Chevalier, the famous singer in the music halls of London of the loves and adventures of the costermonger, will appear in Koster Bial's Music Hall to-morrow night. This will be his first appearance in America.

The persons who crossed the Brooklyn Bridge about 6 o'clock last Monday evening will not soon forget the experience. Home of the women chought, after they had been thrown it, that Dante's Inferno was written half a dozen centuries too soon.

Many real estate brokers have been obliged to reckon with the weather as a factor during the past week. The combination of snow and rain and the resultant slush have deterred many house hunters from going their rounds. In spite of this drawback, however, the sales of dwellings reported during the week aggregated about a million and a quarter of dollars.

From The Phoenix (Arizona) Gazette. J. A. Hansford, a well-to-do farmer living three and a half miles east of phoenix, recently found the skeleton of an Aztec, a prehistoric man, one of the citizens who peopled this valley centuries ago, and placed it under a high state of cultivation, built cities, dug canals, and leveled the surface of the valley.

L. Loris, a Russian who was born in Kovno and educated in St. Petersburg, and who was arrested as a Nilist and thrown into prison, whence he escaped, only to be rearrested, told his story yesterday to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIME.

Dr. Robert L. Bowles, in an importan communication in The British Medica Journal, says that, while the Rontgen ray may not be present in direct sunlight a the sea level, they are probably a constitu ent of reflected light in high altitudes, par ticularly where there is abundance of snow.

This will be an important week in the theatrical history of the season, as four new plays are to be produced and a number of old favorites are to be revived at the leading theatres. The new plays will be presented at Palmer's, the Fifth Avenue, the Garden, and the Star Theatres, and at Daly's, the Harlem Opera House, and the American the bills will be changed.

In addition to their heavy correspondence and numerous engagements, ex-Commander and Mrs. Ballington Booth have been forming plans for organizing their new movement. Though it is only a few days since they opened their offices in the Bible House and notified the public of their intention to inaugurate a movement, they find themselves already at the head of an encouraging force.

LONDON, March 11 -- The backward peoples who still hear the fairies in the breeze and the rustling corn, and get anguish in their waking hours from the threats of the demons about them, have fallen upon evil days. West of the Vistula at least there is hardly any place left now in Northern Europe where they can follow their beliefs to logical conclusions without getting into sore trouble.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- For several years past Prof. W.J. McGee of the Bureau of Ethnology of the Smithsonian Institution has been making a careful study of the Indians of the Southwest of the United States and Northwestern Mexico, about whom hitherto little has been known to the public at large, or, indeed, to science.

From The Cleveland Plain Dealer. Mr. Edison was very fond of his old father, who was physically a giant and at sixty-five could outrun, outjump and out-do any soldier at Fort Gratiot, near where he lived. The elder Edison was very economical in his habits, and disliked anything that looked like extravagance or waste of money.

From The National Review. The specialist who is typified in O.W. Holmes's "Scarabee," the man who devotes a lifetime to acquiring abnormal familiarity with the manifest peculiarities of some obscure tribe of insects, does no direct harm to his fellows, and incidentally contributes something, however minute the contribution may be, to scientific progress.

If the proposition to amend the Raines bill made before it has been signed by the Governor, so as to permit the sale of malt liquors alone on payment of half the tax imposed upon the "traffic in liquors," is intended as a sop to any or the opponents of that measure, it will prove entirely ineffectual.

Chief Conlin late yesterday exercised his power of making transfers, details, and assignments for the first time since the Corporation Counsel decided that he alone, and not the Police Board, was vested with such power.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Mr. Morgan of Alabama, the Senator who believes that war with Spain would follow the adoption by Congress of resolutions favoring Cuban belligerency, and who would like to see the United States plunged into a war because of his belief that the country then would go to a silver basis, says he will call up Monday the joint resolution he introduced yesterday granting belligerent rights to the Cuban insurgents.

The office of a Confederate newspaper and a country Confederate newspaper at that, might not seem the choicest place in the world for the cultivation of literary ability. Yet, such was the training school of Joel Chandler Harris, whose entertaining stories of old plantation days have charmed hundreds or readers.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 22 -- The first athletic meet of a series of four to be given by the Williams College Athletic Association was held in the gymnasium yesterday afternoon. H. W. Fifer, '98, secured the most points and has a good lead in the contest for the cup which has been offered to the man doing the best work in the four meets.

One of the latest volumes of contemporary literature treats upon the important subject of babies. It is not a very large book -- merely a pamphlet. It has, however, the quality which goes into the make-up of the best literature -- truth. It is the annual report of the babies' wards of the Post-Graduate Hospital.

Little light was thrown yesterday on the cause of the accident Saturday afternoon on the high curve of the elevated railroad at One Hundred and Tenth Street and Columbus Avenue. The reticence of all the officials of the road and their refusal to discuss the subject makes it a difficult matter for the police to select any one in particular on whom to lay the blame.

MADISON, Conn., March 22 -- The way in which the opponents of the Rev. W.T. Brown, whose trial for heresy is to begin March 24, have been noting the alleged heretical assertions of the young pastor is interesting.

From The London Daily News. Mr. Barrett Browning, "egregio figlio" of the "grande e genialissimo poeta inglese," is the most popular man in Venice just now for the magnificent manner in which he responded to the request made to him to lend the Rezzonico Palace for the ball given in aid of the Society of the Croce Rossa -- a charitable association to which belongs some of the noblest Italian ladies.

Anstole France in E Echo de paris. There was a fountain that the gooseberry branches bordered, in the domain of Bourlemont, near the village of Domremy, a half league from the house on the hills where Joan of Are lived. The name of the fountain was Good-Fairies-Our-Lord. At the entrance to the forest was a tree the shadow of which wan large and beautiful.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., March 21 -- It is easy to Imagine, when walking down the straggling main street of Mamaroneck, that one is hundreds of miles from New-York. There is little sign anywhere of metropolitan life at this season of the year. The illusion that one is in a remote country village is greatly heightened by meeting in the street types of genuine old residents, who remain unaffected.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 -- Rear Admiral Makaroff of the Russian Navy, who was aboard the battleship Massachusetts during her builders' trial trip, speaking of the vessel's performance, said "I was greatly impressed by the care shown by the Cramps in studying the working's of the machinery with a view to improvements, if any might be made.

William Quan Judge. William Quan Judge, who was President of the American Theosophical Society, died of consumption. Saturday, at 325 West Fifty-sixth Street, in his forty-fifth year. He had been ailing for some time, when last May the disease which ended his life was determined.

Corp. Stevens of Company F was the one marksman to earn special distinction at the regular weekly shoot of the Seventh Regiment Rifle Club at the armory range Saturday evening. In the rapid-fire match he made a score of 88, which is the record for that style of shooting. This match is shot under particularly exacting conditions, reading as follows: "Time limit, one minute standing, one minute prone.

The revolution in Nicaragua, according to information received through, private channels yesterday, is more serious than the dispatches from that country indicate. The strict press censorship established by President Zelaya renders it impossible for news of any character, except that Which is favorable to the Government, to be made public.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the arguments of the anti-suffragist is that if women be allowed to vote the corrupt or purchaseable vote of women -- which even a suffrage fanatic would not be so unwise as to imply would not exist -- would be used as the purchaseable male vote is now used -- to further selfish ends and promote unwise and corrupt legislation.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 22 -- The Huguenot Wheelmen bowlers won two games last evening at the gymnasium from the Yonkers Bicycle Club's bowling team. The Huguenots have now played 10 games and won 12. Only one match remains to be played in the Westchester Cycle League tournament, which will take place to-morrow night at Tarrytown between the New-Rochelle Wheelmen and the Tarrytown Cycle Association.

We observe that many persons insist upon regarding Senator ALLISON as a "moderate protectionist," and are saying that for this reason they prefer him in the place of MCKINLEY as a candidate for the Presidency. This myth about the "moderate" views of ALLISON concerning tariff duties has survived the publication of much proof which should have disposed of it long ago.

United States Senator George C. Perkins of California has written a letter to the editor of a Republican paper in his State thanking him for sending him clippings from the newspapers in which his name was mentioned for the Republican nomination for the Vice Presidency, and adding:

BOSTON, Mass., March 22 -- Massachusetts Republicans are beginning to be "afraid" of Reed, and if the Maine candidate is wise he will spare no effort to bottle up William E. Chandler of Now-Hampshire. Mr. Chandler is writing Mr. Reed a bimetallist with persistency that suggests another motive than the desire to advance the Maine man's candidacy for the Republican nomination for President.

By the tariff law now in force cotton ties -- the bands of iron or steel used in baling cotton -- were placed on the free list. Immediately after it became known that the Wilson Ways and Means Committee intended to make this change, the high-tariff organs began to be filled with protests long, loud, and deep.

Preparations are now being made for the third American National pilegrimage to Rome, Lourdes, and the Continental shrines. The expedition will be under the spiritual direction of the leathers of Mercy of West Twenty-fourth Street, and is being organized by Mr. and Mrs. F.H. Throop of Brooklyn.

GLASGOW, March 14 -- The Riviera is at the present time not only the yachting centre of Europe, but it is the centre of fashion, and, what is of more interest to many people, it is the centre of royalty. Queen Victoria has just arrived at her favorite Mediterranean residence, Cimier, at Nice, and in that Mediterranean paradise are assembled the Prince of Wales and various less important notabilities.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 22 -- Mrs. Annie Colligan, wife of John Colligan, a saloon keeper at 74 First Street, had a desperate struggle with a burglar at 1 o'clock this morning and managed to hold him, despite the fact that they both fell down stairs during the struggle.

From The Westminster Gazette. The other day I told your readers the story of Bonelli, who secured the price put on the head of a well-known brigand by murdering an old pilgrim and palming off his body as that of the brigand. An even stranger story remains to be told about the brigand himself. Casanova, commonly called Cappa, was already dead when Bonelli was beheaded.
From The London Chronicle. The Sultan has ventured out among his faithful people, and, to his surprise, has reached his palace again unharmed.

Each day brings out some new objection to the Raines bill, or some new aspect to an old objection. The sugar-coating of promised supplemental legislation by which it is proposed to make the-dose more palatable to Gov. Morton will not suffice to make the "medicine" acceptable to many a Republican who considers himself as loyal to party as is the gentleman who occupies the Mayor's chair in the New-York City Hall.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., March 22 -- Miss May Wright, niece of Judge Wright of Trenton, N.J., has brought suit against Charles W. Lynde of Patchogue for alimony on a decree of divorce obtained in 1893. Lynde and Miss Wright was married in 1884 in Trenton soon after Lynde had been graduated from Princeton College.

A Cuba Liberty Festival in aid of the sick and wounded patriot soldiers attracted many sympathizers to the Grand Central Palace last night. There was a delightful programme of instrumental and vocal music and a spectacular fantasia with stereopticon adjuncts entitled "From Slavery to Freedom."

From The Richmond (Va.) Religious Herald. Among the many incidents of the olden time that interest us now. Dr. J. Russell Hawkins tells us of one that happened in James River, at the Falls of Richmond, in the year 1779. He assures us that many of the leading citizens of Richmond at that time were eye witnesses to the fact, and that he had it straight from them.
ITHACA, March 22 -- The ever-dreaded final examination week for the Winter term is now on and the campus has assumed the quiet, serious air which is always attendant upon this part of the term.
The University Club elected on Saturday five Council members and seven members of the Committee on Admissions.

Among the treasures in the rooms of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions was the collection of idols from the Hawaiian Islands. These images, all of the most hideous aspect and of strange composition, have for more than half a century attracted the attention of visitors.

PROVIDENCE, March 21 -- Local stocks have continued quiet, with prices ruling firm, and but few sales of importance. The bank stocks are in good demand. Among the sales of the week may be mentioned American National at 45@46. A small lot of Merchants' National has been sold at 64 1/2, and Atlantic National has changed hands at 36.

From The Westminster Gazette. A remarkable story of adventure has been told to M. Cochefort, head of the Paris Detective Service, by an escaped convict named Bourdet. According to his story, Bourdet, an engineer by trade, was sentenced to a long term of penal servitude in the year 1881.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 22 -- The 'Varsity crew has been taking its final practice in the tank this past week. The river is now clear of ice and the boathouses are in readiness for the crew. But it probably will not be ready to go on the water before Tuesday. The class crew, however, will get out to-morrow. The class races are coming early in May.

Herman Burkhardt, a bright-looking ten-year-old boy, told a pathetic story of destitution and desertion yesterday in the Jefferson Market Police Court. He was arraigned on a technical charge of vagrancy.

PART I. "And so you call this Prof. Rontgen's discovery 'wonderful'?" said the little French doctor, who looks about twice as old as he is, and seldom talks. "Pardon me. Monsieur, but he is an infant in science. There has been that discovered, beside which his photographs of skeletons are nothing -- things so strange that the world will hardly suffer them to be whispered.

LONDON, March 22 -- Lord Salisbury has written a letter to Sir James Stansfield, who was Chairman of the recent demonstration in Queen's Hall in favor of the principle of arbitration in all disputes between Great Britain and the United States, acknowledging the receipt of the memorial adopted at the meeting.

The Assembly Judiciary Committee has reported favorably the bill of Mr. HENRY CARY SANGER for the suppression of corrupt practices in elections. It is a very good measure so far as it goes. Its object is to turn the light of publicity on all expenditures for political purposes, and that is an excellent object.
When Warden O'Rourke of Bellevue Hospital was dismissed for alleged irregularities, it was rumored that the affairs at the Morgue would soon undergo an investigation.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 22 -- The fourth and last hall play of the year was given in Philalethean Hall on Saturday evening. The Amazons was the play chosen by the committee, which included Miss Mary Noxon Sanders, Chairman; Miss Gertrude Chesley, Miss Lilian Bayliss, Miss Helen Stamford, Miss Alice Evasion, and Miss Agnes Lee.

MONDAY -- A.M. The stock market was dull and prices showed a declining tendency London was not an important factor either way, but probably sold more than it bought. The effort to unite the free silver and protectionists interests has caused uneasiness abroad, and has induced a disposition to liquidate investments in this country.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 22 -- It is stated to-night that the Republicans who have been foremost in pushing Senator Davis as a candidate for President will immediately take steps to get him to withdraw. The returns are all in, and the victory which McKinley has scored in Minnesota is pronounced.

It seems just a little remarkable that CHU FONG, the manager of the local Chinese theatre, should have brought himself into disastrous conflict with Occidental laws by presenting a play, which, on authority so eminent as that of the United States Consul at Amoy, belongs to the Po-Yank, or "Virtue Rewarded," division of dramatic literature.

Mihram Dalmajian, an Armenian refugee who recently escaped from Turkey, is staying in an Armenian boarding house at 390 Third Avenue with two of the companions who escaped with him. There were four in the company, but one went West a few days ago to teach in a school.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 22 -- The Daily Princetonian, the undergraduate organ of Princeton University, has taken up the agitation for a new gymnasium, and, under the caption, "The Greatest Need of Princeton Students," published the past week a series of letters from physicians, trainers, and Captains of athletic teams, setting forth the imperative demand for a new gymnasium at Old Nassau.

HOBOKBN, N.J., March. 22 -- The senior inspection party, under the supervision of Prof. Denton, started on Monday afternoon for Danbury, it being, as anticipated, smaller than usual Prof. Denton had arranged an exceedingly fine programme.

The Central Turn Verein gave its annual exhibition and entertainment in the Assembly Rooms of the Central Opera House last night. The attendance was large, and the different features of the performance were heartily applauded. The different classes in athletics gave exhibitions of their skill, and all showed a high grade of proficiency.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 22 -- As soon as President Hill's refusal to withdraw his resignation was made known, the following, committee of the Board of Trustees was appointed to have charge of the selection of a successor: Dr. E.M. Moore, Sr., Elon Huntington, and Martin W. Cooke of this city, John P. Townsend of NewYork, and Prof. H.C. Vedder of Crazier Theological Seminary, Chester, Penn.

From The Minneapolis (Minn.) Tribune. Matt Carlyle, a famous stalker of the Rocky Mountains, whose home is somewhere in a gully between The Gap and Glacier, on Canada's side of the line, came into Minneapolis this morning and bought a supply of ammunition, as well as two Winchester rifles, from a local firm.

An analysis of the reports made to the Controller of the Currency showing the condition of the National banks in ten places on the 28th of February gives some interesting results as to the proportion of gold and silver in their specie reserve. The gold consists of gold coin, gold Treasury certificates, and gold Clearing House certificates, the latter item in New-York and Philadelphia only.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 22 -- The State Democratic Executive Committee has advised Gov. Foster that it is inexpedient to hold an election for a Congressman in the Fifth Louisiana District at the time the State election is held. The Governor will not issue a proclamation for the election of a Congressman in that district until after the general State election.

From The London Chronicle. Every one who has "done" the Louvre will remember the low-pitched and some, what gloomy halls in which are stored the treasures of Egypt. Beneath those lie yet more darkly mysterious vaults, inaccessible to the public, though approarhed by a wide and handsome staircase, such as would lead one to imagine that it communicated with apartments of some importnnce.

The first step in a plan to effect a reconciliation between the Ballington Booths and the leaders of the Salvation Army has been taken by Gen. William Booth, who has ordered Col. Eadie to "farewell" and return to London. In obedience to the General's order, Col. Eadie yesterday began his "farewell" services.

FORT MONROE, Va, March 22 -- The "man behind the gun" is being carefully and systematically trained in his duties on board the warships of the North Atlantic squadron, lying at Hampton Roads. In addition to the aiming and sighting drill, which enables a, man to determine his "personal error" and to make allowances for it, there is another very instructive drill which has been begun recently in the squadron.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 22 -- The Democratic State Convention will meet in Montgomery April 21. The Republican and Populite State Conventions will be held in the same place April 28.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 22 -- The game of basket ball between the freshmen and sophomores, at Smith's College, the score of which was printed in to-day's NEW-YORK TIMES, created much excitement, as the teams were so evenly matched.

MONACO, March 22 -- Most all the yacht racing on the Riviera thus far this season has been characterized by strong mistrals, or almost flat calms. The racing here to-day was perfectly uninteresting, owing to the fact that there was not enough wind to permit the yachts to finish before sundown. The regatta opened with the sun shining brightly and a faint breeze stirring.

ALBANY, March 21 -- The local security market during the week has been fairly active. In bank stocks 15 shares of National Exchange sold at par. A small amount of Albany Railway and Municipal Gas sold at current quotations. New-York Air Brake is down for the week 1/2 percent., with the stock offered at S. Hudson River Telephone remains very strong, sales being made at the highest prices yet reached.

On the third floor of the tenement house 343 West Twelfth Street yesterday, Mrs. Incarnation Rexach succumbed to a lingering malady which had threatened her life for months, and her husband, Antonio, once the heir of a proud and wealthy Spanish family, but now a humble cigarmaker, made a vain attempt to follow her to the grave.

The hotels are filling up with the delegates to the Republican State Convention to be held to-morrow. Many of the delegates yesterday had a close view of the famous New-York "dry" Sunday. All had heard of it, but many had never before experienced it.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- McKinley's "fatfrying" methods continue to annoy Senator Chandler. He has information that the Ohio candidate's managers are trying to raise $250,000 to make the nomination of their man certain, and he is determined to block the game if possible. He made a fresh onslaught upon McKinley to-night which abounds in good campaign material for the Democrats.

Wild March winds have been playing battledore and shuttlecock with westwardfaring craft. Of all the sailing fleet which made port yesterday not one escaped the storms which have been raging along the Atlantic coast, the gales blowing first from one direction and then from an opposite point of the compass.

From The Springfield (Mass.) Republican. A large amount of stolen property has been turned over to the Boston police by Charles S. Lecky, who was arrested Wednesday, and confessed to being a flat thief who has been operating in Boston for same time past. He says that he has been a thief only for the last two months, but he admits that in that time he has probably broken into twenty-five flats and houses.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 22 -- Frederick W. Herbst, who has been prominent in Republican politics in the State for several years, said to-night, when shown Senator Chandler's severe criticism upon the methods or the McKinley leaders:

BERLIN, March 22 -- There has been much quarreling over the property left by Emin Pasha, the some time Governor of the equatorial province of the Soudan, to rescue whom from the Mahdists Henry M. Stanley made his last trip to Africa.

ALBANY, March 22 -- There is no definite news here to-night as to the fate of the Raines Liquor Tax bill, but it is intimated that Gov. Morton will make known his action on the measure at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning.

Bacon of Norwich, and grandson of old Dr. Leonard Bacon of Yale. He spent his boyhood until 1877 in Germany and Switzerland. He was graduated from Yale College in 1881, and from the Divinity School in 1884. Ho took the Berkeley prize on admission to the freshman class, and in the junior year the second Winthrop prize, open to the classes of 'S1.

As an experiment the bowling tournament of the Long Island Association of Cycling Clubs proved a decided success and exceeded in interest the expectations of its promoters. It was managed by the Social Intercourse Committee, of which David M. Boe was the Chairman, William O. Tate Secretary and Treasurer, and F.G. Hedge.

The police bicycle squad had a field day Saturday. All but one of the force made arrests, and the entire force appeared in Yorkville Police Court yesterday with prisoners, one having arrested his man at 8:30 yesterday morning.

KEY WEST, Fia., March 23. -- The wrecking steamer George W. Childs, returned here this morning from a cruise to Cape Florida, reports that on March 19 the steamer Three Friends was lying alongside a larger steamer in Turtle Harbor. The large steamer had no name.
