In baseball annals Monday, April 13, is set down as "Harry Wright Day," and the recurrence of this anniversary will be suitably commemorated by a great baseball revival, or tournament, in the pretty little Illinois city of Rockford. From 1863 to 1871 Rockford was the cradle of the great American sport in the West.

JAMAICA, L.I., April 11. -- For many years, and until the Queens County Tax Arrears Commission came into existence, there was no logical system in the county for clearing up the arrearages of taxes upon lands in the different towns. Thousands of pieces of land in arrears were annually bought in by the towns because there was no other bidder at the annual tax sales.

YONKERS, N.Y., April 11 -- The man who was found off the sugarhouse dock by two fishermen yesterday morning has been identified by Mrs. Mary A. Berrlem of 407 Hawthorne Avenue as Joseph B. Jones. At the Coroner's inquest to-day Mrs. Berriem swore that Jones had resided with her from September until Feb. 7, when he disappeared.

Magistrate Cornell, in the Essex Market Police Court, yesterday requested Abraham H. Sarasohn to call the attention of the Bar Association to the alleged practices of certain lawyers in trying to secure clients in damage suits against the surface and elevated rcads.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 11. -- The excise law in Hudson County will, it is expected, be strictly enforced Sunday. The charge of Justice Lippincott of the Supreme Court to the Hudson County Grand Jury on Tuesday last was very strong against Sunday liquor selling in Jersey City and Hoboken.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The marriage of Miss Josepha Newcomb, daughter of Prof. Simon Newcomb, to Edward Baldwin Whitney of New-York, Assistant Attorney General, took place at noon, at the Church of the Covenant, the Rev. Tuenis Hamlin officiating. The bride is a very handsome young lady, and the bridegroom is the son of the late Prof. William Dwight Whitney of Yale College.
The Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman of the Temple Emanu-El preached a sermon yesterday morning which is likely to cause as great a sensation as did the plagiarized sermon of the Rev. Dr. Parker Morgan.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Chief Engineer A. G. Menocal of the Nicaragua Canal Company, reviewed before the House Commerce Committee this morning the report of the Board of Engineers which investigated last Summer the Nicaragua Canal project.

Many of the London papers are devoting a good deal of space and all the humor which the editors have at command to comments on the recent passage by the Ohio Legislature of a law to prevent women from wearing big hats at the theatre. Not since the Venezuela excitement died out has any American happening attracted from our cousins so much attention as this seemingly inconsequential and certainly rather absurd example of paternalism.

We referred some days ago to indications that the influence of the two Eastern Republican bosses, QUAY and PLATT, was being exerted to procure favorable reports from the House Committee on Territories with respect to the bills for the admission of Arizona, New-Mexico, and Oklahoma.

LONDON, April 11 -- Paris has a well-known trick of not doing what everybody agrees in expecting her to do, and this needs to be kept in mind now, because everybody is hearing some whispered phase of general suspicion that grave things are on the point of happening in France.

In baseball annals Monday, April 13, is set down as "Harry Wright Day," and the recurrence of this anniversary will be suitably commemorated by a great baseball revival, or tournament, in the pretty little Illinois city of Rockford. From 1863 to 1871 Rockford was the cradle of the great American sport in the West.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has been called to dispatches from Albany to your paper, giving account of an interview with State Engineer Adams. He was opposing the Mahany bill in Congress, appropriating $2,000,000 to widen the Erie Canal locks, and stated that I was the originator of the scheme, as also of the Mahany bill.

Next in importance to good roads to the touring wheelmen is the matter of guide boards. The one has been neglected as much as the other in this State, but through the intelligent efforts of Chief Consul Potter and other officials of the New-York Division both will show improvement in due course of time.

" The circus whip is of more importance than it seems. The ability to send the long lash flying in wonderful undulating curves, in and out, over and under, to the right or to the left of performing animals, and back again almost instantaneously, with a loud report, is the work of an artist.

JAMAICA, L.I., April 11. -- For many years, and until the Queens County Tax Arrears Commission came into existence, there was no logical system in the county for clearing up the arrearages of taxes upon lands in the different towns. Thousands of pieces of land in arrears were annually bought in by the towns because there was no other bidder at the annual tax sales.

The twenty-ninth games of the Seventh Regiment Athletic Association, held at its handsome armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Streat last evening, were as well managed, as successful, and as enjoyable as any that have preceded them. The armory was crowded with a bevy of handsome women, escorted by members of the regiment and veterans who always assemble to enjoy these games.

JERSEY CITY, April 11 -- United States Commissioner Isaac Romaine and Secret Service Agent Esquirel are trying to study out a mild swindle that developed at the Hudson County Jail during the week. One of the prisoners in the jail is James E. Wilson, alias Arthur Hammond. He came here last November to engage in the "greengoods" business, but some of the first circulars he sent out were returned to Chief of Police Murphy.

John L. Waller, formerly United State's Consul at Tamatave, Madagascar, who was condemned by the French to twenty years' imprisonment on a charge of having violated the Military Code of that nation by corresponding with the enemy regarding French operations in Tamatave, arrived from Southampton yesterday as a second-class passenger on the steamship New-York.

From The Toronto (Ontario) Mail and Empire. Judge Curran rendered an important judgment in Montreal a short time ago in the case of Ouellette vs. Sicotte. This was an action of damages taken by a former sexton of the Church of St. Vincent de Paul against one of the parishioners, whom he charged with having been the cause of his dismissal from office.
CINCINNATI, April 12 -- The following official statement is sent out from the offices of the Western Methodist Book Concern in this city:

Now, we have always held that Russia is entitled to an ice-free port in the Pacific. It is out of the question that so colossal an undertaking as the transsiberian railway could be allowed to end in a remote harbor frozen for five months in the year. Mr. Balfour, we were glad to see, declared that the Government would put no obstacle in the way of such an acquisition by Russia.

The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott preached last night in Plymouth Church on " Evolution and Miracles." The sermon was the sixth in a series on " The Theology of an Evolutionist." All the sermons in this series have attracted large congregations, but the degree of interest shown last night was unusual.
The Rev. Dr. M. Harris of Temple Israel, One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue, preached in Temple EmanuEl, Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street, yesterday morning.

BUFFALO, April 12 -- Aritono Yamagata, Field Marshal of Japan and Minister of War, arrived in Buffalo at 6:30 o'clock this evening, accompanied by seven of his countrymen. He was received by Gov. Morton's staff and was entertained at dinner to-night. The Japanese Consul General to the United States, K. Miyagawa, met the party at Niagara Falls and occupied Yamagata's attention with business matters until the train reached Buffalo.

We congratulate the people of Chicago upon the result of their recent municipal election. The old gang still controls the Council, it is true, by a majority vote, but it can no longer override the Mayor's vetoes. Owing to the election of a considerable number of honest men, there is at last ground for hope that the city will cease to be "the dirtiest, filthiest spot in the world."

HOBOKEN, N.J., April 12 -- New-Yorkers practically owned this city again to-day. The warm sunshine and balmy breezes of the morning acted as a stimulant to thirst, and thousands fled from the metropolis to the saloons, beer gardens, and music halls of Hoboken.

A determined effort is being made to defeat a bill now before the Assembly Committee on Cities, which, it passed, will make radical changes in the present Tenement House act. The proposed amendments are vigorously opposed by the departments of the City Government which have most to do with the buildings.

To all outward appearances there was not a saloon open in this city yesterday, but the Raines law was nevertheless evaded by many saloon keepers, who ran "speak-easies" in adjoining apartments. These places were in rear rooms, in cellars, and up stairs. At least one was on the opposite side of the street from a saloon.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 12 -- With all the solemnity and dignity befitting the occasion, the body of the late Right Rev. Bishop Ryan was removed this afternoon from his residence to the cathedral, where it will be buried Tuesday morning under the altar, beside those of his predecessor, Bishop Timon, and the late Vicar General Gleeson.

BERLIN, April 12. -- Prince Hohcnlohe will meet Emperor William in Vienna Tuesday, prior to the Court dinner, which will be given in honor of the Kaiser. The Austrian Ambassador here, M. de SzogyenyMarich, will go to Vienna to take part in tne conferences which will be held during the Emperor's two days stay at the Austrian capital.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., April 12 -- The change of one vote in the recent election in the town of Brookhaven would have saved, two candidates considerable worry and the town the cost of a special election. Brookhaven's town charter provides that the President of the Town Board of Trustees shall be elected by the people.

April 12. -- The programme of the movements of the Emperor in Venice, as received here last night, fixed the official exchange of visits between the Kaiser and King Humbert for to-day, which, formal visits are to be followed by an interview between the two monarchs, the highest members of the Italian Ministry, the Italian Ambassador to Germany, and the Ger- man Ambassador to Italy.

TACOMA, Washington, April 12 -- The Rev. Father Tosi, in charge of the Catholic missions on the Yukon River, has returned to Juneau, Alaska, after making an extraordinary trip of 2,000 miles from Kozizefski, his station on the Yukon, through the Aleutian Archipelago, to the most northern point of Alaska, Point Barrow.

Cornelius Vanderbilt and Chauncey M. Depew got back yesterday from their long Western trip. Neither of these much-traveled men, who have seen most of the rest of the world, had ever been in California, and Dr. Depew, in particular, was full of enthusiasm over what he had seen.

DANBURY, Conn., April 12 -- This city was the scene of a shooting affray early this morning that may result in a double murder. One man is dead and another is dying in the hospital. William Flitcroft, who did the shooting, is under arrest. His victims were Frank Ketchum of 31 Osborne Street and Willis Tomlinson, who boards at 62 Beaver Street.

HAVANA, April 13. -- Col. Tort reports that the column under his command has had a series of fights with 2,000 insurgents, led by Masso, Castillo, and others. The scene of the engagements was south of Guira de Melena, in the southwestern part of the Province of Havana.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 13. -- It is announced this evening that, acting on the advice of his physician, ex-Speaker Crisp has been compelled to give up his appoinments for speaking. He and Secretary Smith have met in four joint debates, and since the second one, which was at Atlanta, Judge Crisp has suffered in health.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The President today nominated ex-Gov. Fitzhugh Lee of Virginia to be Consul General of the United States at Havana, Cuba, vice Ramon O. Williams, resigned. This nomination was predicted in dispatches to THE NEW-YORK TIMES this morning.

PATERSON, N.J., April 13. -- Two attempted highway robberies, accompanied by considerable shooting, occurred here late this evening. One of the highwaymen was captured. One of the men attacked was shot and had to be sent to the General Hospital.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The Judiciary Committee of the Senate lost no time in disposing of the joint resolution, referred, to it last Thursday, proposing a remonstrance with the British Government in the matter of the imprisonment of Mrs. Maybrick. The joint resolution was reported back to-day adversely, on the ground that the Senate had no jurisdiction over the subject.
A most successful athletic meeting was held last evening in the Fourteenth Regiment Armory, Brooklyn, by the Fourteenth Regiment Athletic association and the Bay Ridge Athletic Club.

It has long been the practice under the election laws of this State to destroy the ballots after they have been counted and the returns have been made up on the night of the election. This shuts the door to fraud by recounting after the general result has become known and is capable of being thrown into doubt by disputes in one or more districts.

The Greatest Show on Earth began its third week with unabated interest to the public yesterday. Madison Square Garden was filled from arena to roof at the matinee and evening performance, and the common expression of wonder is that so much novelty is developed in a field from which so much has been drawn before.

Most of Mayor STRONG'S memorandum stating reasons for withholding the city's acceptance of the Greater New-York bill is devoted to an expression of his approval of the general plan of consolidation and dissent from the proposition that the charter legislation be submitted to a vote of the people.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- A telegram received at the Navy Department reported a collision between the coast defense vessel Monterey and a Swedish merchantman of 3,000 tons at Seattle, in which the Monterey escaped with slight injury. The Swede struck the warship on the starboard quarter dead abeam.

The Young Men's Democratic Club of Brooklyn celebrated the anniversary of the birth of Thomas Jefferson by a banquet at the Hotel St. George last evening. Many of Brooklyn's best-known Democrats were present.

Public attention has been altogether too much diverted from the essential merit of Dr. MORGAN'S course in presenting to his congregation on Easter Day what he modestly esteemed to be a better, sermon than, with his pressing engagements, he could himself prepare. It was undoubtedly an erfor for the rector of the Church of the Heavenly Rest not to make clearer his obligations.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Some of the leading Democrats who recently have been looking over the political field and considering the course to be followed by the party at the National Convention have expressed opinions compelling the conclusion that they have found the free-silver element in the party so large that it would be hopeless to undertake to secure a sound-money declaration at Chicago.

GLEN COVE, L.I., April 13 -- An explosion in the discharging tube of the Dudley powder-pneumatic gun for throwing high explosives, at Matinicock Point, this afternoon, resulted in serious injury to one man. Two others received slight hurts and several spectators were made deaf. The gun was wrecked and the loss to the Sims-Dudley Defense Company is more than $10,000.

The Presbytery of New-York assembled for the "stated Spring meeting" in the Presbyterian Building, Fifth Avenue and Twentieth Street, yesterday. The Rev. Dr. J.F. Sutton, Moderator, occupied the chair.

DENVER, Col., April 13 -- Denver yesterday was the centre of one of the worst storms that ever blew over the Western country. East of here the country is inundated with from a foot to three feet of water, while on the south and west meagre reports tell of disastrous snow blizzards that have swept away every vestige of animal life in their path.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Action was taken by the House Ways and Means Committee this morning with reference to the bill repealing that section of the tariff law which makes alcohol for use in the arts free. The sub-committee which reported this bill brought forward an amendment the effect of which was to deprive the Court of Claims of jurisdiction of all accrued claims of manufacturers for rebate, under existing law.

The place of action, he fancied, should be a New-Hampshire village, and the time the year 1852, when Franklin Pierce ran for President.

SING SING, N.Y., April 13. -- There is much apprehension felt in this village over the unexplained disappearance of Isaac B. Noxon, who, until within, a few weeks, had been for thirty years the cashier of the First National Bank, and Secretary of the Sing Sing Savings Bank. The banks have conducted business in the same building, and at the same desk.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Representative Aldrich of Illnois gave out a statement of Mr. Reed's strength as compared with that of other candidates, with reference to which he said:

ALBANY, April 13. -- The session of the Legislature to-night was devoid of general interest. The Senate furnished the only incident out of the humdrum, and that was a shore discussion on Senator Wieman's bill to regulate charges for electric lighting in Brooklyn, which came up on a favorable report from the committee, to which Senators Brown, Malby, and Chahoon dissented.

SING SING, N.Y., April 13. -- There is much apprehension felt in this village over the unexplained disappearance of Isaac B. Noxon, who, until within, a few weeks, had been for thirty years the cashier of the First National Bank, and Secretary of the Sing Sing Savings Bank. The banks have conducted business in the same building, and at the same desk.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 13. -- It is announced this evening that, acting on the advice of his physician, ex-Speaker Crisp has been compelled to give up his appoinments for speaking. He and Secretary Smith have met in four joint debates, and since the second one, which was at Atlanta, Judge Crisp has suffered in health.
WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Representative Aldrich of Illnois gave out a statement of Mr. Reed's strength as compared with that of other candidates, with reference to which he said:

The Greatest Show on Earth began its third week with unabated interest to the public yesterday. Madison Square Garden was filled from arena to roof at the matinee and evening performance, and the common expression of wonder is that so much novelty is developed in a field from which so much has been drawn before.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Action was taken by the House Ways and Means Committee this morning with reference to the bill repealing that section of the tariff law which makes alcohol for use in the arts free. The sub-committee which reported this bill brought forward an amendment the effect of which was to deprive the Court of Claims of jurisdiction of all accrued claims of manufacturers for rebate, under existing law.

The confession of HOLMES, the murderer who is to be hanged in Philadelphia on May 7, in which he has undertaken, as he remarks, "to make known the details of the twenty-seven murders of which it would be useless to say longer I am not guilty," is a statement so extraordinary and revolting that it must excite much discussion as to the character and mental condition of the human fiend who wrote it.

" Do you know that there is a dangerous poison in half the water we drink! " It was an eminent professor of natural science who recently made this startling remark. " I am only stating a fact," he continued, " when I assert that in the springtime nearly all our drinking water contains traces of poisonous vegetable or animal matter.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- A telegram received at the Navy Department reported a collision between the coast defense vessel Monterey and a Swedish merchantman of 3,000 tons at Seattle, in which the Monterey escaped with slight injury. The Swede struck the warship on the starboard quarter dead abeam.
PHILADELPHIA, April 13. -- William F. Harrity, Chairman of the National Democratic Committee, speaking to-day of the money question, said:

GLEN COVE, L.I., April 13 -- An explosion in the discharging tube of the Dudley powder-pneumatic gun for throwing high explosives, at Matinicock Point, this afternoon, resulted in serious injury to one man. Two others received slight hurts and several spectators were made deaf. The gun was wrecked and the loss to the Sims-Dudley Defense Company is more than $10,000.
A most successful athletic meeting was held last evening in the Fourteenth Regiment Armory, Brooklyn, by the Fourteenth Regiment Athletic association and the Bay Ridge Athletic Club.

It has long been the practice under the election laws of this State to destroy the ballots after they have been counted and the returns have been made up on the night of the election. This shuts the door to fraud by recounting after the general result has become known and is capable of being thrown into doubt by disputes in one or more districts.
Senator Hill remained at the Hotel Normandie yesterday until about 2:30 o'clock, when he started to take the 3:30 train for Washington.
PHILADELPHIA, April 13. -- William F. Harrity, Chairman of the National Democratic Committee, speaking to-day of the money question, said:
BOSTON, April 13 -- "El Capitan," a comic opera, by John Philip Sousa and Charles Klein, was produced here to-night by De Wolf Hopper. It was well received. The story is funny and the music lively.

It is an evil thing for any community to be forced to live under a law which reasonable men of a law-abiding disposition feel justified in denouncing, and which men can seek to violate or to evade, not only without any sense of criminality, but without bringing upon themselves the condemnation of the general public.

CHICAGO, April 13. -- Subpoenas for scores of the highest railroad officials, living here and in the East; for the biggest packers of meat, shippers of dressed beef, manufacturers, and wholesale merchants here, have been issued by authority of the United States Court for this district, commanding the appearance of these prominent citizens before the next Federal Grand Jury, which meets May 4.

Japanese merchant in Washington. There were also present M. Odagire, the Japanese Chancellor in this city; Mr. Nagaski, agent of the Japanese Bank; a committee representing the Japanese citizens in New-York City and Brooklyn, and Ter M. Uyeno, Y. Uyeno, and S. Arakawa, representing Japanese merchants in this city.

LONDON, April 13. -- The Standard will tomorrow publish a dispatch from Madrid commenting upon the serious corruption in yesterday's election. About half of the electors abstained from voting. Barely half of the seats were contested owing to the local arrangements. Canovas del Castillo expects that there will be 330 Conservatives in the next Cortes, including the West Indian members.

ALBANY, April 13. -- Mayor Strong has vetoed the Greater New-York bill. His message on the measure, which has been under lock and key here since it was received Friday, was read in the Senate to-night. It was in line with the position the Mayor, took a week ago, when at one of his Cabinet meetings, he indicated that he would disapprove the bill.

LONDON, April 13. -- The Standard will tomorrow publish a dispatch from Madrid commenting upon the serious corruption in yesterday's election. About half of the electors abstained from voting. Barely half of the seats were contested owing to the local arrangements. Canovas del Castillo expects that there will be 330 Conservatives in the next Cortes, including the West Indian members.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The President today nominated ex-Gov. Fitzhugh Lee of Virginia to be Consul General of the United States at Havana, Cuba, vice Ramon O. Williams, resigned. This nomination was predicted in dispatches to THE NEW-YORK TIMES this morning.

From The Washington Times. The law passed by Congress two years ago ordering the destruction of all weapons taken from persons convicted in the Police Court of carrying them has proved to be a popular measure.
PHILADELPHIA, April 14. -- In speaking today of the political situation in the Democratic Party, National Chairman William F. Harrity said:

The trial of Victor S. Flechter, who is charged with unlawfully having in his possession an alleged Stradivarius violin, said to have been stolen from the late Prof. Jean Joseph Bott, was continued yesterday before Recorder Goff and a jury, in Part I. of the General Sessions Court.

BINGHAMTON, April 14 -- For the last few weeks the heads of the departments of the Erie Railroad in this city have, one by one, been ushered out of the service, and new and cheaper men have been employed to fill the positions. The same thing has happened in Elmira and other points along the line.

ALBANY, April 14. -- The Senate bills prohibiting the hounding and jacking of deer were before the House to-day. With Mr. Sanger's bills for the same purpose, they were made a special order for Thursday.

A memorial meeting of the New-York Press Club was held last night in honor of the memory of Col. John A. Cockerill, who died recently in Cairo, Egypt. There was a large attendance of members. Resolutions were adopted deploring the death of Col. Cockerill, who was President of the Press Club for five years.

ALBANY, April 14. -- J. Archibald Murray of New-York City addressed the Assembly Cities Committee this afternoon in favor of amending the New-York City Rapid Transit bill. His amendments provide that Broadway below Fourteenth Street shall be exempted from an underground railroad, and that openings on Broadway below Thirty-fourth Street shall be bridged, so as to allow a continuance of street traffic while the road is being built.

The Columbia crews, university and freshman, have now been rowing on the Harlem River nearly every day for four weeks. Albert Putnam, '97, who, owing to his lack of weight and strength, only made a substitute's position on last year's 'Varsity crew, has been doing the coaching, and expects to continue in this position until Walter B. Peet shall relieve him.

ALBANY, April 14 -- The Nixon bill, giving the Railroad Commission authority to pass on the capital stock of surface and elevated railroads, was advanced to third reading in the House to-day, after an amendment had been adopted, taking from the Commissioners the fight to estimate the value of franchises and providing that only those companies incorporated under general laws shall take advantage of the act.
From The Baltimore Sun. The following advertisement appeared in Friday's Sun:

LOUISVILLE, April 14. -- Gov. W.O. Bradley is to-night uppermost in the contest for the Republican instructions for President, but there is such a strong sentiment in favor of McKinley that there is no telling which one will win out to-morrow. Bradley had the better organization and won the instructions in a majority of the District Conventions.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The anniversary of Senator Morrill's eighty-sixth birthday was celebrated to-night by a large and brilliant reception, at his residence, on Thomas Circle. The rooms were handsomely decorated with flowers sent the Senator. President Cleveland sent pansies and orchids, which were arranged on a table near the mantel, flanked by jars of roses and other flowers sent by other friends.

The declaration of Controller ROBERTS that he will not pay the special agents of Excise Commissioner LYMAN unless they are appointed after passing competitive examinations is consistent with his previous attitude and action in a similar case, which was sustained by the Court of Appeals, and it may well be inspired by a sense of official duty.

The petition of the women Principals of the public schools for a modification of the present course of studies is still under consideration by the Committee on Instruction of the Board of Education. The board has not dealt with it.

A fire alarm box which happened to be out of order and a defective water tower cost dry goods merchants and insurance companies of this city something like $500,000 last night. So far as could be learned, the defects in the box and tower were due to the negligence of no one.

Under the auspices of the Society of Colonial Dames of the State of New-York, Berthold Fernow, late State Archivist of New-York, has prepared a calendar of the wills on file and recorded in the offices of the Clerk of the Court of Appeals, of the County Clerk at Albany, and of the Secretary of State.

YONKERS, N.Y., April 14. -- A conference between Coroner Miles, Capt. Mangin, and a number of insurance men was held in Capt. Mangin's office this morning, and startling developments in relation to the North Broadway conflagration in this city on Monday, April 6, have been announced.

QUARANTINE, S.I., April 14. -- Capt. Henry M. Kenner and Mate T.E. Russell of the American schooner Elisha Gibbs were passengers on the British steamer Kingswell, which arrived to-night from St. Michaels. The Kingswell left Licata March 14, Messina 18, and Palermo 21 with a cargo of fruit and sulphur for this port, and stopped at St. Michaels to replenish her coal supply.

ALBANY, April 14. -- W.F. Sheehan appeared before the Senate Committee on Commerce and Navigation this afternoon in behalf of the Brooklyn City surface railroads, and asked the committee to delay action and grant a hearing next Tuesday on Senator Page's bill, which authorizes the Brooklyn Bridge Trustees to lease the bridge railroad to the New-York and Brooklyn elevated railroads, to form a connecting link between the elevated railroads of the two cities.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, April 14. -- The latest Church and State deliverance of the Mormon leaders, in the form of a manifesto purporting to define the political status of the high Church officials, has been pondered over for a week by the people of Utah, and they are still as far from a satisfactory conclusion as they were when it was first delivered.

ALBANY, April 14. -- The propriety of putting the New-York street-cleaning force in uniform was under discussion by the Senate at its night session. Senator Grady's bill giving Common Councils power to order city employes to wear uniforms and requiring heads of municipal departments in cities to wear uniforms like those ordered to be worn by their subordinates was lost --14 to 11.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 14 -- Col. James E. Pepper, the noted distiller and breeder and racer of thoroughbred horses, filed a deed of trust with the Safety Vault and Trust Company of this city this afternoon. The cause of his action was an attachment suit in favor of Walter T. Hatch Sons, on a note of $5,196, to the order of Otto A. Kraus of New-York.

MADRID, April 14. -- The Havana correspondent of the Imparcial telegraphs that the advance guard of Maceo's force has had an engagement near Leehuza with the Alfonso XIII. Battalion. The Spaniards were compelled to fall back upon their main body near San Claudio.

The forces of ex-Senator Jacob Worth won a decided victory over the forces of City Works Commissioner Theodore B. Willis, at the meeting of the Kings County Republican County Committee, which was held in the new Johnston Building, Brooklyn, last night. Not only did the Worth men outvote the Willis men, but they gained four new members of the County Committee, and hereafter they will have a safe working majority.
We find in The New-York Tribune the following extraordinary assertion:
LINNEUS, Mo., April 14. -- The Republicans of the Second Congressional District elected delegates to the St. Louis Convention and instructed them for McKinley.

SYNOPSIS. Letitia, a little New-England girl, lives with her Great-aunt Peggy, her own parents having died, in a house where her grandmother and great-grandmother had lived. Her great-aunt Keeps her very busy, and, as she is inclined to be lazy and disobedient, she becomes restless. There is a little green door in the cheese room which she has been forbidden to open.

-- The yellow pine lumber manufacturers of Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Arkansas, and Missouri, at a meeting in Birmingham, Ala., yesterday agreed on an average out of $1 per 1,000 feet. This is to meet the recent withdrawal of Texas manufacturers from the Southern price compact and cutting in price that has been produced by dullness in trade.
At the Mayor's own request, the Board of Aldermen passed three resolutions over his veto yesterday.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 14. -- According to reports from excellent Republican authority, there is war to the knife in the party in Connecticut, and it is of such a split-up character that the warring groups are divided into these factions: The Fessenden element, the Platt crowd, the McKinley shouters, the Reed boomers, the Cookeites, and the Porter men.

ALBANY, April 14. -- The Court of Appeals to-day affirmed judgments of conviction for murder in the first degree in the cases of Tufil Tuczkewski, Louis P. Hermann, and Charles Pustolka of New-York City. In the case of Tuczkewski the opinion is written by Judge Haight, while Judge Martin was the dissenting Judge.

CLEVELAND, April 14. -- Col. W.S. Edwards, President of the famous Driving Park at Glenville and Chairman of the Board of Stewards of the Grand Trotting Circuit, has called a meeting of his associates to be held at Detroit on Thursday of this week. As Fleetwood Park is the only member in this State that will give a meeting this year the series of harness races will be largely confined to Michigan, Ohio, and Indiana.

There is a bill now before Congress to provide a new member of the Cabinet, a Secretary of Commerce and Manufactures. This is the result of efforts, made on several occasions during the last ten years, to secure the enactment of laws for the establishment of a department of the Federal Government especially devoted to the commercial and industrial interests of the country.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The interesting Lang case is before Gen. Miles for recommendation. The medical board which met at Governors Island, New-York Harbar, to determine whether Lieut. Clarence E. Lang, Second Artillery, was demented or sane, or whether he was entitled to retirement, found that officer able to discharge his duties.

FLUSHING, L.I., April 14 -- When Mrs. Goodridge, wife of Dr. E.A. Goodridge of Sanford Avenue, opened her husband's office door this morning at 7:30 o'clock she was startled by the discovery of an infant without any clothing. Mrs. Goodridge called the doctor. He picked the babe up, wrapped it in a blanket, and took it to the Flushing Hospital.

This is a posthumous volume from the pen of the late Prof. Herberf Tuttle of Cornell University. The series to which it belongs comprises several volumes, making a history of Prussia. The volume now published embraces that portion of the Seven Years' War beginning with the Prussian occupation of Saxony, about the middle of 1756, and extending to the suspension of hostilities after the battle of Leuthen, in December, 1757.

A commission was appointed last year in pursuance of an act of the Legislature to recommend changes in methods of legislation in this State. The fruit of its labors is now in the hands of the Judiciary Committees of the two houses in the form of two bills amending the "legislative law."

Rarely has there been better reason for treating with distinguished consideration a visitor from abroad than exists in the case of YAMAGATA ARITONO, the Japanese statesman and soldier now in this city. The State officials have done well in paying him unusual honors, and the municipal authorities might imitate the example thus set without exposing themselves in the slightest degree to the suspicion of showing an undemocratic regard for rank and title.

PITTSBURG, April 14 -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Pittsburg Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis Railway Company was held here to-day. Those present and the proxies held by the Secretary represented $34,000,000 of capital stock, out of a total of $40,000,000. The annual report was approved, showing gross earnings of $15,439,706.82, an increase as compared with 1894 of $1,191,251.09.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The House to-day passed, without division, and practically without objection, the bill making appropriations for fortifications and coast defenses. Its passage was advocated by Messrs. Hainer (Rep., Neb.,) Sayers (Dem., Texas,) Bartlett (Dem., N.Y.,) Livingston (Dem., Ga.,) Hemenway (Rep., Ind.,) and Cannon (Rep., Ill.,) all members of the Committee on Appropriations, and by Mr. Baker (Rep., N.H.)

The fact that Deputy State Excise Commissioner Hilliard had announced he was retain in offer eight Tammany Democrats gave rise yesterday to the story that Tammany and the Piatt people had entered into a deal by which in return for the retention in office of the few Tammany Inspectors and clerk the Tammany votes would be delivered to the Greater New-York bill when it comes up for passage over the Mayor's veto.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 14. -- The suit for the transfer of the management of the Bentley estate in Jersey City from Mrs. Emily Bentley, the widow of Peter Bentley, to a receiver had a further hearing before Vice Chancellor Pitney to-day. The action was brought by the oldest four of Mrs. Bentley's children, on the ground that she had used the estate extravagantly and was not a proper person to care for it.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Cuba owes her wealth, her prosperity, and her advancement, as compared with other Spanish-American countries, to her proximity to the United States; the chief products of her rich soil, sugar and tobacco, find a remunerative market at her very doors.

ALBANY, April 14 -- The Court of Appeals to-day in the case brought to test the efficacy of the bill compelling barber shops in all places of the State except New-York and Saratoga to close on Sunday handed down an opinion written by Judge Vann sustaining the law. All the Judges concur in the decision except Judges Gray and Bartlett, each of whom writes a dissenting opinion.

From The Cleveland (Ohio) Leader. As a result of the experience of Judge Walter C. Ong on the criminal bench, a bill was introduced into the Legislature at Columbus a short time ago by Representative Bloch, providing that the testimony given before a Coroner in cases of homicide and the like shall be declared incompetent testimony in a trial in the criminal court.

Controller Fitch sent a communication to the Police Board yesterday, in which he set forth the reasons for his refusal to honor a requisition for $9,416.53, which had been made upon his office by the Police Commissioners, for the purpose of reimbursing policemen who had spent their money in procuring evidence and for the prosecution of criminal complaints during 1895.

-- William P. St. John, President of the Mercantile National Bank, gave a theatre party last night at Abbey's Theatre. His guests were received at Sherry's shortly before 8 o'clock by his mother and Mrs. Bolton Hall and Mrs. Lucien Vallois, formerly Miss Stebbins of New-York, and now residing in Paris.
Clams, hard, properly called quahaugs, and soft, nanninoses, and the little gray Northern shrimp are beginning to interest those who like sea food.
ALBANY, April 14. -- There has been a general hustling and a putting on of screws to-day to insure the repassage of the Greater New-York bill.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- That Commander William Folger, United States Navy, has been restored to the good graces of the Navy Department was shown to-day by the issue of an order assigning him to duty as Inspector of the Eleventh Lighthouse District, with headquarters at Detroit, Mich.

Harold Nelson, seventeen years old, was arrested on Monday night by detectives of the Central Office for the theft of diamond jewelry valued at $1,620 from the residence of Prescott Hall Butler, 34 East Thirty-seventh Street, where he had been employed as underbutler.

F.G. Pierra, one of the most prominent of the Cuban patriots in this city, has had his veracity and honesty assailed by Congressman Boutelle of Maine, in connection with the duties that he performed as Secretary of the late Pan-American Congress. Mr. Pierra, at the time of the Congress, worked in connection with Secretary of State Blaine, and large contributed to the success that was attained.

From Our Own Correspondent. GLASGOW, April 1. -- Admiral Victor Montagu has advertised his two-year-old forty-rater Carina for sale, and if the cutter is sold our forty-rater class will be limited to Fife's last year Isolde and Watson's last year Caress. Fife's Isolde is wintering ashore, in Robertson's building yard, Sandbank-on-the-Clyde.
The Board of Estimate met in the Mayor's office yesterday to pass on the form of contract that will be submitted to those who wish to bid for the city's ashes and refuse.

From The Washington Post. "I am not giving any more interviews to the newspapers," says Senator Chandler when he is asked if he has any further contributions to the anti-McKinley literature, or if he wants to add anything to the now famous letter of explanation and apology addressed to Senator Lodge.

F.E. Bacon, E.C. Bredin, Shaw, and Bradley, the English champion athletes, have been invited to visit this country next September and compete in a series of matches with champions of the New-York Athletic Club.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The Arizona Statehood bill was ordered to be favorably reported this morning by the House Territories Committee. This object was not gained, however, until a strong protest had been made by three members of the committee against taking a vote at this time.

TUESDAY -- P.M. General firmness was the feature of today's market. Crop reports were more favorable, the political situation, both in this country and Europe, was less disturbed, and the weather was more seasonable. These were all factors in the creation of cheerfulness in speculative circles.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 14. -- The Rev. Cornelius G. Bristol, rector of the Church of the Good Shepherd in this city, which was founded by Mrs. Colt, mother of the late Caldwell H. Colt, has received a unanimous call to the rectorship of St. Thomas's Church, at Mamaroneck, N.Y., and it is expected here that he will accept of the new field.

There is a row among the Platt Republicans of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District over Edward Lauterbach. Some of the members want another leader selected for the district, because they say Mr. Lauterbach has to attend to all the patronage of the city, and in so doing neglects the Twenty-ninth, which is his own district.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., April 14. -- The special trains from the East bearing delegates to the seventeenth annual meeting of the Hotel Men's Mutual Benefit Association of the United States arrived at Los Angeles at 12:30 o'clock midnight, accompanied by the Reception Committee, composed of members of the California Hotel Association.

From Harper's Weekly. The speech on the Venezuela controversy which was recently made by ex-Minister Phelps had the very great advantage of clearness and power. It was a weighty utterance, and there is a certain attractive simplicity about the argument that this country ought not to interfere in the affairs of foreign countries except to protect its material interests-itself.

Were old-fashioned instruments of torture long since abandoned, but there is a tormentor who still continues to agonize the joints, muscles, and nerves of many of us. The rheumatism, that inveterate foe to daily and nightly comfort, may be conquered by the timely and steady use of Hosteller's Stomach Bitters, which likewise eradicates neuralgia, bilious, malarial, bowel, stomach, and nerve complaints.
The Central Opera House contained an assemblage of over 600 saloon keepers, including a few women, yesterday afternoon, in response to the following circular letter:

-- H.W. McVickar is known to the readers of our humorous weeklies as a prolific draughtsman of clever ideas and somewhat circumscribed technique. He has in his day illustrated a few books, generally dexterously, now and then with much originality, yet never quite satisfying. There may be seen just now, at Knoedler's Gallery.
This announcement, which would be an exceedingly interesting social chronicle were it true, was pronounced yesterday by the parents of Miss Moeran to be without foundation:

LONDON, April 14. -- American horse owners made their bow to the English public to-day at the Newmarket Craven meeting, the colors of Duke Wishard and Pierre Lorillard being seen in the races. Mr. Croker's string was not at the course, though he had several entries in different events; nor did Charles Littlefield or Foxhall Keene's candidates appear.

A decision of much, importance to the Atchison and Atlantic and Pacific Roads was filed in Topeka and St. Louis by a special board of arbitration a few days ago. The arbitrators were Milton H. Smith, President of the Louisville and Nashville; Edward S. Washburn, Vice President of the Kansas City, Fort Scott and Memphis, and W.W. Finley, Third Vice President of the Southern Railway.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The Chief of the Bureau of Statistics reports that the total values of the exports of merchandise from the United States during the month of March, 1896, and during the nine months ended March 31, 1896, as compared with similar exports during the corresponding periods of the preceding year, were:

CHICAGO, April 14 -- The rates decided upon by the new Transcontinental Freight Association are a good deal of a surprise to those who have been led to believe for several weeks that they would show a general advance. The first copy of the rates agreed upon by the association has reached this city, and an examination shows a considerable advance in rates west-bound, but a slight reduction in the tariffs applying to east-bound traffic.

Senator SQUIRE of Washington delivered in the Senate yesterday what seems to have been a very sensible speech in favor of his own bill providing for the strengthening of our coast defenses. It was a speech especially calculated to benefit the body to which it was addressed, because the Senate has been so particularly "forthputting" and belligerent during the present session.

The recent exposure of the insurance swindlers who have been operating on forged Lloyds charters has led a great many persons to believe that the entire Lloyds system was involved, that all the Lloyds companies are worthless, if not fraudulent. As a matter of fact, the Lloyds system of fire insurance is as strong and sound to-day as ever it was.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, April 7. -- The Bonilla Government of Honduras, in sheer hopelessness of affecting any sort of permanent alliance with Nicaragua, is initiating a scheme looking to the freeing of the Mosquito territory from Nicaraguan control and restoring Chief Clarence, who was deposed about two years ago, under a Honduranean protectorate.
The sale of the library of the late James J. Cronin was concluded yesterday by Bangs Co. Among the books sold were the following:

JAMAICA, L.I., April 14. -- Warrants have been issued by Justice B. Frank Wood for the arrest of Samuel B. Cisco and Charles P. Hunter, charging them with violating the compulsory education law in not sending their children to the colored school. The men will be arrested and arraigned in the morning.

According to information given at the Sub-Treasury, where secrecy in regard to gold continues to be the policy, the Government reserve made a slight gain yesterday. A withdrawal of $140,000 was followed by a deposit of $300,000, including the gold withdrawn. The deposit wag made by a bond subscriber.
The first day in New-York of the Marquis Yamagata, Japan's greatest military leader, was passed very quietly, the Marshal leaving the Waldorf only for a ride to Grant's tomb.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The regular weekly meeting of the Venezuelan Boundary Commission to-day was devoted to the reading of the reports made by the various members on the sub-topics to which they were individually assigned. No executive action was taken, and the question of sending a member or members abroad to collect information was not discussed.

Mr. CHAUNCEY F. BLACK is an able man who has done good service to the Democratic Party and to the country in the cause of tariff reform. He is the Chairman of the National League of Democratic Clubs, a thoroughly systematic organization extending throughout the Union, which has carried on with great vigor and skill an invaluable campaign of education.

The halls of the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Ninth Avenue, overflowed last evening with enthusiastic persons who went there to view the seventeenth annual exhibition of the New-York Microscopical Society.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, April 7. -- The elective members of the new Jamaica Legislative Council, having failed in their attempt to interfere in imperial concerns by passing a motion advising the recognition of the belligerency of the Cuban insurgents, have proceeded to put themselves on record against the policy and action of the mother country in another matter.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- John D. Hart, the steamship owner of this city, was arrested this afternoon on the charge of violating the neutrality laws between this country and Spain in connection with the last voyage of the steamship Bermuda, which he owns. He had a preliminary hearing before United States Commissioner Bell, and was bound over in $500 bail for a further hearing to-morrow.

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., April 14 -- Bright, sunny skies, a warm, southerly wind, and a most excellent and stiff hunting field, brought together a large field of members of the Meadowbrook Hunt Club to-day, when an exciting and invigorating run of twelve miles across country was had across the Wheatley and Harbor Hills and a portion of the Hempstead Plains.

"What's in a name? It's all right to ask the question in a spirit of levity or sarcasm, but I tell you there's a lot in a name, especially in our business. Take my name, for instance," said Babette Rodney of "The Lady Slavey" company; "I often wish it were plain Mary Jones or Jane Smith; then there would be some distinction to it.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- Frederick A. Starr, Professor of Anthropology in the University of Chicago, returned yesterday from a three months' trip through unexplored portions of Guatemala and Mexico. Prof. Starr's object in making the trip was to visit all the ruins in the two countries, which in his trip last Summer he had heard so highly praised, and to find the pigmy tribe which was supposed to live somewhere about there.

-- James P. Bartlett, for many years one of the most prominent bankers of Portsmouth, N.H., died yesterday. He was cashier of the New-Hampshire State Bank, and afterward President of the New-Hampshire National Bank. He became cashier of the Mechanics and Traders' Bank in 1882, holding that position until a year ago.

HOBOKEN, N.J., April 15. -- A magnificent marble baptistery, one of the most artistic of its kind in America, was solemnly dedicated in Trinity Church to-day, in memory of the late John Stevens of Castle Point. Mr. Stevens was for years one of the vestrymen of the church, and one of its most liberal supporters.

BOSTON, April 15. -- From the description of wreckage passed off Barnegat Light by the schooner William K. Park, Capt. Lake, which has arrived at Portsmouth, N.H., it is feared that some steamer plying to the West Indies, either from New-York or Halifax, N.S., has foundered.

The warm weather of the last three days has had a disastrous effect on the the atrical business, not only in this city, but wherever the heated term has been felt. There is no business so susceptible to the influence of heat as the theatrical, and this has been especially the case since the institution of roof gardens in this city, which have taken the place of inside places of amusement during the Summer.

ALBANY, April 15. -- The Senate repassed the Greater New-York bill to-day over the vetoes of Mayor Strong of New-York City and Mayor Wurster of Brooklyn. The vote was 34 in favor and 14 against such action.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- After a discussion of a little more than half an hour the Senate this afternoon, in executive session, ratified the treaty between the United States and Great Britain providing for the appointment of a commission to assess damages alleged to have been sustained by Canadian sealers whose vessels were seized by the Government of the United States for alleged illegal sealing.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Postmaster General Wilson to-day issued the order relating to the consolidation of the Brooklyn offices, which has been delayed for a month owing to the state of affairs in the Senate. The order consolidates the independent offices within the City of Brooklyn, and establishes six carriers and eleven sub-stations, effective May 1, 1896.

NEWARK, N.J., April 15. -- Miss Elizabeth Balfour Clark, eldest daughter of William Clark, the millionaire owner of the extensive thread and cotton mills in Newark and Scotland, was married at noon to-day in the North Reformed Church to Thomas Laidlaw, a wealthy iron manufacturer of Glasgow, Scotland.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 15. -- Miss Elizabeth Heloise Weber, daughter of Col. John B. Weber, ex-Congressman and ex-Immigration Commissioner, and Lieut. Godfrey Lynet Carden, United States Revenue Marine Service, were married at 10 o'clock this morning at the First Presbyterian Church. Dr. S.S. Mitchell performed the ceremony.

WEDNESDAY -- P.M. While the stock market was less active than yesterday, the trading was better distributed. Prices came higher from London, and the word from that centre was that there was more disposition to trade in Americans than had been shown for some time.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 15 -- Upon the advice of his physician, State Excise Commissioner Lyman has gone to Oswego for a few days for rest and recuperation.

JERSEY CITY, April 15. -- Charles H. Voorhis, a well-known lawyer, whose home is at 114 Clifton Place, shot himself in his office in the Davidson Building, at Montgomery and Washington Streets, to-night. He placed the muzzle of a pistol just below his right temple, and, firing, the bullet passed almost through his head.

LONDON, April 13 -- Interest in the races at the Newmarket Craven meeting here to-day centred in the race for the Column Produce Stakes, for three-year-olds, over the Rowley mile -- one mile and eleven yards -- as Leopold de Rothschild's splendid colt St. Frusquin, the son of St. Simon and Isabel, and already a favorite at 3 to 1 for the Derby, was a starter.

It is, of course, without any intention to prejudge the case of a violin dealer arrested for stealing a Stradivarius that we call attention to a peculiarity in the case. Thus far it depends entirely, not merely upon the testimony of experts, but upon the testimony of experts of two kinds, namely, connoisseurs of violins and experts in handwriting.

The remarkable showing made by the "mileage Bends" of the Brooklyn Bicycle Club in the annual contest which closed on the first of the present month has caused general talk among cyclers throughout the metropolitan district. Allart's record beats that made by Shadbolt three years ago by about 1,000 miles. Medals and bars for mileage records for the year have been presented as follows:
LANCASTER, Penn., April 15 -- The Lancaster County Democratic Convention to-day indorsed ex-Gov. Pattison for President.
The following letter was sent yesterday to Lieut. Gov. Saxton by Col. Waring, Commissioner of the Street Cleaning Department:

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- Storage Battery and Pennsylvania Heat stocks were again the feature of the local market to-day. At the opening Heat preferred advanced to 18 3/4, but subsequently reacted, and closed unchanged at 18. The common closed 1/4 higher, at 13 1/8. In Storage the common sold up to 36 1/2, and closed at 36 1/4, a net gain of 1/2 per cent.

[Copyright, 1896, by Bacheller, Johnson and Bacheller.] PART I. Sackville Street, Dublin, was looking very much alive on a fine Spring morning in the first decade of this century -- before "the distressful country" had recovered the fury and despair of Emmet's insane attempt at rebellion -- while the southern and northern districts were still honeycombed with secret societies and hopeless plots against the English Government.

TRENTON, N.J., April 15 -- The Republican State Convention for the election of delegates to the St. Louis Convention will be held in this city at noon to-morrow. The more conspicuous politicians present to-night are Senator W.J. Sewell, Gov. Griggs, Congressmen Gardner and Parker, ex-Congressmen Kean and Buchanan, Elias Ward, Franklin Murphy, and Garrett A. Hobart, who is a candidate for Vice President of the United States.

It is probably a sufficient comment on the assumption that the Spanish elections represent the will of the Spanish people to point out that not a single Socialist appears in the list of members elected. Bear in mind that the suffrage in Spain is practically universal, or "manhood suffrage," and the irrelevancy of this return is apparent.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Chauncey F. Black evidently did not suspect, when he promulgated his preposterous programme to nominate a Presidential candidate upon a platform pledging the President not to exercise his Constitutional right to veto bills, that there was so much resolution left in the Democratic Party as he seems likely to develop.

James Walsh and his son, Thomas J. Walsh, who, until December last, as Walsh Son, conducted a banking business at 5 Wall Street, were arrested yesterday afternoon and arraigned before Magistrate Mott on a charge of larceny in the Centre Street Police Court. The complainant is James A. Walsh, a manufacturer of bags, whose office is at 116 Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Senate to-day adopted a joint resolution authorizing the Secretary of War to issue to any person to whom a medal of honor has been awarded by the joint resolutions of 1862 and 1863 a rosette or knot, to be worn in lieu of the medal, and a ribbon, to be worn with the medal -- to be of a pattern prescribed by the President of the United States.

Democratic victories in the New-Jersey charter elections on Tuesday excited more than passing interest at the Produce Exchange because many of the members reside across the North River, and two of them, William A. Holmes, the commercial market reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES, and Henry Guilerd of the firm of Guilard, Rouse Bostwick, inspectors of provisions, were nominated by the Democrats for the offices of Aldermen for the Second and First Wards of Bayonne.

CHICAGO, April, 15. -- There was 1c range to wheat prices to-day, but the volume of trade was not large or important. The outside still holds aloof, and fluctuations depend on the activity with which scalpers and local professionals trade. There were reports of frost in California in circulation this morning, and although it was claimed that no damage had been wrought still there was strength imparted to prices by the information.

The result of the deliberations of the woman Principals of the public schools of this city, who have been at work for several weeks on a plan to amend the present curriculum, is being awaited with the greatest interest. Meetings of the Principals are held from time to time, and the work is not far from completion. The result will be given to the Committee on Instruction of the Board of Education early in May.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 15. -- The Mississippi is on the rampage from Grand Rapids to St. Paul. The river has been rising rapidly here for two days, and is now eight feet higher than it was Sunday. A further rise of two feet will drive the people on the west side flats to the hills.

ALBANY, April 15. -- Gov. Morton has signed the Anti-Coal Trust bill. He did so at 5 o'clock this afternoon, having waited as long as he could do so, as the bill would have become a law to-morrow had he not acted to-day.

ALBANY, April 15. -- It will require few if any more exhibitions such as were given yesterday with the bill which allows the elevated railway companies to grab the Brooklyn Bridge to bring a scandal on this Legislature. The action of the Senate Committee on Commerce and Navigation on this bill was about the best, or worst, display of how a political "pull" can be worked to business advantage that has been seen.
Messrs. L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for Henry I. Beers to E.E. Murphy the plot at the southeast corner of One Hundred and Fourteenth Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, 118.5 by 131.2 by 100.11 by 69.3.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., April, 15. -- When the St. Lawrence Presbytery, in session here yesterday afternoon, adopted the report of a committee recommending the dissolution of the relations between the Rev. William N. Cleveland, brother of the President, and the church at Chaumont, of which he has been pastor, it was supposed that the Chaumont Church troubles were ended, but Pastor Cleveland is proving himself a stubbern, fighter.

BOSTON, April 15 -- Local stocks were very quiet, the interest being centred in Pioneer and Quincy Mining. The latter was weak on the report of a petition for an injunction restraining the company from paying its dividend from its surplus. Pioneer closed 1/8 higher than last night, at 9 7/8. Gossip has it that the monthly statement about to be issued will show up as well as was expected.

CORONADO, Cal., April 15 -- There was more riding of a sensational nature at the Coronado track to-day. Had Kiser held to pace this morning, the world's half-mile-record would have been his. Two tandem teams, Dow and Parker to the quarter, and Randall and Schefski clear through, paced, and the latter team finished in 0:47 3-5, a wonderful performance, the tandem record being 0:50 and the single 0:48.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- It was made pretty clear from an incidental remark in the Senate to-day that the predictions as to an early adjournment of Congress are not likely to be verified.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Commander Booth-Tucker closed his series of meetings in Chicago last evening. The only reference he made to the dissensions in the army was in the form of a three-fold denial. The Commander said:

A somewhat novel view of tariff discrimination on the part of foreign countries was expressed at a recent hearing before the Ways and Means Committee in Washington. An association of manufacturers of wheat flour demanded "retaliatory legislation" against Germany, France, Italy, Spain, Belgium, Switzerland, Portugal, and Sweden because those countries impose on imported flour duties which are higher than those which they impose on imported wheat.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- The most important announcement made in this week's bulletin of the Racing Board is the line of the National circuit. The opening meeting will be held in Oakland, Cal., on May 1. and the closing one in Washington, on Oct. 17. The first circuit meet in NewYork State is scheduled for Aug. 20, at Niagara Falls.
CHICAGO, April 15 -- John G. Carlisle, Secretary of the Treasury, arrived in this city from Washington this morning on the Pennsylvania limited.
At the request of the Excise Board, its counsel, Julius M. Mayer, gave an opinion yesterday as to what kind of places may be granted hotel licenses.

Police Commissioner Parker, it would appear from the most recent developments in the Police Board contest, has been placed in a most unenviable position by the remaining Commissioners, Messrs. Roosevelt, Grant and Andrews.

BOSTON, Mass., April 15 -- The third cushioncarrom game in the second series of the international billiard match, which was played to-night in Bumstead Hall, was between Maurice Daly, the ex-champion, and Albert Garnier, the champion of Belgium, Barnier is an adept at this class of play, and the large number of spectators present took the liveliest interest in every shot that he made.

In The Cleveland (Ohio) Leader of the 12th inst. there were published a forcible protest, filling three columns, against the discharge of the city's sewage into the adjoining lake from which the public water supply is drawn and also an article concerning "the efforts which are being made" throughout the civilized world "to prevent or cure tuberculosis in the form commonly known as consumption of the lungs."

PORTLAND, Me., April 16. -- The friends of Thomas B. Reed threaten, to establish for him the reputation of being "all things to all men," at least so far as the currency question is involved. When the Presidenial campaign began, there was a natural and proper curiosity to know the attitude of the various candidates on the leading issue of the day.
The gathering of the Republican County Committee last night had been looked forward to with much interest, and the interest was sustained throughout the meeting with more vehemence than elegance.
Two benefit performances were given in this city yesterday, in aid of two worthy charities, and, in spite of the extreme heat, they were remarkably successful.

ALBANY, April 16 -- When the bill which proposes to give up the Brooklyn Bridge to the elevated railroads shall be reached on the calendar in the Senate, something is likely to be said with reference to the suspicious and indecent haste with which it was rushed through the Committee on Commerce and Navigation.

TRENTON, N.J., April 18 -- Whoever the nominee of the St. Louis Convention may be, so long as he shall be taken from the West, New-Jersey will ask for the nomination of Garrett A. Hobart of Paterson for Vice President. The delegates who assembled here to-day at heart were for McKinley.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 16 -- The members of the Meadowbrook Hunt Club abandoned the anise-seed bag to-day, and by way of variety had a deer hunt across a portion of the Hempstead Plains and the grounds about the country seats at the club members near the clubhouse. The members assembled at the clubhouse at 3:30.
ALBANY, April 16. -- Influences, which are ordinarily powerful have been at work here to-day against the Greater New-York bill.

James Connolly, the watchman at the Oil Seed Pressing Company's works on Irving Street, near Columbia Street, Brooklyn, discovered a fire on the top floor of the threestory brick factory at 9:15 o'clock last night. An alarm was immediately sent out, and when the firemen arrived they sent out two other alarms, bringing nine engine companies, three truck companies, the water tower, and the fireboat Seth Low to the scene.

In spite of the many discouragements which lie before an organization devoted to the performance of unpublished and previously unheard music by American composers, the Manuscript Society appears to have come to stay. The fourth public concert of its sixth season was given last night at Chickering Hall, and there was a large and interested audience.

At the meeting of the Sinking Fund Commission in the Mayor's office yesterday Controller Fitch urged the passage of a resolution authorizing the Corporation Counsel to draft an amendment to the Raines bill exempting the restaurants situated in the public markets from the strictures with which they are now burdened.

There was nothing surprising in the issuance of another Church and State manifesto by the Mormon leaders. Since the change from religious warfare in Utah to legitimate politics GEORGE Q. CANNON and the other less potent leaders have been ready to meet every protest against their political interference with a new declaration of their intention to keep religion away from politics.

Inquiries made yesterday among those who are active in matters connected with public schools, their system and course of study, showed that the changes to be proposed by the women Principals in the present curriculum are of a radical and aggressive nature.

A meeting of the Executive and Standing Committees of the Tenth Branch of the Association Opposed to the Extension of Suffrage to Women was held yesterday afternoon at the house of Mrs. Charles F. Clark 831 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The baseball season of 1896 was opened auspiciously for the Washington Club, it winning from New-York by better all-around work. Gleason's two low throws and Clark's wild pitch in the fifth inning allowed five run's eventually to be scored. There was a crowd present numbering 9,500 people, and it filled every seat in the ground.

From The Buffalo Express. Edward A. Cummings is fifty-one years old, healthy and robust, and by occupation a stationary engineer in Lyons, Wayne County. On the morning of June 7 last Mr. Cummings overslept himself, and upon getting up found that he had but a few moments in which to get to work.

The lawyers of East New-Jersey have induced Chancellor McGill to establish a branch court at Asbury Park to accommodate the lawyers practicing in the territory between South Amboy and Toms River. The new court will be presided over by Vice Chancellor Frederick Stevens of Newark, and will be held in the Post Office Building in Asbury Park every two weeks.

Mayor Strong received Field Marshal Yamagata of Japan in his office yesterday. The Field Marshal, his secretary, and Japanese Minister Kurino, with the Mayor's secretary, Mr. Hedges, drove to the City Hall from the Hotel Waldorf, in an open carriage. They arrived at the Mayor's office promptly at 12 o'clock, and found the Mayor and almost all the heads of the city departments awaiting them.

BELLOWS FALLS, Vt., April 16 -- Central Vermont matters continue to interest citizens along the line of the Rutland Division. Nearly all locomotives and crews of men, except enough to man a few local trains, have been transferred to the Central Division. The Boston and Maine, between here and Windsor, is rushed with three times as much traffic as last week, drawing Central freight in addition to their own traffic.

ALBANY, April 16. -- The report of the committee to consider a scheme of international arbitration was submitted to the State Bar Association at its special meeting in Albany this afternaoon. The report covers thirty type-written pages, and the reading of it occupied about an hour. The association adopted it with some amendments, but it was decided that it should be reprinted before being given out for publication.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Secretary Hoke Smith and ex-Speaker Crisp have returned from Georgia, and both have talked about the political conditions in that tSate. Secretary Smith is in fine health and prepared to resume debates with Mr. Crisp on the silver question; but Mr. Crisp is ill, and will not take to the stump again.

ALBANY, April 16. -- The Page bill, divesting Chief Conlin of the authority to make assignments and transfers of members of the force, and transferring such power to the Police Commissioners, who may exercise it by a majority vote, was taken up in executive session by the Senate Cities Committee this afternoon.
Laws may change, but New-York will have its annual trout exhibition, which marks and celebrates the opening day of angling for Salvelinus fontinalis throughout the State.

Baron Constantin de Grimm, the well-known cartoonist, died yesterday afternoon at 12:30 o'clock of rapid consumption, at his home, 222 East Fifteenth Street. He had been confined to his room since Sunday, but only his most intimate friends knew of his serious condition.

From The London Times. The British School at Athens has undertaken, besides its excavations on the Island of Melos, some excavation work in Athens itself, which, so far as one can judge at this early stage, gives promise of very important results for the topography of ancient Athens.

-- On Wednesday, April 15 the competition for the decoration of the Common Council Chamber at the City Hall, in Philadelphia, closes. It is expected that all the designs will be in the hands of the architect, Mr. Powell, at that date, and within a week or so the jury will have been selected and the prizes awarded.

The bill introduced by Senator Page, directing the Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge to lease the railroad tracks on that structure to the elevated railroad companies, is not regarded with favor by the Bridge Trustees. The hasty action taken by the Senate committee Wednesday has intensified the feeling.

WHITE PLAINS, April 16. -- In the Westcheater Temporary Home investigation today further evidence in defense of Superintendent Pierce was given by former inmates. The testimony varied but little from that of former witnesses for the defense. Two employes, however, added fresh evidence.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- The Peffer resolutions calling for an investigation into the "facts and circumstances" connected with the recent bond issues at last have the right of way in the Senate. They have been kept back since their introduction largely through the efforts of Mr. Hill, who detected their true inwardness.

BOSTON, April 16 -- Local stocks were very quiet, and the tone was somewhat heavy. Speculation was almost wholly confined to Pioneer and Merced. The former declined 1 1/2, to 8 3/8, on the statement issued last night. Merced declined, probably in sympathy, 1 1/2, to 17 1/2. The balance of the list was so dull that the story of the market is only the record of small sales in a few stocks.

Mayor Strong gave his second hearing yesterday afternoon on the Pavey-Page compromise School bill. He heard those who favor the measure, and there was a large attendance in the Council Chamber. The seats of the Aldermen were filled with women, many of whom are prominent in the best circles of the city's social life.

The proposition of Chauncey F. Black to require the Democratic nominee for the Presidency to pledge himself not to exercise his power of veto against any scheme of financial legislation which may receive the assent of a majority of the Democratic Congressmen, was widely discussed by prominent Democrats yesterday.

THURSDAY -- P.M. The tone of the stock market continues satisfactory, although the advances to-day, except in a few specialities, were not pronounced. The upward movement has been continuous for almost a week, and it was natural that the traders should take profits. All offerings, however, were easily absorbed, and the market closed at a slightly higher level than yesterday.

The long-backed commerce destroyer Columbia and the armored cruiser New-York are anchored off Stapleton, S.I., with more ill feeling than distance between the two. One is flagship of the station, and knows it. The other is just a plain consort.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 16. -- Cornell University Library has just secured another extensive collection of books, this time on South America. It was gathered mainly during his eight years' residence in Brazil by a former Cornell student, Herbert H. Smith, well known in the scientific world as an explorer and an entomological collector, and the author of one of the best modern works on the natural and sociological features of Brazil.

-- Countess Hartenau, the morganatic widow of the late Prince Alexander of Battenberg, is about to marry an Austrian officer of high rank. The Countess is beautiful and clever, and before Prince Alexander married her, was a well-known opera singer, by name Johanna Loisenger. She was of humble birth, but great talents, and has numerous relations in lowly stations of life.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- Diamond Match for the first time in several weeks closed lower than on the preceding day. Strawboard was in demand, and advanced to 46, but sold off to 45, where it closed. New-York Biscuit advanced to 96 3/4, the highest price the stock has reached. It closed at 95 1/2.

Prof. John Fiske the historian, spoke last night in Sherry's before the Nineteenth Century Club on "The Future of Man from an Evolution Standpoint." He began by showing that progress was not a universal concomitant of evolution, and that it was only achieved when all the conditions were favorable.

Canon Mason of Canterbury Cathedral, England, gave last night, in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd, which adjoins the General Theological Seminary, at Ninth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, the first of a series of five lectures on "The Conditions of Our Lord's Life upon Earth as Set Forth in the Gospels."

Buyers were plentiful at the American Horse Exchange yesterday afternoon, when W.D. Grand offered the choice lot of high steppers brought here by M.H. Tichenor Co. of Chicago. Leading spirits of the coaching and tandem set were out in force, along with many rich fanciers, who like to parade their horses in the show ring.

Police Commissioner Parker had the soft and gentle smile of some of his Quaker ancestors on his face when he reached Police Headquarters yesterday afternoon. He bore no rancor against any of his colleagues, and the suggestion of a personal difference between Mr. Roosevelt and himself made his smile break into a laugh.

The Harlem Charity Festival last night for the benefit of several unsectarian charities up town, was a social and financial success, the Harlem Opera House being crowded with well-known men and women.

It looks very much as though Police Commissioner PARKER had put himself in a position which would make harmonious action with his colleagues difficult, if not impossible, hereafter, and would make it necessary to a successful administration for him to get out or for Chief CONLIN to change his attitude, or else for the Legislature to amend the law, which requires unanimity in making promotions without the recommendation of the Chief.

From The Edinburgh Scotsman. A curious attempt is being made for the first time to occupy again some of the old stone cities of Northern and Central India, built by Mohammedan or Hindu dynasties, and long ago abandoned to malaria, the panther, and the snake. Of these Akbar's Windsor, Fathepoor Sikri, near Agra, is the finest.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Edward Farrar of Toronto, one of the leaders of the Liberal Party in Canada, has addressed a long and carefully prepared communication to the House Committee on Ways and Means on the subject of reciprocity. Mr. Farrar, after an exhaustive review of the past history of the subject, says:

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Orders were issued by the Navy Department to-day detaching Lieut. Commander Richardson Clovar from the Bureau of Navigation, and directing him to assume command of the dispatch boat Dolphin, sometimes called the President's yacht. He will relieve Commander W.T. Burwell, who will be placed on waiting orders.

The Day Star Industrial Home for Friendless and Destitute Women, at present located at 213 West Twenty-fourth Street, is in need of donations of money and clothing for the unfortunate women sheltered and cared for in the institution. The home was founded about two years and a half ago by Mrs. B.G. Draper, (Sister Charlotte,) and during that time over 600 homeless and destitute women have been received there and cared for.

An account was printed in THE TIMES ten days ago of the fifteen-story office building to be erected at the northeast corner of Broadway and Pearl Street, on plot 75 by 150.
