Some mystery surrounds the case, and the Mulberry Street detectives who have been investigating it have been unable to discover much about the cause of the quarrel between the men.

It is no wonder that the perilous position of Bulawayo should be the most exciting topic in England. The British "sphere of influence" in Matabeleland is upheld by young men in the service of the South African Company. This company rather more than represents in the social life of Great Britain what was represented there a century and a quarter ago by "the Honorable East India Company."
AUGUSTA, Me., April 19. -- Gov. Cleaves has appointed Thursday, April 23, as a day of "fasting and prayer."

Charles Fischer, a German decorator, who was once a public official in his native town of Stuttgart, Wurtemberg, was found dead in his poorly furnished room in the boarding house 79 East Third Street, yesterday morning. He had committed suicide by turning on the gas, having died apparently while asleep.
Santanelli, the Western hypnotist, gave a "seance hypnotique" at the theatre of Hammerstein's Olympia last night, which was well attended, and both interesting and amusing.

From Our Own Correspondent. GLASGOW, April 7. -- The Emperor of Germany's large cutter being built here is getting into shape. She is planked up to the covering board, and shows an extra length of counter. What will interest Americans is that, while it is denied that the Emperor will challenge for the America's Cup, the cutter's load water line is 89 feet, or just inside the limit for a challenger.

It is worth noting that business men are now openly basing their calculations for the future on their estimate of the chances for a gold-standard declaration in the Republican platform. This may not be a controlling factor in their calculations, and there are without doubt only relatively few business men who take so broad a view of what will affect affairs, or look so far ahead.

"The Buccaneer" had its first performance last Monday evening at the Hyperion Theatre, New-Haven. The show was prounounced a great success by the Yale boys. Of course, however, as on every other "first night," there was some hesitancy and not a great deal of enthusiasm. Saturday night the troupe performed at the Academy of Music, Brooklyn.

From The London Chronicle. Two estates of great historical interest are announced for sale. One is Cornbury, Oxfordshire, the seat of Lord Churchill, which was once the royal hunting ground of Henry II., when the wild boar was hunted in the celebrated Wychwood Forest, then extending to nearly 7,000 acres.

Pennsylvania State College plays the Fordhams at baseball, at Fordham, to-morrow. The visiting team is one of the strongest, and the Fordham team is playing rapid ball, so this game ought to be an exciting one. The team that is to represent Fordham in the relay at Pennsylvania is doing very well. It is matched against Johns Hopkins and City College.

It was an exceedingly "dry" day in Brooklyn yesterday. This was due to the manner in which District Attorney Backus interpreted the Raines law Saturday. Mr. Backus stated that a "mere restaurant" could not serve liquor to guests on Sunday. By a "mere restaurant" he said he meant a restaurant that was not attached to a hotel.

ALBANY, April 19 -- St. Peter's Episcopal Church was filled this afternoon with one of the most distinguished gatherings ever assembled in Albany, the occasion being the church service held by the Philip Livingston Chapter of the Sons of the Revolution, which called out representatives of all of the old families of the Hudson, Mohawk, and Champiam valleys.

ALBANY, April 18. -- The local security market was quiet and irregular, with few changes in prices during the week. The only activity was in Commercial Union Telegraph and Troy City Railway. The latter advanced 1 per cent. Celluloid is offered at about 2 per cent below last week's figures. The company is said to be doing a larger business but at a smaller percentage of profit than last year.

ALBANY, April 19 -- Mayor Thacher of this city has given out for publication a letter he has received from Senator Cantor relating to the Albany Police bill and the reply he has sent to Mr. Cantor. Mr. Cantor, in his letter, says:

A general statement regarding the Summer courses of New-York University has been issued and sent to all inquirers. During the six weeks from July 6 to Aug. 14 twenty-eight courses are offered by professors and instructors of the university. The courses include work in mathematics, chemistry, biology, experimental psychology, comparative study of systems of education, Latin, Semitic languages, German, French, economics, and physical training.

Harry Rosenfeld, nine years old, of 7 Allen Street; Harry Kalzen, eleven years old, of 11 Allen Street, and Morris Weintraub, eleven years old, of 12 Essex Street, were charged with being professional pick-pockets in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday by Detectives Brown and Formosa of the Central Office.

John S. Bodin, twenty-one years old, a student of Trinity College, Hartford, Conn., came to New-York Saturday as a member of the college ball team. When the team was ready to start for the ball grounds it was discovered that Bodin was missing. The game was played without him.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., April 19 -- This city and Hoboken gave examples of the two extremes in excise regulation to-day. Hoboken kept open house, and invited thirsty New-Yorkers to spend the day with her, while this city was a sort of Sahara, dry and arid, with only an occasional oasis where beer and whisky welled.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

The United States battleship Indiana, the first of her class to be commissioned, made her first appearance in New-York Harbor yesterday. The big floating fortress groped her way through a thick fog which hung over the Narrows during the early forenoon hours, and shortly after 10 A.M. her ponderous anchor splashed into the water off Tompkinsville, S.I.

ALBANY, April 19. -- The end of the legislative session being near at hand, there will be a rush of routine work this week, caused by the desire legislators feel to progress local legislation to please their constituents. Some important measures also will be considered, and all in all there will be a good deal for the Legislature to attend to this week.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 19. -- The fourteen men who are training for the Henley contest on the other side of the Atlantic have been changed from the Yale barge to the Yale shell, a movement in the programme of the practice work of the Yale Varsity crew that marks definitely a great advance in Yale rowing.

While the East Drive in Central Park was crowded yesterday afternoon with thousands of vehicles, an inexperienced bicyclist at Seventy-third Street ran against a large gray horse drawing a double-seated road wagon. A runaway with disastrous consequences followed.

MONDAY -- A.M. The rapid transition from Winter to Summer weather has had a beneficial effect on business throughout the country, and the changed condition has been reflected by higher prices on the Stock Exchange. At the up-town hotels, accommodation is at a premium, owing to the presence of a small army of buyers here to replenish stocks depleted by the revival throughout the country as a consequence of the more seasonable weather.

Mayor McGuire of Syracuse has made up his official mind that the city ordinance regulating the speed of railroad trains in the streets of that town must be strictly enforced. This policy affects most seriously the movement of the New-York Central's passenger trains through Railroad Street, and it is particularly detrimental to the Empire State Express.
"I'm so happy," said Tootsie, with a great sigh. "Can I come to-morrow?"

"Thoroughbred," which was produced with unmistakable success at the Garrick Theatre last evening, is an English comic play by Ralph Lumley, which is not very new, and has doubtless undergone some changes since it has been in the possession of Charles Frohman. All the text of the part of Decker, a prodigiously wealthy American, courting an Earl's daughter, was not written by any Englishman.

A red cow, reported to be mad, terrorized half the population of upper First Avenue early last evening. Where the cow came from was not at first a question. It was seen charging down First Avenue, near Firty-third Street, at 5:30 o'clock, and a big crowd of men, women, and children started in pursuit.

MONDAY -- P.M. There were unmistakable signs of improvement in the stock market to-day. Trade broadened considerably, and prices almost without exception advanced. Commission-house orders were fairly numerous, and the traders were more inclined to take chances on the long side than they have been in recent months.

ELIZABETH, April 20 -- Chief Consul Gentle and the Board of Officers of the New-Jersey State Division of the League of American Wheelmen held a meeting here on Saturday night. Reports from different sections were very gratifying as to the prospects for a large increase in membership, and just to boom things during the height of the season a number of prizes were offered.

It would be disgraceful if the present Legislature should fail to submit to a vote of the people the prison labor amendment of the Constitution which was proposed by the last Legislature. The Constitutional Convention of 1894 very unwisely incorporated in the fundamental law a section, to take effect Jan. 1, 1897, which prohibits not only farming out or contracting prison labor or its product, but selling the product.

STAPLETON, S.I., April 20 -- The Spring meeting of the Brooklyn Presbytery was held in the First Presbyterian Church, on Browell Street, this afternoon. There was a large attendance. The Rev. R.S. Dawson of the Ainsley Street Presbyterian Church was Moderator. The Rev. Lewis Wellsley was Stated Clerk.

The examination of Emanuel Ninger, alias Joseph Gilbert, who is charged with being engaged for twenty years in counterfeiting United States notes of large denominations with pen and pencil, was begun before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday.

CORONADO, Cal., April 20 -- The banquet of the seventeenth annual meeting of the Hotel Men's Mutual Benefit Association of the United States was given this evening at the Hotel Del Coronado, Coronado Beach, Cal.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 2 1/2 @ 3 per cent. The last loan was made at 3 per cent.

There seems to be a general preparation to evade what was supposed to be the most stringent provision of the Raines liquor law on the part of the keepers of restaurants and saloons who are so situated that they can convert their premises into "hotels" within the definition of that term in the statute.

ALBANY, April 20 -- If the Republican "organization," otherwise Mr. Platt, next Fall shall be able to levy for campaign funds on the private interests which have been advanced by this Legislature because of "organization" orders, the treasury will be amply provided for.

A new operetta that can be depended upon to amuse the public in these days is rare enough to deserve a thoroughly hearty welcome. Such a welcome was accorded by a large audience at the Broadway Theatre last night to "El Capitan." This was written by Charles Klein and composed by John Philip Sousa, the popular bandmaster.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 20 -- Ex-Congressman W. D. Bynum, who is practicing law in this city, is watching with the interest of a veteran politician the situation antedating the Chicago and St. Louis Conventions. Mr. Bynum is a sound-money advocate of the most pronounced type, and he does not believe that there will be a split in the party at the Chicago Convention.

SYNOPSIS. Col. Capel, an English officer, sent to take command in the Cork district of Ireland during the troublesome times of the first decade of the century, arranges to stop on his way from Dublin and visit Mr. John Digby and his daughter Grace at Athgarven. He is specially charged to secure one Valentine Costello, a young Irishman, educated in France, who is active in behalf of the Fenians.

BALTIMORE, April 20 -- At the next general election, which will occur in 1897, the voters of Maryland will cast their ballots for or against an amendment to the Constitution providing for the application of the merit system of appointments in all offices of the city and State, whether large or small, "so far as practicable."

Out or compliment to his friend and compatriot, Alexander Lambert, Director of the New-York College of Music, Ignace Paderewski, the great pianist, visited the institution yesterday and gave an impromptu musicale at 3:30 P.M. Pupils of the college and a few friends crowded the college hall.

Justice Osborne, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, in denying the application of Edward J. McKeever Brother for a peremptory mandamus to compel Commissioner Willis of the Department or City Works to award them the contract for cleaning the streets and removing ashes, said:

ROME, N.Y., April 20 -- The trial of the youthful train wreckers, J. Watson Hildreth of New-York and Theodore Hibbard and Herbert Plato of Rome, was opened here this afternoon at an adjourned term of the Supreme Court for the Fifth Judicial District, Justice Peter B. McLennan of Syracuse presiding.

At the meeting of the New-York Retail Grocers' Union last night the counsel of the association explained the opinion of the Corporation Counsel as to the effect of the Raines law on grocers who sell liquors.

FREMONT, Ohio, April 20 -- A cyclone swept through the rural portion of Sandusky County this afternoon. It is known that two persons are dead, and it is believed that when full news of the storm shall come in it will appear that other lives have been lost. The list of dead and injured as it stands now is as follows:

ALBANY, April 20 -- Assemblyman Armstrong's Bicycle Baggage bill, which was signed by Gov. Morton to-day, is regarded as one of the most important measures of legislation which has yet been enacted in the interest of the 100,000 wheelmen of the State.

At the meeting of the Park Commissioners yesterday Commissioner McMillan introduced a resolution that Corporation Counsel Scott be asked for his opinion on the question whether golf, tennis, baseball, or any other game may lawfully be played in Central Park on Sunday. The resolution was carried.

Commander Ballington Booth and Mrs. Booth were the principal guests of the gregational Club of New-York and Vleinity at the regular dinner and meeting of the club last night, in the St. Denis Hotel, Broadway and Eleventh Street.

The organization known as the Immigration Restriction League, and whose headquarters are in Boston, has appointed a committee to look into immigration matters at this port. It consists of Prescott Farnsworth Hall, George Loring Briggs, and Robert De Courcey Briggs.
The one hundred and twenty-first anniversary of the Battle of Lexington was fittingly celebrated last evening at Delmonico's by the Daughters of the Revolution.

George H. Jessup and Horace Townsend's Irish play, "Myles Aroon," was presented at the American Theatre last night to a large audience, and appeared to have lost none of its popularity since the days of Scanlan in the title role. The part of the young gardener was taken by Mr. Andrew Mack, whose rendering of Irish songs -- some of them his own compositions -- earned for him frequent recalls.

In reply to a report printed yesterday that the American Cotton Oil Company was in a bad condition, that it would probably pass its dividends, and that the retirement of Edward D. Adams and of former President Thomas R. Chaney indicated serious dissensions in the management, the Executive Committee of the company authorized President George Austin Morrison to say:

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 20 -- In all the tables sent out from Washington each week by Gen. Grosvenor, the thirty delegates in Indiana have been placed in the McKinley column, and they have been conceded to him on all hands, although only twentysix of them have been elected.

The annual election of the Tammany Society, or Columbian Order, was held last night in the Wigwam. A large number of the braves voted. There was no opposition ticket. Only one change was made in the list of Sachems, and none in the list of officers. In the list of Sachems J. Sergeant Cram was substituted for Gen. Daniel K. Sickles.

Santanelli, the hypnotist, had announced that at the close of his exhibition in the theatre of Hammerstein's Olympia last night he would put one of his subjects into a state of hypnotic sleep, in which he would remain until Saturday night.

The golf season is now fairly under way. The impetus it received last week at Lakewood has given it a better start than even the most enthusiastic golfers could have imagined. The Lakewood tournament demonstrated that those players who have kept their hand in during the Winter at Palmetto, Lakewood, and Baltusrol begin the year with a great advantage over that portion of the golfing community which has been "laying off" during the year.

The annual dinner of the veterans of the Seventh Regiment was held last night at Sherry's, The dinner commemorated the seventy-second anniversary of the organization of the regiment and the thirty-fifth anniversary of its departure for the war.

The war between the Nassau Electric and the Brooklyn Heights Railroad companies is on. The Nassau Company is now conveying passengers from any part of Brooklyn to Coney Island for 5 cents, and the Johnson syndicate, which controls the Nassau and Atlantic Avenue systems, is trying to get the Prospect Park and Coney Island Railroad, to shorten the time of the run from the city to the island.
Carnegie Lyceum was crowded last night when "The Buccaneers," a two-act operetta, was produced by the Columbia University Musical Society. Performances will be given every night this week.

The old town of Flatbush, now the Twenty-ninth Ward of Brooklyn, has a ghost, a Simon-Pure, sure-enough ghost, that nightly walks on East Broadway, near Nostrand Avenue, and stops at the house of Charles Norton to make inquiries for a hand that it lost there many years ago while its restless spirit was in the flesh.

Dickson had this misfortune. Like an inoffensive passer-by on whose head a signboard unhooked by a storm falls, Dikson became frightfully rich through an absurd succession of circumstances which were as if they had been borrowed from the combinations of the most commonplace melodramas.

LONDON, April 20 -- In the House of Commons to-day the Right Hon. Henry Chaplin, President of the Local Government Board, introduced a bill providing for the reduction of rates on agricultural lands. In the course of his speech Mr. Chaplin declared that land was at present taxed out of all proportion to its ability to bear the burden.

The subject that has for weeks engrossed the attention of all Berlin, and of all political Germany, at last made its appearance yesterday in the Reichstag. It is no doubt objectionable that in a country in which dueling, when it has fatal consequences, is recognized as an offense, a man should have killed another in a duel without subjecting himself to prosecution.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Peffer bond resolutions have been sidetracked by the Senate, so that the appropriation bills may be disposed of, with the understanding that the bond resolutions shall hold their place and finally be brought to a vote in case their friends shall muster sufficient strength to force them to that point. This decision was reached to-day, after Mr. Peffer had attempted vainly to have a time set for taking a vote.

LONDON, April 20 -- The Times will to-morrow publish a dispatch from Mafeking, dated yesterday, saying that Capt. Duncan telephones from Rulawayo that he is confident that he will be able to resist an attack by the rebellious Matabeles. The most he fears is treachery on the part of the natives within the town.
No. 649 East One Hundred and Sixty-first Street, for a one-story frame store and workshop, by Henry Ubelhor of 643 East One Hundred and Sixty-first Street; cost, 2,000.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 20 -- Mrs. Hannah Bartow, if she lives until May 1, will be 101 years old. She enjoys goad health, and is as active as a person half her ago. Her sight is good. She never wore glasses, and does considerable sewing. She is slightly deaf.

There were several public hearings before Mayor Strong yesterday on bills that have passed both houses of the Legislature. The bill appropriating $2,000 to pay for the transcription, of indictments in the District Attorney's office was among them. The work entailing this expenditure was done as the result of the reported loss of several important indictments.

Chief Conlin said yesterday that under his direction the police made a special observation Sunday relative to the enforcement of the Raines law in the saloon "hotels." The result was that in about twenty-five cases evidence was obtained that the law was not complied with as required by the provisions of the act.

Messrs. Slawson Hobbs have sold for the estate of Charles F. Tag, the lot on the south side of Seventy-sixth Street, 400 feet east of Columbus Avenue. The purchaser will erect on the lot a dwelling for his own occupancy.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The second day's race meeting at Bennings was marked by much better weather conditions than prevailed on the opening day. The temperature was Summerlike, but not uncomfortable. There was a failing off in the attendance, and the grand stand showed a somewhat "beggarly array of empty boxes."

FERREL, N.J., April 20 -- Surrounded by four generations of descendants, which include 142 persons, "Aunt Hannah" Chard to-day celebrated her one hundred and seventh birthday at the home of her seven- , ty-year-old son Joel.

The Daughters of the American Revolution opened their exhibition of Colonial, Revolutionary, and other historical relics in Assembly Hall in the United Charities Building, at Twenty-second Street and Fourth Avenue last night. The exhibition will last one week.

BOSTON, Mass., April 20 -- Patriots' Day, commemorating the battle of Lexington, was appropriately observed as a general holiday in this city and throughout Massachusetts to-day. Public buildings and exchanges were closed, and business was generally suspended.

P. B. Thurber, a member of the new East River Bridge Commission, and Clarence A. Henriques of the Board of Trustees of the Brooklyn Bridge, yesterday expressed their opinions of the Page bill, which provides for the running of the cars of the elevated railroads across the present bridge structure. Mr. Thurber strongly favors the bill, believing that it will confer enormous benefits upon the public.

Ice two months ago was selling at $1.50 a ton wholesale, or about 1 cent for fourteen pounds. The price now at retail, thanks to the Ice Trust, or Consolidated Ice Company, is at the rate of 1 cent for one and a half pounds for those in the greatest need of the commodity -- the poor of the city and tenement house dwellers.

We find in a long statement "given out at the headquarters of the Theosophical Society" in this city much that is peculiarly interesting -- because of the source of the information -- with respect to the coming election of a President of the society, to succeed the late Mr. JUDGE, and concerning the unsuspected and hitherto unknown Mahatma who is to be accepted as the occult director of the organization.

Alonzo Roosevelt Thompson, general manager of the J. Walter Thompson Advertising Company, was stricken with apoplexy in the firm's office in The Times Building last night about 6 o'clock. He died an hour later without recovering consciousness. Dr. Harrington of the Astor House and another physician were summoned when Mr. Thompson was first stricken, but they were unable to render any aid.

On Sunday last WARNER MILLER was presumably attending church in Herkimer or spending the interval between services in thanking his Maker that the Herkimer Sabbath, so far as he knew, was not as the Sabbath of New-York, and in congratulating himself upon the success of his efforts to spread the Herkimer Sabbath, as he understands it, over the whole Commonwealth.

STAPLETON, S.I., April 20 -- Mrs. Constance Clason, wife of Hans Clason, the bride of nine days, who disappeared Saturday, is once more at her father's home, in Court Street, Boyd Hill. She was joyfully received by her mother and sisters, who had begun to fear she was dead.

NORWALK, Conn., April 20 -- Ex-Gov. Thomas M. Waller, S. Harrison Wagner, and Frederick H. Reed, representing a syndicate of New-York capitalists, were in town this morning, and in company with Secretary George W. Mansfield of the Norwalk Tramway Company, were taken to Gregory's Point, and then over the Broad River extension.
HAVANA, April 20 -- Gen. Melquizo reports that his command has dispersed parties of rebels near Jaruco, Province of Havana. The rebels lost ten killed and the troops six wounded.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- The market showed considerable activity during the latter part of the day; Diamond Match advanced to 194 3/4. New-York Biscuit was dull. It sold as low as 93 5/8, but recovered again to 94 1/2 and closed at that price. Lake Street was in good demand at 27 1/2 @ 28, and closed at 27 3/4. The cables were active. West Chicago sold at 103 7/8.
To the Editor of The New-York Times: Webster defines the word "metropolis" as meaning the "chief city or capital of a Kingdom, State, or country."

The Presbytery of New-York had an exciting meeting yesterday in the session room of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street. The Rev. Dr. James Chambers was the Moderator. The chief interest in the meeting was aroused when the Rev. John C. Bliss offered the following committee report:

The new battleship Indiana, which had anchored off Stapleton, S.I., Sunday morning, after her trip from Hampton Roads, tripped her anchor yesterday afternoon and headed up stream, bound for the navy yard. She was watched from the Battery by interested crowds, and harbor craft of all description saluted the stately vessel as she swept majestically up the Bay.

The annual meeting of the Manufacturers' Association of Kings and Queens Counties was held in the Pouch Mansion, Brooklyn, last evening. A resolution to the effect that, as the present monetary system and the agitation in Congress tend to unsettle values and depress business throughout the country, therefore the Manufacturers' Association recommends a gold standard, and a gold standard only, was unanimously adopted.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- In the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill reported to the Senate to-day, the committee has made a large number of increases over the bill as it passed the House. Chief among these are the allowances for officers of United States courts, over which a hard fight was made by the House in Committee of the Whole.

The new battleship Indiana, which had anchored off Stapleton, S.I., Sunday morning, after her trip from Hampton Roads, tripped her anchor yesterday afternoon and headed up stream, bound for the navy yard. She was watched from the Battery by interested crowds, and harbor craft of all description saluted the stately vessel as she swept majestically up the Bay.

The annual meeting of the Manufacturers' Association of Kings and Queens Counties was held in the Pouch Mansion, Brooklyn, last evening. A resolution to the effect that, as the present monetary system and the agitation in Congress tend to unsettle values and depress business throughout the country, therefore the Manufacturers' Association recommends a gold standard, and a gold standard only, was unanimously adopted.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- While the Indian Appropriation bill was pending in the Senate to-day, the committee amendment for tha payment of specific sums to fourteen lawyers for legal services to the Western Cherokee Indians was taken up, and Mr. Chandler (Rep., N. H.,) stated his objections to it.

The Parkway Driving Club will have a four days' Spring meeting, beginning Wednesday, May 27. Five hundred dollars is offered in purses each day. The programme will be: First day, 2:50 and 2:26 classes, trotting; second day, 2:45 class, pacing, and 2:21 class, trotting; third day, 2:32 and 2:16 classes, trotting; fourth day, 2:38 class, trotting, and 2:08 class, pacing.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The action of the Ways and Means Committee of the House in deciding to report a bill concerning alcohol used in the arts seems to have been misunderstood. The bill reported merely repeals section 61 of the tariff act of 1894. That section provides for the withdrawal of alcohol to be used in the arts free of tax.

The New-York State Board of Examiners to Select Improved Arms for the National Guard held its first meeting for the actual testing of arms yesterday in the armory of the Thirteenth Regiment, at Sumner and Putnam Avenues, Brooklyn.

The policy of the Republican Party in Congress concerning the admission of New-Mexico, Arizona, and Oklahoma to the union of sovereign States does not appear to be exactly consistent with the same party's policy with respect to the tariff.

ALBANY, April 20 -- The scandalous action of the Senate Committee on Commerce and Navigation in rushing through the bill to give the Brooklyn Bridge to the elevated roads was too rank even for this Legislature.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Col. William R. Morrison has come out into the open in an interview which he must have desired to have published, for there is no man more averse than he to interviews that he considers ill timed. But if Col. Morrison regarded this as the time for its utterances he did not make so sure that his utterances would meet with approval from the wise men of the Democracy.

BERLIN, April 20 -- In the Reichstag to-day Dr. Bachem, the Centrist leader, raised a debate on the question of dueling, by calling attention to the recent duel between Lieut. von Kettelshodt, an officer attached to the imperial yacht Hohenzollern, and Herr Zenker, a prominent Berlin lawyer, resulting in the death of the latter.

ALBANY, April 20 -- Adjt. Gen. McAlpin has practically completed his detail for service at the State Camp, which will open July 27 and continue six weeks. The Seventh Regiment was accorded the honor of opening the camp last year. The Twentythird Regiment will probably be selected this year.
ALBANY, April 20 -- The Republican leaders here are as confident to-night that the Greater New-York bill will be repassed by the Assembly as were the leaders in New-York yesterday.

A big bay horse was being led from Tattersalls sales stables last night through Third Avenue on its way to Huntington, L.I., by the Twenty-third Street Ferry. It was in charge of C.E. Brown of Huntington.

Commander Ballington Booth of the Volunteers has made a rejoinder respecting the correspondence between his father and himself, made public by Commissioner Booth-Tucker, and purporting to be all the correspondence that has been exchanged regarding the Salvation Army troubles.
PARIS, April 21 -- Leon Say, the French statesman, died this morning, aged seventy years.

BABYLON, L.I., April 21 -- Oscar Conklin, a resident of East Islip, and a young lady, while out walking last night, had a peculiar experience. A big man, carrying a club, appeared before them, and attempted to strike Conklin with the club. The young woman screamed, and Conklin tried to overpower the man, whom he recognized as a lunatic named Goldstein, who had been confined in the Central Islip Insane Asylum.

THREE RIVERS, Quebec, April 21 -- The water in the St. Lawrence River has risen two feet since yesterday, and is now higher than the great flood of 1865, the highest on record. An immense loss has been sustained by farmers near this city, barns being carried away and logs, lumber, and cordwood swept down the river in large quantities.

President Coleman of the National Cycle Board of Trade sent out a circular letter last evening to the stockholders of that organization asking for opinions on matters of general Importance to the cycling world. The questions are:

ALBANY, April 21 -- The Court of Appeals decided to-day that Maria Barbella, the condemned murderess, should have a new trial. The condemned woman has been confined in Sing Sing for some time awaiting execution for the murder of her lover and betrayer, Domenico Cataldo.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- There is much mystery surrounding the detachment of Civil Engineer Peary from the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and the action of the Navy Department in placing that officer on waiting orders. The denial from Exeter, N. H., to the effect that Lieut. Peary has neither funds nor plans for another polar expedition has not made the matter any more clear.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 21 -- The Westchester County Teachers' Institute was continued to-day, according to programme. There are 289 teachers registered, and all have been very regular in attending the various exercises. There are generally three exercises going on at the same time, in different portions of the schoolhouse.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Weather Bureau has issued its crop bulletin for the week ended yesterday. The following are abstracts:

The second "administration dinner" was enjoyed last night at the Lotos Club. The festivities were entirely" under the rose," but opportunity was had of learning just enough of what passed to heighten imagination as to what was not to be learned.

The Lenox Library has recently secured for the New-York Public Library a valuable addition of books relating to American history and genealogy. The historical matter consists entirely of town history, and is particularly rich in the New-England field. This collection makes the Lenox Library, regarding these subjects, second in the city, the New-York Historical Society being first.

Americans must have control of their tempers as they read Mr. Lecky's book, for they will come across many things in it which will stir them to anger. In using the United States to illustrate his general proposition that the tendency of democracy is toward misgovernment, Mr. Lecky severely criticises our institutions and our political methods.

The Rev. Dr. Donald McLaren of Brooklyn will be one of the passengers that sail on the Fulda from New-York next Saturday. Dr. McLaren will take his wife and daughters, and will be gone for six months, visiting Scotland, the home of his ancestors, before he returns.

ALBANY, April 21 -- Chairman Lauterbach of the New-York Republican Committee succeeded to-day in again getting the bill to lease the Brooklyn Bridge to the elevated railroads out of the Senate Committee on Commerce and Navigation. There was no repetition, however, of the indecent haste of last week.

Marie Corelli ironically dedicates her new book to "those self-styled 'progressivists' [dreadful word] who by precept and ex- ample assist the infamous cause of education without religion, and who, by promoting the idea borrowed from French atheism, of denying to the children in board schools and elsewhere the knowledge and love of God as the true foundation of noble living are guilty of a worse crime than murder."

A mass meeting was held last evening at Checkering Hall under the auspices of the Armenian Relief Association. The objects of the meeting were to protest against the expulsion of missionaries from Armenia, to denounce Turkish interference with the relief work, to inaugurate plans for the permanent rescue of the Armenians, and to demand that the Christian Governments of the world prohibit the resumption of the massacres.

BALTIMORE, April 21 -- The time-honored statute known as the Eastern Shore law, which provided that one of Maryland's representatives in the upper house of Congress should be a resident of the Eastern Shore of the State, appears to have been unintentionally repealed by the late session of the Maryland Legislature.
BERLIN, April 21 -- The Reichstag, by a unanimous vote, adopted a resolution condemning dueling, the special motion made on behalf of the Freisinnige and Centrist Parties being withdrawn.

Ferdinand J. Bennett, a well-known and popular newspaper man, died of pneumonia and laryngitis yesterday morning at 19 Debevoise Place, Brooklyn. His body was sent to his parents' home, in Fulton, N.Y., last evening.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 21 -- Reports this afternoon from Sandusky County show that the cyclone was more disastrous than it was at first said to be. In addition to the two persons reported dead last night, at least five more persons are fatally injured.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., April 21 -- A mass meeting was held in this city this evening in the interest of McKinley. Ex-Assemblyman E. Watson Gardiner presided, and the speakers were Senator Frank D. Pavey, Charles H. Dennison, T. St. John Gaffey, and Col. Lovell H. Jerome, all of New-York. Resolutions indorsing McKinley for President were adopted.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The second day's session of the American Society of Religious Education was addressed this morning by Dr. F.B. Palmer of Fredonia, N.Y., on "Religious Education Defined." The speaker advocated the making of education real by teaching the Bible and taking truth as the standard.

The Commissioners of Appraisal for the Grand Boulevard and Concourse, which has been laid out from One Hundred and Sixtyfirst Street and Mott Avenue to the Mosholu Parkway, have filed a partial report. It comprises a preliminary estimate of damages for the first section, which extends from One Hundred and Sixty-first Street to Walnut Street, a distance of a mile and a third.

JERSEY CITT, April 20 -- The Hudson County Grand Jury to-day took action which will probably result in giving the people a reform Sunday movement that will meet with public approval and be successful. It began with an investigation into the cases of the saloon keepers who were arrested in this city last Sunday.
Thomas Brown, a young married man living at 19 Marion Street, died Friday from pleuro-pneumonia. He was buried Monday in Calvary Cemetery.

As Spring business foreshadows the course of trade for the year, the signs of improvement which have appeared in the financial district, in the last few weeks, have been watched with increasing gratification by merchants. The security markets rarely fail to reflect conditions and to indicate the outlook for the remainder of the year.

This posthumous book by the famous Chicago humorist, like most of his widely popular writings, treats in a light and telling way of domestic experiences common to nine-tenths of the people who buy and read books in the United States, the "plain people," in moderate circumstances. Mr. Baker is a mild-mannered gentleman of scientific aspirations, and his wife is actually, if not confessedly, the head of the family.

What was very nearly a serious accident occurred during the production of "The Village Postmaster" at the Fourteenth Street Theatre, Monday night. At the close of the third act, Bertha Creighton, who plays the heroine, is in a wheat stack, beneath which is a thrashing machine in motion.

A pretty wedding last evening was that of Miss Anna Belle Rogers to Charles Tobias, which took place at 112 East Twentyfifth Street, the home of the bride's father, Capt. Belden J. Rogers of the Old Guard. The Rev. Dr. John Wesley Brown, rector of St. Thomas's Protestant Episcopal Church, performed the ceremony.

News down town yesterday that an order had been issued from the Chancellor's Court, in New-Jersey, requiring the Directors of the American Tobacco Company to show cause why they should not be enjoined from paying a scrip dividend of 20 per cent., as proposed by them, had no effect on the price of the company's stock.

For some time past Long Island City has been casting about for more water and endeavoring to obtain a supply that would be ample in case of a big fire. In the past at every big fire the water has failed the firemen. The result was high insurance rates. The city last night concluded a contract which promises to prevent any failure of the supply in the future.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- There was little attention given to any stock to-day but Diamond Match. The stock advanced to 200, 150 shares selling at that figure. It closed at 198 3/4. The balance of the market showed little change from yesterday's close. Bank clearings were $14,608,390. Money loaned at 6@7 per cent. on time and 6 per cent. on call.

LONDON, April 21 -- No American horses were started in the races run at the Epsom Spring meeting, though Richard Croker had Americus entered for the great Surrey Handicap, and Nantucket and Red Banner in the Westminster Plate.
After a separation of twenty years, the two associations of the Congregational Churches of New-York and Brooklyn have at last taken the first definite step toward a reunion.

Orders were issued yesterday to such subordinates of the New-York Central and the West Shore Railroads as may be concerned in the handling of bicycles at the railway stations or on trains to comply with the provisions of the new law regarding the free transportation of bicycles as baggage. No passenger can claim free transportation for more than one bicycle at a time.

BALTIMORE, April 21 -- In the Third Republican Congressional District Conventions held here to-day, Dr. William S. Booze, who was Harry Welles Rusk's opponent two years ago, and Who unsucessfully contested Rusk's election before the House of Representatives, was nominated for Congress in the Third District.
Toppie and Tootsie had another great day yesterday. It was really almost as good as the circus, for they were the chief performers, and Toppie was by all odds the star.

After numerous adjournments the suit brought at the request of the Inter-State Commerce Commission to test the legality of the new joint traffic agreement, came up for argument before Judge Miller, in the United States Circuit Court, in this city yesterday. The Government was represented by United States District Attorney Macfarlane.
The most interesting side of a circus is behind the scenes. If there were admission tickets to that part of the performance the seats in front might be empty.

From The New-York Staats-Zeitung, April 22. The twaddle in which Mr. William R. Morrison has indulged anent the currency problem is surprising only for the reason that the man had shown more character in the agitation for a better tariff. As for any intellectual greatness, Morrison never had any.

ALBANY, April 21 -- The Platt politico-legal syndicate, (limited,) for the control of legislation and with plenary powers in the matter of the pushing along of bills from one stage to another, has had one little set-back, temporarily at least.

Society's pet wheel club, the Michaux, had its final indoor ride of the season at Bowman's Academy last evening. The event was of considerable social importance, as about everybody who is anybody within the charmed circle was present. Indeed, no session of the swell club ever had so many spectators and riders as graced the occasion last evening.

BIRMINGHAM, April 21 -- The thirty-second annual Shakespeare commemoration of the Birmingham Dramatic and Literary Club was held to-night in the Grosvenor Room of the Grand Hotel. About 300 guests were present, among them being Ambassador Bayard and Mrs. Bayard. George W. Parker, the American Consul and President of the Club, occupied the chair.

MILWAUKEE, April 21 -- Whatever doubt there may have been as to the intention of Brayton Ives to keep faith with the reorganization committees of the Northern Pacific was dispelled yesterday when answer was filed to the suit of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company by Mr. Ives, admitting all of the allegations of the complaint.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Had there been a quorum present to-day at the close of a six hours' session, the Populist vote of the House of Representatives would have been increased from seven to eight, by the adoption of a resolution declaring Albert T. Goodwin entitled to a seat as representative from the Fifth District of Alabama.
ALBANY, April 21 -- Senator Mullin has prepared a statement of the total appropriation carried by this year's annual Supply bill as compared with that of last year, as follows:

JERSEY CITY, April 21 -- Circulars have been scattered in the northern section of the city, on the Heights, calling for a public meeting to be held Saturday night at Prank's Hall, in Bowers Street, to "protest against the insults offered to children in Public School No. 7."
VIENNA, April 21 -- Baron Maurice de Hirsch, the great financier and philanthropist, died last night on his estate at Presburg, Hungary, from a stroke of apoplexy.

Nikola Tesla is still devoting a great deal of time to the scientific investigation of the Rontgen ray effects. In a long communication to The Electrical Review, to be publisbed to-day, he announces, among others, two interesting results he has achieved. One of these is that if a sensitive film be placed between two plates, say of magnesium and copper, a true Rontgen radiograph would be obtained after a very long exposure in the dark.

To Chief Conlin was yesterday granted a leave of absence for fifty days by the Police Commissioners, but, Mr. Andrews insisting, it was recorded on the minutes that the assent of the board was given on account of Mr. Conlin's ill health. The application for the furlough was as follows:
The warm weather of the past week has had a remarkable effect in increasing the demand for all kinds of Summer goods.
Oscar S. Straus, formerly United States Minister to Turkey, in speaking to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES about the late Baron de Hirsch yesterday, said:

The intimate friends of Ignace J. Paderewski have long since known that the great pianist had learned to love America dearly, and they also knew that he intended to give substantial evidence of it. While he has been considering various plans for some time of showing his gratitude for the extremely generous receptions extended to him in all parts of this country, it was not until yesterday that he came to a decision.

TUESDAY -- P.M. Profit taking on the recent advance caused a check in the upward movement to-day, although there was no evidence of weakness developed. Advices from London indicated a growing interest in American securities, particularly in investment bonds. At the same time the foreigners were sellers of Louisville and Nashville and Union Pacific.

An immense white city, floating on oceans blue, with fairy pillars and quaint cut turrets, fantastic minarets, columns, and cupolas. That was the way an immense field of icebergs looked to the voyagers of the Atlantic Transport steamship Mobile, which yesterday arrived in port.

The trial of Victor S. Flechter, who is accused of having unlawful possession of a Stradivarius violin stolen from the late Prof. Jean Joseph Bott two years ago, was resumed yesterday before Recorder Goff, and when the court adjourned for the day the defendant's bail was increased from $1,000 to $10,000.

WEST POINT, April 21 -- The cadet baseball team is rapidly getting in fighting trim. The opening game last Saturday with Lafayette, while not a victory, showed decided improvement over last year's work. The great drawback to the team is the little time allowed for practice. Previous to Saturday's game the cadets had only one hour's outdoor practice.
Mr. George R. Read has sold for the Equitable Life Assurance Society, to a Mrs. Tracey, at $70,000, the four-story brownstone dwelling 123 East Twenty-first Street, (Gramerey Park,) 27 by 98.9.

The police of the Sixth Precinct, Brooklyn, have a new mystery on their hands. A woman, about fifty years old, drove a peddler's wagon up to the Maujer Street side of St. Catherine's Hospital at 4 o'clock P.M. yesterday and assisted a well-dressed man to alight. He seemed very ill, and, with difficulty, descended to the pavement.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 21 -- The Democratic State Convention to-day declared its preference for William E. Russell of Massachusetts for President. The following platform was adopted:

Mr. Leopold Schepp, a cocoanut importer of 169 Hudson Street, this city, whose vessel, the Whitford, was recently seized by a Colombian man-of-war, received yesterday the following letter from, secretary Olney of the State Department:
One Hundred and Sixteenth Street to One Hundred and Twentieth Street, Amsterdam Avenue to Boulevard, for a four-story brick public college building, by Columbia College, owner; cost not estimated.

The New-York State Board of Examiners for the Selection of an Improved Arm for the National Guard devoted the second day of its tests, yesterday, to the Briggs-Kneeland rifle. The tests took place in the Thirteenth Regiment's armory in Brooklyn.

-- Many society folk will attend the musical tea to-morrow afternoon at the home of the Misses Ely, Riverside Drive and Eighty-fifth Street. Among the women who will receive the guests will be Mme. Calve, the opera singer. The reception is for the purpose of aiding in the effort to raise a two-hundred-thousand-dollar endowment fund for Mount Holyoke College, South Hadley, Mass.

The story of an alleged conspiracy to insure the cargo of the ship L.E. Cann for a large sum of money and to scuttle and sink her at sea was told yesterday before Justice Giegerich and a jury in Trial Term, Part VII., of the Supreme Court, when the trial of a suit brought by Stevens Voisin against the Commercial Mutual Insurance Company was resumed.
Richard Redamacher, a saloon keeper of 35 Ralph Avenue, Brooklyn, was accused in the Ewen Street Police Court yesterday of stealing electricity.

Bradley B. Smalley of Vermont arrived at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night. He came here from Burlington on business, and will probably return, to Vermont tonight. Mr. Smalley is the Democratic National Committeeman from his State, and has been one of the most influential Democratic managers of National campaigns for the last sixteen years.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Notwithstanding a card that was light, a series of very interesting events, spiced with some rather brilliant racing, delighted the visitors at Bennings to-day. The attendance has been so light that the price of admission will hereafter be but 50 cents, with an extra charge of the same sum for admission to the private inclosure, where such betting as there is may be done.
ALBANY, April 21 -- A hearing was had this afternoon before the Senate Committee on Commerce and Navigation on the Eldridge-Brackett bill "to improve the upper Hudson and to prevent freshets."

The unusual weather for the season has had a depressing effect on the trade in various provisions, and, although prices declined considerably, that did not seem to stimulate trade to any appreciable extent. The wholesale dealers and receivers, to whom the goods come pouring in every day from all parts of the country, have been anxiously looking for cooler weather, that they may save considerable of their perishable goods.

Goldsmith traveled all the way to Holland to teach the Dutchmen English, and did not discover until he reached the Netherlands the utter futility of his mission. He did not know a word of Dutch. For her self-appointed task, to "render into English" the Russian of Mme. Kovalevsky, the Baroness von Proschwitz is somewhat better equipped than Goldsmith was, but her English is often clumsy.

Nothing could be better than the platform of the Massachusetts Democrats on the money issue. There is no dodging, no "paltering in a double sense," no vague phrase. It is the work of men who know what they mean and who intend that every one who cares to shall know also.

GLASGOW, April 11 -- The Emperor of Germany's new cutter, Meteor, looks a very sweet and handsome vessel as she lays under the shed she has been built in at Meadowside, the building yard of Messrs. Henderson at Partick here. Designed by Mr. Watson, with less beam than Valkurie III., she has finer ends, and has considerably less hollow in her floor than our last challenger.

The Biological Society of Washington has published an interesting and important paper by Dr. C. Hart Merriam, Chief of the Bureau of Ornithology and Mammalogy, Department of Agriculture, entitled "A Preliminary Synopsis of the American Bears."

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- The feature to-day was Union Traction, which declined 1 7/8, to 15 7/8, on rumors of another strike. After the pressure to sell was over, the stock rallied to 16 3/8. Union fours and Philadelphia each closed 5/8 lower, at 72 1/8 and 69 5/8, respectively. The specialties were dull, and closed at declines of 1/2 for Storage common, 1/4 for Pennsylvania Heat preferred, and 1/8 for Heat common.

NEW-HAVEN, April 21 -- McKinley seems to be quite as strong in Connecticut as has been represented by his friends in their forecasts. In the preliminary work of the State Convention, which will be held to-morrow, the Ohio candidate has won a decided victory over Reed. His partisans say two-thirds of the delegation to St. Louis will favor the Ohio candidate.

HAVANA, April 21 -- Official reports giving further details of the engagement between the insurgents and Gen. Meiquizo's command, which was reported yesterday, have been received. According to these reports, the Spanish officers have been informed by peasants that the rebels buried eight more dead and carried away with them seventeen wounded men.

The office of the United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Fortyfifth Street, was the scene of a fashionable gathering yesterday afternoon, when Miss Azuba L. Barney of Irvington, N.Y., and Reginald H. Jaffray were married.
The funeral of Austin Abbott, Dean of the Law Department of the New-York University, was held in Broadway Tabernacle yesterday afternoon. There was a large attendance.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The American Society of Mechanical Engineers, which has membership of 1,800 men, embracing the most distinguished mechanical and electrical engineers of the country, through its governing body appealed last week to the Congress of the United States in behalf of the passage of the Wilson-Squire Engineering and Educational bill.

Mrs. Jeannette Colley was arraigned in Jefferson Market Court yesterday on a charge of vagrancy. She entered the West Twentieth Street Police Station Sunday night, and said she had forgotten the address of a niece with whom she resided. Before the case had been disposed of Joseph Sunderland of 421 West Thirtyfirst Street reached the courtroom, and said he was Mrs Colley's niece's husband, and that Mrs Colley had been living with them.

PARIS, April 21 -- It was officially announced this evening that the Ministry, in view of the Senate's attitude in barring the expenditure necessary to maintain the troops in Madagascar, had decided to resign, but were unwilling to abandon office before explaining to the Chamber of Deputies the facts of the situation.

What is now known as the Democratic Young Men's Organization, and what was formerly known as ex-Sheriff James O'Brien's Democracy, met in the annex of the St. Cloud Hotel, Forty-second Street and Broadway, last night, and adopted resolutions indorsing William E. Russell of Massachusetts as "a most desirable candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination."

It is expected that the convention of the American Medical Congress, to be held in Atlanta, Ga., May 5 to 8, will be largely attended from the Eastern and New-England States. The Southern Railway, "Piedmont Air Line," is a direct line from the East to Atlanta, making the trip from New-York in less than twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Senate Committee on Naval Affairs this morning considered and ordered a favorable report on a communication from the Secretary of the Navy urging that the appropriation in the Naval bill providing for the enlistment of as many additional men as in his discretion may be deemed necessary, not exceeding 1,000, shall be immediately available upon the passage of the bill.

Mayor STRONG seems to have been a good deal impressed by the opposition of Trustees and teachers to the reform School bill, and has shown considerable hesitation in taking action upon it. It would be most unfortunate if his wavering mind should finally conclude to withhold the city's acceptance.

Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, Chairman of the Reorganization Committee of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, made a statement yesterday concerning a report that a large amount of securities of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company had disappeared, and no account therefor had been given.

ROCKVILLE, Conn., April 21 -- Burglars made an unsuccessful attempt to blow open the vault of the Tolland Savings Bank and the large safe in J.P. Root's store in Tolland early this morning. They entered the bank through a window and drilled three holes around the lock of the vault. They then exploded three heavy charges, tearing off the outside part of the vault doors, with the combination, but not affecting the lock.

Latest English sporting papers announce that Richard Croker's Americus (Rey del Carreres) was made the favorite for the Kempton Park Jubilee Stakes on Friday, ousting Victor Wild from the place which he had held ever since the weights for the race were announced. The race is to be run on May 9 over the Jubilee course of one mile.

With "Gryll Grange" the republication of Peacock is finished. It was written in 1861, and Mr. Saintsbury calls it "the last and mellowest fruit from Peacock's tree." A quaint, delightful book it is, though one must be prepared for its quality beforehand. It will not do to approach Peacock in the spirit with which one takes up Scott or Thackeray.

NEWARK, N.J., April 21 -- The twenty-eighth annual convention of the Congregational Association of New-Jersey was opened in the First Congregational Church here to-day. It will continue until to-morrow night. The association includes all Congregational Churches in New-Jersey, Maryland, Delaware, and the District of Columbia.

LONDON, April 21 -- The Times will tomorrow publish a long dispatch from G.W. Smalley, its correspondent in America, which is devoted to dispelling the illusions that the Venezuelan boundary dispute has passed dangerous stage, that the negotiations are prospering, and that the British Blue Book on the subject created a favorable impression in the United States.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 21 -- The Citizens' League has elected its candidate for Mayor by over 10,000 majority over Congressman Charles F. Buck. It has also elected its entire city and councilmanic ticket.

"Ten beers and one hard-boiled egg scarcely constitute a meal," said President Roosevelt of the Police Board yesterday in talking on the subject of "fake" hotels under the Raines liquor tax law, "nor is a lodging house a hotel. As for meals, that is all a question of evidence, but in my opinion a dozen beers and a small sandwich are not a meal.
The biography of Prof. Huxley, by his son, Leonard Huxley, will not be ready before the Autumn.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Another day's discussion of the opinions of Col. Morrison has made it plain that he will have to cultivate the field before he becomes a thoroughly acceptable candidate for President with either the silver men or the soundmoney men. The talk to-day betrayed the existence of doubt in both camps as to the availability of Col. Morrison.

CONSTANTINOPLE, April 21 -- A letter received here from Marash, dated April 8, says that typhoid fever is increasing in that city, and that both doctors who were sent there to work among the sick are prostrated with the disease. The city is quiet, but the inhabitants of the outlying villages are in terror and flocking into the city.

C. Barnum Seeley is having a thirty-footer built by Hunt, at Bridgeport, that will add considerable interest to the thirty-foot class. When the class was first arranged it looked as though all the boats would be turned out by Herreshoff and from the same model, but the yachtsmen who organized the class thought that it would be better to have other yachts race.

A trolley express system will soon be operated in Brooklyn. The Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company, has made a contract with the National Express Company for the transportation of baggage throughout the city on a plan similar to that employed on steam railroads, and in a short time regular express cars will be running over all the lines controlled by the Brooklyn Heights Company.

Gen. Lloyd E. Baldwin died suddenly of apoplexy yesterday at Willimantic, Conn., aged eighty-six years. He was born in Norwich, but had lived most of his life in Willimantic. He was prominent in the military affairs of his State, and in old militia times was Colonel of the Fifth Regiment, and at one time General of the Fifth Brigade, being at the time of his death the oldest living Brigadier General in Connecticut.

A good deal of a muddle has been produced over the Greater New-York bill through the incapacity of the legislators and the local politicians and many of the "organs of public opinion" to deal with it on the merits of the proposition which it embodies. There is little prospect of a time when action upon this subject can be obtained without this kind of meddling and muddling.
ALBANY, April 21 -- The Greater NewYork bill will be taken up in the Assembly to-morrow, and the Republican leaders say it will be passed. Seventy-six votes will be needed.
The following statement has been sent out by T. Estrada Palma:

The recently organized Yorkville Cricket Club played the first match of the season at Astoria on Monday. It had for opponents the team of the steamship Teutonic, and had to submit to defeat at the hands of the sailors by a margin of 15 runs. J. Heaton both batted and bowled most effectively for the Teutonics.

The Bijou Theatre was crowded to the doors last evening by an audience which assembled to do honor to May Irwin, on the occasion of the three-hundredth performance of her farce, "The Widow Jones." The weather had cooled somewhat toward evening, so that it was comfortable in the theatre, and the performance was never better or more lively.

Edna Steimquist, who was a kitchenmaid in the service of I. Townsend Burden, Dec. 27, when jewels valued at $58,000 were stolen from the rooms of Mr. and Mrs. Burden, was sent to the Tombs yesterday by Recorder Goff.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 2 1/2@3 per cent. The last loan was made at 3 per cent.

Ex-sheriff John J. Mitchell of Queens County was buried yesterday from St. Mary's Church, in Long Island City, where a solemn requiem mass was celebrated at 10 o'clock A. M. The Rev. James H. Mitchell. Chancellor of the Diocese of Brooklyn, a brother of the ex-Sheriff; Bishop McDonnell of Brooklyn, and Vicar General Farley of Brooklyn officiated at the services.
Mrs. Anna Von Gahlen -- wife of Theodore Von Gahlen, formerly a First Lieutenant in the German Army -- who died at her home 146 Meserole Street, Brooklyn, was buried Tuesday in the Lutheran Cemetery.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 22 -- The recently constructed quarters for Troops A and D, at Jefferson Barracks were burned to-day. The contents of the buildings were saved. The loss is estimated at $15,000.

ALBANY, April 22 -- A bill to reorganize the management of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge was introduced to-day by Assemblyman O'Grady. The bill was referred to the Committee on Rules, from which it can be reported for final passage as soon as it is printed.

William G. Choate gave Justice William J. Gaynor some pretty hard rubs while he was engaged in the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday making an argument in the appeal of the Commissioners of the East River Bridge from the order of Justice Gaynor enjoining them from carrying out the contract for the purchase of the Uhimann bridge franchise for $200,000.
Messrs. L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for the King estate, at about $400,000, the block bounded by Ninetieth and Ninety-first Streets, the Boulevard and West End Avenue, containing twenty-six lots.

William Turner, a traveling tinker, without home or friends, had a narrow escape from death by starvation while locked in a freight car of the Lehigh Valley Railroad. He entered the car at Elizabeth to sleep the night of Sunday, April 12. He was locked in shortly afterward and remained a prisoner until yesterday morning, when he was released in the freight yard in Jersey City.

The Fine Arts' Federation of this city has resolved to draw up a petition asking the Senate of the United States to take some immediate action in regard to the bill now pending for the preservation of the Palisades.
NEW-ORLEANS, April 22 -- Indications are that Louisiana will have a Gubernatorial contest similar to that in Tennessee a year or more ago.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- Union Traction was the feature at the opening to-day, declining from 16 1/4 to 15 1/8 on renewed strike talk. About noon the stock rallied to 15 7/8, and closed at 15 5/8. The 4s declined 1/2, to 71 5/3. Philadelphia lost 3/8, to 69 3/8. In the specialties, Storage common and Pennsylvania Heat and Power both gained 1/2, and Heat common 1/8.

The bell at the residence of William K. Vanderbilt, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-second Street, rang sharply late Tuesday night, and when the footman opened the door he found a well-dressed and respectable-looking woman on the stoop. The woman said she wanted to see Mr. Vanderbilt. The footman told her that his employer was at home, but that his rule was not to see anybody at so late an hour.

The mystery of the man who was driven by a woman to St. Catharine's Hospital, Brooklyn, and left to die in the street, on Tuesday, was cleared up yesterday. Detective Becker of the Stagg Street Police Station learned that the woman was Mrs. Julia Leonard of Astoria Avenue and Merrise Street, Maspeth, and that the man was her stepson, John Leonard.

HAVANA, April 15 -- Governor General Weyler's chief of staff gives this list of acts by insurgents which caused Gen. Weyler to proclaim them criminals and threaten them with death. Gen. Weyler authorizes its publication "that the facts may be proved and the world may see to what use the arms sent to the insurgents are really put."

A delightful ramble through some of the famous cathedrals of England was enjoyed by a large number of the parishioners of the Church of Zion and St. Timothy last evening, through the medium of an illustrated lecture by the Rev. Dr. Henry Lubeck, rector of the church. The lecture was of rare historic and artistic quality.

As a result of sharp practice resorted to by petty lawyers immigrants at Ellis Island have been fleeced of their scant funds. Commissioner Joseph H. Senner yesterday caused to be posted in various languages the following notice:

PARIS, April 22 -- The opinion is almost general in the lobbies of the Chamber of Deputies that the Radicals in the Chamber will, at the sitting of that body to-morrow, endeavor to provoke a vote of confidence in the Ministry, even after the Government's statement has been made announcing the intentions of the Ministry; but it is believed that Premier Bourgeois will persist in resigning.
OTTAWA, Ontario, April 22. -- In the Senate this afternoon Sir Mackensie Bowell announced that Parliament would be prorogued to-morrow evening at 8 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The baseball game to-day was very loosely played on both sides. Brooklyn, winning through better hitting and McJames's liberality with bases on balls. Copt. Joyce was hit in the face with a pitched ball in the second inning, and was compelled to retire. Lush was sent to second, Rodgers going to third.

The pacemakers that will assist Capt. M. Gibb and the officers of the Century Wheelmen of New-York, on their Spring century run to Patchogue, L.L, and return, on Sunday, April 26, are as follows: Regular division -- Carl Von Lengerke, Atalanta Wheelmen, chief pacemaker; George C. Wheeler, Mount Vernon Cycle Club; Daniel M. Adee, Liberty Wheelmen: A.L. Stark-weather, East Orange Cyclers; Thomas Ward, Riverside Wheelmen.

One Hundred and Seventh Street, south side, 325 feet west of Columbus Avenue, for a two-story brick laundry, by the Little Sisters of the Poor, 135 West One Hundred and Sixth Street, owners; cost, $10,000.

The suit of the Rome Bank against J. B. Brewster Co., carriage manufacturers, for the setting aside and declaring fraudulent an assignment made by the defendants on Oct. 11, 1895, came up for hearing in Part V. of the Supreme Court yesterday before Justice Truax.

A bill introduced by Senator Hill, and which passed the United States Senate yesterday, may have an important bearing on the proposed rowing regatta in which crews from Columbia, Harvard, Cornell, and the University of Pennsylvania are to participate in June next.
It was only by coolness and prompt work that a panic was averted at the Standard Theatre last night during the performance of "Chimmie Fadden" by Charles H. Hopper and his company.

A well-dressed man of middle age entered the editorial department of The Herald yesterday about 5 P. M., and, sitting down at one of the reporters' tables, started to write. When asked what his business was he paid no attention to the inquiry, and at 5:30 o'clock a policeman who was summoned took the stranger to the West Thirtieth Street Station.

EGG HARBOR CITY, N.J., April 22. -- This city to-night is a nest, with fire for its walls. Blazing pines make a circle about it, smoke pours thickly over it, and twice the flames have leaped so far above their kind that watchers knew two buildings had been swept out of the path of the destroyer.

The eve of William Shakespeare's birthday was made the occasion last night by the Shakespeare Society of New-York for an elaborate banquet at Delmonico's given to Augustin Daly in appreciation of his "loyalty, scholarship, and devotion to the highest standard of dramatic excellence, and most especially to his distinguished successes in the mounting of Shakespearean comedy.

The marriage of Miss Sarah Elizabeth Erving, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Erving, to James G. King took place yesterday afternoon at 3:30 o'clock in the Reformed Episcopal Church, at Madison Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. Only relatives and a few intimate friends of the bride and bridegroom were present, the bride's family being in mourning for Miss Van Rensselaer.

The Brooklyn enemies of the Greater New-York measure were dumfounded when they learned that it had passed yesterday. Their flag bearing the inscription "The Greater Brooklyn" still continued to unfold in the breeze at Court and Joralemon Streets on the building owned by A.A. Low, who has from the outset been opposed to consolidation.

Corporation Counsel Scott, in answer to a request from Chief of Police Conlin, has written an opinion respecting the duties of the police in dealing with the numerous hotels which have sprung up since the Raines tax law went into effect.

BOSTON, April 22 -- Local stocks were very dull, the only feature of interest being the Mexican Central issues, which were quite active and strong. There was one sale of Bay State Gas 5s at 78 -- 1 3/4 below the last sale of some days ago.

NEWARK, N.J., April 22. -- The family and friends of Miss Elenor Stine of 65 Pacific Street were surprised yesterday by the following notice, which appeared in a local newspaper under the heading of marriages: WHITE -- STINE. -- On April 13. 1896, CLARENCE E. WHITE of Boston. Mass., to Miss ELENOR STINE of this city, by the Rev. Dr. Mayberry of New-York.

Mayor Patrick Jerome Gleason of Long Island City became infatuated with a baby boy on a train between Wading River and Long Island City yesterday morning, and as the child's mother, a widow, was willing the boy should be taken by the Mayor, it now depends on the Mayor's daughter whether little Edward Bradley will change his name to Patrick Jerome Bradley, and be adopted by Long Island City's Chief Magistrate.

The fate of the magnificent scheme for consolidating into one grand metropolis the community which has gradually been growing together upon New-York Bay is now in the hands of Gov. MORTON. It is not simply the approval of the bill creating a commission to prepare for the consolidation that depends upon him, but practically the whole course of action that is to follow.

ALBANY, April 22 -- The Assembly repassed the Greater New-York bill to-day over the vetoes of Mayors Strong and Wurster. The consolidationists found when the vote came that they were sailing close to the wind, for they had two votes only to spare. Seventy-six votes were needed to pass the bill.

BOSTON, April 22. -- After a run of thirty-five hours from the Delaware Capes, the United States battleship Massachusetts, at 7.30 this morning, dropped anchor in President Roads. The run was uneventful, but the performance of the ship was perfectly satisfactory and showed that the Massachusetts is in every way equal, if not superior, to her sister ship, the Indiana.

Our Congressional jingoes would do well to lay to heart the effect which their performances have already had in Spain. The rumors of negotiations between our Government and that of Spain concerning Cuba have taken a definite enough form to be the subject of comment by the press of Madrid.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 22 -- The Georgia Railroad Commission yesterday investigated the question of control of the Georgia Southern and Florida Railroad. The presumption of the commission was that this company was controlled by the Southern Railway, because it is a commonly accepted fact that the Southern owns a majority of the stock of the Georgia Southern and Florida.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 22 -- Princeton defeated Dickenson in a loosely played game to-day, scoring 25 runs to 0. Princeton's work at the bat was again the noticeable feature, although the visitors succeeded in striking out eight men. Score:

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The President has not heard the recent Democratic suggestions about the use of the veto power or he has regarded them lightly, for to-day he sent to the Senate two vetoes of bills which he has seen fit to disapprove, although there was no Constitutional question involved in either of them requiring the exercise of the veto.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- There was again heavy trading in Diamond Match. It opened at 199 1/2, advanced to 205 1/2, and closed strong at 205 bid. New-York Biscuit was not as active. It declined from 95 to 94 1/4. The feature of the day was the weakness in Strawboard, which sold off from 43 1/2 to 40, but recovered quickly to 41 1/2. There was but little demand for Metropolitan.

Passenger Agent Taylor of the Fall River Line yesterday confirmed the news from Boston that Chauncey G. Carter, a Harvard student, who left Fall River on the steamboat Pilgrim on Saturday, April 11, had been missing since that time, and that a dress-suit case containing articles of clothing, memoranda, and an overcoat was found in the stateroom.

WEDNESDAY -- P.M. A dispatch sent from this city was published in The London Times this morning setting forth that the Venezuelan matter had not pased out of the dangerous stage, that negotiations are at a standstill, and expressing the opinion that the uncertainties are many and the perils grave.
The New-York Vegetarian Society met last night to consider different kinds of foods. Meats and fish were declared impure and lacking in the nourishment that vegetable foods possess.

LONDON, April 22 -- United States Ambassador Bayard to-day visited the principal educational and literary institutions of Birmingham, and was afterward entertained at a public luncheon by Mayor Smith, who was recently raised to the dignity of Lord Mayor.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 22. -- At the Westchester County Teachers' Institute this morning Conductor Bugbee spoke in the primary department on "Primary Methods," and in the advanced department on "Geometry," and conducted the "Round Table Conference." Miss Anna K. Eggleston spoke in the intermediate department on "Language Work," and in the primary department on "Moral Instruction.
The cargo of the Ward Line steamer Seneca, lying at Pier 17, East River, was discovered on fire soon after 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

The armory tests of the Briggs-Kneeland rifle were completed yesterday by the State board which is examining arms for the purpose of making a selection of a new rifle for the National Guard, at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory, Brooklyn.

-- Semi-official announcement was made yesterday that the time for deposits of securities of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company with J.P. Morgan Co. will expire to-morrow, and will not be extended. Owing to the rapid removal of obstacles to the reorganization and the prospects of an immediate decree of foreclosure, the deposits of securities are expected to be very heavy in the two days left open by the reorganization managers.
BALTIMORE, April 22 -- The Republican State Convention to-day refused to instruct its delegates to St. Louis for any candidate.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Shortly after dark this evening a disturbing rumor was circulated to the effect that while President Cleveland was driving to his Woodley house after leaving the Executive Mansion this evening his carriage came into collision with a cable car. The report said that the President had been thrown out and had received "serious injuries. Inquiries were numerous from all directions.
ALBANY, April 22 -- The Ford bill, requiring a certain standard for lager beer, ale. and porter, was given a hearing to-day before the Senate Committee, on Public Health.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 2 1/2@3 per cent. The last loan was made at 3 per cent.

Weakness in the pitching department and costly errors when the bases were occupied are the cause of the defeat of the New-Yorks in their game against the Philadelphias on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. For two innings Jouett Meekin showed some of his old-time form and disposed of the visitors without a run.

LONDON, April 22 -- The St. James's Gazette, commenting on the dispatch to The Times from G.W. Smalley, the correspondent of that paper in the United States, representing that the Venezuelan dispute is still a question of great gravity and cause for alarm, says:

A sea food staple of the poor folk in Summer, the weakfish, may this year cost double the price of last year. There is "a corner" in this wholesome table commodity which may increase its retail value 100 per cent.

The scheme for leasing the railroad on the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge to one of the Brooklyn elevated railroad companies came too late to be properly considered at this session. of the Legislature, and it is a matter which should not be acted upon with haste. It was seriously compromised last week by the hurried and inconsiderate action of the Senate Committee on Commerce and Navigation, which naturally excited suspicion.
It is proposed to erect a memorial in honor of the late Rev. Thomas McClure Peters, who was rector of St. Michael's here for more than fifty years.
