CHICAGO, April 22 -- Ex-Gov. Pattison of Pennsylvania, on his way to Omaha, said to a reporter:

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Having yesterday invited severe denunciation by voting to award a lot of Indian lawyers a great deal more money than they seem to be entitled to, the Senate to-day, in considering the Indian Appropriation bill, took a more reasonable course in disposing of the item for the support of sectarian schools for, the Indians.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The fourth day at the Bennings track was in some respects an improvement upon the preceding days. The temperature was delightful; there was a very perceptible increase in the attendance, and no small degree of enthusiasm was manifested. The card was light, but the races were up to the average.

A war cloud has burst over the camps of the New-York City Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, and a strong effort is to be made to prevent the re-election of Mrs. Donald McLean as Regent at the annual meeting on April 30. The opposition will seek to elect Miss May Van Buren Vanderpoel, the present First Vice President, as Regent.

LONDON, April 22 -- At the Epsom Spring meeting to-day the race for the City and Suburban Handicap of 2,000 sovereigns, the first of the great English races of the year, was won by "Barney" Barnato's Worcester. Baron de Rothschild's Amandier was second, and Col. North's Hebron third.
Fire was discovered about 6 o'clock last evening on the third floor of the Cable Building, Broadway and Houston Street. It burned rapidly, and soon spread through three offices.

The police force of Jersey City is claiming a new record. The day of the tallest policeman and the fattest policeman has gone by, and the man who can lose the post weight in a given time is now the candidate for honors.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- Chief in importance to wheelmen in New-York City in the weekly bulletin of Chairman Gideon of the League of American Wheelmen's Racing Board is the suspension for one year of all the men who competed in the bicycle races at the Seventh Regiment games on the evening of April 11.

Paderewski sailed yesterday on the steamship Teutonic, not to return to this country probably for two or three years, as he intends to devote that time to composition. He had much to say of the gratification that his last and most profitable visit to this country had been to him. His admirers gave him a veritable ovation before the steamship drew away from her pier.

As soon as it was shown that the French Senate, by a majority of not far from two to one, was determined to prevent a Ministry of which it disapproved from carrying on the Government, there was nothing for the Ministry to do but to resign. It was paralyzed at once by the refusal of the Senate to give it money to go on with.

The Nixon bill, which fixes the rate for fares on the elevated roads and surface lines of this city at thirty rides for $1, and which has already passed the Assembly, will, if it passes the Senate and becomes a law, cause the employment of a large additional force of men and in all probability a considerable reduction in wages.

-- The Edison Electric Illuminating Company of New-York reports its gross earnings for the month' of March at $184,150.64, and the net earnings at $88,494.81. The gross earnings of the company for the same month in 1895 were $166,683.57, and the net earnings $77,897.98, showing an increase of $17,473.07 in the gross earnings and $10,596.88 in the net earnings in favor of the present year.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 22 -- The Connecticut Republican State Convention to-day declared itself for a single gold standard, for protection, and for the Monroe doctrine, and pledged its support to the "man that shall be nominated by the National Republican Convention."
Cyclists wishing to Join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The first session of the National Arbitration Conference was called to order this afternoon at Metzerott's Music Hall, in this city. Written acceptances were received from nearly 400 prominent men in forty-six States and Territories.

DENVER, Col., April 22. -- The American National Bank failed to open its doors this morning, a notice being posted on the window that "by order of the Directors, the bank is in the hands of the Government." Bank Examiner Hille took charge. The event caused much excitement, and a run was at once precipitated on the National Bank of Commerce, a crowd of clamorous depositors gathering soon after 10 o'clock.

S.M. Prevost, General Manager of the Pennsylvania lines east of Pittsburg, has issued his annual report showing the result of the operation of the lines east of Pittsburg and Erie for the year 1895. For that year the earnings were $39,599,001, and the expenses $26,032,873, making the net earnings $13,566,128, which is an increase over 1894 of $1,713,741.

A.L. Canby, manager for Francis Wilson, is here, arranging for the appearance of his star at the Harlem Opera House next week, which will close his season. Mr. Canby says that Wilson's season has heen a very satisfactory one, considering the hard times. Mr. Wilson has a new production in view for his nest season, which will open at Abbey's Theatre next all.

The testing of rifles at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory, Brooklyn, was continued yesterday by the State Board of Examiners for the selection of an improved arm for the National Guard. The Winchester rifle was the arm inspected, and it was put through the course prescribed by Adjt. Gen. McAlpin without injury to the piece.

From The Chicago Record. A few months ago one of the Tokio newspapers asked the school children of Japan to express their opinions by ballot as to who was the greatest man in the history of the world. Very naturally the four chief heroes of the late war with China received the highest number of votes.
Andrew H. Green, Chairman of the Commissioners of the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge, will soon call the Commissioners together to take up the question of laying out a freight approach.

The fine new battleship Indiana, the pioneer ship of her class, is now at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Hundreds of people interested in fighting machines of the floating type have inspected the ship since her arrival at the yard, and all of them found something to marvel at and to admire.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Mercer won his second game from Brooklyn to-day, and, while batted hard, kept his opponents' hits well scattered. Stein had but little speed, and the small score is accounted for by the sharp fielding of the visitors. Dailey essayed to catch Stein, but was not in condition, and retired at the end of the second inning in favor of Grim.

Gustav H. Schwab, New-York agent of the North German Lloyds, was a passenger on the steamship Trave of the North German Lloyd Line, which arrived from Bremen yesterday. Mr. Schwab left here on March 7 for a business tour through Spain. He disembarked from the Kaiser Wilhelm II. at Gibraltar, and visited Grenada, Seville, Cordova, and Madrid.

ALLIANCE, Ohio, April 23 -- Congressman Taylor, in the Eighteenth District Republican Convention, held here yesterday, made an attempt to demonstrate that McKinley is a sound-money man. In the course of a speech he said:

An exhibition of water colors and pastels, by W. Hamilton Gibson, may be seen at the galleries of the American Art Association, on Madison Square South. There are, too, numerous drawings, including a selection of the originals of various illustrations which have appeared in Mr. Gibson's works, "Sharp Eyes" and "Strolls by Starlight and Sunshine," with pictures in wash, body color, pencil, pen, and monotint, designs for magazines and other Duplications.

Application was made to Justice Andrews, in Special Term, Part IV., of the Supreme Court, yesterday by Acker, Merrall Condit and Blackford's for the appointment of a receiver for Hooper C. Barrett and for an order setting aside the conveyance of the lease and property of the Barrett House, at Broadway and Forty-third Street, made by Barrett to his wife, Norma Barrett, on Dec. 26, 1895.

BOSTON, April 23 -- Local stocks show considerable activity between investment buying in the better class of stocks and selling in the mining shares. The latter were weak, with Merced leading, with a decline of 1 1/2, to 14 1/4. Montana declined 1/2, to 76 1/2, and Pioneer, which opened up 1/8, closed 1/8 lower, at 87. Quincy Mining scrip was steady at 80.

The Democrats of Louisiana appear "on the face of the returns" to have reelected Gov. FOSTER, but they came perilously near to defeat, mainly on account of the fight against a corrupt ring in the City of New-Orleans. The people of that city have had a severe lesson in the evil consequences of a close connection between municipal administration and party politics.
ALBANY, April 23 -- The Republican Senators in caucus this morning kicked over the traces and refused to follow the dictation of Mr. Platt's leader, Ellsworth.

The answer of the American Tobacco Company to the application for an injunction to prevent the company's paying a 20 per cent, dividend in scrip was filed with Chancellor McGill at his law office, in Jersey City, yesterday.
In the current issue of The Electrical Engineer a writer has this to say about acetylene as the latest rival of the electric light:
Thomas C. Platt was not ready to say last night whether any supplemental legislation to the Greater New-York bill would be passed at this session.

-- The executive officers and General Passenger Agents of the Western roads have been in joint session in Chicago for two days trying to formulate and agree on the details as to the new mileage ticket restriction plan that was decided on last week by the managers. No final agreement was reached, and the meeting will continue.

The "difficulty" which animated the Washington dispatches to-day and which animated the Naval Committee room yesterday was quite sufficiently disgraceful. But we may derive some comfort from reflecting how much worse it might have been. It might, for example, have been fought out upon the floor of the House and have constituted a National scandal.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Secretary Herbert is in favor of the double turret as adopted for the Kentucky and Kearsarge, and unless the Walker board, now in session, produces something new and startling against the system, the two-storied structure will be included in the plans of the battleships authorized in the Naval Appropriation bill pending in Congress.

The news of the appointment by State Excise Commissioner Lyman of excise officials for the Kings County district reached Brooklyn late last night, and the enemies of Mayor Wurster were greatly elated.

The new thing at Koster Bial's last night was Edison's vitascope, exhibited for the first time. The ingenious invertor's latest toy is a projection of his kinetoscope figures, in stereopticon fashion, upon a white screen in a darkened hall. In the centre of the balcony of the big music hall is a curious object, which looks from below like the double turret of a big monitor.

The feature of the regular weekly sale at the American Horse Exchange yesterday was the first appearance of Morgan-bred stock under the hammer in this city. There has been a recognized family descended from Justin Morgan that has produced many noted harness racers, but it is only of late years that an official register of Morgans has been opened.

NEWARK, N.J., April 23 -- Martin Doyle, forty years old, was committed to await the action of the Grand Jury to-day by Justice O'Reilly of South Orange on the charge of assault and battery on Elizabeth Edward of South Orange. Doyle was taken from South Orange to be brought to the County Jail here, and while on the way he managed to slip the handcuffs from his hand.

-- R. C.W. Hutchins of Brooklyn have purchased the Nonparell, and will fit her out at once. The Nonparell was built in England, and was rigged as a yawl. She was last owned by H. Sanderson, and was wrecked at Larchmont two years ago.

BOSTON, April 23 -- The battleship Massachusetts was given a preliminary run by the builders over the official course to-day. The trial was so satisfactory that only two-fifths of the distance was steamed over. The ship was speeded for a little less than two hours, and in that time she averaged 15.59 knots an hour, which is 59 of a knot above her contract speed.

Mrs. Ida De Treville of 201 West One Hundredth Street, wife of Jonn De Treville and said to be connected with the Calhoun family of South Carolina, died Wednesday morning from a self-inflicted wound, but the fact of her suicide did not become public until yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The National Arbitration Convention to-day adopted resolutions declaring its views with reference to the establishment of a permanent international court of arbitration. The Committee on Resolutions reported the following as a substitute for the several propositions referred to it:

A great day for golfers in this vicinity is promised to-morrow. Besides the St. Andrew's and Knollwood Country Clubs, which will formally open their season of tournaments, the Essex County Country Club of Orange, N.J., will have a little informal playing by the members, and the Paterson Golf Club of Paterson, N.J., will also open its season.

Commissioner Willis, Walter B. Atterbury, Controller Palmer, County Clerk Saffen, Sheriff Buttling, Robert Sharkey, and Jacob Brenner held another conference in the Brooklyn Club yesterday. Messrs. Willis, Atterbury, and Brenner represented the Wurster-Willis faction, and the others the Worth faction.
The house of J.P. Lonsdale at, 623 Avenue E. Bayonne, was entered by burglars Wednesday night One hundred dollars in cash and a gold watch were taken.

The Grard Jury found several indictments yesterday for excise violations, and it was reported that it was not altogether satisfied with the action of the police under the Raines law. It was said that the jurymen thought too many arrests were made upon insufficient evidence, and have decided to throw out about half of the complaints.

Vicomte Clary, who died at Paris on April 7, aged eighty years, was a nephew of Queen Julie, wife of the first King of Sweden of the Bernadotte line. In Algeria, as aide de camp of Marshal Bugeaud, he tired of the army, resigned his commission, studied for the bar, and became an advocate.

The President of the Yale Union, the debating society of the university, which will meet the Harvard Union in the annual debate next week, announced yesterday that the following judges have been selected for the debate: Elihu Root of New-York City, Walter H. Page, editor of The Atlantic Monthly, and Albert Shaw, editor of The Review of Reviews.

In continuing his argument in the Joint Traffic Association test case before Judge Wheeler, in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday, James C. Carter, general counsel for the railroad companies, said that the trunk line roads were compelled to enter into the joint traffic agreement (the legality of which is questioned by the Interstate Commerce Commission) as a matter of necessity in order to protect their interests and expedite business.

ALBANT, April 23 -- By a score of 20 to 15 the Democrats of the Assembly this afternoon proved to the Republicans of that house that, while the majority might turn out laws with the dexterity of a patented machine, it was away behind the minority in playing ball. It was the annual game of baseball that was played, and it was the usual farce, although two of the first-termers evidently took the thing seriously.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 23 -- As reports of the election from over, the State are received the situation is improving for the Democrats. Foster's majority in New-Orleans is now certain to be 5,000; the few remaining precincts will not change that majority to any extent.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Cleveland was fishing to-day on the preserve of Henry Harrison, near Leesburg, in Loudoun County, Va., about forty miles from Washington. He spent yesterday clearing up public business so that he could take the holiday.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 2 1/2 @ 3 per cent. The last loan was made at 3 per cent.

The Thirteenth Regiment, known as the "mother regiment," last night celebrated the thirty-fifth anniversary of the departure of the regiment for the seat of war, at the Sumner Avenue Armory, Brooklyn.

Edgar Allan Poe's cottage was the subject of much oratory in Mayor Strong's office yesterday. A bill has been passed by the Legislature providing for the removal of the cottage from its present site, One Hundred and Ninety-second Street and King's Bridge Road, 82 feet to the west to the proposed Poets' Park, which it is suggested the city shall establish.

-- Coleridge, at Nether Stowey, in Somersetshire, wrote "Christabel" and the "Ancient Mariner"; but Coleridge's cottage is in peril of becoming a village public house. A committee leased it, three years ago, at L15 a year for fifteen years; but some of the members of the committee have died, and the rest will not, or cannot, make up the deficiency in subscriptions.

District Attorney Fellows and a member of a committee representing the Central Labor Union presented to the Grand Jury yesterday morning the complaints of employes of the Metropolitan Traction Company.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The fifth day of the Bennings races was a gratifying exhibition in many particulars. The day was an ideal one for racing cloudy and cool, the attendance was greatly improved over the preceding days, and the events were well contested. The favorites won every one of the events.

HAVANA, April 23 -- The rebels have captured Cruces, an important town near Santa Clara. The Spanish troops remained within the forts about the town, apparently afraid to venture forth to attempt to repulse the insurgents. The latter, after entering the place, set fire to the houses of several well-known supporters of the Government.
Brookline Street, south side, 40 feet west of Webster Avenue, for a two-story frame stable and workshop, by Cornelius B. Sehuyler of Decatur Avenue and Brookline Street, owner; cost, $400.

Herr Engels was brought by the role which he played at the Irving Place Theatre last night into direct and somewhat dangerous comparison with an extremely popular American comedian. "Der Compagnon," a farce by Adolf l'Arronge, is the work which, translated, slightly condensed, and still more slightly "adapted" by Miss Martha Morton, became "His Wife's Father," and was presented by Mr. William H. Crane at the Fifth Avenue Theatre fourteen months ago.

The consolidationists in Brooklyn were jubilant yesterday over the result of the passage of the Consolidation bill. On top of the Brooklyn Real Estate Exchange there floated a bright red flag labeled, in white letters. "Greater New-York."

-- The new mosaic decorations which have been carried on in the choir of St. Paul's Cathedral, London, under the superintendence of the late George Richmond, R.A., have recently been thrown open to public inspection. Many difficulties presented themselves to the architect in the construction of his design for the mosaics.
Andrew H. Green, President of the Greater New-York Commission, said yesterday that he had no doubt that Gov. Morton would sign the Greater New-York bill.

-- The Shakespeare Club of New-York City commemorated the birthday of the poet last evening by giving an elaborate reception at the Marlborough. The guests were received by Frederick George Smedley, the President of the club; Mrs. Frederick George Smedley, Mrs. John De witt Warner, Miss Lilian Mills, and John Kyle.

Inspector Moses W. Cortright, the only officer of rank between Captain and Chief in the Police Department, was on Wednesday afternoon detailed to the command of the force by Chief Conlin, who thereupon began his furlough of fifty days.

ALBANY, April 23 -- State Excise Commissioner Lyman to-day appointed the following special agents at $1,200 each to serve in Erie County: P.I. McDonnell, Jacob Gundlach of Buffalo, and R.W. Larkin of Clarence. The cashier appointed is Frederick O. Murray, the assistant cashier James W. Harrington, and the auditor J.P. Loftus.

THURSDAY -- P.M. Strength was the feature of the market until the afternoon, when a break of 5 points in American Tobacco caused hesitation in the whoie list. The excuse given for the decline in Tobacco was the probability that the payment of the scrip dividend recently declared would be enjoined by the courts.

LONDON, April 23 -- The Vicar of Trinity, (the Rev. George Arbuthnot,) whose guest Mr. Bayard was to-day, dedicated a window, at a cost of $400, with money received from American visitors to Shakespeare's tomb and from others whom the vicar interested in the project during a recent visit to the United States.

PARIS, April 23 -- The members of the Bourgeois Ministry proceeded this afternoon to the Elysee, and formally tendered their resignations to the President, who accepted them as soon as they were presented.

Henry Hentz, Chairman of the Sound-Money Committee of the Chamber of Commerce, referring yesterday to the active efforts of commercial bodies throughout the country in the movement to secure the adoption of sound-money planks in the platforms of the two political parties, said:

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

VIENNA, April 23 -- The Unterhaus of the Austrian Diel, by a vote of 173 to 61, today rejected the scheme of universal suffrage proposed by the German National, Young Czech, and Democratic Parties. After disposing of this proposal, the House proceeded to discuss the Government's scheme of electoral reform.

Two hundred and thirty of the 350 saloon beepers in Hoboken who are members of the Hoboken Inn Keepers' Protective Association yesterday received notice from Julius Schlatter, Secretary of the association, in regard to the Sunday observance question.

The much-talked-about cross-island highway on Long Island between Patchogue and Port Jefferson, a distance of fourteen miles, is again up for consideration. A Board of Commissioners appointed by the County Judge met yesterday at Patchogue to hear arguments for and against the road, which runs across Brookhaven town through several villages.
"Do I like them? Well, you may take away my bed and take away my grub, but don't take away those fellows. And I haven't any favorites. If one is stupid he is the same to me."
ALBANY, April 23 -- In advance of any action by Gov. Morton on the Greater New-York bill, suggestions are heard as to the Commissioners to be appointed under it.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Judge Windes this morning decided the famous Kennett, Hopkins Co. petition for a mandamus to compel the Chicago Board of Trade Directors to restore the firm to its former membership. The court declined to issue a mandamus as to Francis J. Kennett, but granted one to J.F. Harris, Kennett's former partner.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 23 -- The Academic Faculty to-day announced the successful competitors for the commencement appointments from the present senior class to speak on the commencement stage in June. The Latin salutatory, the highest honor usually conferred at Princeton, was captured by Frederick William Loetscher of Dubuque, Iowa.

NEWARK, N.J., April 23 -- The baseball season of the Atlantic League began to-day. The opening game in this city was between the Newarks and Metropolitans of Jersey City. About 1,500 persons, including many ladies, were present. The game was very interesting until the seventh inning, when Korwin of the Newarks lost control of the ball, and sent several men to bases on balls, which netted the visitors six runs, and gave them the game.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- Jephtha Howe, the St. Louis lawyer who, with H. H. Holmes, was indicted for conspiracy at the time of the discovery of the fraud against the Fidelity Mutual Life Association, is in town for the purpose of having the indictment abandoned by the authorities. Howe arrived in Philadelphia almost simultaneously with Mrs. Pietzel, for the murder of whose husband Holmes is to be hanged May 7.

Miss Annie Josephine Levi read a paper on "Intermarriage" before the New-York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women, which met yesterday afternoon in the vestry rooms of the Temple Beth-El, at Fifth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street. The meeting was well attended, and the paper attracted much attention.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- There is no likelihood that the bill introduced in both houses providing for the establishment of a military and National park upon the Palisades of the Hudson will pass. It was referred to the Senate Committee on Military Affairs a few days ago and will be sent to the Secretary of War to-morrow, in accordance with custom.
LONDON, April 23 -- In the house of Commons to-day Mr. Labouchere asked the Government a number of questions in regard to the Venezuelan dispute.

Wilson Marshall is having his schooner Atlantic go: ready at Greenport. She will be ready by June 1, and will then look like a new yacht. Several boats hare wintered at Greenport, and are now being prepared for the yachting season. Commodore Roome's Vivid is hauled out at Fordham's yard for general repairs. George Ide's cutter Cora is nearly ready for her rigging.

PARIS, April 23 -- The Champ de Mars Salon was officially opened to-day. Changes which have been made in the exhibit since the publication in these dispatches of a partial list of the contributions have rendered the display far below the previous exhibitions in point of excellence. DagnanBouveret's "Last Supper" is the only canvas which is likely to be seriously discussed.

What excuse or reason there can be for Gov. MORTON'S delay in signing the elevated road lamp bill passes all comprehension. The Manhattan Company has no vote, and controls, directly at least, but very few of them. The Governor is a man who cannot be even suspected of yielding to arguments of the kind to which, with obvious success, this corporation instinctively resorts when dealing with statesmen of a different class.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

James M. Platfoot, Superintendent of the Long Island State Hospital at King's Park, L.I., was arraigned before United States Commissioner Morle, in Brooklyn, yesterday, on the charge of having violated the internal revenue law in manufacturing cigars without furnishing a bond to the Collector.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Argument in the sugar-bounty cases was continued in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day. E.B. Whitney, Assistant Attorney General, finished his argument, begun yesterday.

The trial of Victor S. Flechter, who is charged with receiving a Stradivarius violin, stolen from the late Prof. Jean Joseph Bott, two years ago, was resumed yesterday in Part I. of the General Sessions Court, before Recorder Goff.

HARRISBURG, Penn., April 23 -- Senator Quay's Presidential boom was launched today by the Republican State Convention, but there was a McKinley demonstration that detracted somewhat from the expected joyousness of the occasion. The Senator's old-time enemy, "Chris" Magee of Pittsburg.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Indian Appropriation bill, carrying an amount of about $9,100,000, was passed by the Senate to-day, after a long discussion about the lawless condition of affairs in the Indian Territory.
SING SING, N.Y., April 23 -- Louis P. Herrmann and Charles Pustalka, the New-York wife murderers, were put to death in Sing Sing Prison shortly before noon today. Both men met their fate calmly.

Messrs. Frederick Southack Co. have sold for the Robert L. Cutting estate the four-story and basement brownstone dwelling 141 Fifth Avenue, and for Clarence A. Seward the adjoining similar dwelling 143 Fifth Avenue, at a total of $225,000. The lots together make a plot 48 by 90. Beginning on May 1, the present buildings will be torn down and a nine-story fire-proof store and lofts building will be erected in their stead.

John Mackin, who was convicted Wednesday of the murder of his wife, shows signs of breaking down in the Hudson County (N.J.) jail. He weeps and appears nervous. He told Constable Kaiser that the jury had acted without giving the evidence due consideration. He will be sentenced May 2 to be hanged, the penalty for murder in the first degree in New-Jersey.
A Jesse Seligman memorial given to the Hebrew Orphan Asylum by subscription was unveiled at the asylum. One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, yesterday afternoon.

Mayor Strong gave his approval to the Pavey-Page Compromise School bill yesterday. He announced his determination a few minutes after he had a conference with President Maclay of the Board of Education and School Commissioner Strauss, both of whom are opposed to the bill.

James F. Brackett, dressed in the uniform of a United States soldier, was arraigned in the County Court, Brooklyn, before Judge Hurd, yesterday, charged with grand larceny, in stealing a time-dating stamp from Louis A. Richards of 218 Pulton Street.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 23 -- The Dominion Parliament was formally prorogued at 8 o'clock to-night by the Governor General. His Excellency proceeded to the Senate Chamber and took his seat upon the throne. The members, of the Senate and House being assembled, his Excellency closed the sixth session of the Seventh Parliament of the Dominion of Canada with the following speech:

ALBANY, April 24. -- Superintendent Kilburn of the State Banking Department has appointed Charles W. Hermans of Albany and Edward H. Thompson of Millerton, whose names were on the civil service list, as Bank Examiners.

CAPE TOWN, April 24. -- A dispatch from Bulawayo, dated April 24, says that Commander Duncan, with 100 whites and 200 natives with Maxim and Hotchkiss guns, met the Matabeles three miles out from Bulawayo.

HAZELTON, Penn., April 24. -- An exciting shooting affray occurred at White Haven this morning when a posse of citizens attacked a band of robbers who were fleeing from Mauch Chunk. Five men gained an entrance to the East Mauch Chunk Post Office shortly after midnight. They blew open the safe with dynamite.

We have had no expectation that the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court would hold otherwise than it has done, that the Raines liquor-tax law is Constitutional. We have not hesitated to say that the contention that it was in any sense a special city law was absurd.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- There was a brief but important meeting of the Executive Committee of the new Transcontinental Freight Association at the Auditorium today, the result being of vital interest to every shipper on the Pacific coast and in contiguous territory. At the Milwaukee meeting the roads agreed to advance rates about 25 per cent., after the Panama Railway war had forced them to do business at a loss since 1893.

The Metropolitans, or, to be more correct, the second nine of the New-York team, who represent Jersey City in the Atlantic Association, played the opening local championship game with the Newark team on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. Lake the Giants, the Metropolitans made a failure.

The fight between the beleaguered British in Bulawayo and the Matabeles seems to have been a severe and desperate affair. As the account comes from a British source, there is no reason to doubt its assertion that the British got much the worse of the fight, and it is not unfair to suspect that the result was even more unfavorable in fact than it is in the report.

The success attending the first annual field day of the Drisler School Athletic Association, held at Berkeley Oval yesterday afternoon, was most encouraging to the 800 enthusiastic schoolboys and their friends present. Two records were broken, excellent time made, and exciting finishes were furnished in every events.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 24. -- Hartford again defeated New-Haven to-day by 7 to 6. The New-Havens had an excellent chance to win in the last inning, with two men on bases, but Clements was steady, and the last batter knocked an easy grounder. Gilman pitched for New-Haven, and was hit Safely eleven times. The score:

MADRID, April 24. -- A dispatch to the Imparcial from Havana says that Gen. Gonzalez, who sailed from Manzanillo with a large force, landed near Fort Zanya and marched to the relief of that place. The fort had been besieged for five days by 3,500 rebels under Rabi, whose guns were served by Americans.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 24. -- The slander case against the Rev. Dr. Joseph Pullman of the First Methodist Church of this city, brought by Mlle Jane May, the French actress and pantomimist, in which she asked for $25,000 damages, alleging that the clergyman, from the pulpit, referred to her as a "low, brilliant swell Parisian courtesan," is to be withdrawn.

There was a recommendation in Secretary LAMONT'S last annual report Which gathers force and timeliness just now from the liberal provision which is certain to be made for carrying forward the work of coast defense.

Undoubtedly Gen. WEYLER has made a much more energetic use of the forces under his command than his predecessor made. It seems that he has succeeded in establishing, for the first time that it has been established since the insurrection began, a chain of posts across the island, amounting to a land blockade.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- In the Federal Court suit was brought by Robert R. Beard, receiver of the First National Bank of Pella, Iowa, against the commission firm of Milmine, Bodman Co., Chicago and NewYork, members of the Board of Trade and the Stock Exchange of those cities.

From The Manchester (England) Guardian. The famous Japanese painter, Kyosai, worked only when he was in the mood, and the most munificent offers failed to induce him to accept a commission unless the spirit moved him. One of his admirers, Mr. Kato Shoyo of Hongo, had vainly attempted to induce the wayward artist to begin a painting for him.

The bowling teams of the Chase National Bank, the American Exchange. First National, and Mercantile National Banks bowled in the Bank Clerks' Tournament last night, and three interesting games resulted. The winners were the Chase, First, and Mercantile teams. Garrison of the First made the highest score -- 187, with Booth of the Chase next, with 186.

The work of Boss QUAY, Boss PLATT, and their Western ally, CLARKSON, in the House Committee on Territories appears to have been completed, for a favorable report upon the bill to elevate Oklahoma to the rank of a State has been procured. Action upon this bill was delayed for a long time.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court handed down its decision yesterday affirming the constitutionality of the Raines bill. Justice Patterson wrote the opinion, and the other four Justices -- Charles H. Van Brunt, George C. Barrett, William Rumsey, and Pardon C. Williams -- concurred.

PARIS, April 24. -- A monster meeting was held to-night at Tivoli Hall, under Socialist auspices, to denounce the action of the Senate, which resulted in the overthrow of the Bourgeois Ministry. Thousands of people were unable to gain admission to the hall.

Reports from the Northwest and the Southwest continue to bring assurances of rapidly improving conditions with regard to railway traffic, and the remarkable increase in the earnings of some of the Granger roads shows that the recent hopeful predictions of such railroad Presidents as HUGHITT, MILLER, and CABLE were well founded.

Henry B. Hebert, Chairman of the Produce Exchange Grain Committee, which has been working for an adjustment of grain rates to this port, sent a letter yesterday to Joint Traffic Commissioner George R. Blanchard, which describes the status of the movement by the committee to persuade the trunk line railroads to give this port rates for grain as low as other Atlantic ports enjoy.

ALBANY, April 24. -- The Assembly to-day passed a bill which has evidently something in it for the "Huckleberry" Railroad Company. Discussion of it has brought to the surface other bills, backed by William F. Sheehan, as attorney for the "Huckleberry," which are said to be directly in favor of this corporation, which, a few years ago, made such an extended grab through the agency of the Legislature.

George Munro died suddenly Thursday morning at Pine Hill, in the Catskills, where he had gone to superintend repairs and improvements on his country home. He fell dead on the road between the late Dr. Howard Crosby's house and his own while walking from breakfast to the place where his men were at work.

-- The closing days of a busy season find a few new importations of English pictures at the Blakeslee Galleries, 353 Fifth Avenue. One of the most important of these is a portrait by Sir Thomas Lawrence of a Miss Baring, who is represented facing the spectator and standing in the midst of a Summer landscape.

ALBANY, April 24. -- Senator "Barney" Martin of New-York has been the subject of congratulations this evening for the part he took in summarily ridding the Senate floor of a lobbyist at this afternoon's session. He literally "chased" him out of the room.

If our high-tariff friends who have recently been complaining about the alleged effect of the present tariff upon business and the industries will pause for a moment and inquire as to their own utterances of ten months ago, they will learn something to their disadvantage. It was in last April and May that a very interesting and cheering upward movement in trade and industry began.
ALBANY, April 24. -- The finest exhibition thus far given of "smoking out" the Senators took place this morning.

ALBANY, April 24. -- The legislative subcommittee which investigated the administration of the civil service law last year submitted its report to the Legislature today. The testimony regarding the condition of affairs in the Brooklyn Civil Service Commission was published at the time and is reviewed at length.

ALBANY, April 24. -- The bill of Mr. Sanger, compelling campaign committees to file items of election expenses, failed to secure the Constitutional number of votes in the House to-day, and was declared lost. Mr. Sanger saved the bill from permanent death by moving to reconsider and that that motion lie upon the table.

LONDON, April 25 -- There was a little street fighting between soldiers and police on one side and the populace on the other in Paris last night. Half of the correspondents stationed there for the London papers treat it as trivial; the other half deem it an overture to a sinister period of mob violence.

PATERSON, N.J., April 25 -- Despite the threatening weathter, there was a good attendance at the opening game of the season of the Paterson Golf Club at its links along the Boulevard this afternoon. The opening event was the monthly medal handicap, open to club members only, and about twenty-five men competed. The grounds were rather rough, but the playing was very good, and in one case exceptionally so, A.H. Larkin going around in 96.

The activities of a very busy musical season are rapidly drawing toward a close. The climax of public demonstrations over musical performance was probably reacted a week ago, when the audience at Mr. Paderewski's final piano recital behaved as if he were about to be caught up in a chariot of fire and disappear forever in the impalpable ether, not letting his robe fall upon a successor.

BRIDGEPORT, April 25 -- An old volume of the records of the town of Fairfield, dating back more than 200 years, was found by H. Edward Rowland recently in an old oak trunk in the garret of the Rowland homestead, where it had been hidden for more than 100 years. The book contains the earliest records of the town and the church of Fairfield.

"Thoroughbred," the new comic play at the Garrick Theatre, is bright and ingenious, and so well staged and acted that it will survive any ordinary spell of hot weather; wherefore a long run may be safely expected for it. The author is Ralph Lumley, who made "Aunt Jack," and the piece was done in JLondon by Toole, whose portrayal of old Mr. Rimple was highly praised.

PITTSBURG, April 25 -- The disappearance of the Catholic priest George Francis Dillon and Rose Donovan, both of Braddock, is made interesting by a report that they were married at the Windsor Hotel, Cumberland, Md., Nov. 15 last, by the Rev. J. C. Nicholson, pastor of the Cumberland Episcopal Church.

Gov. Morton and his staff, the Mayors of New-York and Brooklyn, and several thousand people witnessed the unveiling and presentation yesterday afternoon to the City of Brooklyn of W.O. Partridge's bronze equestrian statue of Gen. Grant.

It is generally supposed that cricket in this country is played only by Englishmen, of those who learned the game in England. In New-York and Boston, and, perhaps, Chicago, the majority of cricketers are Englishmen, but in Phila- delphia the crick players, and the future players, are Americans.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., April 25 -- The annual inter-collegiate and inter-scholastic relay race carnival of the University of Pennsylvania was held this afternoon on Franklin Field, the athletic grounds of the University. In addition to the relay races, other athletic events were contested by University of Pennsylvania athletes.

BOSTON, April 25 -- In her official trial trip to-day, the battleship Massachusetts covered the 62 knots of the official Government course in 3 hours 50 minutes and 25 seconds, making the magnificent average for the four hours of 16.15 knots -- a speed which places her in the very front of ships of her class in all the navies of the world.
The fate of a stupendous real estate transaction depends upon Gov. Morton's action with regard to the Greater New-York bill.

Naples Dispatch in The London News. "Per curlosita," as the Italians say, I translate some sentences from a report of the Emperor William's visit recently to Camaldoli, Whither the Archbishop of Naples repaired to meet him. The report seems to be from the pen of the Archbishop's Chamberlain.

"Thoroughbred," the new comic play at the Garrick Theatre, is bright and ingenious, and so well staged and acted that it will survive any ordinary spell of hot weather; wherefore a long run may be safely expected for it. The author is Ralph Lumley, who made "Aunt Jack," and the piece was done in JLondon by Toole, whose portrayal of old Mr. Rimple was highly praised.

Gustave May, one of the most prominent men in the French colony in this city, and a political exile from his native land, died Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. His funeral, which took place from his home, 101 West Eighty-ninth Street, yesterday, was as simple as it was possible to make it.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., April 25 -- Harry Kugler, a local veterinarian, died a few days ago. At first it was doubtful what disease had caused his death, but it has been discovered that he was treating a horse ill with glanders, and it is now recognized that the doctor died from the disease, which he contracted from the horse.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., April 25 -- Two masked men attempted to rob the station agent here to-night. The station agent and Peter Sisco, the colored driver of the Wells-Fargo Express Company at this place, were wounded by a bullet fired at them, but neither was much hurt.
CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., April 25 -- Cripple Creek has lost a million dollars by fire to-day.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The toothsome Potomac shad is in evidence this Spring in numbers so far in excess of the demand that it is becoming a drug in the market. Were it not for orders received from New-York and other large cities where the fame of the fish is great, the local dealers would be in a sad state of mind.
Notice has been sent to the stockholders pf the Southern National Bank asking them to assent, at a meeting on May 28, to liquidation of the affairs of that bank.

From The Kansas City (Mo.) Star. Objects which never fail just now to attract the attention of travelers over Western Kansas are flocks of wild geese feeding upon the rich fields of wheat, which this Spring seem to spread a carpet of green over all the broad domain. To rest and refresh themselves in their annual flight northward, the geese alight in these fields.

Lovers of justice will remark with pleasure that the Rev. Dr. PULLMAN of Bridgeport has been induced publicly to eat some slanderous language which he promulgated from his pulpit against a French actress. They will be less elated by his assertion that, however wounding to his self-love the necessity of retracting his slanders may have been, the utterance of them "has not cost him a cent."

Signs of uneasiness have appeared at the Custom House because of the apparent disposition in Congress to curtail the appropriation asked for by the Treasury Department to cover deficiencies in the regular allowance for the collection of customs revenues.
ROCKVILLE, Ind., April 25 --Peter Egbert, at 7 o'clock this morning, shot and killed Mrs. Herman Haacke, her two children, Herman and Agnes, Sheriff W.D. Mull, Constable W.M. Sweem, and himself.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Cleveland to-day vetoed a bill granting a pension to Francis E. Hoover, who served one year and nine months in the army, and who was pensioned at $50 a month.

We alluded a few days since to the feeling among business men that the Republican Party was about to declare for sound money in no uncertain manner, and that on such a declaration, with a candidate fitly and honestly representing the sound-money sentiment, the party was almost sure to win.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The Rev. Timothy Jonathan Lee, in his denial of plagiarism in the parting ode to his class at Yale College many years ago, advances some startling ethics, even for him.

BOSTON, April 25 -- The steel schooner Ingomar, designed by Wintringham, for John J. Barrett of New-York, was successfully launched this morning from Lawley's City Point yard. Her owner was not present, but was represented by her designer. The Ingomar is 90 feet over all, 63 feet water line, 18 feet 4 inches beam, and 8 feet 2 inches draught, with a steel centreboard 16 feet long, under the cabin floor.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The second conference report upon the Legislative, Executive, and Judicial Appropriation bill was made to the House to-day and agreed to, another conference being ordered upon the few remaining matters in dispute.
MACY'S, Sixth Ave. and 14th Street.

Taking everything into account the past week has been not only a noticeably busy one for real estate men in this city, but also a satisfactory one to many because of the results. The fag ends of the renting season, with the accompaniment of lease making, has brought considerable activity and the sales have been quite numerous.

The Prince de Sagan, believing that he recognized in a character in "La Meute," the new play at the Renaissance, in Paris, a resemblance to himself, challenged M. Abel Hermant, the author. The duel was fought in the park at St. Ouen on the 13th inst., and is thus described by Le Temps:

George J. Gould, President of the Manhattan Railroad Company, and Russell Sage called on Mayor Strong yesterday morning and had a long conference with him in reference to the development of the Manhattan system so as to meet the present demands for rapid transit.

ORANGE, N.J., April 25 -- The Orange Athletic Club baseball nine played its first game of the season this afternoon at the Orange Oval, and fell an easy prey to the Princeton University team. The borne team showed lack of practice, and made costly errors, notably in the fourth inning, when the visitors made five runs. Up to that time the game was a good one.
RICHMOND, Va., April 25 -- The annual congress of the Sons of the American Revolution will be held at Richmond April 30.

It hardly seems possible that in these days any man except an out-and-out churchman can be so moved by the text of the "Stabat Mater" as to be irresistibly impelled to set it to music. Yet without such an impulse he is hardly likely to achieve great success, for this text has been set and reset, composed, discomposed, and decomposed by church writers great and small.

Inspector Thomas Murphy, who has charge of the precincts in the outlying districts of Brooklyn, ascertained, a few days ago that the patrolmen in the Seventeenth Precinct in the Twenty-sixth Ward were not doing their duty, and he started a little investigation on his own account. Dressed in the costume of a farmer he went about Thursday night and early Friday morning and secured the evidence he was after.

LAKEWOOP, N.J., April 25 -- The hunting season of the Ocean County Hunt and Country Club closed to-day with a chase after a live fox. The day was cool and cloudy, but a large number of spectators gathered at the kennels at 3 P.M. to see the start, many of the carriages following along the highway as near the course as possible, guided by the music of the pack.

ALBANY, April 25 -- Senator Raines told the correspondent of THE NEW-YORK TIMES that to-morrow would he about the last opportunity for those who had been selling liquors on Sunday as "hotel keepers" to evade the law.

The royal "Counterblast" proclaims that "smoke becomes a kitchen far better than a dining chamber; and yet it makes a kitchen oftentimes in the inward parts of men, soyling and infecting with an unctuous and oyly kind of soote, as hath been found in some great tobacco takers that after death were opened."

LONDON, April 25 -- The secession of the Healyites from the Anti-Parnellites has now become definite. The party whips have informed Mr. Healy and his friends that they can no longer attend, the meetings of the followers of Mr. Dillon, and that they are at liberty to take independent action in every way.

I have in my mind's eye two old persons, the best I ever knew, the best I ever hope to know. No one would perhaps actually call them "leaders." They never see even the outside of a novel. I have indeed heard them quote "Lothair," and I think "Pickwick" -- which to me is evidence of the tremendous rage there must once have been for these two works of fiction.

Zoological experts at the Smithsonian Institution are busy studying and inventing names for the strange animals cast up by the wonderful artesian well at San Marcos, Texas. Some of them have been forwarded to Washington in bottles and jars, and much excitement has been occasioned among Government scientists.

ALBANY, April 25 -- Nobody who was present in the Senate Chamber this morning could recall that the Senate ever before had held a session on Saturday. The session to-day might have been omitted without injury to the inter of the people of the State. Few Senators were present, and no business of importance was transacted.

TRENTON, April 25 -- The formal observance of the birthday of Gen. U.S. Grant on Tuesday brings to the notice of many prominent citizens of this State pleasant reminiscences showing that he was largely identified with the affairs of New-Jersey. He never was a citizen of the State, but he was a resident during the most important periods of his life.
Among the autographs sold at auction by Bangs Co. yesterday was one by Washington, the price received being $37.

ALBANY, April 25 -- Senator Raines has a scheme for a general investigation of the workings of his new liquor tax law during the Summer, for the purpose of ascertaining what changes should be made in the next session of the Legislature. If he shall succeed in carrying his point a comfortable junket will be provided for such Senators as shall be appointed for the work.

A flood of condemnation is now being directed against the practice of carrying babies on bicycles. It is not recalled that any child has recently-been hurt as a result of this custom, yet the thought of the possibility of accident causes the average woman to grow faint, and every father, unless he be a cyclist, to shudder.

NYACK, April 25 -- An unusually interesting season is anticipated by the Tappan Zee Yacht Club, a wealthy and prosperous organization of Grand View, two miles below this town. The season will be opened on May 30, with a special race for half-raters, open to the clubs of the Long Island Racing Union and the New-York Yacht Racing Association.
An exciting incident happened at the wedding of Miss Minnie Wile and Mr. Eugene Arthur Wolff, which was solemnized at the Temple Beth Zion last evening.
Father William Smith, S.P.M., was talking yesterday or clerical vestments at the House of the Fathers of Mercy, on Twenty-fourth Street.

For two inning's the New-Yorks looked like winners against the Bostons yesterday afternoon. They were playing steady ball and hitting fairly well, and in consequence the 5,000 spectators who journeyed to the Polo Grounds renewed their confidence in the ability of the team to finally win another game.

In the North American continent the spirit of adventure is strong. During the Crimean war I was an attache at the Washington Legation, and as this was above forty years ago, I do not suppose that I am disclosing secrets in saying what then occurred. We received orders to, recruit a force for the Crimea.
"Sorry Charley Boots is not coming East this Summer," remarked The Plunger as he finished reading a letter and proceeded to light his cigar preparatory to his afterlunch siesta.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Erastus Wiman to-day appeared before the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce in advocacy of ah amendment to the Interstate Commerce law, the purpose of which was to justify the creation of an "Outer belt line" to intercept no less than ten railways within fifteen miles of Jersey City, and to deflect freight across the Arthur Kill Bridge.

When William Cowper, himself a Hertfordshire man, clashed off "the diverting history of John Gilpin," he little thought that he had made the Ware Road from London to Hertfordshire the best known in all Britain, that generation after generation would read with delight the story of that famous ride over the stones of Cheapside, on through merry Islington, past "The Bell" at Edmonton, to Ware.

The plain truth is that the natural fighting power of Asiatics and Africans is very nearly equal to that of Europeans, so nearly equal that whenever the dark men are even decently organized and armed, or led by a man of capacity, the white men's advantage disappears, and they have to fight with all the care and generalship and even numbers which they would require in Europe.

When Boss PLATT meets his "Sunday school class" to-day at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, to point out the path of duty for the closing week of the legislative session, he will doubtless be constrained to tell them, perhaps with sad regret, that there is to be no extension of the session for the purpose of passing supplementary Greater New-York bills.

There is to be no supplemental legislation regarding the Greater New-York at this session of the Legislature, and there are indications that Thomas C. Platt has been "jollying" a number of local politicians who had been led to believe that fine jobs were to be provided for them by the consolidation of various departments in the Greater New-YorK territory through the medium of proposed supplemental bills.

Correct answers to the problem published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of April 12 have been received from Edward Miller, New-York, and B.I. Bachman, New-York. In last Sunday's edition of THE TIMES attention was called to the extraordinary progress being made by women in playing whist. A quick verification of it is found in Miss Mervile's solution of the problem of April 19. It is as follows.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- For six innings to-day the Phillies could do nothing with Pitcher Payne. In the seventh he became a trifle wild, sending two men to first on balls and hitting another Grim then made a wild throw, and Hallman a single, all of which netted the Phillies 3 runs. In the eighth inning Payne resumed his wildness, and the Phillies developed a batting streak which yielded 6 runs more.

Our ancestors had a curious habit of connecting the names of plants with those of various well-known animals. Our present habits are so different that many moderns are wholly unable to understand this. To them such names as fox-glove and harebell seem entirely senseless, and many efforts, more ingenious than well directed, have been made to evade the evidence.

Officials attached to the Collector's and Appraiser's departments at this port have been engaged at intervals since Jan. 13 in trying to figure out whether the United States Government is in debt to Samuel Untermyer or Mr. Untermyer to the Government, and what the amount is.

Palmer's Theatre, which has been closed for a week, will reopen to-morrow night, when Herrmann, the magician, will begin an engagement and present some of the new illusions which he has invented since he was last seen here. Besides many feats of sleight-of-hand, he will present for the first time here "Trilby," "The Columbian Transformation," and "The Asiatic Trunk Mystery," illusions which are said to be unusually mystifying.

Senator RAINES tried to offer a resolution yesterday for a special committee of five to watch the operation of his law until the next session. He was out of order, but he will doubtless bring out the resolution to-morrow night, and we should not be surprised to see it adopted.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Secretary Herbert has made the annual allotments of money to the several State naval military organizations of the country, on the basis of returns of the strength of the naval militia up to April 1. These returns show that in fourteen States there are organizations, composed of 293 officers and 3,339 enlisted men.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 25 -- Yale lost another game to the Brown University team to-day. At the outset all the honors were on Yale's side. Until the fifth inning, the score was 5 to 2, in favor of Yale. In the fifth, Brown had a batting streak, and, aided by a couple of Yale errors five men crossed the plate. This lead Yale was unable to overcome.

William Wolf and his wife, Carrie, have been married five months. They live at 193 1/2 Newark Avenue, Jersey City, but Mr. Wolf says he will not live there any longer, because his wife treats him meanly and sometimes locks him in a room and keeps him there until he promises to be good.

The vitascope, Thomas A. Edison's perfaction of the idea that caused the world to marvel when he produced the kinetoscope, has been dividing triumph with Chevalier at Koster Bial's since Thursday night, and "the Wizard of Menlo Park" promises that before many days he will need an entire stage for the screen on which his latest invention shows life and color, with speech and the noise of movement the only things lacking.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 25 -- Arrangements are well under way for the opening race meet of the Crescent Wheelmen, to be held on their famous track, Decoration Day, Chairman Gideon of the League of American Wheelmen Racing Board having already granted a sanction for the event.

BUFFALO, April 25 -- Information was received here to-day that a woman confined in the Wisconsin State Prison at Waupun had confessed to the murder of Montgomery Gibbs, the young lawyer of this city, for which crime Clarence and Sadie Robinson are now serving sentences in Auburn Prison.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 25 -- The Harvard College team was defeated by Springfield this afternoon by a score of 12 to 2. Score:

CONSTANTINOPLE, April 13 -- The firm stand taken by Mgr. Azarin, the Armenian Catholic Patriarch, against the Sultan has surprised those who did not understand his real character. Last Thursday he was called upon by Izzet Bey, and certain articles bearing his signature were shown to him.

Mr. John Hare has now quite recovered -- so far as an observer of his acting can judge -- from the annoying indisposition which caused his temporary retirement. His short Spring engagement at Abbey's began last night, when his admired portrayal of that benevolent old gentleman, Benjamin Goldfinch, in "A Pair of Spectacles," was seen by a numerous assemblage.
MACY'S, Sixth Ave. and 14th Street.

The bill creating a Special Civil Service Bureau in the Fire Department, to consist of a Commissioner, a Deputy Chief, and a Battalion Chief, was before Mayor Strong for a public hearing yesterday. It proposes to establish in the Fire Department civil service arrangements similar to those in the Police Department.

It is already plain that, as the partition of America was the principal European question of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, the partition of Africa is to be the chief European question of the twentieth. The process has already begun. It is rather curious that to-day there should be reported three collisions of native Africans with the representatives of different European nations.

The Rev. Lyman Abbott preached on "The Vicarious Sacrifice'' last evening in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn. The sermon was the last in the series on "The Theology of an Evolutionist," and next Sunday Dr. Abbott will sum up the whole subject in a discourse entitled" The Creed or a Christion Evolutionist."

The recent increase in the number of socalled mediums and mind readers in music halls throughout the country points to a fresh outburst of popular credulity in the simplest and most money-making practice of all charlatans.

TRENTON, N.J., April 26. -- This city has 2,300 bicyclists and 10 clubs, the increase in the latter during the present year being six. The chief distinction now of the wheelmen is that they have among their number a Bishop. Clergymen have been converted to the health-giving recreation at a lively rate, and there are now ten of them who make parish calls astride of a bicycle.

Four horses attached to a Barnum Bailey's circus van, on the way to Madison, Square Garden from Brooklyn for a load, ran away early yesterday morning in Spring Street. The horses broke loose from the van. One pair was caught after having run a block. The other crossed Broadway and got as far as West Broadway.

EDGAR ALLAN POE'S cottage, if removed even so short a distance as 82 feet from its present site, will lose practically all of such sentimental value as now pertains to it. About this there is no doubt whatever, and those who -- for good reason -- regard that value as extremely far from inappreciable, do well in insisting that if the house is to be preserved at all, it should be left where it is.

BERLIN, April 26. -- The prospect of a collision between the French Senate and the Chamber of Deputies resulting from changes in the Constitution placing no control over the power of a single chamber is regarded in responsible Government quarters here as a matter of the gravest concern.

EDGAR ALLAN POE'S cottage, if removed even so short a distance as 82 feet from its present site, will lose practically all of such sentimental value as now pertains to it. About this there is no doubt whatever, and those who -- for good reason -- regard that value as extremely far from inappreciable, do well in insisting that if the house is to be preserved at all, it should be left where it is.

Mrs. Anna Snow, an aged woman who lived with a lifelong friend, Mrs. Mitchell, at 58 East Eighty-sixth Street, killed herself yesterday by jumping from the window of her room on the second story of the house into the rear yard.
WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Joseph H. Manley of Maine grave out the following statement this evening:

Notwithstanding the cool weather, the Harlem River was well covered with boating craft yesterday. It was the liveliest day of the season for the members of the rowing clubs. With few exceptions, the clubs were represented by eights and fours, and almost every club had out an unusually large number of singles and doubles.

The Legislature will adjourn Thursday, and no supplemental Greater New-York bill will be passed at this session. The Greater New-York joint sub-committee of the legislative Cities Committee will, however, be revived and made an auxiliary to the Greater New-York Commission, it being assumed that the Governor will sign the bill creating the latter committee.

Ever since the Kitson-Playfair case was settled with such enthusiastic emphasis in the plaintiff's favor a surprising number of English doctors have been sending to the London papers letters in which they narrate cases, possibly real, but probably invented, that illustrate how wicked it is -- sometimes -- for a medical man to keep secret facts revealed to him in his professional capacity.

CHICAGO, April 26. -- There are growing indications not only that sound money will prevail in Chicago, but that it may carry the day in the Illinois State Democratic Convention, to be held in Peoria June 23. Since the enthusiastic and influential meeting of the leading honest-money Democrats at the Palmer House last Thursday evening there has been a marked change in the general feeling among the Democrats of this city.

CONSTANTINOPLE, April 26. -- John W. Riddle, American Charge d'Affairs, received advices Friday morning from Iskanderoon that the Turkish authorities refused to deliver the Rev. George Knapp, the American missionery, who was recently expelled from Bitlis on charges of sedition, and who was to come to this city for trial, and were determined to send him away from the country on the European steamer that sailed from Iskanderoon Friday evening.

A charming programme was that compiled by Heinrich Zoellner for the concert at the Liederkranz last night. Seldom have so many pleasing novelties and excellent standard works been so tastefully brought together as on this occasion, and no previous concert has been followed with keener interest or more heartily applauded by as large an audience.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., April 26. -- The two masked men who, while trying to rob the railroad station last night, shot Frank Bechtloff, the station agent, and Peter Sisco, an express wagon driver, have not been found. That they were the veriest amateurs their nervousness in handling their rifles showed.

ST. LOUIS, April 26. -- The free-silver Democrats of Missouri have set in motion a plan to capture the Kentucky delegation to the Chicago Convention for Bland. A conference to this end was held here yesterday by leading free-silver Democrats, including nearly all the Missouri delegation to the National Convention.

A part of that "flood" of imports which the Republicans have been talking about for a year and a half, but which is not indicated by the official reports, consists, we are now told, of silks from Japan, and this, a high-tariff organ suggests, "will help American Industrialists to decide whether or not the policy of protection is a good one to re-establish and to maintain."

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Gen. Grosvenor gave out to-night his regular weekly statement of McKinley votes. As usual, he declines to make any figures as to other candidates, confining his figures to a comparison between the McKinley vote and the number necessary to a choice, 456. He also declines to discuss the accuracy of the tables of votes given out by other persons.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 26. -- William McMahon, a lineman in the service of the New-York and New-Jersey Telephone Company, yesterday fell from a pole upon which he was working to the sidewalk, a distance of twenty-five feet. He was badly injured about the back and neck, and was taken to the Monmouth Memorial Hospital.

If there are any little doll ladies, or little doll ladies' small girl mammas, who are thinking of going shopping on Twenty-third Street this week, it would be well for them to postpone the important occasion for at least a few days.

ALBANY, April 26. -- When the Legislature shall enter upon its final week of the session, to-morrow night, it will find the calendars in both houses pretty well cleared up. The Senate and Assembly have each worked so hard for the past two weeks that but little legislation will be left unfinished at the time of final adjournment, Thursday.

LONDON, April 26. -- The Colonial Office has received a dispatch from Sir Hercules Robinson, Governor of Cape Colony and British High Commissioner in South Africa, confirming The United Press report of the defeat of the Matabeles on the Umgaza River by a British force from Bulawayo.

Some light is thrown upon the actual situation in Cuba to-day by the following interview with J. Frank Clark, staff correspondent of The United Press, who has just arrived from Havana. Mr. Clark said:

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The honorable the Senate hangs on to its plunder in the Legislative Appropriation bill "like a puppy to a root." It added to the amount of the bill, as passed by the House, the considerable figure of $247,000. The House has persisted until the Senate has backed down from $103,920, while the House has yielded $59,209, leaving $83,900 in dispute.

Theosophists from all parts of the United States, and some from foreign countries, assembled in the Concert Hall of Madison Square Garden yesterday to attend the second annual convention of the Theosophical Society in America. A more enthusiastic body has rarely gathered in Madison Square Garden.

Strange medicines are current in the cottages in the Dean Forest. Consumption is doctored with a lichten (Sticta pulmonaria) growing on the oak, in extreme cases with the ashes of a jay burned in a peat fire. Prematurely born children are sustained with hare's brains; stiff joints are lubricated with hedgehog's fat, sores with adder's oil.

From Chambers's Journal. Handel, had it not been for his oratorios and his operatic speculations, would have lived and died as poor as the proverbial church mouse. Walsh, his publisher, paid him pitiful prices for his operas. For at least eleven of these works he received no more than 25 guineas each; and the largest sum he was ever paid was only u105, which he got for "Alexander's Feast."

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- It will be some days before the Democrats will begin to make up canvasses of delegates, to separate them for the candidates. Party preference has not begun yet to settle upon men for the nomination. The chief interest is and will be in the platform, and until the expressions of the platform upon the money question shall be decided, men will amount to nothing in the calculations.

Moliere objected to the printing of his plays, on the ground that they were meant to be acted on the stage, with the costumes, scenery, and illusions pertaining thereto, and not to be read in the closet. It was also inferred that Shakespeare entertained the same notion as Moliere, seeing how indifferent he was as to the fate of his plays so long as they were popular on the stage.

CLAY CENTRE, Kan., April 26. -- A cyclone of tremendous force sped through Clay County last night, dealing death and destruction on every hand. So far as known, to-night, five persons were killed, three fatally wounded, and seventeen severely injured.
Herrmann the magician, and Adelaide, his wife, are back in New-York, having arrived from Columbus, Ohio, at 6 o'clock last evening in the private ear in which, they live while on the road.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 26. -- The more the police analyze the confession of Minnie Allen, the Wisconsin prisoner, that she murdered Montgomery Gibbs in this city two years ago, the more they are convinced that she is the Minnie Campbell who assumed to make a similar confession in Laporte, Ind., in December of 1894.
SYDNEY, N.S.W., April 26. -- Sir Henry Parkes, formerly Prime Minister of this colony, died here at 4 o'clock this morning from bronchitis and inflammation of the lungs.

NEWARK, N.J., April 26. -- The city health authorities have been puzzling their brains for some time to find the cause of numerous outbreaks of typhoid fever. Finally Dr. H.C.H. Herold, President of the Board of Health, hit upon the cause. The discovery is causing much talk in medical circles. His discovery is that the outbreaks are due to street paving.

W.E. Hollard, Advocate and Notary of the High Court and Justice of the Peace of the Republic of the Transvaal, and an intimate friend of President Paul Kruger, arrived in this city directly from South Africa, by way of Southampton, Saturday. He is visiting an old friend, Dr. W.A. Be- rendsohn of 142 Bergen Street, Brooklyn.

PALO ALTO, Cal., April 26. -- President Jordan of Leland Stanford Junior University wrote recently to a friend in Havana, a gentleman of Spanish descent and education, an author very well known in Havana, asking him to tell what the real feeling of the intelligent classes of Havana was in regard to the present insurrection.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Jockey McCafferty, who was injured by his horse falling and pinning him to the earth during the races at Bennings yesterday, is resting easily at Providence Hospital, and is reported in no danger.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 26. -- The filibustering steamer Bermuda arrived in port at 6 o'clock to-night, anchored off the Clyde steamship dock, and took on a cargo of large boxes from a barge, besides six eight-cared surfboats.
ST. Louis, April 26. -- Judge H.D. Stevens, President of the A.P.A., when his attention was called to Archbishop Ireland's interview on the A.P.A., said:

The agitation of the money question in the South has not had as favorable results as were hoped for, but it has undoubtedly done great good. Mr. CLARKE in Alabama and Secretary SMITH n Georgia have been working for the cause of sound money in the good old-fashioned way that still obtains in most parts of the South, by a free and detailed discussion of the question at issue.

From The Fortnightly Review. At 7 we continued our journey in calm, hazy weather. We had barely traveled two hours before, on turning a headland, we suddenly espied the bear some 800 yards in front of us. At racing pace the dogs sped away across the hard snow, but the bear did not take long to consider his position, and then to deal with it.

The Hon. John H. Reagan, who was Postmaster General of the Southern Confederacy, delivered a lecture in San Antonio, Texas, on the evening of April 20, in behalf of the fund for a Confederate monument, and "the Southern battle abbey," in the course of which he related the following:

What is generally mentioned in Albany dispatches as the amended ballot law is in fact a complete revision of the entire election law of the State known as Chapter VI. of the General Laws, and it contains many important changes, which ought to have received far more attention than has been given to them.
SING SING, N.Y., April 27. -- Carl Feigenbaum, a German, fifty-four years old, was executed in the electric chair in Sing Sing Prison this morning. His was the nineteenth execution in this prison.

LONDON, April 27. -- In the House of Commens to-day the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies, in reply to questions on the subject, said that the Government had received by telegraph the substance of President Kruger's reply to the Government's invitation to visit London to discuss Transvaal affairs.

HAVANA, April 27. -- The Cuban sympathizers in this city are secretly rejoicing over the receipt of trustworthy intelligence that further aid for the insurgents has arrived. An expedition with a large quantity of arras and ammunition has safely landed on the coast of Pinar del Rio, and the supplies are now safe in the hands of the patriots.

At the meeting of the Medical Society of the County of New-York, at the Academy of Medicine last night, Dr. William J. Morton gave a lecture of interest on "The X Ray and Some of Its Relations to Medicine." There were also demonstrations of apparatus at work and stereopticon views.

ALBANY, April 27. -- Assemblyman O'Grady's bill to reorganize the management of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge was passed in the Assembly to-night. The bill was introduced as a result of last year's investigation by the Assembly Cities Committee of the administration of the affairs of the bridge.

Some months ago we commented upon the results of an investigation, made by The St. Paul Pioneer Press, concerning the disappearance of many lakes in Minnesota and the marked reduction of the size and depths of others. A few years ago there were 7,000 lakes within the boundaries of that State.

MILWAUKEE, April 27. -- Arguments were begun before Judge Jenkins to-day looking to the making of a decree of sale and the payment of interest on bonds in the Ninth Circuit, being the Northern Division of the Northern Pacific Road. Several conferences have been held between the different parties relative to the stipulation to be filed.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., April 27. -- Evidence has been secured which indicates that the fire was the work of an incendiary, for the purpose of robbing the First National Bank, which had on deposit over $100,000.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The distribution of the diplomas and medals awarded to exhibitors at the World's Columbian Exposition At Chicago will begin to-morrow. The delay of three years has seemed long to some of the exhibitors, but the Government has made all the haste possible in order to afford those entitled to the evidences of merit to hold the parchments and bronze disks which will now be put in their possession.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 27. -- It looks now as if the Common Council will take up the investigation of the work and methods of the Bridgeport Traction Company which was so suddenly choked off by the City Attorney here a year ago. Mayor Clark, although friendly to the street car corporation during its trials last year, has suddenly changed front, and is vigorously pushing forward the new inquiry.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27. -- Brooklyn defeated Philadelphia to-day by bunching her hits in the last three innings of the game. Up to the seventh inning Taylor had the visitors well in hand, they securing but two singles. In the seventh, however, McCarthy and La Chance made triples and Shindle rapped out a single, two earned runs being the result.

PRETORIA, April 27. -- John Hays Hammond, the American mining engineer, and the other members of the Johannesburg Reform Committee who were absent from the court on Friday when pleas of guilty of treason and lese majeste were entered by the accused, attended court to-day with the other defendants.

Mr. CHAMBERLAIN'S statement in, the House of Commons was not especially illuminating. It was not to be expected that President KRUEGER would proceed to England in pursuance of Mr. CHAMBERLAIN'S invitation. The invitation was not a summons, and under the treaty England has no power to issue a summons.

ALBANY, April 27. -- Senators Krum and Brown, who hail from the Susquehanna Valley, succeeded in convincing the Governor, with the aid of Thomas C. Platt, that Charles A. Weiting of Cobleskill was the proper kind of a Republican to put at the head of the Agricultural Department. Mr. Waiting's nomination was sent in to the Senate to-night and referred.
ALBANY, April 27. -- The Governor to-day signed the Page-Pavey School bill.
