At Durland's Riding Academy last evening the firth annual Horse Show, under the management of the company, was opened very successfully. The academy was well filled with ladles and gentlemen, who have still a love for the horse in spite of the bicycle craze, which has swept over the country.

BOSTON, April 27. -- Lieut. Gen. Longstreet was the principal orator at the celebration by the Middlesex Club of the anniversary of the birth of Gen. Grant. He was warmly welcomed by his New-England audience. His remarks were largely in a reminiscent vein, but he said of Gen. Grant:

NEWARK, N.J., April 27. -- H. Davis, second baseman for the Metropolitans of Jersey City, was ordered off the field in the game with Newark this afternoon for using insulting language to Umpire Sullivan. Six hundred persons witnessed the game, which was rather one-sided, the home team winning by the score of 8 to 3.

The proposition to revive the Lexow Sub-Committee of the Senate and Assembly Committees on Cities, to act in an advisory or subsidiary capacity lo the Greater New-York Commission, is an impertinence. The commission should be left to do its work without being interfered with by any political committee.

Another defeat was charged against the New-Yorks at the Polo Grounds yesterday. After starting off to the bad early in the game, by dint of perseverance they managed to overhaul their opponents in the sixth inning, and at the end of the seventh the score was even. After this a series of errors by Stafford and Connaughton and clever bat work on the part of Boston gave the visitors the game.

GALENA, Ill., April 27. -- Thousands of people from this and adjoining States met together in Galena to-day, to honor the memory of her most renowned citizen, Gen. Grant. The event to-day was of a double nature, the reunion of the survivors of the Twelfth Illinois Regiment also taking place.

While that magnetic and irresistible public entertainer who calls himself Herrmann (to which in his advertisements he frankly appends " the great ") is no stranger to New-Yorkers, and his repertory of tricks of legerdemain does not grow much with years, people do not tire of him. He " draws " here as no other modern magician of the stage, no matter how clever and ingenious his trickery may be, can hope to " draw."

When the Republicans of Pennsylvania in their convention last week formally introduced Mr. QUAY to the party throughout the Nation as their candidate for the Presidency, they overlooked a little matter which was entitled to some consideration. We refer to the provisions of the treaty which QUAY recently submitted to the Pittsburg bosses, MAGEE and FLINN.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 27. -- The following letter from Mr. T.C. Platt was read at the Grant memorial dinner to-night:

The seventy-fourth anniversary of the birth of Gen. U.S. Grant was observed last night by the Grant Banquet Association with a dinner at the Hotel Waldorf. The ballroom was utilized for the occasion, and covers were laid for 100. A huge American flag covered the wall back of the guests' table, and was flanked with, portraits of Grant and Lincoln.

BOSTON, April 27. -- At the Bowdoin Square Theatre to-night Elita Proctor Otis appeared for the first time in this city in " Carmen," a play adapted from the story of Prosper Merimee and Bizet's opera, by Marie Doran and Mollie Revel. The plot follows closely that of Bizet. The play was received with many evidences of favor to-night.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Secretary Hoke Smith, has recommended to the Attorney General the dismissal of the suit against the Burlington and Missouri River Railroad Company to recover about 50,000 acres of land in Kansas and Nebraska erroneously patented to the road, upon which about 2,000 homesteaders have settled.

The trial of Cornelius B. Parker, who is under indictment on evidence presented by the Parkhurst society for conducting "policy shows," was begun yesterday before Judge Cowing, in Part IV. of the General Sessions Court. Parker is called the "Policy King," and is charged with being the financial backer of hundreds of "policy shops" in this city.

The public has scarcely yet begun to appreciate the magnitude and importance of the change which PLATT has managed to introduce into the legislation of the State of New-York. It was set forth at length in an Albany dispatch in these columns some days since, and we have reason to know that it is very painfully appreciated in legislative circles.

ALBANY, April 27. -- Gov. Morton has signed Assemblyman H.T. Andrews's bill providing that elevated railways in cities of over 1,200,000 inhabitants shall equip immediately two-fifths of all their cars with the most improved system of lighting now in use.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- There was a good deal of interesting and adroit beating about the bush in the Senate to-day. The Naval Appropriation bill was under discussion, and the talk turned upon a proposed amendment to prohibit retired officers from employment by firms supplying armor plate to the Government.
ALBANY, April 27. -- In its closing week the Assembly has been called upon to investigate a scandal growing: out of numerous errors in the bills pending.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Mr. Joel D. Hubbard of Missouri, of the House Pacific Railway Committee, filed to-day a minority report against the bill recently reported by the majority for the settlement of the indebteaness of the Central and Union Pacific Railways to the Government. He asserts that every representative of the Government but one favored foreclosure.
The personal and political friends of Civil Justice Jacob Neu of Brooklyn had a dinrer in his honor in the Art Assembly rooms, in Montague Street, last evening.

The Giants made their sixth unsuccessful effort to wm a game of ball on the home grounds yesterday, a state of affairs due to the excellent fielding on the part of the Boston players. Captain Duffy'S men handled the ball from start to finish without an error of any description, and to this alone can the victory be attributed.
ALBANY, April 28 -- Both the Senate and House did good work to-day in clearing the calendars. In the Senate the following were among the bills passed:

SING SING, N.Y., April 28 -- Maria Barbella, who since her conviction of murder in the first degree in July last has been in the prison here, was taken to New-York to-day. Detective McNaught of the Central Office and the prisoner's counsel, Emanuel Friend, visited the prison this afternoon.

LONDON, April 28 -- The trial of Dr. Jameson and his fellow-raiders was resumed in the Bow Street Police Court this morning. The street in the vicinity of the court was much quieter than upon the occasions of previous hearings of the case, and the courtroom was not nearly so crowded as formerly, though there were many distinguished persons present.

Burgesser, Ralph Barker, George E. Brightson; J.H. Buttle. H. Barber, Mrs. Barber, Miss Barber, Miss Bauermeister, Mr. Baraldi. Frank H. Belcher, H.R. Benedict. James W. Batchelor, Mrs. Batchelor.

ALBANY, April 28 -- The Union Railway Company or the Huckleberry system, which has three billsup here backed by a big lobby and ex-Lieut. Gov. William, F. Sheehan, got a black eye in the Senate toay. Bold John Raines, Chairman, of the Senate Committee on Railroads, wanted to report from that committee in favor of the bill allowing the Huckleberry to increase its capital stock from $2,000,000 to an unlimited extent.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Colector Kilbreth of New-York is in Washington with the object of urging upon the Secretary of the Treasury and Through him the Senate the necessity of the adoption of a paragraph in the Deficiency Appropriation bill covering the deficiency in the customs service.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- From 50 to 150 is the majority for the silver men in the Chicago Convention that the silver Democrats now are looking for. As has been stated in these dispatches, the men who are putting out these figures believe in the efficacy of sanguine reports to affect the color of delegations to be elected.
At the sale yesterday by Bangs Co. the following prices were obtained:

JOHANNESBURG, April 28 -- The most intense excitement was caused here when it became known that the leaders of the Reform Committee had been sentenced to death, and extremely severe sentences pronounced against the other members of the committee. A public meeting has been summoned, to give expression to the popular disapproval of the action of the court.

ALBANY, April 28 -- Senator Timothy "Dry Dollar" Sullivan pulled Thomas C. Platt's chestnuts out of the fire in the Senate to-day. Through a combination between the ultra-Platt men and Sullivan, Platt was just able to squeeze through the resolution reviving the Lexow sub-committee of the Senate and Assembly so that it may act as a whip over the head of the Greater New-York Commission during the Summer and Fall.

Is bodily comfort. This unspeakable boon is denied to many unfortunates for whose ailments Hostetter's Stomach Bitters is a promptly helpful remedy. The dyspeptic, the rheumatic, the nervous person troubled with biliousness or chills and fever should lose no time in availing themselves of this comprehensive and genial medicine.

It the figures that appear in the baseball tables under "Games Won" and "Games Lost" should happen to get transposed some night in the hurry of going to press, what a leap to the front would the NewYork players instantly take! And apparently they are trusting to an accident of this sort to give them at least the simulacrum of glory.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Senate Committee on Naval Affairs this morning made public the testimony recently taken by it in secret sessions on the subject of armor plate, the prices paid therefor, and the ownership of patented processes of manufacture, under the resolution of Senator Chandler of Dec. 31 last.

Booth-Tucker, the successor to Ballirgton Booth as Commander of the Salvation Army in the United States, was arrested last night by Detective Coyle and taken to the Elizabeth Street Police Station. A charge of disorderly conduct was made against him. "Steve" Brodie gave security in $500 for his appearance in the Centre Street Police Court s morning.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 28 -- The Mount Vernon Driving Club will open the racing season in this vicinity Decoration Day, on the Allendale track, a mile north of this city. There will be trotting and pacing in the 2:27 and three-minute classes. A trophy known as the Mount Vernon Cup, will be offered for roadsters owned and driven by members of the club.

Max Landrofsky was charged in the Essex Market Court yesterday with conducting a swindling game. It is alleged that he has a habit of becoming engaged to young women, on the east side and shortly before the wedding day disappearing with all their valuables.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Mr. German met public expectation to-day by employing the Naval Appropriation bill as a club to pound the Republicans for their extravagance in public affairs. His well-known hostility to the naval establishment and the plans of the Administration concerning it naturally detracted from the force of his argument, which was based on his amendment cutting down the number of battleships from four to two.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- Lawyer Bullock of Indianapolis, who is in this city, in the interest of H.H. Holmes, the convicted murderer of Benjamin F. Pietzel, who is sentenced to be hanged May 7, to-day admitted that a reprieve would be applied for.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A warm, clear day and a field of fair proportions attracted a comparatively numerous crowd to Bennings to-day. The entries as set forth at first numbered thirty-five runners, but four were scratched.

Jennie Mafera, a pert little girl with jet black hair, large, bright, black eyes, and who is decidedly pretty, was a prisoner in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday afternoon, charged by her parents, Stanley and Mary Mafera, of 188 Allen Street, with being incorrigible. Jennie is thirteen years old, and is rather robust for her age.

FREEHOLD, N. J., April 28 -- Three hundred wheelmen from Monmouth, Ocean, and Mercer Counties met here in the Court House to-day, and decided on the route of the bicycle path from Asbury Park to Trenton. Capt. Albert D. McCabe of the Asbury Park Wheelmen was elected Chairman, and C.H. Savage of Hightstown was the Secretary. Chief Consul Gentle of Elizabeth, representing the New-Jersey Division of the League of American Wheelmen, was present.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- Owing to the rules of the Joint\Traffic Association the lake lines are apparently capturing three-fourths of the total east-bound freight traffic out of Chicago. The total shipments of freight out of this city to the East last week amounted to 240,437 tons, of which 175,538 tons went by water.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 28 -- The Robinson street car lines and electric lighting plant property, known, as the Toledo Electric Street Railway Company, were sold yesterday to the New-York banking house of Blair Co. The parties to the sale are very reticent as to the consideration paid.

In considering the cases of the five Uitlanders, one of them an American, who have been convicted of high treason to the South African Republic and condemned to death on their own plea of guilty, it is necessary to assume that they had taken the oath of allegiance to the republic, and had thus waived the protection of the Governments under which they were respectively born.

FORT MONROE, Va., April 28 -- The Old Dominion steamship Wyanoke, from Richmond, the last save one of the paddle-wheel type of boats engaged in deep-water traffic, while on the way to her dock at Newport News at 3 o'clock this morning ran into the United States cruiser Columbia, which was anchored off the port.

JOHANNESBURG, April 28 -- The most intense excitement was caused here when it became known that the leaders of the Reform Committee had been sentenced to death, and extremely severe sentences pronounced against the other members of the committee. A public meeting has been summoned, to give expression to the popular disapproval of the action of the court.

The small number of hysterical persons who have scared themselves by magnifying PLATT until they can see nothing else, and are shrieking for a veto of the Greater New-York bill, are simply asking Gov. MORTON to stultify himself, and some of them are telling him that he will be a terrible rascal unless he makes a fool of himself.

The bill drawn by Justice BARRETT of the Supreme Court, with the assistance of some of the other Judges of the same bench, providing for special juries in important criminal cases in counties of more than 500,000 inhabitants, which is to say, in this city and Brooklyn, has quietly become a law, and without exciting much attention it has established the most important reform in the jury system of modern times.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- C.H. Knight, United States Vice Consul at Cape Town, South America, has cabled Secretary Olney that the sentence of John Hays Hammond, the American engineer condemned to death for participation in the Jamieson raid, is understood to have been commuted.

The peregrinations of the Heine Fountain have at last ended, it seems. Alter having been taken from Dusseldorf, in the first place, to various large cities of Germany and rejected by the municipal authorities in each case, and then brought to this country and refused several sites by the local authorities, the monument to the great German poet has finally found a resting place through the generosity and enthusiasm of William Steinway and George Ehret.

LONDON, April 28 -- Though the news of the death sentence passed on the five leaders of the Johannesburg movement was a surprise and shock to those here who have watched the case, politicians inside and outside of Parliament admit that the sentence is the natural complement of the plea of guilty.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- Attorney General Moloney is investigating charges which have been made against the officers of the four principal Chicago gas companies composing the trust, which he is fighting in the courts, to the effect that there has been a violation of judicial mandate, enjoining the payment of any dividends on the stock certificates held by the Fidelity Company of Philadelphia.
The seventieth birthday of S.S. Packard, the head of Packard's Business College, in this city, was celebrated last night at a banquet given in his honor at Delmonico's.

HAVANA, April 28 -- A large force of rebels made an attack upon the Spanish gunboats Pizarro and Alvarado, lying along the coast of Santiago de Cuba Province, near Baracao. The gunboats were aided by a force of guerrillas on shore, and the rebels were repulsed with great loss. The Spanish loss was as follows: The commander of the gunboat Pizarro seriously wounded, eleven marines wounded, and a guerrilla officer and seven guerrilas wounded.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Senator Wolcott of Colorado to-day sent the following letter to Irving W. Howbert, Chairman of the Republican Stale Committee of Colorado:

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., April 28 -- It is stated that George Burroughs, a ten-year-old boy, who lived on the outskirts of this city with his mother, and who died a few days ago, was a victim of nicotine poisoning. The child had been a constant smoker since he was six years old, and during the illness which ended his life, begged most piteously to be supplied with tobacco.

The regular monthly dinner of the Democratic Club of the City of New-York, held at its clubhouse, 617 Fifth Avenue, last evening, was practically the opening of the political campaign for this year, and exCongressman Perry Belmont sounded the battlecry in a speech for sound money.

Hester -- Gibb. The wedding of Miss Ada Louise Gibb to William Van Anden Hester, which took place in the Church of the Holy Trinity, at Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, was largely attended by people prominent in Brooklyn social circles.

In the present production of Boucicault's old play, called "After Dark," at the big Academy, there is sufficient variety to suit all tastes except the best, which, of course, is not catered to by managers who present sensational melodrama with music hall trimmings.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Marcus Ruthenburg, formerly of Philadelphia, and until lately an attache of the League Island Navy Yard, has written to Secretary Herbert complaining of certain official acts of Civil Engineer O.C. Wolcott, who has been on duty at League Island since 1891. He is a relative of Senator Wolcott, and is well known in the service, where he is accounted an officer of ability and integrity.

W.F. Hellard, Judge Advocate of the High Court of the South African Republic, who in at present visiting at 142 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, said last night, in speaking to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES regarding the prisoners sentenced at Pretoria, South Africa, for high treason against the Republic, that the message of Joseph Chamberlain, the British Secretary of State for the Colonies, to President Krueger, which carries an implied threat, is a great mistake.

The new hospital in Astoria, L.I., is completed, and in order that the friends and supporters of the institution may have an opportunity to inspect the building, a public reception is to be held there to-morrow afternoon and evening. The reception is not to consist of a simple inspection of the structure and its appointments, but will be enlivened with music, a Punch and Judy show, and other features.

It the figures that appear in the baseball tables under "Games Won" and "Games Lost" should happen to get transposed some night in the hurry of going to press, what a leap to the front would the NewYork players instantly take! And apparently they are trusting to an accident of this sort to give them at least the simulacrum of glory.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Col. William Ludlow, Chairman of the Board of Engineer Officers which last Summer investigated the Nicaragua Canal project, detailed to the House Commerce Committee this morning the nature of the observations made by them while in Central America, the circumstances surounding their work, and the conclusions reached as to the cost and practicability of a canal.

ALBANY, April 28 -- The Court of Appeals to-day reversed the judgment of the lower court and ordered a new trial in the case of The People vs. Vincenzo Nino, appellant. Nino was awaiting execution in Sing Sing Prison for the murder of his wife. Nino killed his wife, Marie, with a razor at their home, 55 Baxter Street, New-York, on Feb, 19, 1895.

PARIS, April 16 -- The official opening of the Champs Elysees Salon, will take place Wednesday, April 29, preparations for which even are well advanced toward completion. The American contributions are more numerous than last year, and fully equal to the former exhibitions in point of excellence.

ALBANY, April 29. -- The Huckleberry Railroad lobbyists made fine progress with the prize measure of their batch of grab-all bills to-day. They managed to get their "omnibus " bill through the Assembly, and if the lobby can manage it they will rush it through the Senate in the closing hours to-morrow.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., April 29. -- "Pattison and a Gold Standard" were the watch words of the Democratic State Convention to-day. The convention was a large one and immensely enthusiastic. The names of President Cleveland, ex-Gov. Pattison, and National Chairman Harrity were loudly applauded whenever mentioned.
MONTPELIER, Vt., April 29. -- The Vermont Republican Convention to-day, while it sent an uninstructed delegation to St. Louis, formally expressed its preference for McKinley for President.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 29. -- Keyser Boelen of New-York City was beaten and robbed and thrown into the Peconic River in an unconscious condition last night to drown.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 29 -- Deserted by her husband and left with three children, the oldest being but six years of age and the youngest two years old, Mrs. Dennis Savage was found by the Elizabeth police last night in her home, at Fulton Street and Newport Road, in an almost starved condition.

WEDNESDAY -- P.M. The announcement that President Kruger had commuted the sentences passed upon the Transvaal reformers was received in this city before the opening of the market, and its influence was pronounced. London has been weak, but it was enjoying a recovery, based presumably on the same news, when our market opened.

The Board of Education held a special meeting yesterday to take action toward dividing the city into school districts, as required by the new school law. The question of laying cut the forty-five inspection districts according to population, as required in the new law, caused considerable discussion, as some of the members were in doubt as to whether general population or school population was meant.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29. -- Following is the Pennsylvania Railroad Company's statement of comparison of earnings and expenses for the month of March and three months of 1896, with the same periods of 1895: Pennsylvania Railroad, lines directly operated: Gross earnings, month of March, increase, $120,400; three months' increase, $662,400; expenses, month of March, increase, $41,400; three months increase, $546,900; net earnings, month of March, increase, $79,000; three months, increase, $115,500.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 29. -- The sixteenth annual meeting of the Women's Missionary Society of the Presbytery of Westcliester, which includes the Presbyterian Churches of Westchester County and the State of Connecticut, convened this afternoon at 2 o'clock in the First Presbyterian Church.

DETROIT, Mich., April 29. -- The Michigan State Democratic Convention to-day, after a stormy fight, indorsed the Administration and financial policy of Grover Cleveland, chose four gold-standard delegates at large, and sent a delegation of twenty-four district delegates to the Chicago Convention, of whom thirteen are counted gold monometallists and eleven silver bimetallists.

ALBANY, April 29. -- With the close of tonight's session the Legislature of 1896 practically completed its work. Although each house has an increased membership over that of last year, the volume of business this year on the whole does not exceed that of last year. In the Senate there were 1.283 bills introduced, as compared with 992 last year.

NYACK. N.Y., April 29. -- Charles Fleichman's new steam yacht Hiawatha was launched from the yards of her builder shortly before midnight to-night. The launch was a very pretty one and in adition to Mr. Fleischman's friends there were several residents of Nyack who witnessed the launch.

In a long letter to THE NEW-YORK TIMES Mrs. Melusina Fay Pierce, who signs herself "Organizer Poe Memorial Association," makes a strong protest against the proposition to widen the King's Bridge Road, "which cuts the site of the Poe cottage in two." Mrs. Pierce advocates the plan of creating a Poet's Park on the top of Fordham Hill, which should include the present site of the cottage.
James G. Wilson, the "green-goods" man who is in the Hudson County Jail in Jersey City serving a sentence imposed by the United States Court at Trenton, is at his old tricks again.

Assistant District Attorney O'Hare refused to say yesterday whether the two missing witnesses against Cornelius B. Parker, who is on trial before Judge Cowing in the General Sessions Court for violating the law against policy playing, had been arrested. They were not produced up to the time of the adjournment of the court for the day.

It is gratifying to find the State Superintendent of Public Instruction, in his annual report, laying special stress upon the practice, which has long been deplored by judicious educators, of trying to cover too much ground in the public schools. He says: " Our children are being hurried on too rapidly.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 29. -- Nebraska Democrats of the sound money school held their State Convention to-day primarily to elect four delegates at large to the Chicago National Convention and incidentally, as the party leaders announced, "to declare to the Democracy of the nation that Nebraska is not wholly silver mad."

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The principal event of the racing here to-day was the Capitol Stakes at a mile. Roundsman, who was an added starter and favorite for the race, won after a clever fight with Septuor. Intermission made the running for six furlongs and then quit badly. In the steeplechase, Gold Dollar fell at the last hurdle, and his rider, Green, had a bad shaking up, but received no serious injuries.
ALBANY, April 29. -- The next to the last day of this remarkable Legislature wound up with a disgraceful and almost liotous scene in the Assembly.

Santanelli, the hypnotist, aroused Lyman Kilmer, at Hammerstein's Olympia Theatre, last night, from the state of sleep into which he put the subject last Wednesday evening. Kilmer slept well during the day, but in the evening he grew somewhat restless, and occasionally turned from side to side on his couch on the stage.

It is not an encouraging undertaking for any pianist to come forward at the close of a long and brilliant season of music and appeal for public attention. It is still more hazardous to do so after a season in which the world's greatest pianist has been arousing an enthusiasm not possible to describe in judicial terms.

Detectives are puzzled by a robbery at the Hotel Maryborough, Thirty-sixth Street and Broadway, yesterday morning. State Senator Thomas A. Darby of Florida is the victim. Because of circumstantial evidence, Louis C. Bloch, who had been a guest at the hotel for a week, and who represents himself as a salesman of Denver, Col., has been arrested.

The Executive Committee of the Consolidation League of Brooklyn yesterday sent a petition to Albany, urging Gov. Morion, in case he signed the Lexow bill, to appoina Edward M. Grout as a member of the Consolidation Commission that is to prepare a charter for Greater New York.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29. -- For three brief innings to-day it looked as though the luckless New-Yorkers were going to score their second victory, but in the fourth the Philadelphia sluggers jumped on "Dad" Clarke's delivery for a total of fourteen bases, yielding six earned runs, and, as it turned out, the game. Clarke then retired in favor of Dobeny.

ALBANY, April 29. -- The Republicans of the Assembly violated the pledges they made during the last campaign and showed that all their talk of civil service was a pure bluff, by killing the Sanger Civil Service bill to-day. The aggregation of spoilsmen who make up the majority has been playing football with this bill all the session, and not one of the leaders ever had a serious idea of passing it.

LONDON, April 29. -- The press view of the annual exhibition of the Royal Academy in the galleries of Burlington House opened to-day and will be continued tomorrow. The exhibition will be opened to the public Monday next. Among the paintings shown is "Clytie." by the late Sir Frederick Leighton, Bart.

HAVANA, April 29. -- The Spanish gunboat Mesagera has captured, near Berracos, on the northern coast of the Province of Pinar del Rio, the American schooner Competitor of Key West, loaded with arms and ammunition, for which she was seeking a landing place.

From Jan. 1 to April 17 the number of Italian immigrants landed at this port was 19,946, and about 6,000 of these arrived during the first two weeks of this month. On the 18th inst. nearly 8,000 more Italians were either on their way to this port or about to embark for It. The number of such immigrants to be credited to the month of April at this port will probably be about 15,000.
AMHERST, Mass., April 29. -- Amherst defeated Wesleyan in a clean and lively game on Pratt Field this afternoon. Following is the score by innings:

Information of an interesting and mysterious nature came to light yesterday concerning the reported purchase or hiring by the Cuban Revolutionary Party for filibustering purposes of the famous ship Howard Cassard, better known on account of its slender shape as the "knife craft."

ALBANY, April 29. -- The Republican Senators caucused this afternoon and considered the various resolutions which have been offered to provide for committees to sit during the Summer and conduct investigations into various matters. The caucus decided that only the Raines resolution, providing for the appointment of a committee of five Senators to watch the operation of the Raines liquor law and report to the next Legislature, should receive favorable consideration.
ALBANY, April 29. -- Adjt. Gen. McAlpin today isued the State camp order. The following organizations are ordered on a tour of duty:

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- In a report to the State Department Mr. Charles Denby, United States Minister to China, says that the imperial sanction has been given for the construction of a railway between Shanghai and Swatow, a distance of sixty-five miles. Part of the stock is to be sold in open market and the rest to be held by the Government.

After playing strong ball in Baltimore, Washington, and Philadelphia, the Brooklyns returned home yesterday and started their local schedule of games, having for their opponents the Washington team. Over 12,000 persons greeted the players; the stands were decked with gay bunting, Conterno's Band discoursed lively music, and everything was in apple-pie order, but the expected happened -- the Brooklyns were beaten.
Miss Elizabeth Swasey Miller and Dr. Curtis Braxton Carter were married last evening at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Henry James Miller, of 309 West Seventy-sixth Street.
The graduates of the Woman's Law Class of the New-York University received something in the nature of a proposal for a conjugal law partnership last evening.

CHICAGO, April 29. -- But a light local business was transacted in wheat to-day. Until a short time after noon the tone was firm at a modest advance over yesterday's closing figures, and the bulls were congratulating themselves on that fact and were even led to predicting better things, but in the light of subsequent happenings it was proved that their confidence was misplaced.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 29. -- A woman dressed in black has been troubling school children for some time past. A day or two ago little Josephine Smith, while on her way to the store to make some purchases for her mother, was stopped by this woman and told to open her hand. This the little girl did and revealed a five-dollar bill.
CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., April 29. -- A second fire, accompanied by loss of life and injuries to many persons, reduced the business part of this city to ashes to-day.
ALBANY, April 29. -- The Senate began its last full day's session by clearing, the floor of all visitors and resolving to honor no passes during the remainder of the session.

The movement in Jersey for special bicycle paths is being agitated not only by the wheelmen, but the farmers as well. In fact, at the meeting in Freehold, on Tuesday, to select a route between Asbury Park and the capital, certain farmers waged a stubborn warfare in an effort to have the line run through a certain section.

SYNOPSIS. A former Ambassador of France to Russia, during a game of chess with the narrator of the story, relates an experience at the Russian Court: Not long after the death of the Czar, Alexander III., a ghost had been seen in one of the corridors of the Winter Palace. While the Ambassador is calling on the Princess Nestikoff, the next day, the son of the Princess, Boris, a page on duty in the palace.

"And they say girls can't play ball!" exclaimed a pretty young woman yesterday. She was sitting high on a platform, wearing the prettiest of rustling silk-lined Spring gowns, a sailor hat that matched the brown of her eyes and the tints of her frock, and a big American Beauty rose, the soft pink of which was just the color of her cheeks.

There is no doubt that the Ministry which President FAURE has accepted is in marked contrast with its predecessor. Several recent changes of Ministry in France have consisted merely in throwing overboard a supposed Jonah or two, in obedience to internal exigencies or possibly to external demands, and continuing the same course with as nearly as possible the same crew.

An interesting development in a suit against the Atlantic Avenue Railroad Company, in Brooklyn, for damages for the killing of a man by a trolley car was made public yesterday, and if allegations made by the company's attorneys are proved to be true, a woman is likely to serve a number of years in prison for perjury.

Edward C. Delavan. Edward C. Delevan a long-time member of the New-York bar, died Tuesday at his home, on Staten Island. Mr. Delavan was born in 1813, and was graduated from Yale College in the Class of '36.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 29. -- Judge Ferguson, in the Criminal District Court, today rendered his decision to the Grand Jury in the election investigation matter. Yesterday the Grand Jury requested him to order the local General Manager of the Western Union Telegraph Company to furnish it copies of all telegrams sent by Chairman Parker of the Democratic State Central Committee and other prominent Democratic managers to parties in the country concerning the election.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Representative McCormick of New-York was the unintentional cause to-day of some speechmaking in the House. He had secured a promise of recognition from, the Speaker, and soon after the session opened asked to have passed a bill providing for the erection of a lighthouse at Orient Point, L.I., and for the lighting of the entrance to Greenport and Sag Harbor, and the west shore of Shelter Island.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 29. -- A new attempt to defraud the public was detected at the Bay District track yesterday. In the last race, Marjorie was heavily played all over the ring. Although in good condition in the morning, the mare warmed up greatly distressed, showing signs of having been "doped." The officials were advised of her condition.
ALBANY, April 29. -- Senator Cantor, the Democratic leader, said to-day, in commenting on the-work of the present Legislature:

PHILADELPHIA, April 29. -- The local market opened weak at declines of 1/2 for Union Traction and 3/4 for Philadelphia on account of strike news. Good support, however, developed in Union, which rallied to 16 1/4 and closed 1/8 lower, a net loss to-day of 1/4 per cent. Philadelphia was heavy all day and closed at 68 3/4, a net decline of 5/8.
PARIS, April 29. -- M. Meline has completed his Cabinet, which is constituted as follows:
Messis, W.B. Taylor Sons have sold, for Mr. Read, the four-story dwelling 53 West Thirty-fifth Street, 21.5 by 55 by 98.9.

HARTFORD, April 29. -- The life of the actress, Miss Dallas Tyler, who is playing in "The Senator" here, was attempted between 6 and 7 o'clock this evening by her husband, George Bethel, at the Hotel Heublein, where she is stopping with her mother, Mrs. Ashlin, while performing with the W.H. Crane company in this city this week.

There is much force in the protest of the Police Board of this city against the compulsory application in the department of the provision of the revised election law which entitles any voter on election day to "absent himself from any service or employment in which he is then engaged or employed, for a period of two hours," and which declares that "this section shall be deemed to include all employes of municipalities."

YONKERS, N.Y., April 29. -- Fourteen boys, ranging from eleven to sixteen years of age, living in and near One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, New-York, were taken to Police Headquarters to-night by Policeman Archer. The boys had evidently left home for a night's fun, and were having it when the officer appeared.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: It is just that Western States, whose influence in Congress and in the National party conventions is cast for the debasement of the currency of the country, should be reproached for their part in the free-silver heresy. But it is not just that this imperfection of vision should be confused with their sparseness or meagreness of population.
WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The political debate precipitated in the Senate yesterday by Mr. Gorman, during consideration of the Naval Appropriation bill, has borne good fruit.

Ex-Gov. Foraker of Ohio, who is in this city, was asked by a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES last evening what there was in the report that he is opposed to Major McKinley as the Republican Presidential candidate. He replied:

From The London Chronicle. At last the majesty of the law has asserted itself over Prof. Quidde of Milnich, and his crime of lese-majeste. This was contained in a speech which he delivered at a public meeting about three months ago, and of which the burden was the connection between imperial militarism and Socialism.

CHICAGO, April 29. -- Trading was confined largely to Diamond Match. The stock opened at 233, sold up to 235 1/2, and as low as 232 1/4, closing at 231 1/2. Some little interest has been shown in Alley L. based on the report that the bondholders will arrive at an amicable settlement in the near future. Cables were almost deserted. Strawboard was weak, selling at 40@40 1/4.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 29. -- It will be nip and tuck in the Republican State Convention to-morrow between the supporters and opponents of McKinley instructions, with the chances, unless there is another change in the situation before morning, in favor of the opposition.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Miss Margaret Skerrett, daughter of Rear Admiral Skerrett, was married to Mr. David Milne of Philadelphia at noon to-day in St. John's Church, opposite the White House, the Rev. Dr. Mackay-Smtth officiating. The best man was Mr. Caleb Milne, and the ushers were Messrs.

Prospects of engagements of Treasury gold to-day for export by to-morrow's steamships received much attention down-town yesterday. The movement of exchange Wednesday first excited fear that the time for gold exports might be close at hand. Rates opened at an advance yesterday, and there were sales of bills for the evident purpose of shipping gold.

HAVANA, April 30. -- A dynamite bomb caused the explosion in the Captain General's palace Tuesday, and not a gas engine, as reported. The noise was tremendous, and caused intense excitement in the palace and vicinity. The Generals and officers rushed about giving orders. Even Weyler left the room greatly excited.

LONDON, April 30. -- A rumor was in circulation on the Stock Exchange to-day that the Transvaal Executive has imposed the punishment of five years' penal servitude, with banishment at the end of that term of imprisonment, upon Hammond, Rhodes, and the other Reform Committee leaders, whose sentence of death was remitted yesterday.

The disclosures already made toy the Boers, not to speak of those which are to follow, recall a striking remark made by our London correspondent at the time of the Jameson raid. This was to the effect that if the same publicity had been available at the time or times when the British Empire was founded that is available now, there would be no British Empire.

The Board of education yesterday adopted a report of its Committee on School System dividing the city into new school districts. Chairman Strauss of the committee announced that after consultation with Superintendent Jasper it had been decided that better results would be attained if the division were into thirty-five instead of forty-five districts.

Of the many commissions appointed by the Legislature in recent years, none hag done more for the positive and permanent good of New-York than the Tenement House Commission, of which Richard Watson Gilder was Chairman, and Edward Marshall Secretary. It brought about a great reform in the construction of abodes for the poorer classes, by which they have been rendered practically fire-proof, sanitary, and far better lighted and more comfortable than formerly.

HARTFORD, April 30. -- Edwin Bethel, the Boston actor who fired four shots at his wife, known as Miss Dallas Tyler, at the Hotel Heublein last evening, was arraigned in the Police Court to-day before Assistant Judge Arthur Perkins, charged with assault with intent to kill. "When asked what he had to say to the charge, he answered, "Nothing."
ALBANY, April 30. -- The legislature of 1895 passed a resolution submitting the question of repealing Section 29, Article III., of the new Constitution to the people. This section reads:

Mr. TELLER gave some interesting testimony at the close of his remarks in the Senate on Wednesday concerning the agreement in 1890 between the Republican ultra-protectionists and the Republican Silver men which insured the enactment of both the McKinley tariff and the Sherman Silver Purchase law.

ALBANY, April 30. -- Assistant Corporation Counsel Clarke, who has been here during the legislative session representing Mr. Scott and paying particular attention to Legislation which affects New-York City, has prepared a list of bills bearing on the city's interests which have been passed by the Legislature.

Pfeiffer -- Kramer. An important wedding in German society circles last evening was that of Miss Elizabeth C. Kramer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Kramer of 524 West One Hundred and Fifty-second Street, to Dr. Felix Pfeiffer, at the home of the bride's parents. Judge J. Henry McCarthy of the City Court officiated.
PRETORIA, April 30. -- A great sensation has been caused here by the publication of a series of telegrams that were entered as evidence at the trial of the members of the Reform Committee.
LONDON, April 30. -- A vastly different aspect has been put on the Transvaal trouble by the publication of a number of cipher telegraphic dispatches, translation of which will be found below.

THURSDAY -- P.M. To-day's stock market was excessively dull, and, in the absence of business, prices receded somewhat. There was a recovery in the last hour, however, which carried prices back almost to the level of yesterday's closing.

ACT I. Scene. Summer evening. Window at back with long bench or chairs underneath it. Doors R and L. The Landlady, seated in a high-backed chair, looks on, knitting all the time. Men in rustic garb, with belts and cartridge boxes and side arms, each carrying a gun, come in gradually, half a dozen or more.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin, who returned from Europe yesterday afternoon, paid a visit to the yacht Defender at 3 o'clock to-day. Mr. Iselin immediately on reaching his home, All View, Premium Point, sent word to Henry Odell, the watchman on the Defender, which lies in the Glen Island Harbor, to bring the little naphtha launch that serves as the Defender's tender, up to Premium Point this morning.

-- The concert given for the benefit of the Five Points House of Industry and the St. Rose Academy at the Press Club, 34 West Twenty-sixth Street, yesterday was well attended. The singing by Miss Margaret Keys, soprano, and A.B. De Frece's rendering of Gounod's "Quando a Te Lieta" delighted the audience.

DENVER, Col., April 30. -- Robert Campbell, a prominent society man of this city, ex-Mayor of Central City, who was impoverished by yesterday's fire at Cripple Creek, his extensive properties there being uninsured, killed himself this morning in a fit of despondency by shooting himself through the heart.

William Herbert Coulson, an amateur chemist, way almost instantly killed at his home, 7 Oak Street, at 11:30 o'clock Wednesday night. The affair was shrouded in mystery, but the mystery did not relate to the tragedy so much as to an invention upon which Mr. Coulson was working with two associates.
ALBANY, April 30. -- Among the bills passed by the Senate at its last session today were the following, which previously had passed the Assembly:

In blue gowns, white caps, and aprons, trained nurses filled the front of the Broadway Tabernacle, on either side of the pulpit, last evening. The body of the church was filled with their relatives and friends.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- Hamilton Dieston, the head of the extensive saw works of Henry Disston Sons of this city, was found dead in bed in his house. Broad and Jefferson Streets, this morning. Heart disease was the supposed cause of death. Mr. Disston was a millionaire and was prominent in Republican politics.

One Hundred and Twentieth Street, south side, 260 feet east of Lenox Avenue, for four three-story and basement brick, dwelling's, by Mattie A. Cockburn of 208 West One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, owner; cost, $64,000.

BOSTON, April 30. -- Local stocks were fairly active, led by Bay State Gas and Dominion Coal, both advancing on expected favorable action by the Legislature on the Whitney Gas bill. Dominion Coal rose 1 1/4, to 14 1/2. Bay State Gas advanced 1 7/8, to 11 3/8 closed at 11. Bell Telephone was strong, gaining 1, to 207. New-Haven and Hartford declined 2 1/4, to 171.

ALBANY, April 30. -- The Huckleberry "omnibus" bill, like all other bills in which the Union Railway Company and ex-Lieut. Gov. Sheehan, as counsel, were so much interested, was left untouched by the Senate to-day.

James Mitchell, Chairman of the New-York Stock Exchange, died yesterday morning at the home of Samuel W. Johnston, 415 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn. He had been a guest there, and intended to remain until his own home at Madison, N.J., which he had rented for the Winter while he was in the South on sick leave, could be made ready for his occupancy.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The President has granted a pardon to R.J. Gilley of Alabama, sentenced in July, 1893, to six years in State prison for conspiracy to intimidate witnesses. In his indorsement the President says he is satisfied that Gilley is not guilty of the charge.
ALBANY, April 30. -- Speaker Fish to-day, in commenting on the work of the Legislature, said:

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The Navy Department authorities know nothing officially of the complaint of any officer of the Dominion steamship Wyanoke of ill treatment by Capt. Sands and Lieut. Commander Allibone of the United States steamship Columbia. The report that these officers forced the Wyanoke officers ashore from the Columbia is discredited in the department.

ALBANY, April 30. -- In the Court of Appeals this morning the Einsfeld case, involving the Constitutionality of the Raines liquor tax law, was argued. The appeal was from the order and judgment entered upon the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Part I., affirming a decision of Justice Pryor at Special Term, directing a judgment dismissing a writ of certiorari directed to respondents, the Commissioners of Excise of New-York.

PARIS, April 30. -- The Chamber, by a vote of 231 to 196, approved of M. Meline's declaration and then adjourned until May 28. The new Premier began by saying that he would not attempt to disguise the difficulty of the task before him and his colleagues. "But," he said, "there are times when politicians who are devoted to their country have no right to shirk the burdens of office.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- In response to a resolution of the House passed April 9, President Cleveland this afternoon transmitted to the House a copy of the correspondence on file in the State Department relating to the case of Mrs. Florence Maybrick, who is confined in en English prison under life sentence for the murder of her husband, a Liverpool merchant.

TORONTO, Ont., April 30. -- The Century Road Club of Canada, which has been defunct for several years, has been revived. In addition to awarding gold bars to century riders the club will control all road racing in Canada and will also work to secure improved roads. To be entitled to the gold bars men riders must cover their hundred miles within ten, and ladies within fourteen hours.

President Young of the League is using his persuasive powers on the obdurate Rusie, and the chances are that the big pitcher will Join the team In the West. There is no truth in the various rumors afloat to the effect that Rusie would be exchanged for pitchers, members of other clubs.

Brooklyn and Washington played a remarkably interesting game at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon. The fielding was sharp and clean, the batting vigorous, and the score at all times close enough to keep the spectators in a ferment of excitement. The Senators started off in the lead in the second inning, and held an advantage of one run until the sixth.

While the second division of the boys in the House of Refuge, Randall's Island, numbering 360 of all ages and sizes, were engaged at play yesterday, Herman Berlin, eighteen years old, was guilty of some infraction of the rules and was taken into the Superintendent's office by Keeper Frank Weiss and reported for misconduct.

The Actuarial Society of America held its semi-annual meeting at an up-town hotel yesterday. Emory McClintock, Actuary of the Mutual Life Insurance Company and President of the Society, was in the chair, and about fifty members were present.

Mrs. Donald McLean was yesterday reelected Regent of the New-York City Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, she receiving 115 votes, while her opponent, Miss Mary Van Buren Vanderpoel, received 76 votes. The full list of officers elected by the Chapter yesterday is:

CHICAGO, April 30. -- The circular issued by Chairman Midgeley of the Western Freight Association regarding the so-called cut in rates made by the Ogdensburg Transit Company is regarded unfavorably by the members of the association, almost without exception. They regard the Chairman's position untenable and it is asserted that it must be abandoned.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The racing at the Bennings track to-day was decidedly tame and uninteresting. The fields continued small, the attendance was light, and the racing rather tedious. In the hurdle race, the last of the afternoon, Caraccas, the favorite, went lame near the finish, which accounted for his defeat by Woodford. Golden Gate fell at the last hurdle, but was remounted and finished for third money.
ALBANY, April 30. -- The Finance Committee's report on the tax rate was made in the Senate immediately after the passage of the Supplemental Supply bill.

The chief characteristic of the Legislature which has just adjourned has been a narrow partisanship and abject subserviency to a party "boss," and it has seriously impaired the value of the session's work, though much that was attempted for party advantage met with defeat.
Alexander E. Orr, Seth Low, William Steinway, and John H. Inman formed the quorum of the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners, which, held its regular weekly session yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, April 30. -- A news agency dispatch from Shanghai, published in The Globe, says that the British steamer On Wo has been sunk by collision with the steamer Newchwang, and that many lives have been lost.

Miss Lottie Schumacher, twenty-two years old, of 23 East Forty-sixth Street, was run down by a beer wagon at One Hundred and Sixth Street and Manhattan Avenue at 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, while riding a bicycle, and received injuries from which she died half an hour later at the Manhattan Hospital.

ALBANY, April 30. -- The Legislature adjourned without date this afternoon, and left the impression upon the minds of all who have watched its course that perhaps the most valuable thing that it has done is to clearly define what is sure to be a most important issue in the next campaign.

ALBANY, April 30. -- Two of the most important measures of the whole session were adopted in the Senate in the last half hour of its final session to-day. They were the bill fixing the State tax at 2.69 mills on the dollar and the Supplemental Supply bill.

ROME, N.Y., April 30. -- The State began to-day to present evidence in support of its charge against the boy Hildreth, accused of helping to wreck the New-York Central limited train near Syracuse Nov. 19, 1895. The most interesting testimony was given by James R. Reynolds, who was the conductor of the unfortunate train.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- The complete failure of the strike on the traction lines was reflected in a stronger and higher market. Union advanced to 17 1/2, and closed at 17 1/4, a net gain of 1 1/8. The fours gained 1 per cent., to 72 1/2. Philadelphia advanced 1 1/2, to 70 1/4, and Metropolitan closed at 107 5/8, a net gain of 1 3/8. The specialties were irregular.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- It being settled that the Republican Convention at St. Louis will nominate McKinley for the Presidency, attention from this time on will be fixed upon the Democratic contest, and particular interest will be felt in the struggle for the control of the Chicago Convention between the silverites and the sound-money men.

The Twenty-second Regiment Athletic Association held a most successful athletic meeting at the armory. Western Boulevard and Sixty-eighth Street, last evening. The sports were viewed by an enthusiastic crowd of spectatcus, who were profuse in their aknowledgments of the form shown by the various competitors.

RICHMOND, Va., April 30. -- The National Society of the Song of the American Revolution met here to-day and observed the anniversary of the first inauguration of Washington as President of the United States, Gen. Horace Porter, President General, called the meeting to order at 10:30 A.M. William Wirt Henry, President of the Virginia Society, cordially welcomed the delegates.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- An attack upon the Administration to-day in the Senate provoked the liveliest discussion of the present session and gave Mr. Hill an opportunity to sound a rallying cry for the Democrats who are determined that the party shall not be committed to the silver heresy.

The first official act of Justice Andrew Lemon, who took his seat yesterday morning on the bench of the Ewen Street Police Court, Brooklyn, was to remove from office Chief Clerk Mortimer C. Earl, a Democrat and Union veteran, and to appoint George E. England, a Worth Republican, whose record as a ward politician and political dependent is well known.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The House Committee on Labor to-day ordered a favorable report on the bill of Mr. Southwick of New-York, to protect free labor from competition with convict labor, by restricting the sale of convict-made goods to the States in which they are produced. The measure...

LONDON, May 1. -- The Prince of Wales's filly, Thais, won the One Thousand Guineas Stakes at Newmarket to-day. The race was run over the Rowley mile, a mile and eleven yards. Thais is a brown filly by St. Serf-Poetry. Douglas Baird's br. f. Santa Maura, by St. SimonPalmflower, was second, and Lord Zetland's b. f. Jolly Boat, by Panserchire-Santa Felice, third.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 1. -- Senator Cullom declines to say whether or not he will withdraw from the race for the Presidential nomination. He shows by his manner that he is very much disappointed at the action taken by the State Convention. His friends say however, that he will not withdraw from the race.
The Professional Woman's League listened to some interesting "firsts" at its regular weekly meeting yesterday afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- Judge Acheson, in the United States Circuit Court, to-day, signed the decree, filed last week by the Pennsylvania Company for Insurance on Lives and Granting Annuities as trustee, for the sale of the property of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad and Coal and Iron Companies, under foreclosure proceedings.
Another Work by Crawford. ADAM JOHNSTONE'S SON By F. Marion Crawford. With numerous illustrations, NewYork: Macmilian Co. $1.50.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 1. -- State Senator Maurice A. Rogers of Camden County, N.J., one of the Republican leaders of the State, to-day swore that William J. Thompson, at one time best known as the "Duke of Gloucester," offered $75,000 if Rogers would induce three Republican Senators to vote for certain race-track bills.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- May Day without the slightest glimpse of sunshine and with a reminding of February temperature would not allow more than the least ordinary congregation at Bennings to-day. The field, numerically trivial, primarily was lessened by the marking out as ineligible at the Leclair black horse Kinglet from the six-furlong feature, with Karma and Flame scratched from the last race, the five-furlong dash.

The political contingencies involved in consolidation are being already seriously considered by the leaders of the regular Democratic organization in Brooklyn. The great question agitating their minds is, whether or not they and their organization are to be swallowed up by Tammany Hall. Some of the leaders over the East River do not allude to it as an act of swallowing, but call it by the milder name of coalescence or amalgamation.

After all the routine business of the Police Board had been disposed of yesterday. Commissioner Parker, to the surprise of everybody, moved to re-elect Commissioner Roosevelt President of the board: He said: " It being the 1st of May, it devolves upon us to elect a President of the board.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 1. -- Joseph H. Choate argued before the Court of Appeals this morning against the constitutionality of the Raines liquor tax law. His first point was that the law was unconstitutional as regards the unequal tax levied for different sections of the State for the same purposes.

A concert will be given in the Metropolitan Opera House to-night under the auspices of the Purim Association for the benefit of the United Hebrew Charities. From a musical standpoint, the affair promises to be one of the most interesting of the season.

CHICAGO, May 1. -- All attention was given to Diamond Match and New-York Biscuit. The former sold between 235 and 238, and closed at 236 3/4. New-York Biscuit broke all records on the Exchange both for the number of shares traded in and in regard to strength. It opened at 93 7/8, the lowest price of the day, and closed within a quarter of a point of the highest, at 101.

Nearly all the final arrangements for the opening of the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club's fourth annual horse show this evening have been completed. The exhibition will continue every fllowing evning throughout the week, except the last day. Saturday, when there will also be in afternoon session. The official programme 13 is follows:

FRIDAY -- P.M. A Stock Exchange holiday in London contributed its influence to a further restriction of business on this market The tone, however, was fairly firm, although operations were confined almost entirely to professional traders. Final prices were not materially changed from yesterday.

The imports of dry goods at the Port of New-York for the week were valued at $1,228,104, against $1,714,399 last week and $2,224,186 for the corresponding week last year. The value of dry goods marketed was $1,314.977, against $1,090,140 last week and $2,079,499 in the same week last year.

Mayor STRONG should have the thanks of all sensible citizens for putting his veto on the bill giving the Fire Commissioners control over the civil service examinations for appointments in their department. And our thanks should be the more hearty because he took time enough for his veto to make it fatal.

Among the bills passed by the Legislature affecting this city is one authorizing an expenditure of $5,000,000 for additional school accommodations. Now, there is no doubt as to where these accommodations are most needed. The money should be expended in providing the means of primary education for all children who are now deprived of it.

Frank X. Sadlier, as receiver of the property of Cassidy Adler, caused to be sold at public auction June 6, 1895, the house and lot 138 West One Hundred and Thirty-third Street. The notice of sale said: "Mortgages -- Subject to a mortgage of $16,000, to be at 5 per cent, for about three years."

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The National bank note circulation outstanding is $224,101,345, an increase during April of $2,873,540. The circulation, based on bonds, is $203,403,230. Coinage executed at United States mints during April aggregated $3,371,670, of which gold coinage amounted to $1,500,600 and silver to $1,831,000. Of the latter, $1,500,000 was in standard silver dollars.

The Actuarial Society of America convened in the meeting room of an up-town hotel yesterday, and opened the second day's session of its semi-annual meeting. President Emory McClintock was in the chair.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Silver Democrats who were talking in a sanguine way a week ago about controlling the Chicago Convention for free silver, and their ability to force the sound-money men to agree to their demands or bolt, are indicating now a great degree of annoyance at the changed conditions, and are indulging in threats of bolting if they shall happen to be in the minority.
WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Secretary Hoke Smith has approved the following grants of land to railroads:

Senator QUAY, who once frightened the leading Republican organ of Philadelphia with the awful risk of "standing dumb" before the revelation of his misdeeds, is reported to feel very glum over the success of MCKINLEY in Illinois. If now there is the same success, or anything like it in Indiana, then, indeed, in the phrase of the Senator, "the jig is up."

Messrs. M. L. Hess have sold for the R. S. Clark estate to a client the property at 830 Broadway, 27.2 by 120.9, with an L 23 by 25, extending northward, at about $145.000. A five-story business building is on the plot.

It seems safe to assume, as everybody does assume, that the victory of McKINLEY in the State Convention of Illinois greatly aids, if it does not assure, his nomination at St. Louis. That would be a most absurd performance, but its absurdity does not diminish its probability.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The House gave most of its time to-day to the Bankruptcy bill, considering it in Committee of the Whole. General debate having been closed, the bill was read for amendment under the five-minute rule.

BOSTON, May 1. -- The general tone wag strong to-day, though in the mining shares there was some reaction toward the end. The Bigelow group were all very strong on rumored buying or insiders. Boston and Montana sold up 2 1/4, to 76, closing at 75. Merced was bid up to 13 5/8, but immediately felt back to 13, closing at 12 1/2. Osceola advanced 1/2, to 25 1/2, but closed at 25.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 1. -- Li Hung Chang, the extraordinary representative of the Emperor of China at the ceremonies attending the coronation of the Czar of Russia in Moscow, arrived here yesterday. He was received by the Russian authorities and the Chinese Legation, and was also provided with a guard of honor.

Programme to be Opened This Morning by the Alumni and University Officers -- The Exercises of the Afternoon Will Be More Public in Character -- Details of the Proceedings and the Names of Some Who Will Take Part.
LONDON, May 1. -- Princess Beatrice, (Princess Henry of Battenberg,) daughter of the Queen, has been appointed Governor of the Isle of Wight.

ROCHESTER, May 1. -- Will H. Vanzandt, the seventen-year-old son of L. H. Vanzandt, of the Rochester Savings Bank, took a spin on his bicycle out in the country Wednesday night. He struck a large stone, which hurled him to the ground. For some moments he lay on the ground, a ringing pain in his head. Then he mounted the wheel and started for his home, the pain increasing all the time.

LONDON, May 1. -- Two noteworthy dramatic performances were given in London to-day to mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of Charles Wyndham's management of the Criterion Theatre. Most of the prominent actors now in England volunteered their services. Wyndham is a very popular man in London both on and off the stage.

The Committee on Vagrancy of the Conference of Charities yesterday submitted to Mayor Strong its conclusions regarding the experiment of establishing a lodging house for homeless men, which it had been asked to inquire into. The committee also made investigations into the past history of such lodgers as were housed, as a basis for the permanent disposition of each applicant.

More than 3,000 people attended the Spring reception in the Metropolitan Museum of Art last evening, visitors continuing to enter the building until after 10 o'clock. The attendance was larger than at any other Spring reception.
NEWARK, N.J., May 1. -- The story told the police by a woman whom Patrolman Adams of this city met on the street on Wednesday night and befriended has turned out to be untrue --

Alexander Bremer, Jr., twenty years old, living at 69 East Eighty-sixth Street, the son of the defeated candidate for Register on the Steckler ticket last year, was a prisoner at Yorkville Police Court yesterday on a charge of forgery.

NEW-ORLEANS, L.a., May 1. -- Every one has been guessing what was the meaning of the conference between President Janvier and Mr. McCloskey, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Citizens' League, and Gov. Foster and his friends two nights ago. The mystery deepened when the same gentlemen of the league met Gov. Pharr and some of his campaign committee to-day and remained in conference with them two hours.
ALBANY, May 1. -- Adjt. Gen. McAlpin has sent the following letter to D. W. C. Ward of New-York City:

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- The dismal failure of the strike on the trolley lines has been followed by a further enhancement in the values of the Traction stocks to-day. Philadelphia advanced 1 per cent., to 71, and the others closed fractionally higher. The specialties were dull, with Pennsylvania Heat the feature. The common advanced to 13 7/8, and the preferred to 17 3/8.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Mr. Butler (Pop., N. C.,) introduced in the Senate today a bill to make the Mexican dollar, the Japanese yen, and the trade dollar equal in value to the standard dollar of the United States, and a full legal tender to any amount for all debts and demands, public or private, and made an argument in support of it.

NEW-HAVEN, May 2. -- The annual tournament of the Yale interscholastic tennis association was held to-day at the grounds of the New-Haven Lawn Club. The grounds were in perfect condition, the players in good form, and the standard of play high. Joseph T. Whittelsey, the veteran tennis authority, acted as referee.

From The Gentleman's Magazine. Dr. Johnson mentions that his curious custom was, on receiving the Queen's annual u50, to disappear for a while, only returning to his usual haunts when all was spent. Questioned as to his motive, he avowed it was to study, but the shortness of the period belied him.

LENOX, Mass., May 2. -- Miss Lucy Frelingbuysen came up from New-York this week and remained for several days. She will occupy the Shaw cottage Redwood, for the coming Summer. It is not yet settled who will have the large Frelinghuysen place opposite the Episcopal church for the coming season.

Having long been madly picturesque, Mr. LAWSON N. FULLER at last seems to have become picturesquely mad. And it's all the fault of the elevated road, a corporation upon which he has lavished for years the hot affection that welled up from a heart youthful and passionate to a degree truly remarkable in these disillusionized days.

From Chamber's Journal. The scene is laid in Griqualand East, a dependency of the Cape of Good Hope. The place, a country schoolhouse, situate in a wide, open plain, with "bush" and "dongas," or gallies, in the distance. The master receives a Government grant; the parents also pay him a small fee monthly.

The American District Telegraph Company will put twenty of its messengers upon bicycles to-day, and if the experiment proves successful many additional wheels will be used. It is thought that bicycles will greatly expedite the messenger service.

From The Contemporary Review. If Gilbert White had never lived, or had never corresponded with Pennant and Daines Barrington, Selborne would have impressed me as a very pleasant village set amid diversified and beautiful scenery, and I should have long remembered it as one of the most charming spots which I had found in my rambles in Southern England.

The course of inland navigation stretches from New-York City to Beaufort, N.C. It is a great commercial highway at present, but the War Department is considering its use as part of the system of coast defense. This route is little known except by traders using it and by those cruising in yachts toward Southern waters.

Despite the changes brought about by the newer custom, the 1st of May is still linked in the minds of real estate men with the idea of moving. It will so continue: also just so long as the law provides that tenancies in this city not otherwise specified as to term shall expire on May 1 in each year.

The Society of American Artists closed its eighteenth exhibition at the galleries of the Fine Arts Society last night. The sales have been few, and the attendance only moderate, but the collection of pictures has been rarely surpassed in quality. The Academy of Design continues on for another fortnight.

"The Rogues' Comedy," by Henry Arthur Jones, which E.S. Willard has just produced at the Garrick Theatre, in London, is a satirical play in three acts. The protagonist is Bailey Prothero, "scheme" promoter, hypnotist, and soothsayer. "Perhaps," says The London Times, "the colossal rogue whom Mr. Willard embodies with a wealth of graphic detail is a trifle too highly colored, a trickster with too obviously shady a record to be accepted in the City.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Silver Democrats are not so willing to indicate, at the end of this week, where they may find the 50 to 150 majority for free coinage in the National Convention they were sure of getting a week ago.

"Yes, the meeting was a complete failure, any way you look at it." Thus the statesman, who had drifted into the club and taken his seat near the group, the central figure of which was the Plunger. The talk was, of course, about racing. It always is when that persistent follower of the game drifts in. The Washington race meeting was the failure that had been referred to.

From The Springfield (Mass.) Republican. At the regular meeting of the North Adams City Council Monday evening Mayor A.C. Houghton, through E.S. Wilkinson, presented the city with a magnificent public library building to be a memorial to his brother, Andrew J. Houghton of Boston. Mr. Houghton's letter to Mr. Wilkinson, which was read to the Council, is as follows:

TROY, N.Y., May 2. -- Transportation business on the Champlain Canal does not start briskly this year, although It is generally thought that the season will turn out to be a good one for the boatmen. Several large contracts for freighting one have been let, but the competition has been keen, and the contract prices for the work are lower than usual.

At a recent meeting in London of the British Ornithologists' Club interest centred in a collection of 900 cuckoo eggs which was exhibited by one of the members, and ever since then, the English papers have been discussing the habits and powers of that somewhat disreputable bird with much energy.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Only two bidders answered the call for proposals recently made by the Navy Department for "About 6,000 tons of nickel-steel armor, to be of the best material and domestic manufacture, part of which will be required to be treated by a process of supercarbonization, known as the Harvey process; to be shaped accurately after patterns or drawings, and of such sizes and general character as may be required."

Public Works Commissioner Collis's letter to Gov. Morton, attacking the Consolidation bill and urging the Chief Executive to veto the measure, was read, yesterday in Brooklyn with some interest, but little surprise. The fight against the bill when it was in Mayor Strong's hands by the Corporation Counsel and the Street Cleaning Commissioner had prepared the Brooklyn, consolidationists for a further on slaught by the rest of Mayor Strong's Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The navy is being equipped with some new small boats of recent design. These craft will be carried on the various ships of war. Those first completed will be used by the cadets at the Naval Academy in their drills.

Paris Dispatch to The London Telegraph. Near one of the gates leading into Paris an old man of stout proportions was seen a day or two ago, wending his way, when a cab, driven at great speed, approached, and, as the man paid no attention to the warning cry of the Jehu, he was knocked down, and the vehicle Passed over his body, to the consternation of the spectators.

The official letters and records of the Revolution are so full of complaints of the inefficiency of the militia that the histories compiled from them scarcely do justice to the bravery and patriotism of these soldiers. Gen. Washington, in his letters to Congress, was forced to emphasize their faults in order to obtain the necessary regular troops.

From The Spectator. Lord Cromer's success is in particular due to his seeing that the only efficient way to rule Egypt was to have an Englishman at hand to say the final word in every department of State. He has never wanted to flood Egypt with English administrators after the manner of France in Tunis.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 2. -- A close contest took place in Annapolis Harbor this afternoon between the twelve-oared cutters, manned by the naval cadets and the New-York Naval Reserve. The race was a mile, and the cadets won by a length. Time -- 8:07. The time of the New-Yorkers was one second more.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 2. -- Prof. Charles M. Mead of the Hartford Theological Seminary, who will deliver the address relating to the services of Dr. William Henry Green of Princeton Theological Seminary, in behalf of Biblical criticism at Dr. Green's fiftieth anniversary, which will take place at Princeton on May 5, is an old friend and associate of the distinguished Princeton Theologian, having been identified with him for years on the Old Testament Revision Committee.

From The Gentleman's Magazine. The learned Camden speaks of Lane as the original English smoker. It is remarkable that so much doubt should have existed among writers even in Eliza-Jacobean times, both as to the date when tobacco was first received in this country and the person by whom it was first introduced.

From Harper's Magazine. So large was Lowell's spirit of toleration, so wide his interest in all good kinds of humanity, that his very catholicism led him sometimes to impute the same quality to others in a larger degree than they really possessed. He could not understand that men who had intelligence and some knowledge of the world should not get on well together, whatever the differences that divided them in matters of politics or faith.

From The London Standard. Baron Hirsch died of syncope at 3 o'clock in the morning, at which hour his moans attracted the attention of the occupants of the adjoining rooms. On entering his bedroom, they found that he had already passed away.

ALBANY, May 2. -- Under the provisions of the Bi-Partisan Police bill, signed by Gov. Morton on Thursday, the Police Board was legislated out of office yesterday. Mayor Thacher, in order to form the groundwork for making a case in the courts, called a special meeting of the Common Council for to-night, to receive nominations and discuss legislative acts relating to the city.

Everything that is artistic in any way belongs to art, it matters not what constitutes its makeup. For the moment it may seem strange to claim that anything as crude as is the ordinary hunters' camp should have anything in common, any relationship whatever, with art in any of its varied branches.
From The Jacksonville (Fla.) Times-Union. W.R. Collins, a taxidermist, guide, and general hunter after birds, reptiles, animals, , had a close call recently.

There is to be a new statue of Garibaldi in Washington Square. The old bronze figure of the Italian liberator is to be taken down in a few days and put up, in an amputated form, near the spot where Garibaldi molded candles on Staten Island. The legs will be cut off and a new pedestal provided.

WEDNESDAY, May 6. -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., auction sale, 275 lots on Undercliff Terrace, Twenty-fourth Ward, contiguous to Morris Dock and Morris Heights stations, and the Washington Bridge. The lots are on Sedgwick, Undercliff, Popham, and Montgomery Avenues, One Hundred and Seventy-seventh Street and Palisade Place and, the streets are graded and sewered.

From The Fortnightly Review. Constantine created his New Rome in 330, as never ruler before or since created a city. It was made a mighty and resplendent capital within a single decade. Italy, Greece, Asia Minor, Syria, Egypt, Mauritania, were despoiled of their treasures to adorn the new metropolis.

TEHERAN, May 2. -- The following details of the assassination of the Shah yesterday were obtained, through official sources this morning. The Shah, accompanied by the Grand Vizier, Asghar, and a number of attendants, paid, a visit to the shrine of Shah Abdul Azim. His Majesty traversed the outer court of the shrine, where he stopped and gave a bank note to an Arab and spoke a few kind words to a water carrier.
