A man named Buggeling has written, and The London Standard has published, the following letter. It does not, indeed, prove quite conclusively the existence of ghosts as a part of the earth's present population, but it does the next thing to that by showing that ghost stories of the most serious kind still survive.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 2. -- Cornell won from Princeton to-day in the most exciting game of baseball ever played on Percy Field. Princeton played steady ball, but Cornell bunched her hits better, and played more brilliantly. At the beginning of the ninth, Cornell commenced to bat Wilson, and scored 5 runs. Then Wilson struck the last two batters out.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- Local stocks to-day were dull and strong. The only important feature was the Tractions, all of which closed at fractional gains, with a decidedly strong undertone. The specialties were featureless, except Choctaw. which closed at 8, and Welsbach Commercial preferred, which sold at 68, The market in general at the close was steady.

From The Nineteenth Century. Germany is England's great trade rival; she has a large mercantile marine, but no sufficient navy with which to defend it from us. Nor could she do much damage to our trade; for she has no good coaling stations, and her foreign cruisers are not powerful enough to force ours.

From The Fortnightly Review. It is also the headquarters of our North American squadron of seven cruisers, whose arsenal, coalyard and dry dock are well protected by the fortress.

ORANGE, N.J., May 2. --The Orange Athletic Club beat the Lafayette College at baseball this afternoon at the Orange Oval before about 500 persons. The Orange men did not improve on their mediocre play of last week, and errors and loose play were the order on both sides. The score:

LONDON, May 2. -- The popular impression is that President Kruger has knocked Mr. Secretary Chamberlain literally over the ropes. I choose this image because in the public imagination here the whole South African business has come down to a personal contest of nerve with science between these two champions.

Mrs. Maggie David, thirty-four years old, committed suicide last evening at her home, 155 Prince Street, by taking carbolic acid. She was the wife of John David, an Englishman, who married her at Manchester five years ago. They came to this country after their marriage. The husband is an artificial flower cutter, and they lived well enough until he began to drink, a year or so ago.

Paris Dispatch to The London News. Another monstrous case of Algerian military discipline is reported. The victim this time was a soldier named Cheymol, brother of M. Paul Cheymol. He was sent, for some breach of rules, to a disciplinary company. This means a sort of penal servitude of the many fearful kinds that have survived the revolution.

A teacher in one of our public schools makes " Arbor Day " for herself by a little celebration which she gives the children under her care. She talks to them of the importance of trees to a fertile country, of the causes of and preventives to destruction of forests, and then, when she thinks they have fully entered into the spirit of the occasion, she appoints the time for their own tree-planting.

By the narrowest possible margin the Washingtons won a game from the Brooklyns yesterday afternoon at Eastern Park. It was a remarkably pretty contest, and while the spectators did not like the result, they went away satisfied that they had witnessed a good afternoon's sport. The game was marked by the sharpest kind of fielding, good pitching by Mercer and Kennedy, and some pretty stickwork at different points.

ATHENS, Greece, April 15. -- The international Olympic games culminated Friday afternoon, April 10. A more perfect day for athletic contests if would be difficult to imagine. Nothing could have intensified the interest of the events, and their importance could have been increased only by the competition of a greater number of representative athletes.
LONDON, May 2. -- SS Mannheim, (Ger.,) Capt. Oekelmann, from Rotterdam for New-York, passed Dover yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, May 2 -- The invitation games of the Yale Track Athletic Association were held at the Yale Field this afternoon and attracted about 1,000 spectators. The entries included athletes from Harvard, Columbia, Dartmouth, and Holy Cross Colleges, Boston, New-York, and New Jersey athletic clubs. Many of the minor colleges and preparatory schools of the East were also represented.

EAST CHICAGO, Ind., May 2. -- The East Chicago Iron and Steel Company resumed operations yesterday. The mill will run day and night, giving employment to 500 men. The works are operating in full in all departments, the difficulties of the company having been adjusted.

Fortunately for the dignity of operatic art, Mme. Calve has never learned to sing "Home, Sweet Home." This was encouraged by the Court, with the intention of giving an impetus to trade, and of gaining popularity by favoring constant festivities, and consequently constant expense.

From The National Review. The fundamental principle of navigation, and therefore the controlling elementary law of maritime strategy, is the physical law of displacement -- that a floating vessel invariably weighs neither more nor less than the quantity of water which its immersed part displaces.
The baby elephants of Barnum Bailey's Greatest Show on Earth have gone into brand-new tailor-made suits. The babies have heretofore been appearing simply in their "figgers."

The Turkiya-el-Fatat, the organ of the Young Turkey Party in Paris, publishes in its last issue the demands of that party. These demands are moderate and sensible. They are: Convocation of the Turkish Parliament, moderate liberty of the press, equality of all citizens before the law, drafting of all Turkish subjects into the army, irrespective of religion.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- After being under consideration a week, and furnishing material for the only political debate of the session in the Senate, the Naval Appropriation bill, shorn of some of its principal features, was passed late this afternoon without a division. Up to the last Mr. German maintained his critical attitude toward the measure.

From the Spectator. At Genoa, Lady Blessington sought the ac uaintance of Byron, then in the toils of La Guiccioli and a vegetarian diet. In later and less affluent days she recorded her impressions of the poet, whose genius she admired, but whose character she divined and despised with all a woman's intuition and contempt for petty blemishes.

BUDA-PESTH, May 2. -- The initial ceremonies of the celebration of the National millennium of Hungary were opened to-day. The skies were clouded in the forenoon, but the weather was otherwise pleasant. Emperor Francis Joseph, as King of Hungary, wearing the uniform of a General, and looking remarkably healthy and vigorous, was received with great enthusiasm as he arrived upon the scene of the ceremonies.

John Hare, the English comedian, will close his first American tour with his performances in Brooklyn this week. He will sail for Europe on the Germanic Wednesday, May 13, but will return here next season to make another tour under the direction of Charles Frohman. Mr. Hare's first American season has been a very prosperous one, and he is delighted with the way in which he has been received.

With fitting pomp and elaborate ceremonial, the new site of Columbia University, on Morningside Heights, was dedicated yesterday before an assemblage of deans, doctors, professors, students, and distinguished guests, among whom were Gov. Morton, Mayor Strong, Gen. E.A. McAlpin, President Seth Low of the university, ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt, President Eliot of Harvard, President Brown, of Lehigh University.

LONDON, May 2. -- Mr. Fife, the well-known yacht designer, has designed a forty-two-footer for a syndicate of Canadian yachtsmen, who propose to challenge the Vencedor. The new boat has a large sail plan. After her skeleton has been fitted, the frames will be taken apart and shipped to Toronto. Emperor William's new yacht, the Meteor, will be launched on the Clyde on May 14.

OXFORD, Penn., May 2. -- The one hundred and seventy-fifth anniversary of the Lower Brandy wine Presbyterian Church, near Centreville, Del., was celebrated April 23. New-Castle Presbytery, to which the church belongs, met there April 21, and took part in the exercises.

Commissioner Eva Booth of the Salvation Army sailed for England yesterday on the Cunarder Umbria, A large delegation of Salvation Army soldiers was on the pier to see her off. The Commissioner is a saloon passenger. She is accompanied by Miss Pease.

The recent mysterious murder near Huntington, West Va., of Robert K. McCoy of the mountaineer family of Pike County, Ky., and the suspicion that the Hatfields were mixed up in his disappearance, recalls memories of the great McCoy-Hatfield feud, which was one of the most sensational subjects for the last generation.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 2. -- Mrs. Boyd and Ralph Boyd have returned to their Summer home, in Highland Park, having spent the Winter in New-York.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 2. -- This is the season of the year when those people who have leased cottages along the seashore, and who are anticipating spending the Summer months there, are wondering whom, they will likely come in contact with and whom they may expect to have as their neighbors while sojourning there.

An interesting relic of that very scarce article "a good Indian while living" will be placed on exhibition to-morrow by Tiffany Co. in their store. It is a silver medal presented to the Pawnee Chief Spotted Horse by President Andrew Jackson in November, 1829, as a token of respect for the Indian chiefs friendly services to the white men.

When the big collection of trotters, pacers, addlers, and high steppers was all disposed of at Madison Square Garden Friday evening a little ever $110,000 had been paid over to W.B. Fasig Co., and nearly 450 horses had changed owners. According to the managers of the sale. which began last Monday afternoon, the most profitable business was done when the average price seemed low.

CAPE MAY, N.J., May 2. -- The one hundred and eighty-second anniversary of the Hounding of the Presbyterian Church at Cold Spring, three miles north of Cape May, will soon be celebrated by appropriate exercises. A few years previous to 1714 the peninsula of Cape May County was settled by colonists from the vicinity of New-Haven and from Long Island.

SING SING, N.Y., May 2. -- The zealous work of friends and admirers in the face of numerous discouragements now seems about to be crowned with success, and a fitting recognition on the part of the Government of the services of Major Gen. William H. Morris is to be made by raisins his little pension of $15 a month to something more adequate.

From The San Francisco Call. A lunatic with a gun cleared out nearly all the worshippers in the First Unitarian Church in Oakland Sunday morning. For several minutes there was intense excitement and a hurried rush to the doors, but when Col. Irish and Judge Yule were seen leading a wild-looking man out the congregation was induced to return and the service was concluded.

LONDON, May 2. -- The questions exciting the lobby of the House of Commons and all the political clubs are how much the inner Cabinet knew of the revelations made at Pretoria before they were known to the public, and whether Sir Hercules Robinson, Governor of Cape Colony and British High Commissioner in South Africa, is implicated in the conspiracy against the Transvaal.

The fourth annual free art exhibition for the benefit of citizens of the east side of the lower part of the city will be opened to-night in the Hebrew Institute, at Jefferson Street and East Broadway.

PLAINPIELD, N.J., Mar 2. -- A pleasant euchre party was given on Tuesday evening by Miss Ernestine Smith and Frank; Smith at their home on Madison Avenue, in honor of Miss Bentley of Westerly, R.I., who is visiting them. The prizes were won by Miss Maude Mosher and Mr. Frank Randolph. The evening closed with dancing and refreshments.

The spectacle was completed by chariots, mechanical effects, devices, recitations, and equestrian ballers, the variety of which united to form a magnificent whole to the eye.

BERLIN, May 2. -- There was a Ministerial crisis in the earlier part of the week over the question of reform in the laws of military procedure in the trial of militaires for criminal offenses, which it was generally believed had reached an acute stage, but it has since been denied upon semi-official authority that such a state of things ever existed.

For two years past the firm of Samuel Ayres Son, at one time situated on Water Street, New-York, and later at Bay Ridge, where the cutters Liris and Kathleen and many steam craft were built, have been established on the Hudson River at Nyack, where a large three-story shop has been built, with a basin and railways, giving excellent facilities for building and repair work.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 2. -- A spell of warm weather has hovered around for the last week and has given to everything a decided Summer aspect, and imbued every visitor with a vacation spirit, that is strikingly noticeable. On the sands the reclining chairs are the favorite accommodations, and in them visitors by the score loll and enjoy daydreams.
ORANGE, N.J., May 2. -- An excellent musical recital was given this afternoon at the Shepard School of Music by the pupils of the school.

WHITESTONE, L.I., May 2. -- One of the best marksmen in the National Guard of this State, as demonstrated by the recent indoor contests for The Eagle Cup, is George W. Lent of this village, a private in Company D, Forty-seventh Regiment.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 2. -- Mrs. J.G. Lovell and Mrs. Sanger sailed for Paris today.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- President Cleveland and all the members of his Cabinet except Secretary Hoke Smith were at Arlington this afternoon to see the body of Gen. W.Q. Gresham buried in the National Cemetery. They had met the train from Chicago at the railroad station, and in several carriages they followed the hearse to the hillside, overlooking the Potomac and the City of Washington.

New-London will be 250 years old next Wednesday, May 6, and its citizens are making great preparations to celebrate this interesting historical event in a most proper and patriotic manner. New-London in recent years has become more prominently known as the scene of college boat races than for anything else.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 2. -- A May dance will be given soon by some Glen Ridge folk under the patronage of Mrs. Edward S. Mapes, Mrg. Henry C. Harris, Mrs. Alexander S. Niven, Mrs. Harris Uhler, and Mrs. John W. Reddall.

Patriotic persons in this city are taking great interest in a proposed one-hundred-thousand-dollar monument to the late Rev. Dr. S.F. Smith, author of "America." It is to be a National monument, erected through a National movement, but whether New-York, Boston, or Washington, the three bidders for the memorial just now, will get it is not known as yet.

SUMMIT, N.J., May 2. -- A very entertaining dramatic performance was given tonight by the pupils of the Short Hills public schools in the Short Hills Casino. The mythological drama. "Theseus," was presented.
The new Excise Department is in full control of the excise machinery in Brooklyn, for the first time since the new State excise tax law went into effect.

The Passion Play of Ober-Ammergau is a crude representation by simple German peasants, and it is enacted but once in each decade. Yet American newspapers and magazines have exhausted their resources to illustrate and describe this rude drama by illiterate folk in an obscure hamlet of a foreign land and thousands of American have flocked thither to feed their hunger for novelty.

From Chambers's Journal. The ordinary gunpowder contained 10 per cent, of sulphur; and on this percentage being reduced to between 2 and 4, it was found that a powder could be produced which burned considerably slower than the ordinary type. Indeed, a powder having this composition is still in use for moderately large guns, and gives excellent results.

Considering how little opportunity there has been for giving the trotters regular work this Spring, the local fliers stepped some creditable miles at the Parkway track yesterday. The occasion was the annual opening of the grounds at Gravesend, where Brooklyn horsemen have enjoyed their favorite sport for several seasons on one of the best half-mile courses in the country.

Francis J. Alvany, the bunko-steerer, known in police circles as "Hungry Joe," will be released, June 20 from the Maryland Penitentiary, where he has been serving a term on a charge to which he pleaded guilty of having bunkoed William J. Bansemer of Baltimore out of $5,000 on Dec. 1, 1890.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 2. -- The annual Caledonian games for the class championship of Princeton were held here this afternoon. For the third successive year the class of '97 won the Championship Cup, gaining 44 1/2 points; '96 had 19 1/2 points; '98, 23, and '99 won 33. The day's feature was the interscholastic relay race, in which the team from Barnard School, New-York, made the mile in 3:39.

Cyclists who ride fast in crowded streets have had a number of ominous warnings within the last few days. A "scorcher" was killed in Baltimore recently while racing with a trolley car, and numerous accidents have occurred in this city as a result of fast riding, not to mention a fatality or two due to inexperience and the criminal negligence of truck drivers.

ROME, N.Y., May 2. -- The jury before which Hildreth, the boy train wrecker, is being tried listened to-day to the conthe day of his arrest to Chief of Police Haggerty. The Court decided that this important evidence was admissible, after listening to an argument against its admissibility based on allegations of duress and of promises or ency.

From The Edinburgh Scotsman. Her Majesty the Queen Empress will receive with satisfaction last year's report of the National Association for Supplying Female Medical Aid to the Women of India. In eleven years since its organization, under the name of the Lady Dufferin Fund, the number of women and girls annually relieved and cured has risen in 1895 to above 1,000,000, (1,054,387.) and in the last three years the number has doubled itself.

LONDON, May 2. -- The largeness of the majority, 177 votes, on the second reading of the Agricultural Rating bill in the House of Commons Thursday night was due to the fact that Mr. Chaplin, the President of the Local Government Board and the introducer of the bill, limited the operation of the measure to five years.

SATURDAY --P.M. Less than 60,000 shares were traded in in to-day's market, and half the total was contributed by Tobacco and Sugar. The only other stocks in which the transactions exceeded 1,000 shares each were Burlington ST. Paul, Louisville and Nashville, Reading, and Wheeling and Lake Erie.

The representative golf club in Philadelphia is the Philadelphia Country Club. The club was not originally formed with any idea of forwarding the interests of the game, but when the golfing fever struck this country, two or three years ago, the Philadelphians caught it, like everybody else, and the club has become far more widely known since golf has been one of its attractions than it ever was before.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 2. -- The great doors of the Casino are now open for the season, and both the grounds and club are being used by the few cottagers already here. Some minor repairs have bee: made, but the greatest changes are yet in order.

LONDON, April 22. -- We were speaking the other evening about Lord Cromer, whose services in Egypt during the past fifteen years have altered so much history, and as there were in the company an ex-official of the English administration on the Nile and an ex-Cabinet Minister who was in office here when Alexandria was bombarded, there was no lack of interesting talk on the subject.

ALBANY, May 2. -- There was an extremely strong tone to the local security market during the week. The adjournment of the legislature without passing the many measures Introduced which would have cut into the revenues or the gas and electric companies gave them a stronger tone. Troy City Railway gained a point, and is now quoted at 91 bid.

There has been trouble in the department of architecture of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, which has culminated in the resignations of nineteen of the most prominent members of that department. These resignations will go into effect May 19.

The seating capacity of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, was taxed to the utmost last night to accommodate the congregation that went to hear the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott deliver the ninth and last sarmon in the series, "The Theology of an Evolutionist." The discourse last evening was a summing up of the whole subject, and a restatement of the ground covered and the conclusions reached in the preceding eight sermons.

"Some of them look prosperous after a season on the road," but I'm afraid it won't last long, and that the usual hard struggle to keep body and soul together until next season opens will soon be in order.

The epidemic of Anneke Jans fever which prevailed in several States during the Winter appears to be dying out. but small outbreaks of a similar disease have been noticed in various parts of the country since the first of April. The distinctive feature of this malady is the patient's hallucination concerning the rightful title to a great quantity of real estate in the "heart" of some large Eastern city.

BERLIN, May 3. -- Prince George, eldest son of the Duke of Cumberland, underwent an operation at Gmunden last Tuesday, and appeared to be rapidly recovering from its effects. Alarming symptoms of pyaemia set in on Saturday, and he is in a critical condition.

The Rev. Dr. Gustav Gottheil, in discussing "Reforms in the Jewish Faith," in Temple Emanu-El, yesterday, strongly indorsed a sermon preached by Dr. Lyman Abbott on resurrection.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 3. -- Harvard University began its last term on Monday after a vacation of a week. The term will last only five weeks before the final examinations arrive.

Mayor Wurster with within a short time have to appoint fifteen members of the Brooklyn Board of Education to fill vacancies that will be made by retiring members. Five women were appointed a year ago by Mr. Schieren, and the women claim that the schools have been benefited by their being on the board.

Depew, in an address to the forty-seven women who received their diplomas as Bachelors of Law from the University of the City of New-York on April 29, said, in part: "The familiar idea through all time has been that the sphere of woman was in the house and in the domestic circle." This Mr. Depew deprecated.

In no line of sport is the work, of men followed so closely.

"The Hymns of the Ordinal" was the subject of Bishop Potter's lecture yesterday afternoon at the Church of the Trans-figuration, East Twenty-ninth Street, near Fifth Avenue. The lecture was one of a series delivered under the auspices of the Church Club of New-York on the liturgical hymns of the Church.

Mr. James B. Reynolds has written a letter to Robert Maclay, President of the Board of Education, in which he says:

PITTSBURG, May 2. -- The market has displayed a broadening tendency during the week. There is every indication that the Morgan-Drexel-Whitney-Stephenson syndicate, which is managing the Consolidated Traction deal, is making preparations to give the enterprise as much of a sendoff in the market as in the furnishing of additional facilities for rapid transfr.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 3. -- Prof. Ladd has been appointed on the Faculty of the Chicago University for the coming Summer university course. He will begin his work there July 1. He will give two courses of instruction, one repeating substantially the same seminary in ethics which he has been conducting this year for graduate students at Harvard University.

Commander Felix MeCurley, U.S.N. Commander Feilx McCurley, United States Navy, Captain of League Island Navy Yard, died at that station yesterday of heart failure. Commander McCurley was born in Baltimore in 1835 and early in life entered the merchant marine service. When the war broke out, he entered the United States Navy as Acting Master.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 3. -- The Republicans of Neptune Township, the home of State Senator James A. Bradley, are troubled over a political scandal that threatens to involve two prominent township officials. The principals are Thomas T. Gravatt and Jonathan T. Applegate, members of the Township Committee.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 3. -- At a meeting held recently at the house of President Morton the plans for the twenty-fifth anniversary celebration next Fall were informally discussed. It was decided to arrange a programme, after the adoption of which by the alumni and undergraduates the permanent committees from those bodies will take the affair in charge.

Sir Charles Rivers Wilson, President of the Grand Trunk Railway, who is at present staying at the Holland House, was asked yesterday by a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES what the general feeling in England was with regard to American railway securities.

GRANTSBURG, Wis., May 3. -- Three dams on Crooked Creek have been washed away and the high water has scattered millions of feet of logs through woods. The loss is heavy. The St. Croix River is higher than known in years.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 3. -- George Simmons Coe who for many years was President of the American Exchange National Bank of New-York, died this morning at his home in this place of paralysis. He had been in poor health for three years, in the course of which he had had four paralytic strokes. It was the fifth stroke that ended his life.

The three-story stable of Lawrence Mulry, at 10 Christopher Street, which gave the firemen trouble in the great blizzard of 1888, was wrecked by fire early yesterday morning, and almost before the firemen had got to work one man in the loft on the top floor had been suffocated, two horses had been burned to death, and two more were so badly scorched that they had to be killed.

LONDON, May 3. -- The Mall has a dispatch from Pretoria stating that the Transvaal Government has asked each of the minor members of the Reform Committee who was sentenced to fine, imprisonment, and banishment to state his reasons for requesting a reduction of his sentence. The four leaders who were sentenced to death were not asked their reasons why their sentence should be commuted.

From The London Chronicle. Baron Hirsch was no student, except of men. He never read a book except a French novel, and his views on such abstruse matters as bimetallism or home rule were based on conversations with experts, rather than derived from personal examination.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 2. -- The local stock market for the week has ruled quiet and firm, without any important feature. The demand for local investment stocks Is good and the offerings, as a rule, continue light. In bank stocks, prices show little change. Among the sales of the week were National Bank of North America at 44 1/2.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Gen. Grosvenor gave out to-night his weekly statement of McKinley delegates elected. He claims the election of 495 delegates instructed and pledged to the Ohio candidate. He points out that there are 118 delegates unelected, and predicts that McKinley will have more than 100 of that number.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Senator Tillman, it is asserted, here, was moved to make his recent violent and blustering speech in the Senate in order to regain, if possible, ground which he feared he had lost by declaring that he would join the Populists if the Democratic National Convention should refuse to indorse free coinage.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 3. -- The faculty of Union has appointed the following seniors as honor men and speakers on the commencement stage: D.H. Craven, Albany; George J. Dann, Walton; A.S. Derby, Sandy Hill; R. Guernsey, East Cobleskill; J. Herring, Walton; G.E. Pollock, North Argyle; M.H. Strong, Schenectady; G.L. Van Deusen, Argyle; H.M. West, Glens Falls, and D.M. Westfall, Jr., Cambridge.
Hudson County early yesterday morning had an exciting race, which began at Bayonne, traversed Jersey City and West Hoboken, and had two finishes, one in Union Hill and the other in Hoboken.
WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Gen. Clarkson, when asked: "Has McKinley a majority of the delegates already, and what of the claim that he will be nominated by acclamation?" answered:

The Aqueduct race track down on the shores of Jamaica Bay was the objective point for a lot of horsemen and lovers of racing yesterday in spite of the threatening weather. Those who made the trip found the track and its appointments so completely transformed that they hardly knew the place.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 3. -- The Rev. Arthur H. Goodenough, pastor of St. John's Methodist Episcopal Church, preached a sermon this evening on "Signs of the Times." The Rev. Mr. Goodenough said he considered the increasing intelligence of the laboring classes a most hopeful sign.

The bill "to establish a uniform law on the subject of bankruptcies," which passed the House of Representatives on Saturday, is one of the most important unpartisan measures with which Congress has to deal. It is so, first, because it involves the use of a power distinctly given by the Constitution to protect and promote honesty in business and to prevent and defeat dishonesty.

Johanna Silver, who, her relatives say, is only fourteen years old, and who lives with her uncle, Charles Barnet, at 130 East Broadway, disappeared from home some days ago. Her uncle notified the police. The next day he learned that the girl was seen on a ferryboat going to Jersey City with Albert J. Oswald, aged twenty-two, of 312 Front Street.

There was published yesterday an interview with a civil engineer, who said that recently, during a visit to Paris, he was engaged in negotiations with the Panama Canal Company and became acquainted with the company's plans. "It is the intention of the company," said he, "to make borings along the route of the proposed canal to demonstrate, if possible, the feasibility of constructing a waterway."

Christendom has a deeper interest in Abyssinia and its remarkable monarch, Emperor Menelek, than the world at large has stopped to consider. It is not the fate of the Italian Army nor the march of the British toward the Soudan that attracts thinking people. It is the general focusing of the world's lenses upon that part of the globe, which was literally the cradle of culture and of Christianity.
A report from the Canadian correspondent of The Iron Age, published in that journal on the 30th ult., contains the following: remarks:

ITHACA, N.Y., May 3. -- The lecture season is at its height at Cornell now, and nearly every department is being strengthened in its courses by a lecture or series of lectures by men of National reputation. One of the most eminent of the year's lecturers is Prince Wolkonski, who has been giving a series on "Russian History and Russian Literature."

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Gen. Clarkson, Mr. Fessenden of Connecticut, Senators Quay and Allison, and other great lights in the Republican Party have been consulted to-day, and Clarkson has isued a bulletin which shows that they do not agree with that other anti-McKinley man, Mr. Manley, about the number of delegates chosen and the instructions under which it is assumed the delegates will act.

The political fight between Sheriff Toffey of Hudson County and Col. Samuel D. Dickinson, the Republican leader in Jersey City, in which the New-Jersey State excise law is being used by the Sheriff as a club with which to punish Col. Dickinson and his friends, the saloon keepers of Jersey City and Hoboken, for preventing his selection as a delegate to the Republican National Convention, was continued yesterday.

The Bank Clerks' Bowling League will give a dinner Wednesday night at Thumann's Alleys, when the prizes won in the recent tournament will be distributed. The ties will be rolled off the same evening. The individual averages of the tournament are:

CAMBRIDGE, May 3. -- Harvard athletes have all settled down to strict training. The crew, one and all, remained in Cambridge and worked harder than usual during the vacation. But the baseball team, while playing every day, did not have any training table, while the track team took no work at all. But Monday morning brought a change.

PRINCETON, May 8. -- Princeton's closely approaching championship games with Yale and Harvard have turned all college eyes to the team which will uphold the honor of the orange and black on the collegiate diamond this year. Princeton opened the season with six veterans on the team, and the first week of practice was devoted to selecting effective men to fill the vacancies.

It may not be until Congress adjourns that the gentlemen having charge of the arrangements for the inter-collegiate rowing regatta will meet to decide on the place for holding the regatta. Poughkeepsie and Saratoga are the two places that are under consideration, as every one interested in such matters well knows.

Annually about this season of the year the Metropolitan Museum of Art, after closing its doors for a Spring cleaning and overhauling, emerges resplendent in fresh paint, newly oiled floors, a general rehanging, and, when fortune has smiled upon it, with many additions in an artistic way, either loaned or of which it may fortunately have become possessed.

AURORA, N.Y., May 3. -- Prof. John Fiske of Cambridge, Mass., delivered two very interesting and instructive lectures at Wells College Friday evening and Saturday afternoon, the subject of the former being "Pocahontas and John Smith," of the latter, "Old and New Methods of Treating History."

NEWARK, N. J., May 3. -- Forty-one cases of contagious diseases were reported to the Board of Health during the last week, and the discussion as to whether illness has been and is being caused by the use on the streets of sand from the filthy Passaic River is being carried on more vigorously than ever.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, May 3. -- The indignation among the liberal Mormons over the latest Church and State developments in Utah has not subsided, and there are indications that the coming campaign will be fought largely on that issue and will furnish some very interesting object lessons.

There is no room for doubt or misunderstanding as to what the Republican Party intends to do with respect to the tariff, and one can easily foresee at this time that the Republican tariff programme can be carried out in the next Congress -- if the party shall be successful in the November elections -- only by the aid of some concession to the silver men.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 3. -- A golf club has been organized among the Faculty and members of the senior class of Union College, and games are played daily in the extensive "pasture" in front of the campus.

The Raines law evolved no new phases yesterday notwithstanding it was the first Sunday that the saloons were under the new Excise Department's jurisdiction. The saloon hotels sold beer and sandwiches and the clubs continued in the even tenor of their way, ignoring the law as inapplicable to them.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Considerable interest is felt here as to the probable course of the Spanish authorities in relation to Cuba. The Queen of Spain's speech, to be Delivered at the opening of the Spanish Cortes at Madrid Monday, May 11, is expected to outline definitely the Cuban policy of the Government.

CAPE TOWN, May 4 -- Sir Hercules Robinson Governor of Cape Colony and British High Commissioner in South Africa, has communicated to the press a series of telegrams arising from 1 complaint made the Transvaal Government had been caused among the owing to the fact that British troops have been retained at Mafeking, on order, is instead of proceeding to Rhodesia.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- This has been a day of reverses for the Republicans of the Senate. They were subjected at the very beginning of the session to the humiliation of seeing the Du Pont case taken from the control of the Republican Chairman of the Committee on Privileges and Elections and made a special order for consideration immediately after the River and Harbor bill shall be disposed of.
The will of George Munro, the publisher, was filed for probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday. It is dated Feb. 18, 1892, and has two codicils, dated Feb. 8, 1894, and Aug. 1, 1895.

The National Armenian Relief Committee has received from Miss Clara Barton, President of the American Red Cross Society, a report of the relief work in Turkey. The report is dated at Constantinople April 16, and says:

It is fortunate that a bad beginning makes a good ending, else people would have become disgusted with racing yesterday. It was the opening day of the racing season in this State, and also the opening day for the completely reconstructed race course of the Queens County Jockey Club. Something like 4000 people were at the track to enjoy the first sport of the season.

ROUE, N.Y., May 4 -- The confession of the boy train wrecker. Hildreth, on trial on the charge of helping wreck the New-York Central fast mail train Nov. 19, 1895, was read to-day to the jury before which he is arraigned. The confession was made to District Attorney Klock in the presence of Detective Latham.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 4 -- One thousand physicians, representing all sections of the country, arrived here to-day to attend the American Medical Association, which meets to-morrow. The total attendance will run up to 2,000.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Senator Cullom was in the Senate Chamber this morning. He declined to go into a discussion of the situation in Illinois further than to say that, he went there fully conscious of the existing conditions.

NEWARK, N. J., May 4 -- The Rev. E.M. Garton, pastor of the Franklin Street Methodist Episcopal Church, preached a special sermon for wheelmen last night. The church was well filled, as provision had been made to accommodate bicyclists to the basement. The preacher had two wheels alongside of his desk, one a man's wheel and the other a woman's.

The municipal elections which were held throughout France on Sunday indicate, so far as they go, that M. BOURGEOIS will not succeed in the appeal which it is to be expected that he will make to the people against the Senate, and incidentally against his successors in office.

Two well-known business men were seated at a lunch table recently, consulting the bill of fare. One of them looked fresh and bright, the other was pale and languid. After a while the sickly looking man threw flown the bill and exclaimed:

All that Brooklyn lacks is a place like Madison Square Garden to hold its own with New-York in the way of horse shows. Even in the circumscribed space of the building on Prospect Park Plaza the fourth annual exhibit of crack high-steppers, roadsters, saddlers, and jumpers that commenced last night opened most auspiciously.

One result of President Roosevelt's tour of the city on Sunday to observe the workings of the Raines liquor law was the ordering yesterday of charges against Capt. Theron S. Copeland of the Thirteenth Police Precinct and two of his policemen for failure to enforce the law.

SYNOPSIS. At the time when Philip II. of Spain was tightening his grip on the Netherlands, 300 years ago a rebellion of the Prince of Orange's partisans was imminent in Brussels. Feria Manrique, a veteran of Philip's army, living in retirement in Brussels, is summoned to the presence of the Spanish Countess de Mirando by Count Mena de Velasco, a Chamberlain of the Regent Duchess.
The Electrical Exposition was formally opened by Gov. Morton last night at 8:30 in the main hall of the Industrial Building, at Forty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

Thomas W. Bradley of Newburg, one of the delegates to the St, Louis Republican National Convention from the Seventeenth Congressional District, has bolted from Gov. Morton and gone over to Major McKinley.
MILWAUKEE, May 4 -- A strike of street railway employes for an advance in wages and recognition, of the union was begun this, morning, tying up every line in the city.

Messrs. B.M. Strauss Co. have sold, for the estate of Edward J. King, to Gutwillig Brothers, six lots, three on the west side or St. Nicholas Avenue, 29.7 1/4 feet north of One Hundred, and Eleventh Street, and three oh the north side of One Hundred and Eleventh Street, 121.11 feet west of St. Nicholas Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 -- The traction stocks were the feature to-day. Union gained 3/8, to 17 7/8; Philadelphia 3/4 to 71 3/4; Metropolitan 3/4 to 108 1/4, and Union 4s 1/2, to 73 3/8. In the specialities the general tendency was upward. United Gas Improvement closed at a net gain of a point. Storage common receivyed good support around 34 3/4 and 35.

George J. Gould and Russell Sage, representing the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company, bad a conference with Mayor Strong yesterday that lasted about two hours. They left a set of plans for exten- sions and improvements with the Mayor, which are said to be comprehensive, but which none of the conferrees would discuss for publication.

BOSTON, May 4 -- The features of to-day's market were Bay State Gas securities, Dominion Coal, and New-Haven. The first two took up the attention of the Street almost to the entire exclusion of the rest of the list. Bay State Gas jumped 1 1/8 on the opening, gained 2 points further, and closed at 16. The firsts rose 7 points to 90, and closed at 88.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., May 4. -- In the village of Clayton to-day Edgar Cecil Plant shot and killed his young wife, whom he married under compulsion less than three weeks ago; stabbed his infant child, and three hours later put a bullet through his own heart. He was twenty-two years old.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., May 4 -- Lehigh defeated Harvard at lacrosse here this afternoon by the score of 4 to 1. The game was very evenly contested in the first half, the score being 2 to 1 in favor of Lehigh. Not until ten minutes of play was the first goal secured for Lehigh by a pretty shot by Bartels. Ten minutes later one was secured for Harvard by Starr.
WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Major Daniel G. Caldwell, Surgeon, United States Army, has been placed on the retired list on account of disability incident to the service.

NEWARK, N.J., May 4 -- Lewis Frank of 9 Warren Street, this city, a collector for the W.C. Hartman Mercantile Agency or New-York, was arraigned before Judge Mott this morning on a charge preferred by Mary F. Riordan, a typewriter, of Harrison. She alleged that when she was sent to Lewis's house to do some work he attempted to kiss her.

The friends of the solid gold standard in Illinois have issued an appeal signed by FRANKLIN MACVEAGH. It is a clear, strong, simple statement which ought to settle the mind of any Democrats in that Statue that are yet in doubt. Mr. MACVEAGH says:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 4 -- The fight in the Methodist General Conference for and against the admission of women as delegates was fairly commenced, but not concluded, to-day. Much surprise was caused by the action of three of the women who have been seeking seats in the conference, who presented a communication, withdrawing their claims in the interest of harmony.
CINCINNATI, May 4. -- A five-story building on the east side of Walnut Street, just south of Fifth Street, collapsed at 7:45 o'clock to-night, and scores of persons were buried in its ruins.

The attention of Samuel Sloan, President of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, was called yesterday to the report in circulation in the Produce Exchange that flour in transit from the West was handled by the Lackawanna at cut rates. Mr. Sloan said: "There is no truth in the story.
ALBANY, May 4 -- State Controller Roberts had drawn up to-day the bonds required of the New-York, Brooklyn, and Buffalo banks designated as depositories of excise moneys.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 4 -- Justice William Haywood has decided that William Thompson, a New-York business man whom Town Marshal Philander H. Johnson charges with "disturbing the peace of the State and inciting the residents thereof to disorder and riot by the use of profane, indecent, and immoderate language on the public street of Rutherford," is not guilty.

Gold to the amount of $2,150,000 was withdrawn yesterday from the Sub-Treasury for shipment by the Spree to-day. Heidelbach, Ickelheimer Co. took $1,650,000. Its destination is supposed to be Russia, which has been absorbing gold steadily for a long time. The rest of the shipment is sent by Baring, Magoun Co. for Kidder, Peabody Co.

The Board of Charities is conducting a rigid investigation to ascertain, if possible, what has been done with the quantities of drugs and medical supplies that were sent to Blackwell's Island during the year 1895. The attention of the Commissioners. was drawn to the fact that unusual supplies were consumed at Blackwell's Island last year.

The understudies of the Giants followed the example of their stars yesterday and administered a defeat to the strong New-Haven team at the Polo Grounds. There was only a small crowd in attendance, but those present witnessed a good game of ball. From start to finish the game was lively, fielding sharp and clean, the base running spirited, and the batting on the part of the Metropolitans very strong.

MADRID, May 4. -- This city was the scene to-day of an imposing religious ceremony, the object of which was to procure the intercession of St. Isidro, the patron saint of Madrid, who lived in the thirteenth century, to bring about the end of the long drought that has done great damage throughout the country, and also to effect the suppression of the Cuban rebellion.

Mayor STRONG seems to be interesting himself in eliciting from the Manhattan Railway Company some kind of proposition for extending the elevated railroads or increasing their efficiency, while the officers of the company appear to be rather indifferent about it, or profess to be so.

The Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge yesterday decided to enlarge and refit their electric plant on Prospect Street, some distance below the Brooklyn entrance to the bridge, so that it will be capable of supplying the motive power to switch cars and, if necessary, to haul trains over the bridge.

The lover of music, in the air or otherwise, can scarcely regard as satisfactory the recent performances of the most eminent Republican soloists. The McKinley boom is, of course, no longer a solo, but a piece of ill-concerted music, with obligates for various unsatisfactory performers.
Controller Fitch opened bids yesterday for $14,039,502.84 in the gold, 3 1/2 per cent, bonds and stocks of the city.

An extensive change in the system of the American District Messenger Company was begun yesterday, when twenty messengers used bicycles in delivering messages. It is hoped that before long all the messengers will be provided with bicycles. When the company decided to use bicycles twenty hoys who were known to be good riders were picked out, and were told to be at the office at Fifty-eighth Street and Fifth Avenue early yesterday morning.

SEATTLE, Wash., May 4 -- The steamer Lakme, four weeks out, reached Seattle yesterday from Cook's Inlet, after a fine passage both ways. On board was Will A. Steel, Secretary of the Washington Press Association, who reports his observations as follows:

Young women in college caps and gowns were the prevailing feature of the thirty-third annual commencement exercises of the New-York Medical College and Hospital for Women, held at the Berkeley Lyceum last evening.

The spoilsmen who thought that they had, in their choice phrase, "downed" the reformers of the State of Maryland are in danger of finding themselves "hoist with their own petard " -- a result which we have the authority of Hamlet for thinking "rare sport" for the intended victims.

The Rev. Dr. C.H. Parkhurst is dissatisfied with the outcome of the trial of Cornelius B. Parker, who has been called "the Policy King." The case was tried last week before City Judge Rufus B. Cowing in the Court of General Sessions. The Judge discharged the jury, which stood ten to two for conviction after it had considered, a verdict for two hours.

There really dwelt in France, when Philippe le Bel was King, a very beautiful and morally reprehensible lady, whose name was Yolande Salliere. We know this, we who are not versed in old French lore, because Mr. Swinburne quotes a paragraph or so of picturesque old French to explain a poem of his, the least objectionable part of which is its title, "The Leper."
BOSTON, May 4. -- Mrs. Kate Stokes-Stetson, widow of John Stetson, late theatrical manager and millionaire, died to-day. Her husband died less than three weeks ago.

MONDAY -- P.M. While the market was very narrow today, its tone was firm. There is apparently no pressure to sell stocks, and those who have short contracts outstanding find it impossible to cover at a profit. The engagements of gold for shipment to-morrow amounted to $2,150,000, but the incident caused no uneasiness.

The Brooklyn Free Kindergarten Society, closed the most successful year of its existence last evening, when its annual meeting was held at Pratt Institute. President Frank L. Babbott acted as Chairman.
Columbia has followed the example of Harvard and Yale, and hereafter music will be one of its university studies.
The Kings County Democratic General Committee met in the Athenaeum, Atlantic and Clinton Streets,. Brooklyn, last night. James D. Bell presided.

Park Commissioner Woodruff of Brooklyn issued an order yesterday prohibiting the riding of bicycles on the main drive of the Ocean Parkway, along which runs the famous Coney Island cycle path. Although this appears to be contrary to the Liberty bill, which gives to bicycles the free use of the highways the same as other vehicles, yet there will probably be not the slightest objection from the wheelmen.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- This was one of Mr. Boutelle's days in the House. He broke into proceedings under suspension of the rules this afternoon to ask that the Senate amendments to the Naval Appropriation bill be non-concurred in, and a conference ordered, and be at once began a speech.
LONDON, May 4 -- Alfred William Hunt. M. A., R.W.S., died yesterday.

We now have proof, in the admissions of the nail manufacturers themselves, that the Nail Trust or Pool, while com- pelling all buyers of nails in this country to pay $2.55 per keg for wire nails and $2.30 per keg for cut nails in carload lots at the mills, sells nails to buyers in Germany and other foreign countries for $1 less per keg.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Commissioner of Patents John S. Seymour transmitted to Congress to-day a report of the operations of the Patent Office for the calendar year 1895. During the year there were 39,145 applications for patents, and 21,998 patents granted. The number of patents which ex- pired was 12,343.
The one hundredth anniversary of the birthday of Horace Mann, the educational reformer, was celebrated last night in the Normal College at Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street.

NEWARK, N.J., May 4 -- At the meeting of the Committee on Roads and Assessments of the Board of Freeholders this afternoon a petition for a trolley franchise was received from the North Jersey Street Railway Company. The petition asks permission to construct a double track surface railroad upon a part of Springfield Avenue.

LONDON, May 4 -- At the request of Mr. Labouchere, Mr. Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies, promised to lay upon the table of the House the Colonial Office records of communications which passed between Sir H.B. Loch (new Lord Loch of Drylaw) while he was Governor of the Cape Colony, and certain Englishmen in the Transvaal in regard to affording protection to the latter.

We ventured to suggest a few days ago that the newly discovered Mahatma -- known, however, only to the select and occult few -- was either the young Theosophist Secretary, CLAUDE FALLS WRIGHT, or the Philadelphia Thaumaturgist, JOHN E.W. KEELY, and referred to some circumstantial evidence which seemed to point to the renowned motor-maker in the City of Brotherly Love.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 8 -- The eighty-fourth annual commencement of the Princeton Theological Seminary, and the fiftieth anniversary of the appointment of Prof. William Henry Green, D.D., LL. D., as instructor in the seminary, took place to-day.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The most gratifying incident of the Senate proceedings to-day was the rebuke administered to the ill-mannered Peffer. The bewhiskered Kansan had been snubbed many times since he came to the Senate, but not until to-day was the fact forced home to his some- what dull comprehension that it does not pay to be rude to a fellow-Senator.

John Stewart and others, who claim to be entitled to a share in the A.T. Stewart property, brought a suit to recover the same. They began their proceedings just before the expiration of the twenty years following Mr. Stewart's death within which period such a suit is permitted. They have filed notices of list pendens against the Stewart property, including the old Metropolitan Hotel site.

The Senate's reduction of the battleships provided for in the House Navy bill from four to two is a surprise, and not an agreeable one, although it is true that we have now ready a much stronger force of fighting vessels than we had a year ago.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., May 5 -- The Sixth District Congressional Convention to-day renominated Congressman James McLachlan of Pasadena. Resolutions instructing the delegates to St. Louis to vote for McKinley and the free coinage of silver at the ratio of 16 to 1 were adopted.
HAVANA, May 5 -- Two rebel bauds attacked the town of Guanajay, but were repulsed with heavy loss.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- The local market is becoming broader, and to-day made considerable headway. At the opening the feature was the tractions, led by Philadelphia, which sold up to 72 1/2. Union touched 18 1/8, and the 4s advanced to 74 1/4. In the afternoon the feature was the specialties, under the leadership of Pennsylvania Heat stocks.

LONDON, May 5 -- Col. North, the "Nitrate King," died suddenly in the city to-day, in the offices of the Guano Syndicate. He was seized with an illness after eating oysters and died within half an hour. The shells of the oysters are to be analyzed, though the general supposition is that Col. North died from heart trouble.

AUBURN, N.Y., May 5 -- As the body of Mrs. Eva R. Sheldon, who was supposed to have committed suicide Thursday last, was being lowered into its last resting place at Brutus, the solemnity of the occasion was broken by a shriek from her daughter, who exclaimed, pointing to her father, Frank Sheldon:

The political associates of Mr. McKINLEY in Ohio desire above all things that the St. Louis Convention shall adopt a platform substantially in accord with that which was adopted by the Republican Convention in their State, and which was written for that convention by Mr. McKINLEY himself.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Mark Hanna, according to news from Cleveland, is now so certain that McKinley is to be nominated that he is considering who shall be allowed to become the candidate for Vice President. The assumption of McKinley men is that, as it will be desirable to enlist the Eastern local interest, an Eastern man will be allowed to take the second place.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 5. -- It is believed now that at least sixteen lives were lost last night in the explosion in the five-story brick building on Walnut Street. Six bodies have been taken from the ruins, and it is known that ten persons are missing.

President Roosevelt of the Police Departmeat and Controller Fitch had a wordy controversy at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in the Mayor's offce. There was talk of "pistols," and a threat by the Mayor that he would place both officials under arrest.

The Directors of the South Africa Company had no choice but to appear to request the resignation of CECIL RHODES. It is not to be supposed that there is any extensive indignation in Ministerial circles at the attempt to steal the Transvaal in defiance of treaties. The pre- vailing sentiment of the Conservative Party doubtless remains that which was expressed in the Laureate's fool-poem about JAMESON, and JAMESON is still the social lion of London.

ALBANY, May 5 -- Gov. Morton to-day signed the two bills of Senator Wilcox designed to carry out the provision of the new State Constitution abolishing contract labor in the prisons, penitentiaries, and reformatories of the State. This provision goes into effect on Jan. 1 next.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 5 -- Thomas O. Bullock, a wealthy resident of this place and a Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad commuter, brought suit for $30,000 damages against the above road in the Morris County Supreme Court to-day. Great interest is manifested in the case by the patrons of the road, as it will decide whether or not they can carry packages in the cars.

Exports of general merchandise from the port of New-York for the week were valued at $7,045,439, against $7,785,331 in the preceding week, and $7,328,506 the corresponding week of last year. Total since Jan. 1. $135,693,978, against $123,715,737 in the corresponding week of last year.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- There is much dissatisfaction in the Navy Department regarding the Senate proposition to provide for ten torpedo boats at a cost of $50,000 each. This sum, say the engineers and constructors, will not suffice to build an effi- cient torpedo boat. It will provide for a craft which has neither speed nor the offensive qualities necessary.

Fletcher Webster Jewell, who secured the signatures of 350 members of Congress to a petition for clemency for John Hays Hammond, the American sentenced to death for treason to the Transvaal Government, is in the city. Mr. Jewell is an American, but has lived in Johannesburg three years, and is a personal friend of Mr. Hammond.

Teresa Carney, a Bowery girl, who was twenty-six years old, and known at the New-York Rescue Band Mission in Doyers Street as "Tess," was killed Monday night on the tracks of the Manhattan Beach Railroad between Evergreen and Central Avenues, Brooklyn, by the last train that left Long Island City for Coney Island.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Frank H. Mason, United States Consul General at Frankfort-on-the-Main, has sent an interesting report to the State Department about the chances afforded for opening a market for American bicycles in Germany. American bicycles and machines of any sort for women were practically unknown in the German Empire until last Summer, when a large number of American cyclists, male and female, made tours through picturesque localities in the Fatherland.

NEW-ROCHELLE, May 5 -- The first meeting of the new Board of Village Trustees was held last evening. The board divided itself evenly in two factions. The five Republican members supported the appointments made by the President and the five Democratic members voted against the President's appointments. President Clarke named Clarence S. Haskell for Superintendent of Public Works.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- The litigations surrounding the foreclosure proceedings of the Lake Street Elevated Road in the State Court was taken up for hearing to-day by Judge Payne. This is the bill filed by the Lake Street Company to restrain the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company of New-York from foreclosing the bonds of the road held by it as trustee.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., May 5 -- This city to-night began the celebration of the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of its founding by John Winthrop the younger, it the armory on Washington and Colt Streets, where literary exercises were held, the largest audience ever in the building assembling to listen to the speeches of well-known orators and the music of the voices of 400 schoolgirls, led by the Third Regiment Band, N.G. Conn.

Sir HERCULES ROBINSON speaks of JAMESON'S raid as coming upon him "like a thunderbolt from a clear sky." We have a haunting recollection of having heard, or seen, that phrase before, but it's a good phrase for all that, and the ancients shouldn't be allowed to monopolize all the good phrases simply because they had the first chance to invent them.
TIFFIN, Ohio, May 5 -- A broken rail on the Baltimore and Ohio Road at New-Haven caused a freight wreck last night, fatally injuring two persons, and seriously wounding a number of others.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 5 -- The Methodist General Conference to-day occupied most of its time in considering the admission of women as delegates, without reaching a decision, on the subject.

The death of Mrs. John Stetson, formerly Miss Kate Stokes, the circus rider and actress, may result in other complications as to the disposal of the late theatrical manager's property, in addition to those caused by failure to find a will.

Seventy-one young men were graduated from the medical department of New-York University last night, at Carnegie Music Hall. Not only were these young physicians there themselves, but their friends turned out in such numbers as to fill the floor, both tiers of boxes, and even the two upper galleries.

Two women and two children who lived at Bushwick and Johnson Avenues, Brooklyn, lost their lives yesterday morning in a fire which was caused by one of the women igniting the gas in a gas stove, over which she had ignorantly thrown a quantity of kerosene oil. Two other children were injured and may die.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Germania Bank was held yesterday afternoon. The election resulted in the continuation of the officers and Directors in their respective positions, some of whom have been with the bank since it was established -- in May, 1869.

BOSTON, May 5 -- Activity in to-day's market has been confined to Montana and the specialties. Montana fluctuated between 75 7/8 and 76 3/8, and closed at 76. West End was also active, gaining 2 1/4 points, to 73 1/4, closing at 73. Bay State Gas opened higher at 17, but dropped shortly afterward to 15 1/2, at which price it closed. The first 5s dropped 1, but recovered 1/2 and closed at 87.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- There are several hundred private pension bills on the House calendar, and the men who introduced them are anxious that they shall be passed. Most of these bills are for the benefit of persons who have tried to get pensions through the Pension Bureau but who have succeeded in convincing that bureau that they are not entitled to receive pensions.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Unless the House shall back down from the position it has taken to-day, the navy will be increased by four battleships, as the House decided when it passed the naval bill.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 5 -- After a great deal of correspondence the Imperial and Canadian Governments have agreed upon the details of a fast Atlantic service. Four vessels are requisite to give a weekly service from both sides of the Atlantic. It has been decided to require a speed of 20 knots an hour from port to port -- that is, an average for the whole trip of not less than 20 knots.

Although absorbing interest in the coming Presidential campaign has been confined mainly to active party workers, some of the manifestations in the political field are engaging the attention of voters who apply intelligent consideration to public questions and who will be guided in their action next Fall by evidences of sincere regard on the part of conventions and candidates for the common welfare rather than for ties of partisanship.

Delmonico's banquet hall was bright with flowers and pretty gowns last evening, when the alumnae of the Woman's Law Class of New-York University met to enjoy their third annual banquet. Lilacs, orchids, carnations, and white roses covered fifteen little round tables in the banqueting hall and the long table that ran across the room.
HIGHLAND LIGHT, Mass., May 5 -- A large steamer has been discovered ashore on Peaked Hill bars.

It has become known to several of the Tammany politicians that District Attorney John R. Fellows is anxious to go back to Congress. It was learned yesterday by a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES, that if Col. Fellows can manage it he will he nominated for Congress in the Fourteenth District by Tammany.

An important chapter was added yesterday to the long history of the effort to secure final disposition of garbage and general refuse by some other method than by dumping at sea. When the Board of Estimate and Apportionment met, Commissioner Waring of the Street Cleaning Department made his report on the bids recently received.
ROME, N.Y., May 5 -- The State to-day rested its case in the trial of young Hildreth for train wrecking. It is expected the case will go to the jury Saturday.

TUESDAY -- P.M. Excessive dullness was once more the feature of the stock market. London did practically nothing and commission business was extremely light. Tobacco and Leather preferred were the only stocks in which the trading exceeded 10,000 shares. The traders generally talked "bearish," hut they failed to show the courage of their convictions.

BUFFALO, May 5 -- District Attorney Kenefick finished summing up for the people in the Sammon murder trial at 4 o'clock this afternoon, and after recess Judge Woodward charged the jury briefly, the case going to them at 5:45 P.M.
The National Electrical Exposition in the Industrial Building was well attended yesterday, both by electrical men and the general public.

Allegheny, Penn., may now be added to the list of American cities which have undertaken to purify their milk supplies by preventing the sale to their inhabitants of milk taken from tuberculous dairy herds. The other towns are Minneapolis, Minn.; Pittsfleld and Lynn, Mass.; Malone, N.Y., and Alameda, Cal.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- In the hearing on the Nicaragua Canal before the House Commerce Committtee to-day ex-Senator Warner Miller submitted documentary evidence to confirm his statements regarding the offer of Mr. Treat of Chicago to build the canal, and the estimate of Engineer Donaldson of London as to the feasibility and cost of the project, which had been called in question by Col. Ludlow.

Another brilliant assemblage patronized the Brooklyn Horse Show last night. The feature of the second evening's programme was the class for harness horses driven by ladies. Eleven of the fourteen entries competed, the finely appointed rigs with their fair drivers making a most pleasing spectacle. After a long and careful examination the Judges rendered a popular decision by sending the blue badge to Chester, driven by Miss C. Adelaide Doremus.

Differences long Continued in the Board of Fire Commissioners have apparently exhausted Mayor Strong's patience. It was reported yesterday that he had determined to ask for the resignation of President La Grange and Commissioner Ford.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- Both New-York Biscuit and Diamond Match opened strong, but failed to hold. Biscuit opened at 108 and closed at 104 1/2, the lowest point of the day. Diamond Match opened at 246 and closed at 242 1/2. The cables both showed strength. Bank clearings were $20,082861. Money loaned at 6@7 per cent, on time and 7 per cent, on call.

SYNOPSIS. At the time when Philip II. of Spain was tightening his grip on the Netherlands, about 300 years ago, a rebellion of the Prince of Orange's partisans was imminent in Brussels. Feria Manrique, a veteran of Philip's army living in retirement in Brussels, is summoned to the presence of the Spanish Countess de Mirando by Count Mena de Velasco, a Chamberlain of the Regent Duchess.

William H. Maxwell, Superintendent of Public Instruction in Brooklyn, in his annual report, which was issued yesterday, said of the Ainsworth law, which requires public school children to be taught the evil effects of alcoholic liquors and narcotics:

SAN FRANCISCO, May 6. -- The match race, at four and a half furlongs, betweeen the two-year-olds, Orestes, by imported Ormonde, and San Mateo, by Salvator, for $1,000 a side, with $1,000 added by the association, was the feature of to-day's card. San Mateo, as usual, got away very well and opened up a gap of several lengths befores Orestes began moving up to his form.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Senator Frye to- day afforded the public an opportunity to know something about how the River and Harbor bill is made up.

CONSTANTINOPLE, May 6 -- Serious disturbances have taken place at Akshehr, between the Kurds and Armenians who are connected with the work of constructing the railway between Akshehr arid Konieh, in Asia Minor, but no details of the rioting have yet been received here.

SYNOPSIS. At the time when Philip II, of Spain was tightening his grip on the Netherlands, 300 years ago, a rebellion of the Prince of Orange's party was imminent in Brussels. Feria Manrique, a veteran of Philip's army living in retirement in Brussels, is summoned to the presence of the Spanish Countess de Mirando by Count Mena de Velasco, a chamberlain on the Regent Duchess.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., May 6. -- The California Republican Convention to-day declared for free silver coinage, and, singularly enough, sent the son of President Grant to St. Louis to advocate that doctrine. The convention also instructed its delegates to support Major McKinley for President. He is entirely satisfactory to the 16 to 1 people.

BOSTON, May 6 -- The market for local stocks was more generally active to-day than for a long time, and, on the whole, the tone was strong. The copper shares, particularly the Bigelow group, were active. Montana sold up 1 1/2, to 77 1/2, then fluctuated between that and 76 1/4, and finally closed at 77 5/8. Old Dominion gained 1, to 17, and Quincy scrip was up 1/2, to 78, receding later to 771/2.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Committee on Ways and Means, through Mr. Dingley, (Rep., Me.,) reported to the House to-day a concurrent resolution providing for the adjournment of Congress May 18. The read- ing of the resolution was greeted with applause. Mr. Dingley asked immediate consideration of the resolution.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- New-York Biscuit opened at 101 1/2, 3 points lower than the close yesterday, and sold rapidly down to 98. It recovered later to 108 3/4, but sagged off to 102 at the close. Diamond Match opened at 240, and sold off to 234, recovered to 240 1/4, and closed at 239 1/2. The balance of the market, though dull, was strong.

A sea cow is the latest addition to the Central Park menagerie. She is said to be the only one in captivity. Her proper name is "manatee," though George Washington Harle, who captured her at the mouth of the St. Lucia River, Fla., calls her by the given name of "Betsy." One of the same species captured in Africa was domiciled in the Park twenty years ago, but died after four years' confinement.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- An editorial article in a local Democratic paper is to the effect that the real purpose of the meeting here Friday of the sub-committee of the Democratic National Committee is to determine whether or not the National Convention shall be held in Chicago.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 -- The local market was active in spots. Closing prices were slightly lower. In the tractions, Philadelphia lost 1/4, to 72 1/8, and Metropolitan, 3/4, to 108, while Union 4s gained 1/2 to 74 3/4. The feature of the specialties was Pennsylvania Heat. The common in the early session declined to 14 5/8, and later rallied to 15 1/2, closing at 15.

Mayor Strong listened yesterday to the arguments of numerous Broadway merchants against the Austin Rapid Transit bill to build an underground road along Broadway. When Alexander E. Orr of the Rapid Transit Commission had replied at some length, and the engineer, Mr. Parsons, had also been heard in favor of the plan, the Mayor said:

"If the Mayor," said Gen. O.H. La Grange yesterday, "is disturbed about this thrashing of old straw of my career as Superintendent of the Mint at San Francisco, let him turn to letters on file in his office from D.O. Mills, John W. Mackay, C.P. Huntington, and James R. Keene.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 6. -- On the eve of the State Convention the question of whether or not the delegates at large shall be instructed for McKinley is somewhat in doubt, largely because it seems to be a matter of indifference with the delegates. Left to themselves, they probably would instruct, and Chairman Gowdy of the State Committee, is doing what he can to have the instructions put through.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Seventy-two private pension bills were acted upon in the House to-day in Committee of the Whole, and Mr. Pickler, the Chairman of the Invalid Pensions Committee, appealed to the House to "make a night of it," but did not succeed, even with a speech full of pumpedup patriotism, including a reference to the aniversary of the battle of the Wilderness.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Baron Clemens von Ketteler, who has been promoted from the post of Secretary of the German Embassy to be Minister to Mexico, entered the diplomatic service in 1879, resigning his commission in the army for that purpose. He was first attached to the Foreign Office at Berlin, and a year later was sent to Pekin as attache.

ALBANY, May 6 -- The visit of Mayor Wurster of Brooklyn to Gov. Morton to-day is looked upon with suspicion in view of the rumors from Brooklyn that certain of the delegates to the St. Louis Convention are inclined to declare themselves favorable to McKinley on the first ballot.

ALBANY, May 6 -- The prompt signing of the Greater New-York bill was one of the requests made of Gov. Morton to-day. The Governor said the question would receive his early consideration. He added that the anti-consolidationists had until Friday of this week to file briefs against the measure, which would preclude action by him this week.

BRUSSELS, May 6 -- Aubrey Beardsley, the English artist, is in this city suffering from a pulmonary complaint, which his physicians fear may terminate fatally. Friends are constanly watching at his bedside.

Two young women were graduated with appropriate exercises from the St. Mark's Hospital Training School for Nurses last evening. They are Miss Anna E. Hartman and Miss Helen M. Brennan. Miss Hartman is to become head nurse in a Staten Island hospital, and Miss Brennan will go to Montreal, Canada.
Aunt Thankfull bobbed a courtesy. The fiddler touched his hat.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Peffer mudslinging bond resolutions, shorn of their stupid insinuations against the Secretary of the Treasury, will be adopted by the Senate to-morrow and go to the Committee on Finance, which will conduct the proposed investigation.

Having proved that electricity can cook, play the piano, pump an organ, and tow a canalboat, the management of the show in the Industrial Building in Lexington Avenue produced a man yesterday who has set out to make artificial daylight. He thinks he has advanced far enough in that line to talk publicly of it and exhibit what he has done.
WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Treasury officials are gratified at the rise in freight rates on gold export shipments and think it will have the effect of preventing, at this time, large gold exports.

In the easiest possible manner the Princeton College team won from the nine of Manhattan College on the latter's ground yesterday. There was a large crowd of the followers of both colleges in attendance, and every play was warmly applauded. Easton pitched for the Tigers for six innings, and during that period the local players failed to send a man around the bases.

CHICAGO, May 6. -- Homer A. Judd, President, and John B. Watkins, Vice President, of the Indian Rice Milling Company, have just been indicted by the Federal Grand Jury at Kansas City for violation of the tenth section of the Inter-State Commerce law, which applies to the reporting of false weight by shippers.

The Citizens' Committee on Public School Reform has very wisely decided that its task is not completed by the passage of the bill doing away with the Trustee system and putting full responsibility upon the Board of Education, and has resolved to continue in existence to watch the execution of the law.

The guarantee companies which have established agencies in close proximity to the office of the Deputy State Commissioner of Excise for the purpose of furnishing bonds for liquor dealers and saloon keepers who apply for the liquor tax certificates are astonished and grieved at the success which has flowed in upon the Fidelity and Deposit Company of Maryland, of which H.B. Platt, a son of "Boss" Platt, is the manager.

"I am a Democrat. I never voted for a Republican for President, but the candidate of that party will have my vote in November if he is strong for gold and stands on a strong platform, and if the Democratic Party is weak in either respect. This is the feeling among business men generally.

Lucien O. Appleby and some of his friends gave the pencilers at the Aqueduct track yesterday a lively turning over in the second race. It was decidedly the sensation of a very pretty afternoon's sport, and there were the wildest sorts of rumors floating about as to the sum that Mr. Appleby took out of the strong boxes of his former associates of the bookmaking fraternity.

Judge COWING'S answer to the criticisms of Dr. PARKHURST upon his judicial conduct will be accepted by most fair-minded men, we think, as entirely conclusive. Dr. PARKHURST was moved by zeal as a reformer, added to something of the partisanship of a prosecutor, to chagrin and resentment by what he regarded as the escape from justice of a guilty man.

At the meeting of the Board of Education yesterday a special committee of five was appointed to prepare new by-laws, rules, and regulations, in conformity with the new school law. The committee is composed of Messrs. Beneville, Hubbell, Prentiss, Peaslee, and Ketchum.
"The Disposal of the Waste of Great Cities" was the subject considered by the Section on Public Health of the New-York Academy of Medicine last night.

Judging from the strong work of Standish, who pitched for the Metropolitans yesterday, it is only a question of time before he will be seen in a New-York uniform. He kept the New-Havens down to four scattering hits in the game on the Polo Grounds yesterday, and his team won easily. The Mets hit the ball hard, and fielded in excellent style.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 6 -- The University of Pennsylvania defeated Cornell here to-day in the first of the five championship games, by a score of 10 to 9. Cornell was outfielded and outbatted in every inning except the ninth, when a repitition of the uphill work against the Tigers was , attempted, but Pennsy's fielding was too sharp. Young was bit less frequently than Wunder, but had poorer support.
The New-York Commandery of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States, 300 strong, held its annual meeting and banquet at Delmonico's last night. The following officers were elected:
FORT MONROE, Va., May 6. -- The flagship New-York and the cruiser Raleigh sailed from this harbor for Tompkinsville at 1 P.M. to-day.

Patriotism, not politics; no man in the United States will be more deeply and heartily rejoiced at the reform "round-up" made yesterday by President CLEVELAND than THEODORE ROOSEVELT.
