Senator Lee Manila of Montana, the colleague of Chairman of the Republican National Committee Carter, and the head of the delegation from his State to the National Convention at St. Louis, was at the Brunswick Hotel yesterday

From The London Chronicle. Prof. Dewar's lecture at the Royal Institution was a rapid survey of the galloping pace at which chemical discovery of value in the arts has lately proceeded. It was a complete justification of Mr. Ludwig Mond's dictum that chemical research spells commercial success.

From The Boston Herald, May 15. With the arrest of William H. Daley and William T. Reid, both of Cambridge, the mystery of the long chain of fires with which Cambridge, Somerville, and Brighton have been afflicted during a period of seven months is brought to an end.

PITTSBURG, May 16. -- The stock market relapsed into comparative dullness during the past week. It is reported that the subscriptions to the common and preferred stock of the Consolidated Traction, which was privately offered to leading capitalists, were largely in excess of the amount it is desired to sell at this time, and that the original subscriptions were scaled down between 20 and 30 per cent.

4Foreign exchange was dull and easier. The posted rates for sterling on Saturday were $4.SS for sixty-day bills and $4.89 1/2 for demand. Actual business was done on Saturday at $4.87 1/2 @$4.87 3/4 for sixty-day bills. $4.88 1/2@$4.88 3/4 for demand, $4.88 3/4@$4.89 for cable transfers, and $4.86 3/4 for commercial.

NEW-HAVEN, May 17. -- Arrangements are now in process of completion for the construction of another handsome dormitory building for Yale University. The new building is to be erected by members of Berzelius, a popular and prosperous Sheffield Scientific School society, and the necessary funds have already been raised.

Coney Island opened her arms wide yesterday and received as many visitors as the trains and trolleys could well carry down there. She did her best to entertain them, too, and, Judging by the number of people who went there and the late hour they staid, she succeeded very well.

The body of Col. John A. Cockerill lay in state all day yesterday in the clubhouse of the New-York Press Club, at 34 West Twenty-sixth Street, and many newspaper men and men of other professions who were friends of the dead man went there during the day and evening to pay a tribute of respect to his memory.

Four Regiments of the National Guard -- the Seventy-first, the Twelfth, the Eighth, and the Forty-seventh of Brooklyn-attended church yesterday, while the Naval Cadets of this port held an out-door service in Madison Square.
ATLANTA, Ga., May 17. -- The Markham House was destroyed by fire to-night, causing a loss of $300,000.

Robert Louis Stevenson's "Picturesque Notes" on Edinburgh, (Macmillan,) as illustrated by T. Hamilton Crawford, make an extremely attractive volume. The illustrations are of a superior order, the paper is fine, the type large, the binding rich and pleasing, and then who could write of Edinburgh with better knowledge, a surer pen, or a saner spirit?

From Temple Bar. The beasts had each two panniers of straw slung across a pack saddle. We crammed these with the scented bales, and then built up others above them, and topped up with a vast and evil-smelling sheepskin. Then we made all fast with ropes done into a "diamond hitch," which British Columbia thinks is an invention of its own.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The public credit is feeling keenly the effects of McKinley's suspicious silence on the financial issue, and is likely to feel it more during the next month, unless some sort of declaration for the gold standard can be worried out of him.

From The London Channels We have received from an authoritative source the exact circumstances connencted with Harem Hirsch's death. We translate it from the French, and our readers may take it that it is an authentic account of the facts. The story entirely contradicts the rumors of suicide.

A large, three-quarter length photograph of Major William McKinley of Ohio ornaments the corridor of the Brooklyn Union League Club, In Grant Square, and attracts the attention of the clubmen as they enter. The Major is attired in the conventional frock coat, and stands in a Napoleonic attitude, with his left hand thrust in his bosom, as Lf tucking away another delegation, and his features bear a look of gratification.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 17. -- A moderate-sized crowd braved the cold wind and gathered at Central Park yesterday afternoon, to shiver and hiss, while a number of bicycle riders gave a poor exhibition of racing, under the auspices of the San Francisco Cycle Racing Association. The racers were not restricted by time limits, and loafed as they pleased.

ROME, May 17. -- Great damage to growing crops and other vegetation has been done by hailstorms, which prevailed to-day in several places in Italy. A severe thunderstorm passed over Parma, and four persons were killed and five injured by lightning.

The action of the United States Senate upon the case of DU PONT of Delaware affords a curious instance of the way in which important precedents are established or maintained. The Senate has always been conservative in deciding contests for seats in its chamber, and has generally insisted upon a title about which there could be no serious doubt.

Our dispatches of yesterday from Milwaukee reported the shipment from the mills of the Illinois Steel Company in that city of 500 tons of steel rails to Japan, and it was noted that the same company had already "shipped several other consignments of rails" to that country.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 17. -- The Washington Reform Club will forward to the Department of Justice at Washington, tomorrow charges against Judge Augustus J. Ricks of the United States Court, in this city.

BREWSTER, Mass., May 17. -- Miss Saldie Hazard was shot and killed by Frederick Alexander this noon. While the Rev. Mr. Dawes of the Unitarian Church was making the opening prayer in the morning services, the congregation heard pistol shots and shrieks on the street. When the people reached the street the body of the victim was lying on the sidewalk, a few hundred yards away from the church.

From The Murray (Idaho) Sun. Charley Elsenstein, the young rancher on the North Fork, at the mouth of Beaver Creek, is deservedly the hero of the Coeur d'Alene to-day, for he has killed the biggest of the bruin family in those parts. For several years it was known around Delta that some wild animal was killing sheep and carrying them off Calves were also missed.
The Royal Academy of Arts celebrated on May 2 the bicentenary of its foundation in 1696 by Frederick Ill., Elector of Brandenburg, afterward Frederick I. of Prussia.

LONDON, May 17. -- The rate at discount during the past "Week for both three months' and thirty-day bills was 1 per cent. The drain in the money market in connection with the Chinese loan has now ceased. The market is depleted. The accumulation of money belonging to Japan which is now in the Bank of England amounts to u15,000,000.

Benjamin Stone, a young cabinet maker, living at 53 Rivington Street, committed suicide at 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning by jumping from the roof of the five-story tenement house 190 Alien Street, in front of an approaching train on the elevated railroad beneath. The train passed by him, merely grazing his left arm, but his skull had been fractured by striking the beams of the elevated structure.

At the conclusion of Claude Falls Wright's lecture before the Theosophical Society, in Chickering Hall, yesterday morning, Ernest T. Hargrove, President of the society, made formal announcement that Mrs. Katherine Alice Tingley is the erstwhile mysterious adept who has succeeded to the esoteric office formerly occupied by Mme. Blavatsky and William Q. Judge.

SENECA, Kan., May 17. -- A terrible cyclone struck this city this evening at 6:40 P.M. The cyclone was followed by a heavy hailstorm, hail as large as walnuts falling. About seventy houses were totally wreeked. Five persons were killed. The dead are two of M.R. Connell's children, one of Peter Assenmacher's children, one of M.E. Voorhees's children, and another whose name has not been learned. Many are badly hurt.

From The London Times. That the death of its founder, Baron Hirsch, should have been felt with especial acuteness by the Jewish Colonization Association will be readily understood by those acquainted with the work that association has been carrying on in the way of finding new homes and lucrative employment, mainly in Argentina, for victims of Jewish persecution in Russia.

CINCINNATI, May 17. -- The worst game seen here for some weeks was that between Brooklyn and the Reds this afternoon. After the visitors had scored 9 runs in their half of the first inning, the locals won in a walk.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- The competition for the decoration of the Common Council Room of the new City Hail of this city is attracting, as it deserves, unusual attention and much newspaper comment.
A swindler who is clever enough to have imposed on many lawyers, and who was exposed in THE NEW-YORK TIMES a year ago, has been caught in this city, and his case will be acted on by the Grand Jury.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

Although the gold standard resolution adopted by Mr. PLATT'S Republican State Committee on Saturday is in its language a malicious parody on the double standard plank which McKINLEY put into the Ohio platform, it faithfully reflects the opinion of the Republicans of this State -- and of the Democrats as well. It declares:

Earnest Democrats who are anxious to see their party properly represented at the Chicago Convention agree with the suggestion made in an editorial article in THE NEW-YORK TIMES last Saturday that it is imperative to send delegates to Chicago who are equipped to labor there day and night in the interest of sound money.

Mr. Platt held no session of his Sunday school class at its customary meelng place, in the Fifth Avenue Hotel, yesterday. He was not there. It was said he had gone to Washington Saturday night, and would have a talk with Senator Quay.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 17. -- A letter from Secretary of the Treasury Carlisle to John H. Johns of Prestonburg, Ky., was published this morning, in which the Secretary refers to the allegation that he on one occasion made a speech in favor of the free coinage of silver. In the course of his letter, Mr. Carlisle says:

In the Church of the Divine Paternity the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Baton yesterday delivered a sermon on "The Forward Movement," taking his text from Exodus, xiv., 15: "Go forward." In his sermon Dr. Eaton referred to the sale of the church in which the service was being held, as in line with the forward movement, and the law of progress in the intellectual and spiritual world, as well as in the world of affairs.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- In a communication from the British Board of Agriculture just received by Acting Secretary of Agriculture Dabney a report is made of samples of imported butter analyzed under the direction of the board from May, 1895, to Febuary, 1896, inclusive The total number of samples so analyzed was 995, representing the products of 12 different countries.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- A block of buildings oppsite the Smitasonian Institution was borned this evening. At least one fireman was killed outright, and three others received injuries that will cause their deaths. The property loss is $200,000.

BOSTON, May 18. -- Russell and McKinley are Harvard's choices for President as shown by the mock National Convention held this evening at the Fogg Art Museum, Cambridge. Nearly every State in the Union was represented, each having a delegation equal to one-half the number of members it sends to the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The American Protective Association Supreme Council closed its sessions to-day, but few delegates remaining to the adjournment. The most important action was that of discontinuing the Advisory Board, which was accomplished after a long discussion, in which it was specifically stated that the recent developments in the McKinley boycott had nothing to do with the action, and no reflection upon Judge Stevens, the Chairman, was intended.

Probably the whole world does not contain another body of men who learn so little by experience and have leas of the business sagacity and enterprise which are the only qualities they boast of, than the New-York theatre managers. For ten days the weather has been as hot as it usually is in midsummer; the skies have been clear, and every night thousands of people have yearned for the opening of the roof gardens.

The new school law required the Board of Education, prior to the 1st of May, to divide the city into not less than fifteen inspection, districts, and made it the duty of the Mayor on the third Wednesday of May to appoint five Inspectors in each district. The Board of Education established no less than thirty-five of these districts, and to-morrow Mayor STRONG will have 175 Inspectors to appoint.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The Fortifications bill was reported to the Senate this afternoon by Mr. Perkins. The estimates for 1897 amounted to $8,045,165. The House bill carried $5,845,837, to which the Senate added $4,918,051, making the total reported to the Senate $10,763,888. The appropriation for the current fiscal year is only $1,904,557.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Through the Rev. Dr. Stafford of St. Patrick's Church, this city, a prominent Republican, who held a foreign mission under President Harrison, addressed several questions to Cardinal Gibbons relative to the recent denials of religious liberty and attacks of the American Protective Association on the Catholic citizens of the country.

BERLIN, May 18. -- In the Reichstag to-day Dr. Lieber, the leader of the Centrist Party, asked the Government when the bill to reform the law governing military trials would be placed upon the table of the Reichstag.
Four fires within a month have convinced the dwellers in the tenement house at 223 Stanton Street that some incendiary has been endeavoring to burn down the house.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- The much-spoken-of century run from Newark to this city, to be held under the auspices of the Quaker City Wheelmen, is now but two weeks off. The fact of the run being taken on Memorial Day will give a number of riders an opportunity of participating who could not otherwise do so.

The virtues for which WILLIAM McKINLEY is chiefly commended by his admirers rise about to the level of the weaknesses for which the opinion of men condemns DANIEL WEBSTER. The Major is silent upon the main question in American politics, and his friends bid him not to speak, though he is much importuned.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

Man, as the poet has observed, never is, but always to be, blest. He is a difficult animal to satisfy. Here are some tens, if not hundreds, of thousands of American citizens demanding that Mr. McKINLEY shall speak up and tell them whether he is in favor of a dollar dollar or a half-dollar dollar.

WEYLER'S order prohibiting the exportation of tobacco from Cuba is plausibly supposed to be meant as a measure of retaliation upon the exiled Cubans, in Florida and elsewhere, who get their livings by making the exported leaf into cigars. Being Cubans, they sympathize with their countrymen and apparently devote a large part of their savings to fitting out expeditions for the benefit of the insurgents.
NIAGARA FALLS, May 18. -- William Shults of this city is under arrest charged with attempting to kill a boy by deliberately throwing him into the river from a pier on which he was sitting.
FALLS CITY, Neb., May 18. -- The "fag end" of the Kansas cyclone of Sunday night invaded Southeastern Nebraska and did a good deal of damage.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for Henry F. Cook to George F. Johnson the five four-story American basement limestone-front dwellings 25 to 33 West Sixty-ninth Street, 300 feet west of Central Park West.

The President of the Theosophical Society announced publicly, on Sunday last, the name of the Society's new Mahatma or Occult Director, which it had been the intention of the Society to conceal for one year from all persons except the fourteen members of the Inner Circle. The premature disclosure was due, it appears, to the "Great Unknown's" indiscreet admission to her "hired girl" that she was indeed the extraordinary personage in question.

The Sovereign, M.C.D. Borden's new steam yacht, was successfully launched from J.M. Robbins Co.'s yard, in the Erie Basin, yesterday. The yacht slid into the water at 12:15, while 2,000 spectators on the docks cheered and all the whistles on the yachts and steamers in the basin tooted a salute to the largest American-built yacht afloat.

With a fresh supply of 200 talesmen, the lawyers in the trial of Mary Alice Almont Livingston Fleming, charged with poisoning her mother, Mrs. Evelina M. Bliss, on Aug. 30, 1895, began yesterday their second week's effort to fill the jury box. There were four vacant chairs, last week's work having yielded eight jurymen.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., May 18. -- Two forest fires swept down on the little village of Waretown to-day and for hours threatened to wipe it out of existence. The 250 men, women, and children of the town turned out to fight the flames, assistance from other places was sent, and the place was saved.
CITY ISLAND, May 18. -- Passed East -- Steam yacht Doctor, T.C. Lyman.

There were three funeral services yesterday over the body of Col. John A. Cockerill, who died April 10 at Cairo, Egypt. The first service was the ritual of the Order of Elks at Scottish Rite Hall. At Calvary Baptist Church the Rev. Robert S. MacArthur read the service of the dead and made an address, and afterward Republic Lodge, No. 690, F. and A.M., officiated at the impressive Masonic ceremony.

Charles W. Dabney, Jr., Acting Secretary of the Department of Agriculture in Washington, has issued a general order to Inspectors to keep a watchful eye on the manner in which railroad companies transport and handle live stock. Mr. Dabney says, in substance:

WASHINGTON. May 18. -- The resolution for the appointment of a select committee to investigate last year's election in the State of Alabama and to report whether a republican form of government exists in that State came up to-day in the Senate, Mr. Alien (Pop., Neb.,) making a motion that the Senate proceed to its consideration.

MOSCOW, May 18. -- Distinguished persons from all parts of the world are arriving here hourly to witness the ceremonies attending the coronation of the Czar. Li Hung Chang, the representative of the Emperor of China, with a large and brilliant suite, arrived here to-day and was received at the station with great enthusiasm.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18.-- The opening was strong, but traders took advantage of the strength to realize, and a reaction followed. Changes in the traction group were fractional. Hestonville advanced a point, to 54. In the industrials Pennsylvania Heat scored a net loss of 3/4. The common closed unchanged. Welsbach sold down to 52, and United Gas Improvement to 70 1/4.

The wind blew at the rate of fifty-two miles an hour between 2:20 and 2:25 yesterday afternoon in this city. It came from the west, and, passing over the dusty roads of near-by sections of New-Jersey, caught up a huge cloud of pulverized earth and brought it across the North River.
BERLIN, May 18. -- Herr Otto Camphausen, from 1869 to 1873 Prussian Minister of Finance, died in this city last night.

More than $1,400 was received last night for the New-York Herald Free Ice Fund at Palmer's Theatre, where Herrmann closed his season with an entertainment for that charity. The programme was long, varied, and sprightly, but the drawing number on it was the bullet-catching trick, Herrmann's latest mystifying device. He reserved it for the end of the programme.

NEWARK, May 18. -- The Ironbound District of this city, one of the toughest in the town, came very near to being the scene of a lynching to-night. Had a policeman not reached the intended victim of the mob just as a man with a clothesline did, the courts might have been saved a case. Even after the policeman arrived and secured the man there were attempts to get the prisoner.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 18. -- The tornado which swept through Northeastern Kansas and a portion of Southeastern Nebraska yesterday afternoon and last night caused at least eighteen deaths and the Injury of scores of persons, and did many thousand dollars' damage in various towns through which it passed, besides incalculable damage in the intervening country.

LYNN, Mass., May 18. -- The residence portion of the town of Nahant was this afternoon the scene of a fire which destroyed five valuable Summer residences, causing a property loss approximating $100,000.

A meeting of the New-York Presbytery was held in the Thirteenth Street Presbyterian Church last night for the purpose of licensing four candidates for the ministry. Of the four two applied for immediate ordination. The Rev. Dr. James Chambers, the Moderator, presided, and the Rev. Dr. Birch acted as Clerk.

Those who were disposed to favor the Raines liquor law because they thought it would be more effective in preventing Sunday liquor selling than the old excise law must be somewhat concerned to observe the multiplication of devices of evasion under it. It looks as though it were the intent of its framers that evasion should be easy, but whether that was so or not, the temptation to evasion was increased.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- In some way unaccounted for, benzine which had been sprinkled upon the carpets and furniture in the three-story dwelling house at 2013 North Twelfth Street exploded this evening, badly wrecking the house and setting it on fire; so severely burning Miss Rosa Griggs, aged twenty-one years, that she died, and badly burning Mrs. S.R. Bentley and her daughter.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The most Interesting and comprehensive publication issued from the Navy Department in a long time is that map of the arctic regions published by the Naval Hydrographic Office. The chart is in two sections and represents the latest surveys and explorations within the arctic circle.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., May 18. -- Forest fires in the vicinity of Davis have been raging more than fifty hours, and now more furiously than ever, despite the efforts of hundreds of men to subdue them. The losses to lumber interests exceed $500,000.

CORTLAND, N.Y., May 18. -- A week from Wednesday the Cortland Athletic Association will give its third annual bicycle tournament, and a great meet is anticipated. Eight events, all for amateurs, have been scheduled, and a number of fliers from the metropolitan district are expected to take part. The prize list is particularly attractive and in a measure accounts for the large list of entries already recorded.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Extraordinary secrecy was observed by Mr. Quay about the brief visit of Mr. Platt to Washington, and Mr. Quay did not admit that Mr. Platt was here until he learned that the two "bosses" were seen riding out into the country Sunday morning.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The Supreme Court of the United States held an extra session to-day for the purpose of hearing argument in the matter of the Horsa Cuban expedition growing out of the conviction of J.H.S. Wiborg, Jens P. Petersen, and Hans Johansen, citizens of Denmark, in the District Court of the United States for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, for a violation of the neutrality laws of the United States.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 18. -- Baptist delegates have been arriving from, different parts of the country all day long, but the principal delegations will arrive to-morrow. The first meetings in connection with the anniversary will be those held by the Woman's Home Mission Society. This will be the nineteenth anniversary of the organization.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- To-day's market showed a broader tendency than has been the case for some time. While the Moores were active, other stocks commanded some attention, notably Lake Street and West Chicago. Diamond Match and New-York Biscuit both opened strong, but failed to find many supporting orders, and both closed weak.

NEWARK, N.J., May 18. -- The Newark dealers in bicycles effected a permanent organization this morning at the Continental Hotel, which will be known as the Newark Cycle Board of Trade. The temporary officers, Frederick Keer. President, and T.H. Reed, Secretary, were continued until such time as it should be deemed advisable to hold an election.

An exception to the general rule that saloon keepers without hotel licenses did not sell liquor Sunday last was found, as alleged, in the case of Frank Shanley of 16 Beach Street, who was arraigned before Magistrate Kudlich in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday.

-- M. Theodore Dubois, whose appointment as successor to Ambroise Thomas at the Paris Conservatoire is announced, is a former pupil and professor of the great musical school of France. He is fifty-nine, and his works, though not reaching the celebrity of other French composers, are marked by great character, chiefly of the religious and stately mold.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- Seymour pitched his first League game to-day, and was so wild that he was taken out of the box in the sixth inning and Campfleld, New-York's new man, was substituted. The bases were full when he came in, and Lange hit the first ball pitched for a home run. Seymour allowed ten bases on balls, four of them in the sixth inning, after two men were out.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The State Department officers feel that the Consular reports which are prepared at infinite pains, and in some cases by much labor and research, by our Consuls in all parts of the world are not fully appreciated at home. These reports aim, under the present system, to point out to American merchants and manufacturers the best markets for their products.

BOSTON, May 18. -- The Rev. Samuel Richard Fuller, rector of St. Paul's Church in Maiden for several years, until suspended by the Bishop of the diocese for marrying after having been divorced, refuses to accept the sentence imposed. In a letter to Bishop Lawrence, he says:

The Astoria Presbyterian Church of Long Island City completed a half century of existence Sunday. The event was very properly observed with special services, in which the congregations of other churches joined. The Astoria Presbyterian Church began its services May 17, 1846. The movement for its creation commenced with a meeting May 6, 1846, at the residence of Henry S. Mulligan.

MONDAY -- P.M. There was very little feature to to-day's stock market. In the early trading prices were heavy, but in, the afternoon there were buying orders from Washington, which checked the decline and carried prices Slightly above Saturday's closing figures.
LONDON, May 18. -- The Princess of Wales held a drawing room on behalf of the Queen at Buckingham Palace this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 18.-- There is a lack of push and energy in the Republican "steering" committee in securing an agreement for an early adjournment that is beginning to cause talk. There is little work to be done that may not be disposed of speedily or put off until December. The River and Harbor bill, which has been passed by both houses and is now in conference, will not provoke much difference of opinion.

NEWARK, N.J., May 18. -- Miles L. Kinney of 45 North Ninth Street, this city, connected with the Honduras Trading Company of New-York, has just reached home after a trip to Honduras, and brings word of the murder of an American named Walton E. Stalee. Mr. Kinney met Stalee on board a steamship while bound from New-Orleans for Honduras.

Acting Police Inspector O'Keefe held an investigation yesterday of the charges of Christian Fiand, a restaurant keeper at 101 Third Avenue, who accuses John McMullen and Richard Mulcahy of the Fifth Street Police Station with clubbing him. As a result of the investigation charges will be made before the Police Board against the two policemen, and Sergt.

There was at least one attempt at train wrecking on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad on Sunday night. The people at Boonton, N.J., say there were two attempts, but the railroad officials at Hoboken say there was but one. According to the railroad men, the only train that was put in jeopardy was the "Boston Flier."

From The Philadelphia Ledger of Yesterday. Yesterday one of Mr. McKinley's organs, which most strenuously maintains that he is In favor of "sound money," prefaces its report in fat, black headlines, of the 16th inst., of the proceedings of the North Carolina Convention as follows:

ST. JOHNS, N.F., May 19. -- Negotiations are being conducted here by Capt. John Bartlett, commander of the arctic steamer Kite last Summer, to procure a steamer to take Lieut. Peary, the famous explorer, north next month on an expedition to secure the immense iron meteorite lying near Cape York, Melville Bay.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 19. -- Delegates to the Baptist Convention still continue to arrive in large numbers. Nearly every incoming train brings visitors from all parts of the country.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Adjournment of Congress continues to be expected early in June by the Republican leaders. The notice which has been given by Senator Butler of North Carolina, that he intends to press for consideration his resolution prohibiting further sales of bonds without new authority of law, might be interpreted as indicating a purpose to prolong the session if Senator Butler were trying to put the resolution ahead of appropriation bills.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 19. -- The annual meeting of the United States Rubber Company was held at the home office here to-day. Out of the 370,000 shares of the company, 305,000 were represented. The report of Treasurer Charles R. Flint, showing the condition of the affairs of the company on April 1, was presented, as follows:

It now seems probable that Pittsburg and Allegheny will be the first two of the large cities in the United States, after Minneapolis, to give force in effective municipal legislation to the plain teachings of sanitary science concerning tuberculous infection derived from milch cows. These two cities, which are separated only by a river, contain 400,000 inhabitants.

LONDON, May 19. -- The Times will to-morrow publish a dispatch from Pretoria, saying that the Executive Council of the Transvaal has decided that Col. Frank W. Rhodes, brother of Cecil Rhodes; Lionel Phillips, George Parrar, and John Hays Hammond, the leaders of the Johannesburg Reform Committee, who were sentenced to death for high treason against the Transvaal, but whose sentences were subsequently commuted, shall undergo fifteen years' imprisonment.

In the course of the examination of John R. Rogers, the theatrical manager and former husband of Minnie palmer, as a third party in supplementary proceedings instituted against him and Simon Dessau, who was at one time known as the "Carbon King," he testified yesterday that he had made a trip to Michigan, "Wisconsin, and California in search of mining property for the Dessau Mining Company, of which Simon Dessau was Secretary and Treasurer.

The trial of Wolf Silverman of 208 1/2 Broome Street, who is accused of having attempted to defraud the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company but of $1,000 by substituting a strong, healthy woman for his wife, during the medical examination which followed the application for a policy on his wife's life, was resumed before Judge Fitzgerald, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday.
The name of Daniel Coit Oilman, LL.D., of Johns Hopkins Unuiversity will be presented when there is an election of City Superintendent of Schools by the Board of Education. This may be to-day.

CLEVELAND, May 19. -- The Methodist General Conference to-day elected as Bishops "Chaplain" Charles C. McCabe and Earl Cranston. Mr. McCabe was elected on the fifteenth ballot, which resulted as follows: C.C. McCabe, 344; Earl Cranston, 328; H. A. Buttz, 112; J.W. Hamilton, 109; T.B. Neeley, 50, and J.W.E. Bowen, 30.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Senator Quay this afternoon candidly admitted that the report was true that he intended to make a visit to Canton, Ohio, and to Major McKinley. He was surprised when, he learned that the report had been published, as he supposed his intention was to be kept a secret for the present.

WASHINGTON, Mav 19. -- The immigration question occupied the attention of the House for a time this afternoon. Mr. Bartholdt, (Rep., Mo.,) from the Committee on Immigration, called up the McCall bill requiring that future male immigrants shall toe able to read and write some language before being admitted. This shall not apply to the parents of any person now residing in this country or who shall hereafter be admitted.

PITTSBURG, May 19. -- Pittsburg won an exciting ten-inning game from Brooklyn to-day. Errors by Stenzel and Donovan put the visitors in the game at several stages, but these two players afterward redeemed themselves, the former by timely hitting, batting in three of the six runs, while Donovan made a remarkable one-hand catch of a line fly from Shindle's bat in the eighth inning, and completed a double play.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Last week the Committee on Commerce passed a resolution to withdraw from the House the Sherman bill, which had been reported a few weeks previously, and which amended the imprisonment feature of the inter-State commerce law by substituting therefor a fine of $11,000 for each violation of the statute.

LONDON, May 19. -- The Sportsman will to-morrow say that all the horses that belonged to the late Col. North, with the exception of Iddesleigh, and all the dogs, with the exception of Fullerton, will be sold at auction in July.

Dr. Louis Dunean of Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, who is now in this city attending the annual meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, has paid a great deal of attention to the subject of the application of electricity as a motive power on existing steam lines.
WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Santa Monica has been again a subject of animated controversy at the Capitol, but this time in the conference between the Senate and the House on the River and Harbor bill.

LEXINGTON, Mass., May 19. -- An unknown man killed himself last night on the bank of the Arlington Reservoir by shooting. He was evidently a traveling man, between thirty and thirty-five years of age, had light complexion, light mustache and white, even teeth. A seal ring was worn on the third finger of the left hand.

SANDWICH, Mass., May 19. -- The forest fire which destroyed such a large amount of property in and around Sandwich only a month ago was at the time considered the worst ever heard of on the Cape, but the Tremont fire, which started at Kelly's sawmill yesterday afternoon, has surpassed even that in the amount of damage done to property.

The Republican State Committee, through its sub-committee, yesterday "pointed with pride" to the record of the last Legislature. The address to the people of the State which the organization decided to issue last Saturday was made public. It was prepared by Edward Lauterbach, W.W. Goodrich, William Barges, Jr., John. T. Mott, and Chairman Charles W. Hackett.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service has received an official report from Dr. Burgess, United States Sanitary Inspector at Havana, stating that on May 15 he paid one of his freauent visits to all of the eight hospitals in and around the city including the military, civil, and private institutions.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- A stubborn conference fight is on between members of the House and the Senate chosen to reconcile the difference between the Naval Appropriation bill as it passed the House and as amended in the Senate. There is danger of the failure of the measure.

Fred Littlefield, who is thought by some to be a paragon among jockeys, and who is referred to by others as "the favorite-killer," had a bad quarter of an hour with The Jockey Club Stewards at Morris Park yesterday. Littlefield had the mount on Abuse in the opening race of the afternoon, which was a run of six furlongs for maidens three years old or over.

There is one short word that the business men of the country ask any candidate to say who wishes their votes. It Is in answer to this question: "What standard for the currency of the United States do you believe in, and will you, if elected, faithfully maintain by every means in your power?"

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Secretary Olney has received a letter from Miss Clara Barton, in which, referring to rumors that she was prohibited from distributing relief in Asia Minor, except under direction and control of the Turkish authorities, and from lists of parsons furnished by Turkish officials, she emphatically denies that any members or officials of the Turkish Government have ever tried in any way to direct or control her distributions.
TAMPA, Fla., May 19. -- The cigar industry of this city is beginning to feel the effects of the war in Cuba to a serious extent.
The plan of organizing an opposition to the Platt machine in this State so that it will be in a position to do active service in the event of McKinley's nomination, is rapidly taking shape.

Stake books for the Brooklyn Jockey Club meeting, which begins Thursday, June 4, were distributed at Morris Park yesterday. Provision has been made for a number of hurdle races during the meeting, which last fourteen days. Following is a list of dates assigned for the fixtures:

Fully seventy-five members of the New-York Cotton Exchange assembled yesterday to take action regarding the prevailing financial conditions. Inasmuch as a large proportion of the members of the Cotton Exchange have Southern affiliations, it was deemed prudent to make some emphatic declaration in favor of, sound money in order to offset so far as possible the silver sentiment which appears to be received with favor throughout the South.

The Law Enforcement Society of Brooklyn is finding fault with Special Deputy Excise Commissioner MICHELL because he does not "take any action regarding saloons that are within the 200-foot limit of churches," but there is no action that he can take regarding saloons that are already there.
WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The Treasury lost only $36,900 in gold to-day, and the net gold reserve remained at $112,310,106.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Col. E.H. Sellers of Detroit, Mich., President of what is known as the National Council of Patriotic Associations of the United States, to-day said that that organization had for its plans and purposes the interviewing of both of the old political parties, with a view of inducing them to incorporate in their platforms the platform and principles of the organization.

The five-cent traffic to Coney Island will cause more trouble than a complaint of disorderly conduct is likely to lead to, if the trolley-car folks are not more careful. Such overcrowding of the cars as there has been Sundays in this month fairly baffles description. The pictures in the illustrated papers give but a faint idea of the facts.

UTICA, N.Y., May 19. -- Corp. Tanner is making a show of himself here in connection with the State Encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic. He was one of the speakers this morning at the Opera House, where the encampment was opened with a public meeting. He and John Palmer and Department Commander Atkinson made addresses in response to the welcoming speeches of the local committee.

BOSTON, May 19. -- The Connecticut Associated Press, (incorporated,) which has for several years conducted a general and State news service, serving from fifteen to twenty newspapers in that State, has placed itself under the control and protection of the New-England Associated Press by a transfer of stock, and Mr. H.H. Fletcher of the New-England Associated Press has been chosen Treasurer of the association

The five-cent traffic to Coney Island will cause more trouble than a complaint of disorderly conduct is likely to lead to, if the trolley-car folks are not more careful. Such overcrowding of the cars as there has been Sundays in this month fairly baffles description. The pictures in the illustrated papers give but a faint idea of the facts.

ST. LOUIS, May 19. -- With intervals of a few hours' clear weather, rain has fallen over a wide section, around St. Louis for three days and is still coming down. At Odin, Pana, Vandalia, Duqoin, and Hillsboro, Ill., last night's storm was of the cloud-burst variety, and small streams became torrents.

VIENNA, May 19.-Archduke Charles Louis, brother of Emperor Francis Joseph, died this morning. Dispatches from Buda-Pesth say that the announcement of his death has created a feeling of sorrow throughout Hungary, where the Archduke was very popular, and casts a shade of sadness over the celebration of Hungary's millennium.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 19. -- M.F. Dwyer has added to the strength of his stable by the purchase to-day of William McGulgan's mare Lady Inez, winner of several good races this year and the best filly racing in the West. She is three years old, by Spendthrift or Albert-Longitude by Longfellow, and was a stable companion of Ben Eder recently purchased by Mr. Dwyer.

-- Odd Fellows high in that order, including the Grand Sire of the United States and the Grand Masters of New-Hampshire, New-York, and Connecticut, took part yesterday in the dedication at Ludlow, Vt., of the Odd Fellows' Home, presented by John S. Gill of Boston. The gift consists of fourteen acres of land and a fifteen-thousand-dollar building.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 20. -- The residents of Rye, who have large landed interests along the Boston Post Road and other main thoroughfares of the Town of Rye, yesterday afternoon opposed the application for trolley franchises from Port Chester to Mamaroneck, and to Rye Beach, made by the Port Chester Electric Railway Company.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- President Cleveland returned to the House to-day, without his signature, a bill granting a pension to Lydia A. Taft. He explained that Taft served as a private in a Connecticut regiment for a period of nearly three years. No application for a pension was made by him, although he lived until 1891, when he died in a Connecticut soldiers' home.

BALTIMORE, May 20. -- The Trustees and Faculty of the Johns Hopkins University and Baltimoreans generally were greatly surprised by the publication to-day of a report that President Gilman's name was being used in connection with the position of City Superintendent of Schools in New-York.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Chauncey F. Black is out again with his demand upon the Democratic Convention at Chicago to pledge its candidate not to veto a free-coinage measure if one should be sent to a Democratic President at the White House. He very earnestly protests against suggestions of bolting, and takes a very gloomy view of the Democratic future following a bolt after the Chicago Convention shall have declared for either gold or silver.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Mr. Alexander W. Terrell, United States Minister to Turkey, feels chagrined over the publication of a story that charges affecting his personal conduct have been filed with the President by the committee of prominent men who called at the White House last week with reference to the Armenian troubles.

The Jasper party in the Board of Education missed a valuable opportunity yesterday. The mention of the name of President GILMAN in connection with the Superintendency of Schools opened to them a comfortable line of retreat. All personal and official obligations to JASPER they have discharged.

Mr. WARNER MILLER'S curious explosion in favor of McKINLEY may fairly be attributed to a desire to antagonize Mr. THOMAS C. PLATT. These eminent ex-Senators are much opposed to each other, and justly so. That Mr. PLATT is for any person or thing is a specious argument for Mr. MILLER why he should be against it.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. May 20. -- Mrs. John S.C. Abbott, widow of the historian, died Monday at the home of her son-in-law, the Rev. Horatio Ladd in Flshkill, Village. She was eighty-six years of age. Mrs. Abbott was of New-England birth and family, and a native of Boston. Her father, Abner Bourne, was one of the public-spirited merchant citizens of Boston at the beginning of this century.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 20. -- There was announced to-day a partial list of clergymen who will officiate at All Saints' Chapel this season, where most of the cottagers worship. It is as follows:

A plan of reorganization has been adopted by the holders of more than two-thirds of the Central Trust Company's certificates of deposit for first mortgage bonds of the St. Joseph and Grand Island Railroad. Some important amendments to the original plan were suggested by the large foreign holders of the securities.

The regular monthly meeting of the East Side Juvenile Protective League, the pioneer juvenile street cleaning association of the city, was held in the headquarters, 26 Delancey Street, yesterday. More than, fifty boys were in attendance.

A Third Avenue open cable car, crowded with passengers on their way down town, crashed into a Thirty-fourth Street cross-town car on its way east a few minutes before 6 o'clock last evening. A woman passenger's arm was broken and a man who stood on the rear platform was severely bruised.

LONDON, May 20. -- The Bath and Somerset County races began to-day. Richard Croker's Nashville, three years old, by Iroquols, out of Boulotte, started in the Durham Park Maiden Plate race, one mile, but was not placed, T.L. Cambie's Gobryas winning.

Corliss amendment, intended to keep out Canadians who have been in the habit of traveling back and forth between the two countries, were put through with such unanimity that the opponents of any restriction were not numerous enough to secure a call of the roll on the passage of the bill.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 20. -- The Populists of Indiana make the announcement that within the last ten days an understanding has been reached whereby the Populists of every State in the Union are to accept the platform and candidate of the Chicago Convention, in case both are for free silver.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 20. -- The convention of the State Exempt Firemen's Association held here to-day was a great success. The town was gayly decorated in honor of the guests. The convention was held in the Opera House, and was called to order about 11 o'clock by President Charles W. Bliss of Trenton.

It does not seem to be clear what commutation has been ordered of the sentences of the prisoners in the Transvaal originally condemned to death on their own pleas of guilty. A sentence of imprisonment for fifteen years, if it has in fact been pronounced, can scarcely be intended to be executed.

CONCORD, N.H., May 20. -- New-Hampshire's Democracy to-day declared for a gold standard, and, by its choice of delegates, gave hearty indorsement to the Presidential candidacy of William E. Russell of Massachusetts.

Joseph B. Frees, who died Tuesday in his rooms above his drug store, at 179 Sixth Avenue, had worked in the same store and lived above it for fifty years. He was born in Frenchtown, N.J., in 1820; came to this city while a boy, and went to work in a drug store lower down on Sixth Avenue, near what was then Amity Street.

The twenty-fifth annual meeting of the American Fisheries Society, which is composed of the members of the Fish Commissions of the various States and others, was opened yesterday in the Battery Park Acuarium.

GEORGETOWN, Demerara, B.G., May 9. -- Information was received here some days ago from Cayenne, French Guiana that a number of convicts had escaped from the penal settlement in the French colony, and the request was made that a watch be kept for the runaways.

It was nothing like as successful a day's sport that the New-York Steeplechase Association furnished yesterday at Morris Park as that of a week ago. The two steeplechases were little short of farces. In that for maidens all but one -- Marble -- fell, and one of them -- Brookdale -- received injuries that were fatal.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The attempt to force the hand of the President in regard to the recognition of Cuba is still being made by members of both houses of Congress, but the resources of delay are such that Mr. Cleveland will probably remain free to follow his inclinations after the adjournment of Congress.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- An act approved by the President to-day "to provide for the safety of passengers on excursion steamers" had its inception in the complaint made by Lord Dunraven of the crowding of the Defender-Valkyrie regatta course. Hereafter there will be no opportunity for excursion steamers and other vessels to interfere with aquatic sports.
MlDDLETOWN, Conn., May 20. -- Wesleyan defeated Trinity on the campus to-day. Poor plays abounded, and Wesleyan rapped Coggeshall all over the field. Score:

Next Tuesday ought to be a halcyon day for the Virginia stogie, the North Carolina cheroot, and the Connecticut wrapper. If Gen. WEYLER and his Government do not change their minds, in the meantime, the exportation of Cuban tobacco will cease on that day. Well, there are some things Americans would miss even more than real Havana cigars and Honradez chips for cigarettes and pipes.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 20. -- Insurance Commissioner Belts of this State to-day served a writ upon the Aefna Life Insurance Company of this city. calling the company into court under the charge that its dividends to stockholders are improperly derived from the mutual department, and that the money should not be so diverted.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- A bolt by one or the other wing of the National Democracy becomes increasingly provable in view of the reports from all over the West. The silver men are using high-handed methods to capture the delegations in several States where they control the party machinery, and the sound-money men are refusing to submit to injustice.

Justice Truax heard argument yesterday in the application of Louis Sternberger to have the question of the custody of his children, Robert S. and Maria, determined by the Supreme Court. Joseph H. Choate appeared for Mrs. Birdie S. Sternberger and Mr. Zabriskie for Louis Sternberger.

Tillie Loch, nineteen years old, of 183 West Sixty-third Street, was fatally burned yesterday afternoon in her home. Her hair was singed off, and nearly every part of her face and body was burned. She was taken to Roosevelt Hospital, where she died last night.

PITTSBURG, May 20. -- The game with Brooklyn to-day was played in a drizzling rain. Hastings started to pitch for Pittsburg, but was wild, and gave way to Gear at the end of the third inning. The latter was not much of an improvement, and, Brooklyn securing a commanding lead, Pittsburg played for delay. The game was little better than a farce.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- From a revenue point of view, the action of the Spanish Government in prohibiting the export of Cuban tobacco will have but little effect in comparison with, the injury it causes the manufacturers of tobacco, and incidentally their workmen. From the latest official figures for the last fiscal year it is seen that 5,679,252 pounds of wrapper tobacco, valued at $7,219,877, was imported into this country.

The annual exhibition week of St. George's Evening Trade School. which opened Monday, is proving very satisfactory to the workers connected with the school and the large number of visitors. The largest number of visitors was present on Tuesday, when they came in such numbers that it was necessary for them to form in line outside the building.

NEW-HAVEN, May 20. -- The term of office of Thomas G. Bennett of this city as a member of the Yale Corporation expires at Commencement this year, and requests were sent out as usual last March for nominations for the election. It is now announced that only three persons received as many as twenty-five votes each for the nomination, that number allowing a candidate to stand.

ALBANY, May 20. -- Ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt was in this city to-day in the interest of his machine. He arrived on the Empire State express and went at once to the Executive Chamber, where he held close consultation with Gov. Morton. He went with the Governor to luncheon at the Executive Mansion, and afterward had mother session in the Capitol.

LONDON, May 20. -- A dispatch from Sir Hercules Robinson, Governor of the Cape Colony, has been received by the Government, in which, it is announced that the Transvaal authorities have reached a decision in the cases of fifty-nine of the members of the Reform Union who were recently convicted in connection with the conspiracy against the South African Republic, and were sentenced to imprisonment, fine, and banishment.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The Senate had an interesting debate to-day on a proposition which has been repeatedly made and favored by members of all parties, and which has never yet been offered in such a way as to secure its enactment. The proposition was to authorize the issue of short-term Treasury certificates to cover temporary deficiencies in the revenue.

BUFFALO, May 20. -- A Buffalo paper today publishes in full the confession of Minnie Allen, the Waupun, (Wis.,) prisoner, who claims to have killed Montgomery Gibbs, the young lawyer for whose murder Sadle and Clarence Robinson are confined in Auburn Prison.

As Cesarine, in the old Dumas play "La Femme de Claude," Sarah Bernhardt illustrated anew at Abbey's Theatre last night, and in some respects quite as strikingly as ever before, the power which her unrivaled genius gives her to make visible and credible every emotional phase and physical characteristic that the author whose words she speaks could have had in mind when he set them down.

CLEVELAND, May 21. -- Bishop Merrill presided at to-day's session of the General Conference. The beginning of the end is at hand, and a motion was adopted ordering that no more memorials or resolutions be sent to the committees.

What stronger name can the delegates from the East present to the Chicago Convention than that of WILLIAM E. RUSSELL of Massachusetts? What more inspiring and uniting candidate can the convention submit to the party and the country?

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 21 -- The platform drawn by Senator Tillman and adopted by the Democratic Convention last night is striking chiefly for its general disagreement with all established order of things. It reads:

San Francisco is now added to the list of cities that have undertaken to prevent the sale to their people of tuberculous milk and to purify all the dairy herds in their suburban "milk districts" by means of the tuberculin test. We spoke two or three days ago of the similar plan recently adopted by the cities of Pittsburg and Allegheny.

Moscow, May 21. -- The great triumphal entry of the Czar and Czarina into the ancient city of Moscow took place to-day. The weather was fine, and the brilliant surroundings, the trappings of royalty, the pomp and glory all combined to make ever memorable the most gorgeous entrance into Russia's old capital that has taken place in modern times.

PANAMA, May 21 -- According to The Star and Herald's Peruvian dispatches, ierola's tenure of office hangs by the slenderest of threads. The men who helped to put him into power have turned round upon him and are conspiring against him. The news of a movement to oust him from the Palace of the Kings may arrive at any moment.

The concern shown by the Association of Savings Bank Trustees lest the consolidation of the Greater New-York should result in incurring new county debts within its area, and in "practically annulling" the Constitutional limit of indebtedness, seems very strange, coming from intelligent and experienced business men, as it does.

It is to be hoped that nothing will interfere with the prospect of obtaining Dr. GILMAN of Baltimore to take official charge of the public schools of this city, for it gives promise of the full accomplishment of the purpose of the new law, which would be of inestimable advantage to the city.

From The London Times. The present condition of the various Jewish colonies established in the Holy Land through the benevolence of societies and private individuals belonging to the Jewish faith in Europe is described in the last report of the British Consul at Jerusalem.

NEW-HAVEN, May 21. -- The annual election to the Yale senior societies took place this afternoon on the college campus. The usual ceremonies of slapping the various candidates on the back in lieu of an election were observed. The elections were remarkable for a larger number of athletes going to Scroll and Keys than usual.

Moscow, May 21. -- When, at 12 o'clock, the Grand Duke Vladimir and his brilliant officers, followed by a detachment of cuirassiers, went galloping out toward the Petroffsky Palace, where the imperial party had spent the night, a cry of delight and cheers burst forth from the crowd at what seemed a foretaste of the function so patiently awaited.

The plans for the extension of the Great Neck branch of the Long Island Railroad to Port Washington are now near enough completion to insure, bar accident, the construction and operation of the new addition before next Winter.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 21. -- The overthrow of the dominant party in the Presbyterian General Assembly, strong in numbers and stronger by reason of long-continued control, was accomplished to-day by the foriorn minority of liberals, which had scarcely numbered at any time in the past five years 20 per cent, of the entire body of Commissioners, by a cleverly conceived and shrewdly conducted manoeuvre that would have done credit to a post-graduate in politics.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I venture to ask the privilege of your columns in order to say to the people of New-York how rare an opportunity I think is theirs in the chance to secure for Superintendent of Public Instruction in this city Dr. Daniel C. Gilman, the President of Johns Hopkins University.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The House to-day in Committee of the Whole considered the Phillips bill authorizing the appointment of a non-partisan commission of twenty-one members to collate information and to consider and recommend legislation to meet the problems presented by labor, agriculture, and capital.
Capt. Berg of the Norwegian steamship Talisman, which arrived here from Demarara yesterday, tells of a remarkably long and vivid electrical storm which the vessel encountered Monday night.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 21. -- The rain which has fallen almost steadily throughout Missouri since Sunday continued to-day. Great anxiety is felt for the safety of people living along the bottom lands of the Missouri, Gasconade, and Osage Rivers.

-- Marshall Way, keeper of the village tavorn at Wheelock, Vt., killed his wife yesterday by clubbing her over the head. The couple had had trouble for some time, and wero trying to arrange for a division of the property, the immediate cause of the murder being a quarrel over the custody of a minor child.

BALTIMORE, May 21. -- Judges Goff and Morris, in the United States Circuit Court, to-day heard the application of Receivers Cowen and Murray of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company to issue receivers' certificates to the amount of $5,000,000 to provide funds for paying various debts and for improvements of the roadbed.

Two very important and authoritative utterances upon the currency have been made in this city this week. It is hardly possible to imagine any sources from which an expression of sanity and honesty on this question could carry more weight and be of more value than from the New-York State Association of Savings Banks and from the New-York Cotton Exchange.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., May 21. -- Senator Edmunds has written a letter to at least one of the delegates chosen to represent Vermont at the National Convention at St. Louis, in which he virtually expresses disgust at the action of the Green Mountain voters in taking a stand which makes it imperative that their delegates shall vote for McKanley at St. Louis.

Alderman Elias Goodman of the Thirty-fourth District, who is an alternate to the Republican National Convention from the Fifteenth Congressional District, made public announcement last night that if an opportunity were afforded him at the St. Louis Convention he would cast his vote for McKinley.

MILWAUKEE, May 21. -- This city is tied up by one of the most remarkable boycotts ever known in the history of the country. The business interests of the community are held by the throat pending a decision of the question whether the Milwaukee Street Railway Company or its striking employes shall win in the struggle in which they have been engaged for the past two weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Secretary Olney has instructed Minister Taylor to make vigorous representations to the Spanish Government relative to the recent edict prohibiting the exportation of tobacco from the Island of Cuba on the ground that it amounts to the practical confiscation of goods in Cuba owned by Americans.

The petition submitted yesterday by the committee of the Zoological Society to the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund will be approved by all persons who desire to multiply the attractions of New-York. Among our many municipal deficiencies, the defect of a "Zoo" such as is maintained abroad and in this country by towns of far less population and pretension is one of the most obvious.

BERLIN, May 23. -- The official correspondence exchanged last Autumn between Secretary of State Olney and Baron von Thielmann, German Ambassador to the United States, regarding the case of Louis Stern at New-York, who was sentenced to fourteen days' imprisonment for insulting Baron von Thuengen, Deputy Comissioner of the Spa at Kissingen, was published to-day.

LONDON, May 21 -- The annual gathering of prominent men interested in South Africa took place to-night at the Hotel Metropole, where the usual banquet was given. The Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies, presided. Among those present were Sir William Dunn, Consul General of the Orange Free State; Sir David Tennant, Agent General of Cape Colony, and Mr. Walter Peace, Agent General of Natal.

LONDON, May 22 -- The House of Commons, in committee of the whole, sat all night discussing the Agricultural Rating bill. After the debate had lasted until 3:15 this morning, closure was adopted, and Mr. Chaplin, President of the Local Government Board and introducer of the measure, moved that a certain clause of the bill be put to vote.

No better proof that racing has again assumed a thorough hold on the sport-loving public could be had than the attendance at the races of the Westchester Association yesterday. Rainy weather was against the chances of good sport, and the card was of very common quality, in spite of the fact that Henry of Navarre and One I Love were to be among the runners.

At the outset of his curious chase of the Presidential nomination, Gov. MORTON was said to have announced that he would take the prize only if it were offered to him with the approval of the entire New-York delegation. That is to say, the Governor would accept a nomination only in response to the call of his party in the State, which he assumed would be fairly represented in the conventions, State and National.

The promoters of the first separate bicycle meet for the intercollegiate championships should feel highly gratified. Nearly all of the big institutions of learning will be represented, some aspirants for honors coming from as far west as Iowa.

Our esteemed Republican contemporary, The Albany Evening Journal, seeks to commend the Raines law to the daily approval of its readers by printing in conspicuous full-face type at the head of its editorial columns the following legend:

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- After two days of rain the sun appeared again here this afternoon, and the Southern championship lawn tennis tournament was continued on the courts of the Bachelors' Lawn Tennis Club. The features of the afternoon play were the Davidson-Beckwith and Geoghegan-Worthington matches. Beckwith is the champion of the Tropical States, although he lives in Cleveland, Ohio, while Davidson is the champion of the District of Columbia.

To-day Mme. Bernhardt sails for France, not to return, according to her manager, for "many years." Many years means a long while for an actress who is a grandmother. Probably most persons in the audience which filled Abbey's Theatre last evening felt that Bernhardt was acting for them for the last time.

A fire which, threatened the lives of the tenants of the five-story tenement house at 70 New Chambers Street was discovered about 7 o'clock last night, and before all the occupants of the house were in places of safety the police were obliged to drag a number of frightened people forcibly from the building.

A very encouraging increase of the exports of manufactured goods is shown by the recent reports of the Treasury Department, and especially by those which relate to the first three months of the current calendar year. Before directing attention to the record for January, February, and March, we should point to the reports for the last four fiscal years, which show that the exports of manufactures were as follows:

William Brookfield, ex-Commissioner of Public Works, ex-Chairman of the Republican State Committee, and one of the strongest anti-Platt leaders in this city, arrived from Europe yesterday on the Furst Bismarck. Mr. Brookfield and Mrs. Brookfield, with their son James, started for the south of Europe early in the year.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The bill to increase the efficiency of the personnel of the navy, which has been under consideration for several months by a sub-committe of the House Naval Affairs Committee, has been practically completed and is now being put in proper form to be laid before the full committee early next week.

Chairman William F. Harrity of the Democratic National Committee was in this city yesterday for a time, and returned to Philadelphia in the afternoon. Mr. Harrity expressed the belief that the sound-money Democrats would control the National Convention in Chicago. He was thus quoted:

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The chaos which prevails in the finances of the United States was brought out in a striking manner by the debate to-day in the Senate. On the one side stood the Populists and silver extremists, urging that the Senate pass a bill forbidding further issues of bonds.

It can be stated on unimpeachable authority that negotiations are pending between representative of the Mertopolitan Traction syndicate and representatives of the New-York and Harlem Railroad for a transfer of the control of the Fourth Avenue and the Madison Avenue street-car lines to the syndicate.

BEAVER, Penn., May 22. -- Senator Quay was seen at his home this evening soon after his arrival from Canton, and was asked to say a few words about his visit, but no amount of persuasion could induce him to discuss it, though he seemed in a happy frame of mind, and conveyed the impression that he might have something to say later. He expects to be in Pittsburg to-morrow.

BOSTON, May 22. -- A letter received in Boston states that the estimated number of refugees in Zeitoun, Central Turkey is from 12,000 to 14,000 Their villages were destroyed by the Turkish soldiery, and they fled without being able to carry anything away with them except the clothes on their backs and a little bedding.

A decision announced yesterday, affecting the construction of a trolley road between the cities of New-London and Norwich, in Connecticut, Still further complicates the situation in that State with respect to the extension of interurban or other trolley lines paralleling steam railroads.

PATERSON, N. J., May 22. -- Francis E. Donnelly, Sr., aged eighty-three, a wellknown citizen, died Wednesday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Elisha E. Carpenter, at 180 Oliver Street, tin Sunday he was seized with an attack of illness, and as his daughtor's house was nearer than his own he went there.

TRENTON, N. J., May 22. -- Charles A. Furbush of Philadelphia has begun suit in the Federal courts against Secretary of State Henry C. Kelsey, the Newark Gaslight Company, the Citizens' Gaslight Company of Newark, and the Newark Gas Company.

CANTON, Ohio, May 22. -- Senator Quay paid a visit to ex-Gov, McKinley, at the latter's home here to-day, by appointment. What took place at the meeting is a profound mystery, as neither gentleman will give an inkling of what was said during their three hours' conversation.

From The London Telegraph. Just now a very knotty question is before the Judges of the Civil Tribunal of the Seine. A prosperous Parisian shopkeeper wants a divorce from his wife by reason of her suspicious conduct.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The Labor Commission bill, discussion of which was begun yesterday, has apparently failed for this session. The rule providing for consideration of the bills excepted conference reports on appropriation bills from its operation, and to-day's session, of the House was exhausted by measures of this character.

An explosion occurred at the Pratt Oil Works, in Brooklyn, shortly after 11 o'clock last night, which shook the entire neighborhood, and was heard all over the Eastern District of the city. Fortunately, though many employes were at work at the time, no one was killed, and a passing truckman was the only person injured, and he was not seriously hurt.
WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The conferrees on the River and Harbor bill have agreed upon the Santa Monica-San Pedro Harbor matter.

Controller James A. Roberts was the second man to make public an interview putting Gov. Motion in the field as a Presidential candidate and declaring that NewYork's delegates would support him at St. Louis. In this Mr. Roberts was only a few minutes behind Warner Miller, their declarations being published in the same edition of the morning papers.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court handed down a decision yesterday denying the motion made on behalf of the Rapid Transit Commissioners for the confirmation of the report of the General Term Commissioners in favor of the plan for the construction of an underground rapid transit system.
A thoroughly representative meeting of German-Americans was held last evening in the Grand Central Palace with William Steinway presiding, to organize the "German-American Sound-Money League."

It will be a matter of keen disappointment to the people of this city that the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court has refused to confirm the report of its Commissioners in favor of the construction of the rapid-transit roads laid out by the Rapid Transit Commission, but from the decision there seems to be no appeal.

Mr. EDWARD LAUTERBACH, who is rather addicted to striking keynotes, has lately struck the keynote of present Republican politics in the State of NewYork. He observed at the housewarming of the Republican Club of the Twentyseventh Assembly District on Wednesday evening: "Whatever a man may be, if he is a Republican he is as good as any of us."

ASTORIA, Oregon, May 22. -- Thirteen prom- inent citizehs have been indicted by the Federal Grand Jury on a charge of falsely witnessing affidavits declaring that certain Chinese were entitled to admission at this port as merchants who had previously resided here. For several months the steamer Signal has been running regularly from British Columbia to this port, and on every trip has landed from ten to fifteen Chinese.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 22. -- The steamer Laurada entered the bar yesterday and was met at Quarantine by J. A. Huau, agent of the Cuban Junta, and a number of friends of Cuba.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 22. -- Charles A. Stratton, a well-known young man of this city, died in the Cooper Hospital to-day from the effects of a pistol wound in the temple inflicted on himself last night.

The story which we printed yesterday to the effect that Senator "TIM" SULLIVAN'S deciding vote to authorize the Lexow sub-committee to perform as a sideshow to the Greater New-York Commission was the result of a bargain with PLATT to "back" HENRY D. PURROY as a member of the commission has the merit of explaining facts which otherwise seemed inexplicable.
As the tugboat Druoella was proceeding up the East River yesterday afternoon Capt. William Hopkins saw the body of a man floating near Nineteenth Street.

The members of the Eighth Regiment had what they called gymkhana games at the armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Park Avenue, last night. The attendance was fairly good, but nearly all who went seemed to be attracted by the dancing, which was to begin as soon as the games ended, rather than by the contests.

There was never a time when the interest of the people of this city was so much centred in the Board of Education as it is now, and it is a favorable moment for directing attention to the tremendous power and responsibility vested in this body of twenty-one unpaid citizens.

Eight members of the Republican National Committee, it was learned in this city last night, have visited Major McKinley at Canton or Mark A. Hanna at Columbus within the last few days. They have been there at the solicitations of the McKinley boomers, who are reported to have been making a campaign among the committeemen.

The May festival of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society Orphan Asylum, given by the Young Toadies and Gentlemen's Circle of the Auxiliary Society, at ths Tuxedo, Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, last evening, was a great success.

Wall Street seems to care very little for the United States Senate. Prices did not budge with the repudiation demonstration by that body on Friday. So far as this feeling relates to the character of the members of the Senate who make up the majority, indifference or scorn is natural.

BERLIN, May 23. -- The food purity agitation, which has been so tenderly fostered by the Agrarian politicians, has received a sensational fillip this week by the seizure of 400 pounds of food, infected with tuberculosis at the Berlin Trades Exhibition, in the institution devoted to the sale of cheap food to the public, where thousands of persons eat dinners daily that cost a penny a head.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 23. -- Princeton defeated Columbia in the dual games to-day by 62 1/2 points to 49 1/2. It was the annual track meeting between the two colleges, and nearly every event was well contested. Fast time was made particularly in the sprints. Following are the results of the different events:

More than 600 bakers employed In 173 bakeries, chiefly owned by Hebrews, on the east side, have been on a strike for several days, and the result has been a scarcity or bread and cake in the shops affected. The object of the strike is to obtain shorter hours and other concessions demanded by the Bakers Union, No. 165, to which the men belong.

The Executive Committee of the Regents of the University of this State has appointed as a State Board of Public Accountant Examiners, under the new law to regulate the profession of public accountants, Col. Charles E. Sprague, President of the Union Dime Savings Bank, and Charles W. Haskins of New-York City, and Frank Brooker of Brooklyn.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23. -- Harvard defeated Pennsylvania this afternoon on Franklin Field, the athletic grounds of the University of Pennsylvania Paine, the visiting collegians' pitcher, was effective until the ninth inning, striking out nine batsmen. O'Donnell started to pitch for Pennsylvania, but Harvard took his measure in the third inning, and in the fifth he gave way to Wunder.

Two alleged swindlers have been arrested and committed to the Tombs by Magistrate Kudlich, in the Centre Street Police Court. The men are accused of using the business reputation of a merchant in this city to secure shipments of goods from, business firms in various small towns, principally in New-England, and then selling the goods below the market value.

SATURDAY -- P.M. Speculative sentiment to-day showed decided improvement. The volume of business for the two hours was increased, notwithstanding the holiday in London. The impression is growing that the damand of representative safes in the East for unequivocal gold platforms from both of the great political parties will be listened to, and that no candidate can be elected unless he stands squarely upon such platform.

LONDON, May 23. -- What strikes one most about the great cumulative pageant at Moscow is the novel effect it is producing on the imagination of outside nations. No one seems before to have realized what a colossal thing Russia really is, or what prodigious results must follow when she begins to move about.

I have selected Shakespeare's "Sonnets" as his most personal utterance, and "Venus and Adonis" as a characteristic youthful poem, avoiding the plays, in which the coloring might be held to be largely of the scene-painting order. I believe this selection is fairly comparable with Marlowe's work.
