John I. Waterbury, T. Jefferson Coolidge, Jr., E. Rollins Morse, Edwin S. Hooley, and Jules S. Bache, forming the Oregon Improvement Reorganization Committee, have formulated a plan of reorganization which was submitted to the security holders yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, May 29. -- The full extent of Wednesday evening's disaster is just beginning to be realized. It is apparent that the greatest loss of life was in this city, where estimates put the figures all the way from 250 to 400. The former figure probably will not be far out of the way. The number of dead thus far reported is 184.

The award of the commission for a statue to Gen. SHERMAN is one of the most discreditable events even in the annals of the public art of the United States. It shows, indeed, the same self-complacent ignorance that is apt to characterize the artistic undertakings of Congress. But it contains besides a very distinct suggestion of trickery and false pretenses.

ROCKFORD, Ill., May 29. -- Godfrey Hildebrand, a farmer, whose wife was beheaded and daughter killed in the wreck of his dwelling by a cyclone Monday, dropped dead yesterday as the funeral procession passed the site of his home. The children of Mrs. Isora Bird, who was killed, died yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Senator-elect Money of Mississippi several days ago addressed a letter to W. F. Harrity, the Chairman of the National Democratic Committee, asking him if it was true, as reported, that he intended to exclude from the rolls of the National Convention any free-silver delegate who had threatened to bolt.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The following message was sent to the House by President Cleveland this afternoon, vetoing the River and Harbor bill:

The Board of Directors of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange of New-York met last Thursday afternoon, and in behalf of the 1,800 members of the Exchange issued a declaration in opposition to the free coinage of silver. The circular says:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 29. -- Granville F. Woods, who is said to be one of the best-known colored men in New-York, has sued Warren F. Spaulding, a wealthy resident of Poughkeepsie, for $5,000 damages, claiming that Spaulding is detaining his wife at his home and preventing her from joining him. Woods is said to have invented and patented over thirty electrical appliances, and his picture and biography have been published in a number of magazines.

The Spanish Consul Gereral at this port, Arturo Baldasano, scurried about the offices of the United States authorities all yesterday afternoon and evening, and Spanish watchers looked sharply for an expedition that rumor had said was to be fitted out for a filibustering run to Cuba.

A number of the small boys and girls of the industrial schools of the Children's Aid Society and the Female Guardian Society had what they considered the very best kind of a Memorial Day celebration yesterday.

The revenue of the Government, as provided by acts of Congress, is not sufficient to meet the current expenditures, required also by acts of Congress which call for the payment of money out of the Treasury for various purposes. Congress has declined to increase the revenue by new legislation.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- There was an accident about three years ago at the old Ford's Theatre, occupied by the Government as an office for the record and pension division of the War Department, Several persons were killed and a small number were seriously injured.

-- Herman Keck, a diamond merchant of Cincinnati, was convicted yesterday in the United States District Court at Philadelphia of attempting to smuggle diamonds. Keck was charged with endeavoring to smuggle the jewels from Antwerp on board the American Line steamer Rhynland with the aid of Capt. Frank Loeswitz of that vessel.

The ministers of Long Island City have succeeded, at least for a time, in their efforts to stop prizefighting. Their work resulted in the postponement of the contest between Maher and Slavin, which was to have been decided at the Eureka Athletic Club last night. They may have been aided in this by Gov. Morton's prompt action in notifying Sheriff Doht of Queens County that the law must be observed.

EAST ST. LOUIS, May 29. -- East St. Louis is waking from its stupor of terror and things are beginning to shape themselves to the amelioration of the condition of the afflicted and the preservation of the property left after the storm.

AMBLER, Penn., May 29. -- The destruction wrought by the cyclone yesterday is greater than at first supposed. Below Ambler and Jarrettown, where the storm was the most severe, no less than seventy-five barns, houses, and other buildings are either partly or completely destroyed. The loss will amount to over $100,000.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Before the River and Harbor bill bad been passed and sent to the President, the Senators and Representatives who built it up were of the opinion that it would be vetoed. From them, and not from the White House, came the report that the bill would be disapproved -- and very naturally.
LONDON, May 29. -- Prof. Sir J. Russell Reynolds, M. D. the celebrated English physician, author and lecturer, Physician in Ordinary to her Majesty's Household, died to-day, aged sixty-eight years.

Columbia College class of '98 burned Legendre itself and a dummy professor of Legendre in a lot at Sixty-ninth Street and First Avenue last night; and by means of a band, independent horns, and their throats, they made a lot of noise in the campus and on Madison Avenue, Forty-third Street, Fifth Avenue, and Sixty-ninth Street.
JERSEY CITY, May 29. -- Reports from the country districts of New-Jersey show that the storm, which swept over the State Thursday afternoon was more destructive than at first reported.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 29. -- Memorial Day will be observed to-morrow in all the villages along the Sound. Flowers are unusually abundant. The fields in many places are white with daisies. The locust trees and many wild shrubs are in bloom, so that flowers in any quantity may be had for the mere trouble of gathering them.

Several inovations will mark this year's opening regatta of the Greenville Yact Club to-day, at the foot of Linden Avenue, Jersey City. The course will be a triangular one, instead of a straight run, as heretofore. The distance will be sailed over three times, making a total of a trifle over nine miles. This inside course will permit the race to be watched by all the guests of the club on the shore.

Although many of the theatres of the city are closed for the Summer, there will be plenty of amusement for the theatre-goers to-day. To-night will witness the opening of the roof gardens four of these being announced to begin their season. They are the Madison Square, the Casino, the American, and Proctor's Pleasure Palace.

Chief Surgeon Cook yesterday made a report to the Police Board relative to the accidental shooting of Central Office Detective Adolph Oppenheim. Oppenheim, while running for a car at Forty-second Street and Broadway, April 22, was shot in the leg by his pistol, which fell from his pocket and was discharged.

If we must have invertebrate musical farce, it is well to have it good of its kind. "In Gay New-York," at the Casino, is vivacious, tuneful, and comic. There was enough of it for two performances Thursday night, but where all the stuff is fairly good the task of selection is easily accomplished.

Greater New-York's star road riders submitted to defeat yesterday at the hands of two young men from New-England. R. M. Alexander of the Hartford Wheelmen Won the Irvington-Millburn, the blue-ribbon race of the year, while Monte Scott of Providence landed the time prize and whittled down three course records.
A correspondent of The London Times has this to say about the newly discovered Bronte manuscripts, to which Harold Frederic recently referred in his dispatches to this paper:

From The Nineteenth Century. Of Magyar art, music seems to have gained the widest admiration, and it is certain that musical executants of the first order, and in the case of Liszt of unique grandeur, have justified part of the expectations with which musical Europe has long looked upon Hungary.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 30. -- The honor man, or the first of the graduating class of the Naval Academy, this year is Naval Cadet Richard Hallett Meredith Robinson, He was born at Ravenna, Ohio, on April 2, 1875, and is the son of Judge George F. Robinson of Ravenna. Cadet Robinson took a leading position in his class from his entrance in the academy.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- "Free silver coinage or no tariff" is to be the policy of the silver States in the next Congress, even more emphatically than in the present Congress. The feeling seems to be strong in the Western States that Major McKinley, if elected President, will approve any silver legislation which is sent to him by the Republican majority in the two houses.

The University of Pennsylvania 'Varsity crew defeated the First Bohemian Boat club in the senior eight-oared shell race which was the final event in the programme of the Harlem River Regatta Association, on the Harlem River yesterday afternoon. The victory was won, by a boat's length, and the crowds on both sides of the river gave vent to their enthusiasm in cheers.

ST. LOUIS, May 30. -- Memorial Day in this city and East St. LOUIS was one of funerals. An almost unbroken line of hearses and carriages, laden with mourners, stretched from early morning from the death districts of St. Louis to Calvary and Bellefontaine Cemeteries. One hundred and twenty-eight victims of Wednesday's tornado were buried.

From The Philadelphia Ledger. Instructions have been issued to the heads of all the different departments of the University of Pennsylvania by the Secretary, the Rev. Jesse Y. Burk, to the effect that the Board of Trustees expects a rigid compliance with the new system of academic costume on all official occasions during commencement week.
Yale easily carried off the honors yesterday in the intercollegiate games at Manhattan Field, with 43 1/2 points, the University of Pennsylvania taking second place with 22 1/2 points.

If we must have invertebrate musical farce, it is well to have it good of its kind. "In Gay New-York," at the Casino, is vivacious, tuneful, and comic. There was enough of it for two performances Thursday night, but where all the stuff is fairly good the task of selection is easily accomplished.

The first decision regarding the application of the Raines liquor law to clubs has been rendered by Judge DAVY of the Supreme Court at Rochester, and holds that legitimate, bona fide social clubs are exempt from its operation. The test case at Rochester was brought in a way to avoid proceedings against the club and to expedite adjudication, but it was also the least favorable to the claim for exemption.
Two large auction sales of building lots in the annexed district were held yesterday.

One of the largest crowds ever at Morris Park, possibly the largest, with the single exception of that present on the first Memorial Day that there was racing at the track, was there yesterday. It was a typical holiday crowd, with the clubhouse and club members' seats practically deserted. The "swell mob" as they are familiarly called, were elsewhere, attracted by other sports among the coteries with which they are affiliated.

The members of the Atlantic Yacht Club opened the yachting season with a hurrah yesterday. The red-and-white burgee was hoisted on the big flagstaff in front of the clubhouse and was saluted toy the big fleet of yachts at anchor. Then twenty yachts raced down to the Southwest Spit and back, and seven of them won handsome silver cups for being first in the different classes.
Bicyclists were abroad, yesterday, and, as a result of the general turning out of riders of the silent steed, a number of riders found their way into police courts, and some into hospitals.

From The Quarterly Review. By the death of Lord Derby and the removal of all other possible competitors, Mr. Disraeli had become the acknowledged chief of the Conservative Party; and with a strong and united majority in Parliament, he was, in fact as well as in name, the ruler of the British Empire.
BOSTON, May 30. -- Bald beat Sanger three times at the meet of the Associated Cycle Clubs at the new Charles River Park this afternoon. Fourteen thousand persons witnessed the races.

John P. Townsend, President of the Bowery Savings Bank, has made an interesting contribution to the currency discussion, in showing how depositors in savings banks would be affected by free-silver coinage, The statement was prepared for the Manhattan Club, and was presented at the meeting of that club on Thursday evening.

NEWARK, N. J., May 30. -- The crack Institute Boat Club of this city carried off the honors today in the twenty-second annual regatta of the Passaic River Amateur Rowing Association by winning three races and showing up well in others. The Passaic River was never more placid and the day never brighter than to-day; in fact, the conditions for good racing were superb.
SENECA, Mo., May. 30. -- A tornado, accompanied by a cloudburst, fell upon this place at 7 o'clock last night.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- The principal event of the observance of Decoration Day in Philadelphia was the unveiling this evening in Fairmount Park of a statue of Garfield. The holding of the unveiling ceremonies after nightfall made it possible to give the event a picturesqueness which it would have lacked in the daytime.

LONDON, May 30. -- Although there has been something like civil war in Crete for months back and the garrison of some thousand Turkish regular troops has actually been besieged inside the fortress of Vamos by five or six thousand armed Cretans since March, Europe has allowed itself to be thrown quite off its balance by a mere street riot in Canea, the political capital of the island.

What EMILE ZOLA has to say in literature nowadays has no great interest. The apostle of "modernity" has become passe. From fierce attack on what was popular in his youth, he has lapsed into querulous defense of what he in his prime made popular, and what, Heaven be thanked! is now far less so.

From The Saturday Review. The two young Austrian, Princes who, by the death of their father, Archduke Charles Louis, are brought into the line of immediate succession, bear a popular ill repute which would have been excessive even in the Munich or Stuttgart of a generation ago.

Honolulu Letter to The Washington Star. For some days we have been waiting with considerable interest, and even anxiety, to learn in what direction our greater volcano of Mauna Loa, now in very active eruption, may vomit forth its desolating lava stream.

From London Truth. A novel and interesting question of medical etiquette was raised in the Brighton Bankruptcy Court the other day. One doctor had made an affidavit to the effect that a bankrupt named William Roser was too ill to attend the court; that his nervous system was shattered, and that he was not likely to recover unless the probability of such an ordeal as a public examination was removed.
MOSCOW, May 30. -- A terrible accident, resulting in the loss of about 1,100 lives, occurred here to-day.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 30. -- No soldiers' monument in Westchester County, it is safe to say, was more lavishly decorated to-day than was the monument of "Tom" Paine, that stands at the right of North Street, a mile and a half from the village.

From The Auburn Advertiser, May 27. The story of the depredations perpetrated by the Earl gang of highway robbers who operated extensively in this vicinity fifteen years ago was recalled to-day by the announcement of his mother's death in faraway Kansas and subsequent proceedings to contest her will.

Mark M. Pomeroy, the well-known newspaper man, died at his home, Fifty-sixth Street and Fourteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning. He was taken ill with valvular heart disease and dropsy about last Christmas. He had a severe attack a month ago, and at that time it was feared that his death would result at any moment.
ALBANY, May 30. -- The body of a man of forty, who was shot in the heart and back of the right ear, was found in Washington Park early this morning. If had evidently been there all night.

We publish, this morning the speech of Mr. JOHN P. TOWNSEND, President of the Bowery Savings Bank, delivered on the 28th at the Manhattan Club. It is a striking statement of the value, the necessity, of the gold standard to the depositors in savings banks. The gold standard of value is the best that can now be had.

Edward E. Bruner, a son-in-law of United States Senator Stephen B. Elkins, died late Friday afternoon at his home, 48 West Fifty-ninth Street. His death is attributed to rheumatism of the heart. It is believed that a bicycle ride which he took last Monday was responsible for his death.

LONDON, May 30. -- The British Consul at Canea, Crete, the scene or serious fighting between Christians and Turks, has telegraphed details of the trouble to the Foreign Office, confirming the worst accounts of the fighting in the streets. Though order has been temporarily restored, the people of the town and in the country around about are preparing for further trouble.

-- There was a serious accident on the Western New-York and Pennsylvania yesterday morning north of Ebenezer Station, N. Y. The second section of freight train No. 143. consisting of eighteen coal cars and an engine, was wrecked by the breaking of a wheel, and was piled up along the tracks. Brakeman Porter Pierce of this city was caught in the wreck and instantly killed.
Decoration Day, 1896, will go on record as a red-letter day. both as a memorial day and as a general holiday for the people.

James Le Baron Johnson, for several years lay reader in Grace Chapel, on East Fourteenth Street, was ordained a deacon in the Episcopal Church yesterday morning by the Right Rev. Bishop Potter. Mr. Johnson had been in retreat since Thursday at St. Philip's Church, Garrisons-on-the-Hudson.
The exercises at Carnegie Hall last evening, which closed the Grand Army memorial programme, drew a large crowd of people.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 30. -- The Seventh, New-York's crack regiment, turned out in full force to witness the baseball game that took place on the parade grounds here this afternoon with the cadets. The early morning trains and boats brought large numbers of enthusiasts, who came fully prepared to "root " for their favorites. Krom Poughkeepsie, Newburg, and Peekskill delegations of uniformed boys and girls arrived early.

BOSTON, May 30. -- Princeton defeated Harvard this afternoon on Holmes's Field in the greatest college baseball game on record. It lasted for sixteen innings, when Princeton gained two runs, ending the game. The final score was 8 to 6.

E. E. Rice is making preparations for the opening of the large circus pavilion adjoining the fireworks at Manhattan Beach. His circus at the beach last Summer was fine, but he intends to surpass it this year. The pavilion has been remodeled and newly decorated.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., May 30. -- The Crescent Wheelmen of this city held a successful race meet at their track, the Crescent Oval. The crowd was a very large one, filling the grand stand and the vacant space around the track. The track was in good condition. There were a number of falls, but no one was seriously injured.

From Macmillan's Magazine. A terrible trial came for the packets on the outbreak of the American war in 1812, The French privateers, well-found though they were and manned with desperate men, were child's play to the American, which were twice as powerful and manned by English deserters.

John. L. White, Vice President, Treasurer, and Manager of the White Locomotive Works, was arrested Friday night in his office at 150 Nassau Street, the charge against him being the larceny of $29,200.

The Cambridge (England) Independent Press retells the story of the hoax perpetrated upon the civic and university authorities at Cambridge on the occasion of the visit of the late Shah of Persia to this country. It was on Saturday, June 28, 1873, at 11 o'clock in the forenoon, that a telegram was found lying on the hallkeeper's table in the Guildhall.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 30. -- An offer of a large marble statue has been made to Princeton University by Dr. J. Ackerman Coles in a letter to President Patton, in which he says:
To the Editor of The New-York Times: Congress doesn't care a straw for New-York. Many men in that body are disposed to vote against anything they think New-York wants. Why?

LONDON, May 30. -- The match races of the New Thames Tacht Club, from South End to Harwich, were sailed to-day. The sky was cloudy, and there was a contrary tide, with the wind from the northeast. The start was made at 9:55 A. M. In the race for the large raters the Satanita crossed the line 10 seconds ahead of the Britannia, which was followed by the Ailsa, Caress, Isolde, Corsair, and Hester.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- A sub-committee of the House Committee on Indian Affairs gave a hearing yesterday to a delegation of Turtle Mountain (Chippewa) Indians, conspicuous and picturesque in their toggery of feathers and furs.

George Moore in The London Chronicle. Passing from Millet to Millais, I wonder which, were choice offered me, I should choose to be? Should I be tempted to choose, in the race for immortal glory, the eight or ten beautiful pictures which Sir John painted in his youth; or should I choose the life work, so deep and simple and strong in its unwavering faith, of J. F. Millet?

Paris Correspondence in London Truth. The death of M. Cernuschi causes a wide gap in a social sphere of which, the rastaquouere world knew nothing. One found in his house the pick of Parisian, society without the taint of fashionable levity or plutocratic "swagger." Everything there was what it professed to be, and the best of its kind.

From The Baltimore American. Ex-Gov. Brown is arranging his affairs preparatory to his departure for Europe on June 6. He said yesterday that he expected to meet a number of Baltimoreans during his trip abroad. He intends to spend some time in Buda-Pesth, and to study the model street railway of that city.

If the Greater New-York Commission shall succeed in devising a charter under which a business-like administration can be established and maintained, it will have done all it can hope to do and more than it will probably accomplish. This sounds absurdly simple and easy. It is really something very like a lofty ideal.

From The Jackson (Mich.) Patriot. C. P. Dickinson, who left Jackson about fifteen years ago for the far West, is now visiting his grandfather, D. R. Palmer of East Main Street. When he left here his capital amounted to but a small amount. After a decade and a half he returns rated as a millionaire and the owner of property of almost untold value.

From The London News. The Archduke Charles Louis was married three times. His first two wives died in their youth. It was as Governor of the Tyrol in 1856 that he was united to Princess Margaret of Saxony, daughter of the poet King John -- he being twenty-three, she only sixteen.

YONKERS, N. Y., May 30. -- The St. Andrews Golf Club held its Decoration Day handicap match this afternoon. The first prize, known as the Governor's, was valued at 550, the second $20, and the third $10. The grounds were in excellent condition, except that the rain of Thursday left some soft spots. The weather was all that could be desired.

BATH, N. Y., May 30. -- Memorial services were held here to-day under the auspices of General George A. Ouster Post, in the Soldiers' Home Cemetery, in the forenoon, and in the afternoon in the town of Bath, at the Casino.
HONOLULU, May 19. -- Kate Field died here to-day of pneumonia, after a short illness. Her remains will be sent to America.

From The Savannah (Ga.) News. Seventy-seven years ago Tuesday, May 26, the first steamship to cross the Atlantic sailed from Savannah. There are probably few people now living who remember that event.

There has been much talk at Headquarters during the past two days because Capt. Schmittberger of the West One Hundredth Street Station has been assigned to the command of a company in the parade while Capt. Devery of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Station has been refused permission to take part.
WASHINGTON, May 30. -- There are seventeen vacancies on the limited retired list of the army, a larger number than has been available for a long time.

There were over 7,000 persons at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon to see the home team, which is running a winning race with some other clubs from being ranked as first -- counting from the bottom -- do battle with the Louisville men, who have first rank at the tall end beyond dispute.

There were loud cheers yesterday from the two grand stands at Fifth Avenue and Madison Square when Wilbur A. Wood, chaplain of Lafayette Post, inarched briskly past in step in the ranks, supporting his injured leg with a crutch. His appearance was taken as a concrete evidence of the invincible grit which had sent so many men between youth and middle age to the front in the four years of the civil war.
Troop C. Brooklyn's cavalry contingent of the National Guard, and many members of the Twenty-third Regiment yesterday visited the Cuban-American Fair, being held in Madison Square Garden.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 30. -- The Larchmont Yacht Club went into commission at 4 o'clock this afternoon. The harbor was filled with the boats of visiting yachtsmen, and fifty guns or more saluted the colors.

The Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club opened its season yesteuday, and with such a delightful day, a gracious House Committee, and an alert Racing Committee, the auspices were of the pleasantest. The beautiful grounds and the clubhouse surmounting the bluff of Centre Island, overlooking Oyster Bay and its picturesque setting of hill and glade, and verdant nature, seemed never more charming.

From The Detroit Free Press, May 23. Failing to negotiate the new stock issue of $125,000 provided for by the Chamber of Commerce several months ago a mortgage was filed yesterday for $125,000 in order to pay the second mortgage already existing, the amount still due the contractors and the architects and a considerable floating indebtedness.

From The Denver (Col.) News. United States Marshal Israel made a number of interesting observations during his visit last week among the ruins of the cliff dwellers in Southwestern Colorado. Mr. Israel made the trip to the distant region for the purpose of serving papers from the court in this city.

From the Boston Transcript. The burning of the Longfellow cottage at Nahant will be felt by all the Nation, for a house which was a favorite, of the poet is, in a sense, the possession of all who have cared for the poet, and the loss in its burning is not to be estimated in terms of insurance.

From Chambers's Journal. As a fact the finest cider is not made by the British grower, but in Normandy. They have in that province brought cider making to perfection. The total produce every, year there amounts to hundreds of millions of gallons; and it is made with the utmost care.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Several of the leaders of both factions of the Prohibition Party are here on their way home from the Pittsburg Convention. Mr. J. H. Southgate of Charlotte, N. C., who was put on the "bolters'" ticket as Vice President with the Rev. Charles E. Bentley of Lincoln, Neb., the defeated broad-gauge leader, as President, is one of them.

HAVANA, May 30. -- Capt. Gen. Weyler has issued a circular giving instructions to the Spanish military officials to supply rations to the families which have taken refuge in the towns only during the next two months, and ordering the officials to take possession, of all cattle found in the fields of the rural districts.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., May 30. -- The French mission ship St. Pierre, 550 tons, bound from St. Pierre for the Grand Banks, to work among the French fishing fleet engaged there, drove ashore at midnight last night on Cape St. Marys and became a total loss. Her officers and men escaped and were landed at Placentia by a fishing boat, which picked them up.

"For ten years on this day." said Gen. Horace Porter to U. S. Grant Post, No. 327, arid to a great throng of citizens and their wives and children, "it has been our sad pleasure to come here and decorate with the choicest flowers yonder little tomb. On April 26, 1897, the anniversary of Gen. Grant's birthday, his illustrious ashes will have been borne to the magnificent building, there to remain undisturbed until judgment day.
It is an interesting business, she is an interesting woman, and, moreover, she is the only woman in the business in this city, and probably the only woman in the country who is similarly engaged.

Mrs. Annie Cunningham, a widow, living in a flat at 315 East Thirty-seventh Street, left her home at 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning, leaving her daughter, Mary, thirteen years old, in the house. When she returned, at 2:30 P.M., she found her daughter dead in a bedroom back of the parlor, with her head under the bed.

Paris Dispatch in The London Times. From Palermo comes a very interesting piece of news, a really curious incident of contemporary history. The Empress Eugenie, arriving on her yacht, the Thistle, at Palermo, received a visit from the Duc d'Aumale, who has been staying at his property of Lucco.

George Moore in The London Chronicle. It has happened to me on more than one occasion to pick out pictures by painters whose work and whose names were unknown to me, and to praise these pictures in no measured terms. The pleasure of discovery leads one easily into exaggeration. Desire to stretch a helping hand to one who, perchance, is in need of one, tempts the critic into the perilous paths of prophecy.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., May 30. -- The American Yacht Club's fleet at Milton Point went into commission this afternoon at 4 o'clock. Mrs. J. H. Wainwrlght broke out the club flag, which was greeted by cheers from the 100 guests and members on the club lawn, and by a salute from the boats in the harbor.

A well-known Russian (writes the Moscow correspondent of The London Times) who was recently asked by a foreigner why so much fuss was made over the coronation of the Czar, replied by simply reminding his interlocutor that Russia had more than 10,000 miles of Asiatic frontier.

BAYONNE, N.J., May 30. -- The games of the New-Jersey Athletic Club at Bayonne this afternoon were successful and entertaining, although no records were shattered. The quarter-mile cinder path was not fast. In the various events enough starters put in an appearance to make the races lively, several heats being required, in some events.

There are differences of opinion among real state men as to the discussion in the Presbyterian Assembly of the advisability of selling the mission building at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Twentieth Street. This large office building stands on the site of the mansion where dwelt Mr. Robert L. Stuart, who was one of the great benefactors of the denomination in his lifetime and by his will.

LINCOLN, Neb., May 31.--The Democrats of Nebraska are divided on the questions of the currency and the merits of fusion, and the rupture will have a marked effect in the campaign, probably on both the National and State tickets.

LONDON, May 31.--The Johannesburg Standard telegraphs that the release of all the members of the Reform Committee, with the exception of Messrs. Rhodes, Hammond, Farrar, and Phillips, the four leaders, who were originally condemned to death, has caused widespread rejoicing in the Transvaal and elsewhere in South Africa.

WEST POINT, May 31.--The annual June examinations will begin to-morrow. They will be held in the new Academic Building. Lieuts, Berry and Russell have been appointed Secretaries of the first and second committees, respectively.

The McKinley pall hung over the stock market all the week, the result being average losses of more than 1 per cent., with exceptional declines in Sugar, Consolidated Gas, General Electric, Manhattan, Louisville and Nashville, Burlington, and St. Paul. The volume of trading was the lightest of any week this year.

The First Presbyterian Church was profusely decorated last evening in honor of the wedding of Miss Mabel Augusta Longstreet and James Hanson Kerr. The ceremony was performed at 8 o'clock by the Rev. Dr. Howard Duffield, pastor of the church, in the presence of a large and fashionable gathering.

ST. LOUIS, June 17.--"Only a snicker; don't sweat yourself to death." This was the advice of the palm-fan dealers who stopped the way of the convention-goers this afternoon. It was good advice and appropriate to the weather. The day had begun with murky clouds overhead, a drizzle of rain, and a broken sky toward noon.

A column of Government troops came to the assistance of the volunteers and the fight was continued...

Nearly the whole of yesterday's session of the trial of the suit for $65,000 brought by Dayid Belasco, the playwright, against Nathaniel Kellogg Fairbank, the Chicago millionaire, in Part V. of the Supreme Court, was consumed in the examination and cross-examination of the defendant.

Joseph L. Parraga, fire and marino in surance agent and broker, at 35 Liberty Street, made an assignment yesterday to John Apdrews, without preference. No particulars of the assignment could be learned at his office yesterday. It was said that he had not been there for several days on account of illness.His home...

It is without prejudice to the hostility with which all right-minded persons must regard the operation of trolley lines in Brooklyn that we call attention to the innovation of " trolley express cars " in that long-suffering suburb. As a matter of fact, the so-called " city express " service throughout the present domain of the...

The Democratic Party in Kings County has selected the following delegates to represent it at the Democratic State Convention to be held at Saratoga. It is said by the regulars that the delegates whose names are given below will not be recognized, because they put an independent ticket in the field last November, thereby...

ST. LOUIS, June 17.--The Republican ticket for 1896 will be in nomination by Thursday night. The platform already has been agreed to, and McKinley will be the candidate for President on a gold Platform.

--Adolph Fromm, Wholesale and retail liquer leader at 2,661 English Avenue, made an assignment yesterday to Juhus A. Mandel, without preference The shenit yesterday received two attachment against Mr. Fromm, one in favor of the California Wine Association. for $2,284, and one in favor of A. A. Wolf Co., for $3,593 They were obtained by Rose Putzel...

The effect of President Cleveland's summary of the financial question of the campaign, his clear definition of the duty of Democrats, and his warnings against the free-silver fallacy were marked yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- Maine was the second State to offer a Presidential candidate.

A report was circulated last night that Miss Grace Wilson and Cornelius Vanderbilt, Jr., had been married at 6 o'clock P.M. at the Vanderbilt home, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, but it was promptly denied by the fathers of the young people.

In a collision between a cable car and a surrey at Thirty-third Street and Third Avenue about noon yesterday Conductor Andrew Gilroy's legs were badly injured and three of the legs of the horse attached to the carriage were broken. Gilroy was removed to Bellevue Hospital, and the horse was shot.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- Senator Lodge of Massachusetts made the motion that the convention proceed to the nomination of the candidate for Vice President. He also moved that the nominating speeches be limited to five minutes. There were some cries of "No, no!" but when Chairman Thurston put the question it was carried almost unanimously.

The death of the late Joseph Smith of Chester suggested to Col. George C. Gilmore of this city the idea of looking up the Smiths who served in the Continental armies from New-Hampshire. As a result he has handed The Union a partial list.

SYNOPSIS. Mrs. Francisco is a woman reporter on The Leader, a newspaper in a river town. She has been assigned to report the Sunday picnic of the "Twenty-Sevens," a tough gang, at the island down the river. Word comes by telephone to the city editor, who does nut like her, that there has been a fight at the island, and he is obliged to send his rival, Merrilees, to look after her.
ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- Mr. Platt was seen at the Southern Hotel this evening after the convention, and made the following statement:

ANDOVER, Mass., June 18 -- Commencement exercises occurred at Phillips Academy to-day, when diplomas were presented to the largest graduating class in the history of the academy -- 102 in the classical and 38 in the scientific department.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., June 18 -- The Democratic State Convention this morning nominated William T. Jeter for Lieutenant Governor, and instructed the delegates to the National Convention at Chicago to vote as a unit on the silver question. A resolution was adopted instructing the delegates to Chicago to place in nomination for the Presidency Stephen M. White of California should a favorable opportunity arise.

The end of the long Fleming trial is at last in sight, and there will be few to regret its conclusion. The woman in black is beginning to show signs of the strain to which she has been subjected, and she doubtless hopes for a speedy ending of the trial.

The name of Mr. McKINLEY first became widely known to his countrymen during the term of the Fifty-first Congress -- 1889-91. He had then been in the House of Representatives some twelve years. At the opening of the first session in 1889 he was a candidate, with Mr. CANNON of Illinois and Mr. REED of Maine, for the Speakership.
In his comment on the Sherman Statue affair, Mr. Boynton, who takes, I am sorry to say, an entirely wrong position in his Washington, letter, makes this statement:

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 18 -- The crews are having ideal weather for their practice on the Hudson. Again to-day the river for miles north and south of Poughkeepsie was as smooth as glass. Nine eights were out at one time, making a picture which gladdened the hearts of lovers of aquatic sports.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., June 18 -- When the news of Mr. McKinley's victory was received over the private wire in the residence of Gov. Morton, the Governor, who had been close to the instrument all day, leaned back in his chair and said: "McKinley is nominated, and the next President has been named."

NEW-HAVEN, June 18 -- The first intercollegiate boat race ever rowed between the East and the West took place this afternoon on Lake Salstonstall, four miles from here, and the West won. The ntestants were the University of Wisconsin and the Yale freshmen. The Westerners took the lead at the pistol shot, and were not headed till the flag was dropped at the finish by the judge.

From The San Francisco Call. The records in the office of the Board of Harbor Commissioners present an interesting history of the efforts made by it to discover a teredo-proof pile. It has sought long and earnestly for such a device, but the claims made-by inventors of so-called teredo-proof piles have been found, when put to a practical test, to be of little or no value.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- The great demonstration of the convention came when ex-Gov. Foraker, in the course of his speech nominating the Ohio candidate, for the first time spoke McKinley's name. It lasted twenty-eight minutes. The demonstration at Minneapolis, when the attempt was made to stampede to Blaine, lasted about twenty minutes.

PATERSON, N.J., June 18 -- This city is wild with delight over the nomination of Garret A. Hobart. He is popular with every one here, and all classes are parading the streets to-night and all the fireworks in the city have been burned.

The Nail Pool, which has increased the price of cut nails by 228 per cent. and that of wire nails by 200 per cent, fortified itself two or three days ago by making terms with three or four outside manufacturers who had begun to undersell the ring price list. The conciliation of these outsiders is now announced by the journals of the iron trade.

In another month we shall be in the height of the American season, and, indeed, many of our cousins from the other side of the Atlantic are here already. We are always glad to see them, first, on the ground of kinship, and, second -- which is a frank admission -- because they add to the volume of business in various directions.

The following private letter received by a gentleman in this city from Prof. Hazen of the Weather Bureau will be of interest. It is certainly desirable that the Government should begin at once a thorough investigation of the causes of these outbursts, and, it possible, devise means to protect the country from their ravages:

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- When New-York State was reached on the roll call there was a ripple of applause, and William A. Sutherland arose and was recognized. As soon as he could be heard, Mr. Sutherland made an announcement which brought another burst.

ST. LOUIS, June 18. -- The nomination of the Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates by the Republican National Convention followed the exciting incidents in connection with the adoption of the platform. The only intervening business was the call of the roll for members of the National Committee.
Sixteen bids wore submitted to Controller Fitch for the purchase of $1,283,909.84 of 3 1/2 per cent. gold bonds and stock of New-York City. These bonds are to be issued for the following purposes:

NEWARK, N.J., June 18 -- James Jameison, a brakeman on the Pennsylvania Railroad, kidnapped his two children, Sadie, aged eight, and Martin, aged five, this morning, and the police of several cities are now searching for him and the little ones. Jameison and his wife have not lived together for some time.

While riding a bicycle in Madison Avenue, between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets, yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Edna Poirier was run over by a heavily laden feed car of the Madison Avenue Line. Less than two hours later she died in the Flower Hospital. She was about thirty years old, and lived with her husband at 453 West Twenty-first Street.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- The roll call on the nomination followed Foraker's speech for McKinley. Madison Vance of Louisiana made the motion to proceed with this, and it was ordered with as much enthusiasm and listened to with as close attention as could have been expected when it is considered that the only thing to be determined by it was the precise vote Major McKinley would receive.

The Rev. Dr. Thomas P. Hughes, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Sepulchre, in Seventy-fourth Street, near Park Avenue, who was accused by a Sunday school pupil, Mary Glavek, of improper conduct toward her, is the a peculiar position, which, he says, he does not relish.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 18 -- The report that Joseph Banigan, ex-President of the Rubber Trust, has purchased the Saxon Woolen Mills property for the purpose of turning the plant into a rubber-goods factory, was again revived to-day. Both Mr. Banigan and Mr. Fletcher, the owner of the Saxon Mills, are out of town, and the rumor could not be verified.

The tenth annual commencement exercises of the Hebrew Technical Institute took place last night in the large hall of the Cooper Institute. When the Rev. Dr. K. Kohler stepped forward on the platform to deliver the opening prayer, every seat in the auditorium was occupied, and hundreds of men and women were standing in the space behind the seats and in the aisles.
Mr. M. Kamak has sold for the Marshall estate at $105,000 the five-story flat on the southeast corner of Columbus Avenue and One Hundred and Fifth Street, 47.6 by 100.11.
"The devil! He's in this school, and he's going to kill us an the teachers!"

The Jews occupy quite a special and peculiar position among the heterogeneous races in Russia. In the Moscow period Jews were not admitted into the country. During the reign of Peter the Great no general laws concerning the Jews were passed but the ukase of 1727 decreed the expulsion of all Jews from Russia, and forbade them to return hither.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- One of the mysteries of New-York politics in the future will be whether Gov. Morton could have been nominated for the Vice Presidency to-day or not. Mr. Platt says the nomination could have been made. Mr. Miller says it could not.

NYACK, N.Y., June 18 -- A fashionable yellow-and-blue wedding took place in Grace Church at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon. The bridegroom was Leroy Frost of South Nyack and the bride Miss Marion Lydecker Towt. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Franklin Babbitt, rector of Grace Church, assisted by the Rev. W.J. Leggett, pastor of the Reformed Church.
The English Consul for Genoa, in his annual report to the Foreign Office, makes the following observations:

PARIS, June 18 -- The following article, published by Perry Belmont in the Paris Temps the principal diplomatic organ of Europe, is having an excellent effect in correcting false and unfavorable impressions on the Continent concerning the attitude of the United States Government:

CHICAGO, June 18 -- But little trading was done in the market to-day. Transactions in the Moore stocks largely predominated. Diamond Match declined at 224 1/2, advanced to 225 1/2, and closed at 224 2/4. New-York Biscuit closed weak at 96 1/4 @ 96 5/8, after opening at 97 1/2. Bank clearings were $15,984,951. Money loaned at 5@5 1/2 per cent. on call, and 5 1/2 @6 per cent. on time.

LONDON, June 18 -- In its issue to-morrow The Daily News will congratulate the Republicans of the United States, if not on their candidate, at least on their refusal to have anything to do with a delusion.

Nearly 500 members of the theatrical profession gathered in Scottish Rite Hall yesterday afternoon to attend the first meeting of the Actors' Society, which was in-, corporated under the laws of the State of New-York May 13 of the present year.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 18 -- Two of society's prettiest girls, Miss Alice Blight and Miss Daisy Patterson, who have just returned from, Europe, joined their parents here to-night.

QUEENSTOWN, June 18 -- The races of the Royal Cork Yacht Club regatta to-day were sailed in bright sunshine and under a strong south-westerly breeze. The yachts carried jibheaded topsails and whole mainsails.

It was in the year 1750, or thereabouts, that James and William McKinley, brothers, of Scotch-Irish, blood, came to this country from the North of Ireland. The two young men soon drifted apart, William becoming the founder of the southern branch of the family, while James settled in York County, Penn.

UTICA, N.Y., June 18 -- The boilers of the pleasure steamer Hon. Titus Sheard exploded while the boat was carrying passengers from Little Falls to the bicycle races at Taylor Driving Park, one mile west of the city, at 2 o'clock this afternoon. Eighteen persons were on board at the time.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 -- The feature of the local market to-day has been the iron stocks. The rest of the list continued dull and heavy throughout the entire day. In the industrials Pennsylvania Heat preferred declined to 20 7/8. The common also sold off fractionally. Storage common, after selling at 30 1/2, declined to 29, and on what looked like good buying orders, advanced to 29 1/2.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Occasionally during to-day's session the wheat market was moderately active, but in the aggregate business was slow and not particularly important. Prices ruled higher at the start, but offerings soon asserted their superiority and prices declined. The crowd had loaded up in anticipation of a bulge resulting from the action of the Republicans at St. Louis, but, finding no enthusiasm on the subject, sold freely.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- Senator Cannon of Utah, young, handsome, and unembarrassed, took his place beside the Chairman as soon as the vote adopting the gold plank had been announced, and was permitted to address the convention on a question of privilege. He read from manuscript what proved to be the formal declaration of the withdrawal from the convention of the delegates from the silver States.

The supplementary proceedings to discover why James Appleton Morgan should not pay $689.65 to Edward L. Stevens was continued yesterday morning in the library if the City Hall before City Court Judge Lewis J. Conlan, sitting in Chambers.

The most sensational thing about the races at the Gravesend track yesterday was the time that was made in the race for three-year-olds, in the Hempstead Handicap. It was a run of six furlongs, and there were four starters. Margrave of August Belmont's string was the favorite in the speculation, but there were many who had a wager on "Jack" McDonald's filly, Intermission, to beat the colt.

The forty-fourth annual commencement exercises of the College of the City of New-York were held last night at Carnegie Hall. Thirty-eight graduates received the degree of Bachelor of Arts and forty-three that of Bachelor of Science.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- The most sensational incident of the day came when Senator Cannon had ceased talking. Teller and Cannon shook hands with the Chairman and walked down the main aisle. Teller was weeping. Tears stood in Cannon's eyes. One by one, Dubois, Pettigrew, Hartman, and the other bolters joined the procession which was led by the Colorado Senator.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- Chairman Thurston found it impossible to call the convention to order at 10 o'clock to-day. There were thousands of empty seats. Not more than half of the delegates were on the floor. It was with the best intentions that Mr. Thurston called upon a singing quartet to entertain the crowd while the seats were filling.

A suit brought by Edward E. Huber against Erastus Wiman and David Bennett King to set aside the assignment made by Mr. Wiman on May 16, 1893, and for the appointment of a receiver for Mr. Wiman's property was begun in the Supreme Court yesterday before Justice Smyth.

Alfred T. White, who was Commissioner of City Works in Brooklyn during Mayor Schieren's administration, has presented to the city more than he received from it during his two years of hard work. The salary of Commissioner of City Works is $6,000 a year. For the two years he was in that position he received $12,000.

LONDON, June 18 -- A deputation of members of the International Arbitration League, including Sir John Robert Mowbray, member of the House of Commons for the University of Oxford, and a number of other distinguished gentlemen called upon Lord Salisbury at the Foreign Office to-day.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- The average St. Louis man strolling up and into the convention, hall this, morning remarked: "Cold wave is breaking." The average New-Yorker, with a fan in one hand and a handkerchief in the other, wearing a two-dollar coat of towel cloth and no vest, remarked, in the words of the poet: "Good Lord, how hot it grows!"

Washington Letter to The Boston Transcript. Mrs. Cleveland introduced a clever innovation at the last ladies' luncheon which she gave at the White House. She enjoys this form of entertaining better than any other, and tries to invent new things for the pleasure of her guests. On this occasion the novelty was an assortment of various kinds of flowers for eating.

At the special levee in the Kremlin during the coronation fetes it was stipulated that every personage, whatever his rank or creed, should uncover before the Czar. The presence of quasi-royal feudatories like the Amir of Bokhara suggested this unusual decree, no doubt.

A team of horses attached to one of the wagons of the National Express Company fell into a street excavation about 10 feet square and ten feet deep, in front of the American Express Company's stables, at 8 Hubert Street, yesterday afternoon, and nearly killed Thomas Sullivan, thirty years old, a laborer, of 253 Mulberry Street, who was working in the bottom of the pit.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- A bolt from a Republican Convention is a new thing. Democratic Conventions have furnished sensational spectacles of this sort, attended by tumult and all the customary demonstrations provoked by the delegates who thus approve or disapprove of such a course of procedure.

I have received the following letter from a lady at Cambridge, giving an account of a very peculiar cycle malady. She particularly desires to know whether other cyclists have ever suffered fom the same unpleasant affection.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- One of the measures which failed to pass the House at the late session of Congress, was the bill to advance Major Gen. Miles to the grade of Lieutenant General of the United States Army. Mr. Hull of Iowa, the Chairman of the Military Committee, reported, the bill favorably early last April.

All of the members of the Board of Managers of the Joint Traffic Association were present yesterday at the hearing given to general passenger agents on applications for differentials on east-bound passenger business. Horace J. Hayden, Chairman of the board, presided.

The New-York and Brooklyn series of baseball games always attracts a goodly crowd, and the first played this year at Eastern Park yesterday was no exception. There were many young women present, and they became as excited as the old-time crank when the Brooklyns tied the score in the ninth inning.

One young woman who makes her appearance daily in the little group which gathers about the close of the market at the north end of the Board of Trade corridor has selected an unusual calling. She is the representative of a cooperage concern, and sells and buys staves and heading.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- Among the first pilgrims to pay their respects to Major McKinley at Canton will be a party of New-Yorkers, who will leave here early to-morrow morning for Canton and remain there a few hours. It will include Cornelius N. Bliss, Gen. C.H.T. Collis, Gen. Anson G. McCook, Col. S.V.R. Cruger, William Brookfield, Gen. Horace Porter, Lloyd Collis, and Henry C. Robinson.

CANTON, Ohio, June 18 -- The fire bells at 5:19 this afternoon struck 918, the number of the delegates in the Republican National Convention; the big cannon on the bluff back of the watch factory boomed and boomed again, and Canton knew that McKinley was a candidate for the Presidency.

ORANGE, N.J., June 18 -- The Washington National League baseball players came to Orange this afternoon and struck a Tartar in the team of the Orange Athletic Club, whom they met at the Orange Oval in one of the closest and prettiest games of the season. The National Leaguers were outplayed, and after ten hardfought innings went off the field vanquished by a score of 5 to 4.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 18 -- Outside the Convention Hall to-day St. Louis has taken on its wonted aspect of peacefulness and indolence. The busy, pushing throngs that crowded streets and hotels in the central section last night have melted away. During the sessions of the convention the streets have been comparatively deserted, while the hotel lobbies have not been so quiet for ten days.

From The Chicago Tribune. Since the death of Emory A. Storrs Chicagoans have been looking for some one on whom the mantle of the great orator might fittingly fall. Many now think that honor is due Henry D. Estabrook, who delivered the oration on the occasion of the dedication of the Franklin Monument in Lincoln Park a week ago.

Five members of the United States Senate lounged in armchairs in an up-stairs parior of the Hoffman House yesterday as they listened vainly for any evidence which might convict some one -- either a Cabinet officer or a financier -- of having done something legally or morally wrong in the heroic and successful effort to preserve the National credit unimpaired during the negotiation and completion of the gold sale contract in January and February, 1895.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A review of American trade with Asia will tie incorporated in the next monthly summary of the Bureau of Statistics of the Treasury Department, which will have special interest in view of the discussion of the effects of Japanese competition with American manufactures.

Undoubtedly the German Emperor's new Meteor is a fast boat, especially in light airs, as might be expected. Her designer has sacrificed everything to "muscle" -- that is to say, to modeling and ballasting her so that she can carry an inordinate spread of canvas. It is not perhaps the most scientific way of designing, but under existing conditions it seems to be the most effective.

Justice Pryor, in the Supreme Court, gave a divorce and his good wishes for her future to Ray Rockwell, an actress, yesterday morning, when she appeared before him in her action against Charles F. Rockwell.

The Republicans of the United States, assembled by their representatives in National convention, appealing for the popular and historical justification of their claims to the matchless achievements of thirty years of Republican rule, earnestly and confidently address themselves to the awakened intelligence, experience, and conscience of their countrymen in the following declaration of facts and principles:
"Why, this is worse than it was when Harrison was nominated," said a prominent politician last night, "and there was no enthusiasm then."

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- If one may judge by its effects to-day, the bolting spirit is a bad one to cultivate. It seems to develop pugnaciousness. A bolter seems to become opinionated. The habit grows on him. Having once bolted he looks upon a bolt as a panacea for all his political ills and uses it on other occasions.

Paris Dispatch to The London Times. Paris is covered with flags. Throughout the city the cafes, public buildings, and a considerable number of private houses are adorned from roof to pavement with the French and Russian flags. At the last moment the Government decided to illuminate the public buildings, and to-night Paris is brilliantly en fete.

ORANGE, N.J., June 18 -- One of the most noteworthy and fashionable, yet withal one of the simplest and most unpretentious, wedding's to take place here this year was solemnized at noon to-day in the Church of the Holy Communion, South Orange, when Miss Eleanor Cross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Cross, and Prof. Allan Marquand of Princeton University were united in marriage.

One of the largest race meets ever held in New-Jersey will be that of the Atalanta Wheelmen at Waverly Park, near Newark, on Saturday afternoon. A total of 229 individual entries has been recorded, making, as designated, 600 nominations for the several events. This is a remarkably large list, and comprising, as it does, all the crackajacks in the metropolitan district, the sport ought to be of the gilt-edge variety.

Gen. William Henry Dimond of San Francisco died at the Gilsey House, Twenty-ninth Street and Broadway, at 7:30 o'clock yesterday morning. Gen. Dimond had suffered for several months from a complication of disorders, and was on his way to Europe to obtain relief, but was stricken on his arrival here Tuesday.

Mrs. Leslie Carter, the heroine of "The Ugly Duckling" theatrical venture, was the star witness in the trial yesterday before Justice Giegerich in the Supreme Court of the suit of David Belasco, the playwright, against Nathaniel Kellogg Fairbank, the aged Chicago millionaire, for the recovery of $65,000 for training Mrs. Carter to become an actress.
ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- William McKinley of Ohio was nominated this afternoon as the candidate of the Republican Party for President, and Garret A. Hobart of New-Jersey was named for Vice President.

All believers in the plan of including in one great municipality the territory already known as Greater New-York will rejoice at such an extension of the regulated civil service system as will take the control of all offices subordinate to the heads of departments and all employments under the City Government, down to that of the humblest laborers, out of politics.

BALTIMORE, June 18. -- The Maryland Institute is one of the largest and oldest art and mechanical schools in the country, and is by far the largest in the South. It has graduated some of the best artists and sculptors and architects of the past half century, and it has been a very valuable influence in the city of Baltimore.

BREST, June 18 -- A representative of The United Press obtained an interview to-day with the two members of the crew of the sunken steamer Drummond Castle, who were picked up at Ile de Molene. One of the men is a seaman named Godbolt, belonging in Yarmouth, and the other is named Wood, a native of London, who was the quarter-master of the Drummond Castle.

Two burglars, whose work evinced that they knew their business entered the apartments of John R. Bellis, on the first floor of 6 West Sixty-sixth Street, some time between 9 o'clock A.M. and 4 o'clock P.M. Wednesday. According to Mr. Bellis, the thieves stole goods valued at about $1,000. Detectives of the West Sixty-eighth Street Police Station are at work on the case.

NORWALK, June 18 -- The annual ten-mile road race of the Alpha Wheel Club was run this morning. The winner was W.A. Gunther of this city, who finished in 27:57 4-5, and captured first time prize. Second time prize was taken by H.H. Leopold of Bridgeport, while T.C. Neilson of Port Chester won second prize, and R.F. Cotter of Norwalk the third.

George J. Gould, Russell Sage, and their counsel, Julien T. Davies, appeared at the meeting of the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday, and at the close of a public hearing, at which nothing of importance was done, went into secret conference with the Commissioners, the result of which could be learned only to a very general and vague extent.

Havana Letter in The London Times. Once again I must refer to the accusations of cruelty made against the Spanirds by the Cubans and their friends. Newspapers in the United States publish repeatedly stories of such atrocious barbarities perpetrated under the Spanish regime, and commited by Spanish officers, that the Spaniards would be deservedly placed outside the pale of civilization if one-half of the charges formulated were true.

From The Fort Washakie (Wyom.) Indian Guide. Not long ago, I read a very interesting article on "Unrecognized Heroes." It called to mind something I had heard that perhaps will be of interest on this subject as well as a revelation to some of your readers.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 19 -- The suit of Richard Burnett and Frederick P. Klenke against the village of New-Rochelle, the Board of Trustees of the Village of New-Rochelle, and the Westchester Electric Railroad Company -- the "Huckleberry Road" -- was before Justice J.O. Dykman of the Supreme Court here to-day.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 19 -- The Democratic State Convention at 12:40 o'clock this morning elected Senator James Jones, Senator James H. Berry, Carroll Armstrong, and J.T.W. Tiller delegates at large to the National Convention. At a late hour the following platform was unanimously adopted:

ST. LOUIS, June 19 -- Chauncey M. Depew of New-York never will have a better opportunity to contest for a Vice Presidential nomination than was presented to him yesterday. It was a part of the wellfounded gossip about the Southern Hotel last night that an earnest effort was made at one stage of yesterday's proceedings to induce Mr. Depew to permit his name to go before the convention for second place.

The sound-money men of the Democratic Party are looking to William C. Whitney as the natural leader of the single standard in the Chicago Convention. He has received since Wednesday letters from conspicuous men of Massachusetts, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Michigan, New-Hampshire, and New-Jersey, thanking him for his determination to battle against the freesilver forces.

The will of Mary A. Livingston, widow of Rear Admiral John W. Livingston of the United States Navy, was filed in the office of the Surrogate yesterday. There is no petition with the will, and the exact value of the estate is not known.

Peter Otto's new stable has aroused the residents on Jackson Avenue to a state of mind which forebodes trouble for him should he return to his former residence on that thoroughfare. Mr. Otto moved to Mount Kisco last May, and soon after his removal plans were filed for the building of the new barn.
The correspondent of The Iron Age at Birmingham, Ala., sends to that journal the following account of a significant sale of American iron in Europe:
CANTON, Ohio, June 19 -- The McKinley League of New-York, which included the seventeen McKinley delegates from that State, burst in upon the Republican candidate this afternoon.

Steps were taken yesterday to procure the indictment of the Rev. Dr. Thomas P. Hughes, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Sepulchre, on charges that have been made by Mary Slavek, the young Normal College pupil who accuses him of assault.

SARATOGA, June 19 -- The thirtieth annual session of the Master Car Builders' Association will close to-day. At the morning session S.P. Bush of Columbus, Ohio, reported on metal for brake shoes, laboratory test. In making this report, he said the committee to which the matter was referred conferred with the Executive Committee of the Committee on Road Tests of Brake Shoes of 1895.

The Rev. Dr. H. Allen Tupper, formerly pastor of the Seventh Baptist Church, has completed his circuit of the globe and returned to his home in Baltimore after an absence of eight months. His experiences as a "globe trotter" will be described by him in a series of books and magazine articles.

PART I. When the King was in his twentieth year the campaign of the Agua Alta occurred. Upon resigning command of the army had promised Pepeta that my fighting days were over, but from the time that the first gun was fired I fretted and chafed. My oranges and grapes no longer engrqssed me, the rose garden was untouched, and the Henequin aloes went to pole unheeded.

The trial of the suit of David Belasco, playwright, against Nathaniel Kellogg Fairbank, Chicago millionaire, for the recovery of $65,000 for training Mrs. Leslie Carter as an actress and putting her on the stage, which has been going on before Justice Giegerich and a jury in the Supreme Court for the last three weeks, was concluded yesterday, so far as the taking of testimony is concerned.
Magistrate Flammer, sitting in the Centre Street Police Court, yesterday was called on to decide a Knotty question. It involved the ownership of a dress suit, for which there were two claimants.

Police Commissioner Roosevelt was among the first arrivals at the Mayor's office yesterday morning, where the hearing on the charges against Police Commissioner Parker was resumed. In the lapel of Mr. Roosevelt's coat was fastened an ivory-colored button, as large as a silver dollar, bearing the portraits of McKinley and Hobart.
The phrase "physical impossibility" has become a sort of standing joke now on the north side.

The Brooklyn baseball players paid their first visit to the Polo Grounds yesterday and defeated the New-York Club by a score of 8 to 2. Sullivan pitched for the home team, while Daub was in the box for the visitors. It was a pitcher contest throughout. Sullivan held the Brooklyn team down to six hits, but they bunched them, and scored 3 earned runs.

FRIDAY -- P.M. Political partisans will probably claim that the strength in to-day's market was due entirely to the results reached in the Republican Convention at St. Louis yesterday. There can be no doubt that the adoption of the gold plank was a long step in advance, but there are few among the banking community who would not have preferred any one of the other prominent candidates to Mr. McKinley.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 19 -- The Rev. and Mrs. Roderick Terry of New-York arrived from that city for the season to-day, and until their cottage is opened they will be guests of Henry G. Marquand.
George R. Bidwell called on Gov. Morton at Ellerslle two days ago, and invited him to preside over the McKinley ratification meeting that is to be held in Carnegie Music Hall Tuesday evening.
DUBUQUE, Iowa, June 19 -- Senator Allison has made the following statement with reference to the action of the St. Louis Convention:

ST. LOUIS, June 19 -- Congressman Grosvenor of Ohio, who has been one of Mr. McKinley's principal lieutenants, naturally is gratified at the action of the National Republican Convention. Mr. Grosvenor says he has no doubt of Mr. McKinley's election.

The New-York Smelting and Refining Company of West and Jane Streets is in financial difficulties, and yesterday the Sheriff received five attachments against it from Charles E. Mahoney in favor of the following creditors: Thomas Carmichael, $16,000; Car Trust Investment Company, $9,000; William H. Davol, $4,232; Post Pomeroy, $3,736, and American Metal Company, $2,624.

HAVANA, June 19 -- Private advices from Camaguey are to the effect that the rebel loss in the battle of Najasa was only 11 killed and 49 wounded, instead of 500 killed and wounded, as was stated in the official report of the fight. The opinion is gaining ground here that the Spanish reports of a victory were untrue.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- Albert Woods, thirty-two years old, the proprietor of a photograph gallery at Washington Park, in this city, and Richard Menzie, twenty years old, a visitor to the resort, were killed by electricity last night. Menzie, at the conclusion of an evening's pleasure, visited the photograph gallery, and as he approached the place, threw out his hand and scraped a wire screen.

Though there were two stakes on for de- cision at the Gravesend track yesterday, neither was of sufficient importance to excite very general interest. The day was a perfect one for racing, and the track was in good condition, but the attendance was rather below the average. Friday is decidedly an off day for the races, as the general opinion is that four days a week are enough for the sport.
A large school in Harlem, which is supported by philanthropists, is visited occasionally by a certain Dr. Lore, who lives in the neighborhood. He is known as the "children's friend."
Sixteen hundred and sixty-nine boy pupils in the city schools applied this year for admission to the College of the City of New-York, and 822 have been accepted.

RHINECLIFF, N.Y., June 19 -- Gov. Morton entertained at dinner to-night at his Ellerslie house the members of the Greater New-York Commission. The dinner was intended as a social affair, Gov. Morton desiring to bring the Commissioners together in a pleasant way, and introduce those who were not already acquainted.

ST. LOUIS, June 19 -- Senator Teller of Colorado feels the need of a rest, and will leave to-morrow for Fulton, Ill., where his aged mother is residing. There he will spend a week or more. He will make the trip by water to avoid the fatigue of railway travel.

NEW-HAVEN, June 19 -- The University of Wisconsin eight left this city this morning in high spirits. Their two special cars were attached to the regular 9:35 express for New-York. All the party were jubilant at yesterday's walk-over in the Tale freshman race. The Wisconsiners go at once from here to Lake Minnetonka, Minn., where they will meet the Minnesota Boat Club in their annual race on July 4.

NEWPORT, Ky., June 19 -- After but five minutes' deliberation, a jury in the Campbell County Circuit Court yesterday afternoon adjudged Alonzo A. Walling guilty of the murder of Pearl Bryan, and fixed his penalty as death.

The attack on the State Democracy and the policy of "harmony" that was made by County Clerk Purroy and his small following in the Tammany Executive Committee meeting Wednesday night has aroused a little feeling among some former anti-Tammany men. There were whispers and rumors yesterday that the State Democrats would resent the attack and withdraw from their agreement to act in concert with the braves.

PATERSON, N.J., June 19 -- This city still is rejoicing over the nomination at St. Louis pf Garret A. Hobart for Vice President. While the people are well pleased with the nomination for first place, it is the second name that catches Patersonians.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- The wheat trade was of a regulation sort to-day, and scarcely any reference to the nomination at St. Louis yesterday was heard. The routine statistical news rather tended to produce an easy feeling, and prices declined immediately after the opening on large Northwestern receipts -- 515 cars, against 471 last Friday, and 118 a year ago -- on lower Liverpool cables, and fine weather.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- The news of the nomination of McKinley for President by the National Republican Convention was received in San Francisco with comparative indifference. There were no cheers from the crowds assembled about the bulletin boards, and, aside from the blowing of some factory whistles, no excitement was noticed.

From two widely separated points Republican journals favorable to silver have given their estimate of Mr. MCKINLEY. The Detroit Tribune, while declaring that the platform on the only important issue before the country is "damnably unpatriotic and un-Republican," has not a word to say against McKINLEY and in substance declares him to be all right.
ST. LOUIS, June 19 -- Mark Hanna is the Chairman of the new Republican National Committee. He was elected at a meeting held in the Southern Hotel this morning.
ST. LOUIS, June 19 -- Somebody asked Mr. Hanna if he was pleased with the outcome of the Presidential fight.

CANTON, Ohio, June 19. -- Canton was awake bright and early this morning, notwithstanding the fact that a large proportion of the population did not cease celebrating the nomination of McKinley until nearly dawn.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Railway legislation will be an important factor in the proceedings of the short session of the present Congress next Winter. Several measures were under consideration at the recent session which will again be taken up in one house or the other, and may call for active exertion on the part of railway men for the protection of their interests.

MILWAUKEE, June 19 -- The street-railway boycott is at an end. It was formally declared off to-day by President James Flint, of the Amalgamated Association of Street-Railway Employees -- that is, it was declared off so far as it was within his power to do so.

The last bit of testimony Is in in the trial of Mary Alice Almont Fleming for the murder of her mother, Mrs. Evalina M. Bliss, the last question and cross-question have been put-and answered, the wearying parry and thrust of word-dueling counsel have ceased. The summing up will be on Monday, and -when the sun goes down that nigrht, Mrs. Fleming will stand on the verge of freedom or in the valley of shadow.

Of course, if these gentlemen were simply seeking the truth they would not have had any disagreeable experiences with the Secretary, because he gave them the truth, fully and in detail.
POUGHKEEPSIE, June 19 -- The Harvard 'Varsity crew rowed over the entire course, four miles, this afternoom, in 19:35, and the freshmen rowed the two miles in 9:14.

NEWARK, N.J., June 19 -- Paterson to-day took the first of the three games to be played here with Newark. It was not until the fifth inning that the visitors found and pounded Bristow's curves, and then it was all up with Newark. The score:

CANTON, Ohio, June 19 -- The Canton delegation, to the Republican National Convention came home this afternoon and went at once to Major McKinley's home. The candidate received the triumphant pilgrims under the trees of the side yard, and they gave him such a tribute as seldom falls to the lot of man.

ST. LOUIS, June 19 -- At a meeting this Morning of the silver men who bolted the Republican Convention an address to the American people was agreed to and issued, and it was ordered that untill a form of organization, should be perfected all general matters relating to this movement, so far as the seceding delegates were concerned, should be under the direction of Senator F.T. Dubois of Idaho.

TORONTO, Ontario, June 19 -- John Beverly Robinson, ex-Lieutenant Governor of Ontario, fell dead Just as he was stepping on the platform at Sir Charles Tupper's great Conservative meeting, held in Massey Music Hall to-night, which he was to have addressed.

It seems that at many ports abroad great injury is suffered by British shipping through the crews of vessels being enticed away from their ships, necessitating the obtaining of others, and in many cases incompetent, hands. In Buenos Ayres this practice is very prevalent, so much so that the attention of the British Government has been drawn to it.

Ex-Congressman Byron G. Stout of Michigan died at his home in Pontiaer, Mich., yesterday -- after a long illness, of cancer. He was born in Richmond, Ontario County, N.Y., Jan. 12, 1820. His parents moved to Michigan two years later. Mr. Stout was graduated from the University of Michigan in 1851.

A keen, active, middle-aged man, dressed in a gray Summer suit, and carrying a straw hat in his hand, walked briskly into Room 309, in the Hoffman House, yesterday morning at 10:30, and looked inquiringly about him.

If the Directors of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad decide at the meeting on Tuesday, or in the near future, to give special train service to cyclists, the New-York City consulate of the league will have figured in a good move.

BABYLON, L.I., June 20 -- Frank. H. Johnson, twenty-two years old, son of Jere, Johnson, Jr., the well-known Brooklyn real estate auctioneer, and Arthur Watts, twenty-two years old, son of Dr. Alfred J. Watts of 1,123 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, were drowned in the Great South Bay last night, between Oak Island and this village.
Mrs. Mary Ann Parker, widow of Dr. Willard Parker. Sr., died yesterday at her Summer home, in New-Canaan, Conn., in her eighty-first year.

This is half-raters' week in the yachting world, and to-morrow, Tuesday, and Wednesday twenty or more of these small racing craft will strive for the honor of being selected to defend the Seawanhaka Cup next month. This cup, which has been given by the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club for international racing in the small classes, was raced for last year by the Spruce IV., owned by Arthur Brand.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 20 -- After four and a half months of constant daily practice, the sturdy youths who compose the Princeton baseball team will be allowed to go out of training and be their own masters again after next Tuesday. On that day will be played the last game scheduled on the Princeton programme.
