Caleb Ford, a clerk, sixty-seven years old, who formerly lived at 316 West Twenty-third Street, died yesterday in Bellevue Hospital. Ford, in stepping off a car six weeks ago, broke his leg, and was taken to the New-York Hospital for treatment. He remained there until last Thursday, when he was removed to Bellevue in an ambulance on the plea that he was insane.

At Koster Bial's the roof garden will be reserved hereafter for promenade concerts, and the stage performances will be given in the big music hall, which has been put in Summer dress, and will be kept as cool as possible by artificial means. This week's programme will introduce to the music-hall stage Marie Dressler, who was recently the successful impersonator of a music-hall songstress in "The Lady Slavey."
During a recent trip up the east coast The Citizen correspondent made a visit to the ostrich farm of Major H.J. Tiffin, at Courtenay, Indian River.

Central Office detectives on Friday night arrested at the Barrett House Nicholas J. Weaver, who is wanted by the Philadelphia police for swindling The Philadelphia Enquirer of $3,000. They arrested him on suspicion because they believed his record was bad, and had read that he had been engaged in illegal transactions in Boston and other cities, and yesterday morning they arraigned him in the Centre Street Police Court.
One of the relaxations of the Summer outing to the woman who has been deep in multifarolus pursuits all Winter is her sewing. To use her needle is so great a novelty that it is a positive pleasure.

LAKE KUSHAQUA, in the Adirondacks, June 20 -- The unique and popular Kushaqua Lodge was opened for the Summer season to-day. Besides retaining all of its attractive features of the last two seasons, it presents some new elements of convenience and comfort. An extensive electric lighting plant has been established here, making this the only hotel in the Adirondacks lighted by electricity.

The north siders want continuous trains on the elevated roads of the Manhattan Railway Company, and they will not rest until the law in this matter is obeyed and they are relieved of the annoyances and dangers of changing cars at the Harlem River.

The States of Wyoming and Utah have recently had their seals made, and are now affixing them to all public documents emanating from the Governor or Secretary of State. That of Wyoming represents a pedestal showing on the front an eagle resting upon a shield. Upon the shield are engraved a star and the figures "44," being the number of Wyoming in the order of admission to Statehood.

MONMOUTH BEACH, N.Y., June 20. -- Dr. Herman Knapp, a New-York oculist, who has a Summer residence at this place, narrowly escaped drowning in the ocean this afternoon. Had it not been for prompt action by his daughter Ida, the doctor would have undoubtedly perished.
SUMMIT, N.J., June 20 -- An enjoyable pound party was held Thursday night in Bailey Hall, Millburn, by the Persevering Circle of the King's Daughters of St. Stephen's Episcopal Church.
There was a thunderstorm hereabout on Wednesday, and a lot of lightning came slashing along with it. The display was very pretty while it lasted, but some people did not care about it.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 20 -- The third annual century run from Newark to Asbury Park to-day was the most successful event ever held under the auspices of the Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey. The start was made at 5:10 A.M. from Washington Park, Newark. There were nearly 400 starters.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 20 -- Not the least delightful of the many pleasant Summer resorts of Berkshire County is Williamstown, with its classical associations, its beautiful elm-shaded streets, and its fine mountain views, with Greylock and its foothills almost in the foreground. There are many very attractive cottages here, which are occupied this season by their owners or those to whom they have been leased.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 20 -- An excursion to Greenwood Lake was made to-day by the Pilgrim Mission Sunday School.
George H. Wyckoff, the President of the Bank of New-Amsterdam, who was shot last Monday by George H. Semple in the bank's office, in the Metropolitan Opera House, died yesterday at 11:20 A.M.

WEDNESDAY, June 24 -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, Edward Browne, referee, 217 East Seventieth Street, north side, 275 feet west of Second Avenue, 25 by 100.5, five-story brick, and brownstone front dwelling. Due on judgment, $1,800.

Miss Georgia Cayvan, the actress -- long a favorite with New-Yorkers -- who left the stage on account of ill health two years ago, returned to this city aboard the steamer St. Louis on Friday last, brimming over with health, spirits, good humor, and hopefulness. A reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES found her last evening trying to keep cool in her city home, at 331 West One Hundred and Twenty-second Street.
John D. Rockefeller addressed the children of the Euclid Avenue Baptist Church yesterday morning.

PITTSBURG, June 20. -- Two sections of a west-bound freight train came into collision early to-day near Wall Station, on the Pennsylvania Railroad. Two freight cars were derailed and thrown against the east-bound track and directly in front of No. 20, the fastest vestibuled train between Pittsburg and New-York.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 20 -- One of the church events in this city in which society people take a great interest is the annual church festival of the Holy Cross Church, which took place this year in the parish building, Wednesday evening. The committee in charge was Miss Annie Murphy, Miss Georgie Fountain, and Miss Agnes Guirk.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 20 -- Mrs. Robert F. Emmet, Jr., who lives on the Pelham Road, and Miss Rosina Emmet, daughter of Temple Emmet of San Francisco, Cal., were riding to-day, and when crossing the Pelham Bridge, on the Shore Road, were thrown from their carriage -- the horse had become frightened and was running away.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 20 -- The marriage of Miss Nellie Baire of this city and Frederick Weber of Deans was solemnized last Sunday, the Rev. Dr. P.T. Pockman of the Reformed Church, officiating. Afterward a wedding dinner was served at the groom's home, at Deans.

There are several blocks in the busiest part of the city the sidewalks of which are never trodden in business hours. Thousands of persons have passed them daily for years, but have not been permitted either to see or to use them. They belong to the public, but they have been alienated as effectually from public use as if they were private property.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 20 -- Gov. Matthews has asked Chairman Holt of the regular State Democratic Committee and Chairman Clark of the free-silver committee to endeavor to bring about an understanding between the two wings of the party.

BERLIN, June 20. -- The Berlin newspapers are filled with references to the presence in Berlin of Li Hung Chang, the Chinese Viceroy, and Field Marshal Tamagata, Commander in Chief of the Japanese Army, who came here from Moscow, where they represented their respective Governments at the coronation of Czar Nicholas II.

Grant in respect to what the Democratic State Convention should do on the sound-money question, They defer to his judgment in that matter, and he will draw up the sound-money portion of the platform.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., June 20 -- Fifteen years ago the Adirondack Mountains were practically unknown save to a few sportsmen and an occasional invalid who had bravely borne the thirty-mile stage ride from Ausable Forks, the terminus of the Delaware and Hudson Railroad, successfully seeking health and strength in this land of pure air laden with the odors of spruce, balsam, and pine.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 20 -- Notwithstanding the unpleasant weather that prevailed early in the week, it did not seem to beep from coming out of the cities those persons who had made up their minds that the time had come when they should begin their outing, for every day, beginning with Monday, nearly every afternoon train brought many passengers prepared to stay a while.

The Vice President came to participate in the exercises at the dedication of the O'Reilly monument this afternoon, and made a short impromptu address after the unveiling.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Five thousand persons attended the tenth annual bicycle meet of the South End Wheelmen this afternoon on the grounds of the Tioga Cricket Club. The weather was perfect, the track was in good condition, and fast time was generally made. There were several "spills," but none of the riders was seriously hurt.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 20 -- The University of Wisconsin crew arrived here to-day at noon in a buffet sleeper over the New-York Central Railroad, and left to-night at 8:05 for Wisconsin. They came on invitation of J.W. McCullough, Commodore of the Cornell navy, and viewed the preliminary work of the crews from the Cornell launch.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- The local market was stagnant and featureless. Outside of a little business by the traders in St. Paul and Reading the market was almost at a standstill. In a number of stocks no sales were recorded. Pennsylvania Heat common advanced 1/8. The close was dull and steady.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 20 -- Mr. and Mrs. Victor Sorchan of New-York are at their villa on the Cliffs to-night, and Mr. and Mrs. F.B. Hoffman of New-York are at the Deblers cottage, Deblers Avenue, for the season.

NYACK-ON-HUDSON, June 20 -- The new sloop yacht Cymbra was launched from the yards of Charles L. Seabury Co. yesterday. She is for Thomas A. McIntyre. Her principal dimensions are: Length over all, 44 feet 9 inches; load water line, 30 feet; beam, 9 feet 3 inches; draught, 7 feet 6 inches. She is built in a thoroughly first-class manner and of the best materials throughout.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 20 -- A telegram was received at Franklin Park to-day from Hudson, N.Y., to the effect that detectives had located the men who bunkoed Columbus C. Beekman, the farmer, out of $3,000 on Thursday. Beekman was asked to go to Hudson to see if he could identify the men, who are now in jail, and he started this afternoon.

In fact, most of those who have yet to arrive are abroad and will be coming in slowly from now until Aug. 1.

VANCOUVER, B.C., June 20 -- Latest advices from Australia report matters lively in cycling circles. The Australian cycle cracks Megson, Lewis, and Payne, have sailed from Sydney for London. They were given a great send-off by their friends and the New South Wales League of Wheelmen. The trio are the best professional riders Australia has produced so far, and they intend to compete in principal events in England.

CANTON, Ohio, June 20 -- One of several delegations that arrived to-day from Wheeling brought a tin banner, five feet square, which was presented to Major McKinley in an address, in which he was mentioned as the "father of the tinplate industry in the United States." Replying to the address, Mr. McKinley said:

CLAYTON, N.Y., June 20 -- The opening of the Summer season at the Thousand Islands for 1896 was marked with more the usual activity, and the prospect for a busy season is very bright at present. The weather is delightful, and the cool breezes over the noble St. Lawrence, are as invigorating as ever.

More than usual interest attached to the monthly meeting of the State Floral Society. While Californians are cultivating the perfection of floral beauty there is a spirit of utilitarianism abroad. This was shown by the discussion of perfume plants. It was begun by Capt. Emil Kellner, who is connected with the agricultural department of Berkeley.

Some of you may go to Hamburg this Summer, while away on your Summer outing, and, if you do, you will be glad to recall an incident in connection with its early history which was long commemorated in the German city. Hamburg is a very old city, and in days gone by it was attacked many times by its enemies, and long and bitter were the struggles of the inhabitants to save their beloved city.

CANTON, Ohio, June 20 -- A trainload of people from Niles, Major McKinley's birthplace, reached here this afternoon. They attracted much attention on the streets, for the banners they bore were sheets of homemade tin stuck into staffs. The factories there closed for the day that the men might have the opportunity to make the visit.

The yachtsmen off Larchmont were treated yesterday to what Commodore Gerry used to call a "rib roast." It was the Spring regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club, and sixty yachts crossed the line. This is a record-breaker for a Spring regatta, and is the biggest event thus far this year.

While the continent of Europe has renounced, if it ever adopted, the superstition of the divining rod, the Anglo-Saxon of these islands and of North America has confidence in a set of ignorant men who pretend to be able by the use of a forked stick to discover hidden sources of water, of metallic ores and of other treasures.

The Marquis de Luppe, a former Chambordist and a son-in-law of the Due de Eroglie, refuses to follow the Due d'OrIeans, now that the Duke's strategy is the same as Gen. Boulanger's. He thinks he owes it to himself to resign membership in the Royalist Committee of Bordeaux. Accordingly, he has written as follows to the Comte de Lur Saluces, President of that committee:

GREENWICH, Conn., June 20 -- The town is almost covered to-day with flags and bunting, and work is suspended. Everybody for miles around is here to welcome Gov. Coffin, who arrived, with his staff, just after 10 o'clock this morning. The streets are filled with the townspeople and visitors, and the day is an important one here.
BAR HARBOR, Me., June 20 -- The season at Bar Harbor is beginning. Many New-Yorkers are already here and settled in their cottages, and others are expected shortly.

Mr. Archdall Reid, in his "Present Evolution of Man," grapples with many of the most abstruse of anthropological theories. If we may barely trace some slight physical gain, or believe that there are certain modifications going on, still to what extent such physical advantages may lead, we can only speculate about.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 20 -- The Summer season of 1896 is upon Atlantic City in full force, and the anticipations as to its success are now realities. Everything wears its Summer aspect. Such a Summer throng, in point of numbers, has never before been known here so early in the season. Surf bathing is now the most popular diversion of the visitor.

After describing the wonderful spectacle in the cathedral, I had no time to do more than give a brief account of the singular scene in the banqueting hall known as the Trapeza. I can now supplement it, however, with particulars of this most purely Russian, or, rather, Muscovite, of all the ceremonies of the coronation.

From The Saturday Review. The Turk has made such a criminal fool of himself in Armenia that all Christendom is prepared to take sides against him and to sympathize warmly with anybody who sheds his blood. The apparent fact that in Crete thus far ten Turks have been slain for every Christian "massacred" makes no difference with outside sentiment.

BAYONNE, N.J., June 20 -- Yachtsmen of the New-Jersey Athletic Club of Bayonne held their first club regatta of the season on Newark Bay this afternoon for the cup presented by Capt. "Joe" Elisworth of Bayonne. Unfortunately, there was not enough wind to properly fill the sails except for a few minutes.

Nobody can look at the presentation in words and pictures on another page of the manner in which the public sidewalks are taken for private use without agreeing that such a state of things is disgraceful to the city. Yet it clearly appears that the municipality not only permits, but in some instances actually connives at, this invasion of its rights.

ST. LOUIS, June 20 -- The Populists, according to Chairman Taubeneck, will support Teller for the Presidency. A statement to that effect will be the substance of an address soon to be issued by the Populists. The document will be addressed to all friends of silver, and will be signed by nearly thirty of the party leaders.

ORANGE, N.J., June 20 -- A novel and attractive lawn festival was enjoyed Thursday night on the grounds at the corner of Grove Place and Greenwood Avenue. It was held under the auspices of the Young Ladies' Auxiliary of the Park Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church. Queen Esmeralda and her band of Gypsies were the principal entertainers.

Arthur Young is shocked, and with sufficient reason, at the game-preserving wastes which surround the French chateaux, but he is also disgusted, in a minor degree, by the want of proper landscape gardening. Their great houses are often built in the purlieus of a town, and what might be made into beautiful grounds abandoned to the baser uses of stables or other utilitarian erections.

Arthur Young was one of the men who, if in the depths of depression at one meeting, are sure to be at the height of exhilaration at the next. Nothing could permanently suppress or daunt him. Compensations were sure to turn up. If his wife was occasionally a thorn in his flesh, he was at least a most affectionate father.

Just at the close of the St. Louis Contention a motion was carried to have prepared and circulated a "full" report of the proceedings of that assembly. When that report appears it will be a good exercise for the "thoughtful" Republicans to analyze and compare the descriptions given by their advocates of the various candidates for nomination.

Creditors of the New-York Smelting and Refining Company, at Jane and West Streets, having failed in the race to put the Sheriff in possession of the property ahead of a receiver, were obliged to content themselves yesterday with presenting their claims. Debts for which attachments were reported on Friday amounted to $25,592.

What (asks a writer in The London Spectator) has happened to the Spanish Army, only recently reorganized by King Alfonso XII., and supposed to be equal for its numbers to any army in Europe, to afflict it with the paralysis which has apparently fallen on it in Cuba?

The sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Finance, which was in this city for several days investigating the manner in which the bond sales of 1894, 1895, and 1896 were negotiated, concluded its sessions yesterday.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 20 -- The Kansas City League is in communication with Senator Teller, who says he will stop at Topeka on his return to Denver next Wednesday and make a speech. This information has been sent out, and it is estimated that 20,000 persons will come here on special trains to see and hear Mr. Teller.

The strong men of the Democratic Party, its men of light and leading and mastery in every State, ought to muster at Chicago on July 7. The fight for the life of the Democratic Party is to be made in the convention there. Loyal Democrats should heed the call of duty and rally for the defense.

NEW-HAVEN, June 20 -- The members of the Connecticut delegation to the National Democratic Convention at Chicago met here this morning and named ex-Gov. Waller as Chairman of the delegation. Judge Lynde Harrison was chosen to represent the State on the Convention Committee on Resolutions, ex-Congressman French, National Committeeman, and James Aldis of Torrington member of the Convention Committee on Permanent Organization.

No two Presidential campaigns are conducted alike, but all are directed by National Executive Committees, and the headquarters of an Executive Committee is always the very vortex of political activity during the continuance of the fight.

TUESDAY, June 23 -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, Mitchell A.C. Levy, referee, 1,680 Park Avenue, northwest corner of East One Hundred and Eighteenth Street, 25.11 by 90, five-story brick and brownstone flat. Due on judgment, $27,200.

The prosecution seems to have made out its case against Police Commissioner PARKER for neglect of duty. It is to be regretted, however, in view of the effect of the trial upon public opinion, that the real case against the Commissioner could not be made more manifest. The charge seems rather narrow and technical.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent action of the Consolidated Milk Exchange in reducing the price of milk from 2 to 1 3/4 cents per quart has caused unfavorable comment, and the dissatisfaction is not confined to producers. Some dealers express their dissatisfaction in quite pointed language.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- William McAdoo, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, will leave Washington Monday morning on the United States dispatch boat Dolphin for an official inspection of the naval militia organization on the Atlantic coast and the great lakes. He will be accompanied by Lieut. A.P. Niblack, in charge of naval militia affairs at the Navy Department, and William Howell, his private secretary.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- West Chicago and Strawboard were about the only stocks that showed an advance to-day. The former sold at 105 3/8, while the latter opened at 38 1/2 for a small lot and quickly advanced to 39 7/8, closing at that. There was little done in the Moore stocks to-day. Prices were heavy, and there seemed to be little inclination to trade.

Weakfish -- not the little "school" fellows, but the sharp-fighting, "yellow-fins," or "tide-runners" of from two to five pounds -- have for the past week been plentiful in near-by waters. The run of the fish may continue for some time, and thus afford pleasant recreation to hundreds who cannot afford outings, even for trout, and pastime to the more fortunate.

With golf at all the country clubs, the yachting season in full swing, and other sports that make people get around early in the morning quite the rage, the quiet evenings in the clubs are missed by such people as are obliged for one reason or another to stay in town. Gossip gets drearily slow.

NEW-ROCHELLE, June 20 -- The main thoroughfare of the eastern part of Westchester County, skirting the Sound, is to-day what was the Boston Post Road 100 years ago. The original turnpike has been straightened in two or three places between this village and Port Chester, but in the main the road is the same as that traveled by the old stage coaches during the first part of the present century.

The effect of cycling on the social customs of England engages the grave and minute attention of The London Spectator, which devotes nearly a page to its discussion. The phase of the wheel's influence that strikes our contemporary most forcibly is, to put it briefly, the abolition of dinner and the advent of lunch.

Thomas C. Platt reached home from St. Louis yesterday, having come in a special car attached to a regular Baltimore and Ohio train. The train was on time, and Mr. Platt and his party landed at the foot of Liberty Street at 6:30 P.M. The other occupants of his car were Charles W. Hackett and his son Fred, Louis F. Payn, J. Sloat Fassett, and Benjamin B. Odell.

The fifteenth annual camp season of the National Guard of New-York, near Peekskill, will be inaugurated next Saturday afternoon, when the Eighth Regiment, Col. Chauncey, forms line on the plateau overlooking Annsville Creek, and the National and State colors are hoisted, while a detail of Capt. Wendel's First Battery fires a salute of twenty-one guns.

From The London World. Russia cannot be judged by the analogies of Western Europe. She is still in the middle ages. The first mishap or mistake of the young Emperor would recall the calamity of his coronation week, in which a reign of mismanagement and misfortune might seem to have been foreshadowed; and the blind ignorance of the Russian masses would lend itself a ready dupe to the suggestions of secret conspirators.

United States Consul Thomas O'Neil, at Stockholm, Sweden, has made a very important report, in connection with the production of butter, which has created quite a sensation in England. A machine has been invented by Herr Salenius, a Swedish engineer, which will transform sterilized milk into butter in one minute.

LONDON, June 20 -- Although Parliament as an institution is a good many hundred years old in England, its capacity for novelty is by no means exhausted. We are witnessing something now at Westminster which no one has ever seen before -- that is, the spectacle of a party with 150 majority quite unable to pass its principal measure.
HACKENSACK, N.J., June 20 -- Mr. and Mrs. E.E. Poor, Jr., have gone to Europe for three months.
The trial of Mrs. Fleming, on the charge of poisoning her mother, has called public attention to the possibility of the conveying of poison by alien substances in combination with food.

The Directors of the Women's Health Protective Association and a number of invited guests went on a trolley excursion yesterday to Fort Hamilton and Bergen Beach. The party left the City Hall at noon, on the parlor car Montauk. They carried with them a basket lunch, which was disposed of at Fort Hamilton, after which the party proceeded to Bergen Beach and back.

CAIRO, June 3 -- The cholera in Alexandria keeps about at the same point, but it is increasing in Cairo. It has broken out in several smaller places, more especially in Bedouin villages. These wandering Arabs upon the first fright scatter to the four winds, in all probability carrying with them cholera germs wherever they go.

LENOX, Mass., June 20 -- This has been one of the busiest weeks in Lenox thus far this season, with many arrivals, much golf playing at the links, and a number of luncheons and teas at the various cottages. The two foreign legations that are to have headquarters in Lenox this Summer arrived this week.
The midsummer meeting of Group VII., New-York State Bankers' Association, will be held at the Grand Hotel, in the Catskills, on Friday evening next and Saturday.
LARCHMONT MANOR, N.Y., June 20 -- Owing to the heavy rains the week was a quiet one at Larchmont. Several cottagers who were expected deferred opening their cottages until pleasant weather.

PATERSON, N.J., June 20 -- Garret A. Ho- bart, Republican candidate for Vice President, arrived home this evening. Mr. Hobart had sent a request by telegraph that there should be no demonstration on his arrival, and his wishes were respected.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, June 20 -- The gangs of carpet pounders, scrubbers, painters, and gardeners who have been the most conspicous part of the population here for the last month have at last seemed to vanish after the worthy manner of Hamlet senior, and left a very neat and clean looking village behind them.

ALBANY, June 21 -- The most disappointed person by long odds of the New-Yorkers who attended the St. Louis Convention was Gen. E.A. McAlpin Adjutant General of the State of New-York, under appointment by Gov. Morton. It is an open secret that Gen. McAlpin, while professing fealty to Gov. Morton in his canvass for the nomination for President, really was working for his own nomination for the second place on the Republican National ticket.

The Germans of New-York and Brooklyn went out by the hundreds yesterday to Ulmer Park, Bensonhurst, to attend the grand prize singing contest of the United Singing Societies of Brooklyn. There were nearly twenty-five societies represented, and they sang steadily through sunshine and rain from 1:30 o'clock, until after 5 o'clock.

LONDON, June 21 -- Halley Stewart, an ex-member of the House of Commons, gave a garden party yesterday at Clapham in honor of the Congregational pilgrims from the United Slates, who are visiting points of interest in this country.

PARIS, June 10 -- In the course of a conversation with a high official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the correspondent of The United Press learned to-day of an interesting incident of the Cuban war, in which James B. Eustis, the American Ambassador to France, was instrumental in saving a French citizen from death at the hands of the Spanish military authorities in Cuba.

The ancient barony of Beaumont has not been long in abeyance, the Queen having already revived it, in favor of Mona Josephine Tempest Stapleton, the elder daughter and co-heir of the late peer. The juvenile peeress is rather more than one year and ten months old, and her sister, a posthumous child, is just thirteen months younger.

Mr. JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN'S Imperial Customs Union was practically tabled by the Congress of Chambers of Commerce to which it was offered. We pointed out at the time that, though he had an idea which is in the line of the evolution of the empire, his scheme was both inadequate and impracticable.

The New-York Tribune published on Friday a long and elaborate biography of Mr. McKINLEY. It fills eight columns, but our neighbor could find no room for any reference to its candidate's record in Congress with respect to silver free-coin- age bills and other legislation designed to undermine, if not to overthrow, the gold standard.

Final arrangements for the great gathering of whist players in Brooklyn this week are now about completed. These annual sessions of the American Whist League are called congresses. There is no legislation worth speaking of, as the rules were thoroughly revised at the first three congresses.

ALBANY, June 20 -- There was very little tradIng in local securities during the week. Troy City Railway 5s and Troy City Gas 5s were a little easier during the first part of the week, but after the offerings were absorbed the price rebounded to the old figures. There are very few investment bonds offering at present. Bank, shares were quiet.
"The ruling and uncompromising principle is the protection and development of American labor aud industry. The country demands a right settlement and then it wants rest."

ST. LOUIS, June 21 -- The result of the Populist conference that has been held here the last few days appears in a circular addressed particularly to Populists and generally to voters of every party asking support for Teller for President. The document is signed by twenty-six leading Populists from six Western and Southern States.
FREEHOLD, N.J., June 21 -- There was a battle to-day on the Manasquan River near here, in which four men were shot. One side used bullets and the other potatoes.

The Spring Street Presbyterian Church celebrated yesterday the sixtieth anniversary of the dedication of its present building. At the morning services the pastor, the Rev. A.W. Halsey, was assisted by the Itev. Dr. William Alkman of Atlantic City, who was in charge of the church from 1869 to 1872, and by the Rev. James Hunter.

Under the name of Mary Watson, Sophie Lyons, one of the most notorious women criminals in this country and wife of "Ned" Lyons, the bank burglar, was arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday. Mrs. Lyons went into a dry goods store at Sixth Avenue and Fourteenth Street Saturday afternoon, and as she was leaving was recognized by Mary Plunkett, the private detective of the store, who rushed up to her and said:

The obstructing of sidewalks by merchants in the territory between Cortlandt and Canal Streets, west of Broadway, part of which is known as the dry goods district and part as the wholesale grocers' district, was a subject of public interest and discussion yesterday.

From Our Own Correspondent. GLASGOW, June 13 -- The Meteor has sailed her fourth race, in the Solent this time, and won her fourth first prize. She beat the Britannia by 25 minutes 50 seconds and the Ailsa by 26 minutes 65 seconds. The Satanita also started, but, setting dropped, gave up.

Mr. Platt was so tired after his return from the St. Louis Convention that he slept fourteen hours after he had reached his rooms in the Fifth Avenue Hotel Saturday night. When he awoke yesterday afternoon he sent word to the clerk's desk that he wished no cards to be sent to him, as he was still too tired to see any one.

Several of the Democratic conventions in the silver States, in an obvious attempt to bolster a weak cause, are appealing in support of silver to the opinions of Jefferson on the subject, and citing the great founder of the Democratic Party to show that Democracy and free silver are natural allies.

Much interest attaches to the meeting of the Board of Aldermen to be held to-morrow, because it is expected that the Committee on Lamps and Gas will then present a report on the petition of the Consumers' Fuel Gas, Heat, and Power Company for permission to lay pipes and mains in the "streets, avenues, and public places."
The Brotherhood of Tailors will to-day begin a thorough and careful reorganization of its affiliated unions in preparation for the great strike that is to begin in July.

From The Chicago Times-Herald. Because her attorneys styled her a "resident" instead of a "citizen" of Nebraska, Florence Joy Reynard has lost her verdict of $7,500 against the Northern Pacific Railroad. Mrs. Reynard was a member of a comic opera company, and was badly injured in a wreck at Brainard in January, 1893.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 21 -- Four men were killed by the 8 o'clock express on the Camden and Atlantic Railroad, at Absecom this morning.

The Critic of June 6 prints the following replies from the Presidents of a dozen American schools and colleges to its inquiry relative to the amount of money presented to the several institutions as endowment funds:

According to Prof. James D. Smillie of the Academy of Design there is good reason to believe that that institution will eventually be joined to Columbia University. There is, he says, much opposition to the plan on the part of certain members of the Faculty of the Academy of Design, but he believes this opposition can be overcome.

PARIS, June 21 -- In the course at an interview to-day with a representative of The United Press Perry Belmont made the following remarks regarding the gold plank adopted by the St. Louis Republican Convention:
ORANGE, N.J., June 21 -- William Vallen, better known in this city as "Vinegar," was drowned in four inches of water in Canoe Brook, in West Orange. He was found close to the Lakeside Avenue bridge.
CHICAGO, June 21 -- The tenth store robbery within the last three months was successfully carried out by five armed men last night.

Berlin Dispatch to The London Times. While from all quarters in England a graceful tribute of congratulation has been paid to the Prince of Wales on his success in the Derby, not a word has appeared in the press here to show that the victories of the German Emperor's yacht arouse the slightest interest among his subjects.

By a stroke of lightning Charles Felentz was killed yesterday afternoon, and from the effects of the same stroke Louise Costello, his sweetheart, with whom he had been walking in Van Cortlandt Park, now lies partly paralyzed in Fordham Hospital.

That peculiar sympathy which some people have for children, Olive Thorne Miller displays in her study of monkey life. Her first acquaintance with the kinkajou came about when she ran across one in a New-York animal shop. She was looking for a bird when she noticed a little hall of golden brown fur, and when it looked at the lady with its pleading eyes, at last her heart was won, and buy it she did.

Five dogs, mad, or called mad by an excited crowd, were killed yesterday by policemen in various parts of the city. One small fox terrier almost caused a panic in Central Park, and drove 200 or 300 persons from the shade of the trees to the glare of the sunny street.

The Invitation which St. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church, situated at Ninety-Seventh Street, corner of Amsterdam Avenue, has extended to bicyclists to come and have their bicycles checked while they worship, was accepted by very few yesterday. There were three bicycles at the service which takes place at 7:30 o'clock in the morning.

William C. Whitney, who abandoned his intended trip to Europe in order to attend the Democratic Convention at Chicago and fight for sound money, has made the following statement, embodying his views on the situation:

Next Saturday will be a great day for cycling over in Brooklyn. The bicycle riders of that city, under the direction of the Good Roads Association, are going to have a big parade to celebrate the completion of the return pathway in the Ocean Parkway, and afterward there will be some fine racing at Manhattan Beach under the auspices of the Kings County Wheelmen.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The bolt of the silver Republicans at St. Louis may make sad havoc with the Republican majority in the Senate, even in case of the election of McKinley. The Question already is beingdiscussed here whether the Republicans will be recognized as the masters of the Senate in the next Congress or be compelled to look on and see the committees reorganized by the free-silver majority.

SYNOPSIS. The old Spanish General Arroya, in retirement, is tempted to join the King's forces at the rebellion of the Agua Alta, the mountains surrounding which he can see from the veranda of his house. He goes to Gen. Maduro's camp, and finds the soldiers insubordinate, they having been harassed by guerrilla bands of the rebels, rumore 1 to be led by a women, the wife of a dead rebel leader.

HANOVER, N.H., June 21 -- The baccalaureate sermon before the graduating class of Dartmouth College was preached to-day by President William J. Tucker from Haggai ii., 23: "I will take thee and I will make thee as a signet." The topic was "The Representative Force of the Educated Man in Society."

CANTON, Ohio, June 21 -- Major McKinley passed his first Sunday as the Republican Presidential candidate in much the same manner as previous Sundays had been spent by him. The principal change was in his surroundings and not his actions. His home sheltered beneath its roof an unusual number of occupants.
Two issues are presented by the nomination of Mr. McKIENLEY on the platform adopted at St. Louis. One is the currency, the other is the tariff.

The Melbourne Argus, which has just celebrated its jubilee, shares with The Sydney Morning Herald the distinction of the leading daily in the Southern Hemisphere. Its original founder, Mr. William Kerr, was a fiery and fanatical Orangeman, who was largely responsible for the riots that were of annual occurrence in early Melbourne, and which, on more than one occasion, required the intervention of imperial troops.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 21. -- Charles A. Mareni, a bicyclist, who left New-York City yesterday to wheel to Canton, Ohio, to see William McKinley, was run into to-day a mile south of Tarrytown, and was so badly injured that he had slightly to delay the pleasure he intends to give the nominee. He will be able to proceed in the morning.
NUTLEY, N.J., June 21 -- This village had a small tornado all to itself this afternoon. It does not appear to have visited any other place.

It had been Mr. Whitney's intention to spend Sunday at his place on Long Island, bat instead he remained at his home, at 2 West Fifty-seventh Street, throughout the day. It was believed that he still hoped to prevail upon Michael Doran of St. Paul, member of the Democratic National Committee from Minnesota, to forego his European trip.

NEW-HAVEN, June 21 -- President Timothy Dwight this morning preached the Yale baccalaureate. The academic and scientific seniors to the number of 600 were present in the body of Battel Chapel, and hundreds of visitors and alumni crowded the galleries. The sermon was unusually impressive and contained many references to President Dwight's college career.

MONDAY -- A.M. The adoption of a gold plank in the platform of the Republican National Convention was the most encouraging incident of the week, and it caused quite a sharp rally in prices. The nomination of Mr. McKinley was not received with enthusiasm in financial circles, because of his unsatisfactory record on currency matters.

The immense parade of bicyclists which will take place on Saturday next-weather favoring -- from Prospect Park to Coney Island will traverse the finest stretch of wheeling road in the country. When completed, this double path will stretch some six miles. It will be nearly level. It will be wide enough to give room for a great stream of riders.

PROVIDENCE, June 20 -- Local stocks have been in food demand during the last week, and there was a fair inquiry for the better class of investments. Bank stocks were somewhat sought for. Blackstone Canal National sold at 25, Commercial National at 47 1/4, Merchants' National at 63 3/4, Mechanics' National at 53 1/4, and a small lot of Traders' National at 46 1/4.
The Republicans at St. Louis adopted a declaration of three distinct points as to the currency:

The American barkenline E.S. Powell, Capt. Hodgkinson, which sailed Sunday for Charleston, carrying a light cargo of general merchandise as ballast, was towed back into port yesterday morning with a gaping hole in her side reaching nearly to the water's edge, her foremast gone, and much of her top hamper carried away.

While a large crowd was not expected and did not materialize, the number of those who "survived" the Manhattan Bicycle Club's double century on Saturday and Sunday was a matter of genuine surprise. Of sixteen starters, fifteen came through, and all were in good shape except two. The man who "died" was E.S. Snow of the Kings County Wheelmen, who, by the way, had badge No. 13.

MONDAY -- P.M. These are disappointing time of the friends of the candidate of prosperity. Everything seems to combine against them, and instead of being in the midst of a boom, prices reflect a disposition on the part of holders of stocks to stand from under.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 22 -- Mrs. Frederick W. Vanderbilt, who, with Mr. Vanderbilt, arrived Sunday for the Summer, had a ladies' luncheon to-day. Miss Gammell also entertained at lunch this noon, her guests including the season's belles.

William C. De Witt, for many years Corporation Counsel in Brooklyn, and at the present time a member of the Greater New-York Commission, was quietly married Saturday evening in the parsonage of the Church of Our Father, Lefferts Place, near Grand Avenue, to Mara Bell Shepard-Langley, formerly the wife of Major William H. Langley.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 22. -- The State campaign opened at Manning this morning. This was the last day on which candidates for the several State offices could come out, and the chief interest centred in the face for the United States Senatorship. Gov. Evans appeared at Manning as the only avowed candidate.
WILLIAM E. RUSSELL shows the right spirit. He enlists for the war and will fight to the end.

The number of times that the Manhattan Railway Company violates the law at One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and the Harlem River is increased each day, but there is no longer any novelty connected with the flagrant, open nature of the violations, for they have now continued day and night during the greater part of two years.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 22 -- The boat that sunk off Premium Point last evening during the squall was the catboat Chinchin, owned by G.W. Scott of the Larchmont Yacht Club and the New-York Athletic Club. Mr. Scott and a sailor were on board. The wind struck the vessel with its sails up. The boat turned over and sank, leaving only the topmast above water.

NEWARK, N.J., June 22 -- James Mac-Cready, formerly an actor well known in the West, was instantly killed this afternoon about 5:30 o'clock in a runaway accident at Hilton. Mr. MacCready for the last five years has kept the Hilton Hotel, from in front of which the racers in the usual Irvington-Millburn road races start.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 22. -- A large and enthusiastic McKinley and Hobart ratification meeting was held in the Town Hall here to-night, and the first campaign banner in the State was raised at the corner of Arlington Avenue and Main Street amid cheers and the setting off of great quantities of fireworks.

This will be the most interesting and important week for Democrats, so far as State Conventions are concerned. It will probably decide whether the silver wing of the party shall carry everything with a high hand at Chicago, or shall be brought to listen to reason and to take a course that will not alienate the powerful Democrats of the great Eastern States.

Messrs. Pincus Loewenfeld and William Praeger have sold the vacant lot on the west side of Madison Avenue, 51.2 feet north of Eighty-first Street, 25.6 by 95, to Lucy D. Rogers and F.H. Hawkins, at an advance on the price paid by them at auction on June 2. The buyers will erect a five-story single brick and stone flat, to cost about $30,000.

H.O. Havemeyer, Jr.'s, half-rater Ideal won the first trial race yesterday off Oyster Bay. It was the first of a series of races to be sailed in order to select the best boat to defend the Seawanhaka Cup, for which G.H. Duggan of the Royal St. Lawrence Yacht Club has challenged. This cup was given by the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club last year for international races in the small classes.

LONDON, June 22. -- When the House of Commons resumed its sitting in Committee of the Whole on the Education bill to-day Mr. Balfour moved that the Chairman leave the chair, which motion is equivalent to dropping the bill for the present session.
PART I. Tom tore open the letter which had just been brought in to him. It was evidently brief. He read it at a glance, then threw it down on the table with an energetic expletive.

Mayor Strong declared himself yesterday in favor of the enforcement of the law against the grabbers of public property who have appropriated the sidewalks to the exclusion of the public, in the wholesale grocery, produce, and market districts between Broadway and the North River, down town.

AUSTIN, Texas, June 22 -- The Congressional Democratic Convention here to-day renominated Congressman Sayers without opposition. A resolution was adopted favoring the free coinage of silver at 16 to 1. The State Democratic Convention will meet to-morrow, and undoubtedly will be dominated by the free-silver element.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 22 -- July wheat lost 1c to-day on a very dull market. There was no bull-news and considerable bear news and the impress of the latter was felt. July opened 1/3c lower, at 54c, and railled 1/3c, then declined to 58 3/8@ 531/2 54c, and closed at 53 1/3c. September opened at 54 5/3c and sold to 54 3/4c, then dropping to 54 1/8@54 1/4c-- the closing price.

LONDON, June 22 -- Sir Augustus Harris, the well-known theatrical and operatic manager, whose critical illness at Folkestone was announced in these dispatches last night, died at 10:30 o'clock to-night.

LONDON, June 22 -- The Yale crew took a tripu up the river as far as Maidenhead yesterday in Bob Cook's launch, which greatly added to the pleasure of their reception in England. Among the visitors to their headquarters yesterday were Mr. C.D. Gibson, United States Consul Savage and J.J. Collins.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 22 -- The trial of James B. Gentry, the actor, for the murder of his sweetheart, Margaret W. Drysdale, (Madge York, the actress,) in this city on Feb. 17, 1895, was begun to-day before Judge Yerkes, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer.

PATERSON, N.J., June 22. -- This city turned out almost every man, woman, and child within its borders to-night to do honor to Garret A. Hobart. Such a demonstration was never seen here before. The scenes of last Thursday night, when the news came that Hobart had been nominated, were outdone, and so were those of Saturday night, when he returned from St. Louis.

CANTON, Ohio, June 22 -- Major McKinley found nothing this morning to engage his attention, save the mail, which had accumulated over Sunday. The newspaper mail has developed as rapidly as the letter mail, and the daily receipts would fill a big packing box, while the letters average probably 1,000.

Eight hundred and forty-three girls from city schools passed the entrance examinations of the Normal College. As this is a larger number than is allowed by law to enter the college in any one year, the required percentage in standing was raised from 75 to 79 on a basis of 100. This reduced the number that may enter the college in September to a little over 600.

Electric fans and open windows made the Mayor's office comfortable yesterday for those engaged in the hearing of the charges against Police Commissioner Andrew D. Parker, but they also confined the proceedings closely to the ttable at which sat the persons immediately concerned.

The power on the Second Avenue trolley line that runs to Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, suddenly failed late Sunday afternoon, and a score of cars were stalled along the dusty road about a mile from Ulmer Park.

HAVANA, June 22. -- It is reported, on good authority, that Capt. Gen. Weyler is pleased with the aspect of military affairs in the island, and that the Government has expressed its approval of his plan of campaign. He is confident that with the reinforcements of 40,000 men, promised him by the Minister of War, he will be able to crush the rebellion, and that he will return triumphant to Spain in June next.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 22. -- Ex-Gov. B.R. Tillman issued a statement yesterday in which he denied that he received any profits from the operations of the South Carolina bond syndicate. The statement follows:
HARTFORD, Conn.. June 22 -- Hartford played without an error to-day, and defeated Wilmington, which earned four of the five runs made. The score:

Horace E. Deming, counsel for N.K. Fairbank, the defendant in the suit of David Belasco for the recovery of $65,000 which he claims is due him for his work in training Mrs. Leslie Carter for the stage and producing "The Ugly Duckling," consumed the greater part of the session of the court yesterday in summing up on behalf of the defendant.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Western sliver men are organizing a propaganda movement for work among the laboring people of the East. The first delegation reached Chicago Saturday, and will give the next six weeks to agitation among the trades unions of the city. It was sent out by the Trade and Labor Assembly of Butte, Mon.
William C. Whitney supplemented the written statement of his views on the financial issue with the following oral expression yesterday:
PEORIA, Ill., June 22 -- The Illinois Democrats will go to Chicago for silver, but they will insist there that the campaign banner shall not declare for "sixteen to one and bust."

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- To-day's session was one of extreme dullness, with a declining tendency, Union Traction was the only stock in the traction group in which there were any sales, and the closing price was at a decline of 3/8. The industrials closed at net declines of 1 3/8 in Storage common, 1 per cent. in Storage preferred and Welsbach, 1/2 in Pennsylvania Heat preferred, and 1/8 in Pennsylvania Heat common.
An interesting decision in a novel case affecting the rights of persons occupying boxes at theatres was handed down yesterday by the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court.

Corlears Hook Park was formally opened last night to the public by the Mayor and other city officials. The spot where the renowned Anthony the Trumpeter passed in quiet the disappointed later years of a remarkable life, and famous in more recent years as the site of Maggie Murphy's home, is now one of the finest parks in the city.

-- Interesting exercises were held in the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce in Knoxville, Tenn., yesterday morning, when the people of Knox County gave to the State of Tennessee a block of Tennessee marble, to be presented by Gov. Turney to the State of Nebraska for the purpose of erecting a monument at Lincoln in memory of Abraham Lincoln.
SHELBYVILLE, Ind., June 22 -- Milton Rolley, an aged pensioner, drew $600 from a bank with which to pay off the balance due on his home, seven miles from this city.

The interviews which were published in yesterday's TIMES about the authorized or permitted obstruction of the sidewalks, so far as they were excuses, had the same ground with which we have long been familiar and of which we are becoming rather weary. That ground was that New-York being a "business city," any enforcement of the rights of the public which put merchants to trouble or expense was a blow to the prosperity of the city.

LONDON, June 22. -- The Standard will tomorrow publish a dispatch from Madrid saying that the Government is still uninformed officially of the report which Gen. Fitzhugh Lee, the American Consul General at Havana, has made to his Government anent the situation in Cuba. If the tenor of the report is as is stated in unofficial dispatches received in Madrid, it will make Gen. Lee's stay in Havana difficult.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Democrats who are not to be frightened by the bluster of the free-coinage advocates are glad that Mr. Whitney has entered the fight, and are inclined to believe that before the Chicago Convention shall be called to order the strong points he has made against a free-silver plank will nave penetrated the minds of many who are to-day shouting for 16 to 1.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 22 -- William C. Whitney came to this city to-night, and went at once to the residence of Senator Hill. Chairman James W. Hinkley of the Democratic State Committee arrived at about the same time, and joined the two in the conference. The nature of the currency plank which the State Convention shall adopt at Saratoga Wednesday was one of the principal topics of this discussion.

Where is the weak spot in your system? Is it a weakness of the stomach which causes indigestion, dyspepsia, biliousness, constipation, headaches and backaches, or is it a general weakness which makes you suffer from tired, languid feelings?
DETROIT, June 22 -- The Journal this evenins says:

COLUMBUS, June, 22 -- As the advance guard of the delegates to the Democratic State Convention arrive, it seems that the sentiment for free-silver coinage is even stronger than anticipated. It is almost Impossible to find an advocate of the single gold standard among the Democrats tonight.

Benjamin Helm Bristow, Secretary of the Treasury during Grant's second Administration, died yesterday in this city at his residence, 27 West Fiftieth Street. The cause of death was peritonitis, due to a sudden attack of appendicitis. He was well and at his office last Thursday.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 22 -- This has been class day at Yale, and the exercises of the forenoon, afternoon, and evening were conducted by the graduating class and devoted to it.

The twenty-fifth annual report of the Middletown State Homeopathic Hospital for the Insane has just been issued. Dr. Selden H. Talcott, the Medical Superintendent, in his report to the Board of Trustees, states that on Sept. 1, 1895, there were in the hospital under treatment 554 men and 561 women, making altogether 1,115 patients.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The citizens of New-York have manifested on various occasions their interest in the preservation of the City Hall Park, mainly on account of its historic associations, but also as having important relations to public health, the embellishment of the city, and the protection of property in case of fire in that vicinity.
The Board of Health will soon select forty rear tenements from a list of twice as many and begin condemnation proceedings under the act passed a year ago.

BOSTON, June 22 -- There was some activity in local stocks to-day, but it was condined to a few specialties. Dominion Coal last 1 1/2 to 11, rallied a little and then closed at 11. Bey Stae Can declined 1/2 to 12 1/2. The 5s were off 1/2, to 84 3/4, and the seconds down 1 to 70. There is no special new in gas circles. The was a sale of Vermont 5s at 05.

It was said yesterday that the Directors of the Mercantile National Bank, of which William P. St. John is President, are considerably concerned over his advocacy of freesilver coinage. Every other Director of the bank is a gold-standard man.

PEORIA, Ill., June 23. -- By a rising vote of 1,069 delegates, and amid a tumult of applause, cheers, the waving of hats, handkerchiefs, and coats, John P. Altgeld this afternoon was renominated by the Democratic State Convention for Governor of Illinois. It was the supreme moment of a convention in which Altgeld was not only the favorite and dictator, but apparently was the only man who undertook to command attention as a serious person.

The Church of the Heavenly Rest was crowded with invited guests last night, when Miss Daisy May Van der Veer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Reeve Van der Veer of 503 West End Avenue, and Gilson Willets were married. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. D. Parker Morgan, rector of the church.

SARATOGA, June 23. -- The crowd was slow in reaching Saratoga, and all the morning there was little to indicate that a State Convention is to be held to-morrow. A few delegates came on the morning trains and found plenty of vacant seats on the big hotel piazzas. They watched the bicyclists on Broadway and strolled to some of the springs to pass away the time.

Mr. E.L. GODKIN contributes to The Atlantic Monthly for July an article on "The Real Problems of Democracy," which is in part an acute review of Mr. LECKY'S recent book. Of Mr. LECKY'S book, he concludes: "The chief objection to it, and to most recent writings of the same sort, is that, while nominally discussing democracy, it really only points out the apparently bad tendencies of democracy.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23. -- Antonio Cuneo of New-York City, who is reported to be worth between $4,000,000 and $5,000,000, was sent to the Receiving Hospital last evening to await an examination by the Commissioners of Insanity. Cuneo's office is at 54 Broadway, New-York, and his home is on Staten Island.

POUGHKEEPSIE June 23. -- Visitors are arriving by the hundreds to see the inter-collegiate boat races to-morrow and on Friday. The hotels are rapidly filling up, and the scene in the corridors is an animated one. "College colors, a nickel or a dime," is a salutation constantly heard from a swarming army of small boys and fakirs.

SARATOGA, June 23. -- The Tammany braves used to come to conventions with brass bands, banners, flags, and other accessories, designed for noise making and show. They invariably marched about the streets cheering for Tammany at every corner and in front of every hotel and public building.
The Sixth American Whist Congress, under the auspices of the American Whist League, was formally opened yesterday morning in the main parlor of the Oriental Hotel, Manhattan Beach.

Father Bruska, the Greek priest of Hoboken, N.J., who was accused of making cigars and failing to pay the Government tax on them, was tried in the United States court in Trenton yesterday. The defense was a general denial of the allegations, and it was shown that those who accused him had difficulties with him over church matters.

What promises to be one of the most interesting yacht races of the season is to be called on July 1, under the management of Messrs. W. W. Hollingsworth, R. Flcyd Clark, W.R. Corwine, and E.T. Birdsall, the Regatta Committee of the Corinthian Fleet of New-Rocheile. That enterprising club offers a prize for the winning yacht in the thirty-foot class, and one for the winning half-rater.

Gen. BRISTOW had many claims to the respect and gratitude of the American people. Among them the strongest was one that can thoroughly be known only to those whose memory goes back a score of years to that confused and anxious period that marked the close of the second term of President GRANT.
WAPPINGER'S FALLS, N.Y., June 23. -- An outrage was perpetrated in the cemetery on the outskirts of this village last night, which has stirred its inhabitants as they seldom Save been stirred.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- The Venezuelan Government has presented to the Venezuelan Commission the second volume of its certified copies of Spanish archives bearing upon the boundary dispute, and has promised the third and concluding volume in a few days.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., June 23. -- Consul General Lee's brother, Capt. D.H. Lee of Stafford County, Va. who is in constant Correspondence with his brother, denies emphatically that Gen. Lee has written the private letter concerning Cuban affairs reported in the morning papers.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 23. -- The Dominion general election has resulted in a sweeping victory for the Liberals. Their majority in the next Parliament over all parties combined will be 30 at least, and their plurality over the Conservatives will be 40.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., June 23. -- Consul General Lee's brother, Capt. D.H. Lee of Stafford County, Va. who is in constant Correspondence with his brother, denies emphatically that Gen. Lee has written the private letter concerning Cuban affairs reported in the morning papers.

SARATOGA, June 23. -- Gov. Flower reached this city at a little before 6 o'clock with the Buffalo delegates. He went to the United States Hotel. Before he got out of the corridor he stopped to shake hands with numerous acquaintances, and while he was there Mr. Whitney returned from Mr. Hill's room.
CANTON, June 23. -- Major McKinley was asked to-night, in view of numerous reports of his intention to visit this and that watering place, whether he intended to leave Canton this Summer.
McKinley and Hobart, pictured in canvas heroics, looked from the wall back of the stage upon an animated scene in Carnegie Hall last night.
The New-Yorks won a close game from Washington yesterday. The home team made all their runs in the third inning, when six men crossed the home plate.

SARATOGA, June 23. -- Judge James F. Swanwick of this village, who is Chairman of the local Committee of Arrangements, said to-day that all of the preliminary arrangements for the convention had been made. The convention hail has been artistically decorated. Portraits of President Cleveland, Senators Hill and Murphy, exGov. 'Flower, and ex-Lieut. Gov. Sheehan have been hung upon the walls and trimmed with flags and bunting.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, June 23. -- The report received here from Georgetown, British Guiana, yesterday, that Mr. Harrison, the chief of a British Guiana surveying party which was engaged in constructing a road from Barima to Cuyuni, was arrested on June 15, by orders from Caracas, and conveyed to the Venezuelan station opposite Yuruan, is confirmed by advices received here this morning from several sources.

SARATOGA, June 23. -- Democrats who are here to attend the State Convention to-morrow call it the skirmish line for Chicago. As the battle there is to be for gold against silver, so the talk here to-day is on that question, and, if the skirmish is an indication of the later conflict, there will be such a fight as is worth going to see.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The death of Gen. Bristow comes with a sudden and severe shock of pain and regret to many, if not to all, who knew him. Few men have inspired more genuine respect; few have won more constant friends; few have better earned and deserved the confidence of his fellow-men.

SARATOGA, June 23. -- The Democratic State Committee disposed of the contesting delegates from Kings County. led by Edward M. Shepard, in short Order tonight, at least in so far as the preliminary roll is concerned.

"Not guilty!" Such was the verdict in the Fleming case last night. It took the jurors nearly twelve hours to arrive at it, but they finally reached a decision, just before Recorder Goff was about to give the order to lock them up for the night.

CANTON, Ohio, June 23. -- Matthew Stanley Quay, Senator, broke in this morning upon the happiness that assurances of victory made by members of his party have brought to William McKinley, Jr., Presidential nominee. Mr. Quay sent a wetblanket letter. It arrived at the McKinley home in the big bundle from the first morning mail.
LONDON, June 23. -- Joseph Prestwich, D. C.L., F.R.S., the celebrated English geologist and author, is dead. He was eighty-four years old.

The authorities of Jersey City yesterday took possession of the property involved in the South Cove grant, given to it by the State in 1886 for $1,000, but which it only recently secured by a decision of the Court of Errors and Appeals after a struggle of fourteen years in the courts, as told in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, when the decision was given.

The halls and corridors of the Union League Club echoed again and again last night with vociferous applause at a special meeting called "for the purpose of giving expression to the views of the club concerning the candidates and the platform of the Republican National Convention held at St. Louis."

The appointment of Assistant Superintendents and a Supervisor of Lectures by the Board of Education and the transaction of other business occupied the attention of seventeen members of the board from 4:30 to 11 P.M. yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 24. -- The free-silver fever in the Democratic ranks in Indiana reached the climax of its virulence to-day, when its victims, in State Convention, rode rough-shod over all opposition, hurled all party traditions and precedents to the winds, ignored the most common principles of parliamentary practice, and hooted and hissed their old time leaders.

-- Judge Wallace in the Circuit Court for the Northern District of New-York, at Syracuse, denied yesterday the motion of Kresser against Lyman, which sought to enjoin the operation of the Raines law, on the ground that Kresser obtained a license for one year from last February. The decision is that the law is a police regulation.

SARATOGA, June 24. -- When the convention met after recess, the scenes of the morning were repeated so far as the applause for the leaders was concerned. Tae report of the Committee on Credentials was the first business, and this was in favor of the sitting delegates in Kings, Queens, and Richmond Counties.

Justice Pryor, in the Supreme Court, yes- terday, dismissed the complaint in the action brought by Wenzel Bridgeman to establish himself as a partner in the busi- ness of Thorley, the florist, with an inter- est of one-eighth.

SARATOGA, June 24. -- With few exceptions the delegates from New-York City and Kings County left for their homes early this evening. The Tammany special train started homeward at 6:30 o'clock, and the delegates expected to be in New-York by midnight. Ex-Mayor Gilrov and a few others remained over.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 24. -- The proceedings before the Committee on. Credentials were the liveliest of the convention. The passage at arms between the Shepard contestants and the old organization men from Kings was interesting, and Mayor Gleason did his annual low-comedy act, to the amusement of the committee.

CAPE TOWN, June 24. -- John Hays Hammond, one of the leaders of the Johannesburg Reform Committee, who, with Col. Francis Rhodes, George Farrar, and Lionel Phillips, was recently released from custody in Pretoria upon the payment of a fine of u25,000, sailed for England yesterday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 24. -- Cornell won the first round in the intercollegiate lowing regatta on the Hudson River here to-day. Her freshman eight defeated in the cleverest possible fashion the crews from Harvard, the University of Pennsylvania, and Columbia.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 24. -- The silver men had complete control of the Democratic State Convention held here to-day. They made the platform, and the convention adopted it by a vote of 542 to 128. The platform is as follows:

SARATOGA, June 24. -- The Sheehan-Purroy row in Tammany was in plain view again here to-day and it has taken on a very ugly look. Peace between them seems impossible. Mr. Sheehan's friends declare that he has knocked Mr. Purroy out at every turn this trip, and that appears to be the case up to date.

AUSTIN, Texas, June 24. -- The silver Democratic Convention, after some, discussion this morning by Judge Reagan on one side and Governor Hogg on the other, adopted Judge Reagan's money plank, as follows:

The most obvious explanation of the Liberal victory in Canada is that which has already been given in the dispatches. "JESHURUN waxed fat and kicked." We on this side of the border are aware that popular disgust with the party in power is likely to be the most powerful factor in bringing the other party into power.
It would be folly to ignore, and impossible to exaggerate, the gravity of the conditions under which this convention assembles.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- The wedding of Miss Bessie German, daughter of Senator A.P. Gorman, to Wilton J. Lambert, took place at 8 o'clock to-night at the residence of the Senator and Mrs. German. The Rev. Father Richards, S.J., President of Georgetown College, was the officiating clergyman, and L.F. Little, son of Judge Little of Louisville, Ky., a college friend of Mr. Lambert, was best man.
The Whist Congress was continued at the Oriental Hotel, Manhattan Beach, yesterday. The weather and whist were about the only subjects that were discussed at the hotel.

The Democracy of the State of New-York will be represented in the National Convention by delegates instructed in the terms of the platform adopted at Saratoga yesterday to use all their influence for a declaration committing the party to the "rigid maintenance of the present gold standard" until the bimetallic standard shall have been established by international co-operation.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 24. -- The free-silver fever in the Democratic ranks in Indiana reached the climax of its virulence to-day, when its victims, in State Convention, rode rough-shod over all opposition, hurled all party traditions and precedents to the winds, ignored the most common principles of parliamentary practice, and hooted and hissed their old time leaders.

BOSTON, June 24. -- Two runs behind in the ninth inning, Boston won out in great style in the baseball same to-day. Tucker hit safely, and Duffy tied the same by his home-run drive. Then Lowe hit safely, made second on Corcoran's error, third on Daly's error, and scored the winning run on Tenney's fourth hit. Tenney made two wonderful running foul catches, and his fielding and batting were the features of the game.

For many months past the combination price of steel rails to buyers in this country has been $28 per ton at Eastern mills and $29 at the mills of the Illinois Steel Company. The Illinois Company and the Carnegie Company are the leading concerns in the combination, which is enabled to exact these prices from buyers in the United States by the tariff duty of $7.84 per ton on foreign rails.

SARATOGA, June 24. -- The delegates chosen by the State Convention held here to-day will take this message from the Democrats of the Empire State to the Democratic National Convention that will be held in Chicago in July:

NEWARK, N.J., June 24. -- Charles A. Storms of Waukegan, Ill., last night was severely injured while attempting to ride a bicycle from Belleville to Bloomfield Cen- tre and back in less than fifteen minutes. Shortly after starting out he rode over a rocky ledge, fell twenty-five feet, and then rolled unconscious into the Second River.

TORONTO, Ontario, June 24. -- The results of yesterday's election show a majority of not less than 50 against the Government and a straight Liberal majority over all of about 30. In addition to the three Cabinet Ministers already mentioned as having been defeated, A.R. Angers, President of the Council, suffered defeat, making in all four Cabinet Ministers who lost their seats.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 24. -- The silver men had complete control of the Democratic State Convention held here to-day. They made the platform, and the convention adopted it by a vote of 542 to 128. The platform is as follows:
CANTON, Ohio, June 24. -- When Major McKinley came down to breakfast this morning he found the postman had left 1,000 letters. The average number of letters received daily is over 4,000.

Two hundred and seventy applicants for the position of special agents in the Excise Department presented themselves in this city yesterday for the competitive civil service examination which is necessary to obtain a position on the eligible list. The examination here is only for the New-York and Brooklyn districts.

Miss Ella B. Ottmann, who is well known in German-American society for her beauty and talents, and Bernard Setzer were married in Grace Protestant Episcopal Church at noon yesterday. The church was finely decorated for the occasion. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. William R. Huntington, the rector, and there was a full choral service.

SARATOGA, June 24. -- The Committee on Nominations of Delegates reported to the convention as soon as the resolutions had been disposed of, and its report was speedily adopted. Each of the delegates at large, namely, Senator D.B. Hill, ex-Gov. R. P. Flower, Edward Murphy, Jr., and Frederic R. Coudert, and their alternates, Robert Earl Smith M. Weed, Jacob A. Cantor, and William Purcell, were greeted with applause, as were some of the district delegates.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 24. -- Gen. James H. Wilson, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, has issued a call for the State Convention at Dover, July 16. This is the regular organization. It is not known what the Addicks State Committee will do.

SARATOGA, June 24. -- To-day's convention was more like a gathering of business men bent on transacting their affairs in an orderly and deliberate way than it was like an ordinary political convention. The hall was simply decorated, and the sounding board back of the speakers' desk was festooned with portraits of Cleveland, Flower, Hill, and other leaders of Democracy.

LONDON, June 24. -- A representative of The United Press was informed at the Foreign Office to-day that the Government would certainly take immediate and energetic measures to obtain the release of Mr. Harrison, the British surveyor who was recently arrested in British Guiana and is now detained at the Venezuelan station, opposite Yuruan.
A meeting of the Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge was to have been held yesterday, but as there was not a quorum present it was adjourned.

HAVANA, June 25. -- Col. Gaston reports that while pursuing the rebel parties commanded by Lacret, Sanguily, and another leader, his scouts killed a German, named Walter Zandt, the manufacturer of the explosives recently used in destroying railway trains. The Spanish troops met the rebels in the Josefa Hills, near Limonar, Province of Matanzas.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 25. -- Sir Charles Tupper is bearing his defeat with philosophical resignation. He has telegraphed for his colleagues to return to Ottawa. When the Cabinet shall reassemble it will then be decided whether or not to meet the House or to resign forthwith. Respecting the elections, Sir Charles says:

Anthony Comstock and his agent, George Oram, yesterday arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court, Russell Hunting, an actor, thirty-one years old, of 45 Clinton Place, on a charge of violating Section 317 of the Penal Code, and Charles M. Carson, thirty-seven years old, who said he was a clerk and lived at Newark, N.J., on a charge of aiding and abetting Hunting in violating the law.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 25 -- Since the opening of the defense in the suit of William J. Thompson against The Philadelphia Press for libel, there have been some startling revelations. Among them was the testimony of Senator Rogers that while racetrack bills were pending in the State Legislature a few years ago.
MACON, Ga., June 25. -- The Georgia Democrats adopted the unit rule in their convention to-day and elected a solid delegation to go to Chicago to fight for free silver.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 25 -- The advance guard of students to see the intercollegiate regatta has been pouring into town all day. The hotels are filled to their utmost. Boarding houses are packed with young men, who swear about both the quantity and quality of the food, while they boast about the certainty of victory for the crew of the college with which they happen to be affiliated.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The Holt will case, which has been on trial in this city for several weeks, was ended to-night, when the jury returned a verdict in favor of the caveators, the effect of which is to set the alleged will aside, or, in the words of the decision of the jury, is substantially a declaration, that the paper presented for probate is not a true testament.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 25. -- Sir Charles Tupper is bearing his defeat with philosophical resignation. He has telegraphed for his colleagues to return to Ottawa. When the Cabinet shall reassemble it will then be decided whether or not to meet the House or to resign forthwith. Respecting the elections, Sir Charles says:
Are we on the verge of financial revolution? No, nor anywhere near it.
CHICAGO, June 25 -- Lyman Trumbull died this morning at his home in this city.

We have received a neat pamphlet containing the "Answer of the Sherman Statue Committee of the Army of the Tennessee to the National Sculpture Society of New-York City." It will be remarked that even in the title there is a begging of the question and an appeal to some assumed sectional prejudice.
Peace at home and abundant capital from abroad will within a reasonable time make the South as rich and prosperous as the North.

The Young Men's Democratic Club of Brooklyn placed itself on record last night in favor of a gold standard. The meeting was held at 44 Court Street, Brooklyn, and the following resolutions were adopted:

A decision was handed down by Justice MacLean, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, in favor of the plaintiffs in a suit brought by Emma Hayes and her four nephews against Leonard R. Kerr, Lawrence R. Kerr, and others, as executors and trustees under the will of Lawrence R. Kerr, to set aside transfers of the premises at 363, 365, 367, and 369 Fourth Avenue, known as the Putnam House.

SING SING, N.Y., June 25. -- George W. Carter, a prisoner serving a term in the State prison, mysteriously disappeared from that institution June 5, 1893, and has never been heard of since. How he escaped puzzled the prison officials, as he was seen a short time before at work in the engine room of the shoe shop, where he was employed as engineer.

Republican quality had its turn at ratifying the St. Louis platform and ticket at Carnegie Hall last evening. For this purpose the Republican Club arranged for good speakers, assembled a high-class platform attendance, and set out to overshadow the demonstration by the County Committee at the same place Tuesday evening.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- While the friends of silver are full of joy over the outcome of the Democratic Conventions in Indiana, Illinois, and Ohio, their demonstrations have not served to weaken the hope of the soundmoney Democrats here that wise counsels will prevail at Chicago and prevent the disruption of the party.

DENVER, Col., June 25. -- Five hundred delegates of all political parties, representing two-thirds of the counties in Colorado, organized to-day the first State Convention of the National Silver Party, adopted a platform, and elected delegates to the National Convention, which will meet in St. Louis July 22. The convention was harmonious and enthusiastic.
ST. PAUL, June 25 -- Infuriated citizens of Southern Minnesota are trying to-night to lynch the tramps who yesterday murdered Sheriff Rodgers of McLeod County.
