WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Senator Peffer of Kansas does not expect Mr. McKlnley's defeat this year, except by a union of all the free-silver forces. On the other hand, such a combination, he believes, would sweep the country. This was the central thought of Senator Peffer's utterances upon the political outlook in an interview to_day.
Four men were painfully injured yesterday afternoon when a north-bound Lexington Avenue cable car came to a sudden stop at Broadway and Twenty-second Street. The cause of the accident is not known.

Miss Louisa Fritz of 324 West Fifty-second Street thought she saw an umbrella that her mother. Mrs. Barbara Burgart, had lost on Monday in the possession of Mrs. Lizzie Crumm of 151 West One Hundredth Street, when they met yesterday in a Sixth Avenue dry goods store.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- The courtroom was again crowded this morning when the Gentry trial was taken up. Gentry's aged mother, as usual, occupied a seat alongside of the dock. The prisoner was composed and he apparently took an interest in the calling of witnesses, , by the court crier before the resumption of the case.

KINGSTOWN, Jamaica, June 25. -- According to advices received here from Georgetown, British Gulana, an armed police force has been dispatched to Acarabisci for the purpose of protecting the British surveyors, who, while engaged in opening a road from the Barima to the Cuyuni River, were stopped by a body of Venezuelans, and their leader, Crown Surveyor Harrison, arrested.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Secretary Herbert to-day began his investigation into the cost of armor manufacture in the United States. The inquiry is the result of Congressional action directing the Secretary to look into the matter with a view to submitting a report on the subject. Mr. Fleischman of the Carnegie Company, Judge McCammer, counsel for the Bethlehem Company, and others interested in armor manufacture were present.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 25 -- Dr. George H. Perrine of Tarrytown, who was the complainant for the people in the recent trial of Dr. T.V. Roe, also of Tarrytown, a dentist, for criminal libel, which resulted in Dr. Roe's acquittal, is now a prisoner himself in the charge of the Sheriff of Westchester County, he having been indicted by the Grand Jury for criminal libel against Dr. Roe.

A rich man who devotes money to the sustaining of a dramatic venture which cannot be sustained on commercial grounds is technically known as an "angel." It is no wonder that he should be so called in "the profession." He is willing to invest money without any distinct prospect of repayment by reason of his interest in the dramatic art.

The Reorganization Committee of the creditors of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau held a meeting yesterday morning in the office of William Steinway and formally adopted the plan for a final adjustment of the finances of the embarrassed firm according to the scheme exclusively outlined in THE NEW-YORK, TIMES of last Sunday.
PARIS, June 25. -- The Due de Nemours died at Versailles to-day.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 25. -- The Czar is suffering from an attack or jaundice.

A meeting to advocate the free coinage of silver was held last evening in the Cooper Union, under the "joint suspices" of the Young Democracy of New-York and the American Silver Organization. The Young Democracy is the old O'Brien Democracy under a new name.

DULUTH, June 25. -- Congressman Charles A. Towne met with an ovation from the people of Duluth on his return to the city last night such as never has been accorded to any other person in the history of the city.

The disagreeable weather still continues to make the players who are attending the Whist Congress at the Oriental Hotel, Manhattan Beach, keep indoors. The fourth day did not materially differ from that of the previous days, as the players in the Hamilton and the Minneapolis Trophy contests and in the progressive match for fours still kept up their play.

CANTON, Ohio, June 25. -- Major McKinley is in great demand as a Fourth of July orator. Invitations from a score of places have been received, asking him to take part in celebrations. A very strong delegation from Columbus, Ohio, headed by Mayor Cotton Alien, called on Major McKinley this evening and urged him to go to Columbus on the Fourth, not as a Presidential candidate, but as an old friend among his own people.

KINGSTOWN, Jamaica, June 25. -- According to advices received here from Georgetown, British Gulana, an armed police force has been dispatched to Acarabisci for the purpose of protecting the British surveyors, who, while engaged in opening a road from the Barima to the Cuyuni River, were stopped by a body of Venezuelans, and their leader, Crown Surveyor Harrison, arrested.

HIGHLAND, N.Y., June 25 -- If confidence can win a boat race, then the Pennsylvania men will win to-morrow's race, hands down. Their defeat yesterday in the freshmen's race has only served as a stimulant, and they are determined that in the 'Varsity race, if they can't win, the winners shall know that they have had a race.

Conventions have now been held in all the States and Territories for the purpose of appointing delegates to the Democratic National Convention at Chicago. From the table herewith given it appears that the convention will consist of 585 advocates of free silver and 344 gold standard men -- 930 in all.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 23 -- By the capsizing of a sailboat at Clearwater Lake, near Annadale, Minn., this morning, John U. Putnam, bookkeeper for J.Q. Adams of the Corn Exchange, Minneapolis; his sister. Miss Anna T. Putnam, employed in the Minneapolis Kindergarten; Miss Bessie Newhall of Minneapolis, and Mr. Sherman of St. Paul were drowned.
Among the advertisements which The London Times, by placing them under the heading of "Miscellaneous," admits that it cannot classify, there appeared on the 15th inst. these enigmatic lines:

SOMERVILLE, N.J., June 25. -- Mrs. Fleming spent the greater part of the day indoors with her children. She seemed in excellent spirits. After luncheon, accompanied by Gracie and Walter, she drove in Mrs. Shaw's closed carriage to this place and visited the leading dry goods house, and spent about two hours there making a number of purchases.

The Tree Planting Association of New-York City which came into life May 22, and which has as its objects the beautifying of the streets of the city and the preservation of trees now growing, met yesterday in the Wool Club, West Broadway and Beach Street, adopted a constitution, and elected officers.
SISTERVILLE, West Va., June 25. -- About 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon a heavy rainstorm passed over this city and vicinity.

ALBANY, June 25 -- Some months ago a request for the loan of the Revolutionary muster rolls of New-York State to the War Department of the National Government was made through Gov. Morton to the State Board of Regents. To-day it leaked out that the Regents, at their meeting yesterday, had refused to loan the rolls.

The United States cruisers Cincinnati and Montgomery left their anchorage off Staten Island yesterday and proceeded to sea for target practice. They will join the battle- ship Indiana, which went out for the same purpose Wednesday. On their return to port in a few days they will prepare for the annual Summer cruise in North Atlantic waters.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- There was no cessation of interest in the Gentry murder trial to-day, and when the Court of Oyer and Terminer opened this morning there was a large attendance. The attendance continued large throughout the day and evening until the case was given to the jury at 9:45 o'clock.

We printed the other day two tables in which the geographical relations of thrift and the silver craze were set forth. The first table showed the silver vote by States and Territories at the St. Louis Convention and the second exhibited in the same order the deposits in the savings banks.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 26. -- Fortytwo cars, with circus seats built on each, were filled with shouting, enthusiastic college boys and their friends, and followed the oarsmen down the river. The cars stood opposite the finish line all the afternoon, and as early as 2 o'clock those who had tickets crossed the river and walked down the track to the train.

The second annual commencement exerrises of the male department of Grammar ichool No. 6, Eighty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue, of which Wilbur F. Hudson is Principal, were held yesterday afternoon. Trustee Joseph Fettretch presided. Louis Strauss was the salutatorian and Henry Schell was the valedictorian.

ST. Louis, June 26. -- Bland headquarters will be opened at Chicago next Monday. Col. Nicholas M. Bell, Col. Joseph K. Rickey, and George W. Allen will be in charge. They are all members of the Bland Executive Committee, of which Gov. Stone is Chairman.

-- Father Mortara, a regular canon of St. Augustine, who has just been appointed to the charge of the Hospice of the Great St. Bernard, is said to be the Edgar Mortara whose kidnapping in 1858 by the Archbishop of Bologna set all Europe in a ferment. The child of Jewish parents, he was alleged to have been baptized by a maid servant, and the Church of Rome claimed him.

BUTTE, Mon., June 26. -- Congressman Charles S. Hartman, the Montana delegate who followed Henry M. Teller out of the St. Louis Convention, visited Butte yesterday, and received the greatest reception ever accorded a public man in the State. Several hundred silver men, including some of the most prominent citizens in Butte, pulled the Congressman's carriage from the station to the hotel, a distance of over a mile.

KEY WEST, Fla., June 26. -- This city was thrown into a fever of excitement this evening by the arrival of the steamer City of Richmond, with all passengers and a prize crew from the revenue cutter Winona on board.

From The Providence (R.I.) Journal. Ex-Gov. Brown is firmly of the opinion that with a united State delegation behind him he would have been nominated at St. Louis for Vice President. His fallure to secure the nomination he attributes solely to the entrance of Gov. Lippitt into the field.

The American Line steamship St. Paul sailed past the Sandy Hook Light Ship at 5:12 o'clock P.M. yesterday the winner of new laurels for herself, her American owners, and her American builders. The Cu- nard steamship Lucania crossed the bar twenty-four minutes ahead of her, after one day's performance that no ship ever built has equaled.

From The St. Paul (Minn.) Globe. Capt. William H. Harries, Collector of Internal Revenue, in a recent conversation touching certain incidents of the war, mentioned Old Abe, the famous war eagle. The Captain was asked for a history of the "bird, and here it is.

We observe in one or two quarters in the West signs of a desire to compromise the silver issue at Chicago. This is a symptom of returning reason, and therefore it is encouraging, but the willingness of Eastern Democrats to compromise the free-coinage issue would depend upon the nature of the bargain.

Greater New-York's entries in the National League baseball race met in a contest at Eastem Park yesterday, and the Brooklyns won, 3 to 1. The alleged Giants, with Clark in the box, were never in the hunt. Payne twirled the sphere for the winning team, and was steady and effective at critical periods. The score:

The letter of Mr. JOHN W. GATES, President of the Illinois Steel Company, to Mr. WILLIAM H. HAWORTH of this city, to which we referred on the 25th inst., we regard as a very interesting and even important contribution to the literature of the impending campaign. We quoted the greater part of this letter on the 25th inst., omitting, however, one paragraph which deserves to be considered by itself.

One of the most flourishing trades on the east side of the city, in the congested district east of the Bowery, which, from the preponderance of the Hebrew population has come to be known as the Ghetto, is the sale of lottery tickets. The police admit that it exists and thrives, and that they have been unable to stop it.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. June 26. -- When the Cornell launch Cornell landed the victorious eight at their boathouse, the great crowd assembled on the wharf cheered and shouted and made a tremendous demonstration. Thousands lined the shore, and the hills directly behind, and they, too, took up the cry.
WASHINGTON, June 26. -- Minister Andrade at noon to-day received the following cable- gram and immediately sent a copy to Secretary Olney:
BOSTON, June 26. -- At a meeting of the Arkwright Club last night, the cotton factors agreed to shut down their mills for at least thirty days.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 28. -- The active campaign of the various silver elements preparatory to the Democratic National Convention, will be commenced Tuesday next, when the Bimetallic National Democratic Committee, which is made up of leading silver Democrats throughout the country, will assemble.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Preparations are being made in Chicago to have delegations of the Iroquois Club and other Democratic organi- zations meet incoming delegations to the National Democratic Convention. Wherever delegations arrive in a body, an effort will be made to meet them at the stations with an escort, consisting of a marching club and a band of music, to escort them to their re- spective headquarters.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 26. -- The fleet of yachts that came up from New-York formed a big attraction for the Poughkeepsians all day. Every time a yacht came to anchor and fired her gun there would be a rush to the waterside on both sides of the river to see the new arrival and admire her good points.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 26. -- Several hundred very young men and a few score of older ones are roaming about this town to-night, exhibiting symptoms of insanity in which melancholia does not figure, and screaming at the tops of their voices that it is of Cornell that they yell.

The sixth annual congress of the American Whist League will adjourn, to-day. The Congress has been most successful, the only drawback being the disagreeable weather. The women who are in attendance had a little change yesterday, as the sun came out long enough to make it pleasant to walk along the beach.

BALTIMORE, June 26. -- Senator German will not attend the Chicago Convention. He will be seeking rest and recreation while men like Whitney and Russell are laboring to keep the Democracy from party suicide. He has refused an appointment as delegate at large from Maryland in place of Charles C. Homer, who declined, and ex-State Treasurer Spencer has been named to fill the vacancy.

BERLTN, June 26. -- The Supreme Court of the empire, sitting at Leipsic, has rejected the appeal of Baron von Hammerstein, formerly leader of the Conservatives in the Reichstag and editor in chief of the Kreuz-Zeitung, from the sentence imposed upon him by the Berlin court upon his conviction of forgery on April 22 last.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 26. -- When the crews reached their starting point three miles up the river, at Krum Elbow, there was no one there to welcome them. The long, snakelike observation train of forty-two cars had waited at the finish line, where it was loaded for the special parlor-car train from New-York, which was expected to bring up Gov. Morton and his staff.

CANTON, Ohio, June 26. -- The women of Canton called this afternoon on Major and Mrs. McKinley and the Major's mother. An unbroken procession of women, two and three abreast, passed through the house, entering at the front and moving out by the side door. The two Mrs. McKinley sat on a platform in the parlor, and the Major, who stood at the left of his wife, made the introductions.

Ex-Senator Warner Miller and his friends have begun a vigorous war on ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt and his followers. The issue between the two Republican factions is sharply drawn, and judging from ex-Senator Miller's speech at the meeting of the MeKinley County League last night, the wounded will soon be falling inside and outside the breastworks.

RALEIGH, N.C., June 26. -- The Democratic Convention was in session until 4:30 o'clock this morning. It elected as delegates at large to Chicago John R. Webster, Thomas J. Jarvis, Edward J. Hall, and A.M. Wad- dell. These and district delegates go with- out instructions as to Presidential prefer- ence, but they are instructed to vote as a unit "unflinchingly and at all hazards for the restoration of silver."

PARIS, June 26. -- A representative of The United Press had an interview with Perry Belmont at the railway station to-night just as Mr. Belmont was starting for Havre on his way to Chicago to attend the National Democratic Convention.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The most alarming report from Cuba with respect to yellow fever comes from Sagua la Grand, where, the Marine Hospital Service is advised by its last report, there are forty-one cases and four deaths. It is expected that within a very short time the fever will become epidemic, and if it does not become virulent in the City of Havana, all previous experiences will be set aside.

Some surprise was expressed yesterday when it was announced that the Democratic Club of the Twenty-first Assembly restrict had invited Senator B.R. Tillman of South Carolina to address the club's members on the subject of free silver.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., June 26. -- One of the most daring attempts at bank robbery was discovered by the local police a few days ago, and the facts were made public last night. A suit of mud-stained clothing was recently found in the rooms occupied by three noted crooks, which led the police to suspect that the trio were tunneling under some bank or safe deposit vault.
The New-Yorks won the game from the Brooklyns yesterday by clever batting in the ninth inning. Both teams played a good game, and the pitchers were batted rather freely. The score:

LOUISVILLE, June 27 -- The Race Committee of the '96 Meet Club, of which M.J. Fleck is Chairman, has completed the largest part of its work. The programme of races has been arranged, prizes, numbering ninety-six in all, secured for each race, and entry blanks are now being mailed to racing men and clubs all over the country.

There has been continued activity at the navy yard during the past week. All departments have felt the impetus of demands upon them for repairs to the home squadron, while the work upon the Puritan and the Chicago is advancing at a steady pace.

KEY WEST, Fla., June 27. -- The case of Perico Torres and other alleged filibusters on board the steamer City of Richmond, charged with violation of Article 5,286, Revised Statutes, was called this morning before United States Commissioner Ramon Alvarez, and was continued until Wednesday in order that the District Attorney might be here.
John Addison Ryman, better known as "Governor Ad. Ryman," the minstrel and negro delineator, was found dead yesterday in his room, in a theatrical boarding house at 142 East Sixteenth Street.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 27 -- Frank H. Escort, Secretary and Treasurer of the Michigan Division, Leagua of American Wheelmen, was deposed this morning by Chief Consul Steele of St. John's for cause. There is said to be a discrepancy in Escott's books. Leo A. Caro, appointed in Escott's stead, has assumed charge of the books.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The Chicago newspapers are full of convention talk, some of it incredible, and all of it based upon very little convention material. S.P. Sheerin, Secretary of the National Committee, is here; so are Mr. Griff and Mr. Prather of Missouri; E.C. Wall of Wisconsin has been here, and Col. Martin, who is Sergeant at Arms, is both here and busy.

Ex-Secretary William C. Whitney said yesterday that there could be no compromise in the Chicago Convention by Eastern sound-money Democrats, and that if a free-coinage candidate was nominated by the Southern and Western men on a free-coinage platform, the party would be disrupted.

Assistant District Attorney John D. Lindsay gave out yesterday a statement as to how the house of I. Townsend Burden of 5 Madison Square North was robbed on Dec. 28, 1895. The details were obtained from the confessions of William Robert Dunlop and William Turner, the two servants, who have pleaded guilty and who are to be sentenced by Judge Cowing in the General Sessions Court to-morrow.

The assault of Firkeh, described at first as if it had been a skirmish in the course of operations on the Nile, may turn out to have been an engagement marking a central point in the modern history of Egypt.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- It is reported that Samuel P. McConnell is to be placed in nomination and supported for President by the Illinois delegation in the Democratic National Convention. If Mr. McConnell shall not get first place on the ticket, it is the intention of Gov. Altgeld and his associate delegates to continue the fight, and, if possible, secure for McConnell the nomination for the Vice Presidency.

With the vacation season at hand a new era dawns upon the thousands who for the first time will associate with their period of rest and recreation the delights of leisure cycling amid new or cherished scenes. To be able to go at will to this place or that, to tour at one's owr pleasure to a distant point, should make many vacation periods this season long to be remembered.

The South a quarter of a century ago, to a large extent, was under the domination of as mean and corrupt a band of political spoilers as ever held power in this country. These men were imported into the South by the triumphant Republicans to complete the destruction of Democracy, and to insure the perpetuation of the Republican Party.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. In- formation of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

There was a serious collision yesterday afternoon in Park Row, near Ann Street, between a Third Avenue cable car and a Dry Dock line horse car, which resulted in the smashing and overturning of the horse car and general excitement around the Post Office. A number of persons narrowly escaped injury, and but for the presence of mind of the driver of the horse car, his horses would have beeen killed.

VANCOUVER, B.C., June 27 -- According to Australian advices, the temporary migration of cyclers Harris, Lewis, Payne, McLean, and Megson to England on professional visits has created a void not easily filled. A few fast men remain, however, including the American crack Martin, Parsons, Crossthwaite, and Turner. Parsons's stay in the colonies for the present is not of long duration, as he shortly leaves for Italy, in company with Porta, the Italian champion.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 27. -- Group VII, of the New-York State Bankers' Association met at Summit Mountain to-day at 11 o'clock. After reports had been made by the various standing committees, a series of discussions, speeches being limited to ten minutes, were carried on by the members on these subjects: "Country collections," "Protection against bank forgeries," and "Guaranteed indorsements."

Capt. T.P. Leathers, the veteran steamboat man, is dead. The familiar form of the venerable old pilot, whose hair was frosted by the snow of more than fourscore Winters, will be seen on the streets no more, and thousands of friends all over the country will learn the sad news with keen regret.

Some landlords are grasping. Some are avaricious. Probably a large majority of them keep hotels for gain, and not for the pleasure of serving the public. Certainly a large majority of the St. Louis landlords thrived for a few days. The- proprietor of one hotel on the night of June 15 began filling his corridor with cots, although he had originally agreed that this should not be done.

ST. LOUIS, June 27 -- The caucus of the managers of the Bland campaign lasted nearly two hours. Among those participating besides the members of the Campaign Committee were Delegate at Large George W. Allen and District Delegates Nicholas M. Bell, Moses C. Wetmore, Hugh Brady, Charles Gregory, J. Wesley Booth, and Col. J.K. Rickey.

It pleases the Republican organs to call the Saratoga platform "a straddle." If we thought that it was one, we should condemn it. If Republicans really think it is one, they must condemn both it and the St. Louis platform, for they are in substance exactly the same thing. The Democrats at Saratoga said:

CANTON, June 27 -- An event to-day which seemed to arose the enthusiasm of the ratification crowd was the arrival of a coon from Apollo, Penn. This coon was sent from Canton to Pennsylvania upon the occasion of a great Republican victory there a few years ago, with the understanding that it should be returned in the event of McKinley's nomination for the Presidency.
The second meeting of the Greater New-York Commission was held in the Board of Aldermen's chamber yesterday, and an adjournment was taken until Sept. 21 at 10 o'clock A.M.

An outcome of the "mixed match" between Brooklyn and New-Jersey was a challenge from eight New-Jersey couples to eight Brooklyn couples. The match was played at the house of Mrs. Ruggles, Bayonne, N.J., last week. It resulted in an overwhelming victory for Brooklyn, the score standing 37 for Brooklyn and 7 for New-Jersey.

Assemblyman Arthur C. Butts yesterday enjoyed the experience of being present at a careful examination of the structure of the Manhattan Railway Company, at One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Third Avenue.

CANTON, Ohio, June 27 -- The nomination of McKinley was ratified here this afternoon. The influx of people from Cleveland and other cities of Eastern Ohio was very large. The speaking was from a stand erected at one end of a vacant lot.

One of the most peculiar products of the Earth is asbestos. It is a mystery. Half of a mineral nature and half of a vegetable nature, capable of being spun into cloth and yet able to resist the strongest acids and the fiercest flames, pliable, and yet often more endurable than the rocks in which it can be found, it is indeed a mysterious substance.

LONDON, June 20 -- London is governed like no other community, big or little, in the world. Its government may be compared to a building the earliest parts of which were built a thousand years ago, and to which every new generation since then has added some new wing or attic or basement, without pulling down much of what it found standing.

The Twenty-second Regiment, with commendable enterprise, has decided to erect a house on Creedmoor range for the exclusive use of its members who go to the range to shoot, and has received permission from the State authorities to this end. The building, a cut of which is here given, is situated near the house erected by the State for the accommodation of riflemen.

Another malady has been discovered by the Faculty. It takes the form of "academy headache." This is not meant as an excuse for boys who attend seats of learning dignified with the name neglecting their lessons, but is an inconvenience which afflicts those who study high art -- not high in an aesthetic sense, but high up on the walls -- skied, in fact.

The campaign in the Soudan has gone far enough to make it clear how greatly the Egyptian troops have been improved under the English protectorate. In the fighting of ten years ago the Khedive's soldiers were so overmatched by the Soudanese, and it must be added that their commanders were so outgeneraled by OSMAN DIGNA, that the occupation of the country was esteemed to be quite hopeless.

LONDON, June 27. -- As might be supposed, the arrest of Crown Surveyor Harrison by Venezuelans, on what is claimed to be British territory, caused many energetic newspaper protests and demands that immediate action be taken to compel his release. A British official of Guiana, who is home on leave of absence, has supplied the Government with information regarding the locality where the arrest was made, and has thrown considerable light on the matter.

The sixth annual congress of the American Whist League, which has been in session since last Monday in the Oriental Hotel, at Manhattan Beach, was finished last night. It was late when the finals were completed, and the full scores will not be known until to-day.

Central Park is never more lovely than immediately after a rain. The rain, like the dew, only to a greater extent, brings out all the fragrance of shrubs and flowers. There is an odor of fresh mold that is delightful. The raindrops shine like jewels on the grass and trees. There is Something even in the absence of the people that is restful.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 27. -- The incoming boats and trains to-night brought to Newport a host of Summer residents, who had reached New-York from Europe by the late incoming steamers. Among them were Mr. and Mrs. Oliver H.P. Belmont, B. Harold Vanderbilt, Buchanan Winthrop, Miss Sibyl Sherman, Mrs. N.D. Clapp, Miss Clapp, Thomas F. Cushing, Miss Edith Cushing, and Howard Cushing.

HENLEY, June 27 -- The river was almost deserted this morning, so far as practicing crews were concerned, owing to the extreme heat. The Leander and New College crews did not row at all. The Yale eight went out on the water at 10:45 o'clock, but stayed only half an hour, rowing short stretches and practicing at raising their stroke.

Audran's "Ollivette," which has not been sung here lately, will take the place of "Pinafore," at the Herald Square Theatre, to-morrow night. Hallen Mostyn, Tom Ricketts, and Ben Lodge have been engaged for the roles of Captain de Merrimac, the Due des Ifs, and Coquelicot. Dorothy Morton will be Olivette and Flora Finlayson the Countess de Rousillon.

Slumbering beneath many a peaceful cornfield in Ireland are buried villages which once stood in the heart of the primeval British forest, engirdled by the waters of some stagnant peaty lake. The Irish farmer of to-day turns up with his plow the wooden piles upon which these lake dwellings rested; they are black with age, but you can yet trace the mortise holes which the ancient Celt made with his primitive flint chisel.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 21 -- The South Orange Field Club and the First Separate Company of New-York had a hotly contested game of ball on the former's grounds to-day. Both teams played fast ball. The score:

We present this morning for the benefit of the Greater New-York Commission a concise account from the pen of our London correspondent of the administrative system, or lack of system, of the British metropolis. We fear that it will not aid the commission very much in its task, but it may afford suggestions and relieve it from the necessity of making fruitless investigations.

Perhaps the most interesting aspect of the growth of Harvard University durig the last twenty-five or thirty years, of which we give a somewhat extended account in this issue of THE TIMES, is the gradual development of what may be called the American idea of university education.

Recalling former military organizations in his History of the Twenty-second Regiment, Gen. George W. Wingate tells us that before the war of the rebellion the National Guard, as an organization, was "more social than military. They were practically self-supporting. The State provided arms, belts, and cartridge boxes.

The Cunard steamship Umbria, which left her pier, at the foot of Clarkson Street, North River, at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, came to a dead stop an hour and a quarter later in the Ship Channel, on the coal-laden wreck of the barge Andrew Jackson, once a swift American clipper, which was sunk on May 22 in collision with the steamship Vedra.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 27 -- The battle of Monmouth, which is said to have been one of the hottest in the history of the Revolution, was fought on Sunday, June 28, 1778. The American Army was commanded by Gens. Washington and Breen, and the British were under the command of Gen. Clinton.

Capt. Robert Graham of the American ship William F. Babcock was arrested yesterday afternoon by United States Deputy Marshals McCarty and McMahon and was arraigned before United State Commissioner Alexander on a charge of having assaulted Seaman James Graves on the high seas.
"Each gold shipment represents a debt paid!" Such was the reply made by a white-haired and very conservative bank President when asked why American gold was sent abroad in such large quantities.

With a permit from the Minister of War, (writes the special correspondent of The London Chronicle from Moscow,) I have just visited the big camp at Khodinskoie Pole, to the west of the St. Petersburg Road, and nearly facing Petrovsky Palace. Unfortunately, my time was short, and I cannot pretend to describe completely a camp which "lies stretching many a rood," and, indeed, many a mile.

Over the return cycle path, in Brooklyn, which lies like a strip of gray ribbon from Prospect Park to the sea, there rode yesterday an army of cyclists. There were all sorts and conditions among them -- the grave and the gay, side by side, each bent on doing his share to celebrate the formal opening of the second path in the imperial Ocean Boulevard.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 27 -- Four boats' crews of the First Naval Battalion of New-York to-day established a camp of instruction at Sands Point, about eight miles from this village. The place selected for the camp is in a shady grove on the grounds of the Sands Point Hotel, which was destroyed by fire some time ago.

LA PLATA, Md., June 27 -- Joseph Cocking, who was awaiting trial on the charge of murdering his wife and sister-in-law, was taken from the jail at Port Tobacco early this morning by a mob of his fellow countians and hanged to a bridge. The mob was composed of about thirty masked men, half of whom, in addition to their disguises, masqueraded in women's attire.

Nothing in the queer personal controversies of French literature can be much queerer than the response of M. EMILE ZOLA to an accusation of plagiarism. A critic of his novel "Rome," as is known, set forth that the novelist had incorporated with his own work, without any sort of acknowledgment, whole pages of a book upon the Vatican.

A decision of the court of last resort in Connecticut concerning the fouling of water courses by sewage discharges from cities and villages encourages riparian owners to take advantage of the law so established. The decision in question, to which we referred some time ago, affected directly the city of Danbury, the plaintiff having been an owner of farm land on the banks of the stream into which Danbury's sewage was discharged.

During the Republican National Convention in St. Louis many figures of speech were used by the various orators. Some of the metaphors were mixed and others were not; some of the similes were new, and some were old; some of the phrases employed were fresh, while others were stale.

KEY WEST, Fla., June 27. -- The case of Perico Torres and other alleged filibusters on board the steamer City of Richmond, charged with violation of Article 5,286, Revised Statutes, was called this morning before United States Commissioner Ramon Alvarez, and was continued until Wednesday in order that the District Attorney might be here.

LONDON, June 27 -- Poor Mr. Balfour, having been forced to exhibit himself in the penitential sheet, candle in hand, for a sufficient period to enable his whole party and the public generally to digest the fact of his unfitness for chief command, it is now smart Mr. Chamberlain's turn to claim popular attention and show what a different sort of person he is.

STATE CAMP PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 27 -- The annual camp season of the National Guard was begun to-day and will continue until Aug. 8. The State camp at Peekskill, overlooking the Hudson, shows a wider spread of canvas than it ever has. Looking down from the Dunderhead, the cantonment looks like a choppy sea of white billows.

At the invitation of Temple Lodge, Major W.S. Brackett of Montana delivered an address on "The Heroic Free Masons of Early Montana; Their Redemption of that Territory from Ruffian Rule in Pioneer Times."

Regardless of the half-holiday yesterday sidewalk obstructors in the wholesale grocery, produce, and commission district down town continued to violate the law. They offended as grossly in the early afternoon as in the morning.

BERLIN, June 18 -- Three brilliant days fell to the lot of the German rowing gentry this year, and on each day the presence of the Emperor on board his little steam yacht Alexandria gave the necessary stamp of "all-highest" approval.

The most sensational criminal case in which Abraham Lincoln was ever engaged was that in which he defended Duff Armstrong, the son of friends of his early years in Illinois, against the charge of murder. For years this case has figured with more or less detail in all biographies of Lincoln, and it has been made a conspicuous episode in at least one novel of Western life, Edward Eggleston's "The Graysons."

BALTIMORE, June 27. -- Joshua Levering, Prohibition candidate for President, made public his views to-day on the campaign. While he does not feel exactly certain that he will secure enough Electoral votes to send him to the White House, he is confident that the ticket which he heads will be considerable of a factor in the race for Presidential honors.

The result of the informal race of the St. Paul with the Lucania is even a greater triumph for the American steamer and her builders than were her previous performances. The American steam merchant marine is in its infancy. To be sure, we held our own fairly well in the maritime contest after canvas had begun to be displaced by steam.

The Council of the Association for the Education of Women in Oxford has decided, pending the revival of the agitation for conferring the Bachelor of Arts degree on women, to issue certificates to those of its students who have complied, with certain conditions of examination and residence.
Henry Kleinkecht, fifty-four years old, a sawfiler, who lives at 613 Ninth Avenue, was fined $5 in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday for reckless driving.

Seven of the sufferers in the St. Louis cyclone are quartered at the Woodlawn police station, at which place they arrived simultaneously with yesterday's heavy thunderstorm. They are members of the one family, composed of Fred Anheuser, his wife, and five children, and had walked all the way from East St. Louis.

From The Paris Messenger. Since it has been ordained that in this good city we cannot live without excitement of some sort, it is fortunate that, failing politics, the dramatic world supplies us with that dose of scandal without which the life of the average Parisian would become blank.

There was an amusing episode at the commencement exercises of the Georgetown University Tuesday. Archbishop Ryan of Philadelphia delivered an eloquent address on "Civil and Religious Liberty." At its conclusion Cardinal Gibbons was asked to say a few words.

Stowe House, long the home of the ducai house of Buckingham, has been placed in the hands of agents to be let or sold. Many readers will remember the place from Pope's often-quoted line -- "A work to wonder at -- perhaps a Stowe." Others will recollect references to its glories in the writings of Horace Walpole, Congreve, and others who have termed it an "Elysium."

When Henry P. McGown, Jr., son of former Judge McGown, and Clerk of Part II., City Court, returned to his home, 25 East One Hundred and Thirtieth Street, on the evening of April 24, he found a letter from his wife telling him that she had gone to Minneapolis, Minn., with her brother, J.H. Demarest, and that she hoped he would get along all right until she returned.
OLD MELBOURNE MEMORIES. By Rolf Boldrewood. Second edition. Revised. 12mo. New-York: The Macmillan Company.

MONDAY -- A.M. Speculation in Sugar was exceedingly heavy during the week, the transactions in it amounting to 579,939 shares in a total for the whole list of 1,219,263 shares. With the exception of a rally of about 3 points on Friday, the course of the stock was downward, and at the close of the week it had lost 8 5/8 points.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 28. -- Some of the Ohio delegates to the Republican Conven- tion at St. Louis gave "Boss" Hanna a reception and dinner last night at the Union Club. Congratulatory toasts were responded to, and Mr. Hanna's generalship was lauded to the skies.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 28. -- Mrs. Sophie Hoffman, a widow, of Austin, Texas, is charged with a unique violation of the postal laws. Post Office Inspector Dice arrested her on a complaint of a young man of another State, whom by letter writing she had beguiled into falling in love with her.

Mr. GEORGE BURTON ADAMS has, in The Atlantic Monthly for July, an arti- cle on "The United States and the Anglo-Saxon Future" which is likely to attract a good deal of attention. Its main prop- osition is that the world is now passing through a "stage of history" which can lead to "nothing less than the domina- tion of the world in ideas, arts, and insti- tutions by some one racial type."

WASHINGTON, June. 28. -- Much enthusiasm is manifested here over the arrangements for the International Christian Endeavor Convention, which will be held here in July. The officials in charge of the public parks and gardens have laid out the Christian En- deavor monogram and combination of the letters "Y.P.S.C.E." in flowers and gayly colored leaves.

ALBANY, June 27. -- There was one active day for local securities during the week. On Thursday quite a number of trades were reported. Albany Railway and Hudson River Telephone were the favorites. The former sold at 133 and 134, and it is believed now that there is none of the stock offering under 135. New-York Air Brake was firmer.

The body of a man who was run over early yesterday morning and almost in- stantly killed lies at the Morgue awaiting identification. The accident occurred at 1:50 o'clock at the junction of Thirty-third Street and Broadway. A wagon was be- ing driven on the down-town car track at a rapid rate of speed.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Mr. Whitney's inter- view, published this morning, makes it plair, to the Western Democrats that they must not expect to see a free-silver candidate and a free-silver platform supported by a United Democracy. Chairman Walsh of the lowa State Committee expresses the controlling sentiment among Western Dem- ocrats when in commenting on Mr. Whit- ney's interview he says:

The turtle belongs to the order of Testu- dinata, shield reptiles, so it could not have been a fish story. And, anyway, he was a Wall Street man, less addicted to fish in any form than finance. He was talking of the turtles on "our farm."

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Controller Eckels, who has started for Chicago in order to be early on the ground with his influence for sound money, has given the Southern Democrats a nut to crack. Before he departed he discussed the question of the shortsightedness of the Southerners in their demand for a financial policy so much at variance with their best interests.
ASHLAND, Wis., June 28. -- "Coin" Harvey, in an interview to-day, said:
The question of selecting Bryant Park as the site of the New-York Public Library, Astor, Lenox, and Tilden foundations, has frequently been presented in THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

The exotic term "borough" does not seem to us very appropriate for such sub- divisions of the municipality as are proposed in Mr. DE WITT'S resolution before the Greater New-York Commission, and the plan of local "home rule" within the future limits of the city is not one which can be carried out with much complete- ness.

BERLIN, June 27. -- In the talk in the lob- bies yesterday the matter of Prince Hohen- lohe's early retirement from the Chancel- lorship was revived and members of the Reichstag who are associated with the Chancellor's inner circle affirmed that it was absolutely certain he would resign within a very short time.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 28. -- The forty-mile relay race of the Westchester Cycling League, that was to have taken place yesterday, was postponed to July 11, owing to the bad condition of the roads.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 28. -- By winning the final championship game at New-Haven last Tuesday, the Princeton baseball team closed the most successful season experienced by Old Nassau in half a decade. Not since the days of Capt. Lana, '01, when Fred Brokaw was behind the bat and "Laurie" Young was the prince of college pitchers, have the Tigers been victorious over all rivals on the diamond.

On the occasion of the celebration of the sixtieth birthday of Tszchi Toanyu Kangi Chaoyu Chuang Cheng Shokung Chinien Chungshi, Dowager Empress of China, who died a few days ago, the Christian women in the empire presented to that royal lady a splendid edition of the New Testament translated into the Chinese language, in token of their regard for her.

Gen. Francois Manigat, styled in Haiti "the man of the future," Minister Pleni- potentiary to France from the Republic of Haiti, arrived in New-York from Port au Prince yesterday by the steamship Prins Willem I. He is a guest at the Ho- tel Griffon, in West Ninth Street.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 28. -- The resi- dents of the hamlet of Pelhamville, which lies between Mount Vernon and this village, are very angry. They say they have been duped and made a laughing stock of by the residents of Pelham Heights, the newly in- corporated village of Pelham, that lies just across the tracks of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railway from Pel- hamville itself.

Guerrilla play in whist and short-suit sy- tems got a set-back in the great National whist tournament at the Oriental Hotel last week. The results of the games for the three cups which ended in the small hours of Saturday night show a clean sweep for the men who adhere to the ortho- dox game and play according to the prin- ciples as laid down by "Cavendish," Trist, Drayson, and the other recognized authori- ties.

In the death of Robert H. Berdell, in this city, last week there was closed a re- markably active and varied career. Thirty years ago Mr. Berdell was conspicuous and influential in railroad matters. He was President of the old New-York and Erie Railroad, which extended from New-York to Goshen, and for more than two years, beginning in August, 1864, he was President of the entire Erie system.
PITTSTON, Penn., June 28. -- Over 100 men and boys were buried alive at 3 o'clock this morning, when an explosion caused the caving in of the lower vein of the Twin Shaft Mine, at Pittston Junction.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 28. -- There is no general law in this State regarding bicycle riding, but the matter is attracting so much attention just now that it is probable that the next General Assembly will be called upon to pass such a law. In nearly every city and large town in the State the authorities have passed bicycle ordinances governing the speed of bicycles and the use of lanterns and bells.

Steps are to be taken to-day to break up the Gas Trust in Brooklyn. Paul E. De Fere and Charles H. Hyde of the firm of Grout, De Fere Mayer will present to the Attorney General at Albany a petition signed by Dr. John C. Lester of 179 Seher- merhorn Street, Brooklyn, to vacate the charters and annul the existence of each of the several gas companies in the combina- tion.

"Disruption" is what Mr. WHITNEY points to as the consequence for the Democratic Party of free silver. It is a plain and ugly word. Mr. WHITNET is the last man in the party to use it lightly or without being compelled to do so. He is a very strong party man. He values organization very highly.
STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, June 28. -- Rain plink-plunking on 600 canvas roofs caused the State camp on Peekskill plateau to stir uneasily before the reveille to-day.

Andrew Mowbray, a carriage and horse dealer, at 237 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, was arraigned in the Grant Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday morning for knocking down Lieut. George T. Hamlin or the Twenty-third Regiment during the wheelmen's parade on the Ocean Parkway, Saturday afternoon, and his examination was fixed for this morning.

The Christian Endeavorers of the Church of the Strangers held special services in the church, at Mercer and Eighth Streets, last evening. They were welcomed by the Rev. D. Asa. Blackburn, pastor of the church, who advised them not to work for the individual church, whether Baptist, Methodist, or Episcopalian, but for all Christianity.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- It is plain the sound-money Republicans will have to take McKinley in hand. That gentleman, following the advice of Mark Hanna, persistently refuses to accept the political situation. The speeches made at Canton yesterday attest to the desire of the McKinley syndicate to subordinate the currency to the tariff question.

MOBILE, Ala., June 28. -- Colyer Hall, a well-known citizen of this county, was ar- rested yesterday, at his home, about ten miles north of Mobile and two miles from Cleveland station, for the alleged murder of his stepfather, a man named O'Ferrall, in Escambia County, Fla., June 10, 1871.

A Washington stamp dealer has a rare Confederate "provincial," as the stamps are called which were used by cities and towns in the Southern States shortly after the beginning of the civil war and before the regular adhesive stamps were issued by the Confederate Government.

Thomas Thornton, brother of James Thornton, the well-known variety actor and song writer, was shot and instantly killed by Policeman William J. Allingham at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning while resisting arrest. John Thornton, another brother, was arrested at the same time, charged with assault and robbery by Charles Melander, a cabinetmaker, of 151 West Twenty-fifth Street.

The Haverford College cricket team, now in England, will play its first important game today, when the crack eleven of Cheitenham College will be encountered at Cheltenham, in Gloucestershire, that county made famous in cricket history by W.G. Grace, the champion.

PART II Shallow people are apt to think that mere recreation and amusement are the principal ends of social meetings and social intercourse, and that when a man goes to a party he goes in the hope of enjoying himself, without ulterior objects. To have penetrated beneath this superficial judgment constituted, in a philosophical view, the chief distinction of Booby Baines.
We have received the following note, the writer of which, by his well-known and valuable service as a sincere and high-minded citizen, is entitled to the greatest respect:

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- According to offi- cial statistics issued by the Director of the Geological Survey, the total value of min- eral products of the United States for 1895 increased over $80,000,000 beyond the value for 1894, or from $327,368,594 to $611,795,290.

The Rev. John L. Scudder of the Congregational Tabernacle, Jersey City, last night spoke of the power for good that is exerted by the secular daily press. It is his practice to deliver a prelude to his evening sermon, taking some topic of the day for his subject. He last night said:

The London Economist remarks the failure of the English markets for American securities to advance on the news on the Republican declaration for the gold standard. After quoting the resolution, it says:

CANTON, June 28. -- The committee ap- pointed by the St. Louis Convention to no- tify Mr. McKinley of his nomination for President will come here to-morrow and discharge its duty. The members of the committee, excepting only Mr. Rogers of Utah, who has telegraphed that he can- not leave home, are in Cleveland to-night.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- One of the most agreeable sea billets is that of Commander in Chief of the Pacific station, where Admiral Beardslee is on duty. The Admiral's two years' tour of duty on the station will have expired in August, and he has asked for another year's duty in command of the fleet.
At least 5,000 Catholics assembled in West One Hundred and Seventh Street, west of Amsterdam Avenue, yesterday afternoon, to witness the laying of the cornerstone of the new Church of the Ascension.

John Robertson. John Robertson died at his home, 203 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, Saturday. He had been ill for a long time. He was born in Scotland eighty-eight years ago. When nineteen years old he went to India as an employe of the East India Company, and remained there for over ten years.

The delegates to the National Democratic Convention, which will meet in Chicago July 7, have been chosen. Under the official call of Chairman Harrity of the National Democratic Committee, the number of delegates was fixed at double the number of members of the Electoral College from each State, with two additional delegates from each Territory and the District of Columbia.

State Chairman Grant of the Texas Re- publican Executive Committee has been busy since his return. When The News reporter called at the committee headquarters, in Sherman, he found Mr. Grant fairly hedged in with letters, principally from Texas Republicans, congratulating him on his recent victory at St. Louis.

At auction, in the Trinity Building Salesroom, yesterday, Mr. Peter F. Meyer sold, under foreclosure, to A.H. Alker, at $14,591, the three-story brick dwelling 228 East Thirteenth Street, south side, 299.3 3/8 feet west of Second Avenue, 21.5 by 103.3.

In the death of Robert H. Berdell, in this city, last week there was closed a remarkably active and varied career. Thirty years ago Mr. Berdell was conspicuous and influential in railroad matters. He was President of the old New-York and Erie Railroad, which extended from New-York to Goshen, and for more than two years, beginning in August, 1864, he was President of the entire Erie system.
CHICAGO, June 29. -- The Democratic Convention hall in the Coliseum will be completed to-morrow or next day. The chairs were arranged to-day and the work on the speakers' platform was completed.

The Stamford Yacht Club had a special regatta yesterday. It was the second race of the Long Island Sound circuit, and was for 30, 21, and 15 footers. Eight 30-footers, two 21-footers, and four half-raters started and furnished very good contests for the Stamford yachtsmen.

BUTTE, Mon., June 29. -- Congressman Charles A. Hartman yesterday addressed a long open letter to Senator Lee Mantle, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, outlining his plan of campaign in the interest of free coinage and giving notice that he will introduce his plan in the form of resolutions to the State Convention.

Just as WARNER MILLER is preparing to lead a fight against the Platt machine in the campaign of this State a familiar cry is heard from the anti-Platt ranks. Gen. SAMUEL THOMAS, who was hot for a fight against PLATT last Winter, now raises his voice for "harmony." "Let us have the factional fight next year or some other year," he says, "and let us all turn in now and work together for MCKINLEY."
William C. Whitney came to his city from Long Island, where he rested over Sunday, and spent the day at his house, 2 West Fifty-seventh Street.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29. -- The local market to-day was weak and suffered sharp declines throughout the list on account of liquidation. The tractions closed at a decline of 1 3/4 in Metropolitan, 1 1/2 in Union, 1 1/8 in Philadelphia, 1 in Union 4s, and 1/4 in Baltimore. In the industrials, United Gas Improvement declined from 70 to 68 3/8, Welsbach Light from 45 1/2 to 42 1/2, and Storage Battery stocks 1 per cent.

Guerrilla play in whist and short-suit systems got a set-back in the great National whist tournament at the Oriental Hotel last week. The results of the games for the three cups which ended in the small hours of Saturday night show a clean sweep for the men who adhere to the orthodox game and play according to the principles as laid down by "Cavendish," Trist, Drayson, and the other recognized authorities.

The last finishing touch has been put on the new floating palace Adirondack of the People's Line, and in honor of the event a reception was given on board the vessel yesterday afternoon. For two hours the stately craft was open for inspection by visitors, all of whom found much to admire in this finely finished specimen of the shipbuilder's art.

HOUSTON, Texas, June 29. -- Shortly after 3 o'clock this afternoon a boiler in the office of The Daily Age exploded, killing Engineer Henry Lyons, Miss Mattie Loeb, a stenographer in the office of W.G. Van Vleck, Vice President and General Manager of the Atlantic system of the Southern Pacific Railway; Edward R. Emery, telegraph operator in the same office, and seriously injuring Mr. Van Vleck himself.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- In the case of the Northwestern Grain Dealers' Association against the railroads traversing Northwestern Iowa, in which the railroads are sued for $1,000,000, alleged overcharges for shipments of grain, the Illinois Central, at Boone, Iowa, has filed a petition for a specific statement.

The Board of Fire Underwriters is going to extremes in its opposition to the removal of the old reservoir, which is a colossal eyesore at what should be one of the most attractive spots in the city, to make room for a library building which would be an ornament and a glory to the city at that very spot.

CANTON, June 29. -- Members of the Notification Committee while here to-day talked confidently of a Republican victory this Fall. Some of them professed to believe the country would cast an enormous Republican vote, and that McKinley and Hobart would have a great many more votes in the Electoral College than were received by the last successful Republican candidates.

BOSTON, June 29. -- Activity and lower prices prevailed to-day in local stocks, but there was no specially unfavorable news, and some of the local specialties held their own. Prominent among these was Boston and Montana, in which selling was heavy. The opening price was 3/4 below Saturday's close, at 83. Then, with same fluctuations, it declined to 80 3/4, recovering to 82.

We see no indications that the Republicans desire the overthrow of free coinage at Chicago. As near as we can come at their sentiments, the Republican newspapers are merry and the Republican leaders exultant over the prospective triumph of silver in nomination and platform.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Much enthusiasm is manifested hers over the arrangements for the International Christian Endeavor Convention, which will be held here in July. The officials in charge at the public parks and gardens have laid out the Christian Endeavor monogram and combination of the letters "Y.P.S.C.E." in flowers and gayly colored leaves.

RICHMOND, Va., June 29. -- Richmond is all ready for the sixth annual reunion of the United Confederate Veterans, which commences here to-morrow, continuing three days, and winding up Thursday afternoon with a grand parade and the ceremonies incident to the laying of the cornerstone of the Jefferson Davis Monument.

BOSTON, June 29. -- By the overturning of a float at Castle Island this afternoon four children were drowned, two were seriously injured, and a score or more received a thorough wetting. Those drowned were:

MONDAY --P.M. To-day's sales of stocks exceeded in volume those of any other day for a long time. Holders could derive little comfort from this activity, because it represented factors hostile to former prices, and it benefited only the bears. Disappointment with the results was increased by reason of indications early in the day, which held out promise of substantial recovery from Saturday's losses.

Just as the steamboat Idlewild, from points up the Sound, rounded North Brother Island, East River, yesterday morning, the 200 passengers aboard rushed on deck and crowded, terrified, toward the stern.

ST. LOUIS, June 29. -- The advance guard of the committee intrusted with the task of steering the Bland boom into the port of a Presidential nomination left for Chicago last night. In the baggage car of the train on which the boomers traveled were stowed twelve large packing trunks containing about a ton of literature concerning the career and speeches of the silver-dollar champion in and out of Congress.

NEWPORT, June 28. -- Mr. and Mrs. John R. Drexel left for New-York to-day on the yacht The Sultana, with a party of guests. Dr. Chauncey M. Depew and John Hone left for New-York on Cornelius Vanderbilt's private car.

The trial of John D. Hart, Emilio Nunez, Capt. John O'Brien, and Mate Edward Murphy, charged with aiding a filibustering expedition to Cuba on the steamship Bermuda, was begun yesterday before Judge Brown, in the Criminal Branch of the United States Circuit Court.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- "McKinley has very few followers in my State," said E.D. Motts, delegate at large from Montana to the Democratic National Convention. "We have not much use for his principles. As to the feeling in the State as to who should be the Democratic nominee for President, that is not well developed enough yet to have fixed upon one man.

The collapse of the Twin Shaft Mine at Pittston is probably the most extensively fatal mining accident that has occurred in this country since the disaster in the Avondale Mine nearly thirty years ago. The earlier disaster resulted from the taking fire of the timber lining of the shaft, which was the only inlet or outlet of the mine, and the consequent suffoca- tion of the miners below.
STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, June 28. -- Rain plink-plunking on 600 canvas roofs caused the State camp on Peekskill plateau to stir uneasily before the reveille to-day.
LONDON, June 29. -- Henry Dunckley, M.A., LL. D., died at Manchester to-day.

Efforts to establish harmony of action among the linseed-oil manufacturers in this country have recently assumed much significance. The condition of the linseed-oil market has been unfavorable to profit making for several months, sharp competition having sent the price down to a point that scarcely covers the cost of production.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 29. -- The visit of the circus made it quite exciting to-day for cottagers, nearly all of whom were present in the afternoon.

LONDON, June 29. -- The town of Gainsborough, in Lincolnshire, was the scene to-day of a ceremony of interest to Americans. This was the unveiling of a memorial stone in the John Robinson Church, so named after the Rev. John Robinson, "pastor of the Pilgrim Fathers," who, after severing his connection with the Established Church in 1604, connected himself with a body of dissenters in Gainsborough.

"Our foreign trade, so precipitately cut off by adverse legislation," said Mr. MCKINLEY yesterday to the convention's committee, "must be reopened on fair and equitable terms for our surplus agricultural and manufacturing products."

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 29. -- The recent rains seem to have had very slight effect on the Tuxedo tennis courts, for they were in prime condition to-day when the Tuxedo tournament was begun. An unusually strong entry list has been obtained, and the meet promises to be of a higher order than ever before.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Following is a statement of the condition of the United States Treasury and the receipts and expenditures of the Government on the 29th day of June, 1896:

ALBANY, June 29. -- Attorney General Hancock has set a hearing, at noon, July 13, on the application of John C. Lestar that he begin an action to annul the charters of the seven Brooklyn gas companies under the name of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company. Paul E. Defere and Charles W. Hyde of Brooklyn, representing the petitioner, appeared before the Attorney General to-day, under the impression that a hearing would be had at once.

Theoaore D. Wilson. Theodore D. Wilson, formerly Chief Constructor of the navy, died yesterday at the Boston Navy Yard, of a heat stroke, received while superintending the undocking of the monitor Passaic. Mr. Wilson had been ill for many years during his several terms as Chief Constructor of the navy, but after relinquishing that position he began to recuperate, and had seemingly largely recovered health and strength.

CANTON, June 20. -- While the Notification Committee was at lunch a delegation from Columbus marched up. Congressman D. K. Watson of Columbus made a speech in behalf of the visiting delegation, eulogizing McKinley's "Americanism." Major McKinley said in response:

PITTSBURG, June 29. -- The Board of Directors of the National League held a meeting in this city to-day and decided that the fine of $100 imposed on Pitcher Amos Rusie last year at Baltimore for alleged drunkenness by President Freedman of the New-York Club was just and proper.
PHILADELPHIA, June 29. -- Wharton Barker, who has announced himself a candidate for nomination for the Presidency, gives to the press the following statement:
HENLEY, June 29. -- Several of the members of the Yale University crew attended church yesterday forenoon, and in the afternoon all of the crew took a trip up the river on a steam launch.

KEY WEST, Fla., June 29. -- The steamers Three Friends and Richmond were seized by the customs officials this morning. The case will be heard Wednesday. The steamers are charged with encasing in filibustering expeditions, in violation of the treaty between the United States and Spain.

On the occasion of the celebration of the sixtieth birthday of Tszchi Toanyu Kangi Chaoyu Chuang Cheng Shokung Chinien Chungshi, Dowager Empress of China, who died a few days ago, the Christian women in the empire presented to that royal lady a splendid edition of the New Testament translated into the Chinese language, in token of their regard for her.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., June 29. -- Haverstraw was decked with flags and bunting to-day in honor of Dr. A.S. Freeman's fiftieth anniversary as a Presbyterian minister. At noon luncheon was served by the ladies of his church to about fifty visiting clergymen. At 3 o'clock services were held in the church under the auspices of the Hudson Presbytery.

Mr. MeKINLEY yesterday made the first formal expression of his views since his nomination in his speech to the Notification Committee. It was a skillful speech, sober, dignified, with little rhetoric, neatly turned to suit the sentiment of the party, and as nearly void of offense to those who have opposed his nomination as he could well make it.

William Robert Dunlop and William Turner, the former servants of I. Townsend Burden, who stole $60,000 worth of Mrs. Burden's jewels last December, were sentenced to nine years' imprisonment at hard labor in Sing Sing, yesterday, by Judge Cowing, in General Sessions, Part I.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The President has commuted to one year of actual imprisonment the sentence of two years in the Fort Leavenworth Penitentiary, Kansas, imposed in September, 1895, on Thomas J. Reed for larceny, committed in the Indian Territory.

BALTIMORE, June 29. -- Cardinal Gibbons gave to the press this evening a copy of the summary of Pope Leo's encyclical letter on the reunion of all the Christian churches. His Holiness evidently had in mind the recent letter of William E. Gladstone, the English statesman and churchman, and the letter may be considered a reply thereto.

John Wallace, a decrepit, one-armed man, seventy-five years old, who lived alone in a shanty on the west bank of the Harlem River, on a line with One Hundred and Thirty-first Street, was found dead in his bed yesterday morning by John Wood of 43 East One Hundred and Thirty-second Street.

CANTON, June 29. -- Official notice of his nomination for the Presidency was served in Mr. McKinley to-day by the committee appointed to do that work by the St. Louis Convention. The important feature of the ceremony was the failure of the Republican candidate to make a straightforward financial declaration in accordance with the declaration of the Convention that nominated him.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., June 29. -- The wedding of Mr. Charles J. Rolfe of Cambridge and Miss Josephine Jefferson, daughter of Mr. Charles B. Jefferson, eldest son of the actor, Mr. Joseph Jefferson, was celebrated at the home of the bride here at high noon to-day, in the presence of about fifty guests, the greater number of whom were relations of the contracting parties.

ALBANY, June 29. -- Superintendent A'dridge of the State Department of Public Works has granted permission to the North End Wheelmen of this city to place the blue line side of the towpath of the Erie Canal, between Thacher Street and Port Schuyler in proper condition for bicycle travel. This is a distance of nearly six miles.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Contrary to the established rule of such occasions, the Generals of the great political battle to be fought out next week are arriving in advance of the rank and file. Senator Jones of Arkansas came in late last night, and this morning Col. T.O. Towles of Missouri, Secretary of the Bimetallic Democratic National Committee, opened up headquarters at the Sherman House, in the parlor adjoining that occupied by the Arkansas Senator.

The contest over the will of Sister Carmelita now going on before Surrogate Fitzgerald has attracted public attention because of the singularity of a nun holding a large amount of property in her own right.

SYNOPSIS. Mr. J. Addington Baines, familiariy known at Rugby and Cambridge as "Booby" Baines, after graduation obtains a clerkship in the Board of Trade. He devotes much attention to society and becomes a favorite with smart people. His salary is small, and his prospective engagement with Miss Addle Swayne, the possessor of u800 a year, is very comforting.
ST. JOHN'S, N.F., June 29. -- Forest fires are sweeping over the northern portion of this island.
The cycling enthusiasts of the Summer colony along the Jersey coast from Sea-bright to Spring Lake are going to follow the fashion and give a parade on Saturday afternoon, July 18.

WATERLOO, Iowa, June 29. -- Ex-Gov. Boies returned this afternoon from his Grundy County farm, where he went immediately on his return from Illinois. When asked if he intended going to Chicago, soon, he replied that he had not determined whether he would attend the convention or not.

PITTSTON, Penn., June 29. -- There is little probability that any of the miners who were entombed yesterday by the cave-in at the Twin Shaft of the Newton Coal Company will come out of the pit alive. The prevailing opinion is that all of them already are dead. Nevertheless, the company is doing everything possible to reach the part of the mine where the men were working when the accident took place.

LAWRENCE, Mass., June 29. -- Jeremiah T. O'Sullivan, a member of the Democratic State Committee, a delegate to the Chicago Convention, and an aspirant for the Congressional nomination in this district, has just returned from New-York City, where he has been in conference with sliver Democrats from the South and West. To a reporter Mr. O'Sullivan said:

At yesterday's meeting of the Board of Fire Commisiners Commissioner Sheffild's resignation from the officie of Treasurer of the board, which was presented several weeks ago, was taken from the table. Mr. Sheffield insisted on the resignation being accepted. He moved that the resignation be accepted, and Commissioner Ford declared elected to the office.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- There was some disposition to sell early in the day, which the bears helped as much as possible. Later good buying from the supporting element had effect to stop further decline. Cables were weak. West Chicago sold at 103 7/8. and North Chicago at 246 1/2. Alley "L" sold at 4, the lowest price on record for the stock.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 30. -- There was another hearing to-day before Justice J. O. Dykman, in the suit of Richard Burnett and Frederick P. Klenke against the village of New-Rochelle, the President and Trustees of the village of New-Rochelle, and the Westchester Electric Railroad Company, otherwise known as the "Huckleberry Road."
As the South by its present course is inviting another period of disorder, misrule, violence, and ruin, it is well to recall that reign of terror which is known as the reconstruction period.

CLEVELAND, June 30. -- The biggest row which has yet occurred at the Brown Hoisting Works took place this afternoon when the men quit work. The non-strikers, who are also the non-unionists, marched out as usual under police protection to take the street car. When the street cars came along they refused to stop, although commanded to do so by the police, the motormen being presumably in collusion with the strikers.

An application has been made to the Attorney General of this State asking him to begin an action to annul the charter of the Union Gas Company of Brooklyn as a combination to put up the price of gas in violation of the anti-trust law.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 30. -- The fine weather that the Eighth Regiment and Squadron A of New-York and the First Provisional Regiment are enjoying in the State Camp has had much to do with the improvement shown by the men since they began drilling on Sunday morning.
The offices of Special Deputy Excise Commissioner George Hilliard were kept open until midnight, and were thronged by saloon keepers and store keepers.

Weather conditions were perfect for rac- ing at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday. Yet the crowd was small for the track that was once at the front of all the race tracks in America, but which has now degenerated into one of the money-grabbing institutions, where sport is made of secondary consid- eration.

Plans for a new Court House for the exclusive use of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court were approved yesterday at a meeting of the Sinking Fund Commission held in the Mayor's office. Corporation Counsel Scott was instructed to-draw up a proper form of contract so that tenders might be received and the work begun as soon as possible.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 30. -- A poll of the Kansas Democratic delegation before leaving for Chicago showed fourteen of the twenty for Bland for President for first choice. As the delegation is to vote as a unit, Bland will get the twenty votes of Kansas on the start.

BOSTON, June 30. -- Local stocks were dull, the specialties only being traded in to any extent. These were Montana, and Old Dominion, Bay State Gas, and Dominion Coal. The tone of the whole market was better than yesterday and there was quite a little advance recorded during the morning, though later there was a reaction, but not to the low point of yesterday.

ALBANY, June 30. -- State Engineer Adams said to-day that he is well satisfied that the canal improvements can all be completed before his present term expires on Dec. 31, 1898, and that the $9,000,000 voted therefor by the people will be amply sufficient to carry on and complete this great work.

Col. Emllio Nunez, Capt. John O'Brien, John D. Hart, and Mate Edward Murphy, late of the Bermuda, do not appear much worried over their trial as filibusters. They gathered in the criminal branch of the United States Circuit Court yesterday before the hour of opening and laughed loudly.

Nothing in the way of manual training results has been seen in New-York before that would compare with the exhibit in the Teachers' College that has been brought together by the American Manual Training Association, which began a two-days' meeting in the college yesterday.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., June 30. -- This has been a gala day in Haverstraw. The whole town is resplendent with flags and bunting, and the people, without regard to creed, are doing honor to Dr. A.S. Freeman. To-night the great parade was held. It was more than half a mile in length and was composed of all the civic societies in the place and the different hose and hook and ladder companies.
A vigorous protest will be made by the honest-money Democrats of Chicago and Illinois against Gov. Altgeld's committing the party to free silver.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- One of the conspicuous features of the day was the conference between the Bimetallic Democratic National Committee and the otuside silver men. It was much more largely attended than had been expected in view of the fact that it was simply a preliminary meeting.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 30. -- Cottagers have engaged two life savers to act as patrol off Easton's Beach during bathing hours. The expense is borne entirely by Summer residents, the subscription list being headed by Louis B. McCagg of New-York.

Only slight show of authority has been needed in the wholesale grocery, produce, and commission district to effect great improvement in the condition of the sidewalks. It is now possible for pedestrians to move about that part of the city without turning into buildings or out into the street in order to avoid obstructions.

William Swansboro, cashier of the Hotel St. George, in Brooklyn, committed suicide in his room, on the tenth floor of the hotel, yesterday evening by shooting himself in the right temple. Death was instantaneous.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The official Treasury statement to be issued to-morrow will show that the receipts from all sources for the fiscal year 1896 approximate $326,500,000, and the expenditures for the like period $352,000,000, making the deficit for the fiscal year $25,500,000. The deficit for 1895 was $42,000,000, and for 1894 $70,000,000, so that the deficit for the last three years aggregates $137,500,000.

The trial of the action brought by Richard White Hennessy to contest the will of his aunt, Mary Frances Baker, known in religion as Sister Carmelita, was resumed yesterday before Surrogate Fitzgerald.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Mary Beaufort won the five-thousand-dollar Horse Review Stakes at Washington Park to-day with ease. There was practically nothing in the race to make her travel at her best. Bessie Wilton took the 2:19 trot handily in straight heats after the first. The field was too large to handle well. The 2:11 pace was productive of some line racing, although Colbert had the field at his mercy in every heat.

HAVANA, June 30. -- On the night of June 26 the inhabitants of Mordazo, in the Province of Santa Clara, were surprised by the presence of rebels, who had entered the town without arousing the troops who were supposed to be deferding the place. The insurgents looted a store and killed a clerk and cousin of the owner.

BALTIMORE, June 30. -- Both pitchers were ef- fective in the main to-day in the New-York-Baltimore ball game, but Hemming had slightly the better of the argument. The game abounded in startling fielding, liberally interspersed with poor playing, the teams sharing each. In the ninth inning New-York scored 2 runs on an error and on Farrell's hit to the open stand.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30. -- The local mar- ket, after a feverish opening, declined 3/8 and 3/4, respectively, for Philadelphia and Union Trac- tion, but in the afternoon recovered its loss, and closed 1/4 above yesterday. The industrials were in better demand, and closed at material im- provement. Welsbach led with a gain of 6 points.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- The sub-committee of National Democratic Committee having charge of the distribution of Convention Hall space and seats among the newspaper applicants, finished its arduous work to-day so far as to prepare a report of its recommendations, to be acted upon to-morrow by the Executive Committee.

LONDON, June 30. -- Yesterday's sitting of the House of Commons was protracted until 8:30 o'clock this morning, when the report stage of the Irish Land bill was passed.
