The challenge races for the Seawanhaka's trophy for fifteen-foot boats, scheduled to begin on Monday next, will undoubtedly be held according to programme.

The thunderstorm which passed over the city early yesterday afternoon was of very short duration, but in passing it deluged the city, choked sewers, flooded cellars along the East River front, and accomplished no inconsiderable damage in several other localities.

Captain of Police George W. Wittman returned yesterday morning from a three months' Eastern trip, made for the purpose of inspecting the Police Departments of Eastern cities. If there is any city of prominence east of the Rocky Mountains that Capt. Wittman did not visit it has not yet been marked on the map.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- A careful canvass of such delegations as have arrived was made this evening by correspondents of THE NEW-YORK TIMES. Inquiries were made to ascertain the preferences for President and the inclination with reference to the abrogation of the two-thirds rule for nominations.

Mrs. Josephine Kiernan and three of her four children, William, seven years old; Thomas, five years old, and Frances, two years old, were poisoned yesterday afternoon at their home, 342 East Sixty-fifth Street, by eating a chocolate pudding which had been baked last Friday, and which, as the attending physicians believe by the action of the air resulted in the development of poisonous ptomaines.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, July 6. -- To-morrow will witness the trial heats for the Grand Challenge Cup, and all the crews who will participate therein are on the anxious seat. Little very hard work was done by any of the oarsmen to-day, they not caring to run any risk on the day prior to the one when all their strength will be required to give good reports of themselves in the actual racing.

NEWPARK, N.J., July 6. -- The bicycle parade and races which were to have taken place to-day at the New-Jersey State Fair Grounds, at Waverly, under the auspices of the Cuban-American Association, have been postponed, and Wednesday has been designated as "bicycle day."

CHICAGO, July 6. -- The California delegation is not unanimous for fre silver. Its vote would probably be cast as a unit for a conservative free-silver platform, but if that platform, should be too radical, several of the regular delegates may refuse to act under the instructions.
Rudolph Rosinsky, a well-known the-atrical agent, whose office was at 1,227 Broadway, died suddenly at Rockaway Beach Sunday afternoon.

BUFFALO, July 6. -- The work of the National Council of Education to-day was along practical and interesting lines. Dr. William A. Mowry of Hyde Park, Mass., Chairman of the Committee on School Sanitation, read a report on "Schoolroom Hygiene."

The case of Mr. HUMBERT, who was ejected from the Third Avenue cable cars on Sunday, is a very good illustration of the impudent way in which the cable company treats the people of the City of New-York. The conductor put him and his boy off the car because the transfer ticket which Mr. HUMBERT presented had, according to the conductor, been issued more than eight minutes previous to its presentation.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- Tammany's special train arrived in two sections at 10:30 o'clock this morning, and the Tigers made their entry on the convention scene as quietly as so many lambs. There was no hurry about their coming. There were fewer than 200 of them, the smallest number of braves that have attended a National Convention in the past twenty years.

The return to the writ of habeas corpus obtained by Mrs. Susan Gormley of 128 West Fiftieth Street from Justice Andrews, in the Supreme Court, directing the authorities of the Juvenile Asvlum to produce in court John Gormley, her fourteen-year-old son, was made yesterday before Justice Stover, in Special Term, Part II., of the Supreme Court.

President Joaquin Crespo of the Republic of Venezuela has issued a letter inviting political exiles from that country to return to it in view of the forthcoming celebration in memory of Gen. Francisco de Miranda, who began the struggle for the emancipation of the Latin-American peoples, and fell a martyr in the cause.

SARATOGA, July 6. -- The three days' celebration of the Fourth of July by the Sons and Daughters of the American Revolution was concluded this morning by a grand patriotic meeting by the Children of the American Revolution in the Town Hall, which was attended by hundreds of persons.

Policeman Devier of the East Sixty-seventh Street Station was patrolling his post, at the foot of East Sixty-seventh Street, a little before midnight last night, when a large white bulldog ran up to him and barked two or three times, and then ran over to Williams's stone yard, across the street. The dog repeated this two or three times, and Devier at last followed the dog into the stoneyard.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- The Ohio delegation had an important and interesting meeting today, and the upshot of it was that the delegation will go into the convention practically unpledged, but with an overwhelming majority in favor of the candidacy of John R. McLean.

Argument was heard in the Supreme Court yesterday before Justice Lawrence on the application for an injunction against the Controller to restrain him from continuing the sale of the franchise for the railroads to be built in the annexed district from the Bronx to the Harlem River, over which there has already been months of litigation.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- The New-Jersey delegates met in their headquarters at the Auditorium Annex this morning, and were serenaded. They did not know whether to take this as a compliment or not, for when the big bass drum was turned so that the inscription could be read it was learned that the music was by Hobart's Band, a musical organization from one of the Western States.

KEY WEST, Fla., July 6. -- Capt. Lowe of the schooner Charles D. Hall arrived at this port yesterday noon and reports that yesterday morning about 10 o'clock he sighted a steam tug off Sombrero Light going in a southeast direction, which he took for the George W. Childs, but the tug kept well away from him, and it was impossible to decipher her name.

The outcome at Chicago will be revolution if not dissolution. The silver men are desperate and hot-headed. The gold men are firm and self-possessed. The silver men can nominate their candidate only by a resort to methods so violent and revolutionary that their successful application would transform the convention into a mob.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- Ex-Secretary Whitney will sit as a delegate in the convention after all. At a meeting of the New-York delegation to-night at the Auditorium Hotel he was substituted in place of Ashbel P. Fitch of New-York City. Mr. Whitney was present at the delegation meeting and made no objection to the proceeding.

The racing stable of Col. Jacob Ruppert was sold at auction at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday. The Colonel will retire from racing, much to the regret of his many friends. His horses sold very cheaply, as the following summary shows:

PHILADELPHIA, July 6. -- Local stocks remain dull; operators prefer the New-York market. Early prices to-day were 1/4 lower than on Friday, but subsequently most of the loss was recovered. At the close the only important change to-day was a decline of 3/8 in Storage common, 1/8 in Pennsylvania Heat preferred, and 3/8 in Lehigh Valley. The market at the close was steady.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 1 1/2@2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- The Connecticut delegation met at its headquarters, in the Palmer House, this morning and perfected its organization. Ex-Gov. Thomas M. Waller is Chairman and ex-Judge Lynde Harrison will serve on the Committee on Resolutions. Mr. Harrison will have several suggestions to make to that committee, and he will make it clear that Connecticut wants no nonsense on the money question.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city. Is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

At this moment, when the coronation festivities in honor of the new Czar are in full swing in the ancient Russian capital, it may not be uninteresting to note that it was during the reign of the first Czar, Ivan IV., surnamed Grozin, (i.e., the Terrible,) that the earliest relations on record of friendly negotiations between England and Russia took place.

It seems to be settled that MAURICE GRAU will succeed to the post of grand opera impresario in London, left vacant by the death of Sir AUGUSTUS HARRIS. From the artistic point of view, Mr. GRAU is a much abler man than his predecessor. He knows the history of impresarioship and has an intelligent and sympathetic knowledge of music.

The assessment of property for taxation in this city for the current year shows an increase of $85,480,488 in the valuation of real estate and of $89,537,243 in the valuation of both real and personal property. The increase in twelve months is much larger than it has been before in many years, but it is partly due to the annexation of certain West- chester towns since the previous assessment was made.

Pierce Manning Butler Young, a Southerner of distinguished career as a soldier, Congressman, and diplomat, who was United States Minister to Guatemala, died yesterday of Bright's disease at the Presbyterian Hospital.
CHICAGO, July 6. -- The gold delegates from Texas, who this morning decided not to apply for admission to the convention, have issued this address:

CHICAGO, Ill., July 6. -- Freight Traffic Manager Cale of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railway has informed Commissioner Midgely of the Western Freight Association that the new St. Louis and San Francisco management believes in association control of competitive traffic. In accordance with that view, the new "Frisco" company will become identified with the Western Freight Association and co-operate with it for the maintenance of rates.
CHICAGO, July 6. -- Chicago weather was on its good behavior again and gave delegates and visitors a bright, agreeable, and moderately cool day.

There was great clamor yesterday at the meeting of the National Association of Naval Veterans over the treatment which Rear Admiral Alman said he received from Mayor Strong when he went to ask him for money in aid of the veterans.

The Deputy Excise Commissioner for this city, the Police Board, the Excise Reform Association, and pretty much everybody else who talks about preventing evasion of the new "liquor-tax law" by what are variously called "Raines hotels," "saloon hotels," and "fake hotels," continue to show the utmost confusion of mind as to the provisions of the law itself and what can be done under them.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- The fight between the opposition of free silver and the infatuated devotees of a debased coinage began this afternoon with a skirmish in the National Committee, out of which the sound-money men came victors.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- The situation on the eve of the convention is by no means satisfactory to the silver leaders. The day has but added to their difficulties. In a preliminary encounter with the sound-money Democrats of the National Committee, they were worsted. That committee this afternoon decided that Senator Hill should be named as temporary Chairman of the convention.
The members of the Republican State Committee began assembling early yesterday in obedience to the call issued by Chairman Charles W. Hackett for the meeting to-day.

The National Cycle Board of Trade has instructed its architect to submit diagrams suggesting the best methods of arranging exhibitors spaces for the Eastern National Cycle Exposition to be held early next year at the Grand Central Palace.

NEWTOWN, L.I., July 6. -- The little courtroom of Justice of the Peace Schumacher, in the Town Hall, was crowded this afternoon when the Russian veterans arrested on a charge of creating a riot in the picnic park in Maspeth Saturday, were arraigned for an examination.
The question of erecting a memorial abbey was generally discussed at the reunion of Confederate veterans who attended the unveiling of the Jefferson Davis Monument in Richmond, last week.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6. -- J.H.S. Wiborg, the late Captain of the steamer Horsa, whose conviction of engaging in an alleged Cuban filibustering expedition was affirmed by the United States Supreme Court, surrendered himself in the United States District Court here to-day for the purpose of completing his sentence of one year and four months.
The annual "dog watch" of the National Association of Naval Veterans was held at Webster Hall last night.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 6. -- Count Hadik of Germany, who was a social favorite here last season, returned to-day and is at Bellevue Lodge for the Summer. H.P. Farrington and Miss Farrington of Croton-on-Hudson have arrived at the Ocean House for the season. Col. and Mrs. R.H.I. Goddard and Miss Goddard of Providence arrived this evening at the Eldridge villa for the Summer.

MONDAY -- P.M. Free sales of securities this morning and free buying in the afternoon, with a decline in the rate of sterling exchange, furnished the features of to-day's market. Between spurts of market activity there were several listless hours. At times in the middle of the day quotations were reported several minutes apart.
The ten-thousand-dollar silver service for the battleship Indiana, which was described in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of March 8, has been placed on exhibition by the makers, Tiffany Co.

Senator TELLER bids fair to suffer the common fate of logical candidates. There is no question that he represents better than anybody else the one idea on which the advocates of limitless silver have determined to make this canvass. He has been a consistent silver man ever since there was a silver question.

Because of his prompt action, Roundsman William H. Sullivan, who is attached to Chief Conlin's office, saved a child from death or serious injury yesterday afternoon. The child was Esther Fuchs, two years old, whose parents live at 44 Orchard Street. The little one had strayed from her home, and started to cross Grand Street, near Essex, in front of a car of the Grand Street cross-town line, going east.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The New-York people who are interested in the submarine boat being built for the navy in Baltimore are concerned whether the Navy Department will authorize the construction of another craft of like type. This, from present indications, does not seem probable, although the matter depends entirely on the results obtained by the boat now under way.

-- Mortimer L. Fell died on Sunday at his home, 19 West Eighty-fourth Street, from pneumonia. He was born in London, England, fiftytwo years ago, but came to this country with his parents when he was three years old. He was engaged in the cloth business for a number of years in this city, and lived in Morristown, N.J., until four years ago, when the family moved to this city.

Fourteen-year-old Lillian Mallory, colored, was charged with the theft of several valuable souvenirs yesterday before Magistrate Flammer, in the Jefferson Market Court. The complainant was Miss Mary E. Stevens, who has charge of a large boarding house for Mrs. L.R. Sawyer, at 153 and 155 Madison Avenue.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- The action of the National Committee in selecting Senator Hill for temporary Chairman and in seating the Michigan and Nebraska gold delegates was applauded by every sound-money man here. Perry Belmont, who arrived to-day and who is at the Palmer House, and Don M. Dickinson expressed great gratification at the result.

Max Glueckman, the self-confessed builder of incendiary fires, went on the witness stand yesterday, before Judge Fursman and a jury, in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, in the trial of Adolph Herschkopf, for the murder of Lizzie Jaeger. Herschkopf is charged with having set fire, on the morning of May 31, 1894, to the house at 129 Suffolk Street, where the girl received fatal burns.
TORONTO, Ontario, July 6. -- The Globe, the chief organ of the incoming Liberal Government, in a leading editorial this morning says:

CHICAGO, July 6. -- A conference of the accredited representatives of free-silver delegations assembled at the Sherman House at 2 o'clock this afternoon. They represented 400 votes. Senator Harris of Tennessee presided, with T.O. Towles as Secretary.

There can be little doubt that the mathematical tripos, as at present constituted, if absolutely the severest and most exhaustive examination in the world. Year by year the researches of great thinkers are bringing within the range of the examination whole new fields of thought, and one trembles to think of the character that the higher parts of the examination will inevitably assume in time to come.

The New-York Tribune explained yesterday, in the course of some remarks about the demand of the tinplate manufacturers for a reduction of wages, that "the combination of tinplate manufact- urers was a defensive movement which followed the organization of the great Billet Pool about April 1."

-- The Eden Musee was well filled last evening, and a good programme was rendered by the orchestra. This included a cymbal solo, a clarionet duet, and two violin solos by Koevessy. Nearly every number secured an encore. Daily afternoon and evening concerts will be given this week, and the programmes will be largely made up of popular selections.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- The National Committee, beginning its meeting at noon to-day, transacted its business at a single session, disposing of all the contests for seats and voting, 27 to 23, to report the name of Senator David B. Hill of New-York for temporary Chairman of the National Convention. The first test vote in the committee was on this proposition, and it showed the relative gold and silver strength of the organization.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- Silver Headquarters, at the Sherman House, to-day gave one an idea of chaos. Silver leaders came in and out and held conferences. Delegates and camp followers wandered in, stood around and carried on animated financial discussions. Schemes and rumors flew around at short intervals.
Amsterdam Avenue, southwest corner of One Hundred and Thirty-second Street, for a five-story brick tenement and stores, by Thomas J. McGuire of 986 St. Nicholas Avenue, owner; cost, $88,000.
"It was such a deliciously diabolical and altogether feminine revenge," he said. " I don't believe any but a feminine mind could have conceived it.

MORRIS COVE, Conn., July 6. -- Rear Commodore Hanan saved the racing yachtsmen of the Atlantic Yacht Club a great deal of worry and trouble yesterday. Chairman Bliss of the Regratta Committee was up early this morning and concocted a scheme to give the yachtsmen a practical test of their knowledge of navigation.

BOSTON, July 6. -- Activity among local stocks was confined mainly to-day to a few mining shares. The tone of the whole market, however, was firm to strong, partly the result of covering by shorts and partly on account of better buying from the outside. Butte and Montana advanced 3/4 at the opening, to 86 1/4, and afterward to 87 7/8, closing at 87 1/2.

AUBURN, N.Y., July 6. -- Two sons of Alfred Bronson, a farmer living on the northern limits of the town, were on a hayrack this evening during a storm, driving swiftly toward their home. A hundred yards from the house the rig was struck by a lightning bolt.
George W. Vanderbilt is one of the noted book collectors of this country. He possesses a collection of rare publications which has few equals either on this continent or in Europe.

The Roman Catholic priest who officiated on Sunday at the funeral of the striker who was killed in the disorders of last week in Cleveland seized the occasion to deliver a wholesome lesson to the assembled multitude of laborers upon the rights of others.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The effect of the bond issue of $100,000,000 last February upon the circulation of the National banks has been an increase of about $16,000,000 in the bonds on deposit with the United States Treasurer. The effect of this issue appears to have been nearly spent with the end of June, for the increase in secured circulation during that month was only $323,090.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- The boomers of the different candidates were astir early. With the beginning of the convention only a day distant, they realized that there was no time to lose. The Bland men, who had been assured yesterday of the support of the Illinois delegation, had the satisfaction of learning at noon that at a caucus of that delegation it was decided, by the vote of 43 to 1, to stand by Bland.

NEWARK, N.J., July 6. -- More than three inches of rain fell here in less than three hours to-day. Many streets in the centre and lower sections of the city were entirely submerged. The water ranged from one to three feet deep in some places, and light vehicles floated when their occupants attempted to drive them through the flooded streets.

Undoubtedly the chances of the drawing for opponents and position at Henley have not been favorable to Yale. The English critics are agreed that the English competing crews are an exceptionally good lot, and in order to win Yale will have to beat three of them in succession.

J.W. Kelly, Jr., and James E. Sullivan of the Amateur Athletic Union Championship Committee, met yesterday afternoon and perfected arrangements for the track and field championship meeting of the Amuteur Athletic Union of the United States, which is to be held Sept. 12. The games will be held either on Columbia Oval, Berkeley Oval, Manhattan Field, Eastern Park, or the grounds of the New-Jersey Athletic Club.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- Lack of buying orders continue to depress the stock market. The only stocks that receive any apparent support are the Moores. There is just about enough buying to hold them steady at the present price. Diamond Match gained 3/8 and New-York Biscuit 1/4 to-day. West Chicago sold to-day in small lots at 99 7/8, the lowest the stock has touched since 1890.

Mgr. Diomede Falconio, the new Papal Delegate to the United States, who is to succeed Cardinal Satolli, is well known here, having spent nearly fourteen years either as a Franciscan friar in the Thompson Street Monastery, or as a professor in St. Bonaventure's Cohege, Allegheny, Cattaraugus County, N.Y.

The George Junior Republic will begin its sixth year of usefulness, activity, and industry to-day, Nearly 150 young citizens left the heat and sultriness of the city last night for Freeville, N.Y., and their camp grounds. The capital and headquarters of the republic are just outside of the village of Freeville, which is about ten miles from Ithaca.

The Executive Committee of the wideawake and bustling North Side Board of Trade met last night at 278 Alexander Avenue. The business incident to the functions of the committee was transacted, and then came under discussion many subjects of vital interest to trans-Harlemites, which will be presented in the form of committee reports on the evening of July 13.

Twenty-nine members of the committee appointed at the Republican National Convention to notify Messrs. McKinley and Hobart of their nominations held a short meeting in Parlor D R of the Fifth Avenue Hotel last evening, to arrange for their trip to Paterson, N.J., to inform Mr. Hobart that he is the Republican candidate for Vice President.

The report which Mr. PERRY BELMONT carries to Chicago of his observations in Europe upon the question of bimetallism will not be encouraging to silver men -- even to those who are looking forward to the day when all the great powers shall unite in making their dream a reality.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The long delay at the doors was equivalent to a notice that the convention would not be called to order at 12 o'clock, the hour set in the official notice. It was near 1 o'clock before the gavel fell. The half hour preceding the first step toward the organization of the convention was full of entertainment to those who were present as spectators.

A black-and-tan dog that had been trotting peaceably along Sixth Avenue, near Twenty-fourth Street, with its mistress yesterday, suddenly tore the leash out of her hand, uttered several yelps, snapped viciously at its owner, and ran howling and snapping down Twenty-fourth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7. -- The local market today was intensely dull and irregular. The tractions were heavy and finished at declines of 1/8@ 1/2. In the industrials the feature was Storage common, which advanced from 26 5/8 to 27 1/4, but in the last hour lost 1/4 of its advance. Weisbach declined 1 1/2, to 42 1/2. The rest of the list was unchanged. The market in general at the close was steady.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The Committee on Credentials organized by electing J.H. Atwood of Kansas Chairman and M.E. Benton of Missouri Secretary. Contests were filed from Nevada, Nebraska, Michigan, and South Dakota.
CHICAGO, July 7. -- Gov. Hogg of Texas, after Chairman Daniel had concluded, presented a resolution for the naming of committees.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- At least 10,000 of the 15,000 persons who witnessed the first day's proceedings of the Democratic National Convention in the Chicago Coliseum were subjected to annoyances never before experienced at a similar gathering. A vast throng was marshaled in front of the great building as early as 11 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Another big increase in the exports of American manufactures during May makes the fiscal year 1896 the banner year in the history of American manufacturing exports. The month of May showed manufacturing exports to the amount of $22,016,999, and the eleven months ended with May show such exports to the amount of $206,591,691.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The semi-annual official Naval Register has appeared from the Navy Department and shows that during the last six months the promotions in that service have been fairly good, due to forty-one resignations, mainly cadetships, thirty retirements, many of which were for service and voluntarily or on account of incapacity, and twenty deaths, some of which were among retired officers, and did not affect the advancements of others.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 1 1/2@2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent.

It is now some time since the Parisians last heard of Mile. Couedon, the prophetess, of the Rue de Paradis; and if the information received by the Petit Journal from Rodez is to be credited, she has now been surpassed by a child of nine years, named Paulin Delpont, living at La Roque, near St. Affrique, in the Aveyron.

BOSTON, July 7. -- The market for local stocks was characterized by extreme dullness. Prices receded a little from yesterday's closing, but more from lack of orders than from any active selling. The list was dull to stagnation. Copper in London receded 1/8, to 49 1/2, for spot, and 49 3/4 for futures. Money at the Clearing House loaned at 3@4 per cent.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The situation, so far as the Democratic Presidential nomination is concerned, continues to perplex the men who ordinarily are able to name the winner hours before the meeting of the convention. The chief incident to-day bearing on this question was the action of the seven Iowa delegates in voting for Hill as temporary Chairman.

The trial of Adolph Herschkopf for murder by arson was continued yesterday before Justice Fursman, in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court. Herschkopf la accused of being the master mind of incendiary conspirators who set fire to the tenement house at 129 Suffolk Street on May 31, 1894, when Lizzie Jaeger, four years old, was so badly burned that she died.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- Memories of the World's Fair were recalled to-day as the convention crowds moved toward the Coliseum. The scenes of the morning were similar to those remembered by the visitors to the great exposition.
Charles H. Ferron, a prisoner in Ludlow Street Jail, was found dead in his cell yesterday. He left the following letter:
Joseph Henry Tooker, proprietor in chief of the Metropolitan Job Printing Office, died suddenly yesterday at his home, 133 East One Hundred and Sixteenth Street.
MADRID, July 7. -- Prime Minister Canovas, replying to Mr. Labra, the leader of the Cuban Home Rulers in the Cortes, said:

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The Committee on Rules met this evening and organized by electing J.B. Richardson of Tennessee Chairman and F.B. Carter of Florida Secretary. H.D. Money of Mississippi offered a reso- lution providing for the appointment of a sub-committee of five to draw up an order of business for the convention, and to re- port in half an hour.

President Roosevelt of the Board of Police was the chief witness yesterday in the hearing before the Mayor of the charges of neglect of duty made against his colleague, Commissioner Andrew D. Parker, with the view of removing him from office as Police Commissioner.

It was reported in the press dispatches of last Saturday that the death rate of the City of Buffalo for the first six months of this year had been only 11.67 per thousand. We could scarcely believe that the figures had been transmitted accurately, but an examination of the news columns of our Buffalo contemporaries proves that there was no error.

Ex-Senator INGALLS is being subjected to large quantities of pungent smoke by the voters of the district in which he seeks election to the House of Representatives. While at St. Louis, before the platform was adopted, Mr. INGALLS announced that he was in favor of bimetallism and that he proposed to return to Kansas and run for Congress on that issue.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- After all the speechmaking, Henry D. Clayton of Alabama, the member of the National Committee who had movede to substitute Mr. Daniel's name, made the last speech, in which he emphatically disclaimed any sectional or personal feeling in the turning down of Senator Hill.

The Republican State Committee has issued its call for a convention to be held at Saratoga on the 25th of August, and this may be regarded as the opening note of the State campaign. It bids fair to be a campaign in which every intelligent citizen will keep his State politics and his National politics apart.

ST. LOUIS, July 7. -- The St. Louis nine lost their thirteenth straight game to-day through weakness at the bat. The game was uninteresting. The game of yesterday, which was a tie, will be played of to-morrow.

Nathan Shelton, formerly Treasurer of the Union Pacific Railroad, and who was prominently identified with a number of Western financial enterprises, died yesterday morning at his boarding house, 50 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, from the effects of falling from the window of his room, on the second floor, to the sidewalk.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 7. -- The naphtha yacht Thelma, owned by J. Adolph Mollenhauer, the sugar refiner of Brooklyn, whose Summer home is at this place, was burned to the water's edge off Huntington Harbor this morning and sank. She is believed to be a total wreck, and may not be raised.

The continued examination in the case of Simon Buttner, proprietor of a Raines law hotel at 46 Third Street, who was charged with violating the provisions of the law in having only eight rooms in his hotel when the law requires ten, was held in the Essex Market Court yesterday.

Frank Lee, of 7 Church Street, Jersey City, was greatly bothered by mosquitoes Monday night. He arose about midnight and after thinking the matter over a while concluded to get rid of the pests by smoking them out.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- An interesting question of army mileage is before the Secretary of War. An Inspector General recently visited an engineer officer and examined the latter's accounts pertaining to certain river and harbor work of which he had charge. He was obliged to hire a team, the place being some distance from the railroad.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The War Department people would not be surprised to encounter the protest of some reform league in the proposition to make tobacco a part of the emergency ration, which the authorities are devising for the soldier in the field.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- Good feeling was restored when the crowd, which had suffered so much while the grates were closed, found itself in the magnificent convention hall proper. No convention ever assembled in a more commodious and altogether delightful shelter.
Harmony under the regular organisation was decided upon yesterday by the Republican State Committee.

LONDON, July 7. -- Sir John Fender, formerly member of Parliament for the Wick District, and known the world over as one of the chief, if not the foremost, of organizers and promoters of ocean telegraphy, died to-day from the effects of a second stroke of paralysis, he having had a similar attack last January, which compelled him to resign his seat in Parliament.
The ship May Flint, formerly the British steamship Persian Monarch of the Wilson Line, is now the largest sailing craft flying the American flag. She measures 3,340 tons.

Anson Davies Fitz Randolph, the wellknown, publisher, died Monday evening at West Hampton, L.I., where he had gone to spend the Summer. Although Mr. Randolph had been ill for some weeks, there seemed to be no reason for expecting a fatal termination of his disease until a day or two ago.

HAVANA, July 7. -- Gen. Bradley Johnson, a New-York newspaper correspondent here, has been challenged to fight a duel by a returned Spanish military officer, who was offended by remarks in Gen. Johnson's published correspondence about the Spanish Army. The chalenger finds himself in a somewhat ridiculous position, as the officers in active service refuse to recognize him as their champion.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The silver leaders tonight did nothing formally. A caucus of the General Silver Committee had been called, but it was decided that nothing could be done, and therefore no meeting was held. Several private conferences of leaders were held, and the sliver caucus idea was brought forward.

Mr. George B. Ruddell has sold for Annie E. Ruddell to W.J. Kronenbitter, at about $23,000, the three-story and basement brownstone dwelling 463 West One Hundred and Forty-third Street, 19 by 56 by 99.11.

George L. Sterling of 113 Madison Avenue, one of the assistants to the Corporation Counsel, was locked up in the West Thirtieth Street Police Station last night, charged by Dr. Norman W. Kingsley of 115 Madison Avenue with being a disorderly person.

The Missouri school teachers, in State Association assembled, appointed a committee to formulate what, in the opinion of the Missouri educators, constituted a real, sure-enough "college." The only institutions in the State fulfilling the requirements reported by the committee are the State University, Washingon University, William Jewell College, Drury College, and Park College.
THE NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES, published this morning, TEN PAGES, contains:

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The Committee on Permanent Organization met after the adjournment of the convention. Gen. E.B. Finley of Ohio was elected Chairman, J.P. Brown of Georgia Secretary, and Dr. W.E. Webb of Missouri Sergeant at Arms. After the organization of the committee had been effected it was supposed that action would be taken upon the selection of the permanent officers of the convention.

Former Judge Leicester Holme of this city has reached San Francisco, Cal., on his return from a two years' tour in the East. Mr. Holme was prominent here several years ago, and for a time filled a vacancy on the City Court bench.

The second day's session of the eleventh annual convention of the National Association of Naval Veterans, in Webster Hall, 119-125, East Eleventh Street, yesterday, was disturbed by a controversy over the report of John B. Wirt of Indianapolis, the National Historian. It was a resume of naval history for the past 100 years, and spoke of Nelson's victories over the French.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 5. -- John K. Cowen of Baltimore, President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad and co-receiver at the present time, may become one of the foremost names in American history as the result of the convention about to meet here. The true inwardness of the action of the Republican Senators from the sage-brush States at St. Louis is gradually becoming clear.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Postmaster General Wilson has amended the regulations relating to free-delivery service which took effect on July 1. Free delivery is allowed in cities of 50,000 inhabitants, and may be ordered in cities having a population of 10,000 according to the last census; also in any city where the Post Office produced a gross revenue of $10,000 during the last preceding year.
CHICAGO, July 7. -- Chairman Harrity, as soon as the prayer had been concluded, announced:...

The leaders of the organized Republican faction in this county held a caucus last night at the County Committee headquarters, in West Thirty-eighth Street. Edward Lauterbach, President of the County Committee, presided. There were a great number of the leaders in the Assembly districts present.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- It had been expected by some of the delegates that Senator Hill would be named as one of the committee to escort Senator Daniel to the chair, but he was not. The committee of three to escort Senator Daniel to the platform was composed of three silver men, Senator J.K. Jones of Arkansas, R.P. Keating of Nevada, and Senator S.M. White of California.

NEW-LONDON, July 7. -- The Sachem and the Amorita furnished the sport in to-day's run from Morris Cove, and but for a particularly spiteful fog bank the Sachem would have beaten the Amorita. The Sachem was well in the lead when the tog shut in so thick that they could not find the finishing buoy on either boat.

-- The Fall and Winter season at Koster Bial's Music Hall will be begun Sept. 7. Among the people who have been engaged are Ciss. Fitzgerald, the Jordan family, aerialists; Eugene Stratton, negre songs in white face: Mile. Diamantine, chanteuse excentrique; Lavater's dog orchestra: the three sisters Macarte, wire performers: Lent Noble, ventriloquist; Griftin and Dubois, knockabout comedians; John Claremont's trained pigs, donkeys, and other animals; and the five Jewetts, acrobats.

George Law, President of the Eighth and Ninth Avenue Railroad Companies, died yesterday at 3:05 o'clock P.M., at his home, 259 Fifth Avenue. He had been confined to his house for nearly a month with erysipelas, and had been unconscious for four days.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- Representatives of the People's Party have issued an address to the free-silver Democrats, warning them that they cannot expect to carry the forthcoming election without Populist aid, and that if such aid is desired, the only way to command it is by nominating Henry M. Teller on a straight sixteen-to-one platform.

PATERSON, N.J., July 7. -- Garret A. Hobart, Republican nominee for the Vice Presidency, was formally notified to-day that he was the choice of the convention. In accepting the nomination, he stood in strong contrast with Major McKinley, the reticent head of his ticket, and declared himself unequivocally for a gold standard.

The Nation of Berlin reproduces a clever article written by Louis Windmuller, a well-known merchant of New-York, who manifests much interest in politics, on the Republican and Democratic National Conventions. The article was written before the Republican Convention was held, and predicted that, although Levi P. Morton was the most reliable gold-standard man, Mc-Kinley would receive the nomination for President.

Exports of general merchandise from the port of New-York for the week were valued at $7,369,063, against $6,748,677 in the preceding week and $4,899,937 the corresponding week last year. Total since Jan. 1, $201,406,844, against $178,085,121 in the corresponding week of last year.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The market remains dull and steady. Strawboard broke to 32. The failure to declare the expected dividend this month is supposed to have been the cause of the decline. North Chicago sold at 235 and West Chicago at 100 1/2 to 100 1/4, the demand being light for both stocks.
The strike of the tailors, which seems inevitable, will probably have a new feature in it, and that is an alliance of tailors with contractors against the manufacturers.

Eleven months and a fine of $300, the heaviest punishment ever meted out to a juvenile offender by the Court of Special Sessions, was yesterday imposed on Robert Rathkoph, alias William Miller, a sixteenyear-old lad, living at 17 Columbus Avenue.
MENLO PARK, N.J., July 7. -- Thomas A. Edison started on a vacation yesterday, and he seemed as delighted as a child in anticipation of a new experience, for he has had no real outing for many years.

No political contest ever ended more satisfactorily to both contestants than the initial struggle of the Chicago Convention yesterday. The sound-money men put up Senator HILL for temporary Chairman in the full expectation that he would be set aside by the silver majority. The sixteen-to-one partisans submitted to the designs of the gold men like an unresisting child.

LEBANON, Mo., July 7. -- "I must refrain from talking politics," said R.P. Bland. "Anything but politics now for a few days. You see, I don't want to force, myself into notice now. I have spoken effectively. The whole country knows my attitude on the issue of the day, and, as for the details of the convention and the attitude of the factors in it, I am in the hands of the delegates.

The marriage of Principal Charles R. Abbott of Public School No. 1, Brooklyn, and Miss Alice Day, a teacher in that school, took place at 11 A.M. yesterday, in St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church, Adelphi Street, near De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn. Mr. Abbott is assistant rector of the church, as well as a school Principal.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The New-Yorkers were not surprised at the defeat of Senator Hill for temporary Chairman to-day. They made their fight on principle, and not because they had any hope of winning it. It appears to-night as though the action of the silver majority to-day had stiffened up the sound-money ranks.

Henry H. Bliss, stepfather of Mrs. Mary Alice Almont Livingston Fleming, was examined again yesterday in supplementary proceedings in Part II. of the City Court by Lawyer Edward A. Scott. The examination was held at the instance of John Q. Maynard, who has a judgment against Mr. Bliss and James O. Kane for $243.33.
Robert S. Blanc, a fish dealer of 150 Eighth Avenue, was found dead in a room at the Vanderbilt Hotel, Forty-second Street and Lexington Avenue, yesterday. He had committed suicide by inhaling gas.
Nos. 31 and 33 North Moore Street, for a six-story brick store and warehouse, by George W. Levy of 121 West Seventy-eighth Street, owner; cost, $75,000.

It must be a very sanguine Yale man who expected that Yale would make any better showing in the first heat for the Grand Challenge Cup at Henley than she has in fact made. The antecedent probabilities were all against her. Against an English undergraduate crew she would have had no inferiority of numbers to draw from, since the English undergraduate crews for Henley represent colleges and not the universities.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, July 7. -- The Yale University crew fell by the wayside to-day in their first and, consequent upon their defeat, their only attempt to win the most highly prized trophy of British aquatics, the Grand Challenge Cup of the Royal Henley regatta. Their opponents were the crack eight of the Leander Rowing Club.

Mrs. Clara Foltz, the woman lawyer, is indignant at the publication of the Chicago Associated Press dispatch announcing that she would present the argument to the Committee on Resolutions of the Democratic Convention at Chicago in favor of a woman suffrage plank in the platform. Mrs. Foltz is still in this city.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The Committee on Resolutions met shortly after 9 o'clock at the Palmer House. Senator Stephen M. White of California was chosen Chairman by acclamation. He was called to the door an instant after, and met the committee representing the Committee on Permanent Organization, which notified him of his selection as permanent Chairman of the convention.

CHICAGO, July 7.--With cheers and shouts of joy--a tumult of applause with throat and feet and hands--he majority of the National Democratic Convention has taken the first step that must end in disaster, as it has been begun with disgrace.

By a vote of 26 to 18 President J. Edward Swanstrom of the Brooklyn Board of Education was re-elected yesterday afternoon, defeating Commissioner Horace E. Dresser, who was regarded as Mayor Wurster's candidate. Contrary to expectation, the proceedings of the Board of Education were entirely harmonious, and were not marked by a particle of bitterness on either side.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The sound-money men are more disposed to keep away from the silver fanatics to-night than ever. They held a meeting to-night and took action, which is construed as favoring a withdrawal from any part in the convention proceedings, going home and reporting with a view to a possible separate organization, to be known as the Sound-Money Democracy.

Several persons are anxious to meet R. Kirschmann, who, until a few days ago, conducted a brokerage business at 50 Broadway. One of them is H.W. Eastman, who was engaged by Mr. Kirschmann on Friday as a clerk; another is Louis Barnett, a Brooklyn jeweler.

Crowds of men around the "tickers" late in the afternoon and those in front of telegraph and newspaper bulletin boards from the time the Democratic National Convention was called to order yesterday, showed the interest that is felt in New-York over the high political game that is being played in Chicago.

Nothing shows more plainly the bitterness reigning in the silver ranks than the miserable attack made by Mr. THURMAN of Ohio, degenerate son of a worthy sire, upon Mr. BLAND of Missouri. This attack is based upon the amazing charge that the wife and daughter of Mr. BLAND are members of the Roman Catholic Church.

LIVERPOOL, July 7. -- Upward of 20,000 persons crowded the landing stage and the adjoining streets when the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Boston landed from the steamer Servia, and cheered the visitors repeatedly and with enthusiasm.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 7. -- The Tupper Government was sitting in Council nearly all day and adjourned late in the afternoon, it being generally understood that the Premier would hand in his resignation, along with those of his colleagues, at a late hour to-night.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The presence of Congressman George B. McClellan of New-York as a delegate in this convention makes some of the old-timers who are here reminiscent. At the National Convention held in Chicago in 1864 his father, Gen. George B. McClellan, was nominated for President. Gen. McClellan was put up on a bad platform and he was obliged to remedy it as best he could in his letter of acceptance.

TUESDAY -- P.M. Stock speculation has assumed a waiting attitude, operators being indisposed to commit themselves pending the outcome of the Chicago Convention. London, for the first time in several weeks, sold more stocks than it bought, although its operations were not large. In fact, the total business of the day was small, less than 100,000 shares changing hands.

BUFFALO, July 7. -- The National Council of Education held its final session this morning. Officers for the ensuing year were elected, a number of important changes were made in the membership roll, and several resolutions of more than passing importance were adopted. The election did not develop a single contest.
The New East River Bridge Commissioners met in their offices, at 49 Chambers Street, yesterday afternoon and considered some of the plans for the structure, but no final action was taken.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- When the Rev. Thomas Green of Iowa advanced to the front of the platform at 11:55 o'clock to invoke the Divine blessing, there were several thousand empty seats in the rear and in the extreme ends of the great hall. The Sergeant at Arms pointed to this fact as indisputable evidence that the distribution of tickets was in strict accordance with the rules of fairness.

Writing under date of May 23, the repre- sentative of The London Times now in Cuba says that "every error made last year in the Spanish method of conducting the campaign in Cuba is now being repeated in an aggravated form. The end of May signals the close of the dry season, and for several months afterward active military operations will be almost impracticable.

William Johnson shot William H. Button in the head about 4 o'clock yesterday aft- ernoon, in Twentieth Street, a few yards from Broadway, fired a shot at a woman who was with Sutton, missing her, and then led two policemen and a crowd an ex- citing chase nearly to the corner of Twen- tieth Street and Sixth Avenue.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Most of the delegates were ready for business at 5 o'clock, but the Chairman did not call for order until fifteen minutes past the appointed time. Mr. Daniel used up his voice yesterday in declaiming against the "goldbugs," and to-day he could not make himself heard a rod away from the desk.

LONDON, July 8. -- The visiting members of the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Boston left the Hotel Cecil this morning for Windsor, marching with band and colors to the Waterloo Station. They were escorted by the band of the Honourable Artillery Company of London, and accompanied by the Earl of Denbigh, Lieutenant Colonel of the Honourable Artillery Company.
A prominent business man of Augusta, Ga., who is visiting this city, said yesterday that the facts in the Tillman South Carolina bond scandal had not yet been published.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- The first sensation of the day came a few minutes later, when the Chairman announced that the Committee on Credentials was ready to make a partial report. Mr. Atwood of Kansas, the Chairman of the committee, took the platform. He is a tall, well-made man, with a clear-cut face and a strong voice.
CHICAGO, July 8. -- The speech of ex-Gov. Waller of Connecticut, made yesterday, is construed by the silver men as a threat that the gold men will bolt the convention.

CLEVELAND, July 8. -- Brooklyn had a walkaway with the Clevelands to-day. Base hits rained like a Summer shower, which, coupled with perfect fielding, made the game easy for Brooklyn. Daub had the Clevelands at his mercy up to the ninth, when three singles and a three-bagger netted three earned runs. Up to that time the Clevelands had trouble to get the ball out of the diamond.
"Report me," signaled Capt. Patten of the American ship Henry Villard.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- A production of gold throughout the world equal to the aggregate production of gold and silver prior to 1873 is the estimate of the officials of the Mint Bureau for the calendar year 1896. The gold production of the world has been climbing steadily upward since 1890, when it stood at $118,848,700.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Some important changes are to be made in the rules which govern the navy. For some time a board has been delving among the naval regulations with the idea of making changes in the publication. Naval regulations appear to be devised for the purpose of revision.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- The Sub-Committee on Resolutions was slow in getting together this morning. In the meantime the minority of the sub-committee had prepared its views. The majority made some revision of the draft prepared last night, and shortly after 9 o'clock the members of the sub-committee retired to an adjoining room for further conference.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 8. -- The National Republican Executive Committee will meet at Mark Hanna's office, in this city, next Tuesday, July 14. The committee will then decide that the National headquarters will be in New-York City, as is customary; will fill the vacancies in the National Committee from Colorado, Alaska, and the District of Columbia, and will decide upon a plan of campaign.

The organizers of the exhibition of 1900 have launched a financial scheme which would seem senseless if they could not count on the passion for lotteries. They have announced the issue of 3,250,000 bonds of 20f. each. The 65,000,000f. thus produced, coupled with the subsidies from the Paris municipality and the State, amounting to 100,000,000f. are to be employed in starting the building operations.

The hearing in the charges against Police Commissioner Parker was resumed before the Mayor yesterday and concluded last night. The session began in the morning, with Commissioner Roosevelt stili on the stand.

Commissioner John L.N. Hunt was elected by the Board of Education yesterday as Assistant Superintendent of Schools and Secretary to the Board of Superintendents for a term of six years, and his salary was fixed at $5,000 a year. He would not resign as School Commissioner, he said after the election yesterday, until he was installed in his new office.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 8. -- The Government has at last resigned. It was 5:30 P.M. when Sir Charles Tupper left the Privy Council Chamber for Rideau Hall with his own resignation and those of his colleagues. He remained with his Excellency until about 7 o'clock.

James Butler appeared before Recorder Goff yesterday as complainant against John T. Murray and Frank Daly, whom he accused of robbing him of a watch, but when court adjourned he was himself technically a prisoner, with prospects of imprisonment for perjury staring him in the face.

A committee of Republicans who de- scribed themselves as "thirty-five prac- tical workers, one from each Assembly district," presented to the Republican State Committee at its meeting on Tuesday a statement which they called a "protest and petition," but which bore the formidable title "McKinley League Memorial."

In his address on "American Literature," to be delivered before the National Educa- tional Association in Buffalo, (which is printed in full in the current number of Harper's Weekly,) Prof. BRANDER MAT- THEWS holds to a view that is neither too optimistic and complacent nor too deprecia- tory of native literary work.

The reply of the National Sculpture So- ciety to the Sherman Statue Committee of the Army of the Tennessee is printed in another column. It will be seen that it declines to discuss the questions of regularity or of etiquette raised by the Sherman Statue Committee and raises sharply and clearly the main issue in- volved in the dispute.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Owing to somebody's blunder a large number of delegates to the National Educational Association Convention at Buffalo were subjected to all manner of annoyances before they were able to proceed east. They arrived in Chicago from the West yesterday morning, and when they boarded the trains for Buffalo found that the Eastern roads refused to accept their tickets, claiming they were not good after July 8.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Between 9 and 11 o'clock this morning 15,000 persons, gathered from the big hotels and centres of interest, filed into the Coliseum. The crowd had little trouble in reaching the hall or in getting in, provided they were equipped with tickets. There was no struggling mass of people banked up in front of the Convention Hall as there was at the opening of the session.

The Board of Police Commissioners met yesterday afternoon and retired Police Captain Jacob Siebert of the Second Precinct, on his own application, on a pension of $1,375 a year. Capt. Siebert was appointed to the police force Feb. 4, 1861, and was made a Roundsman May 3 of the same year.
PHILADELPHIA, July 8. -- The following bulletin has been issued by Chairman Gideon of the League of American Wheelmen:
The Republican County Committee's Committee on Organization field a large meeting last night at the headquarters in West Thirty-eighth Street, and issued a call for primaries and conventions.

Every Yale man, and indeed every Amer- ican college oarsman, will be gratified by the result of the second round for the Grand Challenge Cup at Henley. We have all made up our minds, and indeed the Yale men and their coach have freely admitted, that Yale was "not good enough" to win the cup with this year's crew, and it has been made plain that there were several weak places in the boat.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- The rush for the city after the convention took its afternoon session was prodigious, and men and women streamed from every door of the Coliseum, mounted the stairs leading to the elevated station, filled every trolley car, and walked, pushed, scrambled, and climbed to the platform of the Illinois Central.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- A Knowledge of the gold-brick game has come to President Bailey of the Citizens' Savings Bank and Trust Company of St. Johnsbury, Vt., by the painful teaching of experience. Strangely enough, the same kind of bricks, the same good-natured Indian, and apparently the same actors throughout appear in the case as appeared in a recent case in Connecticut, which found its way into most of the newspapers outside of St. Johnsbury.

Fleming G. Du Bignon of Georgia was in the city yesterday on his way home from Saratoga. It was published that he had gone to Chicago with the Whitney party, but he said yesterday that he felt that he could do nothing at the Democratic convention.
CHICAGO, July 8. -- William C. Cornwell, President of the City Bank, Buffalo, and ex-President of the New-York State Bankers' Association, who is stopping at the Auditorium, said to-night:

Statistics of receipts from the liquor tax are given out at Albany with much satisfaction, because they have proved to be even larger than was estimated. They are nearly $10,500,000 in the whole State, and the returns are not yet complete, so that the amount which will go into the State Treasury will be in excess of the $3,000,000 estimated when the tax rate was fixed.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The fifteenth annual convention of the United Societies of Christian Endeavorers will open its business sessions to-morrow morning at 9:30 o'clock. This formal opening, which will take place simultaneously in the three big tents on the White Lot, was preceded to-night by twenty-two separate meetings in the city churches, where the several delegations have established their headquarters.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- The laxity of discipline among the assistants of the Sergeant at Arms was shown by the confusion on the floor and in the galleries to-day. In numbers, the officials were plenteous. One could scarcely go to any part of the building without stumbling on ushers, doorkeepers, pages, special officers, and police- men detailed for convention work.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- A serious mishap may be said to have overtaken the battleship Oregon. It is now found that the draught of that vessel will not enable the officers to take it to the Mare Island Navy Yard. The ship is at present in San Francisco Harbor, where it was launched at the yard of the Union Iron Works.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, July 8. -- The principal events of the programme of the Royal Henley Regatta to-day were the second trial heats of the eight-oared contest for the Grand Challenge Cup and the single scull contest for the diamond sculls, to determine which crews and individual oarsmen shall row in the final heat in each race to-morrow.

The trial of Col. Emilio Nunez on a charge of violating the neutrality laws against Spain in having engaged in a filibustering expedition on the Laurada, which left this port for Cuba on May 8, was begun yesterday before United States Commissioner Alexander.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 8. -- The Colonia won the schooner race here to-day and the Choctaw the sloop race. It was a slowly sailed race, the yachts being out until long after dark. The wind was light and fluky.
SOUTHAMPTON, July 8. -- Upon the arrival of the steamer St. Paul at this port, shortly after noon to-day, Mr. Chauncey M. Depew and his party landed and took a special train for Henley.

There are five beautiful painted windows in New-York, which, if they were on the other side of the water, would attract many American visitors. They are in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street. The windows are in the chancel, and people who know the churches and cathedrals of the Old World say there is nothing there at all similar to them.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- The following letter, alleged to have been written by United States Senator Hill to The Atlanta Constitution July 13, 1893, on the issue for the campaign of 1896, was circulated quietly to-day in the convention:

A characteristic example of Russian official treatment of the newspaper press in connection with public events is afforded by the contrast between the liberty allowed at Moscow during the coronation and the uncompromising suppression of news reverted to in St. Petersburg as soon as the many foreign journalists, delighted with the generous freedom and assistance accorded them in Russia's ancient capital, have quitted the country.
CHICAGO, July 8. -- The Committee on Resolutions of the National Democratic Convention has adopted the following platform, which will be presented to the convention to-morrow:

The trial of Adolph Herschkopf, charged with the murder, by arson, of Lizzie Jaeger, who died as the result of burns received in a fire which started in Soloman Kleinrock's saloon, in the building at 129 Suffolk Street, was continued yesterday before Justice Fursman in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court.

About the first thing visitors to the Sheepshead Bay race track asked about yesterday was the condition of Mr. Belmont's three-year-old colt Hastings, whose sudden lameness had made Trainer Hyland fear that the colt would not be able to race for the Realization Stakes on Saturday.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Speculative interest in grain to-day was most indifferent. The bulletins from the Democratic Convention attracted more attention than the fluctuations in prices. Toward the close there was a firming up in wheat on the rumor that the Indiana State report showed a falling off of 22 points, and previous to that the general tone was steady.
Messrs. Armstrong Parsons have sold, for Mrs. Rosina Vollhart, at $76,000, the two five-story flats 7 and 9 Carmine Street, 43 by 100.

KEY WEST, July 8. -- There is reliable information that the Three Friends landed an expedition Monday night about 12 o'clock near Camaguey, Cuba, and about 12 o'clock the same night sighted the Spanish warship Alfonso XII. All the men and ammunition having been landed by this time, the Three Friends started on her way back.

The whole responsibility for the dead- lock in the Police Board over promotions has generally been put upon the one Com- missioner who was accused of "holding up" certain promotions which the other three Commissioners insisted upon having made. Little attention has been given to the duty of the Chief of Police in the premises, and he has endeavored to maintain a neutral position.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- The call of the roll was begun amid much confusion. The vote of Alabama was challenged. A roll call showed 7 against the silver men, 14 for them, and 1 absentee; the unit rule gave 22 for the silver delegates. California was also polled, and as there was a dispute over the result, it was polled a second time.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- A meeting of the New-York delegates this morning was called to order at 9:30 o'clock, at the Auditorium. Speeches in favor of bolting, in anticipation of a sixteen-to-one platform, were made by Frederic R. Coudert and Perry Belmont. Ex-Gov. Flower, who had been changing his mind considerably on the bolt question, was in favor of a bolt this morning.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- The report of the Committee on Permanent Organization was presented to the convention, as soon as the report of the Committee an Credentials had been adopted, by Mr. Finley of Ohio. It named Senator White of California as permanent President of the convention, and Thomas J. Cogan of Ohio as permanent Secretary.

The tailors of this city are threatening a general strike again. By tailors in this case are meant those who do the work of the great manufacturers of "readymade clothing," which has become one of the leading industries of this city. The threatened strike is another reminder, such as we have had several times before, of the peculiar condition of this industry in New-York.
Lucky Baldwin came within the proverbial inch of losing his life in Judge Slack's court at 9:45 o'clock this morning.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Mills, who have been away from Newport for two years, were among the day's arrivals for the Summer.

Mayor Patrick J. Gleason's domain was invaded yesterday by Anthony Comstock, Secretary of the New-York Society for the Suppression of Vice, and the man of the battle-axe emblem, his police, law-defying gamblers, and plug-uglies suffered or were furnished with an example of law enforcement that was unexpected, drastic, and full of warning.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Another delay has occurred in making public the correspondence of the State Department and the London Foreign Office relative to the new Anglo-American treaty of Arbitration. It is purposed under this treaty to refer all matters of dispute to a friendly, board of arbitrators.

Mr. SALEM H. WALES, who is a member of the East River Bridge Commission, has submitted to his colleagues a timely and appropriate suggestion that proper attention be given to the architectural attractiveness of the structure which is to span the river in the vicinity of Grand Street. This is a feature of bridge construction outside the essential work of the engineer and it has heretofore been neglected.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- The debate on the platform had been limited to two hours and forty minutes, and after reading the amendment of Senator Hill, Senator Ben Tillman, the dark saturnine blatherskite from South Carolina, the statesman with the pitchfork, was introduced. He was as rabid as usual.

The meeting of the Rapid Transit Commission, which was held yesterday afternoon to receive amended plans for elevated railroad extensions, was a disappointment because neither George Gould nor any representative of the Manhattan Railway Company appeared.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9. -- Local stocks were pressed for sale all day, the feature being the absence of any marked support. The weakness is attributed to liquidation of tired holders, and the calling of some loans. The traction group closed at declines of 2 points in Union stock and bonds, 1 per cent. in Philadelphia, and 1/2 in Baltimore.

A queer-looking structure, so small that it hardly attracts attention, but which is destined to be one of the curiosities of the north side, is being erected in Melrose Avenue, just north of One Hundred and Sixty-first Street.

Scratch a silver man and you come to a Populist. In the heart of each burns the desire to get as much as possible and give as little. If either of them happen to be a debtor, this desire takes the form of repudiation. As most of them are debtors repudiation is the thing they are for, and in the Chicago platform they go for it straight.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- Disorder, restlessness, and inattention ruled the morning session until the voice and the presence of Senator Hill stilled the Populistic mob who in their wildness two days ago trampled on him, but were silent to-day in admiration as he led the battle of the morning against the heresy of 16 to 1.

Col. and Mrs. Richard Lathers celebrated their golden wedding at their home, 248 Central Park West, yesterday afternoon. They were married on July 9, 1846, in St. Thomas's Protostant Episcopal Church, this city, by Bishop Whitehouse. Mrs. Lathers was Miss Abby Pitman Thurston, eldest daughter of the late Charles N. Thurston of Bond Street, this city, who was for some time President of the Exchange Bank of Newport, R.I.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- The Democratic Convention -- or the Populistic element which controls it -- is now ready to ballot for a Presidential candidate. All the "favorite sons" were eulogized in elaborate speeches during the five hours' session last night. The usual shouting was done by each and then the struggle for supremacy was postponed until 10 oclock this morning, the convention adjourning at 12:35 A.M., Chicago time.

They had spent nearly the last cent. The Summer bargain counters had proved most alluring. But they were very hungry after the hard morning's work, and they calculated that together they had money enough for a light luncheon. They dropped into an up-town lunchroom, where everything is prepared with special reference to the tastes of woman shoppers.
The failure of John E. Hoffmire Son, ship joiners, at 808 Fifth Street, promises to be one of the most complicated that has occurred in this city in a long time.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 9. -- Village Clerk Frank J. Cola is the sole officer of this village to-day. He is Acting President, as well as Acting Board of Trustees, of this village, and is a busy man. This state of affairs was brought about by the resigning of the Board of Trustees, after the regular business had been transacted, last night.

SYNOPSIS. Prof. Van Wagener of Berlinopolisville thinks he can revolutionize warfare by enabling soldiers to march very rapidly by means of rubber shirts inflated with hydrogen and leaden soles on their shoes, thus permitting them to take enormous strides. He experiments in the narrator's garden, and gets on very well until he happens to come down on the tall of a pet cat, which claws holes in the professor's inflated shirt.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- The first demonstration of the day for ex-Gov. Horace Boies came when Fred White of Iowa was introduced. He spoke of his State as "Iowy." He proceeded to business at once, declaring in plain words that he was there to nominate Horace Boies. He did not try to work up enthusiasm by any oratorical flights.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The Navy Department will shortly undertake some works of improvement at the New-York and Boston Navy Yards. At the former point the Bureau of Yards and Docks will expend $135,000, and at the latter place less than $10,000. The main item to be considered at Boston is a new boiler equipment for the electric light plant, the only other project being a cart shed of modest dimensions and inexpensive construction.

When it became evident that the delegates to Chicago who favored the maintenance in this country of the money standard of the civilized world were not much more than a third of the delegates in number there seemed to many people to be little use in their going to Chicago at all.

The trial of Adolph Herschkopf for murder in the first degree -- it being charged that he started a fire at 129 Suffolk Street on May 31, 1894, which resulted in the death of Lizzie Jaeger -- was continued yesterday before Justice Fursman, in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court.

NEW-YORK, July 9, 1896. BEEVES -- Receipts were 36 1/2 cars, or 603 head, all for a west side slaughterer with the exception of 31 head; no trading; feeling steady; citydressed native sides quiet at 6 1/4 @ 7 1/4 c per pound, a few extra carcasses selling at 7 1/2 c. No later cable advices. Shipments to-day, 121 cattle on the Brooklyn City to Bristol for Meyer Houseman.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, July 9. -- The Henley course from start to finish was not only more crowded to-day than upon either of the previous days of the regatta, but the attendence of spectators was the largest on record. There were over 3,000 pleasure boats along the sides of the course, and the banks of the river were thronged with people.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The collapse of the big white tent, Williston, at 1 o'clock, this morning, due to the heavy fall of rain last night and the severe windstorm that followed, somewhat disconcerted the Committee of Arrangements with regard to the formal opening of the fifteenth annual international Christian Endeavor Convention, which occurred at 9:30 o'clock to-day.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- Senator Vilas followed Senator Hill. He did not confine himself to the points advocated by Mr. Hill. He addressed himself to the threats of repudiation contained in the doctrine of the silver propaganda, pouring hot shot into the ranks of the theorists and dishonest demagogues who are at the head of the movement to disrupt the Democratic Party.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- If, as is generally understood, the New-York delegation, accompanied by the men from New-England, decline to vote for any candidate named, it becomes a delicate parliamentary question as to how many votes will nominate.
Mr. Julius Friend has sold for William H. Horton, to a client for investment, the six-story business building 158 Wooster Street. 25 by 100.

The man who is charitable to himself will listen to the mute appeal for assistance made by his stomach, or his liver, in the shape of divers dyspeptic qualms and uneasy sensations in the regions of the glands that secretes his bile. Hostetter's Stomach Bitters, my dear sir, or madam -- as the case may be -- is what you require.

PITTSBURG, July 9. -- Corcoran made an untimely error for Brooklyn to-day, in the third inning, and it resulted in giving Pittsburg 4 runs, and practically the game. Pittsburg's hitting was fortunate. A high wind prevailed throughout, and affected both pitchers. Although the score was close, it was a dull, uninteresting game.
The city Civil Service Board has introduced a new method in the examination of candidates for promotion in the Fire Department and in the police force of the Department of Parks.

The financial questions of to-day were matters of interest more than a century ago. This is established in the "Compend of Moral Philosophy" of the Rev. John Andrews, who was "Professor of Rhetorick and Belles liettres" in the College and Academy of Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- West Chicago was again the most active stock on the list. Its supporters were obliged to take about 2,000 shares at the uniform prices of par. The balance of the list was dull and narrow. Dlamond Match sold between 223 and 222 3/4. New-York Biscuit was traded in at 92 1/2. North Chicago sold at 233 1/2. Bank clearings were $13,401,394.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., July 9. -- Passed East -- Steam yachts Halcyon. Howard C. Smith; Seabird, Lewis J. Bird; Oneida, E.C. Benedict; Kalolah, C.L. Hubbard; Hirondelle, C.G. Evans; schooner Coseyte, C.A. Tautum; Alicia, H.M. Flagler, and Free Lance, F.A. Schermerhorn.
CHICAGO, July 9. -- The Democratic National Convention to-day repudiated the past record of the party, and by its utterances went over to the Populist camp bag and baggage.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- The silverites had their inning when Russell had finished and Bryan, "the boy orator" and general demagogue of Nebraska, took the platform. They yelled and raved, waved flags, threw hats into the air, and acted like wild men for five minutes.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Capt. Shoemaker, the Chief of the Revenue Cutter Service, has formulated a system of doing work and making purchases which simplifies the business transactions of the Treasury Department in that particular branch. Not until Capt. Shoemaker's advent was it possible to devise and maintain a method which was at once expeditious and economical.

BOSTON, July 9. -- Local stocks were exceedingly dull. The only interest shown was in a few of the coppers. Prices generally fell below last night's closing, and the market at the close was inclined to weakness. Montana dropped 1 1/8, to 85 1/2, but recovered to 86. Old Dominion lost 1, to 14 3/4, but closed at 15. Tamarack declined 4 1/2, to 78, where it closed.

LONDON, July 9. -- This was a great day in the history of the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Boston. They have been the recipients of the highest honors from everybody English, from the Queen down, and never before have such courtesies been shown by royalty, statesmen, military men, and others to a visiting military organization.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- The New-York delegates immediately after the convention took a recess at 5 o'clock hurried over to the Washington Park Club, where they met and mapped out their policy for the remainder of the convention. The privileges of the club had been extended to the delegation upon its arrival here, and as a consequence the most important meeting of New-York delegates was held under very comfortable circumstances.

Funeral services were conducted last night for Joseph H. Tooker, who died Tuesday at 133 East One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, at Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church, in East One Hundred and Eighteenth Street. The pastor, the Rev. James Montgomery, was assisted by the Rev. J.G. Patterson of the East Harlem Presbyterian Church.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- Senator White was in the chair at the beginning of the evening session, but relinquished the gavel to Mr. Richardson of Tennessee. He faced a turbulent ocean of humanity that went in eddies and through the aisles and kept up a constant roar that hardly could be subdued. The shadows were deep in the long galleries behind the electric lights.
WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The Army Ordnance Office is prepared to make contracts for material aggregating in cost $2,714,538.
From The Staats-Zeitung of Yesterday. The platform drafted by the Committee on Platform is a strange mixture, compounded of paternalism gone amiss, and of radical and extreme Democracy.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- A.D. Smith of Minnesota made a rather dreary, though brief, speech seconding the nomination of ex-Gov. Boies, and then J.S. Rhea of Kentucky presented Senator J.C.S. Blackburn, whose name was greeted with a good imitation of the "rebel yell."

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

Ever since his appearance here from the West there has been in certain quarters a disposition to "jump on" J.J. McCafferty. He has been derided as a jockey and made sport of as a trainer. The silent McCafferty has kept very quiet all through it; has gone on attending to his business; has kept on winning races, and can very well afford to laugh at the people who have been making sport of him.

Astor House tenants, including David A. Doyle, the trunk man on the corner, seem to have made up their minds that there is no use in fighting the law against sidewalk obstructions. Doyle has ceased to use even the Vesey Street sidewalk, confining his outdoor exhibit to the stone stairway that leads from Vesey Street into his basement.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 9. -- Wilfred Laurier arrived to-night at 8:30 o'clock. Although his coming was not generally known, over 2,000 persons met him at the station, and welcomed him to the city. He will call on His Excellency to-morrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9. -- Two tired and dusty wheelmen rode up to the City Hall at 8:30 o'clock last night, and were immediately surrounded by a group of cyclists who had been in waiting many hours, in expectation of their coming.
