The Rev. C.T. Weitzell, one of the assistant pastors of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, preached an eloquent sermon on the life of Harriet Beecher Stowe yesterday morning, taking his text from I. John, iv., 7-8: "Beloved, let us love one another: for love is of God. He that loveth not knoweth not God; for God is love."

DETROIT, Mich., July 12. -- The Free Press, the leading Democratic newspaper of Michigan, to-day announced that it would not indorse the Chicago platform nor candidates. The Free Press declares itself to be hereafter free from any party connection. The Detroit Tribune, Republican, some time ago bolted the Republican Party and declared for free silver.

PROVIDENCE, July 11. -- Local stocks during the week have been extremely quiet. Investors, as a rule, are inclined to wait for lower prices, and, as a result, there has been little or no trading. The bank stocks are a trifle lower, and there is more or less disposition to sell, but few shares have changed hands. City National sold at 50 1/2 and Mechanics' National at 52.

PEEKSKHA, N.Y., July 12. -- Every one was glad to see the sun draw near the western horizon to-day, for the day had been uncomfortable. As a general thing the men staid in camp hunting out shady places where some sort of a breeze could be found, but there were a few who went to Peekskill through the broiling sun.

CANTON, Ohio, July 12. -- The mails of yesterday and to-day have brought Major McKinley in the aggregate more than a hundred letters from sound-money Democrats in various parts of the country. The writers make their communications in confidence, of course, but 95 per cent, of these letters contain direct promises of support coupled with vigorous observations upon the action of the Chicago Convention.

GLASGOW, July 1 -- The Royal Clyde Yacht Club opened the Clyde racing fortnight on June 2, by the first day of its regatta, and the programme for the day included twelve matches. The Clyde at Hunters Quay, the headquarters of the club, is between four and five miles wide, and, after the twelve matches had been stared, the estuary was a crowded panorama of yachts of all patterns and tonnage.
Two deaths in one week from lockjaw is the record in Brooklyn as the result of injuries received while celebrating Independence Day.

From Temple Bar. Leigh Hunt had no sense either of time or of money -- a grave fault, perhaps an unpardonable vice, in a man who had a wife and children depending upon him. As long as he lived he was thriftless and needy, a lender and a borrower, so generous that he could never afford to be just, bringing upon those whom he loved sincerely a constant burden of debt and care.
Tammany Hall has not decided on a course in respect to supporting or not supporting the Chicago platform and the nominees upon it.

W.S.C. Russell in The Boston Transcript. The valley of the Pemigewasset, fertile as it is in natural curiosities, contains at least one spot of remarkable grandeur and beauty scarcely known save to the fisherman whose love of the sport has lured him to the head waters of the Moosilauke, a stream rising in a deep defile on the eastern slope of Mount Moosilauke.

Charles Becker, alias Blosh, alias Bader, alias "The Dutchman," and James Cregan, alias "Joe" Howard, who were arrested in Newark, N.J., on May 13, will be sentenced to-day at San Francisco for the forgery on Dec. I8, 1895, on the Nevada Bank of that city through which they and their associate, Frank L. Seaver, alias A.H. Dean, secured $20,000.

Thomas O'Shea of 348 Eighth Avenue and his brother John of 441 West Thirtieth Street were arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday. John O'Shea was charged with disorderly conduct, and the charge of assault was preferred against Thomas O'Shea by John H. Kennedy of 311 West Twenty-seventh Street.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 12. -- Mr. Leland gave a musicale in the parlors of the Ocean House this evening in honor of his guests. A vocal and instrumental programme of classic music was rendered. Many cottagers were present.

CAMBRIDGEPORT, Vt., July 12. -- Two daughters of the Rev. F. D. Goodrich of this place were drowned yesterday. Miss Rosabel, one of the sisters, was eighteen years old; Miss Lillian was twenty. They recently were graduated from the State Normal School. The girls went out for a walk yesterday forenoon. When 3 o'clock came and they had not returned, Mr. and Mrs. Goodrich went to look for them.

From The Chattanooga (Tenn.) Times, (Dem.) A dozen of Democracy's chief newspapers, located at all points -- south, east, west, north -- have raised the flag of rebellion. One, The Brooklyn Eagle, demands a true Democratic ticket, as a means of holding a healthy nucleus of the party in hand for future work of reorganization.

ALBANY, July 11. -- Local securities were inactive. A few sales were reported, and only a few changes were made in prices. Lower bid and asked prices for Troy City Railway stock was the only change of importance. There was a good inquiry for Troy Gas at 130, with none offered. Commercial Union Telegraph was firmer at 110 bid, but subsequently it reacted to the old prices.
It was an ideal Sunday at Coney Island yesterday, whether viewed from the standpoint of the visitor or that of the people whose solo aim it was to charm the money from the pockets of the public.

CINCINNATI, July 12. -- In the seventh inning, with the score 5 to 2 against them, the Brooklyns bunched their hits, and, aided by Miller's error, succeeded in tieing the score. In the eighth the Reds pounded Harper hard, making five singles and a double, scoring 4 runs. The visitors could not connect with the ball in their half of the ninth, and the Cincinnatis made it eight straight wins.
The Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company stole a march on the Aldermen yesterday, and the probability is that the Aldermen, at their meeting this afternoon, will have a lively time in consequence.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The report from San Francisco that accredited agents of the Japanese Ministry are now in the United States prepared to make contracts for the building of several battleships is denied at the State Department, where the intentions of the Japanese Government, so far as the rehabilitation of its navy is concerned, are well understood.
The Roman Catholic Church of the Vistation, in Verona Street, between Richards and Van Brunt Streets, Brooklyn, was destroyed by fire, which started just before midnight last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 12. -- The Tokio cor respondent of The United Press, writing under date of June 26, thus graphicall describes the devastation wrought by tin seismic wave which recently visited the northeast coast of Japan:
The scheme for the unlimited coinage of fifty-cent silver is wholly opposed to mathematics, logic, and morality.

From The Chicago Times-Herald. The Chicago Convention of 1896 stands unique, and, it is to be hoped, will so continue, as wholly devoid of intentional gayety. Numerous as the speakers have been, not one designed in advance a word of humor, a viaclous reference, a rollicking allusion, or a fresh bit of Summer merriment for the entertainment of the convention.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- A list of thirty meetings, arranged to be held in the tents and churches this afternoon, offered varying attractions to the 40,000 Christian Endeavor delegates in attendance here upon the Fifteenth International Convention. They were mostly denominational rallies, and they drew crowds according to the numerical strength of each particular denomination.

From The San Francisco Chronicle. When the American flag was raised at Monterey on the 7th of July, 1846, California gave no promise of becoming either a populous or a wealthy part of the Union. Though greater in area than the combined States of Connecticut, Vermont, New-Jersey, New-Hampshire, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, Maine, Ohio, and New-York, it produced nothing for export beyond hides, tallow, and a very small quantity of wine.

Mr. BRYAN is reported by one of the papers most friendly to him to believe that he is a "Man of Destiny." He is confirmed in the conviction by the fact that when he made the "great" speech which won the nomination for him he had in his vest pocket a seasoned rabbit's foot.

From The Spectator. India pays for her army, but she does not pay for our fleet, and it is our fleet and not her army which saves her from the invasions which if we lost the command of the sea would in three years destroy at once her commercial prosperity and her immunity from internal disorder.

The Republican press is responsible for much of the "unrest" in the agricultural districts which has increased the number of silverites. Our Republican contemporaries have continually been asserting that the low prices of certain agricultural products were due to National legislation.

Immigration Commissioner Dr. Joseph H. Senner has completed his report for the fiscal year ending with June 30, and, in advance of printing, he gave out yesterday a summary of the statistics it contains.

Not a sign of rain and the thermometer registering the temperature at 79* were the conditions at 9 o'clock yesterday morntag, which made city folk say "It is not good to be here." And straightway they hied themselves out of town to the shaded woods or the breezy shore or for a, sail on the waters of the bay or rivers and up the Sound.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- There is some talk in the Navy Department of the establishment of a naval reserve fleet. It is proposed to make a test of each new ship as it is commissioned, and to select those most expensive to maintain and those least efficient for cruising purposes and lay them up in fresh, water, probably at the League Island Navy Yard, near Philadelphia.

SING SING, N. Y., July 12. -- Capt. John Taylor, the oldest Sandy Hook pilot, died here this morning. He was eighty-two years old. He was retired from active duty as a pilot on Dec. 25, 1895. He was born in New-York City, Oct. 25, 1814. His father was Peter Taylor, a shipbuilder. He was apprenticed to the Sandy Hook pilots while still a boy, and was licensed when but twenty-three years old.

"Well, Boss, we done 'em." The winning jockey had been released from the weighing room, and as he carried his saddle along the track toward the paddock, his slim legs and arms hardly able to bear the weight, he was hailed familiarly by some of the spectators who leaned over the fence, but he kept his eyes toward the ground until a trainer hurried forward and relieved him of his burden.

From The Washington Post. In 1820 James Monroe had no opposition for President, receiving all the Electoral votes save one, which was cast by an elector up in New-Hampshire for John Quincy Adams. This patriotic man said he did not want any one ever to receive the unanimous vote of the Electoral College.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- There has been some question in the War Department as to the action in the case of Capt. Henry Romeyn of the Fifth Infantry. This officer was reported physically incapacitated, and there was a proposition to place him on the retired list, although he does not reach the retiring age until next June.

According to the eightieth annual report of the American Bible Society, which covers the extended work of that organization for the twelve months ending March 31 last, the total issues of Scriptures by the society at home and abroad amounted to 1,750,283 copies. The issues of the society during the eighty years of its existence amount to 61,705,841 copies.

Sherman (Texas) Letter to The Philadelphia Times. To-day is a gala day in Sherman, as well as in the county seats of all the other Texas counties. "First Monday" always is. Fourth of July celebrations may or may not attract a crowd; Thanksgiving Day may be a huge success or a flat failure, but "First Monday" never fails to draw a crowd in Texas.

Mrs. Margaret Welsh is not a woman who screams when she thinks burglars are around. Her opportunity to show herself of the stuff heroines are made of came at 3 o'clock yesterday morning. She modestly told Magistrate Flammer all about it in the Jefferson Market Police Court, where she appeared as complainant against Fred McEneaney of 84 Sixth Avenue.

From The London Chronicle. One of the curious items of this year's commemoration at Oxford has been the dinner with which the Roman Catholic undergradutes celebrated the one hundredth meeting of their Newman Society. The real point of the festivity, at which the Duke of Norfolk was the chief guest, was not its apparent occasion.

From The Saturday Review. In almost any other royal family of our time, the Duke de Nemours, who has just died at Versailles, would have shone as a man of conspicuous ability. Among the exceptionally clever children left by Louis Philippe, however, the fraternal competition was too fierce for the Duke, and many years ago he accepted the inevitable, and consented to become an amiabls and pious nonentity.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- An earnest plea is made by the Biological Division of the Agricultural Department that a bird division, to be devoted to instructing children in the value of our native birds and the best means of protecting them, may be added to the school calendar. The idea originated with Prof. C.A. Babcock, the Superintendent of Schools in Oil City, Penn., where it has been in force with gratifying results for several years.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 12. -- Already the men who have considerable to do with haping the policy of the athletic department of Yale University have begun in an informal way the discussion whether the Yale University football team of 1896 will have the pleasure of meeting the Harvard University football eleven this season.

RYE, N.Y., July 12. -- The beginning of the month found nearly all the families that have country seats in this vicinity settled for the Summer. Thus far the season has been very quiet, socially. There have been coaching parties every day when the weather was pleasant, but the continued rains have made out-of-door amusements impossible.

From The London Daily News. In his speech at the Shepherd's Bush Library, Lord Rosebery incidentally told the story of the gambler who, coming out of Crockford's in an evil frame of mind toward the world in general, vented his wrath against a gentleman who was kneeling against the steps at White's tying up his shoes.

While the Central Labor Union was in session yesterday afternoon a tired-lookingman who had evidently visited several Raines note's came in and sat among the delegates. He said he had come to speak for silver and Bryan, and wanted the delegates and their constituents to vote for him.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., July 12. -- Passed West -- Steam yachts Marietta, Harrison B. Moore; Allegra, C.M. Pratt; Forget-Me-Not, W.H. and G. P. Butler; Maspeth, C.M. Meyer; Countess, G. H. Stover; Hirondelle, C.G. Evans; Lorna, W. L. Stow; Restless, H.W. Silbey; Atalanta, Commodore George J. Gould; Emiline. Stephen W. Roach, and Neaera, C.A. Gould.

The break in the Italian Ministry can scarcely be called a Ministerial crisis. The Minister of War made a proposition about the army which was rejected by the Cabinet, and he thereupon offered his resignation. Apparently as a matter of comity, his colleagues in the Ministry offered their resignations also.

A Cuban woman, said to be wealthy; her cousin, a twelve-year-old girl, and a girl fifteen years old were prisoners last night on a charge of shoplifting. They were arrested in Ehrich Brothers', Sixth Avenue.
C.F. Shanbacher, who wag arrested Saturday night an a charge of obtaining money under false pretenses, was taken before Justice Ludlow at Rosebank, S.I., yesterday afternoon for examination.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., July 13. -- William J. Bryan arrived here on the Illinois Central Road at 5:55 this evening, after a run of three hours and a half from Chicago. At several places along the route he was greeted by crowds of citizens.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The marvelous spread, West and South, of the free-silver-coinage idea is an expression by the people of those regions that they have suffered wrongs demanding redress, and that liberty and equal rights have been undermined by unjust distribution of wealth.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- A sensational passage in recent diplomatic correspondence is the rebuke which Secretary Olney has administered to our representatives in Corea, where we have two officials, J.M.B. Sill, New-York man appointed to the service from Michigan, and Horace V. Allen, his assistant, from Ohio.

WHITBY, Ontario, July 13. -- A shock of earthquake was felt here about 1 o'clock this morning. Hundreds of people were awakened by the shock, which lasted about twenty seconds. In many houses the windows rattled, the dishes were disturbed, and in some instances the furniture tottered. The atmosphere at the time was hot and close.

The North Side Board of Trade met last evening at Its headuqarters, 278 Alexander Avenue. Reports submitted by various committees showed that the north aide has grown wonderfully In population and wealth, and is still keeping up this growth.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The manner of making their protest against the Chicago ticket most effective is the chief topic of political discussion at present among Washington Democrats. That they intend to make a protest has not been for a moment a matter of doubt with any of them. It is thought desirable not to make out a cause of action until after the Populist Convention at St. Louis.
STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 13. -- Col. Story, who was the first man to enlist in the Twenty-third Regiment, was to-day presented with a cut-glass water carafe by Quartermaster Hall.

LONDON, July 13. -- At a meeting of the Bimetallic Leauge here today, an address was delivered by Prof. Francis A. Walker, the American political economist and Superintendent of the Censuses of the United States for 1870. Prof. Walker was cheered as he arose, and frequently was interrupted by bursts of cheers.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 13. -- The Catholic Summer School of America was formally opened this morning at the new auditorium on the assembly grounds at Cliff Haven. The Very Rev. T.E. Walsh, D.D., of Plattsburg, delivered an address of welcome, which Dr. Conaty, President of the school responded to.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Senator Chandler of New-Hampshire does not believe that Mr. Sewall will strengthen the Democratic , ticket much, nor that he will carry Maine or New-Hampshire for Bryan and free coinage.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- William J. Bryan reached the Clifton House at 9:30 o'clock this morning. In the lobby Mr. Bryan met Senator White of California and the other members of the Sub-Committee on Notification, who had come by appointment to have a shat about the arrangements for giving formal notice, of Mr. Bryan's nomination.

PITTSBURG, July 13. -- The second trial of ex-City Attorney W.C. Moreland and his assistant, W.H. House, charged with mis-appropriating money said to rightfully belong to the City of Pittsburg, was called in Quarter Sessions Court to-day before Judges Porter and Kennedy. Messrs, More-land and House had been jointly indicted for embezzlement.

WILKESBARBE, Penn., July 13. -- An express train on the Hazleton branch of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, while rounding a curve this afternoon, between White Haven and Freeland, struck a cow. The engine was derailed and thrown down an embankment 200 feet high, and the three passenger coaches were thrown from the tracks upon their sides.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 13. -- Mrs. William Astor arrived from New-York and Beechwood was opened for the Summer to-day. Col. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor are expected here for August.

From Longman's Magazine. The name of England's greatest novelist is closely associated with Allen's. Before Fielding knew Allen, Sarah Fielding, the novelist's sister, was a frequent guest at Prior Park. She lived very quietly in the neighborhood of Bath, and Allen showed her much kindness.

The Legislature of Louisiana adjourned last week, and The New-Orleans Times-Democrat, in speaking of the measures affecting that city, says: "The reforms will make it a model city in its government, commerce, drainage, and public works. In sixty days New-Orleans has advanced more practically and had brighter prospects brought it than in any previous half century of its existence."

HAVANA, July 13. -- At 8 o'clock this morning an explosion occurred on the railway between Cidra and Sabanilla, in the Province of Matanzas. A passenger train that was passing at the time was badly damaged, and it is believed that many persons were killed. A train, with physicians on board, has been dispatched to attend to the wounded and take them to the hospitals.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., July 13. -- Frederick Ammon, a real estate broker of Brooklyn, quarreled with his wife Friday. He came to Rockaway Beach Sunday and shot himself through the temple in Henry Spatz's hotel at Rockaway Beach. Frank Becker, Frederick Hart, and James Bussoe of Spatz's hotel heard the shot, but thought it was fireworks.

Rosa Finker, eleven years old, of 167 Ludlow Street, died yesterday afternoon in the Pro-Cathedral Mission bath, at 130 Stanton Street, and Hedwig Amende, fourteen years old, of 165 Ludlow Street, is seriously ill in Gouverneur Hospital. She is suffering from the effects of overheating or gas poisoning.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- The Honest Money Democracy of Illinois, through, its Executive Committee, issued an address to-night to the Democrats of other States calling upon them to nominate another National ticket and adopt a platform of "sound money" principles upon which the nominees may appeal to the people of that opinion.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 13. -- Although it was very warm here to-day, the weather was delightful. During the forenoon the thermometer stood at 90, but by 1 o'clock a cool sea breeze made its appearance. Many of the transient guests who came to the hotels over Sunday are holding fast to their rooms, until after the big "bike" parade takes place on Saturday next.
PORTLAND, Oregon, July 13. -- News comes from Grant County that the sheep war, as it is called, is becoming serious, and if the sheep men overstep the quarantine limits there will be bloodshed.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- The "long" and "short" men who have figured so conspicuously in the recent series of daring robberies were arrested last night. The "short" man was placed in the sweatbox for six hours at the Central Station. He broke down under the severe examination, and told the police freely of the long series of crimes which have astonished Chicago and the whole country.

The gold-standard Democrats as a body continue in perplexity. Mr. Whitney, to whom they looked for leadership prior to and during the Chicago Convention, has as yet made public no plan which may be followed.

From The Middletown (Conn.) Press. The "starring" season is at its height in New-Haven, and nearly every oyster grower in that city has some of his boats engaged in ridding the grounds of the most disastrous pest of the oyster -- the starfish. Hundreds of bushels of them are brought ashore every day in which the hunt for them is prosecuted, but the supply never becomes exhausted.

Whatever the effect upon "international relations" of the visit of the Boston militiamen to England may be, it is tolerably certain that the Salem, Cadet Band, which is said to be better than any of the crack regimental bands of London, has gained international renown which will secure to it a National reputation.
CHICAGO, July 13. -- Mr. Sewall has not yet decided whether he will join Mr. Bryan in the speechmaking feature of the campaign. He said to-day he could build better ships than speeches. He added:

From the San Francisco Examiner, July 7. It is only a question of time when "Lucky" Baldwin must be sent to the Almshouse. The poor man is worth now a paltry $3,000,000, and he is becoming poorer every day.

An Eastern Democrat who shouts for BRYAN and SEWALL because he wants free silver and a redistribution of wealth may claim some respect for his sincerity and frankness. But no Democrat who pleads that the ticket must be supported by organization men because it is the product of a regular party convention will convince any one that he believes his own plea.

Whatever doubts or misgivings there may be in regard to Presidential candidates, there can be no question about the importance of making sure of a soundmoney House of Representatives at the coming election. More than once at a critical time in the past we have been saved from a disastrous policy by the firm and courageous attitude of a President holding the power of veto over a misguided Congress.

The candidacy of Arthur Sewall of Bath, Me., for the Vice Presidency, on a platform which makes humanity its pretense, would cause amusement among many shipping people and seamen did it not incite to a feeling of indignation at the hypocrisy of the thing.

Whatever the effect upon "international relations" of the visit of the Boston militiamen to England may be, it is tolerably certain that the Salem, Cadet Band, which is said to be better than any of the crack regimental bands of London, has gained international renown which will secure to it a National reputation.

William Ranken, twenty-eight years old, who inherited property worth several hundred thousand dollars from his father, Henry Ranken, and who was a member of one of the most prominent and wealthy families In Hoboken, N.J., attempted suicide yesterday morning by cutting his throat with a razor.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 13. -- The Hon. Wilfred Laurier, the new Liberal Premier, has practically completed his Cabinet, with the exception of the Department of the Interior, which has been left open for a Western man, probably the Hon. Clifford Sifton or Joseph Martin of Manitoba.
CLEVELAND, July 13. -- Chairman M.A. Hanna of the Republican National Committee has named the Executive Committee for McKinley's campaign. The list is as follows:

Since the Chicago Populist-Anarchist Convention has shown what are the real purposes of the men who seized control of it, it is well to remember how the movement was started. It is Anarchistic and Populistic now, but in the beginning it was, to use their own term, purely capitalistic.

From the Savannah (Ga.) News. Now that the convention has finished its work it is worthy of note that, although certain delegates were running all around town for days, fearful lest William C. Whitney should catch them and bribe them to vote for a goldbug, the only offer of money for the purpose of influencing the action of the convention came from the silver camp.

A rather remarkable specimen of marine architecture came into port yesterday. The British four-masted steel ship Ancona, a sailing whaleback, Capt. Lemuel E. Robbins, arrived from Cape Town, Cape of Good Hope, after a pleasant run of fifty-two days. There are many whaleback steamships afloat, and they have at times entered this port, but this is the first time that a whaleback sailing vessel has been seen here.
All was "harmony" between the State Democracy and Tammany Hall a few days ago. All was working smoothly in the interest of tranquillity and success as against the one enemy of both -- Republicanism.

The large number of pleasure seekers that gathered at Manhattan Beach last right were treated to a varied programme at Pain's open-air theatre that caused delight and surprise, even at this always popular Summer resort.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 14. -- Arthur E. Chandler, Track Superintedent of the Atlantic Coast Electric Railway, and James Sweeny, a laborer, were insantly killed by a trolley car this afternoon.

A correspondent of the American Bible Society in Japan writes, under date of June 16, concerning affairs in that empire and in Korea. He says that owing to the predominance of Russian influence in Korea, Pak Young Hio is staying in Kobe, Japan, and that he is not expected to return to Korea for a considerable time.
Counsel for John Mackin and Paul Genz, sentenced to be hanged in the Hudson County Jail, at Jersey City, to-morrow, are still trying to save their clients.

The trial of Patrolman John A. Williams of the Charles Street Police Station, who, it is said, was indicted at Minneapolis in 1893 for attempted extortion and who swore in his application for appointment that he was never indicted for or convicted of any crime, was continued before Commissioner Roosevelt yesterday.
There were rumors yesterday afternoon and evening that Cornelius Vanderbilt, Sr., had been stricken, with paralysis, and that Cornelius Vanderbilt, Jr., had suffered a relapse, and was seciously ill.

The Social Reform Club of 28 East Fourth Street, which, after every monthly meeting, indulges in a discussion, chose, last night, the topic of the day, gold and free silver. E.H. Crosby, who presided, said, in opening the discussion, that the object was, primarily, to enlighten those present as to what the free-silver question means.
The mystery surrounding the alleged disappearance of the body of Arthur Adams, who died recently on Blackwell's Island of paralysis, was cleared up yesterday morning.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 14. -- The New-York State Council of the Catholic Benevolent Legion opened its fourteenth annual convention here to-day. After a street parade this morning, mass was celebrated by the Rev. John J. McNamee of New-York, State Spiritual Adviser, in Cathedral Hall, The Right Rev. B.J. McQuaid, Bishop of Rochester, occupied the episcopal throne, and in an address said:

Mr. GORMAN has announced in The New-York Journal that he is "determined to stand by the Democratic Party as" he has "always done." This is doubtless intended as a statement that he will vote for and use such power as remains to him to secure the election of BRYAN and SEWALL.

A.H. Page of the firm of Faulkner, Page Co. has never taken an active part in politics. Although he classes himself as an independent, he has been a great admirer of President Cleveland and his policy. In conversation with a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES respecting the coming campaign, he said:

While steaming up the Lower Bay early yesterday morning the steamer Colorado of the Mallory Line, coming in from Brunswick, Ga., with twenty-eight passengers and a general cargo, ran into a barge laden with cellar dirt and was so badly damaged that she was run upon the end of West Bank to save her from sinking in water above her decks.

The State Tax Commissioners have just made a visit to this city preparatory to the annual equalisation of tax assessments, which invariably involves a large addition to the valuation of real estate here for the relief of rural taxpayers.

Mr. BRYAN'S first campaign speech, delivered from an improvised platform at Champaign, Ill., Monday evening, was pretty poor stuff. At the beginning he apologized for the quality of it by saying: "I have just been talking some in Chicago, and am sort of between speeches." When this gentleman is "sort of between speeches" his oratorical output is flat enough, because it is not his custom to speak extemporaneously.

BOSTON, July 14. -- A reception was given to George Fred Williams to-night by his friends in the silver faith, the affair taking the form of a mass meeting in Faneuil Hall, with speeches by the beneficiary, Jeremiah T. O'Sullivan of Lawrence, his chief lieutenant, and other converts to the silver cause.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- The first delivery of silver certificates of the new design approved by the Secretary of the Treasury for the issue of 1896 was made to-day by the Bureau of Engraving and Printing to the Treasurer of the United States. The denomination delivered was the one dollar. It is a very beautiful change from the old conventional bank-note design.

LONDON, July 14. -- The withdrawal of the amendments to the Irish Land bill offered by Mr. Gerald Balfour, Chief Secretary for Ireland, is being sharply criticised by friends of the Government, and has caused much rejoicing among the Radicals, whose supporters in newspaper circles are rejoicing over the Government's discomfiture.

OSWEGO, N.Y., July 14. -- The centennial celebration of the evacuation of Fort Ontario to-morrow promises to be a grand affair. An immense crowd will be in attendance. All railroads running into Oswego will run special trains and excursions by boat from Canada are announced. Department Commander J.S. Graham of the Grand Army of the Republic arrived to-night from Rochester.

The case of Adolph Herschkopf, who is charged with murder by arson, was given to the jury at 3:40 o'clock yesterday afternoon, but at 10:30 o'clock at night the jurymen had not decided upon a verdict, and were locked up for the night. Justice Fursman will open court at 10:30 o'clock this morning.
For a year a gang of young fellows has hung around Seventy-fifth and Seventy-sixth Streets and Avenue A, and made life miserable for the grocers and other dealers in that vicinity.
Justice of the Peace James Clark of Hoboken yesterday performed a marriage ceremony for a Hebrew couple from the neighborhood of the Five Points, New-York.

CENTRALIA, Ill., July 14. -- Candidate Bryan, Presidential standard-bearer of the silverites and Populists who controlled the Chicago Convention, delivered a characteristic speech here to-night. He spoke as follows:

A well-dressed young man slightly under the influence of strong drink caused a panic at Broadway and Thirty-second Street yesterday afternoon, and in a few minutes had attracted so dense a crowd that the cable cars were compelled to slow up in order to avoid injury to those who stood in the street.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 14. -- There is little doubt that the Republican National headquarters this year will be in the West -- either at Chicago or Cleveland.

Justice Stover, in Special Term, Part I., of the Supreme Court, yesterday heard arguments of counsel on either side on a motion for the continuance of a temporary injunction obtained by Mary J. O'Brien restraining the Union Railway Company from constructing the section of the road which is to pass by her property.

Manager "Al" Hayman announced yesterday that the name of Abbey's Theatre would be changed to the Knickerbocker. Mr. Hayman explained that the delay in announcing the new name for the house was mainly due to the fact that the owners of the property, Merrs. Robert and Ogden Goelet, were undecided upon the names Amsterdam and Knickerbocker until yesterday morning, when it was definitely settled to rechristen the theatre the Knickerbocker.
PARIS, July 14. -- What is claimed in some quarters as an attempt to assassinate President Felix Faure was made at 2:50 o'clock this afternoon at the parade ground at Longchamp.

Inspector Cortright made a complaint to the Street Cleaning Department yesterday because four barrels of refuse had been allowed to remain standing in "Cat Alley," opposite Police Headquarters since late last Thursday afternoon. The stench from them was frightful. Ash cart drivers have been in the neighborhood every day, but they would not remove the refuse because it had not been properly separated. Paper was mingled with ashes and garbage.

Commissioner STARIN has proposed that the Rapid Transit Commission revert to the franchise which the former commission tried to dispose of by public sale for an underground railroad and let the contract for municipal construction under that, all the necessary consents having been obtained at the time and still being valid for the routes and plans then adopted.
What the Fourth of July is to all Americans, the 14th of July, the anniversary of the fall of the Bastile, is to the sons and daughters of La belle France.
BOSTON, July 14. -- A large audience assembled in Music Hall this evening to greet the Massachusetts delegation to the St. Louis Convention, and to ratify the nominations of McKinley and Hobart.

COWES, July 14. -- Despite the fact that certain correspondents have denied the truth of the statement cabled yesterday that Mr. Ogden Goelet of New-York has been lying seriously ill on board the yacht White Ladye, which has been anchored in this harbor, The United Press learns that the report was absolutely correct.

ALBANY, July 14. -- State Agricultural Commissioner Charles A. Wieting has received numerous letters from various sections of the State complaining of the ravages of the army worm and asking what measures can be taken to fight the pest.
DOVER, Del., July 14. -- The Republican Convention called by the Addicks committee met to-day. Most, of the nominations were made by county caucuses. The nominees of the convention are:

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., July 14. -- Provincetown, the place where the Pilgrims first landed, was to-day historically recognized, and the townspeople and many visitors witnessed the unveiling and dedication of the monument presented to the town by the State in commemoration of that event.

Mrs. Elizabeth B. Grannis of 33 East Twenty-second Street is the President of the National League for the Promotion of Social Purity. Edward Ince, fifty-four years old, no home, walked through her house on Monday afternoon, undressed himself in the back yard, and then lay down in the yard in a state of perfect nudity.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 14. -- Senator Smith to-day made the following statement with regard to the situation in the Democratic Party:
BREWSTER, N.Y., July 14. -- The Republican Convention of Putnam County was held at Carmel to-day and selected delegates to the State, Congressional, and Judicial conventions as follows:
PHILADELPHIA, July 14. -- Cablegrams received here to-day from Cuba confirm the truth of the story of the killing of Gen. Jose Maceo, brother of Gen. Antonio Maceo, the Cuban insurgent leader.

CANTON, Ohio, July 14.-- Major McKinley had not finished breakfast this morning before callers began to arrive. When he came out on the veranda to smoke his morning cigar all of the chairs were occupied and a fringe of men were sitting around on the edge of the porch and several were on the steps leading up to it.

The taking of the oath of office by Mr. LAURIER, as Premier of the Dominion of Canada, has necessarily given rise to much speculation on both sides of the Atlantic as to the purposes with which he takes office.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 14. -- Hundreds of dollars' worth of feathers and fine fabrics were spoiled this afternoon, a heavy and unexpected downpour of rain coming just when the drives were filled with society people, who left their light traps and took refuge in neighboring stores and cottages.

ALBANY, July 14. -- State Civil Service Commissioner Burt, Secretary Angel, and Chief Examiner Fowler of the State Civil Service Commission to-day called on Gov. Morton and his legal adviser, Mr. Lincoln. With them was a delegation from Brooklyn comprising Corporation Counsel J.A. Burr, Surrogate Abbott, Charles Y. Vandoren, Chief Clerk, of the County Court; Samuel T. Maddox, for the County Treasurer, and John M. Ward, representing the City Controller.

General Humidity was conspicuous at the meeting of the Republican County Committee last evening, but he was entirely lost sight of when the members began the discussion of the complaint from the Thirtieth Election District of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 14. -- Many of the hotel guests and cottagers have been complaining to-day of experiencing extreme heat during last night at this place. It certainly was very warm the early portion of the evening, and it continued so all night, until about 6 o'clock this morning, when a sea breeze struck up, which made the day a pleasant one, but still quite warm.

G.H. Duggan's tiny craft Glencairn won the second race for the Seawanhaka International Challenge Cup yesterday. The race was over a triangular course, and the contest was closer and more interesting than on Monday. The Glencairn was better handled than the El Heirie, and won more on that account than because she was the better boat.

The lady who visited a hospital in Baltimore and tried to make arrangements with the janitor for the admission of a patient whom she desired to have killed and dissected by the doctors was thought to be perfectly sane, because she spoke coherently and betrayed in her behavior no evidences of an unsound mind.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 15. -- The weather was very sultry this morning. Despite this the drills were well executed. The Twenty-third boys are improving daily in their work, and the dress parade is now up to the standard. The officer of the day was Capt. Praeger, and the officer of the guard was Lieut. Hughes.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., July 15. -- Passed East -- Steam yachts Theresa. Gustavus Sidenbu, E.R. Parthenia, Stephen J. Roach; Orienta, E.R. Ladew; Helvetia, C.O'D. Iselin; Duquesne, T. R. Hostetter; Vision, F.H. Benedict; Unquowa, John H. Hall; Charlietta, W.B. Higgius; Forget Me Not, W.H. and G.P. Butler; Alicia, H. M. Flagler; Katrina. Henry F. Noyes; Sapphire. James Stillman; Tomette, Albert B. Hilton, and Allegra, C.M. Pratt; cutter yacht Mineora August delmont.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 15. -- The sweepstakes for thirty-footers to-day was won by the Vaquero II., which was finely handled by her owner. H.B. Duryea. Bayard Thayer sailed his Asahi. The Esperanza, owned by A. Van Winkle of Bristol, also sailed, handled by Capt. Croeker. The wind blew good and strong from the southwest, kicking up a choppy sea.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 15. -- The most important social event of the season thus far took place this afternoon, from 4 to 6 o'clock, when Col. and Mrs. C.L. Best gave a reception at their cottage on Bellevue Avenue in honor of Baron and Baroness de Levay, nee De Wolfe, who were recently married in Bristol.

At the special meeting of the stockholders of the New-York and Harlem Railroad, held in the Grand Central Station yesterday, 85 1/2 per cent. of the $10,000,000 of stock was represented, and the vote to ratify the lease of the Fourth and Madison Avenue surface lines to the Metropolitan Street Railway was unanimous.

Mr. BRYAN has made his first serious campaign speech. With the exception of a stupid jeer at honesty in finance as aristocratic and English, the speech is much more creditable to the candidate than his more ambitious effort at the convention. That, however, is not much of a compliment, for the percentage of sense in his latest speech is still not large.

The advocates of a sound-money policy in this campaign should realize that they have a popular delusion to deal with, and the weapon with which to fight a delusion is the light of reason. Whatever selfish or dishonest motives mine owners and demagogues may have in fostering the free-silver delusion, the fact may as well be recognized that the mass of the people who are carried away by it are honest, though misguided.
The programme for the Larchnmnt race week has been arranged as follows:

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 15. -- William C. De Witt of Brooklyn and David J. Dean, First Assistant Corporation Counsel of New-York, who were appointed by the Greater New-York Commission to draft a Greater New-York charter, are now hard at work on that important matter at the Long Beach Hotel.

ALBANY, July 15. -- Senator Raines's special committee appointed by the Legislature to inquire into the workings of the Raines liquor-tax law held its first meeting to-day in this city at The Tub. The committee is to report to the next Legislature, that its members may have accurate information so as to make such amendments to the Raines law as experience may show to be desirable.

Patrick Sheridan. Postmaster Patrick Sheridan, one of the most prominent Democrats in Elizabeth, N.J., and for many years a noted builder, died yesterday at the age of sixty-two. Mr. Sheridan was born in Ireland, and lived half a century in Elizabeth. He was a man of strict integrity, and a very patriotic Irishman.

SING SING, N.Y., July 15. -- Superintendent of Prisons Lathrop this afternoon instituted a school of instruction in the prison for the purpose of teaching the Bertillon system of identification of criminals, recently adopted by all the State penal institutions. Paul R. Brown, Major and Surgeon, United States Army, of Fort Hamilton, was instructor.

The sudden illness of Mr. CORNELIUS VANDERBILT has produced an effect of which it is worth while to consider the social and even the political aspects. Mr. VANDERBILT is known by name to almost everybody in the country as perhaps the richest man in it, certainly the richest man whose fortune is, so to say, an active and militant force in the development of the country.

The leaders of the New-York sound-money delegates who fought against the debasement of Democracy in Chicago were not ready yesterday to announce their campaign policy. It may be several days before they are ready to do so. Possibly they will wait until after the Populist Convention in St. Louis next week.

BOSTON, July 15. -- The Union Pacific May statement, issued to-day, shows that the gross earnings decreased $1,155; the net earnings decreased $6,615. Last year the Union Pacific May gross earnings decreased $158,796, and the net increased $287,123.

There is reason to believe that one of the passengers on the American Liner St. Louis, which left her dock at the foot of Fulton Street at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, is mourning the loss of valuable jewelry. The jewelry in the possession of the police was recovered in an accidental manner.

The Supreme Court was yesterday, not for the first time, the scene of a striking illustration how alien and remote from any standards or customs with which we are familiar is a considerable part of our population. The occasion was the conviction of another firebug. Incendiarism, regarded as a trade, is of foreign origin and recent importation.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: More than thirty years ago there were a lot of men in this country, who, preferring to be Americans to being partisans, voted, as well as fought, against what had been their party and earned the title of "War Democrats." To-day many of these same men, and others, who have grown up since, are placed in a very similar position.

-- Ex-Senator J.R. McPherson of New-Jersey was at the point of death in Denver, Col., Tuesday, through a severe spasm of asthma. He was attended by his special physician and was pronounced out of danger after an hour of arduous application. The attack was provoked by exposure to a heavy shower that caught the Senator without protection.

Nearly 100 members of the State Democracy assembled at the headquarters, in Twenty-third Street, last night, in response to a call sent out Tuesday by Vice Chairman Francis M. Scott. This was a large attendance, in view of the short notice. Only four Assembly districts were not represented.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 15. -- Another very warm spell was experienced here today. The thermometer was from 90 to 95 the greater portion of the day.

John Mackin, who killed his wife and mother-in-law in Jersey City, and Paul Genz, who killed Clara Arnim, his common-law wife in Hoboken, will not be hanged to-day in the Hudson County Jail, as was expected.

Senator J.K. Jones of Arkansas, Chairman of the Bryan National Committee, misnamed the Democratic committee, was expected to arrive at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night, but did not put in an appearance. A few friends of the coyote ticket called to see what Mr. Jones was going to do about it, but went away disappointed.

A soda fountain that was being filled in the soda water works of John Matthews, 331 to 337 East Twenty-sixth Street, about 7 o'clock last evening, exploded. John Cullen, twenty-seven years old, of 301 East Thirty-third Street, was struck by the fragments and so injured that he died in Bellevue Hospital.

LONDON, July 15. -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Gerald Balfour. Chief Secretary for Ireland, announced that the Government withdrew those sections of the Irish land bill relating to procedure before Land Courts and defining improvements upon landed property, whether made by landlord or tenant.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- The Navy Department has many experiences with inventors, but the most novel of such relationships was developed to-day. A boy, hardly sixteen years of age, with marked foreign accent in his speech, called at the office of the Secretary of the Navy and said he came in response to a letter from the department.

ST. LOUIS, July 15. -- Preparations for the Populist National Convention are rapidly assuming definite shape. National Chairman Taubeneck and Sergeant at Arms McDowell have been busy at their respective headquarters, and expect to have all arrangements completed by the last of the week.

From The Portland Oregonian. SALEM, Oregon, July 9. -- The large rattlesnake captured in Yamhill County yesterday is now the worse for its experience. The original home of this snake is, no doubt, in the famous Thurber snake den, near which it was captured. The Thurber den is on a farm owned by A.W. Rees, in a rocky knoll covering about two acres.
Postmaster Charles W. Dayton made public yesterday the record of the letter carriers of this city during the inspection of the service by the secret agents in April and May.
The Glencairn, the Canadian half-rater, won the third race of the series for the Seawanhaka Cup yesterday, defeating the El Heirie again. The cup now goes to the Royal St. Lawrence Yacht Club.

CANTON, July 15. -- Several hundred Cleveland women came here to-day on a special train to see Major McKinley. The visitors were representative women of their city, and their pilgrimage is regarded as without precedent in political history. Mrs. Elroy Avery made an address of congratulation to which Major McKinley responded. In part he said:
BOSTON, July 15. -- Arthur Sewall had few callers this morning. In conversation today he had little to add to what he had already expressed.
NEWARK, N.J., July 15. -- Senator Smith, before leaving for Europe this morning, outlined his plans for participation in the campaign in a letter to Col. Price, which reads as follows:

From The St. Paul (Minn.) Pioneer Press. To the end that the Government of the United States should become the property of the silver mine owners, its currency debased, its financial policy converted into an instrument of their aggrandizement, and the interests of 70,000,000 American citizens sacrificed to their benefit, they have allied themselves with all the elements of Anarchy and outlawry and all the forces of repudiation.

BALTIMORE, July 15. -- The war between the Baltimore Steam Packet Company and the Seaboard Air Line on the one side, and the Baltimore, Chesapeake and Richmond Steamboat Company and the Southern Railway on the other side, is becoming hot. The latter companies recently put on a line of steamers between Baltimore and Norfolk, invading the Steam Packet Company's (Old Bay Line) exclusive territory.

From the Portland (Me.) Press. The legal fraternity are deeply interested in one of the most curious wills that was ever probated in Portland. The Hon. F.O. J. Smith died twenty years ago, in October, 1876. This will, after making a number of bequests, left the residue of the estate to establish "A Home for Aged Couples."

-- A discussion has arisen in the English newspapers as to the earliest use of a conducting stick by the leader of the orchestra. It grew out of a statement in Dr. Murray's English Dictionary that the year 1867 is the earliest dated reference to the use of the word baton as an equivalent for the conducting stick in English literature.

Andrew D. White has issued from Ithaca a letter to "patriotic Democrats" regarding the duty of good citizens in the present political situation. It is to be put in pamphlet form for circulation, and is expected to have good effect in emphasizing the sentiment in favor of sound money.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The nomination by the so-called Democratic Convention of an out-and-out free-coinage candidate for the Presidency, upon an out-and-out free-coinage platform, calls for, it seems to me, the immediate and resolute action of the gold-standard Democracy of the country in the nomination of gold-standard candidates for President and Vice President upon a gold-standard platform.

There was an uncommonly eager disposition to sell stocks manifested in the Stock Exchange yesterday morning. The news of Mr. Vanderbilt's prostration, coupled with the general feeling of uneasiness that has prevailed among capitalists and security holders since the Chicago Convention, gave the professional bears a rare opportunity, which they promptly embraced.

The lady who visited a hospital in Baltimore and tried to make arrangements with the janitor for the admission of a patient whom she desired to have killed and dissected by the doctors was thought to be perfectly sane, because she spoke coherently and betrayed in her behavior no evidences of an unsound mind.
The four or five doctors who are in attendance on Cornelius Vanderbilt, Sr., who was stricken with paralysis on Tuesday, take a hopeful view of his case.

It has been known for some time that the Venezuelan Government, as well as the people of this city, were not satisfied with the equestrian statue of Bolivar in Central Park. As it was not a pleasing object of art, it was put in a somewhat out-of-the-way spot, where it would not attract too much criticism.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 15. -- An unusually severe electrical storm passed over this section about 1:30 o'clock this afternoon, and did considerable damage. The large flagpole on the beach at the foot of First Avenue, in front of the Coleman House, on which floated the "Peace-on-earth-good-will-toward-men" banner for the last twenty-five years, was shattered by an electric bolt.

SALEM, Ill., July 15. -- In response to Mayor Iakin's proclamation, the Democratic candidate's birthplace was transformed from a sleepy country town to a place of variegated color to-day. Nearly every house had a flag above it, and around porch posts and over doors was red, white, and blue bunting. Three thousand persons gathered.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Senator J.K. Jones, the Chairman of the Bryan-Sewall National Committee, started to-day for New-York to make arrangements for the exhibition to be given later on of the candidates selected by the convention at Chicago.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 16. -- Everything is getting in readiness for the big bicycle parade on Saturday. Yesterday a large force of decorators arrived here, and to-day they are all hard at work putting up flags and other decorations to suit the occasion. Proprietors Sprague of the Howland House and Van Cleaf of the United States Hotel were the two first to display their colors.
PENN YAN, N.Y., July 16. -- The Penn Yan Democrat, the only Democratic, paper in Yates County, has bolted the Chicago platform.

Walter O. Lewis. Walter O. Lewis, who died at the age of eighty-one years, in Germantown, Penn., on Wednesday, was prominently identified with the early history of telegraphy, and was the originator of the system of collecting marine news now generally in vogue.
The Sound Currency Commerce of the Reform Club held a meeting at the club headquarters, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street, last night, to consider plans for a campaign of sound money.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 16. -- The open letter addressed by A.D. White to leading Democrats, asking them to support the Republican candidates in the present emergency, has been answered by Theodore Bacon of this city. In his letter to Mr. White he says:

MASSILLON, Ohio, July 16. -- The driver of Buffalo Bill's band wagon started eight horses under the overhead Fort Wayne bridge at Erie Street at 11 o'clock this morning. He had miscalculated its height and was unable to stop the horses. All the occupants of the band wagon were scraped off in the presence of horror-stricken thousands.

The diamond jewelry found in possession of William Doyle of 56 Leroy Street and Joseph Flynn of 500 Perry Street, Hoboken, who were arrested Wednesday while trying to pawn one of the articles at a Varick Street pawnshop, has been identified as the property of Frank A. Watson and his sister of 51 East Thirty-fourth Street, who sailed for England on the steamship St. Louis.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Decidedly the most interesting recent event in diplomatic circles will be the publicity given in Great Britain and the United States on Saturday next to the correspondence between the two countries with reference to a treaty of arbitration. The exchange of letters between Secretary Olney and Lord Salisbury has been effected through the British Ambassador at Washington, Sir Julian Pauncefote.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 16. -- A general raid was begun this afternoon on the tramps within the village limits. Over a dozen men who could not show that they had any business in the place or means of earning a living were arrested in two hours.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 16. -- A flat-bottomed ferryboat, loaded with between forty and fifty laborers, while crossing the old river channel to-night, was capsized, and between fifteen and twenty of the laborers were drowned.

CINCINNATI, July 16. -- Ed Corrigan, the race-horse owner, was viciously attacked this morning by John Phillips, a negro stableman. Phillips had been discharged by Corrigan. In a spirit of revenge he slashed his former employer several times with a knife and escaped. Corrigan's injuries are not serious.

A Democrat of standing and character who comes out for BRYAN attracts in the field of politics the same amazed attention that in the domain of nature would be bestowed upon water running up hill. A well-organized human mind ought not to act in that way, and would not unless subjected to the play of unusual forces.

Senator J.K. Jones of Arkansas, Chairman of Bryan's National Committee, called the Democratic National Committee by the Populists, arrived at the Astor House early yesterday morning, ate a hearty breakfast, and then went away.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., July 16. -- While the President was fishing to-day a telegram was received from a personal friend in Boston announcing the death of ex-Gov. Russell. The President was very much shocked and spoke very feelingly of the sudden death. In conversation after his return the President made the following tribute:

Mr. DE WITT of the Greater New-York Commission and Assistant Corporation Counsel DEAN of this city, in behalf of a sub-committee of the Committee on Draft of the commission, are engaged in the seclusion of Long Beach in putting in form a first draft for the charter of the enlarged municipality.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 16. -- A peculiar accident happened this morning at the new tower of the New-York and Westchester Water Company, in Glen Park.

The condition of Cornelius Vanderbilt, which had shown signs of improvement Wednesday, changed for the worse during Wednesday night, and when the final bulletin was issued at 10:15 o'clock last night there had been no material change.

HAVANA, July 16. -- Major Fondeviela, who has become noted for his activity during the present campaign, reports from Campo Florido that he met a body of rebels led by Mirabel and routed and dispersed them after a hot fight. Ten rebels were killed and many wounded. The Spaniards sustained no losses.

CANTON, Ohio, July 10. -- With colors flying and band playing, the Cuyahoga County Soldiers and Sailors' Union marched from their special train to Major McKinley's house late this afternoon. This organization is composed of veterans of the war of the rebellion, and is non-partisan. A number of short speeches were made by the vistors.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 16. -- It was reported semi-officially to-day that when the Twenty-third Regiment goes home to Brooklyn Saturday evening, Col. Smith will resign as Colonel of the regiment. It is said that this is on account of the Colonel being unable to agree with the line officers of the regiment.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 16. -- Potter Palmer arrived here to-night to join Mrs. Palmer, who has been here since Tuesday. He was accompanied by H.H. Honore, Jr., of Chicago, and Miss Julia Grant, who will remain with Mrs. Palmer several weeks.
It is not usual that baseless rumors in Wall Street operate for the general good, but such apparently was the case yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 16. -- The Executive Committee of the Republican National Committee reassembled in Mr. Hanna's office this morning: shortly after 10 o'clock. It has been determined that the work at Chicago shall be supervised by Henry C. Payne of Wisconsin, assisted by Chester G. Dawes of Illinois, who will be the Western Secretary.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 16. -- When the four amateurs who are looking for championship honors in the coif tournament at the links of the Shinnecock Golf Club appeared this moraine to resume play, they found that the thunder showers of the early morning had deluged the putting greens and that the condition of the ground was excellent.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- A proposed double payment of over $41,000 and an actual double payment of nearly $9,000 has just been disclosed in the Navy Department, most of it Ruing to the Slate of Alabama.
BOSTON, July 16. -- The Massachusetts Reform Club to-day adopted the following resolutions referring to the death of ex-Gov. Russell:

Recent events have imposed upon the patriotic people of this country a responsibility greater than ths civil war. PAUL SMITH'S, N.Y., July 17. -- Gov. Morton and his party, consisting of twenty persons, arrived at Paul Smith's to-day. They will occupy the H. McK. Twombly camp on the Upper St. Regie.

We have shown how the prices of corn, potatoes, hops, and oats in this country have been depressed recently, not by the demonetization of silver or by the reduction of inoperative tariff duties, but by exceptionally large crops of these agricultural products.

LONDON, July 17. -- In the House of Lords to-day, Lord Salisbury laid upon the table the papers relating to the boundary dispute between Great Britain and Venezuela. Lord Salisbury, in presenting the documents, said that negotiations between Great Britain and the United States in regard to the Venezuela matter were still in progress.

A rather remarkable encounter with three desperadoes, either burglars or kidnappers, is reported by Superintendent Arthur W. Salas of the Westchester Sanitarium to have occurred at the sanitarium early yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Secretary Olney is very anxious to secure a settlement from the Turkish Government of the Harpoot and Marash indemnities. He has recently instructed Minister Terrell at Constantinople to again urge upon the Government of the Porte a prompt payment of these claims.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 17. -- Charles R. Long, former Chairman of the Democratic State and Executive Committees, announces that he will not support the ticket nominated at Chicago. He thinks Kentucky is a doubtful State.

Soudan Letter to The London Times. Men have come in from Dongola, and we know how the news of the disaster at Ferkeh was received by the Dervishes in that city. Mahomed Wad el Bishara was overcome with rage and grief when he read the long roll of dead Emirs which Osman Azrak had sent to him.

ST. LOUIS, July 17. -- The Executive Committee of the People's Party National Committee will meet here to-morrow and decide upon recommendations to be made to the National Committee as to the best course to pursue by the party in the convention next week. The committee is said to be in favor of nominating a ticket and making a platform not unlike the one drawn up at Omaha.

Bryan and Arthur Sewall for President and Vice President of the United States.

The running of cable cars at full speed around the double curve at Union Square is certainly objectionable. It has been made plain that it cannot be avoided without putting in a subsidiary cable running at a slow rate over the curves, which would check the current of travel over the whole line and make it impossible to operate nearly the present number of cars.

SAGINAW, Mich., July 17. -- The closing of the Grand Circuit here marked a successful meeting. Perfect weather ruled, and good fields furnished elegant sport. Every race was filled except the 2:06 pace, and darkness would have prevented that.

HAVANA, July 17. -- Col. Maroto reports that he met the rebel parties, commanded by "El Inglisito," Betaacourt, Aguilar, and Sanchez on the Magdalena estate, near Cidra, Province of Matanzas. The rebels were in strongly fortified positions, but were dislodged after a brilliant charge by the Spanish troops.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The efforts of the United States and Great Britain to agree upon a general arbitration treaty for the settlement of all controversies, through the establishment of a permanent tribunal, as well as the progress of diplomatic negotiations toward solving the Venezuelan problem, are set forth in thirteen communications made public by the State Department to-night.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Although temporarily outside the jurisdiction of the great Republic, yet I have followed with deepest interest the accounts of the revolutionary work which has been perpetrated by the so-called Democratic Convention in Chicago, and I have most thoroughly agreed with the position which THE NEW-YORK TIMES has taken in regard to it.

CLEVELAND, July 17. -- The fiercest fight since the strike of the Brown Hoisting workers began occurred this evening. The militia kept the crowd Hack while the nonunion men were leaving the shops, but the mob increased until it numbered many thousands and extended over a territory of fifteen squares.
REPTON, England, July 17. -- The Haverford College team of cricketers gained a creditable victory here to-day, defeating Repton School by an innings and 27 runs.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Some weeks ago Asa M. Mattice, formerly of the Naval Engineer Corps, wrote to Congressman Francis H. Wilson on the evils of the service with much candor of expression. Mr. Mattice had nothing to fear from the naval regulations, such as engineer officers in the service had, for they are prevented by rules from expressing the barest opinion in public.

Joseph Block, who was last week convicted of burglary in the first degree as a second offense, was sentenced by Judge Aspinall in the County Court yesterday. Much interest was manifested in this particular case, as it was the first case that had come before the Brooklyn Judge under the new habitual criminal law.

The President and counsel of the Manhattan Railway Company went before the Rapid Transit Commission at its meeting on Thursday with a proposition the main part of which was to lay out a lot of surface trolley lines in the annexed district, running through public parks and private property and wherever they would best serve the purpose of feeders to the elevated system, provided the company could be assured against all land damages.

ALBANY, July 17. -- Secretary of State John Palmer, in his office in the Capitol, to-day received the committee representing the Albany County delegates to the Republican State Convention, and heard from the committee that he was the Albany candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Secretary Olney has had occasion to request Secretary Herbert to warn naval commanders against interfering with the diplomatic negotiations of our State Department representatives.

Sweet of the local police force this afternoon, on writs of trespass for $5,000 each, on complaint of the Electric News and Money Transfer Company, with whose success it is alleged the officers were interfering.

LONDON, July 17. -- The Morning Post, commenting upon the correspondence between Great Britain and the United States touching the Venezuelan boundary dispute, will say to-morrow that in the perusal of the correspondence the impression arises that Mr. Olney, the American Secretary of State, is not so much anxious for a settlement of the questions as he is for a chance of putting Lord Salisbury in the wrong.

DALHOUSIE, N.B., July 17. -- The body of ex-Gov. William E. Russell of Massachusetts, who died suddenly at Little Pabos yesterday, arrived here on the steamer Admiral to-day from that place. It was received with every token of respect and sympathy.

In a decision handed down yesterday. Surrogate Arnold declares the will of Angelina Crane. in so far as it leaves $50,000 to the Mayor, Aldermen, and Commonalty of the City of New-York for the erection of a drinking fountain, to be legal.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17. -- An important private conference of "sound-money" Democrats was held to-day in the office of Appraiser Charles E. Ingersoll, James F. Attorney John C. Bulliot for the purpose of protesting against the action of the Chicago Convention. Henry D. Welsh, a Director of the Pennsylvania Railroad, presided.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 17. -- The members of the Twenty-third Regiment were out early this morning, and went through guard mount and the different drills in creditable style. The day was an ideal one for the work. A large crowd witnessed the parade to-day, when Col. Smith reviewed the regiment.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- W.C. Craig, a banker of Yazoo City, Miss., largely interested in the cotton compress business in the South, is in the city. Mr. Craig always has been identified with the Democratic Party, but he says he cannot accept the platform put forth by the Chicago Convention.

BELVIDERE, N.J., July 17. -- This was the tenth day of the trial of Samuel C. Carpenter, ex-Postmaster of Easton, Penn., for the murder of Mrs. Blackrwell. The last testimony was taken this afternoon, and the summing up for both sides was finished it a session held to-night. Judge Gummere will charge the jury at 10 o'clock to-morrow morning.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 17. -- Miss Ogden Jones has a jolly house party that arrived to-day, including Miss Marka De F. Jones, Miss Anna Schwab, Gustav Schwab, Ogden T. McClurg, and Miss Laina Wheeler of New-York.

GENOA, July 17. -- Joseph Alfred Novello, organist, composer, and scientist, died in this city to-day.
